headline: Russia Freed Evan Gershkovich in a Major Prisoner Swap
abstract: Also, a Hamas leader was killed by a bomb planted months ago. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A prisoner swap involving seven countries freed the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, two other Americans and several Russian opposition figures. It was the most far-reaching exchange between Russia and the West in decades.

headline: Israel Confirms Death of Hamas Commander Amid Funerals for 2 Senior Militants
abstract: The Israeli military said it had killed Muhammad Deif, who it called a planner of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel, which would make him the third Iranian-backed militant leader slain in recent days.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Thursday it had killed Muhammad Deif, the Hamas commander who is believed to have been a planner of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel, in an airstrike last month, which would make him the third Iranian-backed militant leader slain in recent weeks.

headline: Punkie Johnson Announces She Is Leaving ‘Saturday Night Live’
abstract: Johnson told a stand-up audience she was leaving “Saturday Night Live” before confirming her departure in an Instagram video the next day.
lead_paragraph: Punkie Johnson, a performer on the NBC sketch comedy series “Saturday Night Live” since 2020, announced on Thursday that she will not return this fall for the show’s 50th season.

headline: Bookmaker for Ohtani Interpreter Plans to Plead Guilty to Federal Charges
abstract: Prosecutors said that Mathew Bowyer, a Southern California resident, was running an illegal sports gambling operation, and that one of his clients was the interpreter for the baseball star Shohei Ohtani.
lead_paragraph: The Southern California bookmaker at the center of an explosive scandal involving the longtime interpreter of Shohei Ohtani, the M.L.B. superstar, has agreed to plead guilty to federal charges that he ran an illegal sports gambling operation and cheated on taxes, federal prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Harris Campaign Looks Poised to Beat Trump’s July Cash Haul
abstract: The Trump campaign reported raising $139 million along with allied groups. The vice president’s campaign previously reported $200 million raised in the seven days after President Biden dropped out.
lead_paragraph: The Trump campaign said that it and its allied groups had raised $139 million in July, an enormous sum — but well short of the $200 million Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign said it brought in amid a huge burst of enthusiasm about her candidacy.

headline: Plea Deal in 9/11 Case Is Announced in War Court
abstract: The accused mastermind of the plot, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, appeared at a session as the agreement was disclosed. A sentencing hearing could begin next year.
lead_paragraph: The man accused of plotting the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, appeared in court on Thursday, watching silently as the prosecutor who had pursued his capital case since the beginning formally announced that a plea agreement had been reached that would remove the possibility of the death penalty.

headline: Harris Remembers Congresswoman Sheila Jackson Lee
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris eulogized the long-serving congresswoman from Texas during a memorial service on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris eulogized the long-serving congresswoman from Texas during a memorial service on Thursday.

headline: Head of an Elite New York School Resigns After Turmoil Over Gaza War
abstract: Joe Algrant will step down as the head of Ethical Culture Fieldston School following a year marked by infighting among parents, students, faculty and alumni.
lead_paragraph: The leader of one of New York’s most elite private schools has left his post after an academic year marked by infighting among parents, students, faculty and alumni over the war in Gaza.

headline: MrBeast Acknowledges ‘Inappropriate Language’ in Earlier Videos
abstract: A representative for the popular YouTuber said that he was “trying to be funny” and made “bad jokes” in older videos of him that have resurfaced.
lead_paragraph: MrBeast, the popular YouTube star known for arranging complex stunts and giving away cash, acknowledged in a statement this week that he had used “inappropriate language” in some of his earlier videos.

headline: Bipartisan Legal Group Urges Lawyers to Defend Against ‘Rising Authoritarianism’
abstract: An American Bar Association task force of prominent legal thinkers gestures at former President Trump without naming him.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan American Bar Association task force is calling on lawyers across the country to do more to help protect democracy ahead of the 2024 election, warning in a statement to be delivered Friday at the group’s annual meeting in Chicago that the nation faces a serious threat in “rising authoritarianism.”

headline: Families of 9/11 Victims React to News of Accused Plotters’ Plea Deal
abstract: While family members differed in their support of the death penalty, many expressed frustration that the case had lingered for so long.
lead_paragraph: One day after federal prosecutors announced that they had struck a plea deal with three men accused of plotting the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, New Yorkers and family members of victims had mixed reactions to the sudden news. Under the agreement, the three men — including Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the accused mastermind — will serve life in prison but avoid a death-penalty trial.

headline: Air Force Finds Mechanical and Crew Failures in Fatal Osprey Crash Last Year
abstract: An investigation determined that missed warning signals and the “catastrophic failure” of a gearbox led to the crash off the coast of Japan in November.
lead_paragraph: An Air Force investigation determined that the “catastrophic failure” of a gearbox led to a deadly Osprey crash off the coast of Japan last year that resulted in hundreds of aircraft being grounded in the United States and abroad.

headline: Harris Says She and Biden ‘Never Stopped Fighting’ for Americans’ Release
abstract: The release of prisoners was a move by President Biden to secure his legacy. On Thursday, he and his White House made clear that Vice President Kamala Harris had been a partner in the effort.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris said that she and President Biden had “never stopped fighting” for the release of wrongfully detained Americans like the ones who were released from Russian custody on Thursday.

headline: ‘The Lord of the Rings’ Is Not the Far Right’s Playground
abstract: MAGA misunderstands the fellowship of the ring.
lead_paragraph: You can’t say you weren’t warned. Right there in the middle of my Times bio, it says, “If there were a Nerd Olympics, I might take the gold medal.” It means I’m ready to bend your ear over “Star Wars.” We can talk for hours about “Dune.” But if you really want to get me wound up, say something about J.R.R. Tolkien and “The Lord of the Rings.”

headline: How 2024 Became a Crypto Election
abstract: Will libertarian derp get a government bailout?
lead_paragraph: I didn’t anticipate the political twists and turns of the past few weeks, but then, who did? One thing I do blame myself for not seeing coming, however, is the extent to which this has become a crypto election.

headline: With Prisoner Swap, Biden Scores a Win as His Term Nears Its End
abstract: The exchange offered a measure of validation for President Biden soon after he abandoned his bid for re-election.
lead_paragraph: Even in the world of presidential multitasking, July 21 turns out to have been an extraordinary, whipsaw Sunday for President Biden.

headline: Trump Escalates Race Attacks on Harris, Worrying Some Republicans
abstract: A day after telling Black journalists that Vice President Kamala Harris had recently decided to become “a Black person,” Mr. Trump shared a photo of Ms. Harris in traditional Indian clothing.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump continued to raise false and incendiary questions about Vice President Kamala Harris’s racial identity for a second day on Thursday, as Republicans watched the former president drive his campaign into a divisive and potentially damaging direction.

headline: The Two Weeks That Changed Kamala Harris’s Vice Presidency
abstract: Two trips Harris took last year set the stage for the ascent that is happening now.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! Yesterday, former President Donald Trump attacked Vice President Kamala Harris over her racial identity, which is something she rarely talked about before a key moment in the spring of 2023. I asked my colleague Erica Green, a White House correspondent, to tell us how Harris’s little-noticed moves in that period reshaped her vice presidency and laid the groundwork for her campaign against Trump. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Tennessee Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Tennessee primary elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Tennessee primary elections.

headline: Gloria Johnson, Tennessee Democrat Who Faced Expulsion, Wins U.S. Senate Primary
abstract: The state lawmaker, who gained national attention for her role in a gun control protest, will challenge Senator Marsha Blackburn, a Republican.
lead_paragraph: Gloria Johnson, a Tennessee state representative who faced an expulsion vote last year for participating in a gun control protest on the Statehouse floor, won the Democratic primary for U.S. Senate on Thursday, according to The Associated Press, and will challenge Marsha Blackburn, the Republican incumbent.

headline: Trump Remarks on Harris’s Multiracial Identity Overlook a Growing Trend
abstract: Demographers say that a growing number of Americans identify as more than one race, and that the number will continue expanding in the decades ahead.
lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump questioned Vice President Kamala Harris’s racial identity in Chicago on Wednesday, he neglected a reality: that the country’s demographics have changed in recent decades, as more than 12 percent of Americans now identify as multiracial.

headline: 2 Officers Shot on Lower East Side in Street Chase of Robbery Suspect
abstract: One officer was shot in the leg and the other in the groin after they responded to a report of an armed robbery at a mahjong parlor. Both are in stable condition.
lead_paragraph: A gunman shot two police sergeants who were trying to arrest him minutes after an armed robbery in a mahjong parlor on the Lower East Side in Manhattan on Thursday, Police Department officials said.

headline: U.S. Recognizes Maduro’s Rival as Winner of Venezuelan Election
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said there was “overwhelming evidence” that Edmundo González had won, despite President Nicolás Maduro’s claim of victory.
lead_paragraph: The United States on Thursday night recognized Venezuela’s opposition presidential candidate, Edmundo González, as the winner of the country’s disputed election.

headline: N.F.L. Sunday Ticket Verdict Is Thrown Out by Judge
abstract: The decision, five weeks after a jury awarded $4.7 billion in damages in an antitrust case, is a reprieve for the league.
lead_paragraph: The $4.7 billion verdict against the National Football League for colluding to raise prices for its Sunday Ticket television package was overturned late Thursday by a federal judge, who disqualified expert testimony used by the jury to determine damages.

headline: Harris Begins Final Phase of Accelerated V.P. Search
abstract: The formal vetting process is finished, and the first major decision of Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign is just days away.
lead_paragraph: The law firm hired by the Harris campaign to investigate potential vice-presidential candidates has completed its work, leaving the final decision — the most important yet of the still-new campaign — squarely in Vice President Kamala Harris’s hands.

headline: First Pass Friday: Why It Pays to Hang in There
abstract: Kate Chin Park offers a challenging puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — It has been a while since I’ve written a First Pass Friday, the occasional feature in which I show readers how I forged my way into the dreaded, second-hardest puzzle of the week (the hardest is on Saturday). I had trouble finding a way into Kate Chin Park’s entertaining, formidable puzzle, so I thought that some of you who are just starting to play the crossword might be interested in seeing how even an experienced solver can be tripped up. Based on the reader responses to earlier First Pass Fridays, it is also an excellent opportunity to feel smarter than me before the solving even begins. No, don’t thank me; that’s what I’m here for.

headline: Two Key Matchups Are Set in Arizona as Battle for House Control Heats Up
abstract: The tossup districts currently held by Republican Representatives David Schweikert and Juan Ciscomani will play a key role in the fight for control. They got their Democratic challengers this week.
lead_paragraph: Primary elections in Arizona this week set the fields for two House races that could help determine which party wins control of Congress in November, as Democrats target two vulnerable Republican incumbents.

headline: Lauren Scruggs Makes History as Americans Win Olympic Fencing Gold
abstract: After Scruggs, 21, became the first Black American woman to win an individual Olympic fencing medal, she clinched gold for the U.S. team.
lead_paragraph: After Lauren Scruggs clinched the gold medal for the United States in the women’s fencing team foil competition on Thursday, she threw off her mask and spun around, her eyes and mouth wide open.

headline: Behind the Prisoner Swap: Spies, a Killer, Secret Messages and Unseen Diplomacy
abstract: The negotiations that led to the prisoner swap and the freeing of Americans wrongfully held in Russia required patience and creativity, but gave both sides what they wanted most.
lead_paragraph: A turning point came on June 25, when a group of C.I.A. officers sat across from their Russian counterparts during a secret meeting in a Middle Eastern capital.

headline: White Supremacist Gang Leader Among Three Killed in Fight at Nevada Prison
abstract: Nine prisoners were also injured in the fight on Tuesday, the Nevada Department of Corrections said.
lead_paragraph: A leader of a white supremacist prison gang was one of three prisoners killed when a fight broke out Tuesday morning at a Nevada prison, the state’s Department of Corrections said.

headline: In Xi’s China, Politics Eventually Catches Up With Everyone
abstract: The author Peter Hessler posed a question with an elusive answer: How could Chinese society open up so profoundly while its politics stagnated or even regressed?
lead_paragraph: In 1996, when Peter Hessler taught at a small college in Sichuan Province, 90 percent of his students came from villages. Mr. Hessler, 5 feet 9 inches, towered over them by about half a head. They often had just one outfit to wear: a blue suit jacket, or maybe a knockoff Chicago Bulls jersey. One student told him decades later that he could afford only one meal a day.

headline: Welcome to the Rejected Housewives Suite!
abstract: My single (and yes, cat-lady) home became a landing zone for friends after their breakups.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t want to own a house by myself,” I said to my partner of four years as we discussed the benefits of owning property in Bozeman, Mont., our increasingly unaffordable mountain town. “We have to try to make this work.”

headline: They United Their Muslim and Jewish Families but Didn’t Stop There
abstract: Safi Rauf, a Muslim humanitarian, was held captive by the Taliban for 105 days. Secret calls on a smuggled phone with Sammi Cannold, a Jewish Broadway director, were his lifeline.
lead_paragraph: Under a huppah in a cornfield in Glenwood, Iowa, Sammi Rose Cannold and Safiullah Rauf took turns reading excerpts from a notebook that she had written in nearly every day for several months.

headline: Ambivalent About Their Next Steps, but Not Each Other
abstract: Nicholas McClure and Jinie Kwak were both in a state of transition when they matched on a dating app almost four years ago.
lead_paragraph: Their relationship began with a lie, or at least a mutually unshared truth.

headline: Vowing to Always ‘Meet in Montauk’ — Just Like Their Favorite Movie
abstract: Nicole Crowder and Mike Ballengee immediately connected over “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind,” and consider themselves opposites who would always seek each other out.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Marie Crowder, who is typically punctual, was late to her first date with Robert Michael Ballengee Jr. In her haste to meet up, she messaged that she was running behind on the Tinder app, where they initially met. But because they had exchanged phone numbers weeks prior, he didn’t think to check the app as he waited outside Spyhouse Coffee Roasters in Minneapolis.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 2, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the conviction of Capt. Moussa Dadis Camara, the former president of Guinea, on crimes against humanity misstated how many people have died in protests under the current rule of Col. Mamady Doumbouya, which began in 2021, according to Amnesty International. It is 47, not more than 100. (Over 100 protesters have been killed in Guinea since 2019, according to Amnesty International.)

headline: Quote of the Day: What Can a City Do When Neo-Nazis March Its Streets?
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “There’s freedom of speech, and there’s hate speech.”

headline: After Two Weeks of Dating, Committed to Being by Each Other’s Side
abstract: Julia Liverton and Marco Santarlasci instantly clicked after meeting two years ago, and each knew after just a few months that they wanted to marry.
lead_paragraph: After his fourth date with Julia Kaitlin Liverton in October 2022, Marco Foster Santarlasci called his parents, excited to share with them that he had met someone special.

headline: Biden and Harris Greet Americans Released From Russia
abstract: Three Americans — Evan Gershkovich, a reporter of The Wall Street Journal; Alsu Kurmasheva, an editor for RFE/RL; and Paul Whelan, a former U.S. Marine — were freed in a prisoner exchange with Russia.
lead_paragraph: Three Americans — Evan Gershkovich, a reporter of The Wall Street Journal; Alsu Kurmasheva, an editor for RFE/RL; and Paul Whelan, a former U.S. Marine — were freed in a prisoner exchange with Russia.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: A sweeping prisoner swap between Russia and the West.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and Kamala Harris, the vice president, welcomed home Americans who had been released from Russian custody, including the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, at Joint Base Andrews in Maryland last night. “Their brutal ordeal is over, and they’re free,” Biden said earlier in the day.

headline: Word of the Day: defamatory
abstract: This word has appeared in 73 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word defamatory has appeared in 73 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 10 in “K-Pop Group Asks U.S. Court for Help Finding YouTube User in Defamation Case” by John Yoon:

headline: Hotels in New York City Don’t Need Licenses. Should They?
abstract: New York’s hundreds of hotels are subject to less regulatory scrutiny than many other businesses. The industry is resisting City Council efforts to change that.
lead_paragraph: The first New York City homicide of 2021 occurred on New Year’s Day in Kew Gardens, Queens, at the Umbrella Hotel, which already seemed aptly named, for the cover it provided over a thunderstorm of illegal activity. Throughout the previous summer, people in the neighborhood had complained about shootings, drug use and prostitution at the hotel. Covid was devastating the hospitality industry; rates at the Umbrella had dropped to $80 a night, and rooms were taken by partyers, disruptive often to the point of violence. Five miles away, at an airport motel in July 2020, two teenage girls were held captive and forced to have sex with strangers.

headline: Archaeologists Find a 2,400-Year-Old ‘Pot of Gold’ in Turkey
abstract: An ancient hoard of Persian coins offers insights into the political landscape around the time of the Peloponnesian War.
lead_paragraph: It is the late fifth century B.C. and a mercenary soldier kneels in his modest quarters, digging a hole in the earthen floor. He places a small jug, called an olpe, in the hole for safekeeping and covers it with dirt. In the olpe are his savings — scores of gold coins, known as darics, each one equal to a month’s pay.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Secret Bundlers, Sham Donations: Adams Is Faulted in Campaign Audit
abstract: A 900-page draft audit of Eric Adams’s 2021 mayoral campaign in New York City found widespread errors that could lead to fines or forfeiture of public matching funds.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, as Eric Adams was running for mayor of New York City, his campaign was raking in donations from a broad range of mysterious sources.

headline: In Tahiti’s Waters, an Ocean Photographer Follows Big Waves
abstract: To capture images of surfers taking on the dangerous swells in Teahupo’o, Ben Thouard must suit up himself.
lead_paragraph: When he was a teenager, Ben Thouard found an old camera in his parents’ attic. The moment would bridge two passions, one old and one new: surfing and photography.

headline: A Triumphant Biden Welcomes 3 Freed Americans Home
abstract: A Biden aide hailed a complicated prisoner swap as an act of “vintage Joe Biden” diplomacy. As he greeted freed Americans, the president seemed intent on showing the world what that meant.
lead_paragraph: The former Marine poked his head out of the jet and then lifted his hand in salute. The Wall Street Journal reporter greeted his waiting colleagues with a wide grin and open arms. The Russian American editor rushed into the arms of her sobbing daughter.

headline: Talking Trump and Economics With Joseph Stiglitz in Sydney
abstract: The eminent economist describes Donald Trump and the MAGA movement as a response to the failure of nearly 40 years of neoliberalism.
lead_paragraph: For more than three decades, Joseph Stiglitz has been working within and critiquing the system of global economics.

headline: Talking Trump and Economics With Joseph Stiglitz in Sydney
abstract: His new book is about reimagining freedom for ‘progressive capitalism.’
lead_paragraph: For more than three decades, Joseph Stiglitz has been working within and critiquing the system of global economics.

headline: Japanese Stocks Tumble 6% as Long-Running Surge Falters
abstract: A rapidly strengthening yen and a sell-off in stocks in the United States pushed Japan’s markets to a second consecutive day of big losses on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A more-than-yearlong rally in Japanese stocks, driven by the country’s depreciated currency, hit a wall at the end of the week.

headline: How Healthy Are Tomatoes?
abstract: They’re juicy, versatile and in season. Here are their nutritional benefits, and recipes to make the most of them.
lead_paragraph: Tomatoes have come a long way since the 16th century, when some Europeans called them “poison apples” because they were mistakenly believed to be toxic. Now, they’re the second-most consumed vegetable in the United States (behind only potatoes) and recognized for a range of health benefits.

headline: Two Projects in Brooklyn Could Affect Popular Green Spaces
abstract: Plans for a tower near the Brooklyn Botanic Garden and a skate facility in Mount Prospect Park bring mixed reactions.
lead_paragraph: Shadows cast by a proposed 14-story tower on Franklin Avenue in Crown Heights, twice the allowable height under current zoning, would have a “significant adverse impact” on plants in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, according to a draft environmental impact statement released by the Department of City Planning in May.

headline: Many of Gaza’s Medical Workers Have Been Detained or Killed
abstract: Out of a prewar total of about 20,000 health workers, 500 have been killed in the war, according to the W.H.O., and more than 300 are in Israeli detention, Gaza’s health ministry says.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Khaled El Serr last spoke to his family in mid-March, a week before Israeli troops raided the hospital in southern Gaza where he worked as a surgeon.

headline: It Was Supposed to Be a Garden Oasis, but It Led to Unexpected Dangers
abstract: In Helen Phillips’s near-future novel, “Hum,” a family’s dream vacation away from technology devolves into a misadventure with major consequences.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a city like New York, but where intelligent robots, known as hums, walk, talk and perform all kinds of jobs. Here, young children universally wear smart watches that track their welfare. Almost everyone is addicted to personal virtual reality pods called wooms.

headline: A Genre-Twisting Novel by an Author Writing About an Author Writing About Exile
abstract: In “Unspeakable Home,” Ismet Prcic writes about a broken writer named Izzy Prcic, who is working on a book about his immigration, displacement and life struggles.
lead_paragraph: The primary narrator of Ismet Prcic’s “Unspeakable Home” shares with the author a name (here shortened to Izzy), a place of birth (Tuzla, Bosnia-Herzegovina), a youthful trauma (the Bosnian war), a debilitating disease (alcoholism) and an eventual escape route (immigration to late-90s America). Still, Prcic, a writer of formally adventurous fictions — his debut novel, “Shards,” manipulated both convention and chronology — would likely bristle at the label of autofiction. His new novel is too kinetic to merit inclusion in that trendy cohort. Part existential cry, part urinal graffito, part anguished confession, “Unspeakable Home” is a survival strategy, a transfiguring of personal memory to obscure the terrible cost of exile.

headline: With Solitude and Untouched Nature, the Quieter Corners of the Adirondacks Beckon
abstract: New York’s Adirondack Park draws more than 12 million visitors each year, but most don’t venture far from the park’s population centers. Here’s where to go to avoid the crowds.
lead_paragraph: At six million acres, New York’s Adirondack Park is the size of Vermont, and larger than all of New Jersey. A unique mix of state and private property that encompasses mountains, wilderness areas and lakes, the park draws more than 12 million visitors annually who want to hike, paddle, explore and more.

headline: Washington Post C.E.O.’s Last Company Lost Millions Betting on Gen Z
abstract: The  Post is creating a division under Will Lewis, its C.E.O., to find valuable audiences in new places. His last company shows that’s a tough road.
lead_paragraph: In late 2020, a news start-up began pitching investors on a bold vision: By creating content native to social media for Gen Z audiences — and later acquiring brands like The Daily Mail — the company would begin to create “the Amazon of News” within five years.

headline: The Christian Case Against Trump
abstract: Evangelicals who have found the weaponization of Scripture distasteful are showing us that their vote is very much up for grabs.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the attempted assassination of Donald Trump on July 13, a video with images of Jesus crowned with thorns, blood running down his face, followed by photos of the former president circulated on social media. Days later, at the Republican National Convention, the evangelist Franklin Graham endorsed Mr. Trump from the stage, saying that “God spared his life.”

headline: Picture Books That Cushion Kids’ Falls
abstract: In a world worth exploring, our reviewer argues, an occasional spill is the price of admission.
lead_paragraph: Young children don’t need pandemics to remind them that life can turn unpredictable and terrifying. They have nursery rhymes like “Rock-a-Bye Baby” and “Ring Around the Rosie” for that — not to mention their own helter-skelter adventures.

headline: Trump Cites Opportunity Zones as a Triumph. Their Success Is Middling.
abstract: A tax incentive, with bipartisan roots, aims to foster development in poor areas. It has fueled building, but it hasn’t always aided local residents.
lead_paragraph: On an Alabama day so oppressive that the sweat pools on your face in the shade, Alex Flachsbart talks almost too rapidly to understand and drives around central Birmingham with similar velocity. Every few minutes, he pulls over to expound on a victory: neglected public housing, a long-empty factory, a crumbling department store, all being transformed into shiny apartments or airy office and retail space.

headline: ‘Elizabeth Taylor: The Lost Tapes’ and the Moment Star Worship Curdled
abstract: The documentary blends audio interviews with footage from her life to provide a revealing look not so much at the actress, but at celebrity culture.
lead_paragraph: This summer, thanks mostly to the rise of Glen Powell, I’ve been in a lot of discussions about the state of movie stardom. The jury’s still out on whether we have “real” movie stars today, but it’s clear that the process of becoming a celebrity is different now from what it used to be. Social media and the popularity of small-screen entertainment have changed the game.

headline: 600,000 Balloons, Turned Into Sculpture at the Armory
abstract: “Balloon Story” is an extravaganza, its creative producer said.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today, and on Fridays through the summer, we’ll focus on things to do in New York over the weekend.

headline: $700,000 Homes in Cape Town
abstract: In South Africa’s legislative capital, you can find a five-bedroom compound in the Western Cape’s wine country, a four-bedroom Victorian from 1901, and a five-bedroom from 2017 in a leafy gated community.
lead_paragraph: Built two decades ago and set on nearly half an acre, this five-bedroom house is inside the 445-acre gated Diemersfontein Wine & Country Estate, which is known for its Pinotage, a South African varietal. It is near Wellington, a town of about 62,000. Cape Town, South Africa’s capital, is a 45-minute drive.

headline: Beyond Facials and Yoga: 6 Resorts With Next-Level Wellness Programs
abstract: Sleep tracking, “snow showers” and underwater “soundscapes” are among the offerings at resorts that also happen to be in dream locations.
lead_paragraph: Wellness travel is booming, and hotels large and small are wooing guests with state-of-the-art spas, fitness centers, classes and retreats. Here are some of the latest properties, where wellness goes beyond facials and yoga to sleep tracking, local rituals and even medical services like getting an echocardiogram. Whether you want to sink into a hot spring in Japan or receive a massage on a train as it rolls toward a Malaysian jungle, these getaways strive to transport you in more ways than one.

headline: Kids at the Olympics: ‘It’s Honestly Kind of Insane.’
abstract: From the shooting range to the swimming pool, teens and preteens are grabbing medals and the spotlight. Nowhere is this truer than at the skateboard park.
lead_paragraph: It was a hot Sunday morning, and the women’s street skateboarding venue at the Place de la Concorde was swarming with teens.

headline: ‘Mountain Dew and Racism’: Identity Enters the Election
abstract: Week 2 of Trump vs. Harris is all about race.
lead_paragraph: The 2024 presidential race is officially in its identity politics stage. From “White dudes for Harris” to “D.E.I. candidate” accusations, the hosts debate how race and racism are being deployed in the second week of the Harris versus Trump election.

headline: Your Feet Are Killing Me
abstract: Are sandals in the city an insult to the eye or the advent of a digital revolution?
lead_paragraph: If for most of recent urban history the preferred form of footwear for men in a city was the shoe, we have definitively entered a new era — the Age of the Sandal. This decidedly unscientific observation is based on a recent walking tour of Manhattan from top to bottom — Inwood to Battery Park — on the East and West Sides. Though things may be different in other American urban centers, this reporter tends to doubt it.

headline: Willing to Die for MrBeast (and $5 Million)
abstract: The contestants in the internet star’s “Beast Games” expected outlandish challenges and signed contracts that acknowledged risks of serious injury and death. Still, few were prepared for the conditions on set.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Donaldson is the internet’s fairy godmother.

headline: ‘Just Don’t Screw It Up’: Three Writers Go Behind the Scenes of Making a V.P. Pick
abstract: Presidential campaign veterans discuss what goes into the veepstakes.
lead_paragraph: Frank Bruni, a contributing Opinion writer, hosted a written online conversation with Beth Myers, who supervised the vice-presidential selection process for Mitt Romney’s 2012 presidential campaign, and Jim Jordan, a manager of John Kerry’s 2004 presidential campaign, to discuss how Kamala Harris might make her decision about a running mate.

headline: Who’s Winning Internet Gold at the Olympics?
abstract: As the world watches the Paris Olympic Games, figures like Pommel Horse Guy, a muffin-obsessed swimmer and a few charismatic shooters have become unexpected stars online.
lead_paragraph: At the Olympic Games, there are the athletes who are rewarded with medals. And then there are the athletes who, for whatever reasons, find themselves rewarded with online love.

headline: Inside the Petrostate Hosting This Year’s Global Climate Negotiations
abstract: In Azerbaijan, the causes and effects of climate change are on vivid display and the painful trade-offs needed to fight it are acutely felt.
lead_paragraph: In a few short months, diplomats from nearly all the world’s countries will descend on Azerbaijan, a small petrostate on the Caspian Sea, nestled between Russia and Iran, to wrangle over how best to avoid the ever-growing dangers of climate change.

headline: What Kamala Harris Learned From a Bruising 2020 Primary
abstract: The vice president has a rare opportunity to reintroduce herself to the American public as a presidential candidate, armed with lessons from the first time.
lead_paragraph: The best day of Kamala Harris’s 2020 presidential campaign was its first.

headline: Job Market Slows Significantly, Raising Economic Jitters
abstract: U.S. employers added 114,000 jobs in July, far short of forecasts, and unemployment rose to 4.3 percent, the highest level since 2021.
lead_paragraph: American employers reined in their hiring significantly in July, intensifying jitters that the economy is cooling faster than expected.

headline: Is the Fed Behind the Curve? As Unemployment Rises, Worries Mount.
abstract: Central bankers are preparing to cut interest rates, and are monitoring job data as they consider when and how much to lower them.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials held off on cutting interest rates this week because they wanted to see slightly more data to feel confident that inflation is truly coming under control. While that approach is cautious when it comes to price increases, Friday’s employment report underscored that it might be a risky one when it comes to the job market.

headline: Can Kamala Harris Rebuild the Democratic Coalition?
abstract: Early polling suggests she has made some progress since President Biden’s exit.
lead_paragraph: With a little over three months until the presidential election, Kamala Harris inherited a Democratic coalition that was badly frayed.

headline: At a Mountain Retreat, Wine, Lamb Kebabs and Lots of Climate Talk
abstract: Azerbaijan last week convened a special meeting of climate diplomats at a remote resort. A Times reporter was there.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, at an ornate hilltop hotel in Azerbaijan’s wine country with panoramic views of the Caucasus foothills, the world’s top climate diplomats debated how to marshal whopping amounts of money to fight global warming and compensate poor and vulnerable countries that suffer its worst effects.

headline: Is Tim Walz the Midwestern Dad Democrats Need?
abstract: The governor of Minnesota wants Democrats to own the normie center.
lead_paragraph: Update: This interview was published Friday, Aug. 2. On Tuesday, Aug. 6, Kamala Harris announced that Tim Walz will be her running mate.

headline: Champagne, Soft Piano and No Lines: Luxe Life at the Olympics
abstract: A new program allows spectators at the Paris Games to upgrade their seats, eat tastier food, tip glasses of bubbly and avoid the throngs.
lead_paragraph: Getting to the Olympics equestrian arena at Versailles — a multihour metro, train and bus extravaganza culminating in a mile-long trek down a dusty thoroughfare — is so arduous and enervating that it almost qualifies as an athletic achievement in itself.

headline: Mark Kelly Is a Different Kind of Democrat
abstract: Mark Kelly’s qualities — sobriety, consistency and military experience — are welcome contributions to the future of Democratic politics.
lead_paragraph: Any discussion of Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, who is on Kamala Harris’s shortlist of vice-presidential picks, invariably includes the phrase “former NASA astronaut.” He flew four Space Shuttle missions — two as commander — the desideratum of a child’s imagining of a future career and a killer résumé line for anyone running for public office.

headline: Russia Released 16 Prisoners. Hundreds of Others Were Left Behind.
abstract: Hundreds of prisoners — including Americans and Russian political activists — are hoping for a diplomatic agreement that might secure their release.
lead_paragraph: For the 16 people released from Russian captivity on Thursday in a landmark prisoner swap, the exchange brought a moment of momentous relief. But many others were left behind.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Aug. 2, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Don’t Listen to the Right. The Kamalanomenon Is Real.
abstract: There was Obama-level excitement at Harris’s Atlanta rally.
lead_paragraph: Tracy Nailor, a 56-year-old Atlanta pediatrician, wasn’t particularly impressed with Kamala Harris when she first ran for president. “I think I succumbed to the narrative about her,” she said. She thought Harris wasn’t experienced or accomplished enough to merit the Democratic nomination. “I just didn’t know enough,” she said. “I didn’t do my homework.” Instead of Harris, she supported the trusted, familiar Joe Biden in the last election.

headline: At 97, This Conductor Is Modest and Extraordinary
abstract: When Herbert Blomstedt, the oldest major conductor active today, led the Vienna Philharmonic, age was only one factor in his remarkable artistry.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been reading news about the U.S. presidential election, you might be forgiven for thinking that age has something to do with ability.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the season finale of “House of the Dragon.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the season finale of “House of the Dragon.”

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Susan Casey, Yunte Huang, Caleb Azumah Nelson and more.
lead_paragraph: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Susan Casey, Yunte Huang, Caleb Azumah Nelson and more.

headline: Navalny Couldn’t Be Freed Until Gershkovich Was Kidnapped. Gershkovich Couldn’t Be Freed Until Navalny Was Dead.
abstract: The plan that freed the journalist was hatched long before he was arrested.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, Russian political prisoners started vanishing from their prison colonies: Their lawyers would come to see them only to be told their clients were no longer there. The disappearance of an inmate is often bad news — it can mean a move to a more remote colony, illness or death. But as the number of “missing” prisoners grew, in the Russian dissident community a mounting sense of anticipation replaced the concern. “A trade,” a prominent Russian in exile posted on his Facebook page, without bothering to explain the reference. “Definitely a trade,” posted a young Russian activist in exile, a day later. “I am hopeful and I’m afraid to say the word,” posted another.

headline: The Zoom Election, Google DeepMind’s Math Olympiad and HatGPT Olympics Edition
abstract: Every presidential election has a defining technology.
lead_paragraph: This week, with hundreds of thousands of people joining online political rallies for Kamala Harris, we discuss whether 2024 is suddenly becoming the Zoom election, and what that means for both parties’ political organizing. Then, Pushmeet Kohli, a computer scientist at Google DeepMind, joins us for a conversation about how his team’s new A.I. models just hit a silver medal score on the International Mathematical Olympiad exam. And finally, it’s time for a new round of HatGPT! This time, it’s a special Olympics tech edition.

headline: 5 Ways to Make Friends (Without Joining a Book Club)
abstract: Experts share strategies for connecting that actually work.
lead_paragraph: My sister Dinah recently told me about an unusual way that she made friends after her divorce. Her youngest was starting her college search, and Dinah was nostalgic for when her children were small. So she started babysitting for a family with toddlers.

headline: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about. (Though one missing movie, “Trap,” was not screened early for critics.)
lead_paragraph: Directed by Carlos Saldanha, this adaptation of the children's book of the same name follows Harold (Zachary Levi) with the magical purple crayon that brings his drawings to life as he encounters adulthood and the real world.

headline: Harris Campaign Says It Raised $310 Million in July, More Than Double Trump’s Haul
abstract: In the seven days after President Biden stepped down as the presumptive Democratic nominee, the Harris campaign raked in $200 million.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign survived a brutal few weeks of fund-raising in July to bounce back so dramatically before the end of the month that she more than doubled the amount of money raised by former President Donald J. Trump, her campaign announced on Friday.

headline: The Gaza Conflict Enters ‘Uncharted Territory’
abstract: In the past, tit-for-tat duels between Israel and its enemies have often ended without escalation. That may no longer hold true.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t think war is inevitable,” Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said on Wednesday, after senior leaders of Hezbollah and Hamas were killed in pinpoint attacks in a suburb of Beirut, Lebanon, and Tehran. He was right; war is never inevitable until it breaks out. But suddenly the possibility of an all-in conflict of unpredictable breadth between Israel and its Iran-backed enemies, into which the United States would most likely be drawn, had become a dangerous possibility.

headline: Long After Surviving the Nazis, They Use A.I. to Remind the World
abstract: The Museum of Jewish Heritage is using artificial intelligence to create an installation where visitors can interact with people who directly experienced the Holocaust.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Jewish Heritage in Lower Manhattan, like other institutions that memorialize the Holocaust, has long relied on survivors to provide firsthand accounts of the cruelties imposed by the Nazis and the various paths people took to endure.

headline: Joe Biden Issues a Stinging Dissent
abstract: The Supreme Court is caught in a crisis of its own making.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is caught in a crisis of its own making.

headline: In Aspen, a New Art Fair Follows the Money
abstract: How can an art fair lure customers and make sales in a down market? Pitching its tent next to billionaires is a start.
lead_paragraph: A down art market? Depressed dealers? Fatigued buyers?

headline: A One-Man Team’s 11-Second Olympics
abstract: Winzar Kakiouea, a 100-meter runner, is the only competitor at the Paris Games from the Pacific island nation of Nauru. His debut came and went in a flash.
lead_paragraph: As his nation’s lone athlete at the Paris Olympics, Winzar Kakiouea carried an additional burden: Most people have no idea that his country is a country.

headline: Why Some Young People in China Pretend to Be Birds
abstract: Some people in China flap and squawk on social media as way of escaping hustle culture. We can explain.
lead_paragraph: To become a bird, pull an oversize T-shirt over your arms and torso. Hide your legs. Let your hands stick out like claws and your empty sleeves flap like wings.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,141, Saturday, August 3, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 419, August 3, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A Major Prisoner Exchange, and U.S. Says Venezuelan Opposition Won
abstract: Plus, Simone Biles takes gold — again.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Secret Succession Fight That Will Determine the Future of Fox News
abstract: Rupert Murdoch is locked in a legal battle over the family’s media empire.
lead_paragraph: For years, Rupert Murdoch seemed content to let his children battle it out for control of his conservative media empire once he’s gone.Jim Rutenberg, who writes about media and politics for The Times, discusses how a secret change to that plan by Mr. Murdoch touched off an ugly family squabble that could influence how much of the world sees the news.

headline: What to See at the Edinburgh Fringe
abstract: Previous editions of the performing arts event launched shows like “Baby Reindeer” and “Fleabag.” Maybe there’s another breakout hit among this year’s more than 3,600 shows.
lead_paragraph: Each summer, artists and audience members from across the globe decamp to Scotland for the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the world’s largest performing arts event. This year, from Aug. 2 through 26, the city will be repurposed into a labyrinth of makeshift theaters, in dingy rooms above pubs, hotel conference rooms and university lecture theaters.

headline: The Harris Electorate
abstract: We examine who plans to vote for her.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris inherited a Democratic coalition that was badly frayed. In polls, young, Black and Hispanic voters abandoned President Biden in droves. And for the first time in years, more Americans said they leaned Republican than Democratic.

headline: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a new SpongeBob SquarePants adventure and an Oscar-nominated film from Cartoon Saloon.
lead_paragraph: Sandy Cheeks, the high-energy Texan squirrel from the SpongeBob SquarePants universe, gets to save the day in this new, bizarro movie that incorporates both live action and animation. Packed into 90 minutes are musical numbers, thick-as-molasses Southern accents and Wanda Sykes as an evil blue-haired C.E.O. named Sue.

headline: Hard Landing Concerns Jolt Global Markets
abstract: Investors are focusing on slowing U.S. economic growth as calls for the Fed to cut interest rates grow louder.
lead_paragraph: Global markets are a blur of red on Friday as investors fret that the U.S. economy is heading for a slowdown.

headline: Chevron, in Snub to California, Will Move Its Headquarters to Houston
abstract: The oil company, which already has extensive operations in Texas, has been at odds with California’s elected leaders over the state’s climate and energy policies.
lead_paragraph: Chevron, the second-largest U.S. oil company, is moving its headquarters to Houston from California, formalizing a long-expected breakup with a state that has pushed aggressively to address climate change.

headline: U.S. to Send More Combat Aircraft and Warships to Middle East, Officials Say
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III directed the new deployments after speaking with his Israeli counterpart.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III on Friday ordered additional combat aircraft and missile-shooting warships to the Middle East in response to threats from Iran and its proxies in Gaza, Lebanon and Yemen to attack Israel in the coming days to avenge the death of Ismail Haniyeh, the Pentagon said.

headline: Why You Should Be Taking a Hard Look at Your Investments Right Now
abstract: After big gains in stocks and mediocre returns for bonds, investors are taking on undue risk if they don’t rebalance their holdings, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: All eyes were on the Federal Reserve this past week, or so several market analysts solemnly said. This was true even though the Fed essentially did nothing in its latest meeting but hold interest rates high to fight inflation, just as it has done for many months.

headline: A Mortgage Alternative for Lower-Priced Homes Comes With Risks
abstract: Seller-financed loans known as “land contracts” don’t involve a bank and lack the consumer protections available with traditional home loans.
lead_paragraph: With traditional mortgages for lower-priced homes hard to get, some home buyers are turning to riskier alternatives, like seller-financed loans known as “land contracts” that don’t involve a bank.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 9: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 9 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced by Aug. 21.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the ninth week of our 15th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: Convicted Assassin Is a Russian Security Agent, Kremlin Acknowledges
abstract: Vadim Krasikov, who was returned to Russia in the big prisoner swap, received a hero’s welcome from President Putin, along with others who were freed.
lead_paragraph: The convicted assassin who was the linchpin of the biggest prisoner swap in decades is a member of the most powerful security agency in Russia, the Kremlin acknowledged on Friday, and had served in a special unit with some agents who now guard President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Tropical Storm Debby Forms Over Gulf of Mexico, Bringing Flooding Threat
abstract: The storm is expected to bring significant amounts of rain to the Gulf Coast of Florida, and it is expected to make landfall as a hurricane by the end of the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Read updated coverage of Tropical Storm Debby.

headline: As the World Looks Elsewhere, Famine Descends on Darfur
abstract: There is little interest in stopping the civil war that is preventing delivery of food aid.
lead_paragraph: Sudan has in this century endured genocide, civil war and partition, and now its crisis has worsened. Famine has officially been declared in part of the Darfur region in western Sudan.

headline: Olympic Officials Defend Fighters’ Eligibility in Women’s Boxing Controversy
abstract: Online fury and unclear rules have left organizers of the women’s boxing competition in Paris facing complex questions about fairness in women’s sports.
lead_paragraph: Lin Yu-ting strode toward the boxing ring on Friday fully aware that she was walking straight into a swirling controversy that has turned the Paris Olympics into a forum for a fierce debate about biology, gender and fairness in women’s sports.

headline: Appeals Court Further Narrows Voting Rights Act’s Scope
abstract: Reversing decades of precedent, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled in a Texas case that different minority groups cannot jointly claim that their votes have been diluted.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court further narrowed the scope of the 1965 Voting Rights Act, ruling that members of separate minority groups cannot join together to claim that a political map has been drawn to dilute their voting power.

headline: Families of Hostages Despair as Hopes for Imminent Peace Deal Fade
abstract: The recent assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, the leader of Hamas’s political branch, halted negotiations for a cease-fire that would bring home the hostages held in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Dekel-Chen, whose son Sagui is held hostage by Hamas in Gaza, said he left a meeting last week with President Biden more optimistic than he had felt in months that a deal to free his son could be close.

headline: A Tomato Sandwich That’s Very Tomato
abstract: This recipe, a riff on pan con tomate, calls for rubbing garlicky toasts with a halved tomato before applying, yes, more tomato.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The tomatoes are perfect right now where I stay, dense with juice, sweet with just a hint of acidity, super robust. They take to salt nicely. They call for herbs, sometimes for cheese. I can use a half dozen or more over the course of the weekend, and doing so makes me feel as if I live in Southern California, driving to buy them in a restored Cabriolet (white, with white interior, vanity plates reading TOM8TO).

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: In this month’s picks, crises occur both in outer space and in empty rooms.
lead_paragraph: The rom-com/sci-fi subgenre is on a roll. For a nice date night double bill, you could do worse than pairing the very funny “Molli and Max in the Future” with this bittersweet take on dating and relationships. The Mexican director Enrique Vázquez’s debut feature is set in a near-future when common wisdom holds that relationships last four years before souring. Whether or not couples still get along by that point, they split and people look for another partner. Getting ready to embark on a new contract, as relationships are now called, Fran (Regina Blandón) makes up answers to her matchmaking questionnaire, which messes up the algorithm. She ends up being paired with the sweetly dorky Roque (Leonardo Ortizgris), even though they don’t seem to share much. But maybe love is not based on perfect sync, after all, and maybe it can last longer than four years. Or can it?

headline: Billie Eilish Joins Charli XCX’s Brat Summer, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by MJ Lenderman, Miranda Lambert, ASAP Rocky featuring Jessica Pratt and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Jolted by Soft Jobs Report, Stocks Tumble to End a Turbulent Week
abstract: The report on hiring in July added to worries about the economy. Stocks fell sharply, and Treasury yields declined in expectation of a Federal Reserve rate cut.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street was jolted by rising economic uncertainty on Friday, and stocks skidded, capping off a turbulent week with a sharp decline.

headline: Olympic Champion Simone Biles Posted on Social Media That She Loves her ‘Black Job’
abstract: Biles is only the third woman gymnast to win the all-around competition twice at the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Simone Biles, who catapulted herself to a sixth gold medal and ninth overall medal in her storied Olympic career with a victory in the women’s all-around gymnastics competition Thursday, seemed to take a not-so-subtle dig at Donald J. Trump on social media.

headline: Benjamin Luxon, Rich Baritone Thwarted by Hearing Loss, Dies at 87
abstract: A favorite of Benjamin Britten, he won acclaim in roles like Don Giovanni, Eugene Onegin and Falstaff until his affliction forced him to largely give up singing.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Luxon, a warm-voiced British baritone who was admired for his singing of German and British song and his robust opera performances, but whose flourishing career was cut short by encroaching deafness, died on July 25 at his home in Sandisfield, Mass. He was 87.

headline: The U.K. Riots Were Fomented Online. Will Social Media Companies Act?
abstract: Prime Minister Keir Starmer called out social media groups for the misinformation on their platforms that sparked violent clashes this week. But holding them accountable is tough.
lead_paragraph: Standing in front of a lectern on Thursday, his voice at times taut with anger, Britain’s prime minister announced a crackdown on what he called the “gangs of thugs” who instigated violent unrest in several towns this week.

headline: The Big Number: 5.25%
abstract: The Federal Reserve left interest rates at a two-decade high, but all the attention was on what it will do next.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials on Wednesday left interest rates unchanged at 5.25 percent, keeping rates at their highest level in two decades.

headline: Manfred Kirchheimer, ‘Indispensable’ New York Filmmaker, Dies at 93
abstract: For decades, he meticulously crafted short films and documentaries in relative obscurity. Then, in his 80s, he enjoyed a burst of productivity and acclaim.
lead_paragraph: Manfred Kirchheimer, a filmmaker who was drawn to stickball, jazz, subway graffiti, gargoyles on old buildings and the memories of aging immigrants, and who after decades of slowpoke perfectionism earned a reputation as a master of nonfiction cinema, died on July 16 at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: Netanyahu, Defiant, Appears to Have Gone Rogue, Risking a Regional War
abstract: Ignoring the efforts of President Biden and the condemnation of many allies, the Israeli prime minister is forcing the pace of the war and feeding the revolt of the far right.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: ‘Trap’ Review: Pop Goes the Thriller
abstract: Josh Hartnett stars as a father with a secret in this M. Night Shyamalan film set at a concert.
lead_paragraph: “Dad, this is the literally the best day of my life,” the teenager Riley (Ariel Donoghue) beams to her doting father, Cooper (Josh Hartnett), in the opening minutes of M. Night Shyamalan’s “Trap.” That feeling won’t last — but for the first half of this mischievous thriller, we’re also having fun.

headline: See Where Countersnipers Could Have Stopped the Trump Rally Gunman
abstract: Where countersnipers were stationed — and where they were not — has emerged as a point of contention in assessing lapses that failed to prevent an assassination attempt.
lead_paragraph: Where countersnipers were stationed — and where they were not — has emerged as a point of contention in assessing lapses that failed to prevent an assassination attempt.

headline: Icon or Eyesore? Palm Springs to Move Divisive Marilyn Monroe Statue
abstract: A truce has been reached in a battle that pitted admirers of the city’s art museum against fans of a giant outdoor Marilyn Monroe sculpture.
lead_paragraph: It was a sweltering day in Palm Springs, and a few intrepid tourists braved the unforgiving sun to snap selfies at the stilettoed feet of a colossal Marilyn Monroe, her white dress seeming to billow up in the hot dry wind.

headline: Sarah Jessica Parker on Her Life in Publishing
abstract: Since 2016, the renowned actress has also worked in publishing, bringing her name and love of books to imprints at two companies. In this episode, she discusses what that work has meant to her.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Jessica Parker has been a familiar presence on TV, movie screens and Broadway stages for five decades. But since 2016 she has also been a force in the book world, initially at the helm of the fiction imprint SJP for Hogarth and for the past two years with SJP Lit, an imprint at the independent publisher Zando.

headline: Protesting Hunger, Nigerians Warn, ‘Life Cannot Continue Like This’
abstract: Thousands turned out across Africa’s most populous country despite government attempts to prevent them. Demonstrations have left at least 13 people dead, Amnesty International says.
lead_paragraph: Nigerians struggling to afford food and earn a living have taken to the streets in nationwide protests that have already left at least 13 people killed, according to Amnesty International.

headline: Who’s Afraid of Being Black? Not Kamala, Beyoncé or Kendrick.
abstract: With her response to Donald Trump’s comments about her background, Kamala Harris showed that Blackness doesn’t need to be explained or defended — an idea underscored by her campaign theme song.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris didn’t take the race bait.

headline: An Autocrat’s Tool Backfires in Venezuela
abstract: Nicolás Maduro claimed victory in his country’s election. But exit polls suggested the opposition leader won a landslide, setting off protests around the country.
lead_paragraph: It is common for autocrats to hold elections. As I’ve written before, winning an election can allow an autocratic leader to claim a popular mandate and to demonstrate to the military and to the political elite that the government’s hold on power is strong enough to make loyalty their safest bet.

headline: Senior U.S. Diplomat Will Lead Kamala Harris’s Running Mate’s Team
abstract: Elizabeth M. Allen, who heads the State Department’s public diplomacy office, served as a top aide to Ms. Harris in 2020 and in the Obama White House.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth M. Allen, a veteran diplomat and political operative, is stepping down from her position as the U.S. under secretary of state for public diplomacy to take on a senior role in Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign.

headline: JD Vance Pioneered ‘New Right’ Economics. Trump May Not Embrace It.
abstract: The vice-presidential nominee favors economic policies that help advance a socially conservative vision of American society — and that sometimes clash with Trump’s own plans.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, is a pioneer in what friends and critics alike call a new form of Republican economic thinking. It’s a vision to steer the economy toward advancing socially conservative goals, even when those policies defy conservative orthodoxy about government intervention in private markets.

headline: Harris Has Votes Needed to Be Democrats’ Nominee, D.N.C. Says
abstract: The party chair said she had won enough delegates to secure the nomination, setting up Kamala Harris to become the first Black woman and person of South Asian heritage to earn the top spot on a major political ticket for president.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has won enough delegates to secure the Democratic Party’s nomination, the Democratic National Committee said on Friday, setting up Ms. Harris to become the first Black woman and person of South Asian heritage to earn the top spot on a major political ticket for president.

headline: U.S. Sues TikTok Over Child Privacy Violations
abstract: The Justice Department said TikTok illegally collected children’s data and knowingly allowed users under the age of 13 to create accounts.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department sued TikTok on Friday, accusing it of illegally collecting children’s data and escalating a long-running battle between the U.S. government and the Chinese-owned app.

headline: Police Investigate Death Threats Against Olympics Opening Ceremony Director
abstract: Thomas Jolly said he had received a barrage of online harassment, after some people interpreted a section of the show as mocking a biblical scene.
lead_paragraph: The Paris police are investigating death threats and online harassment targeting Thomas Jolly, the Olympic opening ceremony’s artistic director, the Paris prosecutor’s office said on Friday.

headline: Read the lawsuit
abstract: The Justice Department said in its legal filing that TikTok had violated a leading child privacy law.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said in its legal filing that TikTok had violated a leading child privacy law.

headline: The Olympics’ No. 1 Fan
abstract: Is anyone as excited by the Paris Games as Antoine Griezmann? It doesn’t seem possible.
lead_paragraph: Some time on Monday night, his head doubtless heavy with sorrow, Antoine Griezmann returned to Madrid. He had stayed away as long as possible, but he was due for his first training session with Atlético Madrid on Tuesday morning. The European soccer season, long and arduous, hangs on the horizon. Summer, for him, had ended. It was time to return to work.

headline: Not One of Us: Trump Uses Old Tactic to Sow Suspicion About Harris
abstract: Politicians have long cast their opponents as outsiders. But Donald J. Trump has taken the strategy to the next level against Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: She is not one of us.

headline: Alan Garber Will Stay On as Harvard’s President
abstract: The appointment of Dr. Garber, who took over as interim president after Claudine Gay resigned, follows months of harsh public scrutiny and immense private turmoil at the university.
lead_paragraph: Harvard University named Alan M. Garber as its president on Friday, a bid for stability after months of harsh public scrutiny and immense private turmoil.

headline: Is It Weird to Care About the Birthrate?
abstract: Pro-natalism in the shadow of the culture war.
lead_paragraph: JD Vance is one of the first important politicians in the United States to directly take up one of the preoccupations of this newsletter — the ongoing collapse of birthrates across the developed world and the grim consequences of an aging, childless future — and it’s fair to say it isn’t going well so far. Not just his dig at “childless cat ladies” but also his past support for a system where parents cast votes on behalf of their children have been fodder for the Democratic Party’s newfound narrative about the Trump-Vance ticket: that it’s creepy, bizarre, weird.

headline: Untitled (The Playlist)
abstract: Hear songs with no firm names from the Cure, D’Angelo, Kate Bollinger and more.
lead_paragraph: Today, Jack White released a new solo album named “No Name,” joining the ranks of the many artists throughout history who have finished a piece of music and, confronted with the challenge of giving it an all-encompassing title, simply shrugged and said, “I’d rather not.” Elliott Smith, for example, had a whole numbered series of “No Name” songs, while the Breeders called their 2002 album “Title TK,” publishing shorthand for “to come later.” The rapper Noname has confused things further, cheekily titling a recent song “Namesake.” The mind boggles.

headline: How Does Your State Make Electricity?
abstract: There’s been a big shift in how America produces power. Each state has its own story.
lead_paragraph: There’s been a big shift in how America produces power. Each state has its own story.

headline: Reflections About the Prisoner Swap
abstract: Readers worry about encouraging hostage-taking and speculate about Vladimir Putin’s thinking. Also: JD Vance; a female president; America at the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Delaware Judge Questions Tesla About Vote on Elon Musk’s Tesla Pay
abstract: Lawyers for Tesla have asked a Delaware judge to reverse her decision to void a multibillion-dollar pay package for Mr. Musk after shareholders approved it a second time in June.
lead_paragraph: A Delaware judge on Friday questioned lawyers for Tesla about why the company asked shareholders to vote on a $55 billion pay package for its chief executive, Elon Musk, after she had struck it down in January.

headline: In Iceland, a Feminist Inspired by the Country’s History Is the New President
abstract: Though the president’s role is mostly ceremonial, Halla Tómasdóttir said that she would seek to raise “the right questions” and bring attention to critical health issues.
lead_paragraph: Seven-year-old Halla Tómasdóttir was confused on her mother’s birthday in 1975. Her mother and aunts weren’t in the kitchen as usual, instead directing their husbands and brothers to do the work. That was because women were taking the day off to demonstrate their value to society amid Iceland’s first national women’s strike.

headline: Kamala Harris Hires Top Obama Advisers, Building Out Campaign
abstract: David Plouffe, who managed Barack Obama’s first presidential bid, is among the new senior staff announced on Friday, along with veterans of both Obama campaigns as well as Hillary Clinton’s 2016 run.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris, who formally won enough delegates to secure the Democratic Party nomination on Friday, is remaking a campaign hierarchy originally built to re-elect President Biden by adding several new advisers to the top ranks of her staff, including David Plouffe, who managed Barack Obama’s first presidential run.

headline: Ippon! Teddy Riner thrills home crowd to grab Olympic gold in judo.
abstract: Facing the No. 1-seeded judoka in the +100kg weight class, Kim Minjong of South Korea, Riner won his sixth Olympic medal.
lead_paragraph: The French judoka Teddy Riner is 6-foot-8, weighs 300(ish) pounds and once went a very, very, very, very, very, very, very (very) long time without losing, a stretch of supremacy that launched him into a realm of renown in France generally occupied by soccer stars, fashion doyennes and philosophers.

headline: Peter C. Theisinger, 78, Dies; Led Mars Rover Missions for NASA
abstract: He directed a team of engineers that built Spirit, Opportunity and Curiosity, mobile robots that offered astonishing glimpses into the planet’s ancient past.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in California, Peter C. Theisinger assembled model airplanes, tinkered with electronic hobby kits and operated a ham radio set. But when it came to building anything bigger than a bread box, even as an adult, he recalled, “I was never mechanical, never tried to fix my car.”

headline: Justin Timberlake, on Tour, Beams Into Sag Harbor to Plead Not Guilty
abstract: The singer’s arrest and prosecution on a drunken-driving charge has drawn the curious to the Hamptons and supplied the internet with meme fodder.
lead_paragraph: Justin Timberlake’s world tour detoured to Sag Harbor, N.Y., on Friday, when a judge suspended his driving privileges in New York while he fights a drunken-driving charge.

headline: Haunting Image: First Photo Released of C.I.A. Prisoner at Black Site
abstract: Lawyers for a prisoner at Guantánamo Bay said the image emerged from a classification review that blacked out much of a legal brief.
lead_paragraph: For years, defense lawyers in the Guantánamo cases have spoken of reviewing disturbing government photos of the prisoners being held by the C.I.A. in the Bush administration’s secret overseas prison, the black sites. But they were marked classified, and the world was not allowed to see them. Until now.

headline: Joe Manchin Is Forcing an Agonizing Trade-Off on Climate Change
abstract: His bill moving through the Senate would deliver a win for both renewable energy and fossil fuels.
lead_paragraph: This week Senator Joe Manchin, independent from West Virginia, called a committee vote on a bill to speed up approval of energy projects that puts environmentalists in a tough spot. It gives them something they badly want, along with something they strongly oppose.

headline: Was I Wrong to Reveal That My Novel Was Inspired by an Adulterous Friend?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on character concerns, both in fiction and real life.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, while raising a child in a small town, my husband and I became close to two other families with children the same age as ours. We socialized frequently, both on and off the playground. Then it came to light that, for more than a year, one of the husbands had been having an affair with the wife of the other, and our chummy sextuplet was torn asunder.

headline: Tech Bosses Preach Patience as They Spend and Spend on A.I.
abstract: Big technology companies show no signs of slowing their spending on artificial intelligence, even though a payoff still looks a long way away.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg, Meta’s chief executive, started 2023 by declaring it the “year of efficiency.” Like several of its big tech peers, Meta cut jobs and mothballed expansion plans.

headline: A ‘Love Activist’ D.J. Opened the Olympics. Then Came a Wave of Hate.
abstract: The French D.J. Barbara Butch wanted to deliver a message of peace in the opening ceremony, but ended up getting savaged online.
lead_paragraph: The Paris Olympics opening ceremony made the French D.J. Barbara Butch famous and infamous around the world. Already known in France as an outspoken lesbian and activist for fat people, Butch — her stage name, of course — appeared with a crown and her mixing board in one of the last scenes, called “Festivity.”

headline: The Court Filing
abstract: The photo was declassified with the release of a 2019 filing by Ammar al-Baluchi’s legal team.
lead_paragraph: The photo was declassified with the release of a 2019 filing by Ammar al-Baluchi’s legal team.

headline: Former F.B.I. Agent Sentenced to Life Plus 20 Years for Sexually Abusing Child
abstract: Christopher Bauer, who was convicted in June, found work as an Alabama state trooper after he was forced out of the F.B.I., officials said.
lead_paragraph: A former F.B.I. agent turned Alabama state trooper who was convicted of sexually abusing an 11-year-old girl over several years was sentenced on Thursday to life plus 20 years in prison.

headline: Russian Dissident Says He Was Traded Against His Will in Inmate Swap
abstract: Ilya Yashin, a prominent opposition politician, said he appreciated his freedom, but told his jailers he did not want it if it meant going into exile.
lead_paragraph: Ilya Yashin, one of the Russian dissidents traded to the West in Thursday’s prisoner exchange for a group of Russian agents, cybercriminals and an assassin, said on Friday that he did not want his freedom if it meant leaving his country.

headline: How to Watch the Summer Olympics in 4K
abstract: You can watch those handsprings in ultra high definition.
lead_paragraph: You can watch those handsprings in ultra high definition.

headline: Does Anyone Have Leverage Over Nicolás Maduro?
abstract: The Biden administration recognized the autocrat’s rival as the winner of Sunday’s election in Venezuela. Yet President Maduro shows no sign of being willing to leave office.
lead_paragraph: The message delivered Thursday night was blunt: The United States recognized Venezuela’s opposition presidential candidate as the winner in Sunday’s election and dismissed a declaration by election officials that the country’s autocrat, President Nicolás Maduro, had won.

headline: Sha’Carri Richardson Is Ready for Her Moment
abstract: Three years after a failed drug test kept her out of the Olympics, Richardson (and her fans) are focused on only one thing: a gold medal in the 100 meters.
lead_paragraph: Sha’Carri Richardson is only interested in moving in one direction: forward. Her preference is to do so very, very quickly.

headline: Death of Black Man at Milwaukee Hyatt Is Ruled a Homicide
abstract: D’Vontaye Mitchell died after being held down by hotel staff members. An autopsy cited restraint asphyxia and the toxic effects of cocaine and methamphetamine as the cause of death.
lead_paragraph: The death of a Black man who was held down by security guards outside a Milwaukee hotel has been ruled a homicide as prosecutors review possible murder charges against four people in connection with his death.

headline: It’s official: Léon Marchand owns the pool after winning his fourth gold medal.
abstract: After winning the 200 individual medley, Marchand joins Michael Phelps and Mark Spitz as the only male swimmers to win four gold medals at a single Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Léon Marchand walked out to an adoring audience before his final individual event of these Olympics on Friday night. He’d already won them over — the home crowd, the city of Paris, the country of France — but he had another race to win.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, August 3, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Agency Votes to Replace Official Accused of Rushing Start of Seabed Mining
abstract: The international agency charged with regulating seabed mining elected a U.N. environmental regulator to replace a leader accused of too-close industry ties.
lead_paragraph: The international agency charged with regulating seabed mining worldwide voted on Friday to replace its top executive, after accusations that the British lawyer running the agency was too closely aligned with the mining industry.

headline: Harris Won Enough Votes to Be the Democratic Nominee
abstract: Also, the Middle East is on edge as Israel braces for retaliation. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Committee announced today that Vice President Kamala Harris had secured enough delegates to clinch the Democratic Party’s nomination for president. She will be the first Black woman and person of South Asian heritage to earn the top spot on a major party’s ticket.

headline: Germany Grapples With ‘Difficult Decision’ in Prisoner Swap
abstract: By releasing a convicted assassin, Germany played a critical role in securing the freedom of 16 people held in Russia. But the decision has raised questions about political influence in legal cases.
lead_paragraph: The convicted Russian killer bounded off a plane in Moscow on Thursday, hours after Germany freed him in a wide-ranging prison exchange with Russia. President Vladimir V. Putin hugged him on the tarmac, in a hero’s welcome.

headline: Hamas Leader’s Funeral Comes Amid Fears His Killing May Block Cease-Fire Deal
abstract: Few Palestinians appeared to heed Hamas’s call for a “day of anger” to condemn the killing of Ismail Haniyeh and Israel’s bombardment of the enclave.
lead_paragraph: Thousands packed Qatar’s largest mosque on Friday for the funeral of Ismail Haniyeh, Hamas’s political leader, hours after President Biden said his killing could hurt the monthslong effort to negotiate a cease-fire in Gaza.

headline: Yvonne Furneaux, Cosmopolitan Actress in ‘La Dolce Vita,’ Dies at 98
