abstract: An Oxford graduate who spoke five languages, she had an early career as a siren before finding critical acclaim in masterworks by Federico Fellini and Roman Polanski.
lead_paragraph: Yvonne Furneaux, a French-born English actress known for her icy beauty and continental air who brought jet-setting panache to critically acclaimed films like Federico Fellini’s “La Dolce Vita” and Roman Polanski’s “Repulsion,” died on July 5 at her home in North Hampton, N.H. She was 98.

headline: Highlights From the 2024 Paris Olympics
abstract: See our photographers’ best images from the Summer Games.
lead_paragraph: See our photographers’ best images from the Summer Games.

headline: The Veepstakes (Pennsylvania’s Version)
abstract: The question of whether Josh Shapiro can deliver the biggest, baddest swing state is complicated.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s supersonic veep search is in its final stages, and she heads into the weekend with much to consider before she announces her choice.

headline: Prisoner Deals Stoke Fears of Perverse ‘Incentive’ to Grab Americans
abstract: Hostile governments like Russia and Iran are often involved, and practical alternatives are hard to come by, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Behind the jubilation over the latest release of Americans unjustly imprisoned abroad are growing concerns that a new era of hostage diplomacy has emerged, with U.S. adversaries concluding that it pays to arrest innocent Americans and trade them for convicted smugglers, hackers, spies — and even killers.

headline: Secret Service Chief Admits Lack of Certainty on Sniper Locations at Trump Rally
abstract: The location of local snipers when Donald Trump was shot has become a point of deep dispute, with local officials suggesting that the Secret Service is trying to shift blame.
lead_paragraph: The Secret Service’s acting director acknowledged on Friday that when he told congressional investigators that local law enforcement snipers should have been able to see the gunman who shot former President Donald J. Trump at a rally, he did not have details from the snipers themselves on their locations.

headline: Judge Awards Schiele Drawing to Heirs of Merchant Killed by the Nazis
abstract: The drawing of Schiele’s wife was the focus of a trial at which three parties, all with Jewish roots, argued whether it had been looted by the Nazis and from whom.
lead_paragraph: For three weeks in May a judge in Rochester, N.Y., heard evidence meant to solve the mystery of who really owns a drawing of a smiling woman by the Austrian artist Egon Schiele.

headline: How Katie Ledecky Won the Most Medals of Any U.S. Female Olympian
abstract: Katie Ledecky now stands alone as the most decorated female American Olympian, in any sport, with 13 medals. And she still has one more race to swim in France. Jenny Vrentas, a New York Times reporter covering sports, explains how Ledecky reached this milestone.
lead_paragraph: Katie Ledecky now stands alone as the most decorated female American Olympian, in any sport, with 13 medals. And she still has one more race to swim in France. Jenny Vrentas, a New York Times reporter covering sports, explains how Ledecky reached this milestone.

headline: What’s Uniting, and Dividing, Native Voters in Arizona
abstract: A usually solidly Democratic vote, Native American voters across the state say they feel increasingly left out of the conversation and are looking for change.
lead_paragraph: A usually solidly Democratic vote, Native American voters across the state say they feel increasingly left out of the conversation and are looking for change.

headline: Passenger Who Tried to Open Cockpit and Exit Door Gets 19 Months in Prison
abstract: Juan Rivas, who threatened flight attendants with a champagne bottle and a plastic knife, tried to open an exit door of an American Airlines plane, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A California man who tried to intimidate flight attendants on an American Airlines flight using plastic silverware from a service cart and a glass champagne bottle, and then tried unsuccessfully to open an exit door and the cockpit, was sentenced on Wednesday to 19 months in prison.

headline: Alongside the Trump-Russia Inquiry, a Lesser-Known Look at Egyptian Influence
abstract: The Justice Department and special counsel Robert Mueller investigated whether a Trump adviser was part of an Egyptian plan, never proven, to funnel $10 million to the 2016 Trump campaign.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2017, as the special counsel Robert S. Mueller III was starting his investigation, his agents and prosecutors were chasing potentially explosive allegations about foreign influence over Donald J. Trump and his campaign.

headline: Shapiro’s College-Era Criticism of Palestinians Draws Fresh Scrutiny
abstract: The Pennsylvania governor, a top contender to be Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate, wrote in his college newspaper that Palestinians were “too battle-minded.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Josh Shapiro, Democrat of Pennsylvania, wrote in his college newspaper three decades ago that Palestinians were “too battle-minded” to achieve a two-state solution in the Middle East, prompting criticism as Vice President Kamala Harris considers him to be her running mate.

headline: Aerosmith Retires From Touring, Citing Steven Tyler’s Vocal Injury
abstract: Last year, the band’s frontman, Steven Tyler, suffered a vocal injury during a show, and the farewell tour was postponed. The band announced its retirement on Friday, saying a full recovery was not possible.
lead_paragraph: Aerosmith, the venerated American hard rock band whose hit records like “Dream On” have reverberated across the airwaves and in sweaty sold-out venues around the world for more than half a century, announced Friday that it was retiring from the tour stage, citing a permanent vocal injury to its star frontman, Steven Tyler.

headline: Defense Secretary Revokes Plea Deal for Accused Sept. 11 Plotters
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III assumed direct oversight of the case and effectively put the death penalty back on the table.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III on Friday overruled the overseer of the war court at Guantánamo Bay and revoked a plea agreement reached earlier this week with the accused mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and two alleged accomplices.

headline: Meta in Talks to Use Voices of Judi Dench, Awkwafina and Others for A.I.
abstract: If deals are struck, Meta may incorporate the actors’ voices into a digital assistant product called MetaAI, people with knowledge of the effort said.
lead_paragraph: Meta is in discussions with Awkwafina, Judi Dench and other actors and influencers for the right to incorporate their voices into a digital assistant product called MetaAI, according to three people with knowledge of the talks, as the company pushes to build more products that feature artificial intelligence.

headline: Maui Wildfire Plaintiffs Reach $4 Billion Settlement as Anniversary Nears
abstract: Hawaiian Electric is expected to pay the largest share — nearly $2 billion — but avoided a heftier price tag that could have forced the utility into bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after a ferocious wildfire on Maui killed 102 people and leveled the historic town of Lahaina, Hawaii’s largest utility has agreed to pay the largest share of a legal settlement totaling just over $4 billion and compensating more than 10,000 homeowners, businesses and other plaintiffs.

headline: Foggy
abstract: Rich Norris’s themeless puzzle shouldn’t be missed.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Rich Norris, a fixture in the crossword community who used to edit the crossword at The Los Angeles Times, is now making a constructing comeback for The New York Times. This is his second Saturday grid of 2024, but his 120th overall; the other 118 puzzles ran between 1994 and 2008. (Thanks to technology, you can solve all of them online, but they predate the Wordplay column, so no hints from us!)

headline: To Lam Confirmed as Vietnam’s Top Leader Until at Least 2026
abstract: Mr. Lam had been filling the post of general secretary temporarily since the death of his predecessor in July. Now he is in position to consolidate power.
lead_paragraph: President To Lam of Vietnam, best known for implementing a sweeping anticorruption drive, will become the country’s next Communist Party general secretary, the government’s Politburo announced on Saturday.

headline: Iran Arrests Dozens in Search for Suspects in Killing of Hamas Leader
abstract: Iran has begun a sweeping investigation into the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, with its intensity a sign of how damaging and shocking the security failure was.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: Marcell Jacobs Has Waited a Long Time to Prove the Doubters Wrong
abstract: When the Italian sprinter came from nowhere to win 100-meter gold in Tokyo, whispers spread about his sudden rise. In Paris, he hopes to silence them for good.
lead_paragraph: The strict security protocols governing the movements of President Sergio Mattarella of Italy dictate that he is not permitted to appear in the same location repeatedly. He is, in this respect and probably this respect alone, like lightning: He is not supposed to strike twice.

headline: Bombs Rain Down in Myanmar as Junta Evades Sanctions to Buy Jet Fuel
abstract: The military has stepped up a campaign of airstrikes, and killed more civilians, to fend off rebel advances.
lead_paragraph: The family ducked for cover when junta jets roared over their home in central Myanmar. U Har San and his wife crawled under a table, and their daughter, eight months pregnant, hid under a bed. Bombs rained down, he said, even though no rebel fighters were in their village.

headline: Deputy Killed and Two Others Wounded in Ambush Shooting in Florida, Sheriff Says
abstract: The deputies were shot while responding to a call in Eustis, a city north of Orlando. Two suspects were found dead in the house, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A sheriff’s deputy was killed and two other deputies were wounded in what officials described as an ambush shooting inside a Florida home on Friday night.

headline: Trump Cancels a Debate With Harris on ABC News and Pitches One With Fox News Instead
abstract: Mr. Trump said in a social media post that the previously scheduled presidential debate to be hosted by ABC News was “terminated” once President Biden dropped out of the race.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump declared late on Friday that he was dropping out of an ABC News debate scheduled for Sept. 10 and presented a counterproposal to Vice President Kamala Harris, his presumptive opponent, to face off on Fox News six days earlier.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 3, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A Critic’s Notebook article on Thursday about the relationship between art and sport at the Cultural Olympiad described incorrectly when the cultural component of the Olympics began. The Olympics have long featured cultural events, but that component was not officially called the Cultural Olympiad until 1992.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Ten Seconds, One-Man Team Could Be Done
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I like the 100 meters because it is short.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How a ‘Dirty Gospel’ Minister Spends His Sundays
abstract: The Reverend Vince Anderson, a mainstay of the Brooklyn music scene, fills his day with worship in two languages, the Mets and a full hour of watering his 92 houseplants.
lead_paragraph: When most people picture a minister, Vince Anderson is not who comes to mind.

headline: Equestrian Is Having an Uncomfortable Moment. Its Olympic Horses Are Not.
abstract: Accusations of mistreatment cast a shadow over dressage and other events. Can cooling tents and locally sourced hay change the narrative?
lead_paragraph: For most of the athletes at the Paris Olympics, the accommodations are to be endured, rather than enjoyed. In the name of sustainability, the beds at the Olympic Village feature cardboard frames and inflatable mattresses. The bathrooms are communal. To the horror of the French, the British have even complained about the food.

headline: A Brooklyn Enclave’s Uneasy Peace With 4,000 New Migrant Neighbors
abstract: A pair of shootings deepened quality-of-life concerns among Brooklyn neighbors of a giant office development being used to shelter migrants from Africa and Latin America.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, as New York City was in the throes of a migrant influx from the southern border, residents near the Brooklyn Navy Yard began to notice a growing number of African and Latin American migrants milling around the neighborhood’s parks and sidewalks.

headline: Inside the ‘Shakespearean Drama’ of the Murdoch Family
abstract: The reporters Jim Rutenberg and Jonathan Mahler, experts on the Murdoch empire, reflect on the revelation and implications of a clandestine legal battle.
lead_paragraph: When Rupert Murdoch married for the fifth time this past June, the wedding was absent a few notable guests: three of his four eldest children, James, Elisabeth and Prudence.

headline: Street Sheds Transformed New York City Dining. Many Will Soon Disappear.
abstract: New requirements for the city’s outdoor dining program are being met with concern by restaurant owners.
lead_paragraph: More than four years after the coronavirus upended life in New York City, some of the most visible vestiges of the pandemic — outdoor dining structures erected outside thousands of restaurants — are facing a deadline that could see many of them razed.

headline: The Pentagon promises to help defend Israel.
abstract: Israel was bracing for retaliatory attacks from Iran and its proxies in the aftermath of a top Hamas leader’s assassination as additional American combat aircraft and missile-shooting warships were being dispatched to the region.
lead_paragraph: Israel was bracing for retaliatory attacks from Iran and its proxies in the aftermath of a top Hamas leader’s assassination as additional American combat aircraft and missile-shooting warships were being dispatched to the region.

headline: Can Harris Build Momentum Among South Asian Voters in Georgia?
abstract: In Georgia, a critical swing state President Biden won by less than 12,000 votes in 2020, Kamala Harris’ political identity has prompted renewed interest among Asian Americans, the fastest-growing group of eligible voters in the United States.
lead_paragraph: In Georgia, a critical swing state President Biden won by less than 12,000 votes in 2020, Kamala Harris’ political identity has prompted renewed interest among Asian Americans, the fastest-growing group of eligible voters in the United States.

headline: The Retirement Home for N.F.L. Players That Never Was
abstract: A planned senior care facility next to the Pro Football Hall of Fame was trumpeted a decade ago. Today, no such place exists and the idea seems to have been dropped.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, the Pro Football Hall of Fame announced plans for a $500 million development on its campus in Canton, Ohio. Included in the renderings was a senior care facility called Legends Landing. It was intended to serve aging N.F.L. retirees, including those with cognitive diseases that researchers have associated with the repeated hits to the head many football players take during their careers.

headline: Amid Heavy Industry, Canada’s Newest (and Tiniest) National Park
abstract: The creation of an urban national park on an unprepossessing parcel of land in the automaking hub of Windsor, Ontario, is also meant to serve as an act of Indigenous reconciliation.
lead_paragraph: The beach is more about broken glass from generations of illicit parties than sand. The roar and squeal of a nearby railway locomotive compete with the birdsong. The wind carries a sweet chemical scent from a cooking oil processing plant to the west.

headline: Ashley Park Wants to Laugh (or Cry) With You at the Theater
abstract: TV shows like “Emily in Paris” and “Beef” are raising her profile, but she’s still a fan of “the magic of a live audience.”
lead_paragraph: Ashley Park has heard the criticism of “Emily in Paris.” The costumes can be garish. (Bucket hats? In the office?!) The characters can be cartoonish. The biggest worry for Emily, the protagonist, is often whether to cut trauma bangs or what outré dress to wear next.

headline: So, Human Resources Is Making You Miserable?
abstract: Get in line behind the H.R. managers themselves, who say that since the pandemic, the job has become an exasperating ordeal. “People hate us,” one said.
lead_paragraph: Show of hands: Who’s fed up with human resources?

headline: Will A.I. Kill Meaningless Jobs?
abstract: And is that so bad?
lead_paragraph: When Brad Wang started his first job in the tech industry, right after college, he marveled at the way Silicon Valley had turned the drudgery of the workplace into a sumptuousness of game rooms, nap pods and leafy hiking trails. This is what it must have felt like to be a guest showing up for a party at Jay Gatsby’s house, Mr. Wang thought.

headline: A Prescription for Physicians: Listen to the Patient’s Story
abstract: In “Telltale Hearts,” a new memoir, Dr. Dean-David Schillinger traces the links between narrative and well-being.
lead_paragraph: One of the riveting tales in “Telltale Hearts,” a new memoir, is about the author’s great-uncle Aladar, a Hungarian Jew who was drafted to fight the Russians in 1916 and spent months in trenches, shooting and getting shot at, and waiting.

headline: In Gaza, Even Poetry and Toilets Aren’t Safe From Thieves
abstract: Israel’s assault has driven Hamas underground, but for nearly two million Gazans, what followed in its wake is a lawlessness that is undermining communal trust.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: Four Great Photography Books Where Words Add Power to Pictures
abstract: New collections by Gordon Parks, Platon, Peter van Agtmael and Myriam Boulos reveal  when you need to tell as well as show.
lead_paragraph: For a documentary photographer who seeks to change the world, images go only so far. Dorothea Lange, a pioneer in the field, put it simply: All photographs, she said, “can be fortified by words.”

headline: Lavish Pre-Wedding Parties That Rival the Main Event
abstract: The celebrations hosted by the Ambani family have thrusts the trend into the spotlight. Wedding professionals say couples are spending more than ever on extravagant events to kick off their nuptials.
lead_paragraph: When Anant Ambani, the youngest son of India’s richest man, married Radhika Merchant in Mumbai this summer, the occasion seemed almost anticlimactic compared with the months of celebrations leading up to their lavish nuptials.

headline: A Former Monk Who Won Powerball Is Giving Millions to Theaters
abstract: Roy Cockrum has donated more than $25 million to 39 theaters, helping the Old Globe in San Diego stage the one Shakespeare play it had yet to produce.
lead_paragraph: When Roy Cockrum, a one-time struggling actor and a former monk, won a $259 million Powerball jackpot in 2014, he decided to splurge on something a bit out of the ordinary: supporting nonprofit theater.

headline: Two New Musicals Poke at the Seamy Underbelly of the American Dream
abstract: Kristin Chenoweth stars in “The Queen of Versailles” in Boston, while a new “Gatsby” musical in Cambridge takes Myrtle seriously.
lead_paragraph: “It may surprise you,” Jackie Siegel says, “but we are not old money.”

headline: In Palermo, a Catholic Saint Joins the Hindu Pantheon
abstract: The Sicilian capital, Palermo, has a long history of cultural melding. Its new arrivals from Sri Lanka have embraced St. Rosalia.
lead_paragraph: After they spread pink petals on golden statues of Ganesh and Shiva, and recited prayers to blue-skinned and eight-armed gods, the Hindu faithful left their temple and headed to a party for another one of their divinities — the Catholic St. Rosalia.

headline: 3 Edge-of-Your-Seat New Thrillers
abstract: Our columnist on three terrific new books.
lead_paragraph: This month’s books deal with disturbances — in people’s minds, in their families and in the heavens. In Sarah Easter Collins’s THINGS DON’T BREAK ON THEIR OWN (Crown, 259 pp., $28) Willa Martenwood has been haunted by the disappearance of her 13-year-old sister, Laika, for more than two decades. One of the manifestations of Willa’s restless obsession is that she sees Laika everywhere, even at the dinner party that begins the story.

headline: Harold Makes the World With His Purple Crayon. Who Made Harold?
abstract: Before there was a feature film or a book, there was Crockett Johnson.
lead_paragraph: “How does Harold draw himself?” my friend Noam wondered. Noam is 4, so he has a taste for the kind of bracing philosophical speculation that “Harold and the Purple Crayon” — the classic children’s book about a young boy and his magical marker — invites, along with wonder, mischief and delight.

headline: He Broke Into a Bank (With Permission). Then He Rented It for $1 a Month.
abstract: After an unconventional negotiation with his building manager, an artist transformed what was once a bank into a studio.
lead_paragraph: Rarely, in New York City, do you hear stories about tenants getting along with their landlords. But Victor Jeffreys II — a 41-year-old artist who has been living in the same apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, for nearly 20 years — got lucky.

headline: Why Are Your Property Taxes Higher Than Your Neighbor’s?
abstract: Property taxes for condominiums in New York City are calculated differently from taxes in other dwellings.
lead_paragraph: Q.: I live in a two-bedroom penthouse in a 174-unit condo building in Midtown, with approximately 1,800 square feet of interior space and 900 square feet of outdoor space. I bought it eight years ago for $2 million. My annual property tax is $60,000. I have seen real estate listings in the city with much lower taxes, such as a four-bedroom house in the Bronx with taxes of $696 a month, and a one-bedroom in Turtle Bay listed for $1.6 million with taxes of $894 a month. Why is my property tax bill so high, and can I appeal it? Or are there ways to lower it?

headline: Not Even the Inside of Your Fridge Is Safe From Decorating
abstract: Some artists use canvas; others, refrigerators. Welcome to fridgescaping.
lead_paragraph: There’s organizing a fridge, and then there’s fridgescaping: the art of decorating a fridge’s interior.

headline: Fires Have Burned 4.5 Million Acres This Year, Blanketing Much of North America in Smoke
abstract: Nearly 90 large fires are raging across the United States, intensifying this year’s fire season. The forecast shows no sign of letting up.
lead_paragraph: Devastating wildfires are breaking out across North America on a daily basis, with smoke and ash spreading over large swaths of the continent from Reno to Toronto and New York. Fast-moving blazes have destroyed homes and charred through thousands of acres of farms and forests. Some have become deadly.

headline: San Francisco Takes Harder Line Against Homeless Camps, Defying Its Reputation
abstract: Mayor London Breed has told city officials to issue citations and encourage homeless people to leave town by offering free bus tickets.
lead_paragraph: The homeless men who huddled in tents on a wide sidewalk near Golden Gate Park in San Francisco knew that city crews were coming to clear them out. But they did not budge.

headline: Should Harris Talk Much About Her Racial Identity? Many Voters Say No.
abstract: Even as Trump plays up racial divisions, many Americans said they would rather not dwell on race or identity. “We can all see that you’re Black.”
lead_paragraph: “Obviously, we have eyes.”

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’: All the Dragons and Their Riders So Far
abstract: The dragons are amassing, and just like their humans, they have histories and personalities, too. Here’s a rundown of who’s riding whom.
lead_paragraph: “House of the Dragon” has finally lived up to its name; it’s all about the dragons ahead of the Season 2 finale, airing Sunday on HBO.

headline: Whirlwind Harris Veepstakes Reaches Its Most Eager Phase Yet
abstract: With Kamala Harris expected to announce her running mate by Tuesday, contenders are making last-ditch efforts to showcase what they could bring to the ticket and keep themselves in the public eye.
lead_paragraph: Just in case anyone had forgotten, Gov. JB Pritzker of Illinois released a nearly four-minute video this week promoting his accomplishments in office.

headline: ‘I’m Definitely Re-engaged:’ Harris Fuels Energy Among Georgia’s South Asian Voters
abstract: In Georgia, a critical swing state President Biden won by less than 12,000 votes in 2020, Kamala Harris’ political identity has prompted renewed interest among Asian Americans, the fastest-growing group of eligible voters in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris is poised to become the first Democratic presidential nominee of South Asian heritage. Her candidacy has reignited debate and engagement among Asian Americans, the fastest-growing group of eligible voters in the United States.

headline: Vince Vaughn Turned This Interview Into Self-Help
abstract: I went in expecting a swaggering, overconfident guy. I found something much more interesting.
lead_paragraph: The Vince Vaughn who lives in my head is one of my favorite comedic actors. He’s the swaggering, charmingly sarcastic and cheerily ingratiating star of that great run of hit comedies from the early 2000s: “Old School,” “Dodgeball,” “Wedding Crashers,” “The Break-Up.” (His cameo in “Anchorman” and recurring role as Freddy Funkhouser on “Curb Your Enthusiasm” are also prime comedic Vaughniana.) And putting my own preferences aside, I’d argue that there’s a whole microgeneration of dudes who tried to swipe the neo-Rat Pack vibes that Vaughn was able to deploy so winningly in “Swingers.”

headline: The Connections Companion No. 420, August 4, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,142, Sunday, August 4, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Canadian Doctors Warn Against Private Medicine as a Cure for the System’s Ills
abstract: The Canadian Medical Association has called for a ban on payments for procedures long covered by public systems and is warning about contracting services out.
lead_paragraph: With perhaps 6.5 million Canadians finding themselves without a personal doctor and with seemingly endless waiting times becoming almost a norm for some medical procedures, private medicine is increasingly being pitched as a solution for those and other problems in Canada’s public health system.

headline: Terrorist Attack on Crowded Beachfront in Somalia Kills at Least 32
abstract: Gunmen and a suicide bomber struck a seaside hotel in one of the deadliest such assaults in the country in months. The Islamist militant group Al Shabab claimed responsibility.
lead_paragraph: A suicide bomber detonated explosives outside a hotel in a popular beachfront area in Somalia’s capital, Mogadishu, before gunmen stormed the building, setting off a four-hour siege that left at least 32 people dead and more than 60 others wounded, the police said on Saturday.

headline: The Best Conversations
abstract: Whether we’re participating in them or listening to them, the goal is to forget about the outcome and just connect.
lead_paragraph: After my recent flight from Maine to New York was canceled, I found myself with the bounty of six hours alone in a rental car. I considered the headway I could make in the audiobook of “Demon Copperhead,” but quickly abandoned that option for several episodes of the podcast “Conan O’Brien Needs a Friend.” I wanted company. If I couldn’t chat away the hours with a passenger in the seat beside me, I wanted to listen to other people hitting it off.

headline: Kamala Harris on Center Stage
abstract: Readers discuss “White Dudes,” her laugh, her previous positions and a columnist’s mixed emotions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why Silicon Valley Should Get Behind Kamala Harris
abstract: Her presidency could support the technological innovation our economy needs.
lead_paragraph: There is a major opportunity for Vice President Kamala Harris and the Democrats in the House and Senate to set our country on a different course.

headline: Can the Harris Sugar High Last? Yes.
abstract: Michelle Goldberg on the power of emotion in politics.
lead_paragraph: With Democratic enthusiasm for Kamala Harris at a fever pitch, the New York Times Opinion columnist Michelle Goldberg spent a day in Atlanta at one of her rallies speaking with voters. In this audio essay, Goldberg argues that the energy among voters she met there is real, and more importantly, will last.

headline: Dogs Are the Best! But They Highlight Our Hypocrisy.
abstract: While we increasingly pamper our dogs, we blithely accept the torture of the pigs we eat.
lead_paragraph: Over the past couple of decades, dogs have evolved into humans.

headline: ‘An End to the Trump Story’: Three Columnists Size Up Harris and Her V.P. Options
abstract: What three columnists are thinking about possible Democratic presidential tickets and the state of the race between Harris and Trump.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Jamelle Bouie, Ross Douthat and Michelle Goldberg to discuss Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate options — whom she will pick, whom she should pick, the Electoral College landscape for her and for Donald Trump, and what surprises and worries them about Harris, the Democrats, Trump and JD Vance. This conversation has been edited and condensed.

headline: My Erotic Awakening in the Pages of ‘Sweet Valley High’
abstract: Twins, one good and one bad. Choose your adventure. Or be both at the same time.
lead_paragraph: When news broke that Francine Pascal, creator of the “Sweet Valley High” universe, died last weekend at the age of 92, appreciations began rolling across the internet like a certain red Spider through a high school parking lot. “Wildly popular,” “staple of my girlhood,” “G.O.A.T. of publishing,” readers proclaimed. Nostalgic and bereaved, I drove to the library to check out a few, only to discover they had been removed from the catalog.

headline: Why Josh Shapiro Would Make Such a Difference for Kamala Harris
abstract: Governor Josh Shapiro would send a signal that Vice President Harris is not captive to the left and that she puts experience ahead of ideology.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has one overriding weakness as a candidate for president — she is perceived as being to the left of Joe Biden. Ms. Harris has criticized U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, supported single-payer health care and even praised the “defund the police” movement. More recently, opponents have blamed her for what they see as a too-porous southern border.

headline: Kamala Harris’s Life in Canada Was Marked by a Yearning for Home
abstract: Ms. Harris went north as a 12-year-old when her mother was recruited to conduct breast-cancer research, but California was always on her mind. The experience of a Canadian friend inspired her to become a prosecutor.
lead_paragraph: While campaigning this past week, Senator JD Vance of Ohio called Vice President Kamala Harris a “phony” who “grew up in Canada,” as former President Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, continued raising false and incendiary questions about the presumed Democratic nominee’s racial identity.

headline: Roaring Back After Crackdown, Bangladesh Protesters Demand Leader’s Ouster
abstract: The demonstrations appeared to be the largest yet, as a deadly crackdown seemed to have made many Bangladeshis even angrier and broadened the movement’s scope.
lead_paragraph: Fresh protests roiled Bangladesh on Saturday, just weeks after a deadly government crackdown, as demonstrators returned to the streets in what appeared to be the biggest numbers yet and escalated their demands to include the prime minister’s resignation.

headline: I Thought I Disliked These Authors. I Was Happy to Be Wrong.
abstract: Italo Calvino? Not so bad! May Sarton? Pretty good!
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Saying the Quiet Part Out Loud
abstract: Two billionaire Democratic donors have publicly pressured Vice President Kamala Harris to replace the F.T.C. chair, Lina Khan. Wall Street insiders are worried that could backfire.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street Democrats have spent the last eight years complaining about their relationship with Washington. They found former President Donald Trump’s presidency unpredictable, and then became estranged from the Democratic Party as President Biden hired the most aggressive antitrust regulators in recent memory. But now that Vice President Kamala Harris is the party’s presumptive presidential nominee, they see a chance to regain influence.

headline: Here’s the latest on the presidential race.
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, rallied in Atlanta on Saturday night, campaigning in a battleground state where Vice President Kamala Harris rallied earlier this week.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, rallied in Atlanta on Saturday night, campaigning in a battleground state where Vice President Kamala Harris rallied earlier this week.

headline: Jackie Fox Saw the Dark Side of Rock. Now She’s Playing Her Own Way.
abstract: The teenage bassist of the Runaways cut her music career short in 1977. Rather than retell her story, she’s reimagined it as a board game, Rock Hard: 1977.
lead_paragraph: Jackie Fox grew up with a guitar in her hand. In 1975, when she was 15 years old, she was pulled off the dance floor at a Hollywood nightclub and recruited to join an all-girl teen rock band. The Runaways became a sensation and tossed Fox and her young bandmates into a turbulent industry that was also violent and sexist. In 1977, Fox quit the band. She never played music professionally again.

headline: Israel conducts airstrikes on West Bank, killing 3 members of Hamas military wing.
abstract: Israel hit a town in the occupied West Bank with two airstrikes on Saturday in the latest use of a once-rare tactic in the densely populated area.
lead_paragraph: Israel hit a town in the occupied West Bank with two airstrikes on Saturday in the latest use of a once-rare tactic in the densely populated area. Hamas said that three members of its military wing and six other fighters were killed in the strikes around the town of Tulkarm.

headline: Cristeta Comerford, White House Chef to 5 Presidents, Retires
abstract: Ms. Comerford, known as “Cheffie” and the first woman and person of color to serve as White House executive chef, reflects on three decades of feeding first families.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the Philippines, Cristeta Comerford helped her mother, a seamstress, cook for a household of more than a dozen. They were simple meals: rice, a vegetable and fish or chicken, sometimes with extra potatoes to stretch the meal.

headline: Who Are the Far-Right Groups Behind the U.K. Riots?
abstract: After a deadly stabbing at a children’s event in northwestern England, an array of online influencers, anti-Muslim extremists and fascist groups have stoked unrest, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Violent unrest has erupted in several towns and cities in Britain in recent days, and further disorder broke out on Saturday as far-right agitators gathered in demonstrations around the country.

headline: How JD Vance Thinks About Power
abstract: Mr. Vance has been blunt about wanting to break norms and test constitutional limits to execute his ideas: “We have to get pretty wild, pretty far out there.”
lead_paragraph: In September 2021, JD Vance offered two predictions about former President Donald J. Trump and one piece of advice.

headline: Man Who Killed 4 After Dispute Over Stimulus Check Gets 145 Years in Prison
abstract: Malik Halfacre, 28, wounded his girlfriend and killed four of her family members in Indianapolis in 2021 after a dispute with her over money, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: An Indianapolis man who killed four people, including a child, after a dispute with his girlfriend over a coronavirus stimulus check was sentenced on Friday to 145 years in prison.

headline: When Elder Care Is All in the Stepfamily
abstract: Adult children are less likely to assist an aging stepparent, studies show. A growing “step gap” in senior care worries experts.
lead_paragraph: The encounter happened years ago, but Beverly K. Brandt remembers it vividly.

headline: A Times Russia Reporter Reflects on Evan Gershkovich’s Release
abstract: Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, was freed on Thursday after 16 months in a Russian prison. Anton Troianovski, The Times’s Moscow bureau chief, shared how he covered the moment.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, multiple planes touched down in Ankara, Turkey, releasing 24 people in a seven-nation prisoner exchange that finally resolved a human drama and diplomatic standoff.

headline: “My New Go-To Brownie Recipe”
abstract: Lidey Heuck’s easy and versatile brownie recipe is already racking up stars and raves.
lead_paragraph: Brownies — especially Lidey Heuck’s brownies — are the most considerate dessert. They don’t require any special equipment or ingredients. They come together in less than an hour. They have all the textures: fudgy in the center, crispy on those corners and edges, crinkly on top. They’re very, very chocolaty. And they don’t call for room-temperature butter, a real boon to those of us who never remember to take the butter out of the fridge.

headline: Long Johns, Forensics and a Bound Russian Killer: Inside the Big Prisoner Swap
abstract: The complex choreography caught some prisoners being freed in their robes and slippers, unaware of their fates, and required forensic experts to make positive identifications.
lead_paragraph: The private jet that took off from southwest Germany on Thursday afternoon was carrying a group that may have never expected to be confined together: police officers, doctors, intelligence agents, a senior aide to Germany’s chancellor — and a convicted Russian assassin.

headline: Tulsa Creates Commission on Reparations for Race Massacre
abstract: The group will develop a plan to carry out reparations and study how they can be made to survivors of the 1921 massacre and their descendants.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Tulsa, Okla., announced on Thursday the creation of a commission tasked with developing a plan for reparations for the Tulsa Race Massacre, one of the worst racial attacks in U.S. history. The commission will study how reparations can be made to survivors of the massacre and their descendants, as well as residents of North Tulsa.

headline: If ‘The Lord of the Rings’ Is a Cautionary Tale, It Was Lost on JD Vance
abstract: He seems to have missed J.R.R. Tolkien’s main point.
lead_paragraph: It is just my luck that the week I was on vacation also happened to be one of the most consequential weeks in recent American political history. In addition to the attempt on Donald Trump’s life and the subsequent Republican National Convention, there was also President Biden’s decision to stand down from the presidential race and hand the baton to his vice president, Kamala Harris.

headline: Relive the Biggest Little Swims in Paris
abstract: Miniature swimming visualizations highlight the greatest performances in the pool at the 2024 Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Miniature swimming visualizations highlight the greatest performances in the pool at the 2024 Olympics.

headline: Is the Men’s 100 Meters Still a Can’t-Miss Olympic Moment?
abstract: Lacking star power and tense rivalries, the event was not even the most anticipated 100-meter race at the Paris Games.
lead_paragraph: Noah Lyles, the brash American with dreams of Olympic gold in Paris, rarely cedes the spotlight.

headline: Alexander Waugh, Literary Scion of a Literary Dynasty, Dies at 60
abstract: The brother, son and grandson of famous English writers, he carved out his own space as a composer, critic, columnist and historian.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Waugh, who throughout his varied career as a composer, columnist and historian bore lightly the weight of his literary inheritance — his father, Auberon, and his grandfather Evelyn were considered among the finest English writers of the 20th century — died on July 22 at his home in Milverton, in southwest England. He was 60.

headline: Simone Biles’s gold-medal-winning Yurchenko double pike, frame by frame.
abstract: Biles won her second Olympic vault title — eight years after her first in Rio — with her signature Yurchenko double pike and then a vault called a Cheng.
lead_paragraph: Simone Biles won the gold medal in the vault with her signature Yurchenko double pike and then a vault called a Cheng. The Yurchenko double pike is the hardest vault in women’s gymnastics: She does a roundoff onto the springboard, a back handspring onto the vaulting table, then catapults herself into a double back flip with her legs straight in front of her.

headline: Hearing Set to Discuss Next Steps in Trump’s Federal Election Case
abstract: The case was on hold during the appeals process, which culminated in a sweeping Supreme Court ruling on presidential immunity. Now the judge must decide which acts in the indictment qualify.
lead_paragraph: After nearly eight months in limbo, former President Donald J. Trump’s federal election interference case sprang back to life on Saturday as the judge overseeing it scheduled a hearing in Washington for Aug. 16 to discuss next steps.

headline: Shapiro Faces Scrutiny Over Sexual Harassment Complaint Against Aide
abstract: The case has attracted renewed criticism now that Josh Shapiro, the governor of Pennsylvania, is on the short list to be Kamala Harris’s running mate.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania, who is on the short list to be Kamala Harris’s running mate, is facing renewed criticism for his handling of a sexual harassment complaint against a longtime top aide.

headline: Violent Protests Grip U.K. in Wake of Knife Attack at Dance Class
abstract: Far-right groups and anti-immigration protesters have taken to the streets after a mass stabbing in the town of Southport was followed by a wave of disinformation about the identity of the attacker.
lead_paragraph: Violence erupted in several cities across the United Kingdom on Saturday amid anti-immigrant protests, as crowds of far-right activists scuffled with the police and counterprotesters in the northern cities of Liverpool, Hull and Nottingham, among other locations.

headline: Algerian Boxer at Center of Olympic Eligibility Fight Clinches Medal
abstract: Imane Khelif advanced to the semifinals, ensuring she will leave the Paris Games with at least a bronze medal.
lead_paragraph: Imane Khelif of Algeria, the boxer at the center of a controversy involving eligibility and fairness that has made the women’s boxing tournament at the Paris Olympics a cultural flashpoint, advanced to the semifinals in her weight class on Saturday.

headline: Killing of Hamas Leader Fuels More Tension Between Biden and Netanyahu
abstract: President Biden has expressed concern that the circumstances of the assassination have thrown cease-fire talks into doubt, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel rejects that idea, officials say.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: Everything You Need to Know to Make the Best Steak
abstract: In the final installment of her YouTube series, Sohla El-Waylly helps demystify how to prepare three types of beef: ground, short rib and rib-eye.
lead_paragraph: In the final installment of her New York Times Cooking YouTube series Cooking 101 Sohla El-Waylly teaches you how to cook three different types of beef — ground, thinly pounded short ribs and a rib-eye — as well as how to repurpose leftovers into a satisfying steak sandwich.

headline: Scribble, Snuggle, Soar: Making the Most of High Jump’s Downtime
abstract: The high jump often presents competitors with an abundance of down time. Two rivals fill it in very different ways.
lead_paragraph: The expected duel on Sunday for an Olympic gold medal in the women’s high jump, between Yaroslava Mahuchikh of Ukraine and Nicola Olyslagers of Australia, should be captivating. And the outcome will depend, in some part, on how they occupy their time between jumps.

headline: Anton van Dalen, Whose Art Examined an Evolving Neighborhood, Dies at 85
abstract: He traced the dramatic transformation of the Lower East Side from his building, where he lived for 50 years. He also assisted the cartoonist Saul Steinberg.
lead_paragraph: Anton van Dalen — a socially conscious artist, dedicated pigeon keeper and longtime assistant to the illustrator Saul Steinberg — lived on the Lower East Side for more than 50 years, documenting the neighborhood’s evolution from dereliction to gentrification in paintings, drawings and sculptures.

headline: Ina Jaffe, Dogged and Award-Winning NPR Reporter, Dies at 75
abstract: She spent decades covering politics and aging in America, and she was the first editor of the NPR program “Weekend Edition Saturday.”
lead_paragraph: Ina Jaffe, an NPR correspondent for roughly 40 years who was known for her unflinching approach to journalism and was the first editor of the network’s initial iteration of the weekly national news show “Weekend Edition Saturday,” died on Thursday at a nursing home in Los Angeles. She was 75.

headline: St. Lucia gets its first gold medal, thanks to the world’s fastest woman.
abstract: Julien Alfred beat Sha’Carri Richardson of the United States by 15-hundredths of a second to win St. Lucia’s first Olympic medal.
lead_paragraph: Julien Alfred, the fastest woman in the Caribbean nation of Saint Lucia, blitzed the field in the 100-meter dash Saturday night at the Paris Games to earn a far more awesome title — the fastest woman in the world.

headline: Weather, Man!
abstract: Scott Hogan and Katie Hale’s puzzle brings the heat (and humidity).
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Tracking Tropical Depression Debby
abstract: See the likely path and rainfall for Debby.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and rainfall for Debby.

headline: Lawyer Who Tried to Set Off Bomb Outside of Chinese Embassy Pleads Guilty
abstract: Christopher Rodriguez tried to detonate a bag of explosives at the embassy in Washington, D.C., by firing a rifle at it but missed, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A Florida lawyer pleaded guilty on Friday to placing a bag of explosives near the Chinese Embassy in Washington, D.C., and trying to detonate it with a rifle, according to court records.

headline: Can Harris Win Back Arab American Voters? The Door May Be Cracked Open.
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris has not strayed from President Biden on Israel policy, but she has taken a stronger tone on the suffering of Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: In Muna Jondy’s family, every topic is fair game on the WhatsApp thread.

headline: Doug Emhoff, Husband of Kamala Harris, Acknowledges Long-Ago Affair
abstract: The relationship with a teacher at his children’s elementary school occurred when he was married to his first wife, years before he met Ms. Harris.
lead_paragraph: Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris, said on Saturday that he had an extramarital affair during his first marriage, years before he met Ms. Harris.

headline: Meet the Nations That Have Never Won an Olympic Medal (and Two That Just Did)
abstract: Gold medals in track and field brought St. Lucia and Dominica into an exclusive club of nations. But for 66 other countries and territories, the wait for an Olympic medal goes on, and on, and on.
lead_paragraph: If it feels like the same countries are winning most of the Olympic medals every two years, that’s because it’s largely true.

headline: How Julien Alfred Beat Sha’Carri Richardson for Gold
abstract: The gold medalist, Julien Alfred of St. Lucia, averaged 23 miles per hour to finish the race in 10.72 seconds, 0.15 seconds ahead of Sha’Carri Richardson of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The gold medalist, Julien Alfred of St. Lucia, averaged 23 miles per hour to finish the race in 10.72 seconds, 0.15 seconds ahead of Sha’Carri Richardson of the United States.

headline: Trump Says Georgia’s Governor Is Hampering His Efforts to Win There
abstract: At a rally in Atlanta, former President Donald J. Trump said the battleground state’s governor and its top election official wanted him “to lose” and falsely claimed that he’d won the state twice.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump suggested without evidence on Saturday that Georgia’s Republican governor was hampering his efforts to win the battleground state in November, a claim that carried echoes of Mr. Trump’s attempt to overturn his defeat to President Biden there in 2020.

headline: Harris to Interview V.P. Contenders in Final Test of Chemistry
abstract: At least three candidates — Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota and Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania — are scheduled to meet with Vice President Kamala Harris on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris will meet with top candidates to serve as her vice president on Sunday, closing out her search for a running mate with a test of whether she and her potential new partner click.

headline: With Smugglers and Front Companies, China Is Skirting American A.I. Bans
abstract: The U.S. is trying to stop China from getting Nvidia microchips to advance its military. The private sector is fighting back.
lead_paragraph: In the southern Chinese city of Shenzhen, a mazelike market stretches for a half-mile, packed with stalls selling every type of electronic imaginable.

headline: The Office Ties That Bind
abstract: How guilty should you feel about leaving the boss who gave you your first big break?
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Takeaways From Our Investigation Into Banned A.I. Chips in China
abstract: The Times found an active trade in Nvidia chips in China despite U.S. national security restrictions, as well as unreported incidents of how the technology had been used to further defense research.
lead_paragraph: The United States has tried, with some success, to halt China’s progress with artificial intelligence amid concerns that the technology is helping modernize the Chinese military.

headline: War Shatters Dating Scene for Women in Ukraine
abstract: While the pursuit of love might seem secondary to dealing with the horrors and privations of the war, many Ukrainians say they need romantic relationships to help them cope.
lead_paragraph: For the past two and a half years, Kateryna Bairachna has wanted to meet someone special. But war always gets in the way.

headline: The Olympic Flame Melts Parisian Cool
abstract: There are people walking around the world’s fashion capital with fluffy cockerels on their heads. This is not normal.
lead_paragraph: Félix Lebrun has the crowd eating out of the palm of his hand. He raises his arms. They cheer. He pumps his fists. They roar. He struts around the sold-out arena, prowling the floor, basking in the noise and the adulation.

headline: Hezbollah and Israel Exchange Limited Fire Over the Border
abstract: The attack from Lebanon did not appear to be the major retaliation that Hezbollah has threatened in the wake of the Israeli assassination of a senior commander.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Hezbollah, the Iran-backed militia in Lebanon, each said on Sunday that they had fired at targets in the other’s territory, amid fears that the region was teetering toward a wider war. But the attack from Lebanon did not appear to be the major retaliation that Hezbollah has threatened in the wake of the Israeli assassination of one of its senior commanders last week.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 4, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about Linda Yaccarino, the chief executive of X, misstated the relationship between Ms. Yaccarino and Lou Paskalis, a longtime advertising executive. Mr. Paskalis said the two remain friends; he is not a former friend who has cut ties. (The error was repeated in a picture caption.)

headline: Quotation of the Day: At a Mountain Retreat, Wine, Barbecued Lamb and Talk of Global Warming
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Even if they’re having an oopsie moment, this is what they signed. We all agreed to this in Paris.”

headline: Why a Black-and-White Feminist Film Was Bigger Than ‘Barbie’ in Italy
abstract: “There’s Still Tomorrow” tells a story of a feminism that everyone can agree on and enjoy.
lead_paragraph: Last summer the hot-pink feminism of “Barbie” took more than $1 billion at box offices worldwide. In Italy, however, “Barbie” was beaten by another film, a feminist dramedy with a clear nod to Italian neorealism set in postwar Rome.

headline: ‘The Construction Worker Smiled and Lowered His Flag’
abstract: An impromptu starting line in Brooklyn, loose change on a sidewalk and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How One Harlem Block Became a Symbol of Urban Despair and Hope
abstract: In a hub for drugs and disarray, some see New York at its worst. Others see a community doing its best to help.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people walk along 125th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues each day and most do not linger. Commuters race to catch trains to Westchester, climbing up to the elevated Metro-North tracks. Others hurry down to the subway, bound for Midtown Manhattan or the Bronx.

headline: Chinese Swimming’s Olympic Haul: More Medals, More Questions
abstract: A meet overshadowed by questions about doping produced more medals, but fewer golds, than China’s swimmers won at the Tokyo Games.
lead_paragraph: After he won a bronze medal at the Paris Olympic pool on Friday night, the Chinese swimmer Wang Shun could no longer avoid the questions. He had declined to speak with journalists after his preliminary swims, but a medal meant a news conference. And a news conference meant there would be questions about Chinese doping.

headline: These Birds Have Their Own Beach. Their Human Neighbors Want In.
abstract: Every summer, a neighborhood in Queens loses its beach to piping plovers, an endangered shorebird. Some residents want it back.
lead_paragraph: Sections of the Rockaway Peninsula, a coastal strip of land in southern Queens, look like beach towns more than the concrete and steel landscape of much of New York City.

headline: Taking Note of History in the Making
abstract: Hours after the attempted assassination on former President Donald J. Trump, a Times editor outlined upcoming coverage of the event for the newspaper.
lead_paragraph: Call it the rough draft of the first draft of history.

headline: Two are dead after a stabbing attack near Tel Aviv.
abstract: Officials called the Sunday morning attack “complex and difficult,” with the victims in separate but nearby locations. The suspected attacker also died.
lead_paragraph: Two people were stabbed to death and two others were injured in Holon, Israel, on Sunday morning in what the police said was most likely a terrorist attack. The suspect was also pronounced dead.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Hamas May Emerge Battered, but Not Beaten, From Israel’s Latest Blows
abstract: The assassinations of two Hamas leaders may be a short-term setback, analysts say, not enough to prevent the group from re-emerging intact — and possibly more radicalized.
lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.

headline: At Least 4 Dead and Dozens Missing After Landslide and Flood in China
abstract: Hundreds of people were forced to leave their homes in a mountainous part of Sichuan Province. An expressway bridge collapsed amid heavy rains.
lead_paragraph: At least four people were dead and 23 others were missing on Sunday, a day after a flash flood and landslide struck the city of Kangding in a mountainous part of Sichuan Province in southwestern China. It was the latest in a recent series of deadly events in China involving extreme weather.

headline: As Hundreds of Churches Sit Empty, Some Become Hotels and Restaurants
abstract: With vaulted ceilings and stained-glass windows, the architectural features of churches have become huge draws for business owners.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Tofano was baptized, confirmed and married at the Good Shepherd Lutheran Church on Lake Opeka in Des Plaines, Ill. When she and her husband, John, visited the church last fall, however, it wasn’t to worship but rather to celebrate their 34th wedding anniversary at what the church had become: the Foxtail on the Lake, a restaurant.

headline: Has the Long Friendship of Bill Gates and Warren Buffett Reached Its Final Act?
abstract: Growing tensions between the two billionaires, over issues both substantive and stylistic, have roiled the world of philanthropy.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1991, Mary Gates, the mother of the Microsoft billionaire Bill Gates, convinced her workaholic 35-year-old son to spend the July 4 holiday at Hood Canal, a scenic, outdoorsy location about two hours from Seattle that had long been the family getaway.

headline: The Nazis Came for France Once. Not Everyone There Was Upset About It.
abstract: In “Paris 1944,” Patrick Bishop tells the story of the German occupation during World War II, with equal attention to French resisters and collaborators.
lead_paragraph: The Liberation of Paris in 1944 is an undeniably alluring subject, especially in the wake of the recent French elections. In July, a coalition of left-wing parties mounted a stunning, last-minute rebuke to what was shaping up to be the country’s first far-right government since World War II.

headline: It’s Lights Out at a Cosmic Restaurant
abstract: Palomar Observatory bids farewell to a tradition of napkin rings, cowbells and astronomical table conversation.
lead_paragraph: If you’re about to stay up all night atop a cold mountain, to squint through an eyepiece at shimmering, impossibly distant specks of light or to stare at pixels on a screen, it helps to have eaten a good meal first.

headline: Browsing Is a Pleasure in This History of the Bookstore
abstract: “People feel differently about their bookstore than they do about their grocery store or electronics store,” writes Evan Friss, in praise of a retail ritual battered by the internet.
lead_paragraph: We all know of food deserts: landscapes where there’s no access to fresh produce, just a Taco Bell or two. Less fretted over are the book barrens.

headline: Trying to Save a Concrete ‘Monument to Corruption’
abstract: An icon of socialist modernist architecture in the capital of the former Soviet republic that is now Moldova has been at the center of a tussle between corrupt developers and preservationists.
lead_paragraph: The 17-story hotel, a giant and graceless gem of socialist modernist architecture cherished by aficionados of concrete, took four years to build in the 1970s and became a proud symbol of the Soviet Union’s embrace of modernity.

headline: How Do You Topple a Strongman?
abstract: After another dubious election victory, Venezuela’s president, Nicolás Maduro, appears firmly in power. The only real potential threat, history shows, may come if his own security forces betray him.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela is in another dark moment.

headline: A Battle Over a Farm, a Mosque and the Moral High Ground
abstract: A proposed “Muslim-friendly” community near Minneapolis was called segregationist. The backlash was called Islamophobic. Who gets to define inclusion?
lead_paragraph: Butch Robinson is done. After dedicating most of his 77 years to growing sod, he just wants to sell his sprawl of green and ease his aching back into the lounge chair of a hard-earned retirement.

headline: The Life and Death of a Political Meme
abstract: Speed and novelty are two essential elements when it comes to out-memeing a political opponent.
lead_paragraph: Most memes age like milk.

headline: Debby Strengthens Into Hurricane as It Approaches Florida
abstract: It is expected to hit Florida early Monday, before moving over Georgia and South Carolina, bringing potentially catastrophic flooding.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the storm.

headline: This Is How the World’s Favorite Scent Disappears
abstract: Vanilla substitutes exist, but there is no replacing the symphonic complexities of the real thing.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of What to Eat on a Burning Planet, a series exploring bold ideas to secure our food supply. Read more about this project in a note from Eliza Barclay, Opinion’s climate editor.

headline: After My Brother’s Overdose Death, Misinformed People Added to Our Grief
abstract: You cannot overdose on fentanyl by touching a person who overdosed.
lead_paragraph: On a crisp December morning in my small Southern hometown, my mother found my brother unresponsive in his bed. She knew she was too late. His body was cold, stiff and blue. Blood had pooled on one side of his face, causing it to swell. After her initial panic and calls to my father and 911, she was alone with my brother. She instinctively did what any mother would do: She covered him with blankets and lay down with him. She wanted to hold her son one more time.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,143
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, August 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 421
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Aug. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Neil Gorsuch Has a Few Thoughts About America Today
abstract: The justice talks about everything from his indictment of the regulatory state to the rights of Native Americans.
lead_paragraph: On July 31, I met with Justice Neil Gorsuch in his chambers at the Supreme Court for a wide-ranging interview about his new book, “Over Ruled: The Human Toll of Too Much Law.” His co-author, Janie Nitze, a former clerk of his, was present for the interview as well.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Online Dating After 50 Can Be Miserable. But It’s Also Liberating.’
abstract: You know so much more about yourself and your desires when you’re older that dating apps — even with all their frustrations — can bring unanticipated pleasure.
lead_paragraph: When Maggie Jones’s marriage collapsed after 23 years, she was devastated and overwhelmed. She was in her 50s, with two jobs, two teenage daughters and one dog. She didn’t consider dating. She had no time, no emotional energy. But then a year passed. One daughter was off at college, the other increasingly independent. After several more months went by, she started to feel a sliver of curiosity about what kind of men were out there and how it would feel to date again. The last time she dated was 25 years ago, and even then, she fell into relationships mostly with guys from high school, college, parties, work. Now every man she knew was either married, too young, too old or otherwise not a good fit.

headline: In Kamala Harris’s Blackness, I See My Own
abstract: Multiracial people have long been a Rorschach test: We bear the anxiety, rage and confusion that others feel about the amorphous construction we call race.
lead_paragraph: We seem to be beginning yet another season of a perennially popular American spectacle, “How Much Is That Mulatto in the Window?” I frequently think that, after 400 years, this show is about to go off the air — jump the shark, as it were. But then it returns, with ever more absurd plot lines. Yet even as a so-called mulatto myself, I can’t stop watching.

headline: A Doping Scandal
abstract: How the Olympic drug testing system is supposed to function — and why it may not be working.
lead_paragraph: When you sit down to watch the Olympics, you expect that you’re seeing the world’s best athletes competing on a level playing field.

headline: At Least 70 Dead as Bangladesh Protests Grow; Curfew Is Reinstated
abstract: Expanded student protests this weekend, after more than 200 people were killed in a government crackdown in July, have plunged the country into a particularly dangerous phase.
lead_paragraph: At least 70 people were killed in clashes between security forces and protesters on Sunday in Bangladesh, as the country’s leaders imposed a new curfew and internet restrictions to try to quell a growing antigovernment movement.

headline: Prime Minister Condemns ‘Far-Right Thuggery’ as Riots Grip U.K.
abstract: Protests escalated over the weekend in towns and cities in England and Northern Ireland, with dozens arrested and more demonstrations unfolding on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Anti-immigration rioters attacked a hotel in the town of Rotherham in northern England on Sunday, breaking windows and appearing to set fires at a hotel that has housed asylum seekers, as riots continued in Britain.

headline: The Soul of Soil
abstract: The dirt beneath our feet is a bigger, bolder world than you think.
lead_paragraph: When my partner and I bought our home in Portland, Ore., four years ago, we immediately began designing our dream garden, intending to replace a derelict grass lawn with ample beds of lush, long-blooming perennials. We soon discovered, however, that our soil was unyielding, clay-heavy and strewed with rubble. In previous, much tinier gardens, I’d circumvented such difficulties with a few bags of high-quality soil from the nursery. Replacing this vastly greater quantity of dirt was neither practical nor financially feasible. Instead, I resolved to remediate what we already had.

headline: Golf Cart Politics: Florida Retirees Flaunt Loyalties to Trump and Harris
abstract: In The Villages, Florida’s retirement mecca, pro-Trump residents have been galvanized by a surprising showing of support for Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: The golf carts lined up by the hundreds, festooned for Trump fandom: a teddy bear with orange hair and a red tie. A surprisingly realistic Trump mask. A Trump rubber duck. An inflatable Trump tube, depicting his mouth open and fists pumped in the air.

headline: Netanyahu Says Israel Was Already in a ‘War Against Iran’s Evil Axis’
abstract: A number of international airlines have suspended flights to and from Israel pending expected retaliation against the country by Iran and its Lebanese proxy, Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: Israel went into a new workweek in a state of deep uncertainty on Sunday, with the potential for attacks by Iran and the militant groups it supports already causing disruptions for many.

headline: Here’s Where Debby’s Rains Are Going Next
abstract: Forecasters are warning of serious flooding across the Southeast this week as the storm moves along the coast.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the storm.

headline: KBBQ to make ASAP
abstract: Eric Kim’s new recipe for Korean BBQ steak relies on a “pitch-perfect” marinade, “salty, sweet and savory in just the right ways.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Korean barbecue is one of the great restaurant meals, a feast delivered in small plates of banchan, piles of lettuce and saucers of ssamjang and sesame oil, alongside large platters of raw, marinated meat for the grill in the center of the table.

headline: Ukraine Has Received F-16 Fighter Jets, Zelensky Says
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky did not say whether the jets had already flown combat missions. A shortage of trained pilots and a limited number of jets will constrain their immediate impact.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said on Sunday that his military had received a first batch of F-16 fighter jets. The long-awaited arrival of the Western-supplied jets should bolster the country’s defenses, although Kyiv appears to have received too few of them so far to have an immediate impact on the battlefield.

headline: Behind the Biggest Prisoner Swap Since the Cold War
abstract: The recent prisoner exchange between Russia and the U.S. — the biggest and most complex since the Cold War — was a diplomatic chess game that required patience and creativity. Mark Mazzetti, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains. An earlier version of a map used in this video referred incorrectly to the status of Crimea by including it as part of Russia. Russia seized the peninsula in 2014, and most countries do not recognize Crimea as Russian territory.
lead_paragraph: The recent prisoner exchange between Russia and the U.S. — the biggest and most complex since the Cold War — was a diplomatic chess game that required patience and creativity. Mark Mazzetti, an investigative reporter for The New York Times, explains. An earlier version of a map used in this video referred incorrectly to the status of Crimea by including it as part of Russia. Russia seized the peninsula in 2014, and most countries do not recognize Crimea as Russian territory.

headline: Harris’s Brother-in-Law, a Corporate Executive, Emerges as a Close Adviser
abstract: Tony West, the top lawyer for Uber, is weighing in on polling and running mates. His presence has made some liberals anxious.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris had a secret weapon on hand as she worked the phones in the hours after President Biden dropped his re-election bid and endorsed her.

headline: In His Stand-Up Special, Joe Rogan Plays Dumb
abstract: On his podcast, Rogan indulges his own obsessions and eccentricities. But in “Burn the Boats,” his Netflix comedy special, contempt for the crowd is a theme.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, Joe Rogan started glitching.

headline: Review: Death Drives a New ‘Tristan’ at Wagner’s Festival
abstract: Thorleifur Orn Arnarsson’s production of “Tristan und Isolde” at the Bayreuth Festival in Germany is an excellently conducted puzzle of grim symbols.
lead_paragraph: Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” is not a love story. It’s a death story.

headline: Inside the Obama-Shapiro Relationship
abstract: The speaking style of Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania, a potential vice presidential pick, can sound suspiciously similar to President Obama’s. But the real connection between the two men is deeper than commonly known.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, a Pennsylvania state representative named Josh Shapiro broke with much of the Democratic establishment to back for president a first-term senator from Illinois named Barack Obama.

headline: Israeli Strike on Gaza Shelter Kills at Least 30 and Injures Dozens
abstract: An Israeli airstrike in Gaza City killed at least 30 people, according to a Palestinian emergency agency and local media outlets. Israel said it targeted Hamas “command and control centers.”
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike on a school functioning as a shelter in Gaza City killed at least 30 people and injured dozens more on Sunday, according to the Palestinian emergency response agency in Gaza and Palestinian news outlets. It was the third attack on a school in the last four days.

headline: How Two Russian Spies Went Deep Undercover With Their Children
abstract: A couple planted as sleeper spies in Slovenia posed as an Argentine art dealer and an entrepreneur. They were caught in December 2022 and sent to Moscow in a sweeping prisoner exchange last week.
lead_paragraph: Darja Stefancic, a painter in Slovenia known for technicolor landscapes, thought it strange when an obscure online art gallery run by a woman from Argentina contacted her out of the blue and asked her to join its thin roster of artists.

headline: A weekend ride through Paris. Prizes for the first three finishers.
abstract: The Olympic road cycling events, open for all to watch, end in a sprint to the finish.
lead_paragraph: They rode out of Paris in the morning, glided past plowed fields and under tall trees and then returned to the capital in the afternoon. That was where the Olympics’ road cycling races were always going to be decided: after the riders ascended the cobblestoned streets of Monnmartre, after they held their nerve on the way back down, after a last dash to the finish in the shadow of the Eiffel Tower.

headline: What’s Rattling Trump: The Size of Harris’s Crowds
abstract: The numbers game is everything to Donald J. Trump. Vice President Kamala Harris’s first big rally appears to have gotten under his skin.
lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump walked onto the stage at his rally in Atlanta on Saturday, fog machines shot white plumes of smoke into the air, heralding his arrival.

headline: Israeli Strike Kills Dozens at Gaza Shelter
abstract: An Israeli airstrike on a school functioning as a shelter in Gaza City killed at least 30 people, according to a Palestinian emergency agency and local media outlets.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike on a school functioning as a shelter in Gaza City killed at least 30 people, according to a Palestinian emergency agency and local media outlets.

headline: Biden’s Proposed Supreme Court Reforms
abstract: The effort is “100 percent politically motivated,” a reader writes; others support the proposals. Also: Solitary confinement; table tennis; interest rates.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kansas Man Who Stole Jackie Robinson Statue Is Sentenced to Prison
abstract: Ricky Alderete was sentenced to a total of 15 years, including 18 months for the theft, and time in prison on other charges.
lead_paragraph: A man who stole and destroyed a statue of Jackie Robinson that stood outside a youth baseball field in Wichita, Kan., was sentenced to a total of 15 years in prison on theft and other charges on Friday.

headline: Monday Briefing: A Tense Wait in Israel
abstract: Plus, philanthropy with a dark twist.

headline: Oysters and Martinis at Rashid Johnson’s Pool Party in The Hamptons
abstract: The artist, and his wife, Sheree Hovsepian, hosted a party at their East Hampton home on Saturday to benefit Creative Time, a public art nonprofit that is celebrating its 50th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: On a quiet road in East Hampton, N.Y., on Saturday evening, cars pulled up outside the artist Rashid Johnson’s home as a pool party kicked off inside the property. Exiting the cars, handing off keys to valets, was a procession of art-world players, philanthropists and socialites wearing sun hats.

headline: After a photo finish, Noah Lyles waits, and waits, and then claims the title of world’s fastest man.
abstract: Noah Lyles came from behind to beat out Kishane Thompson of Jamaica.
lead_paragraph: The race to determine the fastest man in the world lasted fewer than 10 seconds. It took longer than that to determine the winner.

headline: How the 9/11 Plea Deal Came Undone
abstract: A case that had mostly drifted from public consciousness in 12 years of proceedings is back in the spotlight and no closer to trial.
lead_paragraph: In the space of three days last week, the Sept. 11 case was rocked by two decisions that stunned victims’ families and jolted a political debate.

headline: Shares the Same View
abstract: Andy Walker makes his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Admits He Left a Dead Bear in Central Park
abstract: Mr. Kennedy, an independent presidential candidate, confessed to dropping off the bear cub 10 years ago and making it appear that a bike had hit the animal.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the independent presidential candidate, confessed on Sunday that he had left a dead bear cub in Central Park in Manhattan in 2014 because he thought it would be “amusing.”

headline: 5-Year-Old Killed After Bounce House Goes Airborne in Maryland
abstract: Children were inside the play structure at a baseball game when it was carried 15 to 20 feet in the air by the wind. One child died and another was injured.
lead_paragraph: A 5-year-old boy was killed at a professional baseball game in Maryland on Friday after a bounce house was picked up by a wind gust while children were inside of it, the authorities said.

headline: In a Corner of Florida, a Gathering Storm Stirs Familiar Feelings
abstract: Many on the state’s northwestern coast felt they knew what to expect from Debby, which strengthened into a hurricane Sunday night, after a much stronger storm hit the area last year.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the storm.

headline: Jimmy Carter Said to Have Plans to Vote for Kamala Harris
abstract: The former president, whose 100th birthday is Oct. 1, seems to have found some new motivation in the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: Former President Jimmy Carter, who has been in hospice care for more than 17 months, has said that he has every intention of voting for Vice President Kamala Harris in the fall, according to his family.

headline: Greetings, People of Earth
abstract: Humans encounter nonhuman intelligences and try to make sense of them.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s episode:

headline: Belgian Triathlon Team Drops Out After Athlete Falls Sick
abstract: The athlete, Claire Michel, who swam in the Seine River during the women’s triathlon last week, was taken to a clinic in the Olympic Village on Sunday for treatment.
lead_paragraph: Belgium’s triathlon mixed relay team has withdrawn from Monday’s event after one of its athletes who swam in the Seine River on Wednesday became ill, the team said Sunday.
