headline: How Noah Lyles Won the Men’s 100-Meter Gold by a Fraction
abstract: Noah Lyles of the United States beat Jamaica’s Kishane Thompson by five-thousandths of a second to win gold in the 100-meter final.
lead_paragraph: Noah Lyles of the United States beat Jamaica’s Kishane Thompson by five-thousandths of a second to win gold in the 100-meter final.

headline: Harris Faces Party Divisions as She Chooses a Running Mate
abstract: The vice president conducted interviews with potential candidates over the weekend and has fielded concerns from donors and activists over the choice.
lead_paragraph: The competitive, divisive primary that many Democrats long wanted to avoid has arrived anyway — playing out largely behind closed doors in a fight over the bottom of the ticket.

headline: The Willful Amnesia Behind Trump’s Attacks on Harris’s Identity
abstract: Suggesting that there is something contrived about a mixed-race person identifying as Black assumes that the choice wasn’t already made for her.
lead_paragraph: When I was a child, my dad sat my older sister and me down in our living room and explained to us the rules of race in America. A Black man born into a Mississippi where Black boys could be lynched for merely standing too close to a white woman, he met my white mom in 1972. That was just a few years after the Supreme Court in Loving v. Virginia finally struck down 300 years’ worth of laws prohibiting people who descended from slavery from marrying people whose ancestors had enslaved them. In other words, Dad held no illusions about how race worked in our society and felt it was his duty as a parent to prepare us. Our mother might be white, he told us, but in this country, that fact was irrelevant to how we would be seen and treated. She might be white, but we were Black.

headline: Hurricane Debby Barrels Toward Florida
abstract: Hurricane Debby brought lashing winds and rain to Florida’s Big Bend coast as it approached from the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Debby brought lashing winds and rain to Florida’s Big Bend coast as it approached from the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’ Season 2 Finale Recap: Hold Your Fire
abstract: There may be time yet to avoid mass burning and bloodshed, but it is running out very quick.
lead_paragraph: Chekhov warned writers against placing just one gun on the mantel without firing it by the end, let alone a dozen. In its second season finale, “House of the Dragon” calls Chekhov’s bluff 11 times over.

headline: Japan Needs Foreign Workers. It’s Just Not Sure It Wants Them to Stay.
abstract: Foreign employees have become much more visible in Japan. But policies designed only for short-term stays may hurt the country in the global competition for labor.
lead_paragraph: Ngu Thazin wanted to leave her war-torn country for a better future. She set her sights on Japan.

headline: Declaring ‘Crisis,’ South Korean Firms Tell Managers to Work 6 Days a Week
abstract: The move by some influential companies has raised concerns about work-life balance in a country where long hours at the office are common.
lead_paragraph: “Back in the day,” said Lim Hyung-kyu, a retired Samsung Electronics executive now in his 70s, “my weeks were Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Friday, Friday.”

headline: Female Gymnasts Have to Dance. What if the Sport Actually Valued It?
abstract: Olympic gymnastics would be more enjoyable on TV and in the arena if choreography were less of an afterthought, our critic writes.
lead_paragraph: Women’s artistic gymnastics may be one of the few Olympic events to feature music and choreography, but it doesn’t mean the sport takes it truly seriously. In 2016, in the middle of the Rio Games, the specialist publication Dance Magazine declared that today’s floor routines “insult dance.”

headline: LeBron James Faces the Basketball World He Helped to Create
abstract: James is the sport’s global ambassador, and at the Olympics, he is playing in front of — and against — people who grew up dreaming of seeing him in person.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James lowered himself into a cold tub the size of a large Jacuzzi at a practice facility at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, last month.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Kamala Harris’s search for a running mate.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 100 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: How Norway Became a Powerhouse for All Seasons
abstract: With money from an oil boom, Norway, a force at the Winter Olympics for generations, is now churning out elite performers in track, soccer and other sports, too.
lead_paragraph: As the runners hit the penultimate bend, the racing pulse of the music starts to beat faster. The choice, and the timing, are perfect: Darude’s now semi-ancient trance track “Sandstorm.” But very few of the 15,000 in attendance can hear any of it.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Pretty Woman’ and ‘Don’t Forget the Lyrics!’
abstract: HBO airs the classic rom-com. And the competitive singing show broadcasts its season finale.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Aug. 5 to Aug. 11. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Fears of Slowing U.S. Growth Jolt Markets Around the World
abstract: A rout that began in Asia continued in Europe, and U.S. stocks fell sharply. Some investors said the sell-off was an overdue pullback.
lead_paragraph: Anxiety over a slowdown in the U.S. economy intensified on Monday, with a retreat in markets that began last week snowballing into a global rout.The turmoil was the latest example of how distinct economic forces can ricochet across markets, forcing down company stock prices and erasing billions of dollars in value. In this case, a rapidly rising yen over the past week had disrupted the flow of global capital, prompting a pullback from some popular investments.But the sell-off quickly expanded into a more widespread panic that the Federal Reserve may have waited too long to start cutting interest rates, threatening the strength of the U.S. economy.

headline: Samsung Employees Return to Work After Strike Fails to Win Concessions
abstract: The indefinite strike, the first in the electronics company’s history, comprised only a sliver of its labor force and lasted less than a month.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of unionized workers at Samsung Electronics in South Korea, who had declared an indefinite strike last month, had returned to work by Monday after failing to win concessions from the global tech giant.

headline: Word of the Day: labyrinthine
abstract: This word has appeared in 61 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word labyrinthine has appeared in 61 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 11 in “At This Photography Festival, the Camera Points Below the Surface” by Emily LaBarge:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: MS-13 Killed Her Sister. That Was Just the Beginning of Her Pain.
abstract: After Kelsey Cuevas lost her sister Kayla, a driver ran over their mother at the site of Kayla’s memorial. The driver is set to be sentenced to probation.
lead_paragraph: The cycle of violence, retribution and attempts at justice transfixed Long Island for years.

headline: He Took His 68-Year-Old Secret to Court and Finally Confronted His Ghost
abstract: Robin Davis spent a long career in finance and philanthropy haunted by what had happened to him as a boy. Could an unusual trial on Long Island help him find peace?
lead_paragraph: The 79-year-old man sat silently in the back of the courtroom on Long Island, 20 miles from his home in Queens. He wore a dark suit over his slim frame, as if back at his old offices in Manhattan’s financial corridors, at Merrill Lynch and Bank of America and other blue-chip firms.

headline: How 2024 Became the Zoom Election
abstract: Hastily assembled mega-rallies conducted over Zoom are raising millions to elect Kamala Harris, giving the videoconferencing app an unexpected role in this year’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: A month ago, if you had asked me which tech platforms would play a major role in the 2024 presidential campaign, I might have said TikTok or Facebook. I might have said YouTube. I may have even theorized that X would still play a role despite its hard-right turn under Elon Musk’s ownership.

headline: This N.Y.C. Tourist Hub Has Become Trash-Strewn Chaos for Everyone
abstract: Eighth Avenue in Manhattan connects Broadway’s theaters to the Knicks at Madison Square Garden. But it is also crowded, dirty and sometimes dangerous.
lead_paragraph: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

headline: Quotation of the Day: YouTube Tried to Be Netflix. It Found Success as Itself.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I’ll search for ‘cat videos long.’ As long as it’s over three hours, I hit play.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 5, 2024
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Monday, Aug. 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: I Want to Free My Mother’s Killer From Death Row
abstract: We’re good at convicting and punishing people, but we need to learn how to forgive.
lead_paragraph: We’re good at convicting and punishing people, but we need to learn how to forgive.

headline: As Unrest in Bangladesh Intensifies, All Eyes Are on the Army
abstract: The military has a history of coups and counter coups. But in this showdown, it has seemed uncomfortable with the police crackdown on protesters.
lead_paragraph: With Bangladesh’s security forces seemingly on a deadly collision course with angry protesters after a crackdown on Sunday, eyes were turning to the country’s powerful military establishment to see how it might respond.

headline: A Poet Who Considers Timeless Topics, and Finds Ways to Make Them New
abstract: In his latest collection, the Pulitzer winner Carl Phillips relies on sinuous language to evoke love, heartache and the passing of the years.
lead_paragraph: Some poets seek topics never before explored. Others look around and see what seems constant, from antiquity to today: autumn and winter; aging and death; erotic desire, and our regret if it fades.

headline: How Much Alcohol Is Too Much for a Driver?
abstract: Experts argue the U.S. drunk-driving limit is too high.
lead_paragraph: In late 2018, Utah lowered its drunk-driving limit from a B.A.C. (blood-alcohol content) of .08 to .05.

headline: If You Can Do It, You Can Do It at Night
abstract: Travel adventures, from goat hikes to snorkeling, get even better when they’re done under the stars.
lead_paragraph: Hiking and kayaking in the daytime? Fun and invigorating. But under a full moon, those activities can be transcendent. Gazing at blue skies is pleasant — but rather ordinary. Looking up at the night sky, on the other hand, feels as though deep mysteries may be revealed.

headline: The Latest Frontier in Housing Inequity? Pet Friendliness.
abstract: For renters, pet fees and breed and size restrictions make it hard to keep their families together in a tough market. Some lawmakers are listening.
lead_paragraph: Scan the ads for luxury apartments — private dog parks! yappy hours! — and it seems like a golden age for renters with pets.

headline: I Want to Free My Mother’s Killer From Death Row
abstract: We’re good at convicting and punishing people, but we need to learn how to forgive.
lead_paragraph: Your mother is kidnapped from her home and brutally murdered, her body dumped in the woods off a quiet country road. The authorities find a suspect, tell you they’re going to seek the death penalty and ask you if you’re OK with that. How would you react? What would you do?

headline: The Choreographer Bringing Hope to the Stage and Beyond
abstract: Rachid Ouramdane, who presented a major new dance as part of the Cultural Olympiad, directs the Théâtre National de Chaillot in Paris. How does he do it all?
lead_paragraph: Beneath the soaring dome of the Panthéon, performers, dressed in black, spilled across a vast stage. Suddenly their bodies stopped and with it, the breeze in the air. Now still as sculptures, they began to shift their heads, gradually locking eyes with one another and with members of an audience that surrounded them on three sides.

headline: Does an Artist Ever Work Alone?
abstract: Despite the Romantic notion of a solitary genius, most art is the result of collaboration.
lead_paragraph: All of us love the idea of the artist alone: in her studio, painting; at her desk, writing; in her atelier, draping.

headline: How Many People Does It Take to Make a Potato Pizza?
abstract: It’s more than you think. (Especially if you include the cheese makers.)
lead_paragraph: One evening in July 2018, at the end of a long dinner service at Blue Hill at Stone Barns, the influential farm-to-table restaurant in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., less than 30 miles north of New York City, a hungry Dan Barber grabbed a boiled potato off a shelf in the back of the kitchen. This was no mere potato, though, but an experiment: a trial variety named NY162 that he had never tasted before. “I was on the way out to my car when I took a bite, and I stopped dead,” says the 54-year-old chef. It had the sweetness of a plantain and the texture of a yam, and it propelled him back into the kitchen to tell the cooks to try it, too.

headline: A Plant-Based Chair, Three Years in the Making
abstract: Humberto Campana wanted to create furniture from a Brazilian “golden grass.” But first, he would have to wait for the harvest.
lead_paragraph: While on a 2014 trip to Jalapão, a region in the central Brazilian state of Tocantins that’s known for its unlikely combination of springs and sand dunes, the furniture designer Humberto Campana, 71, purchased about 30 disks wound from the golden-hued stems of capim dourado, a grasslike plant native to the area. The disks, which are sometimes used as potholders, sat in his São Paulo studio for five years until he wondered whether they could be joined to make a kind of tapestry that could in turn become a chair. That chair ended up with a bowl-like seat fashioned from a lattice of double-sided circles — sheepskin cutouts in the front and capim dourado disks in the back — though arriving at the finished prototype took another nine months of tinkering.

headline: A Performance Piece That Required a Fencing Coach and a Sex Doll Maker
abstract: The artist Miles Greenberg’s latest show lasted for nine hours. It took much longer to come together.
lead_paragraph: From noon to 9 on a Wednesday this past June, the Canadian artist Miles Greenberg, 26, stood in Walker Court at the Art Gallery of Ontario in Toronto and sliced the air with swords and daggers. Instead of dueling a human opponent, he squared off against a camera held by a robotic arm that countered and recorded his movements. All around him, strewn across the mirrored floor, were nine uncanny silicone sculptures of his likeness positioned as if they’d already been slain. Occasionally the artist stabbed one of his clones, picking up its weapon before reassuming his position in front of the camera.

headline: Everyone Who Made This Happen: Meet the Many People It Takes to Produce One Thing
abstract: The act of creation is rarely a solo affair. Here are five outsize teams behind projects ranging from a performance piece to a new pizza.
lead_paragraph: Even works of art that we think of as coming from the minds of lone creative geniuses were group efforts: Michelangelo, for example, recruited some 11 painters to assist him with the Sistine Chapel. The contemporary land artist Michael Heizer, who makes sculptures out of dirt, rocks and negative space in the Nevada desert, and whom The Times once called “art’s last, lonely cowboy,” has relied on a crew of construction workers to help execute his vision. Still, it’s only in the past few decades that attitudes around labor and the power of collectivism have shifted, making artists not only quicker to collaborate but also to give credit where credit is due. Reflecting on “Womanhouse,” the multiroom feminist art installation that debuted in Los Angeles in 1972 and was created by Judy Chicago, Miriam Schapiro and over 20 California Institute of the Arts students and local artists, Schapiro told the writer Judith E. Stein, “Collaboration was taking place right then and there in my brain and liberating me from the idea of being solitary.”

headline: Will We Have to Pump the Great Lakes to California to Feed the Nation?
abstract: Will We Have to Pump the Great Lakes to California to Feed the Nation?
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of What to Eat on a Burning Planet, a series exploring bold ideas to secure our food supply. Read more about this project in a note from Eliza Barclay, Opinion’s climate editor.

headline: Is There Anywhere You Can’t Wear a Baseball Cap?
abstract: A reader reflects on the proliferation of baseball caps in men’s fashion. Our critic offers an explanation.
lead_paragraph: It is true, the baseball cap has become such a ubiquitous item of clothing that the British milliner Stephen Jones told me they were “the tiara of America.” But it was not always thus.

headline: The People Reimagining ‘Spirited Away’ With Puppets
abstract: Hayao Miyazaki’s classic film is now onstage, brought to life with elements including a nearly 20-foot-long dragon.
lead_paragraph: There was never any doubt as to whether the director John Caird’s stage adaptation of “Spirited Away” would incorporate puppets. They were part of his original pitch to Hayao Miyazaki, the writer and director of the beloved 2001 animated film, in which the heroine, Chihiro, and her parents are transported to another world populated by a colorful cast of Japanese spirits and gods. The questions were, which characters should be puppets, and how would they look and work? Toby Olié, 39, the show’s puppetry designer and director, sketched some initial ideas. Then, in 2021, he and Caird; Caird’s co-adapter and wife, Maoko Imai; the set designer Jon Bausor; and six performer-puppeteers held a two-week workshop in a church hall in East London, during which they explored staging with foam and cardboard prototypes.

headline: Why It Took 30 People to Make This Tote Bag
abstract: Inspired by traditional basket weaving, the Bottega Veneta accessory features leather instead of cane.
lead_paragraph: When Matthieu Blazy was named the creative director of Bottega Veneta in 2021, he urged his staff to find innovative ways of working with leather. This meant looking past the intrecciato, the 58-year-old brand’s trademark technique of braiding flat strips of leather, often into a slanted grid pattern. One of their responses was the Kalimero bucket bag, which is made, without a single stitch, by weaving a single piece of leather around a wood block and was featured in the opening look of Blazy’s first runway presentation three months later. Last summer, after seeing a picture of Sicilian basketry in a book about the island’s craft traditions, the French Belgian designer, 40, issued an updated challenge: to fuse the house’s methods with those of ancestral basket weaving. If his team could make leather resemble denim — or silk or flannel — Blazy, who delights in trompe l’oeil, thought, why not cane, willow or other plant materials?

headline: It’s a Big Day for a Very Important Oyster
abstract: On National Oyster Day, the River Project celebrates a colossal oyster in New York Harbor.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday, and it’s National Oyster Day. We’ll celebrate by checking in on someone who can tell us a lot about the state of oysters in New York Harbor — without saying a word. We’ll also find out why congregants in a church in the East Village are shouting “Earthalujah!”

headline: Why ‘The Great Gatsby’ and Other Broadway Shows Are Turning to Influencers
abstract: To reach younger and more diverse audiences, Broadway shows are increasingly looking to Instagram and TikTok creators.
lead_paragraph: On a 91-degree day in June, a group of 20- and 30-somethings in sundresses and Bermuda shorts was navigating a dimly lit cocktail lounge whose air-conditioning was on the fritz.

headline: Artists and Activists Both Have a Role. But Not the Same One.
abstract: As the literary world is roiled by fights over politics and war, are we losing sight of the writer’s purpose?
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, I was a public-affairs officer in the Marine Corps, a public-relations guy for the military, tasked with “telling the Marine Corps story” and providing accurate information about military operations to maintain the trust of the American people. We weren’t propagandists — we told the truth, and in Iraq we welcomed plenty of embedded reporters who we knew would write extremely skeptical articles on the progress of the war — but there were fairly tight borders around what the military thought the American people needed to know.

headline: The Church Preached Love and Tolerance. Then Racial Politics Tore It Apart.
abstract: In her new book, the Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist Eliza Griswold chronicles the fate of an idealistic congregation fractured by internal divisions.
lead_paragraph: When I picked up Eliza Griswold’s new book, “Circle of Hope,” I thought I was going to be reading a deeply researched story about a unique Philadelphia church. Instead, I found myself reading a story that countless millions of Americans might instantly relate to — about how political disagreements can fracture the closest friendships and break the best institutions.

headline: A Year After a Devastating Fire, Lahaina Is Ready to Rebuild. But How?
abstract: Much of the fire-ravaged community on the island of Maui has been cleared of debris. But for a town steeped in history, there are thorny questions about what the future should look like.
lead_paragraph: Across nine generations, Archie Kalepa’s family has seen the waterfront in Lahaina, a town on the island of Maui, undergo repeated transformation.

headline: This Sandwich Is So Corporate Chain, but So Good
abstract: A simple French dip sandwich from the Hillstone restaurant group represents a certain kind of nice dining.
lead_paragraph: Outside Houston’s, in Pasadena, Calif., a woman in a cream-colored poplin skirt that skimmed the concrete explained the concept of a tradwife to her mother while they waited for a table. Men in perforated polo shirts scrolled on their phones. Just past the koi pond, behind gleaming kitchen windows, cooks shaped bread dough engineered for the restaurant’s relentless output of French dips.

headline: My New Neighbor Has Eight Legs and a Knack for Design
abstract: What we don’t know about the natural world always far exceeds what we do.
lead_paragraph: August is spider season. The orb-weaver spiders in my yard spend winter tucked away in the egg sacs their mothers made for them in autumn. Come springtime, the spiderlings climb out of their egg sacs and promptly disappear. Lots of creatures will eat a baby spider, so early summer is for hiding. By late summer, those who managed to survive are all grown up and ready to commence their important spider work.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’: 5 Questions as We Look Ahead to Season 3
abstract: Where is that wagon going? And who were those unfamiliar dragons? The Season 2 finale left viewers with many cliffhangers and much to ponder.
lead_paragraph: The Season 2 finale of “House of the Dragon,” which aired Sunday on HBO, provided a surprising amount of new information. But it stirred up a lot of new questions, too. Characters with magical abilities showed their hands. One missing major character reappeared, while others began to make their exits. And a few new dragons were spotted along the way.

headline: A Bright New Voice in Fiction, With a Knack for Dark Turns
abstract: Zach Williams makes his impressive debut with an unnerving and surreal collection of stories.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t have to be very smart to write a review of a book of short stories,” John Edgar Wideman wrote in a short story of his own. “All you need to say is that some stories in the book are better than others.”

headline: Flavor Flav Wants You to Watch More Water Polo
abstract: The rapper has become a self-appointed hype man and benefactor to the U.S. women’s team in Paris. He plans to keep the poolside party going into 2028.
lead_paragraph: As the robed members of the U.S. women’s water polo team stood single file at the pool’s edge before their match against Italy at the Paris Olympics, the rapper Flavor Flav stood directly across from them, clapping while the announcer at the Aquatics Centre in St.-Denis, France, listed the American players’ names one by one. He made a heart gesture with his hands.

headline: $1.6 Million Homes in California
abstract: A midcentury-modern home in Pasadena, a Mediterranean-style house in Albany and a three-bedroom retreat in Monterey.
lead_paragraph: A midcentury architect named Lawrence Test designed this house for a plywood company executive, using a notable amount of plywood in its construction. The grounds were designed by Garrett Eckbo, a pioneer of modern landscape design. The home, which has been owned by the same family for five decades, is about five minutes from the Rose Bowl and the hiking trails of Upper Arroyo Park.

headline: An 18th-Century Phenom Arrives at Lincoln Center
abstract: The Festival Orchestra of Lincoln Center will play Marianna Martines’s Symphony in C, a milestone for a composer whose music mostly fell silent after her death.
lead_paragraph: The composer Marianna Martines grew up in Vienna when the city was teeming with towering figures in classical music. Haydn was her neighbor and teacher. Mozart sought her out as a duet partner.

headline: Kamala Harris Surprises Everyone
abstract: Has everything totally switched?
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I have to make a confession: Kamala Harris had a much stronger start than I expected. She appears competent and in command, and she is connecting to voters — everything she wasn’t when she ran for president five years ago. I gather you’re not surprised.

headline: Population Growth Isn’t a Progressive Issue. It Should Be.
abstract: There’s more to the issue than what JD Vance says.
lead_paragraph: JD Vance has repeatedly said that Americans aren’t having enough children. Other right-wing figures agree with him. Elon Musk, broadening the complaint, has said that “population collapse due to low birthrates is a much bigger risk to civilization than global warming.”

headline: In Missouri, Cori Bush Fights for Survival Against an AIPAC-Backed Democrat
abstract: The ultraliberal congresswoman and member of the “squad” is facing a primary on Tuesday against Wesley Bell, a progressive prosecutor whose campaign has been financed by pro-Israel groups.
lead_paragraph: Days before she was set to face a challenger backed by America’s largest pro-Israel lobby in an expensive and contentious Democratic primary, Representative Cori Bush of Missouri doubled down on the stance that has put her job in peril.

headline: Traffic Stop Data Can Shape Policy. It’s Often Missing.
abstract: Areas with good data often have policy debates that are not possible in places with poor data.
lead_paragraph: Last Monday, we published a data-driven look at the decline of traffic stops in America. The cities and states we highlighted weren’t necessarily those with the steepest declines in traffic enforcement nationally — they were places with steep declines that data enabled us to see.

headline: Britain’s Violent Riots: What We Know
abstract: Officials had braced for more unrest on Wednesday, but the night’s anti-immigration protests were smaller, with counterprotesters dominating the streets instead.
lead_paragraph: After days of violent rioting set off by disinformation around a deadly stabbing rampage, the authorities in Britain had been bracing for more unrest on Wednesday. But by nightfall, large-scale anti-immigration demonstrations had not materialized, and only a few arrests had been made nationwide.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,144
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, August 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Democrats Divided Over V.P. Field, and Israel Braces for Retaliation
abstract: Plus, your Olympics weekend wrap-up.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Connections Companion No. 422
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Aug. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: She Used to Be Friends With JD Vance
abstract: Why a friend of Donald Trump’s running mate from law school decided to speak out against him.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, and Sofia Nelson, his transgender classmate at Yale Law School, forged a bond that lasted a decade. In 2021, Mr. Vance’s support for an Arkansas ban on gender-affirming care for minors led to their falling out. Sofia Nelson, now a public defender in Detroit, discussed Mr. Vance’s pivot, politically and personally, with The Times.

headline: One Small Slip Stalls Biles’s Medal Run in Paris
abstract: Four of the eight gymnasts fell off the beam, including Simone Biles and Sunisa Lee, the other American in the event. Alice D’Amato of Italy won the gold medal.
lead_paragraph: After winning three gold medals in her first three events at the Paris Games, Simone Biles was expected to add to that haul on Monday by finishing in the top three on the balance beam — an event she earned bronze on in the Tokyo and Rio Games.

headline: America’s High Drunk-Driving Limit
abstract: We explore why it matters and whether the limit might change.
lead_paragraph: Drunk driving is illegal almost everywhere. But what counts as drunk? Nations answer that question differently. Most say you can’t get behind the wheel when the concentration of alcohol in your blood (commonly known as B.A.C.) is 0.05 percent or more.

headline: Elon Musk Revives Lawsuit Against OpenAI and Sam Altman
abstract: The Tesla chief executive has renewed claims that the A.I. start-up put profits and commercial interests ahead of the public good.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk has revived a lawsuit against OpenAI, the maker of the A.I. chatbot ChatGPT, refueling a six-year-old feud that began with a power struggle at the San Francisco start-up.

headline: The Market Meltdown Intensifies
abstract: Fears of a hard landing are rocking global stocks again as stocks, oil and cryptocurrencies sell off.
lead_paragraph: Stocks, cryptocurrencies, the dollar, oil — they’re all down sharply again on Monday on concerns that the U.S. economy is slowing faster than expected. It comes after a rough week for global markets.

headline: Pentagon Hands Over Last Base in Niger as Extremism Spreads in the Sahel
abstract: Relations between the two countries soured after a coup last year. Now the United States is scrambling to find new security partners.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. military turned over control of its last base in Niger to local forces on Monday, ending a yearslong counterterrorism mission in the West African country even as violent extremism remains on the rise in the region.

headline: Myanmar Rebels Claim Regional Military Base in Major Victory
abstract: The seizure of the military’s northeastern command post gives the resistance control of a city and airport on a crucial trade corridor to China.
lead_paragraph: A rebel army in Myanmar announced this weekend that it had overrun a regional military base near the border with China in what is likely to be the most significant victory yet for a patchwork of resistance groups that have challenged the country’s junta.

headline: Pope Francis Names New Leader for Boston Archdiocese
abstract: Bishop Richard Henning will succeed Cardinal Seán P. O’Malley, one of the pope’s most trusted allies, who is retiring.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis announced the next leader for the Catholic Archdiocese of Boston on Monday, to succeed Cardinal Seán P. O’Malley, one of the pope’s key allies and leader of the Vatican’s office on sexual abuse.

headline: The Author of ‘Red, White and Royal Blue’ Is Back, With More Spice and No Shame
abstract: Casey McQuiston’s debut proved that queer romance can be a hit. In their latest novel, “The Pairing,” sex doesn’t only sell; it’s also “beautiful and really soul affirming.”
lead_paragraph: Until a few years ago, mainstream publishers considered queer romance novels a niche business, a little slice of the market that served a particular population and was never going to deliver a blockbuster.

headline: Can the Higgs Boson Shine on Broadway?
abstract: A musical about particle physics is under development, with David Henry Hwang, the playwright behind “M. Butterfly.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday afternoon in a basement room in Midtown Manhattan, a dozen musicians and actors stood behind a line of microphones and broke into song about particle physics. Urged along by a piano in the corner, their voices blended at times in a heavenly lament about cosmic ignorance and the search for the Higgs boson, a fleck of energy thought to be key to understanding the evolution of the universe.

headline: He Was Freed From a Brutal Russian Jail. Here’s Why He Wanted to Stay.
abstract: The dissident Ilya Yashin calls his release in a prisoner swap last week an ‘illegal expulsion’ by Russia that damages his ability to be heard at home.
lead_paragraph: Escaping the brutal Russian penal system would seem like blessed deliverance to most inmates. But not to Ilya Yashin, who stunned the world last week when he angrily condemned his inclusion in a sweeping prisoner swap that freed him and a handful of other opposition figures in Russia.

headline: CrowdStrike Hits Back in Heated Spat With Delta Over Global Tech Outage
abstract: The cybersecurity company said the airline should take the blame after it struggled to rebound from a software outage that caused disruptions worldwide.
lead_paragraph: A legal dispute is heating up between the cybersecurity company CrowdStrike and Delta Air Lines over a global technology outage last month.

headline: Out and About at the Edinburgh Fringe
abstract: The streets of the Scottish capital are packed as thousands of performers seek to entertain and entice.
lead_paragraph: It’s summer in Edinburgh and visitors from around the world have arrived for the 77th edition of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the chaotic, scrappy, sprawling arts event that opened Friday and runs through Aug. 26. This year, there are more than 3,600 shows on the program, by artists from 58 countries: theater, stand-up, circus and cabaret performances, as usual — but also film screenings, whiskey tastings and a life drawing class with dogs.

headline: Tracking the Remnants of Daniel
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Daniel.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Daniel.

headline: Traders Bet on Fed Emergency Rate Cuts, but Officials Need More to React
abstract: The Federal Reserve cuts rates outside of scheduled meetings only in extreme cases. But job market weakening could make for bigger rate cuts down the road.
lead_paragraph: As turmoil swept through global financial markets on Monday, fueled by concerns that the economy is headed for a hard landing, investors began to speculate that the Federal Reserve could jump in to cushion the fallout with an emergency interest rate cut.

headline: Nvidia Tumbles After Reports of Chip Delay
abstract: The A.I. chip maker’s shares fell in early trading, but the stock pared some of its losses.
lead_paragraph: Nvidia shares tumbled more than 10 percent in early trading on Monday after reports that the company would delay shipments of its newest artificial intelligence chip, but the stock later rebounded as investors’ concerns about the costs of the delay faded.

headline: Advice: When the Stock Market Drops, Stay Calm and Do Nothing
abstract: There is no reason to think that you can predict what will happen in the markets in the next few hours or in the near future. It’s better not to try.
lead_paragraph: Think of what’s happening in the stock market as a kind of fire drill. As we all know from childhood, one of the primary rules is not to panic. And in this case, panicking would mean selling stocks when the market is falling.

headline: Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies plunge, mirroring global markets.
abstract: The precipitous falls show that digital currencies remain vulnerable to the same broader economic forces that affect technology stocks and risky investments.
lead_paragraph: The prices of Bitcoin and other major cryptocurrencies plunged over the last two days, mirroring the volatility in global stock markets and ending a run of growth and excitement in the crypto industry.

headline: Can Stress Really Give You a Round ‘Cortisol Face’?
abstract: Online influencers claim the hormone can change the shape of your face. But experts say that misconstrues how cortisol works.
lead_paragraph: “You’re not ugly. You just have cortisol face,” Mandana Zarghami told viewers at the start of a recent TikTok video, one of many on the social platform blaming a rounded, puffy face on high levels of the hormone.

headline: Can You Find the 12 Book Titles Hidden in This Text?
abstract: This puzzle challenges you to find the names of a dozen medical thrillers tucked within a very short story.
lead_paragraph: This puzzle challenges you to find the names of a dozen medical thrillers tucked within a very short story.

headline: Hetty Lui McKinnon Has a New Dumpling Salad Recipe
abstract: This time with smashed cucumbers and an umami-rich peanut sauce.
lead_paragraph: Hi, everyone! Mia here, your New York Times Cooking newsletter editor, filling in for Melissa Clark while she’s on vacation.

headline: The Director of ‘Deadpool & Wolverine’ on Those Spoilery Surprises
abstract: Shawn Levy explains the thinking behind specific cameos, what was saved from discarded scripts and how they made that end-credits tribute to Fox.
lead_paragraph: Though the director Shawn Levy has spent the last several months promoting his new blockbuster, “Deadpool & Wolverine,” there was so much he couldn’t say until now.

headline: Tracking Post-Tropical Cyclone Emilia
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Emilia.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Emilia.

headline: Why Is Iran Poised to Attack Israel? Here Is a Look at the Crisis.
abstract: Iran has vowed to retaliate for the killing of a Hamas leader in Tehran in late July, an attack for which it has blamed Israel. Diplomats are trying to forestall an Iranian response that some fear could lead to a regional war.
lead_paragraph: The crisis in the Middle East entered a new phase in recent weeks when a Hamas leader was assassinated in the Iranian capital, Tehran. The Iranian government said it would retaliate against Israel. This has provoked international concern that the war in Gaza and a more limited conflict on Israel’s border with Lebanon could widen into a regional war.

headline: To Become the GOAT, Simone Biles First Had to Be a Turtle
abstract: She sealed her legacy with four medals at the Paris Games. She created it by being herself and going at her own pace.
lead_paragraph: To end the Olympics she once thought would never happen for her, Simone Biles began her floor exercise routine on Monday and did what she was made to do: flip and twist and thrill an arena filled with people there to watch her.

headline: On Biden’s Exit, Pelosi Says She Was Driven by Need to Defeat Trump
abstract: A new book by the former speaker details her clashes with the former president, but it was written before her most recent exercise of political might: helping persuade President Biden to end his re-election bid.
lead_paragraph: To hear Representative Nancy Pelosi tell it, her quiet but firm push to get President Biden to withdraw from the 2024 race was a simple matter of the ruthless political math that she has spent decades honing a talent for on Capitol Hill.

headline: Fighting Malaria: The Role of Two Groups
abstract: The W.H.O. and the Gates Foundation respond to a Science article. Also: A revoked 9/11 plea deal; a debate on Fox; mispronouncing “Kamala”; climate-themed movies.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Next Month in the Economy Could Be Crucial for the Presidential Election
abstract: Former President Trump is trying to stoke economic angst, while Vice President Harris projects optimism.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t take long for former President Donald J. Trump to make a political weapon out of Monday’s market sell-off. “Stock markets are crashing, jobs numbers are terrible, we are heading to World War III, and we have two of the most incompetent ‘leaders’ in history,” Mr. Trump wrote in a post on Truth Social. “This is not good.”

headline: A Family Reunion Menu Over 150 Years in the Making
abstract: The food at the Coleman-Richards reunion in Fayette County, Ky., offers a look at the family’s ties to America and Liberia.
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday afternoon last month in Fayette County, Ky., members of the extended Coleman family lined up along a table topped with chafing dishes of white rice, fried chicken wings and dark-green Liberian palava sauce made with stewed spinach. Nearby, a large grill sizzled, hot dogs cooking over its flames. Afrobeats, funk and classic R&B played underneath a tent providing shade from the summer sun.

headline: Tracking Post-Tropical Cyclone Fabio
abstract: See the likely path for Fabio.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path for Fabio.

headline: Tsung-Dao Lee, 97, Physicist Who Challenged a Law of Nature, Dies
abstract: At 31, he and a colleague won the 1957 Nobel Prize in Physics for discovering that subatomic particles, contrary to what scientists thought, are not always symmetrical.
lead_paragraph: Tsung-Dao Lee, a Chinese American physicist who shared the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1957 for overturning what had been considered a fundamental law of nature — that particles are always symmetrical — died on Sunday at his home in San Francisco. He was 97.

headline: Justice Thomas Failed to Reveal More Private Flights, Senator Says
abstract: Senator Ron Wyden sent a letter to the wealthy conservative donor Harlan Crow’s lawyer after records showed undisclosed flights between Hawaii and New Zealand with the Supreme Court justice in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Justice Clarence Thomas failed to publicly disclose additional private travel provided by the wealthy conservative donor Harlan Crow, a top Democratic senator said in a letter on Monday.

headline: Read the Letter to Harlan Crow
abstract: Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, wrote a letter to Harlan Crow asking for details about private travel with Justice Clarence Thomas.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, wrote a letter to Harlan Crow asking for details about private travel with Justice Clarence Thomas.

headline: A Republican State A.G. Fights to Keep Exonerated Prisoners Behind Bars
abstract: In Missouri, Attorney General Andrew Bailey is in a tough primary fight against a Trump lawyer who says Bailey is soft on crime.
lead_paragraph: Over the decades he spent in prison, sentenced to life for a fatal shooting in 1990, Christopher Dunn faced one obstacle after another as he sought to clear his name.

headline: Thousands of users have reported online brokerage outages as stocks tumbled.
abstract: Most of the outages had been resolved by midday on Monday, but investors were frustrated by their inability to trade stocks during a morning of global market volatility.
lead_paragraph: Online stock trading platforms, including Fidelity Investments and Charles Schwab, said users had trouble logging into their accounts on Monday morning, preventing some investors from making trades amid a panic sell-off that reverberated around the world.

headline: Lincoln Center’s Rebranded Orchestra Settles Into Its Debut Season
abstract: Compared with previous seasons, recent concerts by the Festival Orchestra of Lincoln Center were refreshingly casual, but also more mixed.
lead_paragraph: With a new name and a new music director, Lincoln Center’s summer orchestra is getting a fresh start this season. On the evidence of three concerts over the past week and a half, though, the newly minted Festival Orchestra of Lincoln Center is turning its focus to an element that has always been there: the players themselves.

headline: The Economist Who Predicted What Could Well Be the Next Recession
abstract: David Rosenberg has a history of making calls many don’t want to hear.
lead_paragraph: The economist and market strategist David Rosenberg took a lot of heat for predicting that the Federal Reserve’s big increase in interest rates would tip the U.S. economy into recession. “I spent most of the past year being absolutely beaten up,” he told me last week. “I had email from clients that you would not believe, and many cancellations.”

headline: ‘Yo Gabba GabbaLand!’ Revives a Cult Kids Show
abstract: This reboot features the same characters and still emphasizes music and dance while seeking to “make the world of Gabba an actual place,” a creator said.
lead_paragraph: When “Yo Gabba Gabba!” premiered on Nickelodeon in 2007, the series looked and sounded like nothing else on children’s TV. It starred five toys that have come to life, including Brobee; a half-broccoli, half-bee hybrid with a bushy black unibrow; and Muno, a giant Cyclops with bumps all over his cherry-red body. Preschool viewers, typically treated to less challenging musical fare, heard performances from acts like Bootsy Collins, the Roots, My Chemical Romance and Weezer.

headline: How 100-Year-Old Ella Jenkins Revolutionized Children’s Music
abstract: Over seven decades, she brought a world of genres and ideas to songs for the young. On her centennial, what she would really like to do is perform again.
lead_paragraph: When Ella Jenkins began recording young people’s music in the 1950s and ’60s, her albums featured tracks that many of that era’s parents and teachers would probably never have dreamed of playing for children: a love chant from North Africa. A Mexican hand-clapping song. A Maori Indian battle chant. And even “Another Man Done Gone,” an American chain-gang lament whose lyrics she changed, turning it into a freedom cry.

headline: Barbara Howar, Irreverent Memoirist of Washington Society, Dies at 89
abstract: She was already a prominent hostess in the nation’s capital when her uninhibited, best-selling 1973 memoir, “Laughing All the Way,” made her a star.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Howar, a best-selling author, television interviewer and gleefully nonconformist fixture of the Washington social scene, died on Friday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 89.

headline: Crowds Swarm Prime Minister’s Residence After Bangladesh Leader Flees
abstract: Looters made off with furniture, bedding and potted plants.
lead_paragraph: Exuberant looters made off with furniture, bedding and potted plants as they swarmed the Bangladesh residence of the prime minister, Sheikh Hasina, after she resigned her office and fled the country, according to local broadcast footage.

headline: A Race at Warp Speed: For Harris, There Are Advantages in a Late Start
abstract: This presidential campaign is playing out in fast forward. Strategists in both parties say speed is likely to benefit Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Presidential campaigns follow a rhythm. The candidates are generally known by late spring. They are nominated at conventions over the summer. The fall campaign kicks off on Labor Day, at which point the public’s attention turns to the candidates who have spent months preparing for the next eight weeks.

headline: Debby Drenches Florida in Slow Crawl Northeast
abstract: The storm made landfall near Steinhatchee, Fla., as a Category 1 hurricane before weakening back into a tropical storm.
lead_paragraph: The storm made landfall near Steinhatchee, Fla., as a Category 1 hurricane before weakening back into a tropical storm.

headline: The Stock Market Dropped, but Don’t Freak Out
abstract: For the amateur investor, it makes sense to play the long game.
lead_paragraph: The secret to making money in the stock market is to buy low and sell high. Right? Not buy high and sell low.

headline: George Saunders Reflects on His Novel ‘Lincoln in the Bardo’
abstract: The third in a series of conversations with authors appearing on our “Best Books of the 21st Century” list.
lead_paragraph: As part of its recent “100 Best Books of the 21st Century“ project, The New York Times Book Review is interviewing some of the authors whose books appeared on the list. This week, George Saunders — who had three books on the list, including his story collections “Pastoralia” and “Tenth of December” — joins host Gilbert Cruz to discuss his novel, “Lincoln in the Bardo,” and how he came to write a historical novel after decades spent writing largely futuristic short stories.

headline: Virginia Man Threatened to Kill Kamala Harris, Authorities Say
abstract: Frank Carillo, 66, also made threats against President Biden and Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, according to federal prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: A Virginia man has been charged with posting repeated death threats against Vice President Kamala Harris on social media in the days after she became the presumptive Democratic nominee for president, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Walter Arlen, Holocaust Refugee and Belated Composer, Is Dead at 103
abstract: After fleeing Vienna, he was a music critic and teacher before returning to composing in the 1980s. His memories of Nazi barbarism inspired his music.
lead_paragraph: Walter Arlen, a Viennese musical prodigy who fled to the United States after Nazi Germany annexed Austria in 1938 and became a music critic and a late-in-life composer of Holocaust and Jewish-exile remembrances in song, died on Sept. 3, 2023, in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 103.

headline: ‘Google Is a Monopolist,’ Judge Rules in Landmark Antitrust Case
abstract: The ruling on Google’s search dominance was the first antitrust decision of the modern internet era in a case against a technology giant.
lead_paragraph: Google acted illegally to maintain a monopoly in online search, a federal judge ruled on Monday, a landmark decision that strikes at the power of tech giants in the modern internet era and that may fundamentally alter the way they do business.

headline: Lorenza de’ Medici, Who Elevated Italian Cooking, Is Dead at 97
abstract: A descendant of a storied family, she was an author, TV host and cooking school director who showed that Italian cuisine was about more than tomatoes, pizza and pasta.
lead_paragraph: Before Lorenza de’ Medici began publishing her cookbooks in the late 1980s, Italian cuisine outside of Italy was often considered unremarkable fare: red sauce, white sauce, pizza and pasta, all of which could be whipped up in haste from frozen, processed ingredients.

headline: U.S. et al. v. Google: Read the Ruling
abstract: Google acted illegally to maintain a monopoly in online search, a federal judge ruled on Monday. The landmark decision strikes at the power of tech giants in the modern internet era and may fundamentally alter the way they do business.
lead_paragraph: Google acted illegally to maintain a monopoly in online search, a federal judge ruled on Monday. The landmark decision strikes at the power of tech giants in the modern internet era and may fundamentally alter the way they do business.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Long-Shot Challenge to Trump Hush Money Case
abstract: Missouri sought to sue New York under the court’s “original jurisdiction,” which sometimes allows suits between states to be brought directly to the justices.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Monday rejected an audacious lawsuit by Missouri that asked the justices to intervene in the hush money case in New York in which former President Donald J. Trump was convicted of falsifying business records.

headline: X to Close Flagship San Francisco Office
abstract: Elon Musk, X’s owner, has clashed with California’s leaders and has said the social media platform would move its headquarters to Texas.
lead_paragraph: X, the social media company owned by Elon Musk, plans to shut its San Francisco office “over the next few weeks,” according to an internal email obtained by The New York Times.

headline: The Economy Is Looking Pre-Recessionary
abstract: Will a sluggish Fed snatch defeat from the jaws of victory?
lead_paragraph: As an American of a certain age, I know quite a few people who’ve been warned by their doctors that they’re prediabetic. That is, their blood sugar is sufficiently elevated to put them at risk of Type 2 diabetes, even though they aren’t yet showing any symptoms. The good news is that they can greatly reduce that risk by losing weight, improving their diet and getting more exercise. But they need to take action quickly to avoid serious health problems.

headline: Usha Vance Defends JD Vance’s ‘Childless Cat Ladies’ Claim as a ‘Quip’
abstract: Usha Vance said in a Fox News interview that her husband, who is Donald J. Trump’s running mate, had been trying to make a “substantive” point through jest.
lead_paragraph: Usha Vance, the wife of Senator JD Vance of Ohio, defended a 2021 claim by her husband that the United States was led by unhappy “childless cat ladies,” saying that his statement was a “quip.”

headline: After Google Antitrust Ruling, Here’s Where Other Big Tech Cases Stand
abstract: The federal government has more lawsuits in the pipeline trying to rein in the tech giants, including another antitrust case against Google that goes to trial next month.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government’s landmark antitrust trial against Google’s search business concluded on Monday with a federal judge’s ruling that the company acted illegally to maintain a monopoly. But the parade of major federal cases challenging the power of the tech giants is just getting going.

headline: Second Gentleman Merchandise? The Harris Campaign Leans In.
abstract: An old photo of Doug Emhoff caught the internet’s attention, and Kamala Harris’s staff seized a fund-raising opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Megan Burk was on a mission. After President Biden announced he would not seek re-election, Ms. Burk, a bartender in Wilmington, N.C., watched as some people on social media quickly embraced Vice President Kamala Harris as a presidential candidate.

headline: Jenna Ellis, Former Trump Lawyer, Will Cooperate in Arizona Election Fraud Case
abstract: Ms. Ellis is the first of 18 defendants to reach a deal with prosecutors in a case that charges them with trying to overturn Arizona’s election results in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Jenna Ellis, a lawyer who played a major role in the efforts to keep Donald J. Trump in power after his 2020 election loss, reached a cooperation agreement on Monday as part of a deal with prosecutors leading an election interference case in Arizona.

headline: Harnessing the Power of the Immune System
abstract: Dr. Tanya Mayadas of Mass General Brigham demystifies the body’s first line of defense in cancer treatments.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Tanya Mayadas of Mass General Brigham demystifies the body’s first line of defense in cancer treatments.

headline: Personalizing Cancer Care With A.I.
abstract: Using patient data, Dr. Sophia Shalhout and Dr. Kevin Emerick are maximizing benefits and reducing side effects of treatment.
lead_paragraph: Using patient data, Dr. Sophia Shalhout and Dr. Kevin Emerick are maximizing benefits and reducing side effects of treatment.

headline: Finding a Cure With Cellular Therapy
abstract: How Dr. Marcela Maus and Dr. Matthew Frigault are fighting cancer and other diseases using innovative therapies at Mass General Brigham.
lead_paragraph: How Dr. Marcela Maus and Dr. Matthew Frigault are fighting cancer and other diseases using innovative therapies at Mass General Brigham.

headline: Behind the Innovation
abstract: Researchers and clinicians at Mass General Brigham are making breakthroughs in cancer diagnosis and treatments, putting patients at the center.
lead_paragraph: Researchers and clinicians at Mass General Brigham are making breakthroughs in cancer diagnosis and treatments, putting patients at the center.

headline: A Chaotic News Conference Offers Little Clarity on a Boxing Dispute
abstract: Two Olympians whose eligibility to compete as women at the Paris Games has come under scrutiny will fight for medals on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The news conference had been billed as an effort by international boxing authorities to clear up the reasons they banned two athletes from a women’s competition last year, and a chance to shed crucial light on what has become the biggest controversy at the Paris Olympics.

headline: Facing Mass Protests, Bangladesh Leader Quits, Setting Up Power Struggle
abstract: Demonstrators defied a curfew, expecting another in a series of bloody crackdowns, but instead Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina fled.
lead_paragraph: They came prepared for violence. A day after about 100 people were killed in antigovernment protests, hundreds of thousands took to the streets of Dhaka, Bangladesh’s capital, defying a curfew imposed by the government and demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.

headline: She Thought Her Grip Was Unbreakable. Bangladeshis Would Prove Otherwise.
abstract: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, who once brought democratic hope to Bangladesh, turned increasingly autocratic and met her downfall in a crackdown on protesters.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina’s life, as well as her politics, had been defined by an early trauma at once personal in its pain and national in its imprint.

headline: Kennedy Fights to Stay on Ballot, but Everyone’s Talking About the Bear
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s disclosure that he had left a cub’s carcass in Central Park overshadowed his court battle to remain on New York State’s ballot this fall.
lead_paragraph: Lucas Altman remembers it well: On an early October night in 2014, he had taken his two Labradors to Central Park when suddenly they became alert, their tails wagging with the thrill of the hunt as they towed him to a patch of shrubbery.

headline: Mexican Reporter Gunned Down, Even With a Security Detail at His Side
abstract: Alejandro Martínez had received so many threats that the Mexican government appointed him protection. On Sunday, he was shot and killed and his bodyguards wounded.
lead_paragraph: Alejandro Martínez was no stranger to covering the kind of news that took him to crime scenes and fatal accidents across Celaya, a city in central Mexico that has become a cauldron of violence as murder cases pile up.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Global Markets Fell
abstract: Plus, LeBron James at the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: A wave of anxiety rippled through financial markets yesterday. Stocks fell in the U.S. and around the world as investors zeroed in on signs of a slowing American economy.

headline: My Favorite Simone Biles Moment Wasn’t When She Won Gold
abstract: Just because she makes winning look easy does not mean that it is.
lead_paragraph: GOAT. Most decorated. Winningest. It sounds hokey, but the most satisfying and joyful part of the Olympics for me is not which country is leading the medal count but when the best athletes in the world show their respect and admiration for one another, especially after an underperformance. On Monday, the last day of the artistic gymnastics competition, Simone Biles and Jordan Chiles, the Americans who took silver and bronze medals in the floor exercise final, showed such sportsmanship to Brazil’s Rebeca Andrade, who won gold.

headline: Study Puts a $43 Billion Yearly Price Tag on Cancer Screening
abstract: The estimate focused on five cancers for which there is medically recommended screening — breast, cervical, colorectal, lung and prostate — and found that colonoscopies accounted for most of the costs.
lead_paragraph: The United States spent $43 billion annually on screening to prevent five cancers, according to one of the most comprehensive estimates of medically recommended cancer testing ever produced.

headline: Hip-Hop Arrives at the Paris Olympics With Breaking’s Debut
abstract: Breaking spread across the globe in the decades after it originated in the streets of New York City. Its roots will be on display in Paris, if you know what to look for.
lead_paragraph: Breaking spread across the globe in the decades after it originated in the streets of New York City. Its roots will be on display in Paris, if you know what to look for.

headline: Violent U.K. Riots Pose Challenge to Keir Starmer’s New Government
abstract: The new Labour government’s strong law-and-order approach to the violence has mostly spared it from criticism, even from the Conservatives, who only recently left power. But challenges remain.
lead_paragraph: When Labour’s Keir Starmer was elected as prime minister last month, he planned to tackle some of the long-term issues bedeviling Britain. His first priorities included reviving a stagnant economy and repairing the struggling National Health Service.

headline: Former Trump Adviser Kellyanne Conway Lobbies for Ukrainian Interests
abstract: The former campaign aide indicated in a Justice Department filing that she will be paid $50,000 a month by an oligarch to seek support for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: With former President Donald J. Trump and his allies signaling that he will scale back assistance to Ukraine if he retakes the White House, a onetime close adviser has accepted a $50,000-a-month contract to lobby for Ukrainian interests.

headline: Ex-Police Chief Will Be Charged After Raid on Kansas Newspaper, Prosecutors Say
abstract: The former chief, Gideon Cody, will be charged with interference with the judicial process, a felony, after he ordered the raid on The Marion County Record last year, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A former Kansas police chief who ordered a raid last year on the office of a local newspaper and the home of its publisher will be charged with interfering in the judicial process, a felony, prosecutors said on Monday.

headline: U.N. Fires Nine Aid Workers Accused of Taking Part in Oct. 7 Attack, but Clears 10 Others
abstract: Israel accused 19 UNRWA employees of playing a role in the Hamas-led raids that set off the war. Investigators cleared 10 for lack of evidence, but said the other nine “may have been involved.”
lead_paragraph: U.N. investigators cleared 10 employees of a Palestinian refugee agency in Gaza accused of taking part in the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel, but nine others were fired because of possible involvement, the United Nations said.

headline: Vance Is Touring the Same Battleground States as Harris This Week
abstract: The Republican vice-presidential nominee will hold events that overlap with the stops Vice President Kamala Harris has planned, sometimes even in the same city.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance thought he would meet Vice President Kamala Harris on the debate stage. Instead, it might be on an airport tarmac.

headline: Bloomberg Disciplines Journalists Over Prisoner Swap Article
abstract: The news organization said it had broken an embargo about the news in a violation of its editorial standards.
lead_paragraph: Bloomberg News’s editor in chief said on Monday that the publication had disciplined multiple journalists involved in breaking an embargo last week tied to the major prisoner swap, in what he said was “a clear violation of the editorial standards.”

headline: Adin Ross Gives Trump a Cybertruck, a Rolex and Access to a Heavily Male Audience
abstract: The 23-year-old internet celebrity is enormously popular with a testosterone-heavy demographic that the former president sees as critical to his bid for office.
lead_paragraph: What do you give a former president who has everything?

headline: U.S. Troops in Iraq Are Wounded in Rocket Attack on Air Base
abstract: The attack late Monday resembled previous ones carried out by Iraqi armed groups, backed by Iran, which have targeted the base repeatedly over the past nine months.
lead_paragraph: A rocket attack targeting U.S. personnel housed at a base in Iraq’s western desert injured several American troops late on Monday, according to U.S. defense officials.

headline: Stocks Tumbled Over Fears of a U.S. Economic Slowdown
abstract: Also, a judge ruled that Google violated antitrust laws and Bangladesh’s leader resigned
lead_paragraph: A wave of anxiety rippled through financial markets today, with stocks falling in the U.S. and around the world as investors zeroed in on signs of a slowing American economy.

headline: As Israel Braces for Iran’s Retaliation, Diplomats Work to Avoid Wider War
abstract: President Biden convened his national security team and spoke with King Abdullah II of Jordan, and foreign ministers from Islamic countries plan to gather in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Diplomats across the Middle East worked on Monday to contain escalating tensions between Israel and Iran as fears grew of a widening conflict in the region and Tehran vowed to retaliate for the killing of a senior Hamas leader, Ismail Haniyeh, on Iranian soil.

headline: David Lynch Says He Has Emphysema
abstract: The director, 78, confirmed the diagnosis in a social media post after revealing in a magazine interview that he would be limited to directing remotely.
lead_paragraph: David Lynch, co-creator of the groundbreaking series “Twin Peaks” and director of “Mulholland Drive” and “Blue Velvet,” said on Monday that he had emphysema but that he would not retire.

headline: Bangladesh Prime Minister Flees Country After Weeks of Protests
abstract: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina resigned and fled Bangladesh under intense pressure from a growing protest movement enraged by her government’s deadly crackdowns.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina resigned and fled Bangladesh under intense pressure from a growing protest movement enraged by her government’s deadly crackdowns.

headline: JD Vance Just Blurbed a Book Arguing That Progressives Are Subhuman
abstract: A MAGA-world celebration of Francisco Franco and Joseph McCarthy.
lead_paragraph: In a normal political environment, there would be little need to pay attention to a new book by the far-right provocateur Jack Posobiec, who is probably best known for promoting the conspiracy theory that Democrats ran a satanic child abuse ring beneath a popular Washington pizzeria. But “Unhumans,” an anti-democratic screed that Posobiec co-wrote with the professional ghostwriter Joshua Lisec, comes with endorsements from some of the most influential people in Republican politics, including, most significantly, vice-presidential candidate JD Vance.

headline: Trump’s Surreal Summer, in Photos
abstract: Six images that tell the story of Trump’s wild summer.
lead_paragraph: Good evening! Look, before you ask — I don’t know who Vice President Kamala Harris is going to choose as her running mate, but we are all going to find out soon. Tonight, we’re looking at former President Donald Trump’s topsy-turvy summer with someone who has literally seen it all: my colleague the photographer Doug Mills.

headline: 2024 Presidential Election Calendar
abstract: Here are important dates and voting deadlines for the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: Here are important dates and voting deadlines for the 2024 election.

headline: Harris Nears Her Big V.P. Reveal After Fierce Lobbying From Democrats
abstract: The vice president is expected to announce her choice on Tuesday morning. One prominent Democrat recounted being asked by a contender, “Will you please make sure you put in a good word for me?”
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris is expected to reveal her running mate on Tuesday morning, a decision that will end a 16-day sprint to vet, interview and choose a person who could potentially become the future leader of the Democratic Party.

headline: Trump and His Allies Seize on Market Downturn to Attack Harris
abstract: Economists blamed a variety of factors for Monday’s slide. But Donald Trump was trying to disrupt weeks of momentum for Vice President Kamala Harris and her party.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump didn’t wait for the opening bell before blaming Monday’s market sell-off on Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Southern California Fire Destroys Homes and Forces Evacuations
abstract: A blaze in San Bernardino burned suburban homes and threatened others nearby, adding to an already intense California fire season.
lead_paragraph: A fast-moving brush fire burned homes and forced evacuations in the inland California city of San Bernardino on Monday afternoon. Shocking views of the fire tearing across a residential hillside stoked fears that an already dangerous fire season could threaten the more populated parts of the state.

headline: Stocks Steady After Day of Wild Selling
abstract: Wall Street rebounded on Tuesday, retracing some of the losses in the previous day’s rout. Stocks in Japan, the hardest hit by recent selling, jumped 10 percent.
lead_paragraph: A measure of calm returned to global markets on Tuesday, as stocks staged a modest recovery from the panic that had overtaken investors to start the week.

headline: Bit of Ink
abstract: Daniel Raymon rides the current.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Akili McDowell, Star of ‘David Makes Man,’ Is Charged With Murder
abstract: Mr. McDowell, 21, was being held on bond for the July shooting death of a man in the parking lot of a Houston apartment complex, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Akili McDowell, an actor who starred in the television series “David Makes Man,” has been charged with murder in the July shooting death of a man in the parking lot of a Houston apartment complex, authorities said.

headline: Long Battle for a Ruined City Takes a Desperate Turn
abstract: Ukrainian troops are engaged in a harsh struggle for Toretsk, a strategic city in eastern Ukraine that has been under relentless assault by Russian forces.
lead_paragraph: As the Ukrainian soldiers raced through the ruins of the destroyed city under the spying eye of Russian drones, the skeletal remains of blasted-out buildings cast eerie shadows in the light of a full moon.

headline: To Save His Shrinking City, a Mayor Turns to Koreans Uprooted by Stalin
abstract: Like many South Korean cities, Jecheon is being eroded by rapid aging and rock-bottom birthrates. Can ethnic Korean migrants from Central Asia turn it around?
lead_paragraph: The nearby mines shut down one by one. The cement business, once the city’s pride, waned. More than a dozen schools closed, as did one of the two movie theaters. The second would eventually follow.

headline: Star Power Elevates Pin Trading, the Unofficial Sport of the Olympics
abstract: Celebrities and athletes are chronicling the chase for their most prized conquests on social media, with high demand for designs from Snoop Dogg and Simone Biles.
lead_paragraph: Since the Paris Olympics kicked off, a pair of tiny orange Dutch clogs, the unofficial pin of the Netherlands team, has become a coveted currency among the athletes. Nearly an inch long and dangling from a butterfly clutch, the pin exchanged hands between Yara ten Holte, a Dutch handball player, and Ilona Maher, the U.S. women’s rugby star, who gleefully flaunted her prize on TikTok.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: A wave of anxiety rippled through financial markets yesterday, and stocks fell around the world as investors zeroed in on signs of a slowing American economy.

headline: As Ukraine Collects Medals in Paris, Its Sports Pipeline Is in Tatters
abstract: Facilities have been battered. Coaches are in short supply. Children have moved abroad. Ukraine faces a long hard road toward rebuilding its athletic programs.
lead_paragraph: The Olympic medals have come in a flurry for Ukraine in recent days: golds at the track and on the fencing piste, a silver in gymnastics, two other bronzes.

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘Little Turtle’ Reached the Peak at Her Own Pace
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t worry that you are moving slowly. Just be sure of what direction you are going in.”

headline: One of China’s Most Talkative Nationalists Suddenly Goes Silent
abstract: Hu Xijin’s tens of millions of followers have heard nothing from him since late July. Some think one of his posts praising Beijing may have backfired.
lead_paragraph: One of China’s most influential, and garrulous, nationalist voices on social media has suddenly gone quiet, and the country’s internet is wondering why.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 6, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about Iceland’s president, Halla Tómasdóttir, misstated the singer Björk’s connections to Ms. Tómasdóttir. Björk partnered in 2008 with a financial firm of which Ms. Tómasdóttir was a co-founder. Björk was not involved in Ms. Tómasdóttir’s election campaign.

headline: Word of the Day: incinerate
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word incinerate has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 25 in “Safety Agency Faults Norfolk Southern for ‘Vent and Burn’ After 2023 Derailment” by Peter Eavis, Mark Walker and Daniel McGraw:

headline: Harris Officially Secures Democratic Party’s Nomination for President
abstract: The vice president won 99 percent of participating delegates in an unusual, virtual roll call vote that concluded Monday, the party said.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has secured the Democratic nomination for president, becoming the first woman of color to win a major party’s nomination and officially setting up her matchup against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,145
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, August 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: New York City Failed to Halt Major Overspending on Migrants, Audit Finds
abstract: An audit by the city comptroller, Brad Lander, found that a city agency allowed a troubled contractor to bill for unnecessary expenses like unused hotel rooms.
lead_paragraph: Last year, as Mayor Eric Adams sought to relieve the pressure on New York City’s shelter system, he began to send hundreds of asylum seekers to hotels, often in counties north of the city.

headline: One Olympian’s Secret Weapon? His High School Coach.
abstract: All elite athletes make changes to their lives to keep their careers moving forward. For the American distance runner Grant Fisher, the key to success was in his past.
lead_paragraph: The broad strokes of Grant Fisher’s path to the Paris Olympics began to take shape last October at a coffee shop in Salt Lake City.

headline: The Zombie Pharmacies That Are Holding Back New York City Retail
abstract: Over a million square feet of retail space is empty in vacant chain-drugstore locations across New York City. Here’s why it’s so hard to fill.
lead_paragraph: An empty Duane Reade, steps from Wall Street, darkens a landmark office building.

headline: CNET to Be Sold to Ziff Davis in Sign of Possible Media Deals to Come
abstract: Ziff Davis is acquiring CNET for more than $100 million. Its chief executive thinks more acquisitions are on the horizon.
lead_paragraph: CNET, an early pioneer of online tech coverage, is changing hands.

headline: Waiting for a Wider War, Lebanese Civilians Feel Helpless
abstract: Hezbollah’s conflict with Israel has already damaged south Lebanon. Now it could escalate, regardless of what anyone else in Lebanon thinks.
lead_paragraph: The town in south Lebanon appeared deserted, its roads empty and its market shuttered, after months of fighting between Hezbollah and Israel across the nearby border made many residents flee.

headline: The Last Survivors of an Atomic Bomb Have a Story to Tell
abstract: On the anniversaries of the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, we must listen to the few who can still speak to the horror nuclear weapons can inflict.
lead_paragraph: On the anniversaries of the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, we must listen to the few who can still speak to the horror nuclear weapons can inflict.

headline: New Construction Blocking the View? ‘If You Can’t Beat Them, Join Them.’
abstract: Neighbors on Fire Island took a clever approach to a common problem: They hired the same architects at the same time. Now everyone has a view.
lead_paragraph: What do you do when the neighbors’ construction threatens your view?

headline: Wild, Beautiful and Overlooked: Southern Sardinia Is Ready to Share Its Essence
abstract: As travelers discover the Mediterranean charms of this island region, with its idyllic beaches and buzzing capital, locals are hoping to avoid the crowds suffocating so many other Italian destinations.
lead_paragraph: Buzz has been in short supply in southern Sardinia for some time now — some would say ever since the decline of the region’s Bronze Age Nuragic civilization. Yet on Italy’s second largest island, where sheep vastly outnumber people, there’s unmistakable new energy in Cagliari, its small Mediterranean capital, and the surrounding countryside.

headline: The World Is Still Catching Up to the Music of Hector Berlioz
abstract: The Romantic-era composer, the focus of this year’s Bard Music Festival, wrote works that sprang from a mind capable of thinking only in pipe dreams.
lead_paragraph: Hector Berlioz did not have the twilight of a great composer.

headline: To Discover L.A.’s Neighborhoods, Let the Trees Be Your Guide
abstract: There are palms, of course. But the city has one of the most diverse urban forests in the world and each neighborhood has its own characteristic plantings. Just follow the greenery.
