lead_paragraph: There are cities that ask you to look up. New York, of course. Tokyo, Paris, London. Then there are the cities that invite you to look out. The vistas are the party. Los Angeles is a looking-out city. And when you do, what you see are trees.

headline: How the Google Antitrust Ruling May Influence Tech Competition
abstract: Nearly a quarter-century after Microsoft lost a similar case, a judge’s decision that Google abused a monopoly in internet search is likely to have major ripple effects.
lead_paragraph: In 2000, a ruling in a U.S. antitrust case against Microsoft helped set the rules of competition for the digital giant of its day.

headline: Horses: Some People Just Drank Their Milk, Others Built Empires
abstract: Two new books look at how horses and primates helped each other grow from skittish little mammals to conquerors of the world.
lead_paragraph: When a meteor struck the Yucatán Peninsula 66 million years ago, the resulting mass extinction allowed various flora and fauna to seize the new opportunity of the postapocalyptic world. One of them, the first recognizable primate, was a shrew-like creature that dwelled in trees; another, 10 million years later, was the so-called dawn horse — at that point less like what comes around the fourth turn at Belmont and more like an overgrown fox.

headline: As Regulators Close In, Nvidia Scrambles for a Response
abstract: With a 90 percent share of the A.I. chip market, the company is facing antitrust investigations into the possibility that it could lock in customers or hurt competitors.
lead_paragraph: Nvidia rocketed to the top of the tech industry by providing the computer chips essential to building artificial intelligence. By the end of last year, it had more than a 90 percent share of those chips sold around the world.

headline: A Reporter Who Risked and Lost Her Life in Modi’s India
abstract: In “I Am on the Hit List,” Rollo Romig explores the political world of Gauri Lankesh.
lead_paragraph: A decade after their electoral victories kick-started a barbaric epoch of Indian history, Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the Hindu nationalist legislators in his Bharatiya Janata Party no longer appear as dominant as they once did. This year’s elections saw the B.J.P. lose much of its power over the country, as the INDIA alliance — a broad coalition led by the more pluralistic Congress Party — won nearly as many seats as Modi’s party did, forcing it to find new partners to cobble together a governing majority.

headline: Is Nail Polish Bad for Your Nails?
abstract: Here are some signs that it may be time to give your nails a break.
lead_paragraph: Q: I keep my nails near-constantly polished, but I worry that it’s damaging them. Do nails need breaks or time to “breathe”?

headline: An Oral History of Second-Wave Feminism Makes Its Case With Style
abstract: In “The Movement,” Clara Bingham captures the years 1963-73 in the voices of the women who lived it.
lead_paragraph: It’s a common stereotype about second-wave feminism: all anger and no joy. When the syndicated columnist James J. Kilpatrick snidely reviewed the inaugural issue of Ms. magazine, he likened the reading experience to “looking at the slides of carcinoma in a cancer magazine” and accused both Ms. and its staff of being petulant and bitchy, not to mention whiny and self-pitying.

headline: How ‘Coaching’ Became Silicon Valley’s Hack for Therapy
abstract: In the Bay Area, therapists are embracing a new kind of practice: advising executives on becoming their best selves.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, I told my therapist I wanted to become a therapist. He suggested I become a coach instead, like him. Now, to be clear, my therapist, whose name is Peter Carnochan, is indeed a therapist. He has a Ph.D. in clinical psychology, trained as a psychoanalyst in the tradition of Freud and commands high fees from clients in San Francisco and across the Golden Gate Bridge at his own magnificent home under the redwoods.

headline: Dare to Wear White This Fall
abstract: Soft knits, diaphanous dresses and smart separates in shades of ivory, cream and snow are a bright palate cleanser for the season.

headline: In the N.R.A. Case, Wins and Losses for the Attorney General
abstract: Letitia James, the New York attorney general, had sought to dissolve the gun rights group. She succeeded in ousting its head and forcing it to reform.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at the National Rifle Association, which has been fighting for control of its future in a high-stakes trial in Manhattan. We’ll also look at how Robert F. Kennedy Jr. spent Monday fighting to stay on the ballot in New York, even as everybody was talking about the bear.

headline: How to Fall in Love With Baseball
abstract: Radio play-by-play taught me about the game’s stark beauty — and who my grandmother was.
lead_paragraph: The hallmark of a great baseball radio announcer is knowing when to remain silent. That way, the game speaks for itself. Near home base, a pair of parabolic dishes relay the smack of a catcher’s glove, the scrape of spikes on dirt and chalk, the fizz of the crowd. A crack of the bat, caught by a shotgun mic poking out the window of the booth, announces a home run long before the ball drops into the stands. There are many other microphones in the stadium — near the bases and along the outfield wall — but those are for television. Radio ears can handle only so much.

headline: The Warrior Queen Who Carried a Head in a Bag, and Other Omissions
abstract: In her corrective “The Missing Thread,” the classical historian Daisy Dunn paints a fuller picture of the ancient world.
lead_paragraph: Feminist retellings of classical myth and history are having a moment. This is partly a publishing-industry trend, but also the result of a real thirst for stories about women in the ancient world, women whose lives have long been ignored or were never recorded in the first place.

headline: Live, Laugh, Lowboy: Fine Dining’s Love Affair With Inspirational Quotes
abstract: Sayings from Navy SEALs, furniture designers and Steve Martin are just a few examples of how restaurants use signs to motivate their staffs.
lead_paragraph: When the chef Niki Nakayama opened her kaiseki restaurant n/naka in Los Angeles in 2011, she asked herself, “What does this work mean for me and for our staff? What do I want them to feel when we’re doing our work?” Then she wrote the following words on a piece of paper: “Every day, better in every way. Everything is done with focus, heart, gratitude, love, care, purpose, intention, faith.”

headline: The ‘Orgasm Gap’ Isn’t Going Away for Straight Women
abstract: A new study suggests they still have fewer orgasms during sex than men do, even with age and experience.
lead_paragraph: Sex researchers and therapists have long known that women in heterosexual relationships tend to have fewer orgasms than men do. A large new study suggests that this “orgasm gap” persists — and does not improve with age.

headline: One Epic Film, Two Ambitious Actresses: What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: Silvia Moreno-Garcia’s new novel, “The Seventh Veil of Salome,” follows strivers in 1950s Hollywood competing for a place in an industry that does not embrace them.
lead_paragraph: “Movies are not about trust. They’re about moving pieces,” the director Max Niemann says in Silvia Moreno-Garcia’s new novel, “The Seventh Veil of Salome.” Concealment and revelation create the magic we expect from film. Depending on the creator, it can be a heavy-handed act or a subtle art.

headline: Wallet, Keys, Personal Fan? The New Must-Have.
abstract: With temperatures rising, small electric fans have become a go-to accessory at bars, restaurants and even the post office.
lead_paragraph: At “Wine For Me,” a monthly party for natural wine enthusiasts in Brooklyn, attendees were packed inside Public Records, a cafe and music venue in Gowanus, sipping red, white, orange and rosé wines on a hot and humid Saturday afternoon in July.

headline: Josh Hartnett Is in His Dad Era
abstract: The actor, who has spent more than two decades in the movie business and now stars in the thriller “Trap,” discussed fatherhood, fame and his love of the French New Wave.
lead_paragraph: Josh Hartnett has never made a movie that his children can see. “I would love to,” he said. “I just haven’t been offered anything like that, honestly.”

headline: A Jingle Put Cellino & Barnes on the Map. Their Split Inspired a Play.
abstract: Many New Yorkers can rattle off the phone number by heart. “Cellino v. Barnes” chronicles the rise and fall of these prominent injury lawyers.
lead_paragraph: We must begin with the jingle.

headline: What Today’s Nuclear Arms Race Looks Like to Hiroshima Survivors
abstract: The survivors of the last atomic bombs have a warning for us in the new arms race.
lead_paragraph: The threat of a nuclear arms race is building. In an effort to bring light to this new and terrifying nuclear era, Opinion’s editor, Kathleen Kingsbury, and the writer W.J. Hennigan interviewed Japanese survivors of the U.S. atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki. In this audio essay, they share stories from two of the survivors they met, Chieko Kiriake and Keiko Ogura, who were just 15 and 8 years old on Aug. 6, 1945.

headline: What’s Happening in Louisville Could Solve a Housing Crisis
abstract: An organizing effort could set a template for helping the nation’s poorest and marginalized Americans find stability.
lead_paragraph: On an unseasonably warm day in late April in Louisville, Ky., the drone of low-flying helicopters overtook the usual sounds of spring as the wealthy descended on the Kentucky Derby. Less than five miles away in a historically Black neighborhood, Donna Goldsmith, 62, addressed a room of 15 people gathered around a scarred folding table. They are part of Louisville’s burgeoning tenants union, which mobilizes the residents of low-income apartment complexes, rural trailer parks and gentrifying neighborhoods to challenge the corporate landlords that they say have devastated affordable housing. This meeting, like most of their gatherings, started with testimonials.

headline: 50 Years Ago, the World Trade Center Was Home to the Art Crime of the Century
abstract: Philippe Petit saw the human story between the Twin Towers.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago on Wednesday, the French high-wire artist Philippe Petit carried his life a quarter of a mile through the New York City sky on a tightrope. When asked why, he said it was simply because the World Trade Center towers were there.

headline: Recession Fears May Be Overstated, but Not Unfounded
abstract: The economy has repeatedly defied predictions of a downturn since the pandemic recovery began. Now signs of strength contend with shakier readings.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy has spent three years defying expectations. It emerged from the pandemic shock more quickly and more powerfully than many experts envisioned. It proved resilient in the face of both inflation and the higher interest rates the Federal Reserve used to combat it. The prospect many forecasters once considered imminent — a recession — looked increasingly like a false alarm.

headline: What the Polls Say About Harris That the Trump Team Doesn’t Like
abstract: If a major change on the Democratic ticket fires up progressives, it wouldn’t be unusual to see a slightly higher number of progressive likely voters.
lead_paragraph: Now that we have a little more data about how voters are processing the new Kamala Harris-versus-Donald Trump presidential matchup, the poll unskewing — efforts to prove that certain unfavorable survey results are missing the mark — has begun.

headline: ‘We Have Created the Scarcity on Purpose’
abstract: Senator Brian Schatz of Hawaii discusses policies that can make housing and college more affordable.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has transformed the Republican Party on all kinds of issues — trade, foreign policy, immigration. He has challenged, even upended, the old consensus by giving people a very different story about what was wrong in America, about why they were struggling.

headline: World’s Five Leading Chipmakers Have Now Promised U.S. Investment
abstract: The announcement of CHIPS Act funding for a plant in Indiana means the United States will have attracted investment from the world’s top chipmakers.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Tuesday that it would award up to $450 million in grants to a South Korean chipmaker, SK Hynix, to help build its new chip facility in Indiana, in what officials described as a milestone in rebuilding the U.S. semiconductor manufacturing industry.

headline: Trump Pulls Out His Birther Bag of Tricks
abstract: Unmoored by Biden’s decision to pass the baton, the former president has fallen back on the instincts and base impulses that made him a political force.
lead_paragraph: For years, before he won the Republican presidential nomination in 2016, Donald Trump was something like the spiritual leader of the Republican Party’s right-wing base. He earned his place in the hearts and minds of conservative voters by doing what most Republican politicians at the time refused to do: He attacked Barack Obama as a foreign interloper and openly questioned his right to serve as president of the United States.

headline: The Tiny Chinese Restaurant That Became an Olympic Hot Spot
abstract: A few blocks from the table tennis venue, a restaurant has become an unofficial (and unlikely) clubhouse for fans, team officials and athletes.
lead_paragraph: As Tang Zhongqiu knows, there often comes a time in an Asian person’s trip to France when one grows weary of the endless parade of bread and seeks respite in a simple bowl of rice.

headline: Debby Is Expected to Bring Historic Rain to the Southeast. Here’s How Much.
abstract: The National Weather Service has issued strong warnings for Georgia and South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Debby, which came ashore as a Category 1 hurricane along the Florida coast early Monday, will move across the Southeast on Tuesday at roughly the speed of a human walking. That slow pace will allow it to deliver historic amounts of rainfall — most likely measured in feet instead of inches — that could lead to catastrophic flooding over the next several days.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 423
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Harris Is Said to Choose Tim Walz as Running Mate
abstract: Plus, the markets begin to rebound.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: What Just Happened on Wall Street?
abstract: Explaining Monday’s stock-market plunge, and its potential consequences.
lead_paragraph: Every major U.S. stock market plunged on Monday, wiping out billions of dollars in value.

headline: Historically Black Medical Schools Land a $600 Million Donation
abstract: Bloomberg Philanthropies gives what are thought to be record-breaking gifts to the endowments of Meharry Medical College, Morehouse and Howard University.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire and former New York City mayor, is giving $600 million to the country’s four historically Black medical schools, which account for a significant percentage of all medical degrees awarded to Black doctors.

headline: Musket Balls Found in Massachusetts Recall ‘Shot Heard Round the World’
abstract: The discovery of ammunition from the 1700s has revived tales of fighting at the start of the Revolutionary War.
lead_paragraph: Early last year, archaeologists discovered five round objects while working near trails at the Minute Man National Historical Park in Concord, Mass. The spheres ranged from as small as a pea to about the size of a marble and were scattered in the dirt near the site of a Revolutionary War battlefield.

headline: Global Stock Market Chaos
abstract: Monday’s tumult reflects an underlying reality: The U.S. job market is cooling.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was the worst day for U.S. stocks in nearly two years. Markets around the globe fell sharply; the S&P 500 index was down 3 percent.

headline: A Decade Later, ‘The Leftovers’ Seems Almost Like Prophecy
abstract: In interviews, the creators, Damon Lindelof and Tom Perrotta, look back at their HBO grief drama and how it plays differently after the coronavirus pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In “Guest,” an episode in the first season of the HBO drama “The Leftovers,” a woman named Nora Durst (Carrie Coon) approaches a disheveled self-proclaimed prophet named Holy Wayne (Paterson Joseph). She is looking for relief from the torment of her entire family disappearing in a Rapture-like event known as the Sudden Departure, and the prophet clutches her head and quotes from the Bible: “For whoever is joined with all the living, there is hope.”

headline: Who Is Muhammad Yunus, the Next Leader of Bangladesh?
abstract: Mr. Yunus, who received the Nobel Peace Prize for his pioneering work in microfinance, is widely respected in Bangladesh. The ousted prime minister largely saw him as a threat.
lead_paragraph: Muhammad Yunus, a Nobel laureate and microfinance pioneer, is set to become the interim leader of Bangladesh, overseeing a temporary government intended to help stabilize the South Asian nation after a month of political violence.

headline: How Google’s Antitrust Defeat Might Transform Big Tech
abstract: The search giant is likely to appeal a federal judge’s ruling that it abuses its monopoly in the lucrative online business. But the industry could still see major changes.
lead_paragraph: The federal court ruling that Google had abused its monopoly in online search threatens to disrupt one of the most valuable businesses in modern history, and Big Tech more broadly.

headline: U.S. Envoy Says Ukraine’s Economy Needs Reform and Investment to Thrive
abstract: Penny Pritzker, who is leaving her position as special representative for Ukraine’s economic recovery, said the country had made progress but still faced major hurdles.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has “made a lot of progress” on battling corruption, “but there’s work to do” before its economy can achieve its full potential, Penny Pritzker, the U.S. special representative for Ukraine’s economic recovery, said on Monday.

headline: Here’s the latest on the presidential race.
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris appeared for the first time alongside her newly announced running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, introducing him on Tuesday evening at a packed rally in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris appeared for the first time alongside her newly announced running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, introducing him on Tuesday evening at a packed rally in Philadelphia.

headline: ‘The More You Know About Something the Less Scary It Is’: The Week 7 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
abstract: Michelle Zhibing Zhou, 15, writes about a Science article highlighting new research that “sent ripples throughout the leech research community and shivers down my spine.”
lead_paragraph: For 15 years, our Summer Reading Contest has been inviting teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. This year, for the first time, students can submit either written comments or 90-second video responses.

headline: Hurricane Debby Sweeps Cocaine Worth $1 Million Onto Florida Beach
abstract: More than two dozen packages of cocaine were found on a beach in the Florida Keys, according to the U.S. Border Patrol.
lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Debby’s strong winds and heavy rain have downed trees, submerged streets and drenched neighborhoods across Florida this week. The storm also heaved an unexpected type of debris onto one beach: blocks of cocaine worth about $1 million.

headline: Tim Walz Is Kamala Harris’s Choice for Vice President
abstract: The Minnesota governor, a former high school teacher and National Guard member, brings to the ticket Midwestern appeal and a plain-spoken way of taking on Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris, the Democratic nominee for president, has chosen Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate, elevating a former football coach whose rural roots, liberal policies and buzzy takedowns of former President Donald J. Trump have recently put him on the map.

headline: Tim Walz Has Championed Climate as Governor
abstract: Kamala Harris’s V.P. pick, known for his folksy persona and rural Midwestern roots, has elevated the issue of climate change in his state.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of his two terms in office, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota has quietly emerged as one of the nation’s most forceful advocates for tackling climate change.

headline: Who Is Tim Walz, the Minnesota Governor Kamala Harris Picked to Be V.P.?
abstract: Mr. Walz captured Democrats’ attention with his “weird” takedown of Republicans. Here’s a look at the new vice-presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, few Democrats could have identified Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota.

headline: Walz Has Faced Criticism for His Response to George Floyd Protests
abstract: Some believe that Gov. Tim Walz should have deployed the Minnesota National Guard sooner when riots broke out following the police murder of George Floyd.
lead_paragraph: A little more than a year into Tim Walz’s first term as governor, he faced his biggest test.

headline: Where Tim Walz Stands on the Issues
abstract: As governor of Minnesota, he has enacted policies to secure abortion protections, provide free meals for schoolchildren, allow recreational marijuana and set renewable energy goals.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, the newly announced running mate to Vice President Kamala Harris, has worked with his state’s Democratic-controlled Legislature to enact an ambitious agenda of liberal policies: free college tuition for low-income students, free meals for schoolchildren, legal recreational marijuana and protections for transgender people.

headline: Whitney Museum Announces 2026 Biennial Curators
abstract: Marcela Guerrero and Drew Sawyer will organize the 82nd edition of the museum’s signature survey of contemporary American art.
lead_paragraph: The Whitney Museum of American Art has named two curators from its ranks to organize the next edition of its Biennial, what is arguably the most important art show in the United States. The 2026 exhibition will be helmed by Marcela Guerrero, who is known for elevating the work of Latin American artists, and Drew Sawyer, a photography curator who joined the institution last year  from the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: How Far Will a Reader Go to Hear Songs Inspired by Books?
abstract: In search of a connection between two worlds — one beloved, one baffling — a bibliophile made a musical pilgrimage.
lead_paragraph: Halfway through the first show of their summer tour, the Bookshop Band introduced a song written for the launch of “Underland,” Robert Macfarlane’s epic tome exploring the mysteries of the subterranean world.

headline: Axios Laying Off 10% of Staff
abstract: Jim VandeHei, the company’s chief executive, said in an email that the cuts were necessary to adapt to “changes in the media business.”
lead_paragraph: Axios announced on Tuesday that it would lay off about 50 employees, or roughly 10 percent of the company.

headline: A Harris Victory Would Give Minnesota Its First Female Governor
abstract: Lt. Gov. Peggy Flanagan would also become the first Native American person in the role.
lead_paragraph: If Kamala Harris is elected president alongside Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, who has been chosen as her running mate, the state’s lieutenant governor would get a history-making promotion.

headline: Decline in Veterans’ Homelessness Spurs Hopes for a Broader Solution
abstract: Two federal agencies, backed by ample funding from Congress, have quietly shown that it is possible to make progress on a seemingly intractable problem.
lead_paragraph: After two years in the Air Force and decades on Skid Row, Steve Allen was spending his senior years living in his car. John Sullivan, who joined the Army after seeing the film “Patton,” slept on his son’s couch. Home for Babs Ludikhuize, an Air Force veteran recovering from domestic violence, was in psychiatric care.

headline: 19 Facts About Tim Walz, Harris’s Pick for Vice President
abstract: Mr. Walz, the governor of Minnesota, worked as a high school social studies teacher and football coach, served in the Army National Guard and chooses Diet Mountain Dew over alcohol.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota was a virtual unknown outside of the Midwest, even among Democrats. But his stock rose fast in the days after President Biden withdrew from the race, clearing a path for Ms. Harris to replace him and pick Mr. Walz as her No. 2.

headline: Why the Electoral Math on Tim Walz Makes Sense
abstract: If he can reduce Trump’s numbers in rural counties around the country, Harris could win.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of talk that Kamala Harris picked Tim Walz to prevent Josh Shapiro’s views on the Middle East from becoming a distraction. But the more relevant reason that Walz was chosen is electoral.

headline: Comparing the Career Timelines of Trump, Vance, Harris and Walz
abstract: How the 2024 presidential and vice-presidential candidates’ professional records stack up.
lead_paragraph: How the 2024 presidential and vice-presidential candidates’ professional records stack up.

headline: Can Freed Russian Dissidents Help Energize an Opposition Movement?
abstract: The release of activists like Ilya Yashin gives new hope to a movement in which various groups are often at war with each other. But many have doubts.
lead_paragraph: Among Russians who oppose Vladimir V. Putin and his brutal Ukraine invasion, hopes are high that the Russian dissidents freed last week as part of a prisoner exchange with the West will breathe new life into a fragmented opposition force.

headline: More People Are Overdosing on Ozempic Alternatives
abstract: Some patients say it’s easy to get the do-it-yourself doses of compounded semaglutide wrong.
lead_paragraph: Three hours after Becky Cheairs injected herself with the first dose of compounded semaglutide, she started to vomit. Crouched over the toilet, reeling from nausea, she thought there was no way she would make it on the R.V. trip from Arkansas to San Antonio she had planned that weekend.

headline: Fifty Years Later, Philippe Petit Is Still a ‘Man on Wire’
abstract: The high-wire artist has a new show commemorating the 50th anniversary of his walk between the twin towers of the World Trade Center.
lead_paragraph: It was 50 years ago this week that Philippe Petit defied gravity, and the police, by walking a high wire between the twin towers of the World Trade Center, braving the winds some 1,350 feet above the streets of Manhattan.

headline: Festival Winners Crowd New York Film Festival Main Slate Lineup
abstract: Top titles from Cannes and Berlin, like Sean Baker’s “Anora” and Mati Diop’s “Dahomey,” join new work by Pedro Almodóvar, Steve McQueen and RaMell Ross.
lead_paragraph: This fall’s New York Film Festival will feature celebrated prizewinners from Cannes and the Berlinale, organizers announced Tuesday, unveiling a main slate that will join new works from the filmmakers Pedro Almodóvar, Steve McQueen and RaMell Ross.

headline: Scientists Find Arm Bone of Ancient ‘Hobbit’ Human
abstract: New fossils from Indonesia, including the smallest humerus ever found from an adult hominin, belonged to the tiny Homo floresiensis species, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: A new study describes 700,000-year-old teeth and arm bones from one of our most enigmatic relatives: a toddler-size “hobbit” who lived on a small island between the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

headline: West Indian Kedgeree Is ‘Comfort Food for a Quick Weeknight Dinner’
abstract: And more excellent dinner options built on freezer staples.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Mia here, filling in today for Emily Weinstein, who is on hiatus for the next few weeks.

headline: Sadness Among Teen Girls May Be Improving, C.D.C. Finds
abstract: A national survey found promising signs that key mental health measures for teens, especially girls, have improved since the depths of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, a survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on teen mental health focused on a stark crisis: Nearly three in five teenage girls reported feeling persistent sadness, the highest rate in a decade.

headline: 5 Key Reasons That Kamala Harris Picked Tim Walz
abstract: The vice president is said to have liked Mr. Walz’s policies, his Midwestern appeal, and the likelihood that he would be a loyal running mate and governing partner.
lead_paragraph: As Vice President Kamala Harris was landing on her choice of a vice-presidential candidate, a few things about Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota brought him to the front of the pack.

headline: Walz Grew Up in Rural Nebraska, Where Finding a Date ‘Was Kind of a Problem’
abstract: Tim Walz moved several times during his childhood in Nebraska, where his high school graduating class had just 25 students.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate, Tim Walz, wasn’t always a Minnesotan. He was born in rural Nebraska in the small community of West Point, a town of roughly 3,500 people 60 miles northwest of Omaha.

headline: Tim Walz Is the Veep’s Pick for Veep
abstract: Many Democrats see Tim Walz as the hottest Minnesota export since Scotch tape.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, nice to see you on this side of the day! I’m here to guide you through the morning’s big news. I’ll be back this evening.

headline: X, Owned by Elon Musk, Brings Antitrust Suit Accusing Advertisers of a Boycott
abstract: The company claimed that members of the Global Alliance for Responsible Media coordinated to dissuade brands from advertising on X.
lead_paragraph: X filed a lawsuit on Tuesday against the Global Alliance for Responsible Media, a coalition of major advertisers, claiming that it had violated antitrust laws by coordinating with brands to dissuade them from spending money on the social media platform.

headline: The Met Opera Plans a New ‘Ring’ With a Familiar Maestro
abstract: Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the company’s music director, will extend his contract and lead Wagner’s four-opera epic, in a production staged by Yuval Sharon.
lead_paragraph: Wagner’s “Ring” cycle is a mammoth undertaking for any opera company: a four-opera, 15-hour epic that features a cast of warriors, gods, giants and dwarves and some of the most daunting music in the repertoire.

headline: Microsoft Says Delta Was Largely Responsible for Flight Cancellations
abstract: The software company said in a letter that Delta Air Lines had falsely blamed Microsoft for its decision to cancel thousands of flights after a tech outage.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft criticized Delta Air Lines on Tuesday for overstating the technology company’s role in a costly disruption that led the airline to cancel thousands of flights last month.

headline: Who Is Gwen Walz, the Wife of Tim Walz?
abstract: As the first lady of Minnesota, Gwen Walz has championed criminal justice and education reform.
lead_paragraph: Gwen Walz, the wife of Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, has forged a career as an educator and school administrator, a background she has leveraged in her work as the state’s first lady.

headline: Utah Bans 13 Books From All Public Schools
abstract: This is the first time titles have been prohibited statewide, according to a free speech organization. The list includes books by Judy Blume and Margaret Atwood.
lead_paragraph: The state of Utah has ordered schools to remove 13 books from classrooms and libraries, including books by Margaret Atwood and Judy Blume, because they have content considered pornographic or indecent under a new state law.

headline: Masks Could Be Banned in Public in Nassau County, With Some Exceptions
abstract: Violators could be fined up to $1,000, although there would be exceptions for people who wear face coverings for health or religious reasons.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, masks were a symbol of a dire moment as the coronavirus pandemic surged. Less than five years later, they are again the subject of intense political debate, and this week, a county on Long Island took the unusual step of banning them.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Praises Walz as Representing ‘Heartland Values’
abstract: The former House speaker said that if Kamala Harris and Tim Walz, the Minnesota governor, win in November, “they have to govern from the middle for the whole country.”
lead_paragraph: Representative Nancy Pelosi, the former House speaker, praised Vice President Kamala Harris’s choice of Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate on Tuesday, saying he spoke to “heartland values.”

headline: Trump Campaign Attacks Walz as ‘Dangerously Liberal’
abstract: Republicans quickly zeroed in on the liberal policies Tim Walz has signed into law in Minnesota, as well as his handling of unrest in Minneapolis after George Floyd’s murder in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota received a frosty welcome to the presidential race on Tuesday from Donald J. Trump and other Republicans who accused the Democratic vice-presidential candidate of mishandling riots during racial justice protests in 2020 and tried to portray him as an out-of-touch liberal.

headline: ‘Why Trash Your Own Town?’ An English City Reckons With a Riot.
abstract: Days after an angry crowd marauded through Sunderland, people in the industrial port city are trying to make sense of what just happened.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday afternoon, as the pubs in the northeastern English city of Sunderland were filling with young men, Lesley McLaren made a decision: She was closing up shop early.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana Has New Dog Perfume. Veterinarians Turn Up Their Noses.
abstract: An extravagant scent might seem like the height of pampering for your pup. But veterinarians are raising red flags: “Overall, it’s a very bad idea.”
lead_paragraph: A smooth voice intones over swelling violins as a parade of pampered pooches poses on high chairs, each more extravagantly groomed than the last. “I am delicate, authentic, charismatic, sensitive, enigmatic, rebel, fresh, irresistible, clean,” the voice says. “’Cause I’m not just a dog. I’m Fefé.”

headline: 9 Killed After S.U.V. Flips Into South Florida Canal, Authorities Say
abstract: One passenger survived with serious injuries after the vehicle veered off a road in Belle Glade, Fla., on Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: Nine people were killed and one person was seriously injured after the sport utility vehicle they were traveling in veered off the road and overturned into a South Florida canal on Monday evening, the authorities said.

headline: Welcome to Our August Grilling Challenge
abstract: Today’s challenge: Master the basics.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to our August grilling challenge!

headline: Charles Cyphers, Who Played Sheriff Brackett in ‘Halloween,’ Dies at 85
abstract: He was known for his roles as the hard-nosed sheriff in the “Halloween” horror film series.
lead_paragraph: Charles Cyphers, who played the gruff and broad-shouldered Sheriff Leigh Brackett alongside Jamie Lee Curtis in the classic horror film “Halloween” (1978) and in two sequels, has died. He was 85.

headline: Tim Walz, a Fan of The Boss, Proclaimed a ‘Bruce Springsteen Day’ in Minnesota
abstract: The governor and newly-minted vice-presidential nominee has embraced the bard of the working man, honoring the New Jersey rocker last year when he came to St. Paul for a concert.
lead_paragraph: Last year, a blue state governor signed a proclamation declaring March 5 Bruce Springsteen Day.

headline: He Stands Out in a ‘Sea of Elites and Strivers’: Our Writers on What Tim Walz Brings to the Ticket
abstract: Opinion asked eight columnists and contributors to weigh in on how much the Minnesota governor will help Harris against Trump.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Kamala Harris announced that Tim Walz, the governor of Minnesota, was her running mate. We asked eight of our columnists and contributors to assess the pick by rating Mr. Walz on two metrics: how much he’ll help Ms. Harris against Donald Trump and how much enthusiasm he’ll generate.

headline: Iran Executes Another Protester After Trial Condemned by Rights Groups
abstract: Weeks after Iran elected a reformist leader, the authorities executed Reza Rasaei, who was arrested during protests that swept the country in 2022.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian authorities executed a 34-year-old man on Tuesday who was arrested during nationwide protests that shook the country in 2022 and who had been sentenced to death in a trial that rights groups condemned as unfair.

headline: Tim Walz Could Take It to the House
abstract: Football unifies America. Tim Walz can, too.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris has done a remarkable job of consolidating the Democratic Party’s base of women and voters of color since President Biden dropped out of the race just over two weeks ago. She is now polling in a virtual tie with Donald Trump.

headline: Queens Man Is Convicted of Spying on Dissidents for China
abstract: Shujun Wang, who co-founded an organization devoted to democracy in China, used it to gather information for the authoritarian country’s government, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A Queens man who billed himself as a scholar and a democracy activist was convicted in Brooklyn federal court on Tuesday of acting as a spy for the Chinese Communist Party.

headline: E.P.A. Pulls From the Market a Weedkiller Harmful to Fetuses
abstract: The herbicide, used widely on crops including broccoli and onions, can cause low birth weight and impaired brain development, regulators said.
lead_paragraph: In a move not seen for almost 40 years, the Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday issued an emergency order suspending all uses of a weedkiller linked to serious health risks for unborn babies.

headline: Hurricane Scale Alone Can’t Account for a Storm’s Destruction
abstract: Tropical Storm Debby was only briefly a Category 1 hurricane. But a rating can never fully capture how destructive a storm can be.
lead_paragraph: In its brief time this week as a hurricane, Tropical Storm Debby only reached Category 1, not enough to be considered a major hurricane. That hasn’t stopped the storm from causing plenty of havoc as it moves across Georgia and South Carolina. The National Hurricane Center predicted “potentially historic” rainfall of up to 25 inches in some places.

headline: Chloe Coscarelli Returns With Her Vegan Greatest Hits
abstract: The vegan chef has reopened in her original Greenwich Village location; Afghan delights in Beacon, N.Y.; and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Chloe Coscarelli — who got a fast start when it came to vegan dining nearly 10 years ago, then was ousted from her restaurant, By Chloe, by her partner — is back on track. She has reopened a casual restaurant in her original location and is in the kitchen as the chef. Avocado toast, kale Caesar salad, quinoa taco salad and roasted tomato-basil soup do not require kitchen magic to be vegan, but items like mac and cheese, a burger and a hot Italian meatball hero call for the sorts of substitutions that helped vegan food become mainstream. That also goes for the dazzling array of cookies and other sweets rolling out of the oven. She said that an expanded vegan pantry, a more receptive audience and no partner have inspired her this time around.

headline: Venezuela’s Strongman Was Confident of Victory. Then Came the Shock.
abstract: Venezuela’s government believed its control of all levers of power would give the country’s authoritarian president an Election Day victory. A rebellion by its supporters undid the plan.
lead_paragraph: For the Venezuelan government, everything seemed to be falling in place.

headline: Market Crashes Happen. They Don’t Necessarily Mean Much.
abstract: Don’t trust anyone who “explains” what just happened to stocks.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 19, 1987, Black Monday, stock prices plunged, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 22.6 percent in a day. Many commentators rushed to explain what triggered the crash — a response to some political event, some piece of economic data or whatever.

headline: German Court Fines Protester for ‘River to the Sea’ Chant
abstract: A judge said the phrase, used at a pro-Palestinian rally in Berlin days after the Oct. 7 attacks, “could only be understood as a denial of Israel’s right to exist.”
lead_paragraph: A German court ruled on Tuesday that a protester who shouted “From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free” at a rally in Berlin in October had condoned criminal acts — the Hamas-led terrorist attacks on Israel — and gave her a fine of 600 euros, about $650.

headline: ‘Rock Me, Joe’: 9 Songs With Great Guitar Cues
abstract: Celebrate the timeless rock ‘n’ roll tradition of a lead singer cuing up a guitarist by listening to tracks from Pixies, the Runaways and Jimi Hendrix.
lead_paragraph: It would be difficult for me to pick a favorite moment on the Pixies’ bizarro 1989 masterpiece “Doolittle” — a consistent favorite album of mine since I first heard it as a 15-year-old who had very recently learned what “Un Chien Andalou” was. But if you insist, I’ll zoom into the album’s dead center, in the middle of Track 7, when the lead singer Black Francis issues a command from the eye of the storm, intoning like his life depended on it, “Rock me, Joe.” On cue, the band’s guitarist Joey Santiago then lets out a brief but thoroughly face-melting solo.

headline: A ‘Stranger Things’ Prequel Is Coming to Broadway Next Spring
abstract: The play, now running in London, is set 24 years before the start of the Netflix series.
lead_paragraph: “Stranger Things,” Netflix’s enormously popular sci-fi drama, is coming to Broadway.

headline: Walz Instead of Shapiro Excites Left, but May Alienate Jewish Voters
abstract: Many Jewish organizations backed Harris’s pick for running mate, but beneath that public sentiment is unease over antisemitism on both the left and the right.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris faced a difficult choice when it came to Israel and her running mate: Selecting Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania could mollify many Jewish voters and other centrists over a subject that has bedeviled the Biden-Harris administration for nearly a year, Israel’s war in Gaza. It could also inflame the left, which has been protesting the administration for months.

headline: The Kamala Harris-Tim Walz Ticket
abstract: Readers offer mostly positive reactions to the choice of the Minnesota governor. Also: Clarence Thomas’s unreported trips; Jimmy Carter’s vote.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Washington U.S. Senate Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Washington primary election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Washington primary election.

headline: That Drone in the Sky Is Here to Warn New Yorkers About Flooding
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams, an avowed technology geek, is using the city’s drones to deliver a recorded message warning vulnerable New Yorkers of flooding dangers.
lead_paragraph: New York City officials have found a new way to deploy their stable of drones: flying them above vulnerable neighborhoods to blare safety messages that flash flooding may be coming.

headline: Nobel Laureate Tapped to Lead Interim Government in Bangladesh
abstract: The new government was being formed a day after Bangladesh’s longtime leader, facing fierce protests, fled the country.
lead_paragraph: The president of Bangladesh on Tuesday appointed Muhammad Yunus, a pioneer in microfinance and a Nobel laureate, to oversee an interim government, accommodating demands by protesters and offering a reprieve for a country scarred by violence.

headline: With Walz, Harris Passes on a Chance to Redefine Herself
abstract: There will be other opportunities to move to the center, if that’s a goal.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, Donald J. Trump said vice-presidential nominees have “virtually no impact” electorally.

headline: Tim Walz’s Big Climate Ambitions
abstract: Minnesota’s governor, Vice President Harris’s new running mate, has put forth one of the most ambitious climate agendas in the country.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, a former schoolteacher who was first elected to Congress in 2006, will be Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate, she announced this morning, ending several days of speculation.

headline: Walz’s Decades-Old Drunken Driving Arrest Draws New Attention
abstract: Tim Walz ultimately pleaded to a reduced charge of reckless driving after the 1995 incident, which his critics resurface to question his fitness to serve.
lead_paragraph: On the night of Sept. 23, 1995, a 31-year-old Tim Walz was pulled over by a Nebraska state trooper for driving a silver Mazda at 96 miles per hour in a 55 m.p.h. zone. The officer smelled alcohol, and after Mr. Walz failed a field sobriety test and a preliminary breath test, he was arrested and initially charged with speeding and driving while intoxicated.

headline: Niki’s Early Music Makes Her Cringe. Her Emotional Pop Is Growing Up.
abstract: The musician, 25, has paired raw honesty with synth-pop and R&B. On her third album, “Buzz,” she moves toward West Coast folk-rock and explores fresh heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: Niki — the Indonesian pop songwriter Nicole Zefanya — was 11 years old when she saw a Taylor Swift documentary that changed her life. “That memory is just a core memory of mine,” she said.

headline: It took 14 years and 86 days to make an Olympic champion in skateboarding.
abstract: Arisa Trew vaulted into first place with her final run, winning gold.
lead_paragraph: The winner of the women’s park event on Tuesday has been skateboarding for about half of her life. So, not that long.

abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Missouri primary election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Missouri primary election.

headline: Missouri Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Missouri primary elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Missouri primary elections.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Slunk Into Will’s Room and Under His Sheets’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: During our junior year of college, Will taped 50 squiggly worms to his bedroom ceiling, suspending each one on a bit of fishing line. Their little glow-in-the-dark eyes turned into constellations when the lights were off. Will cooked a lot, smoked too much and rarely let us see him upset. He is my best friend. Once, when the world felt like it was closing in on me, I slunk into Will’s room and under his sheets. I didn’t say a word; neither did he. He let me lay as long as I wanted. The stars looked extra wiggly that night. — Teigist Taye

headline: JD Vance Launches Trump Campaign’s First Volleys at Harris-Walz Ticket
abstract: Following a rally in Philadelphia — where the newly minted Democratic ticket will debut Tuesday — Mr. Vance cast the Minnesota governor as too extreme for office.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, on Tuesday criticized Tim Walz, hours after the Minnesota governor was tapped to be Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate, as too extreme for office, the latest in a series of attacks from former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign.

headline: Bangladesh’s Leader Fled Just Ahead of an Angry Crowd, Urged by Family to Go
abstract: As masses of people converged, angry at the killing of protesters, Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina insisted that she could hold on, which military leaders said would mean spilling far more blood.
lead_paragraph: The protesters were closing in.

headline: I Reviewed Restaurants for 12 Years. They’ve Changed, and Not for the Better.
abstract: In his last essay as a restaurant critic, Pete Wells reflects on a dining world of touch screens and reservation apps, where it’s getting hard to find the human touch.
lead_paragraph: This is Pete Wells’s last column as restaurant critic for The New York Times. Read more about his 12 years of reviewing here.

headline: Why Tim Walz Will Be a Potent Weapon for Kamala Harris
abstract: He is of a vanishing political breed: the heartland left populist.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris’s selection of Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate was, like most events of this turbulent political season, mostly unforeseeable just a few weeks ago.

headline: Trump’s Plan for Attacking Tim Walz: Paint Him as a Bernie Sanders Liberal
abstract: The Trump campaign had been preparing for Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania to be Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate. It now plans to stress Mr. Walz’s progressive governing record.
lead_paragraph: The Trump team was all set for Josh Shapiro.

headline: Joss Naylor, the English King of Racing Up Mountains, Dies at 88
abstract: A sheep farmer, he set records in so-called fell running — rugged off-trail competitions that can last days and present painful hazards, including an irate cow.
lead_paragraph: The “Iron Man” of fell running — the somewhat preposterous English sport of off-trail mountain racing — was Joss Naylor, a sheep farmer who, during multiday marathons traversing rugged terrain, endured the loss of all 10 toenails, the skinning of his soles and a kick by an irritated cow.

headline: Kennedy Testifies in Ballot Case, Insisting He Does Live in New York
abstract: In the wake of the revelation that he once dumped a bear in Central Park, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. appeared in court over a challenge to the address on his presidential nominating petitions.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. took the witness stand in Albany on Tuesday in his fight to keep his place on the New York ballot, a case that opponents believe could lay the groundwork for challenges of his candidacy in other states.

headline: This Program Provided More Than a Million Free Covid Shots. Now It’s Ending.
abstract: Clinics that care for uninsured and underinsured people say they are now scrambling to figure out how to pay for vaccines.
lead_paragraph: There are just two doses of a Covid-19 vaccine left in the fridge at Good Samaritan Health Centers of Gwinnett in Norcross, Ga. Once those shots have been used, the nonprofit fears it may have to charge its patients for what was once a free vaccine.

headline: Justice Dept. Charges Pakistani Man in Alleged Plot to Kill U.S. Leaders
abstract: Investigators believe that the targets of the man, who had recently spent two weeks in Iran, likely included former President Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Tuesday that it had charged a Pakistani man who had recently visited Iran with trying to hire a hit man to assassinate political figures in the U.S. Investigators believe that potential targets likely included former President Donald J. Trump, according to a senior law enforcement official.

headline: A Nashville Block Party for a Beloved Honky-Tonk
abstract: Hundreds of fans converged outside Robert’s Western World to celebrate a pivotal anniversary for its owner, JesseLee Jones — and the sounds the venue tries to preserve.
lead_paragraph: Step inside Robert’s Western World, and it’s the music that hooks you. Maybe you don’t know the words, maybe it’s the soundtrack your parents or grandparents loved. But there’s something about the rapid-fire twang of a guitar, the percussive pulse of a slap on a double bass that threatens to burst out of this old honky-tonk.

headline: Kamala Harris Isn’t Playing It Safe
abstract: In picking Tim Walz, Harris is after more than just Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: In picking Tim Walz as her running mate, Kamala Harris is after more than just Pennsylvania.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Harris Picked a Running Mate
abstract: Plus, how breaking made it to the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 100 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: Landlord Is Ordered to Jail Again Over Problems in His Buildings
abstract: A New York City landlord, Daniel Ohebshalom, already served a 60-day sentence on Rikers Island this year. But officials and tenants say he still didn’t fix his apartments.
lead_paragraph: Landlords almost never go to jail over bad conditions in their buildings. But one New York City property owner has been ordered to go back for the second time this year.

headline: Trump Campaign Criticizes Walz for State Law Providing Tampons in Schools
abstract: The law, which was passed in Minnesota last year, includes language requiring menstrual products to be available in bathrooms of all schools for grades 4 to 12 as a way to accommodate transgender students.
lead_paragraph: As part of their effort to portray Tim Walz, the new Democratic vice-presidential candidate, as a far-left liberal, the Trump campaign attacked the Minnesota governor on Tuesday for signing a bill last year that provides access to menstrual products for transgender students.

headline: Arizona Grand Jury Wanted to Indict Trump in Fake Electors Case
abstract: Court papers show that grand jurors signaled their interest in charging the former president, only to have state prosecutors advise against it because of similarities to a federal case against him.
lead_paragraph: A state grand jury in Arizona that charged 18 people this spring in a scheme that sought to overturn Donald J. Trump’s 2020 election loss wanted to indict him, too, according to court papers released on Tuesday.

headline: Trump Says Elon Musk Will Interview Him on Monday
abstract: The owner of the social media platform X has evolved from a skeptic of former President Donald J. Trump to one of his most influential supporters.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Tuesday that he would be interviewed next week by Elon Musk, the billionaire owner of the social media platform X and a former skeptic who has come to embrace his candidacy.

headline: Bush Administration Lawyer Whose Wife Was Killed on 9/11 Supports Plea Deal
abstract: In an exclusive interview, Theodore B. Olson called the agreement that was revoked last week “the best possible outcome.”
lead_paragraph: A former solicitor general of the United States whose wife was killed on Sept. 11, 2001, said he was relieved to hear that a plea agreement had been reached in the case, and puzzled when the secretary of defense upended the deal.

headline: New York City Faces Heavy Rain. Debby May Make It Worse.
abstract: The thunderstorms hitting the New York area are the result of the meeting of a cold front and a mass of very moist air.
lead_paragraph: The thunderstorms and flash floods expected in the New York City area from Tuesday into Wednesday morning would have occurred regardless of Tropical Storm Debby, as a cold front from the north meets a mass of extremely moist air hovering over the metropolitan region, experts said.

headline: Tim Walz Is Harris’s Choice for Vice President
abstract: Also, Debby is bringing historic levels of rain to the Southeast. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris announced today that she had selected Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate, betting that his Midwestern appeal and plain-spoken attacks on Republicans will help her defeat Donald Trump on Election Day.

headline: Who Is Yahya Sinwar, Hamas’s New Political Leader?
abstract: Mr. Sinwar, one of the main architects of the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel, has spent decades with the militant group, working his way to the top of its leadership.
lead_paragraph: Yahya Sinwar, the newly named political chief of Hamas and one of the architects of the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel, has long been viewed as one of the militant group’s most influential leaders, wielding outsize power while remaining mostly hidden in tunnels beneath Gaza. His selection on Tuesday as Hamas’s top diplomatic leader — replacing Ismail Haniyeh, who was assassinated in Iran last week — consolidates his power.

headline: Walz, Throwing Punches at Republicans, Makes His Big Entrance With Harris
abstract: As the vice president introduced her new running mate at an energetic rally in Philadelphia, he quickly demonstrated his ability to deliver searing attacks against Donald Trump and JD Vance.
lead_paragraph: America’s introduction to Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota began with a half-hour of cheering for Vice President Kamala Harris and ended with some of the sharpest attacks Democrats have leveled against former President Donald J. Trump and his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio.

headline: Hamas Elevates Gaza Leader Who Planned Oct. 7 Attacks to Top Post
abstract: The selection of Yahya Sinwar, a prime target of Israeli forces, to replace the assassinated Ismail Haniyeh consolidates authority in the hands of a hard-liner who is in hiding.
lead_paragraph: Hamas has chosen Yahya Sinwar, one of the architects of the deadly Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, to lead the militant group’s political wing, it announced on Tuesday, consolidating his power over Hamas as it continues to fight Israel in the Gaza Strip.

headline: F.B.I. Seizes Republican Lawmaker’s Phone Amid Scrutiny Over Loan
abstract: Representative Andy Ogles of Tennessee reported lending his campaign $320,000 in 2022 before retracting it.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. has seized the phone of Representative Andy Ogles, Republican of Tennessee, as it carries out an apparent investigation into his campaign finances.

headline: The World That Awaits the Next President
abstract: Maintaining our global primacy is worth the price in effort, treasure and sometimes blood.
lead_paragraph: Some questions for the next American president:

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Discusses Kamala Harris’s VP pick
abstract: The Aug. 6, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, reacting to Kamala Harris’s VP pick, Tim Walz. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Boxer in Controversy Over Eligibility Lets Her Gloves Do the Talking
abstract: Imane Khelif, of Algeria, moved past questions about her eligibility with a unanimous decision over her Thai opponent. She will now fight for a gold medal.
lead_paragraph: An Olympic boxing competition that briefly seemed to be about questions about gender, eligibility and international politics proved on Tuesday to be simply about sports, with one fighter beating another without inquiry or controversy.

headline: What Minnesota Voters Think of Tim Walz
abstract: The governor succeeded in projecting an avuncular image. But not all voters are convinced that he rose above partisanship or united the state.
lead_paragraph: If Gov. Tim Walz has achieved anything after 18 years in public office, it has been to convince many of his fellow Minnesotans that he is decidedly not weird.

headline: In Walz, Harris Sees a Battleground Strategy Dressed in Carhartt
abstract: Democrats think Gov. Tim Walz’s cultural ties are needed to talk to rural and working-class voters. But Republicans are not going to let his folksy style obscure a liberal record.
lead_paragraph: In selecting Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate, Vice President Kamala Harris has picked a partner who is many things she is not: a product of small-town America. A union member known to campaign in a T-shirt and camo hat. A white guy who exudes Midwestern dad energy.

headline: Key Election Results: August 6th Primaries
abstract: Get live election results from Kansas, Michigan, Missouri and Washington State.
lead_paragraph: Get live election results from Kansas, Michigan, Missouri and Washington State.

headline: Can You Heal Olympic Heartbreak With Belated Medals?
abstract: A weight lifter walked away from his sport after a bitter loss in 2012. He and other athletes, including a U.S. figure skating team, will receive their medals in Paris.
lead_paragraph: When Jeon Sang-guen’s barbell fell from his hands at the London Olympics, he knew everything was about to change. There would be no medal. No joyous celebration. His career in weight lifting, he knew in that moment, was probably over.

headline: ‘I Am Proud of My Faith’: Shapiro’s Fiery Speech Ends on a Personal Note
abstract: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania rallied Democrats in his home state behind the Democratic ticket after the conclusion of a vice-presidential search that prompted intense public scrutiny of his views on Israel.
lead_paragraph: For years, Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania has said that his Jewish faith drives his commitment to public service.

headline: Federal Appeals Court Upholds Maryland’s Ban on Semiautomatic Rifles
abstract: The court found that the law did not violate the requirements in a recent ruling that expanded gun rights. Lawyers for one of the plaintiffs said they would request Supreme Court review.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Tuesday rejected an effort by gun control opponents to throw out Maryland’s ban on semiautomatic rifles like the AR-15, setting up a potential challenge that could further define the limits of the Supreme Court’s sweeping expansion of gun rights in 2022.

headline: Georgia Board Grants Local Officials New Power Over Certifying Elections
abstract: Across the country, conservative organizations and allies of former President Donald J. Trump have sought to grant local election officials more authority over the certification process.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-controlled Georgia State Election Board approved on Tuesday a measure that could empower local officials to refuse or delay certification of a county’s election results, creating the potential for another disputed and contentious post-election period in November.

headline: Trump Campaign’s Attacks on Walz Over Felony Voting Rights Raise Eyebrows
abstract: Critics of the former president were quick to point out that, if not for policies like the one Tim Walz signed in Minnesota, Donald Trump himself would be barred from voting.
lead_paragraph: Republicans wasted no time in criticizing Gov. Tim Walz after Vice President Kamala Harris picked him as her running mate. But one of the Trump campaign’s attack lines landed awkwardly.

headline: 2 Charged With Hate Crimes in Vandalism Aimed at Museum Officials
abstract: A group of vandals splattered red paint at the home of the Brooklyn Museum’s director and others. The institution has become a target of people opposed to the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Two people have been charged with hate crimes, accused of being part of a group of vandals in June who smeared red paint and graffiti at the homes of the Jewish director of the Brooklyn Museum and other leaders of the institution.

headline: Apple Store Workers Get First U.S. Contract
abstract: The agreement at a Maryland store, the first to unionize, raises wages roughly 10 percent over three years and guarantees benefits and severance pay.
lead_paragraph: Workers at the first unionized Apple Store in the country ratified a labor contract with the tech giant on Tuesday, after a year and a half in which bargaining appeared to stall for long stretches and union campaigns at other stores fell short.

headline: Elissa Slotkin and Mike Rogers Will Face Off in Key Michigan Senate Race
abstract: Democrats were initially favored to hold the seat, but President Biden’s struggles in the state — fueled in part by Israel’s war in Gaza — shifted the contest to a pure tossup.
lead_paragraph: Representative Elissa Slotkin, a Democrat, and former Representative Mike Rogers, a Republican, will square off for an open Senate seat in Michigan in what is likely to be one of the tightest and most closely watched Senate campaigns in the country.

headline: Mexican Drug Lord Is Said to Face Trial in Brooklyn
abstract: The decision by the Justice Department will put Ismael Zambada García in the same federal courthouse where his fellow Sinaloa cartel founder, El Chapo, was sentenced to life in prison.
lead_paragraph: Ismael Zambada García, the Mexican drug lord who was apparently kidnapped by a son of his former partner in crime last month and flown across the border into the hands of U.S. federal agents in Texas, will soon be sent to stand trial in Brooklyn, according to four people familiar with the situation.

headline: What Tim Walz Brings to the Harris Ticket
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris is said to have liked Tim Walz’s policies, his Midwestern appeal and the likelihood that he would be a loyal running mate and governing partner. Katie Rogers, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, takes us inside Harris’s decision on a vice-presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris is said to have liked Tim Walz’s policies, his Midwestern appeal and the likelihood that he would be a loyal running mate and governing partner. Katie Rogers, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, takes us inside Harris’s decision on a vice-presidential candidate.

headline: Harris and Walz Hold First Campaign Rally Together
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris and her newly announced running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, went on the attack against the Trump-Vance Republican ticket during a raucous rally in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and her newly announced running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, went on the attack against the Trump-Vance Republican ticket during a raucous rally in Philadelphia.

headline: 4 Milwaukee Hotel Workers Charged With Murder in Fatal Pinning of Man
abstract: Four workers who pinned down D’vontaye Mitchell, 43, outside a Milwaukee Hyatt hotel in June were charged with murder. His family said he had been having a mental health crisis.
lead_paragraph: Four hotel workers were charged Tuesday with murder in the death of D’vontaye Mitchell, a Black man who died outside a Milwaukee hotel after being subdued by staff members in a scene that was recorded on video and caused a public outcry.

headline: Incumbent Andrew Bailey Wins Republican Primary for Missouri A.G.
abstract: He and his challenger, Will Scharf, were both endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Missouri attorney general, Andrew Bailey, won the primary election on Tuesday to be Republican Party’s candidate for attorney general in the November general election, The Associated Press said.

headline: Communicate Like a Sphynx
abstract: Meghan Morris makes no formal pronouncements.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: What’s Left on Your Summer Bucket List? Tell Us.
abstract: Summer is nearing its end — at least in spirit — and we want to know how you’re making the most of what remains.
lead_paragraph: Did you finish your summer reading pile? Have you watched to an outdoor movie or lounged on a beach yet? Have you summoned the energy to host a cookout?

headline: Introducing Coach Walz: Five Takeaways from Philadelphia
abstract: A glittering night aimed to energize Democrats and banish the doldrums that have gripped the party.
lead_paragraph: The campaign to defeat former President Donald Trump is going to be fun.

headline: Kamala Harris and ‘Coach Walz’ Ease Into Their New Partnership
abstract: A chemistry seems to be developing between Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, who looks as if he cannot believe his luck.
lead_paragraph: “Wow,” Tim Walz kept saying, his face spread in amazement. “Wow.”

headline: Wesley Bell Defeats Cori Bush, a ‘Squad’ Member and Vocal Critic of Israel
abstract: Her defeat is another loss for progressives in a race defined by Democratic divisions over the war in Gaza, with pro-Israel groups pouring millions into a campaign to oust her from office.
lead_paragraph: Representative Cori Bush of Missouri, one of the most outspoken progressives in the House, lost her primary on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, falling to a campaign by powerful pro-Israel political groups intent on ousting a fierce critic of the nation’s war in Gaza.

headline: Boeing Says It’s Changing Type of Panel That Blew Off Alaska Airlines Jet
abstract: The company told regulators the changes in design and production of the door plugs would allow its warning systems to detect malfunctions.
lead_paragraph: Boeing officials told regulators on Tuesday that the aircraft maker would make changes to how it designed and produced the type of panel that blew off an Alaska Airlines jet shortly after takeoff in January.

headline: How Kamala Harris Trusted Her Gut and Picked Tim Walz
abstract: The ambitious Josh Shapiro asked about his role as vice president. The battle-tested Mark Kelly was already seen as a third option. And the happy-go-lucky Mr. Walz promised to do anything for the team.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris gathered some of her closest advisers in the dining room of the Naval Observatory on Saturday, they had more choices than time.

headline: Patti Yasutake of ‘Star Trek’ and ‘Beef’ Dies at 70
abstract: Ms. Yasutake played Nurse Alyssa Ogawa in “Star Trek: The Next Generation.”
lead_paragraph: Patti Yasutake, the actress known for her roles in the hit Netflix series “Beef” and in “Star Trek: The Next Generation,” died on Monday at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 70.

headline: Mike Kehoe, Missouri’s Lieutenant Governor, Wins G.O.P. Primary for Governor
abstract: The winner of the Republican primary is likely to become Missouri’s next governor. But a ballot measure on abortion that is widely expected to appear in November could boost liberal turnout.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Mike Kehoe of Missouri won the Republican primary for governor on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, giving him the upper hand in a contest in November to succeed Mike Parson.

headline: Ferguson and Reichert Emerge in the Washington Primary for Governor
abstract: The two leading candidates, one Democrat and one Republican, have each emphasized their work in law enforcement, in a state looking for solutions to overdoses and violent crime.
lead_paragraph: Washington State’s closely watched race for governor will be a contest between two candidates known for their backgrounds in law enforcement.

headline: Race for Competitive Washington Congressional Seat Turns Into Rematch
abstract: Marie Gluesenkamp Perez and Joe Kent will compete again in November, two years after she beat him by less than 3,000 votes.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Representative Marie Gluesenkamp Perez won a seat in Congress in Washington State, beating her Republican rival, Joe Kent, by less than 3,000 votes.

headline: Quotation of the Day: He’s Still Walking a High Wire
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “People think in old age you cannot do anything anymore. I think it’s the opposite.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 7, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about Bishop Richard Henning being named the next leader for the Catholic Archdiocese of Boston misidentified the diocese where there were political questions on the church’s handling of sexual abuse. It was in the diocese of Rockville Centre, in New York, not in the Providence diocese.

headline: Does a Speedsuit Make You Faster? Maybe. Does It Look Cool? Absolutely.
abstract: Once an outfit strictly worn by sprinters, the single-piece speedsuit has become common among middle-distance runners. Its efficacy is beside the point.
lead_paragraph: Henrik Ingebrigtsen had no way of knowing that he was about to help shape the future of track-and-field fashion when, as a teenager in Norway nearly 20 years ago, he ordered a form-fitting one-piece speedsuit from Nike that was designed for 100- and 200-meter sprinters.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Kamala Harris’s choice for vice president.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 100 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: A Deal That Could Save Venezuela
abstract: A power-sharing deal may be the best way out of Venezuela’s political crisis.
lead_paragraph: It was a stunning victory. As results began to trickle in from around the country, they showed the opposition winning by a more than two-to-one margin. The once-formidable political machine in power proved to be no match for millions of voters who sent a clear message to their authoritarian leader: Your time is up.

headline: How Bangladesh’s Leader Lost Her Grip on Power
abstract: Once viewed as the hope for a democratic future in Bangladesh, Sheikh Hasina turned increasingly autocratic during her years as prime minister. Weeks of violent protests ultimately forced her from office on Monday. Mujib Mashal, South Asia bureau chief for The New York Times, explains how Ms. Hasina fought until the very end.
lead_paragraph: Once viewed as the hope for a democratic future in Bangladesh, Sheikh Hasina turned increasingly autocratic during her years as prime minister. Weeks of violent protests ultimately forced her from office on Monday. Mujib Mashal, South Asia bureau chief for The New York Times, explains how Ms. Hasina fought until the very end.

headline: Word of the Day: ideologue
abstract: This word has appeared in 32 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word ideologue has appeared in 32 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 19 in “Nguyen Phu Trong, Powerful Vietnamese Leader, Is Dead at 80” by Sui-Lee Wee:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: With ‘Sprint’ and Simone Biles, Netflix Fills Olympic Content Gap
abstract: New seasons of documentaries about running, gymnastics and basketball are being filmed this summer as part of a partnership with the International Olympic Committee.
lead_paragraph: The four-person crew from Box to Box Films, the production company responsible for the hit Netflix motorsports docuseries “Formula 1: Drive to Survive,” has often shot in lavish settings like Monaco and Miami.

headline: Capturing the Split Seconds Between Victory and Defeat
abstract: Faced with the challenge of quickly recapping Olympic events, The Times creates its own animated versions of competitions. The internet loves them.
lead_paragraph: It was the summer of 2016, and Derek Watkins, then a graphics editor at The New York Times, was staring down a challenge.

headline: Tax Revenues From New York City Office Buildings Rise, Despite Vacancies
abstract: The assessed market value of the city’s buildings is still growing, according to a report from the state comptroller, leading to a modest increase in tax revenue.
lead_paragraph: Even as office buildings in Manhattan struggle with vacancy rates hovering just below 25 percent, the assessed market value of New York City office buildings has continued to rise, fueling a slight increase in city tax revenue, according to a new state comptroller report.

headline: Manhattan Planned Parenthood Will Stop Offering Abortions After 20 Weeks
abstract: The shift came as Planned Parenthood’s New York chapter revealed plans to close four clinics across the state, as financial issues mount.
lead_paragraph: Planned Parenthood announced this week that its only Manhattan clinic would stop performing abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy, a significant shift in a state that has maintained and even expanded access to abortion in the two years since the Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to the procedure.

headline: Suga, of BTS, Apologizes for Riding Electric Scooter While Drunk
abstract: The artist’s driver’s license was revoked and he may face disciplinary action after failing a breath test, his agency said.
lead_paragraph: Suga, a member of the K-pop group BTS, apologized on Wednesday for driving an electric scooter while under the influence of alcohol, a violation of South Korea’s traffic laws.

headline: Disqualification Costs India a Gold Medal, but Its Future Still Looks Bright
abstract: The wrestler Vinesh Phogat had a chance to become the first woman from India to win an Olympic gold, but she was disqualified when she missed her weight class by a few ounces.
lead_paragraph: Three and a half ounces, roughly the weight of a small banana, three slices of bread, a deck of cards.

headline: Gunmen Kill New Zealand Pilot in Papua Amid Escalating Violence
abstract: Authorities in the Indonesian territory have blamed the killing on a separatist rebel group, which last year was responsible for kidnapping another New Zealand pilot.
lead_paragraph: A New Zealand pilot was killed by gunmen on Monday in the restive Indonesian territory of Papua, where violence between the authorities and separatists has escalated in recent years but where foreign victims are rare.

headline: What Does It Mean to ‘Engage Your Core’?
abstract: The advice is common — and vague. Here’s how to do it properly.
lead_paragraph: When I began weight lifting in my late 30s, my coaches often gave me a somewhat baffling cue.

headline: Before Reality Became Debatable, There Was ‘The Blair Witch Project’
abstract: Twenty-five years ago, the indie horror blockbuster compelled audiences to ask, “Was that real?” The question now permeates our age of misinformation.
lead_paragraph: “In October of 1994, three student filmmakers disappeared in the woods near Burkittsville, Maryland while shooting a documentary. A year later their footage was found.”

headline: Read Your Way Around Denver
abstract: Much of Colorado’s literature is about the flow of people whose imaginations, like the novelist Peter Heller’s, were ignited by myths of unbridled freedom. He recommends some favorites.
lead_paragraph: When I was 13 and visiting family in Vermont, my cousin Geordie handed me a copy of a Louis L’Amour western, one of the paperbacks sold in truck stops across the country. The snow was falling slowly on leafless maples and I read all morning. I was fired by images of aspen forests and rimrock and mesas, of elk stepping into high meadows. I can’t remember the title — the man wrote more than 100 pulp novels, mostly in his bathtub — but I remember the cover: a cowboy on horseback splashing across a creek, leading a packhorse. He was wearing a six-gun and looking over his shoulder with a hard, desperate expression, and I thought, “I want to do that: I want to be desperate and hard and unbeholden, and drift the high lonesome on horseback.” Years later, when I finally got to Paonia, Colo., I bought a horse and borrowed a packhorse and rode to Wyoming. I wore a cowboy hat that made me look like a mushroom. The trip took a month. The power of fiction.

headline: How to Win a Zillion Blue Ribbons? Ask the State Fair All-Stars.
