lead_paragraph: Very soon, the federal government may authorize the killing of nearly a half-million barred owls in the Pacific Northwest in a desperate bid to save the northern spotted owl. The killing could go on for decades.

headline: As Opioid Deaths Plague Baltimore, the City’s Strategy Is Silence
abstract: The city has declined to divulge its plans or hold hearings on one of the worst public health crises in the United States, saying it does not want to jeopardize its lawsuit against drugmakers.
lead_paragraph: For years, Baltimore’s leaders gave overdoses little public attention, even as the death rate swelled to unprecedented levels. But for a few weeks this summer, it seemed that the city would respond to its drug epidemic with new urgency.

headline: At 50, ‘The Texas Chain Saw Massacre’ Still Cuts Deep
abstract: Eli Roth, Paul Feig and other directors with movies out this month explain how this gory horror classic has inspired their work.
lead_paragraph: The movies never recovered after “The Texas Chain Saw Massacre” hit theaters in 1974. Focused on a family of cannibalistic, butcherous crazies living in a rural house of horrors, Tobe Hooper’s sleaze-oozing film rattled audiences and was banned in some places. It also inspired filmmakers to take horror in new, more brutal directions.

headline: A Hip-Hop Comic Book Star Comes to Life in Steel
abstract: A statue of Rappin’ Max Robot is bound for Paris. But first it’s making a stop in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll meet a new iteration of Rappin’ Max Robot that is bound for Paris, via the Bronx. We’ll also get details on Robert Kennedy Jr.’s testimony in the court case seeking to have him removed from the November ballot in New York.

headline: The Emotion I Didn’t Expect as a New Parent: Regret
abstract: A new father reflects on the feelings of regret he has around becoming a parent.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of How to Live With Regret, a series exploring the nature of regret and the role it plays in all our lives. Read more about this project here.

headline: If the Vicious Drug Lord Doesn’t Get Them, the Deadly Storm Might
abstract: In “House of Bone and Rain,” Gabino Iglesias sets a supernatural revenge fantasy against the approach of Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico.
lead_paragraph: In 2022, to observe the five-year anniversary of Hurricane Maria, the Whitney Museum of American Art staged a powerful show of contemporary Puerto Rican artists responding to the horror and inevitability of that Category 4 storm. The exhibition’s title borrowed a verse from the poet Roque Raquel Salas Rivera: “no existe un mundo poshuracán,” or, roughly translated, “a post-hurricane world does not exist.” The hurricane’s devastating effects, in other words, are being felt to this day.

headline: Bernie Sanders Thinks Trump Fever Has Broken
abstract: Democrats lost ground with rural voters. Sanders says Minnesota governor Tim Walz on the ticket gets them “back into that game.”
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday afternoon, just hours after Vice President Harris announced that Tim Walz, governor of Minnesota, would be her running mate, Astead sat down with Senator Bernie Sanders in Burlington, Vt.

headline: How to Avoid Another Recession
abstract: The Fed should preserve its option to pivot as new developments arise.
lead_paragraph: Financial markets have suddenly begun to price in the risk of a U.S. recession. The S&P 500 closed on Wednesday down almost 7 percent from one month ago, with nearly all of the decline concentrated in the past few days.

headline: The Political Appeal of the Aggressively Normal Dad
abstract: The vice-presidential candidate Tim Walz, and his online fans, have elevated Midwestern dad vibes into nostalgic art.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota presents as a regular dad from the Midwest. He hunts. He fishes. He ice fishes. He is a fan of football, whether high school, college or pro. He takes photographs of fun birds and posts them to social media. He is so normal that his normality has become exceptional.

headline: 100 Years of James Baldwin
abstract: How his “radical honesty” gave me permission to be myself.
lead_paragraph: Robert Jones Jr.’s first novel,“The Prophets,” was a best seller. But his path to becoming a writer was not easy or obvious. It was not until he decided to go back to college at 31 that he encountered, for the first time, James Baldwin’s “radically honest” writing. That fateful introduction produced a fundamental change in Jones’s life and gave him a new sense of purpose. Here, he remembers Baldwin and the essay that changed everything.

headline: Downsizing With $700,000 on the East Side of Manhattan, Where ‘Charm Is More Expensive’
abstract: To find the right one-bedroom, a couple eschewed prewar style in favor of a cookie-cutter co-op.
lead_paragraph: To find the right one-bedroom, a couple eschewed prewar style in favor of a cookie-cutter co-op.

headline: Harris’s Rise Has Unsettled Trump, Who Is Struggling to Focus, Supporters Say
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s allies want him to talk about the issues, but he seems distracted by Kamala Harris’s burst of momentum.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump dialed into “Fox & Friends” on Wednesday morning for his first interview since Vice President Kamala Harris picked Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate.

headline: A Grown-Up Take on Jell-O
abstract: Plus: glass cabins in Oregon, art about parenthood and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: In the morning, I splash water on my face and use Dior Prestige La Micro-Huile de Rose Advanced Serum and put on some SPF. After school drop-off, I do my real routine. I splash again with water and use Rovectin Calming Lotus Water Toner. I do three layers of that. I go in with [my brand] Eadem’s Milk Marvel Dark Spot Serum and then a thin layer of Cloud Cushion Airy Brightening Moisturizer. My sunscreen is Innisfree’s Daily UV Defense, which I’ve been using for 10 years. It’s sheer and gives a finish that’s not too oily or matte.

headline: Heat Waves and Droughts Are a Bonanza for Junk Food Companies
abstract: Heat waves and droughts are a bonanza for junk food companies.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of What to Eat on a Burning Planet, a series exploring bold ideas to secure our food supply. Read more about this project in a note from Eliza Barclay, Opinion’s climate editor.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Muttontown, N.Y., and Redding, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, three-bath house built in 1964, with a bluestone front porch, a foyer, wood-burning fireplaces in the living room and the den, a formal dining room, an eat-in kitchen, a sunroom, a laundry room on the main floor, an updated roof and windows, and an attached two-car garage with loft storage, on 2.18 acres. Patricia Cadavid, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 516-459-6480; danielgale.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are in the East Village, on the Upper West Side and in Hunters Point.
lead_paragraph: A newly renovated one-bedroom, two-bath, roughly 1,400-square-foot apartment with quartz countertops, a breakfast bar, an open living/dining room with a skylight, a den/home office with a Murphy bed, a primary suite with a walk-in closet, skylights, built-ins, zoned heating and air-conditioning, Bluetooth surround sound and wood-burning fireplaces, on the top floor of a five-story self-managed co-op in a brownstone from 1848 that’s a designated landmark. Grant Braswell, Sahar Aubon and Patrick Esparrago, Compass, 202-841-2370; compass.com

headline: Help! I’ve Been Ripped Off. I Want My Money Back!
abstract: Our columnist addresses a case of wire fraud, a credit card scheme and a dubious website — just three examples of the types of reader woe that regularly surface in the Tripped Up inbox.
lead_paragraph: I took a 7.95-euro taxi ride in Paris and charged it to my Citi credit card, but the driver refused to provide a receipt, and my card was charged $795.85. Citi would not reimburse this obvious fraud. Can you help? Ann, Philadelphia

headline: Opinion Today: How to Live With Regret
abstract: “No regrets,” sounds nice, but is it real? Would we even want it to be?
lead_paragraph: “No regrets.” It’s a phrase you come across a lot these days. It’s on T-shirts and bumper stickers. It’s in Instagram bios and pop songs. It is tattooed on forearms and emblazoned on the covers of self-help books.

headline: Vibes and Polls and Positioning of the Harris Candidacy
abstract: Trump campaign staffers may be able to define her if she doesn’t beat them to the punch.
lead_paragraph: As I wrote Tuesday, Kamala Harris passed on an opportunity to define herself as a moderate when she selected the progressive favorite Tim Walz as her running mate over more moderate options.

headline: U.S. ‘Dissatisfied’ With China’s Disclosures About Stabbings
abstract: The U.S. ambassador has criticized the handling of an attack on four instructors from an American college, but China’s foreign ministry called it an “isolated incident.”
lead_paragraph: The incident passed in moments: Two American instructors from a college in Iowa were each stabbed in the back on June 10 in northeast China. Two of their colleagues were then slashed on their left arms as they turned to face the assailant. A Chinese national who tried to intervene was knifed in the abdomen.

headline: U.K. Officials Express Relief After Far-Right Protests Fail to Materialize
abstract: The authorities had been braced for further violence after anti-immigrant demonstrations in previous days had descended into riots.
lead_paragraph: British officials on Thursday expressed relief and cautious optimism after far-right protests failed to materialize the previous night and thousands of antiracism demonstrators took to the streets instead.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,147
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, August 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 425
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Aug. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Philosopher Kwame Anthony Appiah Wins Kluge Humanities Prize
abstract: Appiah, a scholar who is known for his approaches to ethics, language, nationality and race, will receive the honor from the Library of Congress.
lead_paragraph: The philosopher Kwame Anthony Appiah is this year’s winner of the John W. Kluge Prize for Achievement in the Study of Humanity, a $500,000 prize awarded by the Library of Congress recognizing work in disciplines not covered by the Nobel Prizes.

headline: Dispatches From a Kamala Harris Field Office
abstract: One group of voters may pose the biggest challenge to Democrats’ momentum.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s ascent to the top of the Democratic ticket has transformed the U.S. presidential race. But the real test awaits: Will the party be able to translate that energy into a winning coalition of voters in November?

headline: The Campaign for the Midwest, and Antiracism Demonstrations in the U.K.
abstract: Plus, a Hawaiian town debates how to rebuild.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Americans’ Struggle with Mental Health
abstract: We explore why rates of anxiety and depression are higher than they were before the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: It is no mystery why rates of anxiety and depression in the United States climbed in 2020, at the height of the pandemic. But then life began a slow return to normal. Why haven’t rates of distress returned to normal, too?

headline: How Anti-Immigrant Riots Flared in the U.K.
abstract: A far-right movement fueled by disinformation has brought fear and violence to cities across England and in Northern Ireland. That has in turn prompted counterprotests.
lead_paragraph: After more than a week of sporadic far-right violence, a fever seemed to ease in Britain on Wednesday night. An unconfirmed list of more than 30 target sites associated with the migration system, widely circulated online, summoned few would-be rioters but drew a heavy police presence and large crowds of protective counterprotesters.

headline: ‘Dance First’ Review: Beckett Encounters Himself
abstract: Samuel Beckett’s life is reduced to mommy and daddy issues in a biopic that offers simple explanations for the career of a complex writer.
lead_paragraph: It may well be that the happiest day of Samuel Beckett’s boyhood was when he flew a kite with his father. It may also be that one of his great regrets was not winning the approval of his disciplinarian mother.

headline: ‘Girl You Know It’s True’ Review: Milli Vanilli, Fictionalized. Again.
abstract: This film, based on the lives of the duo who lip-synced their way to stardom and downfall, fills in many of the details behind the facade.
lead_paragraph: The true story of the 1980s German musical duo Milli Vanilli could be seen by cynical observers to have begun as farce and ended as tragedy. But despite this fictionalized film’s arguably goofy direct-address narration — from the actors playing the duo — it takes its subjects and their convoluted, unfortunate circumstances seriously.

headline: ‘The Instigators’ Review: Bumblers in Beantown
abstract: Casey Affleck and Matt Damon star in a Boston heist that goes sideways.
lead_paragraph: The best joke in “The Instigators” is a crack about the public school curriculum in Quincy, the suburb just south of Boston that outsiders never pronounce correctly. (It’s closer to a “z” than an “s.”) It feels like an inside joke, as do later affectionate jabs at other Greater Boston locales, lingo and corrupt politicians. This is sort of a heist movie, but it is first and foremost a Boston movie, full of Boston guys and Boston accents and (South) Boston places and Boston humor. Heck, “The Instigators” is practically Boston: The Immersive Experience.

headline: Are We Happy Yet?
abstract: The American obsession with individually defining, tracking and boosting happiness may be making us miserable.
lead_paragraph: Three times a day my phone pings with a notification telling me that I have a new happiness survey to take. The survey, from TrackYourHappiness.org, asks me a series of questions about what I was doing the moment right before I take it, whether I wanted to be doing it, how focused I was on my task, how productive I was being and how happy I felt about it all. I measure my emotional levels with a little toggle that slides from “bad” to “good.” Though the trackers’ authors offer a disclaimer that “correlation does not prove causation,” results from thousands of its users published in 2010 suggest that people are happier when they are focused.

headline: What’s Driving the Topsy-Turvy Markets
abstract: A key jobless claims report could join a hiring slowdown, corporate earnings, and growth worries weighing on investors during an August to forget.
lead_paragraph: Even by August’s typically volatile standards, markets have been especially choppy this month, with some of the biggest intraday stock swings of the year occurring over the past week.

headline: 2 Youths Planned Attacks on Taylor Swift’s Vienna Concerts, Authorities Say
abstract: A suspect confessed to a plot using explosives and other weapons to kill as many attendees as possible, security officials said. The singer’s three-concert Vienna run was canceled.
lead_paragraph: The youths accused of planning to attack a Taylor Swift concert in Vienna had hoped to kill as many people as possible, the Austrian authorities said on Thursday, outlining a plot designed to copy some of the worst terrorist assaults of the last decade.

headline: Olympic Medals Offer Ukraine a Brief Respite From War
abstract: Ukraine has won 10 medals so far at the Paris Olympics. Each has been celebrated in the war-torn country as a symbol of resilience and defiance.
lead_paragraph: Yevhen Litvinov was brushing his teeth on Thursday morning when his phone started buzzing — a friend had sent him a YouTube video showing the victory of the Ukrainian boxer Oleksandr Khyzhniak at the Paris Olympics overnight.

headline: CNN’s Media Chronicler Strikes Out on His Own
abstract: Oliver Darcy is starting a subscription-based news site dedicated to covering the media industry, joining a crowded field.
lead_paragraph: Just how big is the market for news about the news?

headline: Trump Says He Will Hold a News Conference at Mar-a-Lago on Thursday
abstract: The former president’s prominence in news coverage has slipped since President Biden withdrew from the race and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump plans to hold a “general news conference” on Thursday afternoon at his private club and home, Mar-a-Lago, the first such event he has held in months.

headline: Burned Out of Lahaina, Thousands Try to Rebuild Lives Elsewhere
abstract: Many struggled to find housing and work after the wildfire destroyed the seaside town on Maui last year. But they have faced new hardships.
lead_paragraph: For Ernesto Perez, life on Maui wasn’t easy. But it was pleasant and peaceful, and a long way from the cartel violence of Mexico that his family escaped nearly three decades ago.

headline: 36 Hours in Helsinki
abstract: Find the secret to happiness in Finland’s capital — perhaps while sweating in a wood-burning sauna or sipping cocktails on a schooner.
lead_paragraph: Find the secret to happiness in Finland’s capital — perhaps while sweating in a wood-burning sauna or sipping cocktails on a schooner.

headline: Can Fed Officials Still Nail the Landing? As Rate Cuts Near, It’s a Moment of Truth.
abstract: The Federal Reserve was about to cut interest rates, turning the corner after a long fight with inflation. But now, its soft landing is in question.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s fight against inflation was going almost unbelievably well. Price increases were coming down. Growth was holding up. Consumers continued to spend. The labor market was chugging along.

headline: Kieran Culkin, Bob Odenkirk and Bill Burr to Star in Broadway ‘Glengarry’
abstract: A revival of “Glengarry Glen Ross,” David Mamet’s classic play about unscrupulous real estate agents, is to open next spring.
lead_paragraph: “Glengarry Glen Ross,” David Mamet’s Pulitzer Prize-winning drama about the world of unscrupulous real estate agents, is returning to Broadway next spring with a starry cast for its seedy offices.

headline: The Trial Judge Who Has to Clean Up the Supreme Court’s Mess
abstract: Judge Tanya Chutkan now has to determine which charges against Trump involved official acts, and which did not.
lead_paragraph: Pity Tanya Chutkan, the punctilious federal district judge in Washington who inherited the ill-fated Jan. 6 prosecution of Donald Trump one year ago and has since done everything by the book, only to be rewarded with an eight-month delay while the defendant pressed his claim that he exists magically above the law.

headline: From Tips to TikTok, Trump Swaps Policies With Aim to Please Voters
abstract: The former president’s economic agenda has made some notable reversals from the policies he pushed while in the White House.
lead_paragraph: At his convention speech last month, former President Donald J. Trump declared that his new economic agenda would be built around a plan to eliminate taxes on tips, claiming that the idea would uplift the middle class and provide relief to hospitality workers around the country.

headline: The New A.I. Deal: Buy Everything but the Company
abstract: Google, Microsoft and Amazon have made deals with A.I. start-ups for their technology and top employees, but have shied from owning the firms. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: In 2022, Noam Shazeer and Daniel De Freitas left their jobs developing artificial intelligence at Google. They said the tech giant moved too slowly. So they created Character.AI, a chatbot start-up, and raised nearly $200 million.

headline: What to Know About the Park Fire, the 4th Largest in California History
abstract: The rapidly spreading fire has consumed over 427,000 acres since it started burning in late July.
lead_paragraph: The Park fire, the largest wildfire currently burning in the United States, has torn through over 427,000 acres in Northern California in recent weeks and has destroyed hundreds of homes and other structures.

headline: ‘I Am Speaking Now’: At a Rally in Detroit, Harris Stares Down Her Detractors
abstract: The vice president’s reaction to pro-Palestinian protesters shows how she can turn efforts to rattle her to her own advantage.
lead_paragraph: When protesters first interrupted Vice President Kamala Harris at a rally in Detroit on Wednesday evening, she smiled, with a gentle corrective.  “I am speaking now.”

headline: These Chipotle-Honey Chicken Tacos Are Push-a-Button Easy
abstract: Let your slow cooker (or pressure cooker) do the work for this spicy, smoky-sweet five-star dinner. You’ve got some summer to soak up.
lead_paragraph: I know that back-to-school and cozy season messaging have begun to swirl around in the ether, but: It is still summer. I live in a part of the world that has particularly punishing winters, so you will have to pry warm weather and sunshine out of my sticky, sweaty hands.

headline: Over 100 Homes Damaged in Alaska After Glacial Lake Releases Flooding
abstract: The flooding this week in Juneau, Alaska, topped a record set last year when the same glacial basin overfilled, rapidly inundating nearby neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: More than 100 homes in Juneau, Alaska, were damaged by flooding this week after a glacial lake overflowed, sending surging water to nearby neighborhoods in what has become a recurring problem for people in the state’s capital.

headline: A Republican Governor’s Plea to Stop the Personal Attacks
abstract: Responses to an essay by Gov. Christopher Sununu of New Hampshire. Also: “Weird” as a campaign epithet; Cori Bush’s defeat; famine in Sudan; the 1964 World’s Fair.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Donald Trump, Prince of Self-Pity
abstract: There is no end to his hallucinatory disadvantages.
lead_paragraph: The size of the crowd at a rally for Vice President Kamala Harris in Atlanta last month rivaled the turnout for Donald Trump days later only “because she had entertainers,” Trump told the audience at his event, referring to the rappers Quavo and Megan Thee Stallion. “I don’t need entertainers.”

headline: 2024 on Track to Be the Hottest Year on Record
abstract: Last month was slightly less hot than the record-breaking July 2023, but the year is still likely to be the hottest ever, according to European climate scientists.
lead_paragraph: This year is on track to be the warmest on record after the previous high set in 2023, according to the European Union’s Copernicus Climate Change Service.

headline: ‘It Ends With Us’ Review: Love Hurts, and Sometimes Bruises
abstract: Blake Lively plays Lily Bloom, a flower lover with a thorny personal garden, in this gauzy adaptation of Colleen Hoover’s best-selling novel.
lead_paragraph: Buried under the gauzy romanticism of “It Ends With Us” — under the softly diffused visuals, the endless montage sequences, the sensitive mewling on the soundtrack and the luxuriously coifed thickets of Blake Lively’s sunset-on-Malibu-Beach dyed-red hair — is a tough little movie about women, bad choices, worse men and decisions that doesn’t fit into a tidy box.

headline: Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
abstract: Jillian Steinhauer covers Maria Prymachenko at the Ukrainian Museum, Khadim Ali  at Aicon and Jody Wood at Open Source Gallery.
lead_paragraph: If you know the name Maria Prymachenko, it might be because in February 2022, Russian forces attacked a Ukrainian museum that housed 14 of her paintings. People saved her art from the blaze, and Prymachenko — a cultural icon in Ukraine — became an international symbol of a nation’s resilience.

headline: Army Helicopter Crashes in Alabama, Killing One
abstract: The fatal crash of an Apache helicopter during flight training on Wednesday is part of what Army officials have called a troubling trend.
lead_paragraph: A flight instructor was killed and a student pilot was injured when a helicopter crashed at a military base in Alabama on Wednesday, according to military officials.

headline: Veterans and Lawmakers Lobby in Bipartisan Push for MDMA Therapy
abstract: The F.D.A. is poised to rule on the therapeutic use of the club drug Ecstasy, a potential watershed moment in the nascent field of psychedelic medicine.
lead_paragraph: More than a half century after federal regulators banned most psychedelic compounds, the Food and Drug Administration is nearing a decision on a novel treatment for post-traumatic stress disorder that pairs talk therapy with MDMA, the club drug commonly known as Ecstasy or Molly.

headline: Veggie Taco Party!
abstract: It’s my go-to meal for a crowd of vegetarians, or anyone who’d love stuffed pepper tacos, green peach salad with lime dressing and jiggly coconut pudding.
lead_paragraph: When my friends who don’t eat meat or dairy come over for dinner, I want to shower them with abundance. I want them to take a scoop of all that’s being passed around the table, and I want all the scoops to taste good together. In other words: I want my friends to feast!

headline: Teach Writing With The New York Times: Our 2024-25 Curriculum
abstract: Our nine writing units are based on real-world features like reviews, photo essays, narratives, podcasts and more.
lead_paragraph: Please note: Fully updated versions of each unit, as well as all supporting materials, will be published before each related contest opens for submissions.

headline: Harris Doesn’t Support Arms Embargo on Israel, a Top Adviser Says
abstract: Her national security adviser offered one of her first firm policy positions on the Gaza war a day after she had two exchanges with Palestinian supporters in Michigan, one cordial and one confrontational.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s national security adviser said on Thursday that she did not support an arms embargo on Israel, laying out one of her first firm policy positions since becoming the Democratic nominee on how she would approach the war in Gaza.

headline: U.S. Mortgage Rates Drop Sharply, With 30-Year at 6.47%
abstract: The key mortgage rate had its biggest one-week decline of the year, falling to the lowest level in 15 months.
lead_paragraph: Mortgage rates have fallen to their lowest level in more than a year, a balm for prospective home buyers and sellers in a challenging real estate market.

headline: Jake Paul Lends His Celebrity (Some of It) to Olympic Boxing
abstract: Paul, a social media influencer and boxer, usually promotes professional fighting. Now he’s in a partnership with U.S.A. Boxing, but his output in Paris has been minimal.
lead_paragraph: On one of Jake Paul’s recent Instagram stories, he voiced displeasure to his nearly 27 million followers at a decision by a set of boxing judges at the Paris Olympics. An American boxer had lost by split decision during a semifinal bout, and Paul labeled the result an “absolute robbery.”

headline: How Tim Walz’s Time in the House Paved the Way for His Ascent
abstract: The congressional voting record of the Democrat nominee for vice president shows his liberal streak, but with a deference to a conservative district’s needs.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tim Walz was traveling across his conservative, rural district in 2014, holding town halls across southern Minnesota, when a voter confronted him with a prickly question about his support for the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Where (and How) Americans Are Taking Advantage of Clean Energy Tax Credits
abstract: Households claimed more than $8 billion in climate-friendly tax credits last year, according to new data. Here’s who benefited and where.
lead_paragraph: Households claimed more than $8 billion in climate-friendly tax credits last year, according to new data. Here’s who benefited and where.

headline: The Barber Will See You Now. The World Will See You Next.
abstract: At the Olympic Village, cuts, styles and manicures are free. The benefits, the athletes say, are priceless.
lead_paragraph: They are one of the most popular teams at the Olympics. Their hand-eye coordination is off the charts. Their uniforms? Head-to-toe black and très chic.

headline: Engineered Virus Steals Proteins From H.I.V., Pointing to New Therapy
abstract: After promising results in monkeys, scientists plan to test the new treatment in a few people with H.I.V.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have developed a new weapon against H.I.V.: a molecular mimic that invades a cell and steals essential proteins from the virus.

headline: Anna Marie Tendler Knows You Think Her Book Is About John Mulaney
abstract: Ms. Tendler was a regular subject in her famous ex-husband’s stand-up. After a public divorce, tabloids have framed her new memoir as a tell-all about their relationship, but readers might be surprised by what they find.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2021, Anna Marie Tendler went on a first date at Ernesto’s, a Spanish restaurant on the Lower East Side, and made small talk about the menu with a man she had met online and vetted on a FaceTime call.

headline: Ship Brings Rocky Clues to Life’s Origins Up From Ocean’s ‘Lost City’
abstract: Scientists in an expedition to the Mid-Atlantic ocean ridge lifted almost a mile of precious rocks from beneath an exotic feature linked to life’s possible beginning.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have long argued that regions deep in the Earth’s oceans may harbor sites from which all terrestrial life sprung. In the Atlantic, they gave the name “Lost City” to a jagged landscape of eerie spires under which they proposed that the life-preceding chemistry may have churned.

headline: To Team Trump, Harris’s ‘Not Going Back’ Promise Will Prove a Big Mistake
abstract: The race has been upended with the replacement of President Biden. But the Trump team said Thursday morning that “the fundamentals of the race have not changed.”
lead_paragraph: Since replacing President Biden as the presumptive Democratic nominee, Vice President Kamala Harris has been punctuating her rallies with a new slogan: “We’re not going back.”

headline: Tropical Storm Debby Highlights the Southeast’s Climate Vulnerabilities
abstract: The region faces a confluence of factors, including the fastest sea level rise in the country, increasingly humid temperatures and extreme rainfall.
lead_paragraph: With Tropical Storm Debby unleashing a weeklong deluge along parts of the Eastern Seaboard, I’ve been thinking about an area of the country that isn’t always top of mind when it comes to the most severe effects of climate change.

headline: Advertising Coalition Shuts Down After X, Owned by Elon Musk, Sues
abstract: The Global Alliance for Responsible Media will dissolve after Mr. Musk accused the group of orchestrating a boycott.
lead_paragraph: An influential advertising industry group said it would shut down after being sued this week by X, Elon Musk’s social media company, according to an email sent to its members and obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Man Dies in Texas Lake During CrossFit Games Swimming Competition
abstract: Search-and-rescue teams were called after a participant in the event had not been seen in the water for some time.
lead_paragraph: A man was found dead in the water during a swimming event on Thursday at the CrossFit Games, an international competition being held in Fort Worth that draws some of the world’s fittest competitors.

headline: NOAA Forecasts Highly Active Hurricane Season Will Continue
abstract: The agency’s new forecast predicts that as many as 24 named tropical storms could form between June 1 and Nov. 30.
lead_paragraph: This year’s hurricane season could rank among the busiest on record, according to an update from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration on Thursday.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’: Meet the Candidates
abstract: Steve Martin is out, and the roles of Kamala Harris and Donald Trump seem settled. But the internet has been busy dream-casting the rest of the “S.N.L.” election ticket.
lead_paragraph: The approach of another presidential election brings with it many questions: In what direction is the United States headed? Who will be our next president and vice president? And, most crucially, who will play them on “Saturday Night Live”?

headline: Why White Supremacists Are Trying to Attack Energy Grids
abstract: An ideology with roots in white supremacist writings in the 20th century found renewed attention in neo-Nazi online groups in the 2010s and has inspired recent plots, say researchers.
lead_paragraph: Three men with ties to white supremacist groups were sentenced to prison last month for planning to attack a power grid in the northwestern United States.

headline: Los Angeles Actor Is Arrested on Sexual Assault Charges, Police Say
abstract: Gabriel Olds, who played the Christian broadcaster Pat Robertson in the 2021 movie “The Eyes of Tammy Faye,” has been accused of sexually assaulting three women.
lead_paragraph: A Los Angeles actor was arrested on Wednesday after three women accused him of luring them into a “false sense of security” on dates and then sexually assaulting them, the police said.

headline: What Debby Might Bring to New York City
abstract: The former tropical storm could unleash isolated storms and flooding on an already soaked region on Thursday and Friday. A separate system could bring heavy rains on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: The remnants of Tropical Storm Debby will surge northward on Thursday evening, diminishing in power but still threatening to bring isolated severe storms, heavy rain, flooding and even the chance of brief tornadoes by Friday to New York City and the Northeast.

headline: Students, Tell Us About Your Experience With the Summer Reading Contest.
abstract: This year we added the option of submitting a 90-second video response. What did you think?
lead_paragraph: As we wrap up the 15th year of our Summer Reading Contest, we’re seeking student voices on what it has meant to you to participate. In addition, we want to hear what students thought about this year’s new option to submit video responses.

headline: Our Student Podcast Contest
abstract: We invite students to create an original podcast of five minutes or less that informs or entertains. Contest dates: April 16 to May 14, 2025.
lead_paragraph: Do you listen to podcasts? Do you tune in to find out what’s happening in the world? To stay up-to-date on sports, music, film, fashion or TV? To get advice? To laugh? To hear a good story? To learn something new?

headline: Tiny Memoir Contest for Students: Write a 100-Word Personal Narrative
abstract: We invite teenagers to tell a true story about a meaningful life experience in just 100 words. Contest dates: Nov. 6 to Dec. 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Can you tell a meaningful and interesting true story from your life in just 100 words? That’s the challenge we pose to teenagers with our 100-Word Personal Narrative Contest, a storytelling form popularized by Modern Love’s Tiny Love Stories series.

headline: How to … : An Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers
abstract: We invite students to explain how to do any task in 400 words or fewer. Contest dates: Feb. 12 to March 12, 2025.
lead_paragraph: Do you know how to fix a brake light? What about how to memorize Shakespeare? How to keep a goldfish alive? Spot a shooting star? Write a love letter? Forgive someone?

headline: Open Letters: Our Opinion-Writing Contest
abstract: We invite students to write public-facing letters to people or groups about issues that matter to them. Contest dates: March 12 to April 16, 2025.
lead_paragraph: What’s bothering you? Who could do something about it? What could you say to them that would persuade them to care, or to make change?

headline: Dam Breach in Rural Georgia Floods Communities Downstream
abstract: The overflow sent floodwaters into neighborhoods miles away, causing property damage but no injuries, officials said.
lead_paragraph: At least four dams in Georgia were breached, releasing water as Tropical Storm Debby soaked the state this week. But only one of the dams posed any danger to people and property, according to information released on Thursday by the Department of Natural Resources.

headline: Swifties in Vienna Cry, Commiserate and Try to Shake It Off
abstract: Taylor Swift fans from around the world grappled with disappointment and fear after a terrorism plot derailed the Vienna dates of the Eras Tour.
lead_paragraph: Just as she was boarding her flight at Boston Logan International Airport headed for a Taylor Swift concert in Vienna, Mary DePetris excitedly checked the online fan group, Swiftie Nation.

headline: Trump Falsely Claims No One Died in Jan. 6 Capitol Attack
abstract: In fact, four of his supporters died in the crowd that day, and others died within days.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump claimed at his news conference on Thursday that no one died during the violence at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. But, in fact, four of his own supporters in the crowd that day died of various causes — and others, including a Capitol Police officer, died within days.

headline: Iranians Accused of Smuggling Missile Components Intended for Houthi Rebels
abstract: The Justice Department charged two Iranians with smuggling missile parts that were seized in January in the Arabian Sea. The search resulted in charges for four others and the deaths of two Navy SEALs.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has charged two Iranians with smuggling missile components bound for Houthi rebels that were seized in the Arabian Sea in January during a nighttime search that resulted in the deaths of two Navy SEALs, according to a court document unsealed on Wednesday.

headline: Mary Wings, Pioneering Creator of Queer Comics, Dies at 75
abstract: She was the first openly gay woman to write a comic book about lesbians. She went on to write detective novels with a queer woman in the lead.
lead_paragraph: Mary Wings didn’t know what “lesbian” meant until she was in her late teens — but as soon as she found out, she knew it described what she’d been feeling for years.

headline: 6 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Longtime readers of The New York Times may recognize the name Margalit Fox from the byline of some of our most memorable obituaries. But Fox (who worked at the Book Review before she started reporting on dead people, and who retired from The Times in 2018) has also written five books, on topics ranging from linguistics to true crime; her latest, “The Talented Mrs. Mandelbaum,” explains how a 19th-century Jewish immigrant worked her way up from street peddler to mastermind of a vast criminal enterprise that made her one of America’s first mob bosses. That’s one of our recommended books this week. Maybe read it with Dan Slater’s “The Incorruptibles,” which takes the story of Jewish organized crime in New York into the 20th century?

headline: Let’s Review Restaurant Etiquette
abstract: Three general managers weigh in so that everyone — diners and staff — have the best restaurant experience possible.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I noticed something peculiar. In the post-pandemic return to commuting, people seemed to have forgotten that if the train car is packed, you need to take off your backpack to make space. This rule, along with countless others, forms the bedrock of making the subway as pleasant an experience as it can be — even if that particular bar isn’t very high.

headline: Third Death Is Tied to Listeria, Health Officials Say
abstract: The death in Virginia came amid a nationwide outbreak linked to Boar’s Head deli meats. More than 40 people have been hospitalized.
lead_paragraph: A third person has died from consuming products tainted with listeria, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday, the latest death connected to a nationwide outbreak that began in May and has been linked to meats sliced at deli counters.

headline: 3 Columbia University Deans Who Sent Insulting Texts Have Resigned
abstract: The deans were put on leave earlier in the summer after sending messages that disparaged Jewish panelists. A fourth dean, who is tenured, will remain at the university.
lead_paragraph: Three Columbia University deans who exchanged disparaging text messages that the university president said “touched on ancient antisemitic tropes” during a forum about Jewish issues in May are resigning, a spokeswoman said Thursday.

headline: Mockery Won’t Increase Fertility
abstract: Culture warriors aren’t going to change plunging birthrates this way.
lead_paragraph: I am an enthusiastic natalist. By that I mean that I want our nation to grow, I want people to have as many children as they want to have, and I want those people who are on the fence about having children to feel encouraged about their ability to raise one.

headline: Every Four Years, He Gives Ireland a Reason to Watch Basketball
abstract: While the Irish have no team in the Olympic tournament, Timmy McCarthy’s eccentric, enthusiastic commentary has earned him his own fervent fan base.
lead_paragraph: Every four years, the Summer Olympics brings forth a collective fever dream of strange, communal treasures. We discuss synchronized diving instead of the weather. Flavor Flav is temporarily rebranded as a champion of women’s water polo. The phrase “pommel horse” re-enters our shared lexicon. Snoop Dogg feeds carrots to dressage horses.

headline: Friday Briefing: Trump and Harris Agreed to Debate
abstract: Plus, how Olympians get paid.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 90 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: ABC Says Trump and Harris Have Agreed to Debate on Sept. 10
abstract: The ABC anchors David Muir and Linsey Davis will moderate the candidates’ first face-to-face encounter since Kamala Harris entered the race.
lead_paragraph: The debate is on.

headline: Trump Suggests That President Should Have a ‘Say’ in Interest Rates
abstract: Donald J. Trump said presidents should have input on interest rates, a comment likely to stoke fears that he could try to limit the Federal Reserve’s political independence.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump suggested on Thursday that the president should have a say in setting interest rates — a comment that could rekindle fears that the Republican nominee might try to influence the politically independent Federal Reserve if he is re-elected to the White House.

headline: Trump Claims Jan. 6 Crowd Rivaled the 1963 March on Washington. Estimates Say Otherwise.
abstract: The former president said during a news conference that the attendance at his rally on Jan. 6, 2021, was equal, if not larger, than the March on Washington in 1963.
lead_paragraph: “If you look at Martin Luther King, when he did his speech, his great speech. And you look at ours, same real estate, same everything, same number of people. If not, we had more.”— Former President Donald J. Trump

headline: Noah Lyles Wins Bronze in 200 Meters, Then Reveals He Has Covid
abstract: Lyles said he started feeling ill two days ago and knew it was more than just soreness from winning the 100. In Paris, there are no testing requirements, and national governing bodies develop their own protocols.
lead_paragraph: Almost as soon as he crossed the finish line in the 200-meter dash on Thursday night, Noah Lyles looked winded. He lay on his back on the purple track at Stade de France, after finishing third in a race he had dominated for the last three years, and struggled for breath.

headline: Trump Tries to Wrestle Back Attention at Mar-a-Lago News Conference
abstract: In an hourlong exchange with reporters, the former president criticized Vice President Kamala Harris for not doing the same, insulted her intelligence and boasted about the size of his rallies.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump tried on Thursday to shoehorn himself back into a national conversation that Vice President Kamala Harris has dominated for more than two weeks, holding an hourlong news conference in which he assailed Ms. Harris’s intelligence and taunted her for failing to field questions similarly from journalists.

headline: Maine Will Vote on a New State Flag
abstract: A state committee selected a contest winner from more than 400 submissions. The Chuck Norris flag didn’t make the cut.
lead_paragraph: For more than a century, Maine’s state flag has been a bit cluttered.

headline: Jacques Lewis, French Veteran of U.S. Landing on D-Day, Dies at 105
abstract: Believed to be the last surviving Frenchman to wade ashore with Americans, he was attached to an Army unit that stormed Utah Beach and helped drive Germans out of France.
lead_paragraph: Jacques Lewis, who was believed to be the last surviving French soldier to clamber ashore with U.S. forces at Normandy on D-Day in 1944, died on July 25 in Paris. He was 105.

headline: Trump and Harris Agreed to a September Debate
abstract: Also, Ukraine launched a surprise push into Russia. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump held a news conference this afternoon at Mar-a-Lago in an effort to recapture some political momentum after Vice President Kamala Harris’s sudden ascent. During the event, he proposed three dates for debates in September, and ABC News confirmed that it would host a debate between Trump and Harris on Sept. 10.

headline: Newsom Clears Homeless Camps in L.A. County, Where He Wants More ‘Urgency’
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom, frustrated by county leaders who spurned his executive order cracking down on encampments, visited their turf to clear homeless sites.
lead_paragraph: The stop in Los Angeles came without the usual courtesy notice.

headline: 46 Convictions Thrown Out After Detective Lies Under Oath
abstract: The office of the Queens district attorney, Melinda Katz, had reviewed the cases after the detective, James Donovan, pleaded guilty to perjury last year.
lead_paragraph: A New York court set aside 46 convictions in cases that featured testimony from a former Police Department detective who had perjured himself, the Queens district attorney announced on Thursday.

headline: Rising Waters From Tropical Storm Debby Put North Carolina Waste Sites at Risk
abstract: Tropical Storm Debby brought intense rainfall and flooding threats to North Carolina this week, highlighting the vulnerability of hog lagoons and wastewater treatment plants.
lead_paragraph: As Tropical Storm Debby moved over North Carolina and raised the threat of flooding across the state, on Friday morning officials were monitoring more than 90 sites, including dams, wastewater treatment plants and lagoons holding animal waste,  a number that more than doubled since Thursday.

headline: In a Swampy North Carolina Town, Floods Are ‘Just Getting Tiresome’
abstract: The roughly 1,600 residents of Bladenboro, N.C., have gotten used to storm systems inundating their streets. And the floods just keep coming.
lead_paragraph: Emily Dowless was having trouble resting on Wednesday night. She looked out of a window at her home in Bladenboro, N.C., and saw sheets of rain inundating the city. Then a firefighter she knew in town called to say that the roads beside her small home décor business, Market on Main, were flooding — again.

headline: This Bawdy Dramedy Presents a Fantasy of Online Sex Work
abstract: A new Norwegian series on Max follows a stifled wife and mother who finds excitement and a new identity by posting explicit photos online.
lead_paragraph: The Norwegian dramedy “MILF of Norway,” (on Max in Norwegian, with subtitles, or dubbed) follows a stifled wife and mother looking for attention, approval, money, pleasure — a jolt. And if all it takes is posting some topless photos on the internet, what of it? “A little change should be fun,” her dry husband tells her. “You need that.” If only he knew.

headline: Sydney McLaughlin breaks her own 400-meter hurdle record. Again.
abstract: Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone broke her own world record on her way to winning gold for the United States in the 400 meter hurdles.

headline: Brooklyn Jail Is Too ‘Inhumane’ for 75-Year-Old Tax Scammer, Judge Says
abstract: A federal judge said he would sentence a man to house arrest instead of jail time if the Federal Bureau of Prisons sent him to the long-troubled Metropolitan Detention Center.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Long Island said he would vacate the sentence of a 75-year-old man convicted on tax fraud charges and instead place him on house arrest if he were sent to serve time at a troubled jail in Brooklyn, citing “inhumane treatment” at the facility.

headline: Duane Thomas, Enigmatic Running Back for the Cowboys, Dies at 77
abstract: He led Dallas to its first Super Bowl victory after engaging in a well-publicized contract dispute in which he called Coach Tom Landry “plastic” and refused to talk to reporters.
lead_paragraph: Duane Thomas, whose brief period of brilliance as a running back with the Dallas Cowboys in the early 1970s was overshadowed by a highly publicized contract dispute with the team that ended up shortening his career, died on Sunday at his home in Sedona, Ariz. He was 77.

headline: Biden and Leaders of Qatar and Egypt Plan ‘Final’ Cease-Fire Proposal
abstract: The leaders said “the time has come” to conclude a deal between Israel and Hamas, insisting that the negotiators meet in Cairo or Doha next Thursday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and the leaders of Egypt and Qatar said on Thursday that they were prepared to present a “final” cease-fire proposal to end the war in Gaza and called on Israel and Hamas to return to the negotiating table next week to settle the conflict.

headline: Rikers Inmates Are Routinely Denied Medical Care, Court Filing Says
abstract: The Legal Aid Society and Brooklyn Defender Services asked a judge to hold New York City’s Department of Correction in contempt of court.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Correction Department has failed to take detainees to medical appointments thousands of times every month, in some cases never notifying them and later saying they “refused care,” according to a court filing on Thursday by groups that have sued over access to health care in the city’s jails.

headline: House Republicans Pivot Scrutiny From Biden to Harris
abstract: Three months ahead of the election, congressional Republicans are moving to close a strategic gap.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Tonight, my colleague Luke Broadwater tells us how the House Republicans who have spent lots of time investigating President Biden are switching gears. And we have a dispatch from Donald Trump’s news conference at Mar-a-Lago. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Tim Walz and the Weird Politics of Free School Lunches
abstract: Another reminder that MAGA isn’t “populist.”
lead_paragraph: You could say that Tim Walz became the Democratic vice-presidential nominee with one weird trick — that is, by using that word to describe Donald Trump and JD Vance, a categorization that went viral. In his maiden campaign speech he upgraded it a bit further to “creepy and weird as hell.” (If you think that’s over the top, have you seen Trump’s bizarre rant speculating about whether Joe Biden is going to seize back his party’s presidential nomination?)

headline: A.C.L.U. Must Reinstate Employee Falsely Accused of Racist Language, Court Rules
abstract: The case put the legal group on the spot for taking positions on free speech and workers’ rights that seemed at odds with its mission.
lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union lost a case about offensive speech and workers’ rights — over its own workplace.

headline: Israel Prepares for Expected Attacks by Iran and Hezbollah
abstract: Israel advised people to stock up on food and water in fortified safe rooms, while Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told soldiers that Israel is “prepared for defense, as well as offense.”
lead_paragraph: Israel is girding for widely anticipated retaliatory attacks by Iran and Hezbollah, telling its people this week to stock up on food and water in fortified safe rooms, while hospitals prepare to move patients to underground wards and search-and-rescue teams position themselves in major cities.

headline: Samsung Recalls 1 Million Stoves That Started 250 Fires and Killed Pets
abstract: Thirty models of Samsung stoves were part of the recall over fires started by accidental contact.
lead_paragraph: A recall has been issued for more than one million Samsung stoves after hundreds of reports of them being turned on accidentally, leading to fires that injured dozens and killed at least seven pets, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said in a statement on Thursday.

headline: Donald Trump Can’t Get Over What Happened to President Biden
abstract: At a news conference in Florida, Mr. Trump said “the presidency was taken away from Joe Biden” by a cabal of Democrats including Barack Obama, Nancy Pelosi and Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: To hear former President Donald J. Trump tell it, he has just been heartsick over all that has happened to poor old President Biden these past few weeks.

headline: That Time Trump Nearly Died in a Helicopter Crash? Didn’t Happen.
abstract: In a news conference, the former president recounted a brush with death alongside Willie Brown, the former San Francisco mayor. A few aspects of the story don’t hold up to scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump told a jaw-dropping story on Thursday about nearly dying in a helicopter ride with Willie Brown, the former California politician and ex-boyfriend of his rival, Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Kamala Harris Isn’t Giving Interviews. Any Questions?
abstract: Critics say the vice president has been too cautious with the press. Her supporters think it’s the right strategy at the right time.
lead_paragraph: The press has questions for Vice President Kamala Harris. She isn’t giving a whole lot of answers.

headline: Entry Fee for Some Clubs
abstract: Hemant Mehta opens our solving weekend with one of the crunchiest crosswords in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Chi Chi Rodriguez, the Golf World’s Swashbuckling Champion, Dies at 88
abstract: He won eight PGA Tour tournaments and two senior majors — but it was his flair on the greens that made him one of the sport’s most popular players.
lead_paragraph: Chi Chi Rodriguez, whose flamboyance on the course and passion for the game of golf transformed him into one of its most popular players through his more than three decades on the pro tours, died on Thursday. He was 88.

headline: New Footage From the Trump Assassination Attempt Shows a Frantic Police Effort to Reach the Gunman
abstract: Bodycam videos and other footage provide new insights into the law enforcement response and presence at the building where the shooter was positioned.
lead_paragraph: For about two and a half minutes, at least five Pennsylvania law enforcement officers converged around the warehouse where a gunman had clambered onto a roof near a rally held by former President Donald J. Trump, struggling to reach the attacker before he shot at Mr. Trump, newly released police videos and a social media video show.

headline: How China Built Tech Prowess: Chemistry Classes and Research Labs
abstract: Stressing science education, China is outpacing other countries in research fields like battery chemistry, crucial to its lead in electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: China’s domination of electric cars, which is threatening to start a trade war, was born decades ago in university laboratories in Texas, when researchers discovered how to make batteries with minerals that were abundant and cheap.

headline: 3 Rings, 2 College Students and 1 Big Risk
abstract: Arya Singh let down her guard with Logan Mundy in a way she rarely did with others. Afterward, things became thrillingly normal.
lead_paragraph: Meeting someone from a dating app no longer seems like the perilous concept it once did — for most people. The risk assessment was different for Arya Channeng Singh, who was born with spinal muscular atrophy, or SMA, a neuromuscular disorder that affects motor neurons and, in her case, requires the use of a wheelchair.

headline: Nothing Messy About Their Love Story
abstract: As a houseguest in 2016, Daniel Weingart didn’t make a great impression on Aspen Matis. But her opinion of him shifted a year later.
lead_paragraph: Aspen Matis said she was turned off by Daniel Jordan Weingart after he stayed with her for a week in October 2016. The two had never met before.

headline: He’s a Man of Few Words. Especially Over Text.
abstract: Kate Mullen and Wes Skillicorn complemented each other’s personalities — especially when life threw them a curveball.
lead_paragraph: After connecting with Kathryn Elizabeth Mullen on the Hinge dating app in April 2020, Weston Hjalmar Skillicorn suggested meeting at 8 p.m. in a remote mountain location outside Denver to watch the sunset the next day.

headline: I’m a Stripper. My Boyfriend Saw Me Through the Eyes of a Customer.
abstract: My job has meant independence, healing and freedom. Why couldn’t my partner see that?
lead_paragraph: I was 24 when I started stripping. A friend and I were sipping tea on the couch, two young idealists in Berlin discussing how we needed money. From there, things went surprisingly fast, as they tend to do in this industry. My friend saw an ad on Craigslist, and not long after we found ourselves staggering half-naked down a smoky, strip-club hallway in high platform heels.

headline: How the Olympics Mascot Went From Bizarre to Beloved
abstract: Merchandise featuring the cheery red figure, which is based on a symbol of the French Revolution, has become a best seller at boutiques around Paris.
lead_paragraph: Some think it’s a cross between the Eiffel Tower and a beret. Others see it as a goofy, red French Smurf. Most people can’t even pronounce its name.

headline: No Corrections: Aug. 9, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Liverpool Sends a Message to Far-Right Rioters: Not Here
abstract: The city in northern England has a long history of protest. That tradition continued this week, with counterprotesters delivering a firm rejection of anti-immigrant violence.
lead_paragraph: The residents of the southeast Liverpool neighborhood of Edge Hill had spent Wednesday preparing for trouble.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Paris Strategy for the Dutch: Fist Taps Only
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It is the same with hydration, sleep, food. Everything counts. The details matter.”

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Plans for a Harris-Trump debate.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 100 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: My Beloved Italian City Has Turned Into Tourist Hell. Must We Really Travel Like This?
abstract: Bologna has turned into a mortadella nightmare.
lead_paragraph: A little more than 10 years ago, Bologna, my Italian hometown, was not really considered a big tourist destination. Group tours would come, but the city was primarily known for being the place with one of the oldest universities in Europe. Its cuisine — dishes like tortellini and tagliatelle — was an attraction, too, but in a subdued way.

headline: A Pastry That Tastes Like Home
abstract: The cheese scone is so essential to the New Zealand diet that it is almost impossible to find a cafe without a plate of them on the counter.
lead_paragraph: During a recent visit to Wellington, the capital of New Zealand and my childhood home, there were three things on my mind: Family, friends and cheese scones. Reconnecting with the first two was the trip’s purpose. The third is what got me really excited.

headline: Word of the Day: cuneiform
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word cuneiform has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 13 in “Who Kissed First? Archaeology Has an Answer” by Franz Lidz:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Olympic Marathon Course Is a Torture Test. That’s by Design.
abstract: “Oh, my gosh,” one Olympian gasped when she got her first look at the hilly, demanding course. “This looks ridiculous.”
lead_paragraph: Ed Eyestone is not one for hyperbole. A cleareyed coach and two-time Olympian, he will casually describe his athletes’ 23-mile training runs in a way that makes it sound as if they had gone for brisk walks. He understands that hard training is a part of the profession and that marathons are inherently challenging, so why oversell the struggle?

headline: Covering the U.K. Riots Amid Disorder and Misinformation
abstract: Megan Specia, who is based in London, discusses the countrywide protests that began largely because of false information online.
lead_paragraph: On July 29, a knife-wielding assailant went on a stabbing rampage at a Taylor Swift-themed dance class in Southport, England. Three young girls — ages 6, 7 and 9 — were killed and 10 others, including children, were wounded.

headline: A Growing Number of Homeless Migrants Are Sleeping on N.Y.C. Streets
abstract: As New York City officials struggle to provide shelter for nearly 65,000 asylum seekers, some have said they feel safer sleeping in parks, on the subway and on streets.
lead_paragraph: As New York City grapples with the formidable challenge of housing nearly 65,000 asylum seekers from the southern border, a related problem has emerged: A noticeable and growing number of them are sleeping outside.

headline: Was the Great Brooklyn Goldfish Heist a Rescue? Or a Robbery?
abstract: In Bedford-Stuyvesant, an animal lover thought she was doing the right thing by freeing fish from a sidewalk pit. The man who created the pond saw it differently.
lead_paragraph: The great Brooklyn goldfish heist started, as many dubious plans do, at a bar in the early morning. Inside the Bad Luck Bar in Bedford-Stuyvesant on Thursday, Max David and Emily Campbell met and hatched a simple scheme:

headline: On Netflix, a Very British ‘Love Is Blind’
abstract: The creators of a new version of the reality show, in which contestants agree to marry before meeting face to face, sought to challenge a nation’s archetypal reticence.
lead_paragraph: Tom Stroud, a 38-year-old advertising consultant, sits on the floor of a 12-foot-square room on the reality dating show “Love is Blind: U.K.,” facing a blank wall. On the other side is Natasha Waters, a 32-year-old job counselor, who has just told Tom that he’s everything she’s looking for in a man. He’s flattered — but he needs to let her know that he’s interested in somebody else.

headline: Keeping Up With the Reality TV Producers
abstract: The video game The Crush House asks players to race around capturing hookups and squabbles while catering to in-game audiences with very different desires.
lead_paragraph: The colors are bright pastels and, like in many reality TV shows, the setting is a Malibu beach home. But the extroverted cast members in The Crush House are as goofy and floppy-limbed as the inflatable figures outside gas stations.

headline: How Will Breaking Be Scored at the Olympics?
abstract: A panel of nine judges will apply Olympic rules to the dance form that originated as a free-flowing expression of hip-hop culture.
lead_paragraph: Amid the dynamic head spins, twirling windmills and athletic airflares that will be on display at the Place de la Concorde during breaking’s Olympic debut, one question looms large: When dance is crammed into the category of sport, how is a winner determined?

headline: Once Sidelined, Breaking’s B-Girls Now Throw Down at Center Stage
abstract: Women are competing in breaking in greater numbers and, thanks to better training and more opportunities, with more dynamic moves.
lead_paragraph: The story is an essential piece of hip-hop canon: DJ Kool Herc set the musical genre in motion at a party thrown in the Bronx in 1973. A detail sometimes left out is that the party was the brainchild of his sister Cindy Campbell, who wanted to collect enough money to buy new school clothes. That night, at their apartment building, he extended the breaks — the popular drum interludes in songs — allowing partygoers a longer period to show their moves and helping to launch breaking (never “break dancing”).

headline: A New Biography Attempts to Complicate an Elliptical First Lady
abstract: In “The Mysterious Mrs. Nixon,” the historian Heath Hardage Lee tries to give the oft-maligned “Plastic Pat” her due.
lead_paragraph: It’s no mystery why the first lady Pat Nixon was once the most admired woman in America. Silently glued to her adored husband’s side, perfectly poised Pat epitomized white womanhood on the eve of the feminist revolution.

headline: ‘The Garden Adds Color and Brightness to the City’: Letters From P.S. 130 Students
abstract: Elementary school children have been writing letters to Mayor Eric Adams in an effort to save Elizabeth Street Garden, where the city is planning to build housing.
lead_paragraph: When Dylan Sam, who just finished third grade at Public School 130 Hernando De Soto, found out that Elizabeth Street Garden was in danger of being demolished, he was shocked — and confused.

headline: How ‘Head Hunters’ Shook Up Jazz (and Herbie Hancock’s World)
abstract: The 1973 album proved that jazz could make a major impact on the modern pop mainstream. Its surviving musicians are reuniting for a Los Angeles concert this month.
lead_paragraph: Herbie Hancock still vividly recalls the night, 51 years ago, when the Pointer Sisters skated circles around him.

headline: Ferguson 10 Years Later: How Protests Gave Way to Politics and Policy
abstract: The shooting death of Michael Brown created a political incubator of emerging local leaders, some of whom are finding themselves in the corridors of power.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Brown Jr., an unarmed Black teenager, was fatally shot in 2014 by a white police officer and his body left in the street under the August sun, the small St. Louis suburb of Ferguson roiled and plunged into crisis.

headline: A Show of Support for Hamas in a Rival’s Backyard
abstract: After Hamas’s political leader was killed, some honored him in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, where a rival Palestinian faction is dominant.
lead_paragraph: On the day that Hamas’s political leader was assassinated in Iran, small groups of Palestinians in a number of West Bank cities turned out to protest, some chanting pro-Hamas slogans and waving the armed group’s green flag.

headline: Habitat for Humanity Helped Them Get Homes. An Insurance Crisis May Take Them Away.
abstract: In New Orleans, low-income homeowners are at risk of losing houses built by the nonprofit as more storms hit the city and property insurance prices soar.
lead_paragraph: The house that Kevin Hargrove built with the help of Habitat for Humanity volunteers had everything he wanted for his family: It was in the same New Orleans neighborhood where he’d grown up, with plenty of space for his daughters. A charity had donated furnishings, so as soon as the construction was finished, they stepped inside and it felt like home.

headline: Gay Men Have Long Been Obsessed With Their Muscles. Now Everyone Is.
abstract: In Hollywood, on Instagram and beyond, the male-on-male gaze still decides what’s hot and what’s not.
lead_paragraph: LAST FALL, I found myself facing a health issue caused by, among other things, a lifetime of running away from my own body. Getting better and stronger, my doctors informed me, would require the surgical removal of the air quotes I had for years placed around the phrase “aerobic exercise.” Henceforth, working out wouldn’t be optional, and it would need to be defined as more than a brief, daydreaming amble on the treadmill while Bravo played on mute in the background.

headline: ‘It Ends With Us’: Your Reading Continues Here
abstract: Whether the Blake Lively movie brought you to the Colleen Hoover universe or you’re a longtime CoHo fan looking for more emotional, spicy stories, these novels are for you.
lead_paragraph: In the past few years, no writer has dominated the best-seller list quite like Colleen Hoover. The prolific author was one of the breakout stars of the self-publishing boom over a decade ago, and her global following has only grown with BookTok’s embrace of her novels. Now Hoover — CoHo to her fans — is setting her sights on the silver screen, with the release of “It Ends With Us,” the first film adaptation of one of her books; the movie, starring Blake Lively and Justin Baldoni, opens in theaters Aug. 9.

headline: An Italian Nobleman’s Villa Is Restored to Its Former Glory
abstract: The eldest son of the Etro family joined the throngs buying up centuries-old properties in Puglia but had the good sense to leave his (mostly) alone.
lead_paragraph: “BY CHANCE, THIS has become a gay mecca,” says Jacopo Etro one September afternoon while drinking white wine, his Sicilian partner, Alessandro Genduso, off playing tennis, their 5-year-old daughter, Roberta, out with the nanny. “Because the prices are not so expensive and the beaches are nice,” he explains, adding that here in Puglia, the heel of Italy’s boot, people wake up each morning and decide, based on the winds, whether the Adriatic or Ionian Sea is calmer for swimming. Etro, who’s 61 and avoids the cruisier spots along the coastline these days, suggests another reason why men from Rome, Milan and other European cities have begun transforming the area’s castles and masserias into hotels and guesthouses, or why discreet foreign dignitaries have set up weekend refuges: For two decades, the region has been governed by leftists; Puglia’s current president, Michele Emiliano, “is very gay-friendly,” Etro says. The previous president, Nichi Vendola, who served for a decade until 2015, was himself a gay man, one of the first out politicians in Italy. But Etro has more outré theories, too: “It’s also because of the inhabitants, you know? Being a little bit Greek,” he notes with a smile, referring to when Puglia was colonized by the Greeks in the eighth century B.C. “There are a lot of bisexual people here. They get married and then go both ways.”

headline: How to Avoid Rental Car Toll Fees
abstract: Using the rental company’s transponder can rack up hefty charges, but there are workarounds, from apps to paying by mail.
lead_paragraph: Paying tolls when you’re driving a rental car is largely unavoidable, but you can avoid paying hefty fees just to activate the device that allows you to pay tolls.

headline: ‘Industry’ Is Back With Boats, Cocaine and Bigger Ambitions
abstract: In its new season, the HBO finance drama expands beyond the trading floor and moves into the network’s marquee Sunday-night slot.
lead_paragraph: The creators of “Industry” pitched the Season 3 opener to HBO with three words: “Coke and boats.”

headline: Is a Disney Theme Park Vacation Still Worth the Price?
abstract: As Disney has raised the cost of tickets and hotel rooms at its theme parks, and added pricey, difficult-to-navigate tools, even its most loyal fans are asking themselves if they should rethink their vacations.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Jake Williams, a filmmaker and content creator in Toronto, made his long-awaited return to one of his favorite places on earth: Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla. After traveling to Disney World and Disneyland multiple times a year since childhood and becoming an annual pass holder as an adult, Mr. Williams hadn’t been to a Disney park since 2019.

headline: $750,000 Homes in Belize
abstract: On Ambergris Caye, the Belize island known for its water sports and pristine beaches, buyers can find resort condos and single-family homes.
lead_paragraph: This two-bedroom, two-bath condominium is in the Phoenix resort, in the heart of San Pedro Town, a community of about 16,000 residents on the southern end of the 25-mile-long Ambergris Caye.

headline: The Pleasures of a One-Bedroom, One-Bathroom Cabin
abstract: “It’s probably the best place I’ve ever lived,” said the owner of a little house in the mountainous Methow Valley of Washington.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a certain kind of architecture buff, it doesn’t get much better than having the award-winning architect Tom Kundig — known for his inventive, industrial-looking structures — build your house. So when Chris Rogers commissioned Mr. Kundig to design his home in 2009, it was a dream come true.

headline: Don’t Get Fooled Again by Crypto
abstract: Politicians’ newfound love of crypto probably has more to do with a cynical bid for young voter support and Silicon Valley cash than a maturing of a financially perilous set of assets.
lead_paragraph: Crypto appears to be on the verge of mainstream acceptance. The price of Bitcoin, the original (and still most prominent) cryptocurrency, hit an all-time high recently, while the Securities and Exchange Commission has loosened rules that make it much easier to invest in crypto. Donald Trump is vowing to make the United States “the crypto capital of the planet,” and a new Republican-sponsored Senate bill demands that the Fed invest billions in bitcoin. Even Kamala Harris is reportedly more open than President Biden to crypto’s potential.

headline: How to Cope When the Markets Panic
abstract: Take a deep breath and make sure you’re well positioned for a potential storm, our columnist says. But stick it out for the long haul.
lead_paragraph: Time can speed up radically in the markets. It accelerated to supersonic speed over the past week, and you could have gotten whiplash if you tried to keep up with it all.

headline: 5 Ways to Improve Your Fitness on Vacation
abstract: Fitness experts share their tips for managing your workout routine while traveling.
lead_paragraph: The next time you’re trying to fit in a workout on a trip, it might be comforting to know that even fitness experts don’t necessarily recommend a “no excuses” attitude.

headline: On Governors Island, You Can Dance at a Jazz Age Lawn Party
abstract: Michael Arenella will be the bandleader at the event, and he’ll also be dancing the Charleston.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today, and on Fridays through the summer, we’ll focus on things to do in New York over the weekend.

headline: Nancy Pelosi: ‘It Didn’t Sound Like Joe Biden to Me’
abstract: The former speaker of the House discusses the election, Trump and the art of power.
lead_paragraph: The remarkable thing about the past couple of months in politics has been watching the Democratic Party act like something we have not seen for a long time — a political party. A party that makes decisions collectively. A party that does hard things because it wants to win. A party that is more than the vehicle for a single — usually — man’s ambitions.

headline: This New Olympic Sport Is One of America’s Greatest Cultural Exports
abstract: The hip-hop curriculum at this public high school in France helps breaking flourish far from the country where it was born.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, breaking makes its Olympics debut at the Place de la Concorde in Paris. This form of dance, created by Black youths in the Bronx in the early 1970s, has traveled far from its birthplace. It is now studied, practiced and performed enthusiastically in countries all over the world — and has inspired Olympic-bound B-boys and B-girls, as the dancers are called, from a diverse group of countries including Canada, Ukraine, Japan, South Korea and France.

headline: 7 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: In this romance based on the book of the same name by Colleen Hoover, flower-lover Lily (Blake Lively) falls in love with picture-perfect neurosurgeon Ryle (Justin Baldoni, who also directed), but discovers he may not be so perfect.

headline: Frame by Frame, Moments From the Summer Games
abstract: See the Summer Olympics in a series of composite images.
lead_paragraph: See the Summer Olympics in a series of composite images.

headline: What the Olympics Can Teach Us About Excellence
abstract: It’s not achieving a goal that matters.
lead_paragraph: We are drawn to stories of individuals who not only embody the pursuit of excellence, but also have humility.

headline: You’ve Lost Weight Taking New Obesity Drugs. What Happens if You Stop?
abstract: Many patients are eager to discontinue Wegovy or Zepbound when their weight loss plateaus. But doctors say it’s difficult to go cold turkey.
lead_paragraph: Susana Parks was delighted when she lost 40 pounds on Eli Lilly’s obesity drug, Zepbound. But now that she is at her goal weight, she has questions: Can she stop taking the drug? And if she does, how can she maintain her weight loss?

headline: Wall Street on Edge After a Week of Wild Swings
abstract: Investors have a factor to consider beyond the pace of inflation: Could the next sign of sputtering economic growth send stocks into a tailspin?
lead_paragraph: After a wild week in the markets that rekindled fears about the strength of the U.S. economy, investors are wondering what comes next.

headline: From Walz, a Rosier View of a Midwestern Upbringing
abstract: The major-party vice-presidential candidates — Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota and Senator JD Vance of Ohio — are presenting dramatically different recollections of their small-town roots.
lead_paragraph: In the western Nebraska town where Tim Walz came of age, teenagers gathered at the Frosty Drive-In after football practice and spent summers working on farms. Foosball was popular, and so was Pizza Hut. The high school mascot was a badger.

headline: Harris Used to Worry About Laughing. Now Joy Is Fueling Her Campaign.
abstract: Democrats are smiling again, and so is a vice president who once weighed the political risks of cheerfulness. The high spirits are also providing air cover for scathing attacks on Republicans.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, early in her vice presidency, when Kamala Harris, aware of reams of conservative news coverage criticizing her laughter, privately wondered to confidants whether she should laugh, or show a sense of humor, at all.

headline: Who Won Big in the Supreme Court’s Latest Term? The ‘Regulated Community.’
