abstract: The phrase, used across industries to signify a shared subjugation to regulatory fiat, has been popping up after three Supreme Court decisions last month.
lead_paragraph: As the dust settles from the high-octane Supreme Court term that ended last month, one clear winner has emerged: the “regulated community.”

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including screenings of “The Texas Chain Saw Massacre,” which soon turns 50.
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including screenings of “The Texas Chain Saw Massacre,” which soon turns 50.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Aug. 9, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 4 Ways to Keep Your Vacation Going After You’re Back
abstract: Those good vibes seem to disappear immediately, but it’s possible to extend them.
lead_paragraph: After I returned from a recent family vacation, I was struck by just how much time my husband and I spend discussing our paper towel supply. Are levels getting dangerously low? Is it time to restock? Our recycling bin comes up a lot, too.

headline: Google’s Monopoly Money + Is the A.I. Bubble Popping? + The Hot-Mess Express
abstract: “Maybe this actually is a chance to press the reset button on the internet.”
lead_paragraph: This week, a federal judge ruled that Google acted illegally to maintain a monopoly in online search. David McCabe, a New York Times reporter, joins to discuss what happens next. Then, are we in an A.I. bubble? We weigh in on the wild market swings that started the week and consider the argument that A.I. is overhyped. And finally, it’s time for our new segment: We bat around some of the weirdest recent tech drama — including a MrBeast competition that went awry and a founder who dropped a diss track aimed at a rival. All aboard the Hot-Mess Express.

headline: Why Vermont Is Nervously Watching the Remnants of Hurricane Debby
abstract: It appeared that the state would avoid widespread damage this time, but there is a growing realization that Vermont is more vulnerable than ever to flash flooding.
lead_paragraph: As the remnants of Hurricane Debby trudged up the East Coast on Friday, residents of Vermont, a state already battered by a series of severe floods, were once again nervously watching the skies and the rivers that course through the landscape.

headline: Tim Walz Is Vibing
abstract: Democrats are trying to make the election about who is cool and who is weird. Will it stick?
lead_paragraph: This week on the show, Michelle Goldberg joins Michelle Cottle and Ross Douthat to debate the gambles or gains Kamala Harris has made by picking Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate. They also discuss the ways the Trump-Vance ticket could recalibrate to regain their lead.

headline: ‘Mafia Spies’ Recounts the C.I.A. Plot to Kill Castro
abstract: The docuseries tells the bizarre but true story of the C.I.A.’s various schemes to use the mob to assassinate the leader of Cuba.
lead_paragraph: The stories have swirled around for years, often in the form of feverish conspiracy theories. The major players should ring familiar by now: John F. Kennedy. Fidel Castro. The C.I.A. The mob. Oliver Stone’s 1991 movie “JFK” raised the delirium to operatic heights; Don DeLillo’s 1988 novel “Libra” gave it a jolt of postmodern cool.

headline: A Must-See Film About a Terribly Difficult Subject
abstract: “Sugarcane” follows survivors and investigators after the horrifying treatment of Indigenous Canadians was discovered at residential schools.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to stories that hold the potential to slide from sensitive to sensational, documentarians can take several approaches. There’s the talking-head driven journalistic approach, in which the story and its analysis are laid out, beat by beat. There’s also the more lurid approach that films about cults and crime can employ, with re-enactments and ominous musical cues.

headline: About 400 Million People Worldwide Have Had Long Covid, Researchers Say
abstract: The condition has put significant strain on patients and society — at a global economic cost of about $1 trillion a year, a new report estimates.
lead_paragraph: About 400 million people worldwide have been afflicted with long Covid, according to a new report by scientists and other researchers who have studied the condition. The team estimated that the economic cost — from factors like health care services and patients unable to return to work — is about $1 trillion worldwide each year, or about 1 percent of the global economy.

headline: Meet Rebeca Andrade, Brazil’s Powerhouse Gymnast
abstract: Rebeca Andrade of Brazil, who finished second to Simone Biles in the all-around and vault finals, won gold in the floor routine. She talked to us about her experience in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Rebeca Andrade of Brazil, who finished second to Simone Biles in the all-around and vault finals, won gold in the floor routine. She talked to us about her experience in Paris.

headline: Cool Songs for a Hot Summer
abstract: New tracks from Jack White, Meshell Ndegeocello and more.
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, the chief pop music critic at The New York Times, recommends some rowdy rock, some unstoppable rhythms and a call for perseverance.

headline: The Real Reason Trump and Vance Hate Being Called ‘Weird’
abstract: It reminds voters how far out of the mainstream Republicans have gotten.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, Democrats taunted Donald Trump as “dangerous Donald.” In 2020, they moved on from dangerous to say that Trump’s Republican Party was a threat to the “soul of America.” Both messages — one relatively successful, one much less so — emphasized the threat that Trump posed to America and the world.

headline: After a Brief Appearance, Carles Puigdemont Flees Spain Again. Why?
abstract: The Catalan separatist leader, who has been living in self-imposed exile since a failed independence bid, vanished almost as quickly as he surfaced this week. Here’s what we know.
lead_paragraph: Carles Puigdemont, the fugitive Catalonia pro-independence leader, has dodged the Spanish authorities and fled the country again after popping up in Barcelona this week and holding a public rally, his lawyer said on Friday.

headline: A Swing in Momentum
abstract: We explain the state of the 2024 race.
lead_paragraph: Everything seems different now.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 426
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Aug. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,148
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, August 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Breaking’s Olympic Debut
abstract: A sport’s journey from the streets of New York all the way to the Paris Games.
lead_paragraph: More than 50 years after its inception, “breaking” — not “break dancing,” a term coined by the media and disdained by practitioners — will debut as an Olympic sport.

headline: Trump Tries to Retake the Spotlight, and Ukraine Pushes Into Russia
abstract: Plus, Noah Lyles’s Olympic run with Covid.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: As Ukraine Pushes Deeper Into Russia, Moscow Sends Reinforcements
abstract: The Ukrainian police said they were evacuating people, perhaps in anticipation of a retaliatory strike, but the goal of the military operation on Russian territory remained unclear.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces pressed deeper into Russia on Friday, trying to capitalize on their surprise cross-border offensive, as Moscow moved quickly to shore up its defenses against the largest assault on Russian soil since the war began.

headline: Appeals Court Orders License Restored to Philippine News Site Rappler
abstract: The case, brought after Rappler was singled out by former President Rodrigo Duterte, was one of many facing the outlet and its co-founder, the Nobel laureate Maria Ressa.
lead_paragraph: A Philippine court has reversed a ruling against the independent news website Rappler and called for the company’s business license to be restored, the company said on Friday, in a rare victory for the free press in Southeast Asia.

headline: Breaking’s Key Player Is a D.J. From Brooklyn
abstract: Stephen Fleg will help provide the soundtrack for a new sport’s Olympic debut. He gets to pick the songs, and the competitors have no idea what he’ll play.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Fleg has been training much of his life for his Olympic moment.

headline: Belarus Casts Aside Dissident Athletes, Their Talent ‘Buried’
abstract: Many elite athletes who spoke against their autocratic leader must watch on the sidelines while those who stayed quiet or showed loyalty compete in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The Belarusian-born sprinter Kristina Timanovskaya set off the biggest political crisis of the Tokyo Games after her delegation tried to forcibly send her home for publicly complaining that the head coach had signed her up for the wrong Olympic event.

headline: 3rd Teenager Arrested in Planned Attack on Taylor Swift’s Vienna Shows
abstract: The authorities said the 18-year-old was connected to the main suspect and had recently sworn allegiance to the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Vienna have arrested a third teenager in connection with a foiled terrorist attack on a Taylor Swift concert in the city this week.

headline: Trump Restates His Desire for More Say Over the Fed
abstract: The former president made his clearest statement yet that he wants influence over the central bank’s rate policy if he wins re-election.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has repeatedly questioned the principle of the Fed’s political independence and criticized Jay Powell, the central bank’s chair. (Remember when he called Powell a “bigger enemy” than President Xi Jinping of China?)

headline: Here’s the latest on the presidential race.
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris and her new running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, took their campaign rollout to a crowd near Phoenix on Friday evening — part of a renewed push to put Sun Belt states back in play and keep Arizona’s 11 electoral votes in the Democratic column.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and her new running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, took their campaign rollout to a crowd near Phoenix on Friday evening — part of a renewed push to put Sun Belt states back in play and keep Arizona’s 11 electoral votes in the Democratic column.

headline: Tourists Accused of Defacing Joshua Tree National Park With Paintballs
abstract: Three tourists from Germany shot paintballs at signs, bathrooms and dumpsters, officials for the park said, violating rules against defacing federal property.
lead_paragraph: Three tourists from Germany who were accused of firing paintballs at signs, bathrooms and dumpsters in Joshua Tree National Park in Southern California were cited for defacing property, according to park officials.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 10: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by Aug. 16 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced by Aug. 28.
lead_paragraph: Students, we want to hear about your experiences with the Summer Reading Contest. Let us know via this short survey.

headline: Tim Walz: Governor, Vice-Presidential Candidate, Local Music Fan
abstract: Kamala Harris’s running mate is a rock fan with an affinity for Minnesota artists including Bob Dylan, Prince, the Replacements and Hüsker Dü.
lead_paragraph: When Beto O’Rourke and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota served in Congress together in the 2010s, they would go on early morning jogs and talk about their shared love of music from Minnesota, from icons like Bob Dylan and Prince to the indie rock ferment the Twin Cities produced in the 1980s, including the Replacements and Hüsker Dü.

headline: What to Know About Online Paycheck Advances and Why They Face Scrutiny
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has proposed a rule that would treat the offerings as loans, requiring the providers to disclose their charges as interest rates.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of Americans who need cash before their next payday are tapping online paycheck advances. But the fees that often come with the advances are drawing scrutiny from a federal consumer watchdog.

headline: Can This Woman Save the United States?
abstract: (The storied ocean liner, that is.)
lead_paragraph: Susan Gibbs needs to find a new parking spot, fast. And not just any parking spot will do.

headline: Here Are the Olympic Moments We Won’t Forget
abstract: It doesn’t take a medal to make a lasting memory.
lead_paragraph: Success and failure. Exhilaration and agony. Gold, silver and bronze.

headline: Nancy Pelosi on Joe Biden, Tim Walz and Donald Trump
abstract: The former Speaker of the House discusses the election and the art of power.
lead_paragraph: The former Speaker of the House discusses the election and the art of power.

headline: Debby’s Remnants Leave Behind Flooding in Parts of the Northeast
abstract: Debby moved through the northeast into Canada on Friday after inundating the Northeast on Friday. Some areas on Saturday remained at risk of flooding.
lead_paragraph: The remnants of Tropical Storm Debby moved through the East Coast into Canada overnight on Friday after inundating parts of Pennsylvania, prompting tornado alerts and causing airport delays at some major Northeast cities.

headline: The Paris Bridge of Olympic Joy and Its Violent Past
abstract: The Pont du Carrousel, gathering place of joyous crowds, has come to symbolize a season of magic. It was not always so.
lead_paragraph: If the Olympic Games have made of Paris a midsummer night’s dream, perhaps the Pont du Carrousel has been its heart, a dimly lit bridge over glittering water, a merry-go-round of incarnations as the weeks have passed.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Including titles by Brando Skyhorse, Barack Obama, Costica Bradatan and more.
lead_paragraph: Including titles by Brando Skyhorse, Barack Obama, Costica Bradatan and more.

headline: Doug Emhoff Stresses a Personal Push Against Antisemitism
abstract: At an event in Paris to commemorate a 1982 attack on a Jewish deli there, Kamala Harris’s husband said, “Part of fighting hate is living openly and proudly as a Jew.”
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris’s husband, Doug Emhoff, landed in Paris this week, the Summer Olympics were naturally on the schedule. He watched the U.S. men’s basketball team rally against Serbia, attended track and field events and is to lead the American presidential delegation at the closing ceremony on Sunday.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include anarchists, hostage crises and sweaty M.M.A. fighters.
lead_paragraph: Rent or buy on most major platforms.

headline: Our Five-Star Tomato Tart
abstract: If your tomatoes aren’t perfect, so much the better — a quick blast in the oven and some dollops of ricotta and pesto make them shine.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. This is Tejal, filling in for Sam.

headline: Are Robot Massages Worth the Hype?
abstract: A.I.-informed massage robots will arrive at some Equinox gyms this month. I gave one a try.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, the room looked familiar. As with past massages I had received, the lights were dim, the air smelled vaguely of aromatherapy and there was an inviting bed in the center of the space.

headline: Travis Scott Is Accused of Assaulting a Security Guard in Paris
abstract: The rapper, who was in France for the Olympics, was taken into police custody at the George V hotel, the Paris prosecutor’s office said.
lead_paragraph: The star rapper Travis Scott was detained on Friday in Paris, where he was visiting for the Summer Olympics, after a conflict with a security guard at a luxury hotel, the Paris prosecutor’s office said.

headline: Trump’s Tax Plan Could Add to Debt Burden. Harris’s Plan Tracks Biden’s.
abstract: The former president’s proposals to cut taxes would lose far more revenue than his plans to raise tariffs. The vice president has not released specifics.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump keeps adding new tax cuts to his list of campaign promises, and their projected costs keep piling up.

headline: Harris Fights Uphill Against Trump in Arizona, Backed by a Revived Party
abstract: The battleground state, where Kamala Harris will rally on Friday, has drifted toward Donald Trump since he lost it in 2020. Democrats hope her momentum could turn their fortunes around there.
lead_paragraph: As Vice President Kamala Harris fights for the votes of Americans threatening to abandon the Democratic Party, she faces challenges across the battleground states, from working-class Nevada communities to Arab American enclaves in Michigan.

headline: Facing Turmoil at Home, Young Artists Find a Musical Haven in New York
abstract: Hundreds of students from Venezuela, Afghanistan, Israel and elsewhere converged at Carnegie Hall, using music to cope in a time of strife and unrest.
lead_paragraph: As the tour boat in New York Harbor approached the Statue of Liberty, Miranda Marín, a 12-year-old violinist from Venezuela, turned to a group of friends gathered near the bow and jumped up and down.

headline: Conner O’Malley’s Intensely Funny, Deeply Stupid Manosphere
abstract: A cult hero in the comedy world, he specializes in desperately ambitious men doomed to fail. But don’t ignore the element of empathy.
lead_paragraph: Everyone has something that would make them snap. Losing a job perhaps. The death of a loved one. For Conner O’Malley’s character in one of the funniest sketches on the series “I Think You Should Leave With Tim Robinson,” it’s a bumper sticker that reads, “Honk if you’re horny.”

headline: Tim Walz Was a Clear Eyes, Full Hearts Kind of Coach
abstract: “The guy was never negative,” another coach said. “That’s what we loved about him. Everything was a positive.”
lead_paragraph: Minneapolis’s Metrodome hummed, its sidelines jammed on a fall Friday night. The Mankato West Scarlets, who had started the 1999 high school football season with a miserable record of 2-4, had improbably swaggered into a state championship game. Now, less than three minutes stood between them and a title.

headline: The Perseids Meteor Shower Is Peaking. Here’s How to Watch.
abstract: Warm summer nights and swift colorful streaks make this meteor shower a crowd favorite, but this year, observers may have to compete with light from the moon.
lead_paragraph: Our universe might be chock-full of cosmic wonder, but you can observe only a fraction of astronomical phenomena with your naked eye. Meteor showers, natural fireworks that streak brightly across the night sky, are one of them.

headline: Kevin Sullivan, Pro Wrestling’s ‘Prince of Darkness,’ Dies at 75
abstract: Modeling himself after the heavy metal bands of the 1970s and ’80s, he played the role of an occult-inspired villain and tangled with the likes of Hulk Hogan.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Sullivan, a professional wrestler who rose to fame as a twisted villain who locked heads with some of the biggest names in the business, including Hulk Hogan, died on Friday in Concord, Mass. He was 75.

headline: The Presidential Campaign’s Carbonated Détente
abstract: In a land of plenty that reveres personal freedom, we imbibe as we wish.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has ever stood in line at a modern coffee shop and eavesdropped on fellow patrons’ painstakingly specific orders (skim milk, soy milk, oat milk, decaf, half-caf, blended, frothed, iced) knows that the adage is wrong: We are not what we eat. We are what we drink. It’s how we intentionally brand ourselves, unintentionally reveal ourselves or some combination of the two.

headline: The End-of-Summer Reading Roundup
abstract: Fall is on the horizon. Here are the books that have been keeping us company lately.
lead_paragraph: It’s August, which means that Labor Day and back-to-school are just around the corner. The vacation that seemed so leisurely a month ago suddenly feels a little more frantic. But there’s still time to squeeze in a last batch of summer reading. On this week’s episode, Gilbert Cruz chats with his colleagues Joumana Khatib and Anna Dubenko about the books that have been occupying their attention this season, and discuss whether “summer reading” should even exist as a category.

headline: U.S. Vies With Allies and Industry to Tighten China Tech Controls
abstract: The Biden administration must navigate the interests of U.S. companies and allied governments as it tries to close off China’s access to advanced chips
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is fighting to overcome opposition from allied nations and the tech industry as it prepares to expand restrictions aimed at slowing China’s ability to make the most advanced semiconductors, which could be used to bolster Beijing’s military capacity.

headline: 10 Moments of Beauty at the Paris Olympics
abstract: The Summer Games are known for athletic excellence, but they provide plenty of aesthetic excellence along the way.
lead_paragraph: Some people watch the Olympics for the events. Others watch for the hot athletes.

headline: Injera Is the Soul of Ethiopian Cuisine
abstract: Injera takes days to prepare, but this quick recipe streamlines the process.
lead_paragraph: With a swift flick of the wrist, Gennet Wondimu, owner of Ye Geny Injera & Mini Market in Inglewood, Calif., slipped a woven mat, called a sefed, under a freshly prepared injera and transferred it from the hot mitad, or griddle, to a long table to cool. Tiny holes covering the surface of the bread stared back invitingly.

headline: Tim Walz Seeks to Build Trust, One T-shirt at a Time
abstract: Kamala Harris picked a running mate whose casual clothes have helped make him relatable in appearance.
lead_paragraph: A Nebraska native with a gun license and workwear in his closet, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota is, of course, now also the Democratic candidate for vice president of the United States. Whether in a blocky sports jacket and tie or a T-shirt and Red Wing boots, Mr. Walz brings to the Democratic ticket a kind of down-home lack of fuss that is seldom seen anymore in politics.

headline: Trump’s Call to End Taxes on Social Security
abstract: Readers worry about the impact and suggest it’s just an empty campaign promise. Also: Trump’s news conference; V.P. candidates’ military records; Jewish voters.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Harris Skipped Over a Pennsylvania Star. Will It Matter in November?
abstract: Gov. Josh Shapiro won’t be on the Democratic ticket, and nor, for that matter, will the Scranton-born President Biden. But party officials in the battleground state are cautiously hopeful.
lead_paragraph: To Josh Shapiro’s supporters, the case for him as Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate was clear: He was the popular governor of Pennsylvania, and could help her lock down the most important battleground state on the map.

headline: Ross Terrill, Insightful Expert on Communist China, Is Dead at 85
abstract: In the 1960s, he was among the first Westerners allowed into the country, and for decades he helped the rest of the world understand it.
lead_paragraph: Ross Terrill, a political scientist and journalist whose extensive travels in China, beginning in the 1960s, made him one of the West’s most insightful guides to the country as it grew from self-imposed isolation to become a global superpower, died on Aug. 2 at his home in Boston. He was 85.

headline: Biden Promised Peace, but Will Leave His Successor a Nation Entangled in War
abstract: The president has spent much of his tenure mobilizing military might against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and supporting Israel.
lead_paragraph: Speaking from the Oval Office last month as he explained his decision not to seek re-election, President Biden boasted about his accomplishments. One of them, he suggested, was presiding over an era of peace.

headline: Shawn Mendes Returns Full of Questions, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Leon Bridges, Ravyn Lenae, Kelsea Ballerini and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Passenger Plane Crashes in Brazil, Killing 61 Onboard
abstract: The Brazilian authorities said no one survived the crash, outside São Paulo on Friday afternoon. The airline, VoePass, said the cause was unknown.
lead_paragraph: Above the small city of Vinhedo, Brazil, on Friday, a passenger plane was falling from the sky. Residents began filming.

headline: A Musical Tour of Tim Walz’s Minnesota
abstract: The state is a hotbed of corrosive underground rock, birthplace of two acclaimed icons, home to a lively hip-hop scene and a bedrock of ’80s pop and funk.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Vice President Kamala Harris announced that she had chosen a running mate: Tim Walz, governor of Minnesota. The news cast a spotlight not only on Walz, but on Minnesota’s culture — and in particular its rich, varied musical history.

headline: Should Soccer Make Space for Other Sports?
abstract: The saturation of soccer can be suffocating for the rest of the athletic landscape.
lead_paragraph: For almost half a century, the BBC’s broadcast schedule on a Saturday afternoon was both startlingly simple and comfortably unchanging. It amounted, in fact, to just a single word, one that somehow conveyed everything while telling viewers absolutely nothing. That word was Grandstand.

headline: Judge Gives Trump and Prosecutors More Time to Assess Presidential Immunity
abstract: Judge Tanya Chutkan, who is overseeing the election interference case against the former president, gave both sides a few more weeks to consider a Supreme Court ruling’s impact on the case.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge presiding over former President Donald J. Trump’s election interference case on Friday delayed until the end of the month a deadline for the defense and prosecution to send proposals for how to assess the impact of the Supreme Court’s recent ruling granting former presidents broad immunity against criminal charges.

headline: Finding the ‘Olympic Spirit’ at La Villette
abstract: La Villette, a park in the north of Paris, has been transformed into Nations Park for the Olympics. Rory Smith, a global sports correspondent for The New York Times, explains how the park embodies the spirit of the Games.
lead_paragraph: La Villette, a park in the north of Paris, has been transformed into Nations Park for the Olympics. Rory Smith, a global sports correspondent for The New York Times, explains how the park embodies the spirit of the Games.

headline: Taylor Swift Fans in Vienna React After Cancellations
abstract: Taylor Swift fans described their disappointment after organizers canceled her Eras Tour dates in Vienna after Austrian authorities uncovered a terrorist plot targeting the event.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift fans described their disappointment after organizers canceled her Eras Tour dates in Vienna after Austrian authorities uncovered a terrorist plot targeting the event.

headline: Cash App Users May Claim Up to $2,500 in Data Breach Settlement
abstract: A proposed $15 million settlement stipulates that account holders can file for losses related to breaches disclosed in 2022 and 2023. A deadline looms for those claims.
lead_paragraph: People who have used Cash App accounts may be entitled to receive up to $2,500 each as part of a $15 million settlement related to a data breach involving the popular payments and investment platform, according to court documents and the company.

headline: How to Save Disney
abstract: Three ways to revitalize the House of Mouse.
lead_paragraph: Let’s take a break from the drama of the 2024 election, the great struggle to rule the American imperium, and talk about another empire dealing with turmoil and self-doubt: the almighty Walt Disney Company, the House of the Mouse, which is currently poised somewhere between cultural hegemony and internal decay.

headline: The Big Number: $8.4 Billion
abstract: Disney’s weaker-than-expected revenue at its theme park unit.
lead_paragraph: Disney reported revenue of $8.4 billion for its theme park unit for the three months that ended in June. While that was a 2 percent increase from the previous year, it was lower than expected, in a sign that stubborn inflation and high interest rates were weighing on Americans’ ability to sail on Disney cruise ships and visit parks like Disney World.

headline: A Trust Would Give Me Big Bucks if I Had Children. I’m Concerned.
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on a wealthy family’s philanthropic planning.
lead_paragraph: In a recent visit, my parents, both in their 70s, outlined their intentions for their considerable assets, which include a trust worth millions of dollars. They propose that my brother and I (both in our 30s) serve as trustees. We would receive an unconditional portion of the trust, with access to a majority share with conditions.

headline: Stroke by Wobbly Stroke, Learning to Accept Imperfection
abstract: During a recent assignment, a reporter learned the basics of calligraphy — and with it, how to practice self-compassion.
lead_paragraph: “Embrace the wobble,” Laura Edralin, a calligraphy teacher, told me as I wrote something that could only be described as an extremely wobbly “K.” It was my first calligraphy class, and, sitting alongside other students who seemed to know what they were doing, I was feeling very out of my depth.

headline: Think You’ve Planned for Retirement? Beware the Tax Torpedo.
abstract: The complicated way Social Security is taxed can catch middle-income earners by surprise.
lead_paragraph: Look out for the Social Security tax torpedo. It may be heading toward the hull of your retirement accounts as we speak. And if it hits, you may not even realize it.

headline: Tim Walz’s Class Project on the Holocaust Draws New Attention Online
abstract: Mr. Walz, now the Democrats’ vice-presidential nominee, asked his high school students in 1993 which country was most at risk for genocide. Their prediction came to pass: Rwanda.
lead_paragraph: The prediction was spot on: Rwanda was barreling toward a devastating genocide.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, August 10, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Latino Rights Group Breaks With Its History to Endorse Harris-Walz Ticket
abstract: Leaders of the group, known as LULAC, said members were stirred to make their first formal endorsement over concerns about the potential impact of another Trump presidency.
lead_paragraph: The League of United Latin American Citizens, one of the nation’s oldest Latino civil rights organizations, said on Friday that it supported Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, the first formal endorsement of a presidential ticket in the group’s 95-year history.

headline: Video and Airplane Sketch Raise New Questions About Saudi Ties to 9/11
abstract: The F.B.I. received a trove of evidence from British authorities between 2001 and 2002. Two significant pieces of information, which were not shared with the 9/11 Commission, have recently emerged.
lead_paragraph: A trove of evidence seized by British authorities from the home of a Saudi national with ties to the Sept. 11 Al Qaeda hijackers is now being made public for the first time as part of a long-running lawsuit against the kingdom’s government by the families of some of the victims.

headline: Smartmatic Executives Charged With Bribery of Philippine Official
abstract: The Justice Department said the executives from the voting technology company had funneled at least $1 million to obtain a contract to provide voting machines in the 2016 Philippine elections.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department on Thursday charged three current and former executives at Smartmatic, the voting technology company, with taking part in a bribery scheme in the Philippines.

headline: Childhood Vaccines Aren’t Just Saving Lives. They’re Saving Money.
abstract: Over the past three decades, routine immunizations have prevented 1.1 million deaths and saved the United States $540 billion, the C.D.C. estimated.
lead_paragraph: There’s no way to put a price on the pain and suffering prevented by childhood vaccines. But as it turns out, you can pinpoint the savings to the country.

headline: The Australian Professor Who Turned Breaking on Its Head
abstract: Rachael Gunn, known as B-girl Raygun, displayed some … unique moves as she competed in a field with breakers half her age. The judges and the internet were underwhelmed.
lead_paragraph: Breaking made its debut as an Olympic sport Friday, and among the competitors was Dr. Rachael Gunn, also known as B-girl Raygun, a 36-year-old professor from Sydney, Australia, who stood out in just about every way.

headline: For Years, He Demanded to See the Video. Finally, It Set Him Free.
abstract: At his murder trial, Arvel Marshall pressed prosecutors to turn over surveillance footage of the crime scene. He knew it would show the truth.
lead_paragraph: As his murder trial began in December 2009, Arvel Marshall made a desperate plea to his lawyer: Ask for surveillance videos of the Brooklyn street where he was accused of fatally shooting a 22-year-old man.

headline: Mísia, Who Brought a Modern Flair to Fado Music, Dies at 69
abstract: With her smoky voice and her high-fashion look, the self-proclaimed “punk of fado” found stardom by shaking up a venerable Portuguese genre.
lead_paragraph: Mísia, an acclaimed singer who helped modernize fado, a traditional Portuguese music known for wistful songs of fate, loss and regret, with a runway-ready style sense and an eclectic approach that earned her the label “anarchist of fado,” died on July 27 in Lisbon. She was 69.

headline: How to Handle Jet Lag, According to Very Frequent Travelers
abstract: A long flight can be exhausting, but recovering from it needn’t take up half your trip.
lead_paragraph: Fatigue, irritability, dehydration, brain fog: these are just a few of the unpleasant side effects of taking a far-flung trip, though even jumping a couple of time zones within the United States can wreak havoc on energy levels. Purported remedies for jet lag abound, but here are a few tried-and-true methods that can help you feel better faster — without drinking multiple espressos upon landing.

headline: Tracking Tropical Storm Maria
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Maria.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Maria.

headline: Evidence Shows ‘Hand to Mouth’ Production of Russia’s Advanced Weapons
abstract: A report by independent investigators said that Russian cruise missiles were used in combat sometimes just weeks after rolling off the factory floor.
lead_paragraph: The Russian cruise missile that slammed into a children’s hospital in Kyiv last month left behind clues about Russia’s defense industry after more than two years of war.

headline: Workout Clothes Stink. Here’s How to Clean Them.
abstract: Hydrogen peroxide can help.
lead_paragraph: Hydrogen peroxide can help.

headline: Former Twitter Board Member Sues Elon Musk’s X For $20 Million in Pay
abstract: After purchasing Twitter, Mr. Musk failed to cash out Omid Kordestani’s stock, according to allegations in a new lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: A former Twitter board member, Omid Kordestani, sued the social media company owned by Elon Musk on Friday, claiming that the billionaire refused to cash out more than $20 million worth of shares.

headline: Overlooked No More: Renee Carroll, ‘World’s Most Famous Hatcheck Girl’
abstract: From the cloakroom at Sardi’s, she made her own mark on Broadway, hobnobbing with celebrity clients while safekeeping fedoras, bowlers, derbies and more.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: J. Robin Warren, Who Proved That Bacteria Cause Ulcers, Dies at 87
abstract: He endured skepticism but won a Nobel Prize for his work upending the conventional wisdom that stress, diet or alcohol caused the painful condition.
lead_paragraph: Dr. J. Robin Warren, an Australian pathologist who shared a Nobel Prize for discovering that most stomach ulcers were caused by the bacterium Helicobacter pylori — and not, as had been widely believed, stress, alcohol or spicy foods — died on July 23 in Inglewood, Australia. He was 87.

headline: Learn to Make the Best Roasted Eggplant of Your Life
abstract: This summer staple has a reputation of being bitter, seedy, even greasy at times, but a few small considerations can make it excellent.
lead_paragraph: Eggplant is much maligned. It’s known for being bitter and seedy, woolly and dry, even greasy at times. And, of course, it can be all of these things when it isn’t treated right. Eggplant is a diva, and with some attentiveness to its needs, it can become a crisp, creamy delight.

headline: Jan. 6 Rioter Sentenced to 20 Years for Assaults on Police
abstract: David Dempsey received one of the stiffest sentences issued so far in the riot after attacking the police with his hands, his feet, a flagpole, crutches, pepper spray and broken pieces of furniture.
lead_paragraph: A California man who attacked police officers at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, in a sustained assault with his hands, his feet, a flagpole, crutches, pepper spray and broken pieces of furniture was sentenced on Friday to 20 years in prison — one of the stiffest penalties issued in more than three years of prosecutions of the rioters.

headline: Elon Musk to Speak to West Point Cadets
abstract: The billionaire owner of the social media platform X and Tesla’s chief executive will deliver the keynote speech at an annual event.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the billionaire owner of the social media platform X and Tesla’s chief executive, will deliver the keynote speech at the annual convocation of the United States Military Academy next Friday, West Point officials said.

headline: This Is a Picture of the Last Thing Seen by NASA’s Asteroid Hunter
abstract: NEOWISE, a spacecraft that studied faraway cosmic objects before shifting its focus closer to home, has reached the end of its life. But its legacy lives on.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, scientists and engineers in Southern California got an exclusive glimpse at a recent snapshot of Fornax, a constellation of stars in the Southern Hemisphere.

headline: An Artist Documenting the Beauty of Queer Black South Africa
abstract: Zanele Muholi discusses visual activism, gospel music and walking more than 15,000 steps in a day.
lead_paragraph: The artist Zanele Muholi finds the people they photograph at parties, weddings and funerals. Muholi also meets them at Pride rallies and protests for L.G.B.T.Q.I.A.+ rights in Johannesburg and Cape Town before taking the sitters’ portraits in a setting of their choosing. Muholi, who identifies as nonbinary, has a nomadic artistic practice; they move their studio with them through the country. “I work as I go. From any space. Whenever I feel like photographing [and wherever] is safe and conducive for a shoot,” they say. Their portraits are often black and white, which Muholi considers more timeless and less noisy than color, but the works are in no way quiet. In their self-portraits, Muholi’s use of deep saturation and heavy contrasts not only dramatizes the pigment of their skin but also blurs the line between photography and painting. Their portraits of others are typically more spare but are similarly striking, thanks to the direct eye contact of the sitters, who seem to be assessing the viewer in return and whom Muholi calls “participants” rather than “subjects.”

headline: How to Watch Biden’s Interview on CBS
abstract: The president spoke with Robert Costa in his first interview since ending his re-election campaign. The discussion will air on “CBS Sunday Morning” at 9 a.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: President Biden sat on Wednesday for his first interview since announcing his decision to end his re-election campaign, joining CBS News’s Robert Costa for a discussion in the White House residence that will be broadcast on Sunday morning.

headline: Fact-Checking Claims About Tim Walz’s Record
abstract: Republicans have leveled inaccurate or misleading attacks on Mr. Walz’s response to protests in the summer of 2020, his positions on immigration and his role in the redesign of Minnesota’s flag.
lead_paragraph: Since Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota was announced as the Democratic nominee for vice president, the Trump campaign and its allies have gone on the attack.

headline: Iowa Law Requiring Schools to Remove Books With Sexual Content to Take Effect
abstract: A federal appeals court lifted an injunction on the law, which had already led to the removal of thousands of books from public school classrooms and libraries.
lead_paragraph: A law in Iowa that bars public schools from having books that depict sexual acts can take effect, following a ruling by federal appeals court judges on Friday.

headline: Joe Rogan Would Like to Clarify: He Did Not Endorse Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
abstract: A day after praising Mr. Kennedy, the podcast host was backpedaling. “This isn’t an endorsement,” Mr. Rogan posted, and he advised that he is “not the guy to get political information from.”
lead_paragraph: The world’s most popular podcaster has, sort of, but not really, thrown his support to one of the 2024 presidential race’s least popular candidates.

headline: Howie Cohen, Whose Alka-Seltzer Ads Agreed With Viewers, Dies at 81
abstract: A copywriter, he and a partner in 1972 came up with “Try it, you’ll like it” and “I can’t believe I ate that whole thing.” Soon, sales were, well, fizzing.
lead_paragraph: Howie Cohen, an advertising copywriter, often said he was congenitally familiar with indigestion. So perhaps it was only natural that in the 1970s, he, along with an ad agency colleague, would conjure up a catchy slogan that would not only sell more Alka-Seltzer but also become an American pop culture punchline: “I can’t believe I ate the whole thing.”

headline: Trump Says He Wants to Cut Taxes. Harris’s Plan Mirrors Biden’s.
abstract: Also, Russia is scrambling to halt Ukraine’s surprise offensive. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: For months, Donald Trump has been adding new tax cuts to his list of campaign promises. He says he wants to exempt tips, cut the corporate rate and end the tax on Social Security.

headline: Two Rivals in Michigan’s Crucial Senate Contest Say They Were Both Swatted
abstract: Representative Elissa Slotkin, a Democrat, and former Representative Mike Rogers, a Republican, disclosed that they were targeted on Thursday and Friday.
lead_paragraph: The two leading contenders for Michigan’s open Senate seat disclosed that they had been targeted in separate “swatting” incidents in a span of less than 24 hours, just days after winning primaries in a crucial contest that could determine which party controls the chamber.

headline: Can You Be Emotionally Reliant on an A.I. Voice? OpenAI Says Yes.
abstract: A report acknowledged that users of GPT-4o form unusual bonds with the software’s voice response feature, which the company says warrants further study.
lead_paragraph: In a report released this week, OpenAI revealed that it had considered the potential for users to form an emotional reliance on its new, humanlike voice mode, which is featured in its popular artificial intelligence chatbot, ChatGPT.

headline: Stellantis Will Lay Off Up to 2,450 at Michigan Truck Plant
abstract: The move is the latest sign of trouble for the trans-Atlantic automaker, which has had sluggish North American sales and has said it needs to cut costs.
lead_paragraph: Stellantis announced plans on Friday to lay off as many as 2,450 workers later this year at a pickup truck plant near Detroit, the latest sign of trouble for the trans-Atlantic automaker.

headline: In the ring, only one thing matters for Imane Khelif: the gold medal.
abstract: Khelif weathered two weeks of distractions, breezing to the gold medal in women’s boxing.
lead_paragraph: Imane Khelif’s first fight at the Paris Olympics was won in 46 seconds. Her fourth, and last, delivered a gold medal. In time, the joy and pride and relief that victory brought may allow her to forget everything that happened in between, including questions about her eligibility.

headline: A Financial Tale of Two Potential Vice Presidents
abstract: JD Vance and Tim Walz both came from modest backgrounds, but they have had very different trajectories when it comes to their personal fortunes.
lead_paragraph: After JD Vance was elected to the Senate from Ohio in 2022, he and his wife bought a five-bedroom house — their third home — for $1.6 million in Alexandria, Va., not far from the Capitol. Their real estate agent told a local magazine that the buyers paid in cash.

headline: F.D.A. Declines to Approve MDMA Therapy, Seeking More Study
abstract: The agency said there was insufficient data to allow the use of a treatment for PTSD that involves the drug known as Ecstasy.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday declined to approve MDMA-assisted therapy for the treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder, dealing a serious blow to the nascent field of psychedelic medicine and dashing the hopes of many Americans who are desperate for new treatments.

headline: Defense Dept. Contractor Arrested With Dozens of Classified Documents
abstract: Investigators are still trying to determine why the contractor, Gokhan Gun, who became an American citizen in 2021, hoarded so many documents.
lead_paragraph: A Defense Department contractor was arrested on Friday with dozens of highly classified documents he had obtained using his security clearance, as he prepared to depart for a trip to Mexico, according to prosecutors.

headline: Illinois Sheriff Will Resign Amid Backlash Over Fatal Shooting by Deputy
abstract: Jack Campbell, the sheriff of Sangamon County, was criticized for hiring the deputy, who has now been charged with murdering Sonya Massey in her home last month.
lead_paragraph: Jack Campbell, the Illinois sheriff whose deputy was charged with murder after fatally shooting a Black woman in her home last month, said Friday that he would leave his position by the end of the month amid calls from the public and the governor that he do so.

headline: Trump Claims He Has Helicopter Trip Records and Threatens to Sue
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump insisted that he was in a dangerous helicopter landing, though the man he said he was with said it never happened.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Friday afternoon vehemently maintained that he had once been in a dangerous helicopter landing with Willie Brown, the former mayor of San Francisco, and insisted he had records to prove it, despite Mr. Brown’s denial.

headline: Harris Has a Big Campaign Launch — and Big Tests Ahead
abstract: Fresh challenges in the offing could determine how long the vice president’s honeymoon will last.
lead_paragraph: If you are Vice President Kamala Harris, another Democrat or any other person who happens to want Harris to become president, the last two weeks and five days have probably felt like a dream.

headline: Israel Launches Another Offensive in Gaza’s South Amid Push for Truce
abstract: The United States, Egypt and Qatar are trying to restart peace talks between Hamas and Israel, while Israel carries on its operation in Gaza and braces for attacks by Iran and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli ground assault in the southern Gaza Strip on Friday forced tens of thousands of Palestinians to flee their homes and shelters, many for a third time or more, even as the United States and some Arab allies pressed both Israel and Hamas to restart peace talks.

headline: How Online Hatred Toward Migrants Spurs Real-World Violence
abstract: Social media posts assailing immigrants have fomented a climate of fear and hatred in Britain, Portugal and other countries. The vitriolic language is now spilling onto the streets.
lead_paragraph: Social media posts assailing immigrants have fomented a climate of fear and hatred in Britain, Portugal and other countries. The vitriolic language is now spilling onto the streets.

headline: Ultraconfident Affirmation
abstract: Spencer Leach’s themeless puzzle will shake, rattle and roll us around.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Spencer Leach has a gift for tweaking things that might look irritating at first into amusements — every corner of this puzzle had a clue or entry that could have made me bristle, until I parsed it completely, got the wink and had to smile. This is Mr. Leach’s fourth Saturday puzzle for The New York Times, and it comes with a number of debut entries, only some from current parlance, that make for a fresh solve.

headline: Harris Rides Momentum to Arizona, for What Campaign Says Is Largest Rally Yet
abstract: Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, drew 15,000 at a rally near Phoenix, the campaign said. To win in Arizona, they will need the diverse coalition that gave President Biden the state in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris rolled into Arizona on Friday evening with the same political momentum that has infused her first swing across the country this week, drawing a crowd that her campaign estimated at more than 15,000 — her largest yet — in a Western state that not long ago appeared to be falling off the battleground map.

headline: Famed Double Arch Collapses in Glen Canyon National Recreation Area
abstract: Changing water levels and erosion are believed to have contributed to the collapse of the geologic feature, which was formed from 190 million-year-old Navajo sandstone, the National Park Service said.
lead_paragraph: A popular double arch that hung over the turquoise waters of Lake Powell in Utah’s portion of Glen Canyon National Recreation Area collapsed on Thursday, officials said.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Flipping, Twisting, and Pushing for Respect, Smiling All the Way
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not enough to be good — you have to look perfect in your face, in your makeup, in your body..”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 10, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Aug. 1 which fact-checked former President Donald J. Trump’s remarks during his appearance at the National Association of Black Journalists Convention in Chicago, misstated Vice President Kamala Harris’s account in her autobiography of retaking the bar exam after failing on her first attempt. Ms. Harris wrote that she retook the test in February 1990 and passed; her subsequent exam was not left unaddressed in the book.

headline: China’s Great Wall of Villages
abstract: China has moved thousands of people to new settlements on its frontiers. It calls them “border guardians.”
lead_paragraph: China has moved thousands of people to new settlements on its frontiers. It calls them “border guardians.”

headline: How Economic Grievances Were Exploited in Britain’s Violent Unrest
abstract: Nationalist hatred has been linked to forces like stagnant wages and declining services, even though research shows immigration helps many economies.
lead_paragraph: Like many cities around Britain shaken by anti-immigrant riots over the past week, Hartlepool, a seaside town on the northeast coast, has partly recovered from the devastating waves of industrial decline that began washing over the country in the 1980s.

headline: Bangladesh Put Its Eggs in One Economic Basket. Now, a Reckoning.
abstract: Garment exports lifted the country to new heights. But overreliance on that industry also helped bring down Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Bangladesh was hailed as an economic miracle. Its singular focus on exporting textiles and apparel delivered rapid growth, lifting millions out of poverty and winning the country’s prime minister, Sheikh Hasina, fame and admiration.

headline: Who Won the Olympics? All the Ways We Could Think Of to Track the Medal Count.
abstract: Which country won the most events involving nets, balls or weapons? We (over) analyzed the medal standings in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The United States had an excellent showing at the Summer Olympics in Paris. It won the most medals by far, and tied with China for most gold medals — the first such tie at a Summer Games.

headline: Dear Pentathletes: Enjoy Your Last Ride. Get Ready for the Obstacle Course.
abstract: Pentathlon will trade show jumping for an obstacle course in 2028, after accusations of horse mistreatment in Tokyo. Athletes aren’t thrilled. But they could have been pillow fighting.
lead_paragraph: The farrago of a sport that is the modern pentathlon owes its rarefied existence to Pierre de Coubertin, the father of the modern Olympics, who, according to legend, imagined it as a test of mettle for a typical French cavalry officer. Caught behind enemy lines, such a man might have to fence with and shoot at his pursuers; run toward safety; swim across a body of water; and ride away on a random horse he happened to encounter.

headline: Yes, Trump Was in a Scary Helicopter Ride. But Not With That Politician.
abstract: There was a helicopter. It did make an emergency landing. But a former California lawmaker says Donald Trump has mixed up one Black lawmaker for another.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was doubling down on Friday about his story of nearly crashing during a helicopter ride once with Willie Brown, the notable Black California politician.

headline: What We Know About the Plane Crash in Brazil
abstract: The twin-engine turboprop passenger aircraft crashed near São Paulo, killing all 62 people onboard. Officials are investigating the cause.
lead_paragraph: A passenger plane carrying 62 people crashed on Friday outside São Paulo, Brazil. No one onboard survived.

headline: Inside One of the Last Functioning Hospitals in Gaza
abstract: Dr. Ahmad Yousaf is an American pediatrician who recently returned from a medical mission with MedGlobal in Gaza. He shared rare footage from inside Al Aqsa Hospital, where he captured harrowing conditions for staff and patients, particularly children.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ahmad Yousaf is an American pediatrician who recently returned from a medical mission with MedGlobal in Gaza. He shared rare footage from inside Al Aqsa Hospital, where he captured harrowing conditions for staff and patients, particularly children.

headline: Susan Wojcicki, a Pivotal Chief of YouTube, Dies at 56
abstract: She helped turn Google into an internet juggernaut and became one of the most prominent women in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: Susan Wojcicki, who helped turn Google from a start-up in her garage into an internet juggernaut, and who became one of Silicon Valley’s most prominent female executives with her leadership of YouTube, died on Friday. She was 56.

headline: Fine-Tuning His Attacks on Harris, Trump Tries Using Her Words Against Her
abstract: Donald J. Trump broke from his routine at a rally in Montana to play videos designed to portray Kamala Harris as inept and dangerously liberal.
lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump continues to reach for attacks on his new opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, that might halt her political momentum, he unveiled a new tactic at a rally in Bozeman, Mont., on Friday night, aiming to use Ms. Harris’s own words against her.

headline: A Bike-Riding Barber Cuts Hair on Broadway, in the Park and on the Roof
abstract: Julien Howard, who is known as the Vélo Barber, travels around New York City by bike in search of the “dopest” places to cut hair.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a barbershop where the sky is the ceiling and the bustling cityscape of New York City forms its walls. That is the world of Julien Howard, who is known as the Vélo Barber.

headline: How a Subway Mosaic Artist Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Jackie Chang, who designed the mosaics at a Brooklyn subway station, spends her day designing in her studio, making Taiwanese breakfast and practicing violin.
lead_paragraph: Jackie Chang was exiting the Metropolitan Avenue-Lorimer Street subway station near her home in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, several years ago when she heard a man in front of her grumble, “It looks like a museum in here,” with an expletive.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How the Olympics Warp Time
abstract: Doesn’t it seem like the Paris Games have gone by fast? Imagine having your success or failure defined by thousandths of a second.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say you learned to tell time on a simple, round analog clock, with 12 big numbers and two hands. The Olympic Games present a mind-bending puzzle: What if, between each of those big numbers, there were scores of smaller numbers? And what if, between the smaller numbers, there were hundreds more numbers?

headline: Cross-Tabs: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin
abstract: Results of New York Times/Siena College polls of Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin conducted among 1,973 registered voters from Aug. 5 to 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of New York Times/Siena College polls of Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin conducted among 1,973 registered voters from Aug. 5 to 9, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate in Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin
abstract: Results of New York Times/Siena College polls of Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin conducted among 1,973 likely voters from Aug. 5 to 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of New York Times/Siena College polls of Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin conducted among 1,973 likely voters from Aug. 5 to 9, 2024.

headline: Toplines: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in Pennsylvania
abstract: Results of a Pennsylvania New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 693 registered voters from Aug. 6 to 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a Pennsylvania New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 693 registered voters from Aug. 6 to 9, 2024.

headline: Toplines: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in Wisconsin
abstract: Results of a Wisconsin New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 661 registered voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a Wisconsin New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 661 registered voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.

headline: Toplines: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in Michigan
abstract: Results of a Michigan New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 619 registered voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a Michigan New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 619 registered voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in Pennsylvania
abstract: Results of a Pennsylvania New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 693 registered voters from Aug. 6 to 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a Pennsylvania New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 693 registered voters from Aug. 6 to 9, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in Michigan
abstract: Results of a Michigan New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 619 registered voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a Michigan New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 619 registered voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters in Wisconsin
abstract: Results of a Wisconsin New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 661 registered voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a Wisconsin New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 661 registered voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate in Pennsylvania
abstract: Results of a Pennsylvania New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 693 likely voters from Aug. 6 to 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a Pennsylvania New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 693 likely voters from Aug. 6 to 9, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate in Michigan
abstract: Results of a Michigan New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 619 likely voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a Michigan New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 619 likely voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate in Wisconsin
abstract: Results of a Wisconsin New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 661 likely voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a Wisconsin New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 661 likely voters from Aug. 5 to 8, 2024.

headline: In Counterculture San Francisco, a Church Has Become the Place to Be
abstract: Yoga, laser art and Bobby McFerrin are attracting residents who are longing for a community — but not necessarily religion.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco residents have always celebrated the new, the innovative, the cutting-edge. The weirder, the better. But these days, they are flocking to a surprising venue for the cool factor: a church that is older than the city itself.

headline: When All You Have Left Are Memories, Plus a Hippopotamus
abstract: Yoko Ogawa’s “Mina’s Matchbox” is a novel of family secrets and formative childhood moments recounted by a young girl.
lead_paragraph: “Mina’s Matchbox,” the latest novel by the Japanese writer Yoko Ogawa, is a story of first enchantments and last gasps. In 1972, a 12-year-old girl, Tomoko, leaves her widowed mother in Tokyo to spend a year with her maternal aunt’s family, heirs to a soft drink fortune. Everything about them feels foreign to Tomoko, from her dashing half-German uncle, who picks her up at the train station in his shiny Mercedes, to the family’s wunderkammer-like estate at the foot of a mountain in Ashiya, an affluent coastal town.

headline: The Essential Shel Silverstein
abstract: He was irreverent, absurdist and ahead of his time. Here’s the best of the best by the groovy pied piper who made poetry fun.
lead_paragraph: If you were lucky enough to be read to as a kid, you probably found yourself face to face with Shel Silverstein, whose iconic bald head appears on the backs of most of his books.

headline: Your Online Lender May Not Be a Bank. Here’s How to Keep Your Money Safe.
abstract: The collapse of a little-known intermediary named Synapse Financial Technologies has put a spotlight on the risk that customers face when using popular banking start-ups.
lead_paragraph: If it looks like a bank, advertises like a bank and accepts money like a bank — it still might not be a bank.

headline: Ariana Greenblatt on the ‘Stupid’ Movie That Inspires Her
abstract: “It’s a big part of my personality,” admitted the actress, who broke through in “Barbie” and is now in the sci-fi film “Borderlands.”
lead_paragraph: After playing America Ferrera’s defiant daughter in “Barbie,” Ariana Greenblatt has lots of mentor options. There’s Margot Robbie (“so cool”). Michael Cera (“I love him so much”). Greta Gerwig (“yeeessss”).

headline: Myha’la Arrives
abstract: The one-name star of the HBO show “Industry” is composed under pressure.
lead_paragraph: On a humider-than-humid afternoon in July, Myha’la stepped into a teahouse in her Brooklyn neighborhood and joined the line leading to the front counter.

headline: Monet, Taylor Swift, ‘Moana’: What Got Readers Through Their Grief
abstract: After our series on how artists have been affected by loss, we asked readers what helped them when they experienced it. These are 15 of their answers.
lead_paragraph: Over the Memorial Day holiday weekend, we published The Grief Project, a series of interviews with artists who discussed the ways that loss affected their work and creativity. We also asked readers about the art and culture — whether it was a book, a movie, a song or anything else — that helped them remember or cope with losing a loved one. Hundreds responded. Here is what some of them said.

headline: Ditching Wedding Stationery for Informal Text Invitations
abstract: Some couples are taking the casual approach to sending out wedding invitations, opting for texts or emails instead of traditional printed cards.
lead_paragraph: “There is NO obligation to come if you can’t!” part of the message read.

headline: How Hollywood Glamour Is Reviving the Endangered Broadway Play
abstract: George Clooney, Robert Downey Jr., Denzel Washington and Mia Farrow are coming to Broadway, where some producers see plays with stars as safer bets than musicals.
lead_paragraph: Robert Downey Jr. is deep in rehearsals for his Broadway debut next month as an A.I.-obsessed novelist in “McNeal.” Next spring, George Clooney arrives for his own Broadway debut in “Good Night, and Good Luck,” and Denzel Washington returns, after a seven-year absence, to star in “Othello” with Jake Gyllenhaal.

headline: 5 Podcasts for the Constantly Online
abstract: As the internet continues to alter every aspect of our lives, these shows explain the latest TikTok trends, celebrity in the social media age and more.
lead_paragraph: Doing things online is now such second nature — whether banking, dating or work meetings — that it’s easy not to notice it at all, just as scrolling TikTok or X has become a kneejerk response to moments of boredom or social awkwardness. But the internet’s integral, and always evolving, role in our culture is worth paying attention to.

headline: The Lying Game
abstract: How bad could it be?
lead_paragraph: Sometimes my friend and I play a game.

headline: For a ‘Citizen Artist,’ Creativity Is a Matter of Survival
abstract: Her residency and exhibition at the University of Chicago highlights vanessa german’s determination to tap into the power of love and art to heal traumas — including her own.
lead_paragraph: When I sat down to interview the artist vanessa german in her bright, airy temporary studio at the University of Chicago, she was the one who asked the first question. And the second, and the third. She wanted to know who I was and what motivated me in my work and life. She listened to my answers so intently that I was momentarily unnerved.

headline: Can I Let My Niece Live in My Rent-Stabilized Apartment?
abstract: To live in a rent-stabilized apartment in New York, it must be your primary residence. But how far can you bend the rules?
lead_paragraph: Q: I miraculously landed in a 300-square-foot, rent-stabilized apartment in the West Village in 1997. It’s a walk-up dump, but in a good location. I lived and worked in New York City until 2016, keeping the apartment to use for myself and my brothers. Two years ago, my niece moved in. I pay the rent, which is very low, and she reimburses me. I would love to get rid of the apartment, but she’s ecstatic to be there. I know that subletting to her is not allowed. I think the super is aware, but doesn’t seem to care. What kind of trouble can I get into?

headline: In the Fierce Lobster Roll Rivalry, There Are Only Winners
abstract: Whether you are a buttered Connecticut-style fan or a partisan of the Maine rolls with mayo, summer is your season.
lead_paragraph: At Jordan Lobster Farm in Island Park, N.Y., lobster rolls, served warm or cold, seem to be on every table. The cold version, with just enough mayonnaise to bind the meat and some chopped celery together, is a best seller. But about four years ago, a warm version that comes with a side of drawn butter was added to the menu at this casual seafood restaurant.

headline: What’s So New About the ‘New Right’?
abstract: JD Vance and his allies represent a mind-set that dates back to the McCarthy era and the dawn of the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, a loose coalition of conservative thinkers, journalists, publications and think tanks have emerged under the banner of the New Right. With Senator JD Vance, Donald Trump’s running mate, as its flag-bearer, this still-disparate group has been hailed as the intellectual heft behind the MAGA movement, and even as the future of American conservatism. Its very name declares a radical break with the Republican past — “very nascent, very bleeding edge,” is how Vivek Ramaswamy, a former presidential candidate, described it. But how new is the New Right?

headline: How to Avoid Online Scams and What to Do if You Become a Victim
abstract: Here are tips on how to dodge some of the most devastating schemes and what to do if you or someone you care about becomes ensnared.
lead_paragraph: Cybercrime is on the rise, but even the best antivirus software can’t thwart scammers who target the human psyche.

headline: ‘Operation Knock-Knock’: Venezuela Sweeps Up Dissenters After Disputed Vote
abstract: The Venezuelan authorities have launched a nationwide sweep, called Operation Knock-Knock, that is targeting anyone even perceived to be challenging the autocratic president’s re-election.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people gathered several days ago outside a detention center known as “Zone 7” in Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, huddled around lists of prisoners, as they clutched plastic bags filled with meals they had packed for the inmates inside.

headline: Can Dirt Clean the Climate?
abstract: An Australian start-up is hoping fungi can pull carbon dioxide from the air and stash it underground. It’s one of several ventures trying to deploy the superpowers of soil to slow global warming.
lead_paragraph: Across 100,000 acres in the vast agricultural heartland of Australia, an unusual approach is taking root to slow down the wrecking ball of climate change. Farmers are trying to tap the superpowers of tiny subterranean tendrils of fungus to pull carbon dioxide out of the air and stash it underground.

headline: Harris Leads Trump in Three Key States, Times/Siena Polls Find
abstract: New surveys of Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania taken this week offer the latest indication of a dramatic reversal in standing for the Democratic Party since President Biden abandoned his re-election bid.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris leads former President Donald J. Trump in three crucial battleground states, according to new surveys by The New York Times and Siena College, the latest indication of a dramatic reversal in standing for Democrats after President Biden’s departure from the presidential race remade it.

headline: Relive the Biggest Little Runs in Paris
abstract: Miniature running visualizations highlight the greatest performances on the track at the 2024 Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Miniature running visualizations highlight the greatest performances on the track at the 2024 Olympics.

headline: New Battleground Polls Show Harris Has Fundamentally Changed the Race
abstract: On question after question, at least for now, most voters don’t seem to have major reservations about her.
lead_paragraph: If there were any doubt whether Kamala Harris has transformed this year’s presidential election, this morning’s latest New York Times/Siena College polls put it to rest.

headline: Inside the Worst Three Weeks of Donald Trump’s 2024 Campaign
abstract: People around the former and would-be president see a candidate knocked off his bearings, disoriented by his new contest with Kamala Harris and unsure of how to take her on.
lead_paragraph: The Aug. 2 dinner at the Bridgehampton, N.Y., home of Howard Lutnick, the Cantor Fitzgerald chief executive, was a high-powered affair. Among the roughly 130 people who dined under an air-conditioned tent were some of Donald Trump’s wealthiest supporters, including the billionaire hedge-fund financier Bill Ackman, who sat next to the former president, and Omeed Malik, the president of another fund, 1789 Capital.

headline: The Man Who Tried to Solve Immigration for the G.O.P.
abstract: The senator discusses how political calculations killed his border bill, the evangelical Christian vote and preparing for life after Trump.
lead_paragraph: At a campaign rally in Georgia late last month, Vice President Kamala Harris spoke to supporters about one of the biggest issues in this election: immigration. She talked up her record as the former attorney general of a border state, and she made a promise that if elected president, she would “bring back the border-security bill that Donald Trump killed” and sign it into law.

headline: ‘They Are Burned Alive’: A Doctor Captures the Toll of War on Gaza’s Children
abstract: An American pediatrician spent three weeks in one of Gaza’s last functioning hospitals. He shared a record of what he witnessed, including rare footage from inside the hospital, with The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Ahmad Yousaf, an American pediatrician and the director of an intensive care unit in Arkansas, embarked on a medical mission to Gaza, believing his expertise could help patients receive the advanced health care he was accustomed to providing. But what he encountered far exceeded his worst expectations, compelling him to document the devastation.

headline: How One Church in San Francisco Is Reinventing Itself
abstract: The Grace Cathedral in San Francisco costs $17,000 a day to operate. Bell tower tours, yoga, sound baths and Bobby McFerrin are helping to pay the bills.
lead_paragraph: The Grace Cathedral in San Francisco costs $17,000 a day to operate. Bell tower tours, yoga, sound baths and Bobby McFerrin are helping to pay the bills.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 427
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Aug. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,149
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, August 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: More Cities in Canada Dabble With Pedestrian-Only Streets
abstract: The pandemic made willing partners of retailers and restaurants to rethink how streets for cars can be converted into spaces for pedestrians.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare for traffic barriers to signal much other than a construction detour, but the bollards and concrete slabs blocking cars from a handful of Montreal roads this summer have a dual purpose. They also represent a type of public space emerging in more Canadian cities: pedestrianized streets.

headline: A Head-Spinning Debut
abstract: Breaking, the hip-hop dance style born in the Bronx five decades ago, is now an Olympic sport.
lead_paragraph: Breaking is a new sport at this year’s Summer Olympics — at least we’ll call it a sport for the sake of the Games. You probably know it as break dancing, the art form in which performers spin, pose, glide and dance across the floor with incredible athleticism and charisma. The event debuted yesterday in Paris with the women’s, or B-Girls’, competition. Ami Yuasa of Japan, known as B-Girl Ami, bested Lithuania’s Dominika Banevic, or B-Girl Nicka, to win breaking’s first gold medal. The men, or B-Boys, are competing today.

headline: Russia Pushes Back at Ukraine’s Cross-Border Assault, but Kyiv Presses On
abstract: After several days of fighting in southwestern Russia, both sides are claiming successes. The battles are still being waged.
lead_paragraph: Russia is pushing back against Ukraine’s largest assault into Russian territory since the start of the war, sending troop reinforcements, establishing strict security measures in border areas and conducting airstrikes, according to the Russian Defense Ministry. One of the strikes on Ukrainian troops involved a thermobaric missile that causes a blast wave and suffocates those in its path, the ministry said.

headline: Natural Birth and Breastfeeding:The Decisions That Women Face
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Michelle Goldberg, part of a series challenging conventional wisdom.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: My Mother’s Favorite Music Taught Me How to Live Courageously
abstract: Juan Gabriel showed us a different way to exist, even if the world didn’t seem ready for it.
lead_paragraph: In the thick of the pandemic I moved back to El Paso, Texas, on the U.S.-Mexico border, where I’d been raised, for what I thought would be a temporary stay. But then the desert whispered. After years away, my body hungered for the quiet wisdom of this land.

headline: There Is Still a Biden Scandal
abstract: America could stand to learn a bit more about how the White House has been working recently.
lead_paragraph: One of the Biden White House’s greatest achievements, from the perspective of its staffers, if not necessarily the country, has been to deny the press the kind of juicy leaks that were constant under Donald Trump and frequent under his predecessors. Save for a very narrow period of time, that is, when there was a push to force an aging president toward the exits: Then and only then we got a drip-drip-drip of fascinating inside information.

headline: Trump, by the Numbers
abstract: It can be treacherous, measuring your worth in ego arithmetic.
lead_paragraph: As long as I’ve covered Republican campaigns, there has been racial fearmongering: Dark-skinned people are coming to hurt you. Be very afraid.

headline: My Travel Tips for Seeing the World’s Best Places
abstract: From fake wedding bands to decoy wallets, here’s some advice for safely roaming our planet.
lead_paragraph: ’Tis the season for vacations, so let me make my pitch that the best travel is not lounging at a beach resort but rather journeying into a different world. We all need relaxation at times, but nothing beats the thrill of a trip of discovery and the education that comes with it.

headline: Kamala Harris Is Speaking. Is She Listening?
abstract: For a candidate who positions herself as caring, her failure to acknowledge the pain of Gaza protesters is especially jarring.
