lead_paragraph: At a campaign rally in the Detroit area on Wednesday, Kamala Harris was speaking about the threat of Project 2025 and the Trump agenda when a small group of protesters interrupted her. I couldn’t make out their words, but it was reported that they were shouting something about Gaza. Harris reacted with her trademark “I am speaking now.” The protesters persisted. Harris’s tone grew stern. “You know what?” she said. “If you want Donald Trump to win, then say that. Otherwise, I’m speaking.” She continued, to cheers from the crowd. The protesters were escorted out.

headline: The Social Media Olympics
abstract: More lenient posting rules for Olympic athletes have helped spark a deluge of successful social media content. Some say that’s changing how we watch the Games.
lead_paragraph: Just moments after the American wrestler Sarah Hildebrandt won a gold medal at the Paris Games, she let the whole world know what she was thinking:

headline: Aftermath of Israeli Airstrike That Killed Dozens in Gaza City
abstract: Palestinians looked through rubble after a deadly Israeli airstrike hit a school turned shelter in northern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Palestinians looked through rubble after a deadly Israeli airstrike hit a school turned shelter in northern Gaza.

headline: Is It Harris’ or Harris’s? Add a Walz, and It’s Even Trickier.
abstract: With Vice President Kamala Harris and Gov. Tim Walz running on the same ticket, grammar geeks are in overdrive.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris chose Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate, she put to rest weeks of speculation over the future of the Democratic ticket. But the battle over apostrophes was just getting started.

headline: ‘This Recipe Just Made My Summer’
abstract: This charred corn and chickpea salad with lime crema is fast and easy, and it’s already a hit with readers.
lead_paragraph: I know I just recently wrote about a different Hetty Lui McKinnon recipe — her dumpling and smashed cucumber salad, and quite, er, effusively — but look at this charred corn and chickpea salad. The burnished little corn nuggets, together with plump lil’ chickpeas! The peppery arugula and tender cilantro! Everything bound together with a simplified crema, a mix of sour cream, lime juice, garlic, salt and pepper! You’ll excuse me for my excitement over another Hetty hit.

headline: When Olympic Sponsors Go Rogue
abstract: LVMH and Samsung intruded on previously sacrosanct spaces at the Paris Games, angering fellow sponsors and raising concerns about a repeat at the closing ceremony.
lead_paragraph: When the French luxury goods conglomerate LVMH agreed to pay about $175 million to underwrite the organizing committee for the Paris Olympics, the company, owned by France’s richest person, Bernard Arnault, asked for more than any previous sponsor had ever done. Organizers of the Games, desperate for that cash, appeared to have said yes at every turn.

headline: Where Does JD Vance’s Ideology Really Come From?
abstract: The vice-presidential candidate has right-wing friends in high places.
lead_paragraph: The single most troubling thing about Senator JD Vance — his bizarre understanding of the work of J.R.R. Tolkien notwithstanding — is his close relationship with some of the most extreme elements of the American right.

headline: Ancient Calendar, Recently Discovered, May Document a Long-Ago Disaster
abstract: The markings on a pillar in southern Turkey are more than decorations on the stone, a researcher at the University of Edinburgh says. They may memorialize a time when comet fragments struck Earth.
lead_paragraph: A researcher at the University of Edinburgh has discovered what he believes is the earliest calendar of its kind at Gobekli Tepe, an archaeological excavation site in what is now southern Turkey that used to be an ancient complex of temple-like enclosures.

headline: Israeli Strikes on Schools Pose a Life-or-Death Choice for Civilians
abstract: Schools in Gaza have taken in tens of thousands of people seeking safety. Israel, arguing that Hamas uses the shelters, has struck school grounds repeatedly.
lead_paragraph: A deadly Israeli strike on a school turned shelter in northern Gaza on Saturday exposed an agonizing dilemma for civilians in Gaza seeking safety after 10 months of war.

headline: Travis Scott Released From Custody After Confrontation at a Paris Hotel
abstract: The star rapper had been accused on Friday of assaulting a security guard at a luxury hotel in Paris. No charges were filed against him, according to prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: The rapper Travis Scott was released from police custody on Saturday, a day after he was detained following a confrontation with a security guard at a Paris hotel, prosecutors said.

headline: The U.S. women’s soccer team finds its way back to the top by beating an old rival.
abstract: Mallory Swanson scored the winner in the 57th minute, neatly slotting home a shot from the left side off an assist from Korbin Albert.
lead_paragraph: Led by a new coach and a largely refreshed roster after a disappointing World Cup performance last year, the U.S. women’s soccer team claimed Olympic gold for the first time since 2012 with a 1-0 victory over Brazil at Parc des Princes in Paris on Saturday.

headline: The Olympics’ Toughest Act: Balancing Sports and Politics
abstract: The Olympics have long been a stage for political expression, for athletes who take the opportunity. Some do, while others choose to focus strictly on their sport.
lead_paragraph: The athletes had lost. Their time in Paris was over. And they were, in this moment of defeat by a team from a political rival, not even allowed the comfort of their homeland’s name and flag.

headline: Los Angeles Has Promised a ‘Car-Free’ Olympics in 2028. Can It Do It?
abstract: The countdown is on for the city, which will host the next Summer Games and is working on transit upgrades to accommodate hundreds of thousands of visitors.
lead_paragraph: In their winning bid to host the 2028 Summer Olympics, Los Angeles leaders pledged that the city’s version of the Games would be the greenest ever — a goal they planned to achieve in large part by making access to the event “car-free.”

headline: Hawaii Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Hawaii primary elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Hawaii primary elections.

headline: Harris Campaign Says Walz ‘Misspoke’ in a Comment About His Military Service
abstract: The Democratic vice-presidential nominee has come under attack from Republicans, who have suggested that he overstated his military record and avoided combat.
lead_paragraph: Officials for Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign are trying to clean up remarks made in 2018 by her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, that gave the impression that he had served in combat, just days after the campaign had inadvertently drawn attention to them to illustrate Mr. Walz’s views about responsible gun ownership.

headline: Walz in the National Guard: A Steady Rise Ending With a Hard Decision
abstract: In a military career that spanned three decades, Tim Walz achieved one of the highest enlisted ranks in the Army. Some peers took issue with the timing of his retirement.
lead_paragraph: In the 1980s, the U.S. military was in the middle of a transformation. The Vietnam War was over, and a force once staffed with drafted troops who had fought and died in the jungles of Southeast Asia was transitioning to ranks filled solely with volunteers.

headline: The B-boys and B-girls of breaking put a new spin on the Summer Games.
abstract: The first Olympic breaking competition received energetic response from those in attendance, but the sport’s future in the Games remained unclear.
lead_paragraph: Breaking announced itself as an Olympic sport in Paris, making a memorable debut powered by a backbeat. Time will tell if the sport — really more of an art form — will become an Olympic staple, but it didn’t lack for exposure at these Games.

headline: Eddie Canales, 76, Dies; Gave Migrants Water, and Dignity
abstract: After a long career as a union organizer, he came out of retirement in 2013 to form the South Texas Human Rights Center and provide lifesaving aid.
lead_paragraph: Eddie Canales, a human rights advocate who fought to save migrants trekking across the harsh terrain of South Texas, died on July 30 at his home in Corpus Christi. He was 76.

headline: U.S. men’s basketball was tested. Stephen Curry had the answer.
abstract: A flurry of Stephen Curry 3-pointers helped the United States survive a French challenge and win a fifth straight gold medal.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Curry had French defenders draped all over him like shrink wrap, but it hardly mattered. Fans across the world had seen this show before; only the stage was different. Playing in his first Olympics, Curry made the most of the moment, sinking a series of late 3-pointers — each more preposterous than the last — to lead the United States to a 98-87 win over France in the men’s basketball gold medal game.

headline: Take the El Train
abstract: Caryn Robbins presents an excellent puzzle for her Sunday debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: What Caused a Plane to Fall From the Sky in Brazil?
abstract: Officials are investigating potential causes of a plane crash that killed 62 people near São Paulo. Using videos and other clues, aviation experts have formed theories.
lead_paragraph: Brazilian investigators on Saturday began analyzing the black boxes from a São Paulo-bound flight to try to understand why the passenger plane fell from 17,000 feet on Friday, in a crash that killed all 62 on board.

headline: Israel Criticized After Strike Kills Scores in Gaza
abstract: Israeli officials defended the attack on a former school compound, saying Hamas was using it as a base for military operations in Gaza City.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike early Saturday hit a school compound in northern Gaza where displaced Palestinians were sheltering, killing dozens of people, according to Gazan officials.

headline: Harris Hopes a New Playbook Will Neutralize G.O.P. Attacks on Immigration
abstract: The Democratic presidential nominee has been pummeled by Donald J. Trump and other Republicans on her immigration record. She is now trying an approach that Democrats say has worked before.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Republicans have pummeled Vice President Kamala Harris on immigration, blaming her for President Biden’s policies at the border.

headline: Hawaii 1st Congressional District Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Hawaii primary election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Hawaii primary election.

headline: Hawaii 2nd Congressional District Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Hawaii primary election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Hawaii primary election.

headline: Hawaii U.S. Senate Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Hawaii primary election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Hawaii primary election.

headline: Rallying in Las Vegas, Harris Pledges to End Federal Taxes on Tips
abstract: In the final stop of the Harris-Walz introductory tour, Vice President Kamala Harris said that, if elected, she would end federal income tax on tips, mirroring a proposal made by former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris said on Saturday that she would seek to end federal income taxes on tips if she were elected president, mirroring a policy proposal that former President Donald J. Trump made earlier this year.

headline: The Olympics, a Triumph of Ambition, Lift France From Its Gloom
abstract: All sectors of society came together to achieve the nation’s dream for the Games. Success has shown that unity is possible, if often elusive.
lead_paragraph: Even the jumps at the Olympic equestrian events were meticulously crafted works of art. In the gardens of the Château de Versailles, riders negotiated fences modeled on the Arc de Triomphe, the Eiffel Tower, Paris bistros, streets with a horse in their name like Passage du Cheval Blanc and a stained-glass window from Notre-Dame.

headline: Too Much of Our Seafood Has a Dark Secret
abstract: We use the world’s fish as if it were a limitless line of credit. But this credit is running out.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of What to Eat on a Burning Planet, a series exploring bold ideas to secure our food supply. Read more about this project in a note from Eliza Barclay, Opinion’s climate editor.

headline: Disney Details Vast Theme Park Expansion Projects
abstract: The company, which has recently seen softening visitor demand, will spend billions to build new rides and expand its cruise ship fleet to 13 from nine.
lead_paragraph: When Disney announced last year that it planned to spend $60 billion over the next decade to expand its theme park and cruise businesses, double the amount spent over the previous decade, the company’s stock price instantly dropped.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 11, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: The My Ten article on July 28, featuring Leslie Uggams, included an incorrect statement by Uggams about her voting history. Uggams, 81, has voted since she was of voting age, not since she turned 18. (The voting age was 21 until it was lowered to 18 in 1971.)

headline: Quotation of the Day: Lahaina Sifts Its Layers of History as It Rebuilds
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “If you look at Lahaina from the mountain to the ocean, you could basically have a walk through time.”

headline: What Killed Harmony Ball-Stribling?
abstract: One woman’s death reveals the myriad ways in which social and economic factors endanger pregnant women in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The last day Byron Stribling spent with his wife, Harmony, was the Fourth of July in 2021. A great day, he always says.

headline: The Most Wanted ‘Girl’ in Fashion
abstract: How did Miu Miu become fashion’s biggest success story — halfway to $1 billion in sales for 2024?
lead_paragraph: Every season, many lovely dresses are shown in many lovely cities. Runways are a montage of opulence — exquisite suits in Paris, sumptuous bags in Milan. It can be beautiful. It can be skull-crushingly boring.

headline: Bari Weiss Knows Exactly What She’s Doing
abstract: The founder of The Free Press has built a new media empire by persuading audiences that she is a teller of dangerous truths.
lead_paragraph: Bari Weiss has long been blessed with two superpowers, those close to her say: She knows how to make useful enemies, and she knows how to make useful friends.

headline: A Place Where It Snows All Summer
abstract: At a factory in western New York, the holiday décor brand Buffalo Snow has been manufacturing blizzards for almost 40 years.
lead_paragraph: On an 80-degree Friday afternoon in July, at a factory just outside Buffalo, it was snowing.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘We Exchanged Small Talk, and I Asked Him About the Hat’
abstract: Saving a treasured item from the trash, making summer plans and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: A Jazz DJ’s Lifetime of Knowledge Leaves Queens for a New Nashville Home
abstract: Phil Schaap’s childhood home held what may be the largest collection of recorded jazz interviews, an archive that will now be housed at Vanderbilt University.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, the red clapboard house on Clio Street in eastern Queens seemed frozen in time.

headline: Behind the Scenes of the ‘Treasure Hunt’ for Olympic History
abstract: Members of the Olympic Museum’s heritage acquisitions team fan out during the Games to get donations to put on display in Lausanne, Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: They met in locker rooms. They met in suites. They met in hallways. The interactions were usually brief.

headline: The Summer Camps of Ukraine’s Forests: Hikes, First Aid and Military Readiness
abstract: As the once carefree summers of Ukrainian childhood and young adulthood are forever altered by war, traditional camps have taken on a more patriotic tone.
lead_paragraph: In a forest in western Ukraine, a few dozen young men and women stood at attention in two lines in the fading evening light. Some had fake guns slung over their shoulders.

headline: A Telling of the Scopes Monkey Trial Where Evolution Is Not the Point
abstract: In “Keeping the Faith,” Brenda Wineapple finds an ongoing battle over the soul of America in a century-old trial.
lead_paragraph: The schools were banning books. White supremacists were marching in the streets. The donor class was waging a war on democracy. Immigrants, wayward women, bad music and a godless elite were blamed for, well, everything. There’s a lot about the 1920s that feels familiar today. How are we to make sense of the last time America came this close to fascism?

headline: She Was Caught Off Guard When He Left Her. Maybe She Shouldn’t Have Been.
abstract: In the Swedish author Moa Herngren’s latest novel, “The Divorce,” a middle-aged mother is about to head off on a family holiday in the Baltic when she realizes her husband isn’t coming.
lead_paragraph: Despite a beautiful translation by Alice Menzies — the prose elegantly simple, self-assured — the Swedish author, journalist and screenwriter Moa Herngren’s latest novel, “The Divorce,” is a literary train wreck: horrifying, if compelling enough to be so. Fans of “Bonus Family,” the Netflix show she co-created, may want to set aside a day to tackle this new episode in her oeuvre. But those who prefer logical chronologies, or characters whose thoughts and interactions resemble those of human beings, or some self-awareness on the part of the author, may wish to steer clear.

headline: The Surprise of the Olympics: Breakers’ Delight
abstract: Breaking, the dance form created more than 50 years ago in the Bronx, has made its Olympic debut. It’s not a sport, but does that matter?
lead_paragraph: By the time the B-girl finals wrapped up on Friday, the newly introduced Olympic event of breaking had passed a test. It was not awful. It was not just a litany of power moves. It was funny. It was sweet. Musicality mattered. By the end, I was completely invested.

headline: Can Free Rent Revive Downtown San Francisco?
abstract: The city, which is among those most devastated in the country after the pandemic, is trying to lure businesses back with a free-rent period.
lead_paragraph: There’s a buzz of energy in downtown San Francisco from a source that has been missing for years: occupied storefronts.

headline: One Man’s Quest to Make Luxury Sunblock
abstract: Dermatologist Antony Nakhla created a beauty brand for his clients who include some of Southern California’s most pampered people. But he wondered: Could he also get them to use sunscreen?
lead_paragraph: Before he introduced his skin care line, Dr. Antony Nakhla, a Newport Beach, Calif. based dermatologist, would frequently vet the products his patients were using. More often than not, he was unimpressed.

headline: Why Schools Are Racing to Ban Student Phones
abstract: As the new school year starts, a wave of new laws that aim to curb distracted learning is taking effect in Indiana, Louisiana and other states.
lead_paragraph: Cellphones have become a school scourge. More than 70 percent of high school teachers say student phone distraction is a “major problem,” according to a survey this year by Pew Research.

headline: Rethinking Tourism With the Renewal of a Beloved Italian Path
abstract: Officials hope the reopening of the Via dell’Amore will be an opportunity to rethink tourism in Cinque Terre, getting visitors off the beaten path.
lead_paragraph: In Riomaggiore, one of the five vertigo-inducing villages that make up Cinque Terre, which hug the steep cliffs of Italy’s northwestern coast, just about everyone has a memory of the Via dell’Amore, or Love’s Lane.

headline: Kid Rock Threw the Party. MAGA Faithful Brought the Joy, Rage and Smirnoff Ice.
abstract: A music festival headlined by the pro-Trump musician offered a snapshot of a maturing American subculture, with a mash-up of hedonism, rebellion and beer-guzzling pursuit of happiness.
lead_paragraph: Alan Jeanetti, a 73-year-old retired barber, was tailgating with friends before Rock the Country, a touring music festival headlined by the pro-Trump musician Kid Rock. Mr. Jeanetti’s head was wrapped in a star-spangled bandanna. His T-shirt declared, “I Don’t Care.”

headline: Atop ABC, a Personal Connection to Kamala Harris
abstract: The candidate is a longtime friend of Dana Walden, a senior Disney executive whose portfolio includes ABC News, the host of the next debate. ABC says she does not weigh in on editorial decisions.
lead_paragraph: On paper, the potential for a conflict of interest seems obvious: ABC News, the host of next month’s high-stakes presidential debate, falls under the purview of a top corporate executive at Disney who happens to be longtime friends with the Democratic nominee.

headline: Sidestepping Deployed Kenyan Forces, Haiti Gangs Continue Reign of Terror
abstract: Weeks after an international police force began arriving to take on gangs, armed groups are redirecting their campaign of terror outside the capital.
lead_paragraph: In the predawn hours on a Sunday in late July, members of one of Haiti’s largest armed gangs attacked the town of Ganthier, about 25 miles east of the capital and on a road that the authorities say is used to smuggle weapons.

headline: The All-Male Christian Group Seeking a Resurrection in the Trump Era
abstract: At a gathering this weekend, the evangelical organization Promise Keepers leaned into partisan politics it once eschewed.
lead_paragraph: With his back to the U.S. Capitol, Randy Phillips faced a sea of evangelical men who had traveled from all over the country to pray, sing and recommit themselves to their families.

headline: Black Men Rally for Kamala Harris, and Confront an Elephant in the Room
abstract: “I’m standing behind a Black woman to be president of the United States, and it doesn’t make me any less of a Black man,” said the Illinois attorney general. “I’m asking all of you all to do the same.”
lead_paragraph: A day after Vice President Kamala Harris announced that she intended to seek the Democratic presidential nomination, more than 40,000 Black men from across the country convened on a virtual fund-raising call to discuss what the moment required of them.

headline: How Has Tech Changed Your School Experience? We Want to Hear About It.
abstract: Some states are banning phones in schools to reduce classroom distraction and cyberbullying. Tell us about your experience with tech in schools.
lead_paragraph: Digital devices and apps can be great tools in schools. They can also be a classroom distraction or even a weapon.

headline: The Taste of Dirt
abstract: Daisy Alioto has big ambitions for her small media empire.
lead_paragraph: Daisy Alioto, a 33-year-old writer, editor and media executive, was looking at the 140 tons of dirt in the Earth Room, a permanent installation created by the conceptual artist Walter de Maria on the second floor of a loft in the SoHo neighborhood of Manhattan.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Kamala Harris’s First Week With Tim Walz
abstract: Lofty condemnations of Donald Trump have given way to mockery. A tough interview with a top journalist? That can wait. Above all, Democrats are in a surprising place: on offense.
lead_paragraph: As supporters walked into the first rally for Vice President Kamala Harris and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, they were given light-up wristbands like the ones Taylor Swift’s fans wear at her concerts.

headline: Tim Walz’s Long Relationship With China Defies Easy Stereotypes
abstract: Mr. Walz, the Democrats’ vice-presidential nominee, taught in China and has visited the country around 30 times. But he has also been critical of the Chinese government’s human rights record.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1989, Tim Walz faced a difficult choice.

headline: For Some Jewish Democrats, Heightened Worries About Antisemitism
abstract: Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania, who is Jewish, was subjected to intense opposition as Vice President Kamala Harris considered him for running mate.
lead_paragraph: For many American Jews, the prospect of Gov. Josh Shapiro of Pennsylvania as a running mate for Vice President Kamala Harris prompted elation — a balm for the feelings of alienation and anger they have harbored amid a wave of anti-Israel sentiment and rising antisemitism.

headline: Do Trump Fans Believe the Harris Hype? Not a Chance.
abstract: The former president’s loyal supporters say the buzz around Vice President Kamala Harris is merely a “honeymoon phase.”
lead_paragraph: Inside the sometimes upside-down world in which former President Donald J. Trump and his most passionate supporters commune, the current trajectory of the presidential race is totally fine. This has not been the worst three weeks of Mr. Trump’s campaign. Nothing to worry about.

headline: After Cold Shoulders for Biden, Senate Democrats Wrap Their Arms Around Harris
abstract: The change at the top of the Democratic ticket has scrambled strategies for congressional candidates, Democrats and Republicans alike.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden campaigned in Michigan last month, Representative Elissa Slotkin, the Democrats’ nominee for the state’s open Senate seat, was nowhere to be found. But on Wednesday night, just weeks after that no-show, Ms. Slotkin announced her full-throated support for her party’s new presidential ticket at a Detroit rally.

headline: ‘It Ends With Us,’ a Romance Based on a Best Seller, Soars at the Box Office
abstract: The film, which cost $25 million to make, is on track to earn an estimated $50 million in North America on its opening weekend, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: Colleen Hoover’s book “It Ends With Us” has been a fixture on the best-seller list for years. And now, the movie adaptation has become a smash at the box office. The $25 million film from Sony Pictures is on track to earn an estimated $50 million in the United States and Canada, box office analysts say.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 428
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Aug. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,150
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, August 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Katie Couric: Network Newscasts Need to Better Reflect America
abstract: In a year when the United States may see its first female president, we can’t have network newscasts that only feature male anchors.
lead_paragraph: Norah O’Donnell recently announced that she will be stepping down as anchor of “CBS Evening News” after the election, after five years at the helm. I know her tenure must have been both exhilarating and challenging — seeing a network anchor wearing lipstick and earrings might still be slightly jarring to those viewers who assume that authority figures have to look like Walter Cronkite.

headline: How Kamala Harris Is Already Changing the Face of Presidential Power
abstract: She has a unique challenge about what her race and gender mean together, which could reshape how Americans think about politics.
lead_paragraph: I have not been the biggest fan of Kamala Harris, but to my surprise, the candidate who underwhelmed in 2020 is gone. Since she became the presumptive Democratic nominee, I have watched all of candidate Harris’s public appearances for a sense of how she intends to run and possibly govern. The audiences have been vastly different — among them, the annual conclave of Zeta Phi Beta sorority, a National Federation of Teachers convention and the Philadelphia rally where Tim Walz made his first official appearance as her running mate.

headline: Biden Made Trump Bigger. Harris Makes Him Smaller.
abstract: Her campaign wants to be talked about and knows how to get people talking.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris has a very different theory of this election than Joe Biden did.

headline: To Save Conservatism From Itself, I Am Voting for Harris
abstract: If Trump loses, conservative Americans will have a chance to build something decent from the ruins of a party that was once a force for genuine good.
lead_paragraph: I believe life begins at conception. If I lived in Florida, I would support the state’s heartbeat bill and vote against the referendum seeking to liberalize Florida’s abortion laws. I supported the Dobbs decision and I support well-drafted abortion restrictions at the state and federal levels. I was a pro-life lawyer who worked for pro-life legal organizations. While I want prospective parents to be able to use I.V.F. to build their families, I do not believe that unused embryos should simply be discarded — thrown away as no longer useful.

headline: Schools Have a Tech Problem
abstract: We explore some of the tech challenges faced by educators.
lead_paragraph: As the new school year begins, school districts across the United States are cracking down on cellphones in classrooms. Teachers are tired of constantly pressing students to stop watching TikTok and messaging friends during class. In many schools, students have also used phones to threaten or bully their classmates.

headline: With Marathon Gold, Sifan Hassan Tests the Limits of Endurance
abstract: The Dutch Olympian added a victory in the longest race of the Games to her bronze medals in the 5,000 and 10,000 meters. “What was I thinking?” she said afterward.
lead_paragraph: Sifan Hassan couldn’t stop laughing at herself.

headline: What Will It Take for Hollywood to Grow Up?
abstract: Even R-rated movies are childish now.
lead_paragraph: By the end of this weekend, “Deadpool & Wolverine,” the latest film from Disney’s recently beleaguered Marvel Cinematic Universe franchise, will likely have surpassed $1 billion in worldwide ticket sales. This success would seem to be a win for audiences that want both big franchise movies and adult content. Unlike most of Disney’s superhero movies, which are carefully engineered to appeal to the widest possible commercial audience (adults, children and international censors), the R-rated “Deadpool & Wolverine” is stuffed full of foul language, sex jokes and gore.

headline: Biden Says He Dropped Out to Avoid Becoming a ‘Distraction’ for Democrats
abstract: In his first interview since ending his campaign, the president said it was imperative for the party to beat Donald J. Trump and accused him of being an ally of the Ku Klux Klan.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said in an interview that aired on Sunday that he had abandoned his bid for a second term because he did not want to create “a real distraction” for Democrats, but he expressed no second thoughts about whether he could still do the job, despite concerns about his age and capacity.

headline: Blueberry, Almond and Lemon, a Truly Great Trio
abstract: Yotam Ottolenghi’s iced, berry-dotted loaf cake is a summertime New York Times Cooking classic.
lead_paragraph: Good morning! Tejal here, filling in for Sam.

headline: Scofflaws and Other Hazards on the Roads
abstract: Readers react to articles about the rise in traffic deaths. Also: Neo-Nazis in Nashville; JD Vance and the rule of law; a ban on masks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Olympic Marathon Course Lets Amateurs Inside the Ropes
abstract: A public marathon and a series of overnight 10Ks offered recreational runners a chance to feel closer to the Games.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Jacquet, 49, is not an Olympic athlete, nor any kind of athlete at all.

headline: What ‘It Ends With Us’ Says About the Blake Lively Brand
abstract: The images onscreen are informed by the actress’s offscreen businesses, making the movie a fascinating study in the uses of star power.
lead_paragraph: Blake Lively’s hair is like a character unto itself in the new romantic drama “It Ends With Us.”

headline: Man Who Attacked Muslim Postal Carrier Is Sentenced to 37 Months in Prison
abstract: Kenneth Pinkney, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., pleaded guilty to a hate crime in assaulting the carrier, who was wearing a hijab as she delivered the mail in October.
lead_paragraph: A Florida man who engaged in a hate-motivated assault against a Muslim U.S. Postal Service carrier who was wearing a hijab in October, about two weeks after violence in Israel and Gaza erupted last year, was sentenced to a little more than three years in federal prison on Friday, prosecutors said.

headline: Bob Tischler, Who Helped Revive ‘Saturday Night Live,’ Dies at 78
abstract: A producer of “The National Lampoon Radio Hour” and albums by the Blues Brothers, he became S.N.L.’s head writer after a dismal season early in its history.
lead_paragraph: Bob Tischler, who was part of the production and writing team that helped revive “Saturday Night Live” after that groundbreaking comedy show fell into a deep creative trough in the 1980-81 season, died on July 13 at his home in Bodega Bay, Calif. He was 78.

headline: JD Vance Supports Trump on Presidential Influence Over Federal Reserve
abstract: The Republican vice-presidential nominee said presidents should have a say in determining the benchmark interest rate.
lead_paragraph: JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential candidate, said on Sunday that he “absolutely” agreed with Donald J. Trump’s recent suggestions that presidents should have a say in determining the Federal Reserve’s benchmark interest rate, signaling his support for political influence over the central bank.

headline: Jordan Chiles Lost a Bronze Medal Because an Appeal Was Four Seconds Late
abstract: An inquiry by Chiles’s coach led judges to adjust her score and give her a medal. A court ruled the inquiry came too late. Now, the I.O.C. wants her bronze back.
lead_paragraph: After learning that she might lose the bronze medal she won in the floor exercise at the Paris Olympics — the only individual medal she won at these Summer Games — the American gymnast Jordan Chiles took to social media on Saturday and posted four broken heart emojis on a black background.

headline: JD Vance Repeats ‘Anti-Family’ Criticism of Democrats on Sunday Morning News Show Tour
abstract: The Republican vice-presidential nominee also defended Donald Trump’s abortion policies.
lead_paragraph: In three interviews broadcast on Sunday morning, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, repeated his description of Democrats as “anti-family,” defended former President Donald J. Trump’s abortion policies and suggested that Vice President Kamala Harris was racist.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Woman Who Could Smell Parkinson’s’
abstract: She first noticed the scent on her husband. Now her abilities are helping unlock new research in early disease detection.
lead_paragraph: Les Milne was a consultant anesthesiologist, and his wife, Joy, typically found that he came home smelling of anesthetics, antiseptics and blood. But he returned one August evening in 1982, shortly after his 32nd birthday, smelling of something new and distinctly unsavory, of some thick must. From then on, the odor never ceased, though neither Les nor almost anyone but his wife could detect it. For Joy, even a small shift in her husband’s aroma might have been cause for distress, but his scent now seemed to have changed fundamentally, as if replaced by that of someone else.

headline: What to Know About the Democratic National Convention
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, will be the stars in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention is almost upon us, following the Republican convention last month. Once it’s over, it will be a 75-day sprint to Election Day.

headline: ‘Serenity Now!’ How ‘Seinfeld Night’ Became a New York Summer Tradition.
abstract: It’s a night that combines the zaniness of “Seinfeld,” a Coney Island freak show and a lower-level minor league baseball team with nothing to lose.
lead_paragraph: It all began 10 years ago as a whimsical one-off minor league baseball promotion that ended with a contest.

headline: Monday Briefing: Israel Widens Evacuation Orders
abstract: Plus, house calls for nomads.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, tens of thousands of people have fled the city of Khan Younis in Gaza after Israel’s military told them to evacuate. A new order issued yesterday covered the neighborhood of al-Jalaa, part of a humanitarian zone in southwestern Gaza. The Israeli military said it was planning to fight in the area because Hamas had “embedded terrorist infrastructure” there. Here’s the latest.

headline: Man Is Charged With Hate Crime in Stabbing Near Brooklyn Synagogue
abstract: The police said the man, Vincent Sumpter, yelled “Free Palestine” before stabbing another man near the headquarters of the Chabad-Lubavitch movement.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old Brooklyn man was charged with assault as a hate crime after the police said he yelled “Free Palestine” and “Do you want to die?” before stabbing a young man near a synagogue in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn early Saturday morning.

headline: Tom Cruise Jumps Off Stadium Roof to Pass Baton to Los Angeles
abstract: Cruise, one of Hollywood’s most well-known movie stars, rappelled down into the Stade de France, and the crowd of Olympians went wild as Paris handed over to the next Summer Games, in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: No, it wasn’t a scene from “Mission: Impossible.” Tom Cruise, one of Hollywood’s most well-known movie stars, rappelled down into the Stade de France as H.E.R. played guitar, and the crowd of Olympians went wild as Paris handed over to the next Summer Games, in Los Angeles. He accepted the Olympic flag, shook a lot of hands, jumped on a motorcycle, and drove right out of the stadium and into prerecorded footage.

headline: Tie, as Shoes
abstract: Shaun Phillips is back again already? You better believe it.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Trump Falsely Claims That the Crowds Seen at Harris Rallies Are Fake
abstract: The former president, in a series of social media posts, said that Vice President Kamala Harris had used A.I. technology to create images of fake crowds at her events.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has taken his obsession with the large crowds that Vice President Kamala Harris is drawing at her rallies to new heights, falsely declaring in a series of social media posts on Sunday that she had used artificial intelligence to create images and videos of fake crowds.

headline: Paris, Uncharacteristically Giddy, Bids Au Revoir to the Olympics
abstract: A joyous Games, a cleaned-up Seine and improvements to the region brought cheer to Parisians as they handed off the Summer Olympics to Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: There were French firemen flipping like acrobats, a musician playing a piano that hung vertically in the air, and Olympic athletes overwhelming the stage and forming a mosh pit around the French electro-pop band Phoenix.

headline: The Hacking of Presidential Campaigns Begins, With the Usual Fog of Motives
abstract: Donald J. Trump said Iranians hacked his campaign but only obtained “publicly available” data. Microsoft said a “high-ranking official” at a presidential campaign was a hacking target.
lead_paragraph: For the third presidential election in a row, the foreign hacking of the campaigns has begun in earnest. But this time, it’s the Iranians, not the Russians, making the first significant move.

headline: Jordan Chiles Lost a Bronze. She’s Not the First American Affected by a Medal Change.
abstract: A court invalidated the gymnast’s win. Here are other notable cases of Americans who lost (or gained) a medal after an event.
lead_paragraph: Taking away an Olympian’s medal is unusual — but not uncommon. On Sunday, the American gymnast Jordan Chiles became the latest athlete to lose one.

headline: How Close Are the Planet’s Climate Tipping Points?
abstract: Earth’s warming could trigger sweeping changes in the natural world that would be hard, if not impossible, to reverse.
lead_paragraph: Earth’s warming could trigger sweeping changes in the natural world that would be hard, if not impossible, to reverse.

headline: Swim Towards the Shark
abstract: In a crisis, when all logic suggests that you get away, how will you respond?
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Harris Appeals to Tech Leaders in a Return to San Francisco
abstract: A Sunday fund-raiser offered Vice President Kamala Harris a chance to turn the page on a sometimes frosty relationship between President Biden and Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden who?

headline: Nights in Las Vegas Are Becoming Dangerously Hot
abstract: In some fast-growing Sun Belt cites, “the overnight lows kind of sneak up on you.”
lead_paragraph: In some fast-growing Sun Belt cites, “the overnight lows kind of sneak up on you.”

headline: Mayor Adams Names Robert Tucker as New Fire Commissioner
abstract: Mr. Tucker will succeed Laura Kavanagh as leader of the Fire Department. A longtime supporter of the department, he has worked for 25 years in law enforcement and private security.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York on Monday named Robert S. Tucker to head the Fire Department, replacing the first female commissioner, who faced resistance from top chiefs during her short tenure.

headline: Spain Is Thirsty. Here’s How It Gets Water.
abstract: To supply water for a number of needs, from tourism to agriculture, the country and other dry nations are increasingly relying on desalination plants that convert seawater into fresh water.
lead_paragraph: On a fiery hot day in late June, tourists filled the cafes and hotel rooms along Spain’s Mediterranean coast, including in Torrevieja, a small city of tightly stacked apartment blocks running along a curved beach.

headline: How Los Angeles Aims to Make a Profit on the 2028 Olympics
abstract: The Summer Games will be the third for Los Angeles as host, but it will be a challenge to repeat the financial success of 1984.
lead_paragraph: What Paris Olympics? Los Angeles is already looking ahead.

headline: The Filipinos Living in the Shadow of China’s Military Might
abstract: More than 200 civilian settlers on a contested island in the South China Sea find themselves on the frontier of a possible conflict with China.
lead_paragraph: For travelers flying into the tiny island of Thitu, the reality of China’s territorial ambition becomes instantly clear. There they are: dozens of Chinese ships surrounding a speck of land that a few hundred Filipinos call home.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 90 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Chimp Crazy’ and ‘The Challenge’
abstract: HBO airs a new documentary that could fall into the category “exotic animals as pets gone wrong.” The MTV competition show is back for a 40th season.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Aug. 12-18. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: What’s Happening in Britain Is Shocking. But It’s Not Surprising.
abstract: The chaos has been coming.
lead_paragraph: The scenes are shocking.

headline: Firefighters Battle ‘Extremely Dangerous’ Wildfire Near Athens
abstract: The blaze broke out in a town near the Greek capital on Sunday, damaging buildings and prompting evacuations. Strong winds have helped the fire spread.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of firefighters in Greece were battling a major wildfire on Monday that broke out near Athens a day earlier and has raced through parched forest, destroying properties and prompting evacuation orders, according to the authorities.

headline: Word of the Day: luminescent
abstract: This word has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word luminescent has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 15 in “Diving Into the Dominican Republic’s Springs and Rivers” by Mya Guarnieri:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: His Murder Conviction Was Overturned. Why Is He Still in Prison?
abstract: Brian Scott Lorenz was convicted of killing a young mother near Buffalo in 1993. The district attorney is fighting a judge’s decision last year to throw out the case.
lead_paragraph: After 30 years in jail, Brian Scott Lorenz thought he might be going home. Last summer, an Erie County judge threw out his conviction in a 1993 murder that had set off a raft of accusations involving bad cops, famous killers and prosecutorial misconduct.

headline: Uber, Facing Sexual-Assault Litigation, Pushes Plan That May Curb Suits
abstract: Uber has spent millions trying to get a proposal on the Nevada ballot that would restrict the legal fees that bankroll many lawsuits against companies.
lead_paragraph: It has been a decades-long dream of corporate America: making it harder for aggrieved customers, workers and others to file lawsuits against companies seeking compensation for alleged injuries, mistreatment and other harms.

headline: These Are New York’s Hottest Bus Stops. And Not in a Good Way.
abstract: Bus stops without trees or shelter are leaving riders sweating as they wait — and wait — for buses that a transportation group says do not come fast enough.
lead_paragraph: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Olympics’ Most Difficult Balancing Act: Politics
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It’s as if he told the refugees in the camp, ‘Nothing is impossible; here I am.’”

headline: No Corrections: Aug. 12, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Debunked Science Put This Man on Death Row. He’s About to Be Executed Anyway.
abstract: Charles Don Flores deserves a trial based on evidence, not discredited science.
lead_paragraph: Charles Don Flores deserves a trial based on evidence, not discredited science.

headline: U.S. Moves a Guided-Missile Submarine to the Middle East Amid Fears of Escalation
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III spoke with his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, the Pentagon said. In an unusual disclosure, it said Mr. Austin had ordered a submarine to the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has ordered the guided-missile submarine Georgia to the Middle East, underscoring the threat of the regional crisis involving Israel and Iran that has threatened to spark a wider war, the Pentagon said.

headline: How to Make a Nation of Meat Eaters Crave the Humble Bean
abstract: When it comes to food, pleasure is what changes the world.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of What to Eat on a Burning Planet, a series exploring bold ideas to secure our food supply. Read more about this project in a note from Eliza Barclay, Opinion’s climate editor.

headline: A Nazi Villa So Tainted Berlin Can’t Give It Away
abstract: The former estate of Joseph Goebbels, the Nazi propaganda minister, is too expensive to keep and perilous to sell. No one knows quite what to do with it.
lead_paragraph: Behind thickets of beech trees, overgrown with nettles and beside a blue lake an hour north of Berlin, a villa that once belonged to a Nazi mastermind quietly rots.

headline: The Science That Put This Man on Death Row Has Been Debunked. He’s Going to Be Executed Anyway.
abstract: Charles Don Flores deserves a trial based on evidence, not on discredited science.
lead_paragraph: The Opinion video above is the final episode in a series of three videos that take a stand against the death penalty in the United States. It features Charles Don Flores, who has been on death row in Texas since 1999, awaiting execution for a murder he insists he didn’t commit. That is where we met and filmed him.

headline: My Old Church’s Fundamentalist Wing Canceled Me
abstract: David French responds to reader reactions following his split from his church.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, the Opinion columnist David French and his family were canceled by their former church. In response, French wrote about the painful experience of being abandoned by his faith community. The column led to an outpouring from readers sharing their own thoughts and similar experiences. In this audio essay, French sits down with his editor, Aaron Retica, to discuss the fallout and listen to some of the responses he received from readers.

headline: Roam With Cowboys and Flamingos in France’s Wild, Wild South
abstract: Horses, bulls and birds of all types live among the pink marshes of the Camargue, a rugged landscape shaped by the relentless push and pull of sea and river.
lead_paragraph: A flamboyance of flamingos was feeding on plankton in a reed-lined marsh. The water reflected their lithe bodies beneath clouds the color of their plumage, blushed by the setting sun. Suddenly, my guide told me to grab my binoculars: Black silhouettes of cows waded through the marsh like hippos in the Serengeti. I had never seen cattle so graceful in the water. This aquatic ballet perfectly summed up the Camargue.

headline: Shelby Lynne Meets Her Moment, Again
abstract: Twenty-five years after the album that reshaped her career, the singer and songwriter unlocked a new creative groove, with the help of an all-female team in Nashville.
lead_paragraph: Shelby Lynne left Nashville both physically and metaphorically behind two and a half decades ago.

headline: Nate Silver Gives Us Good Odds for a Bad Future
abstract: In “On the Edge,” the election forecaster argues that the gambler’s mind-set has come to define modern life.
lead_paragraph: A common trope in dystopian fiction — “The Hunger Games,” “Chain-Gang All-Stars” — is the wealthy society that devotes itself to ever more exotic and expansive forms of gambling. Nate Silver, best known as a statistician and election modeler, makes the case that we are at least partway there.

headline: I.V.F. Threats in Alabama Drive Clinics to Ship Out Embryos
abstract: A court ruling that deemed frozen embryos “children” has motivated some patients and clinics to move embryos out of red states.
lead_paragraph: An emerging movement against in vitro fertilization is driving some doctors and patients in red states to move or destroy frozen embryos.

headline: A Boxy Bag Adds Structure to Any Outfit
abstract: Here are a few of the best, in neutral shades and classic rectangular shapes.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Pink Building Stands Out
abstract: A new building in Fort Greene was designed to encourage a more intimate living space, according to the builders.
lead_paragraph: At the intersection of Myrtle and Vanderbilt Avenues in Brooklyn, a restaurant and fish market sit on one side of Myrtle, while townhouses and an apartment building line Vanderbilt. Some of these buildings are made from brick, and most are neutral toned. But at the corner, one building is an outlier: It’s pink.

headline: They Gave a Home on Long Island a New Life. Then It Changed Theirs.
abstract: How the reimagining of a Hamptons house turned into a business partnership between a couple and their designer.
lead_paragraph: AS AN ANALOGY for life’s unpredictability, a home renovation goes far. There are few more literal ways in which we try to make our visions of the future concrete. But pipes leak, budgets creep and patience runs thin. Then there are the strange, happy accidents that come from making something personal under heightened conditions. When Andy McCune and Allie Fitzpatrick hired the interior designer Lauren Piscione to help them update an unusual modern house on Long Island in 2021, for example, they couldn’t have foreseen the joint venture they’d all begin together two years later.

headline: Do Countertop Compost Machines Really Work?
abstract: We’ve got the dirt on what the devices actually do, and what they don’t.
lead_paragraph: The sad vegetables at the back of your fridge won’t just be wasted when you finally throw them away: They could also contribute to global warming.

headline: Should You Get Another Covid Shot Now?
abstract: The virus is spreading, but new vaccines coming this fall could offer better protection. We asked experts about the right time for a booster.
lead_paragraph: Patients keep asking Dr. Peter Chin-Hong, an infectious disease specialist at the University of California, San Francisco, the same question: Is it time to get another Covid shot?

headline: Brands Love Influencers (Until Politics Get Involved)
abstract: Marketing firms are using artificial intelligence to help analyze influencers and predict whether they will opine about the election.
lead_paragraph: Brands love when social media stars take to Instagram or TikTok to advertise their soap, probiotic sodas, makeup and more. But many of those same brands are eager to avoid influencers who discuss politics.

headline: She’s Fighting Big Oil in Texas. But Republicans Want to Make Her D.A.
abstract: Looking to oust a Democratic district attorney in rural West Texas, Republicans have an unusual candidate: a Trump-hating lawyer who’s spent years battling over oil wells.
lead_paragraph: Few Democrats hold local office in the conservative parts of Texas, and Republicans have been eager to replace one who seemed particularly vulnerable: a longtime district attorney in a sparsely populated area of deep red, oil-rich ranches that lie some 250 miles east of El Paso.

headline: The Great Barnard College Diploma Mix-Up
abstract: Many graduates received someone else’s diploma in the mail. The college blamed a clerical error.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at why some Barnard College diplomas were recently mailed to the wrong graduates. We’ll also look at why more migrants are sleeping on city streets, in parks and on the subway.

headline: An Unexpected Bright Spot in Theater? Look to Wisconsin.
abstract: No musicals and no mics: At American Players Theater in Wisconsin, nothing comes between the actors, their words and the public.
lead_paragraph: For a regular theatergoer, a recent July evening in rural Wisconsin was peak surreal.

headline: Meet the ‘Hydraulic Press Girl,’ Dancing the Undanceable Online
abstract: Sarah McCreanor, or Smac, has attracted millions of followers with her reproductions of the weird-yet-familiar images and memes that shape internet culture.
lead_paragraph: Like comedians, dancers tend to be good imitators. They’re both masters of fine detail, able to pinpoint and replicate the minutiae that make a choreographic phrase, or a sketch character, click into focus.

headline: U.S. Officials to Visit China for Economic Talks as Trade Tensions Rise
abstract: The recently established U.S.-China Financial Working Group is set to meet for discussions about financial stability and curbing the flow of fentanyl.
lead_paragraph: A group of senior Biden administration officials is traveling to Shanghai this week for a round of high-level meetings intended to keep the economic relationship between the United States and China on stable footing amid mounting trade tensions between the two countries.

headline: What Happens Now in Young Thug’s YSL Trial?
abstract: Already the longest in Georgia history, the star rapper’s trial has been turned upside down. Here’s the latest as the case resumes after an eight-week delay.
lead_paragraph: More than two years since the arrest of the star Atlanta rapper Young Thug on racketeering, gang conspiracy and weapons charges, his trial alongside five co-defendants is already the longest in Georgia’s history. And it is nowhere near finished.

headline: Harris Should Take Divisions Over Gaza Seriously
abstract: It’s not just a few hecklers. Michigan voters’ concerns about Gaza cannot be dismissed.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, the signs did not look good for Kamala Harris in Michigan. Literally. A digital billboard on the side of a barn, which I saw while driving to Grayling, read, “Willie Brown Endorses Kamala,” a farmer’s snarky reminder of a chapter of Ms. Harris’s life — when she briefly dated the speaker of the California Assembly — that I’m pretty sure she’d prefer voters forget.

headline: $2.6 Million Homes in California
abstract: A renovated 1951 house in Los Angeles, a home with San Francisco Bay views in Greenbrae and a shingled house near the water in Manhattan Beach.
lead_paragraph: This house is in the hills of Echo Park, five minutes from Echo Park Lake, where swan-shaped paddle boats are available to rent, and from a busy stretch of Sunset Boulevard with cocktail bars, music venues and restaurants, including a brewery serving organic vegan food and a popular pizza parlor. It is within 10 minutes of Dodger Stadium and the walking trails surrounding Silver Lake Reservoir.

headline: Britain’s Anti-Immigrant Riots Pose Critical Test for Starmer
abstract: Even after restoring order, the new prime minister faces a bigger challenge: defusing the issues of fraying public services and a cost of living crisis that underlie the unrest.
lead_paragraph: With cars being torched and mosques and hotels housing asylum seekers under attack, the riots that swept Britain over the past two weeks have posed the first direct challenge to the new prime minister, Keir Starmer.

headline: The Harris-Walz Ticket Is Our Opportunity for Political Imagination
abstract: The candidates are creating space for our most extravagant imaginings.
lead_paragraph: Since Kamala Harris announced her campaign for president, I have felt about politics something other than despair and disgust. I wouldn’t call it hope, but I am engaged. I am curious about what is possible.

headline: New Public Art Rides the Rails in Chicago, Timed to the Convention
abstract: When the Democratic National Convention kicks off on Aug. 19, an array of art tied to the election season will greet visitors and Chicagoans alike.
lead_paragraph: Public art by world-renowned creators is a seminal part of Chicago’s urban landscape. Anish Kapoor’s beloved silver sculpture in downtown Millennium Park, known as “The Bean” (officially “Cloud Gate”), is as much a symbol of the city as Chicago’s sports stars and its skyscrapers.

headline: California’s Rice Royalty Is Stepping Down
abstract: Koda Farms, a family-run rice business revered by chefs, ends a century-long tradition.
lead_paragraph: When the water is cut in August, the rice fields of South Dos Palos, Calif., go from green to gold. As the plants dry, Robin and Ross Koda, the brother and sister duo who manage Koda Farms, wait for just the right moment to harvest.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,151
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Hacking Hits the 2024 Race, and a Pivotal Week for Gaza
abstract: Plus, a cheery au revoir to the Paris Olympics.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Connections Companion No. 429
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Aug. 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Inside the Three Worst Weeks of Trump’s Campaign
abstract: Kamala Harris’s entry into the race has knocked the former president off his bearings, unsure how to take her on.
lead_paragraph: For much of the past year, Donald J. Trump and those around him were convinced that victory in the presidential race was all but certain. Now, everything has changed, after the decision by President Biden not to seek a second term.

headline: The Changing Supply Chain
abstract: We explore why commerce has changed — and how companies and governments are reacting.
lead_paragraph: For decades, major companies have behaved as if geographic distance were almost irrelevant. A factory in China was the same as a factory in Michigan. The internet, container shipping and international trading arrangements had supposedly shrunk the globe.

headline: Facing a Ukrainian Incursion, Putin Directs His Rage at the West
abstract: Russian forces are pummeling Ukrainian positions along the front lines, Ukrainian military officials said, as attacks on Russian soil by Ukraine continue.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia lashed out at the West over Ukraine’s weeklong incursion into Russian territory, in a tense televised meeting with his top officials on Monday, a sign of how the surprise attack has unsettled the Kremlin.

headline: Investors Brace for Another Big Week
abstract: A new batch of inflation data and earnings from major retailers will again put the spotlight on consumer confidence and economic growth.
lead_paragraph: A sense of calm has returned to global markets on Monday, but the economic conditions that triggered last week’s roller coaster swings are still on many minds ahead of a pivotal week.

headline: Man Charged After Stabbing in London Tourist Hot Spot
abstract: A girl, 11, was recovering in a hospital after being attacked on Monday. The police said her mother, initially thought to have been stabbed, had not been injured.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE: A man has been charged with attempted murder after he stabbed an 11-year-old girl on Monday in London’s Leicester Square, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: Three Studies of MDMA Treatment Retracted by Scientific Journal
abstract: The psychedelic treatment, for PTSD, was rejected last week by government regulators.
lead_paragraph: The journal Psychopharmacology has retracted three papers about MDMA-assisted therapy based on what the publication said was unethical conduct at one of the study sites where the research took place.

headline: Piecing Together an Ancient Epic Was Slow Work. Until A.I. Got Involved.
abstract: Scholars have struggled to identify fragments of the epic of Gilgamesh — one of the world’s oldest literary texts. Now A.I. has brought an “extreme acceleration” to the field.
lead_paragraph: In 1872, in a quiet second-floor room at the British Museum, George Smith, a museum employee, was studying a grime-encrusted clay tablet when he came across words that would change his life. In the ancient cuneiform script, he recognized references to a stranded ship and a bird sent in search of land. After he had the tablet cleaned, Smith was certain he’d found a prototype of the biblical flood story.

headline: Democrats Turn to Their National Security Go-To for Trump Assassination Inquiry
abstract: Representative Jason Crow of Colorado, whom Democrats tapped for impeachment, investigations and tough questioning of President Biden, is their top member of a task force investigating the shooting.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jason Crow, a Colorado Democrat and former Army Ranger, had just ordered his second martini at a bar in Bucharest, Romania, when Representative Nancy Pelosi, the former speaker, called him with an urgent question: How quickly could he get to Ukraine?

headline: Make This Garlic Chicken With Guasacaca Sauce for the Sauce Alone
abstract: The mix of avocado, jalapeño, vinegar, lime, garlic, parsley and cilantro is simultaneously silky and sparkling.
lead_paragraph: Hello there! “Happy” Monday. Mia here, filling in for Melissa Clark, who will be back next week.

headline: For the Rescuer of an Ancient Shipwreck, Trouble Arrived in the Mail
abstract: The packages were sent to a woman whose work had led to the heralded recovery of the Kyrenia, and to new insights into classical Greek seafaring. But their ancient contents were a problem.
lead_paragraph: In the 1960s, Susan Womer Katzev, a marine illustrator, and her husband, the archaeologist Michael L. Katzev, spent two summers diving with a team beneath the lapping waves of the Mediterranean off Cyprus.

headline: Heat Contributed to 47,000 Deaths in Europe Last Year, but Relief Programs Helped
abstract: A new study shows how deadly warming can be, and how behavioral and social changes can reduce mortality.
lead_paragraph: More than 47,000 Europeans died from heat-related causes during 2023, the world’s hottest year on record, a new report in Nature Medicine has found.

headline: Elections Officials Battle a Deluge of Disinformation
abstract: County clerks and secretaries of state are overwhelmed this year, as they stare down a “perpetual moving target” of new conspiracy theories, political pressure and threats.
lead_paragraph: Tate Fall is overwhelmed.

headline: Netanyahu Slams Gallant for Questioning the Goal of ‘Total Victory’ in Gaza
abstract: A strongly worded statement from the Israeli prime minister’s office accused Yoav Gallant, the defense minister, of harming the chances of reaching a hostage release deal.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel blasted his defense minister, Yoav Gallant, on Monday after the Israeli news media reported that Mr. Gallant had disparaged the Israeli leader’s goal of “total victory” over Hamas, the armed Palestinian group Israel has been battling in Gaza.

headline: Do You Know These Novels That Were Adapted Into Video Games?
abstract: Try this short quiz on popular fiction that has been transformed into interactive adventures.
lead_paragraph: Try this short quiz on popular fiction that has been transformed into interactive adventures.

headline: Gas Explosion Destroys House in Maryland, Killing Homeowner and Gas Employee
abstract: A 35-year-old contractor with Baltimore Gas and Electric was investigating an issue at the home, which exploded early Sunday morning.
lead_paragraph: A gas explosion in northern Maryland destroyed a home on Sunday morning, killing the 73-year-old homeowner who was reportedly preparing the property for sale, fire officials said on Sunday.

headline: Swedish Prosecutors Drop Case Against Disqualified Eurovision Entrant
abstract: Investigators could not prove that Joost Klein, the Dutch entrant, had behaved threateningly during an incident shortly before the event final.
lead_paragraph: Swedish prosecutors said Monday that they were closing an investigation into Joost Klein, the Netherlands entry to this year’s Eurovision Song Contest, whom organizers threw out of the singing competition hours before the final in May after an altercation with a camerawoman.

headline: Calvin Royal III Creates a Ballet Festival With Intention and Care
abstract: With “Unite,” a festival he planned and curated at the Joyce Theater, Royal is “taking the time to do things right,” he said.
lead_paragraph: It was oppressively hot on a recent afternoon in a dance studio at a former Boys’ Club of New York in the East Village. Two long-limbed dancers, precise but visibly tired, rehearsed, as a coach gave suggestions. The whirring of fans made it almost impossible to hear what was being said. But the two dancers, Chloe Misseldine and Calvin Royal III, had no trouble understanding each other. The moment Misseldine faced Royal and stepped into a long, stretched arabesque, his face lit up.

headline: Wildfire Spreads Near Athens
abstract: Firefighters were working around the clock to contain the fast-moving blaze.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters were working around the clock to contain the fast-moving blaze.

headline: It Was a Hot Real Estate Trade. Now Investors Are Worried.
abstract: Drawn by the opportunity to invest with private equity firms, small investors rushed into real estate investment trusts. But the funds have lost some appeal as interest rates have climbed.
lead_paragraph: Given the opportunity to park money with the world’s largest private equity firms, ordinary investors rushed in. Getting out might not be so easy.

headline: Trump Returns to X in Victory for Elon Musk
abstract: The former president posted a campaign video ahead of a scheduled interview on the platform with Mr. Musk, who reinstated Mr. Trump’s account shortly after buying the site in 2022.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump posted on X Monday morning, handing a victory to Elon Musk, the social media platform’s owner, who for months has urged the former president to use the site again.

headline: Paying More Attention to His Appearance Than Hers
abstract: They’re the same age, but pundits and voters can’t stop talking about how much older Tim Walz looks than Kamala Harris. It’s not the only way her running mate seems to be absorbing some of the scrutiny usually heaped on female candidates.
lead_paragraph: Historically, women in the public eye have been described as women first, and everything else second: “women politicians,” not just politicians; “women authors”; or “women artists,” for example. Along with the labeling comes the long list of expectations, especially in politics, which typically breaks down into three basic categories: body (Is she pretty enough, or maybe too pretty? Does she dress badly or too well?); temperament (Is she nice or overbearing? Is she too emotional? Too ambitious?); and family (Is she a childless cat lady? A mother? Is her husband really running the show?).

headline: Harris Says Trump Will Repeal Obamacare. Trump Now Claims He’ll Make It ‘Better.’
abstract: The popularity of the Affordable Care Act has changed the political strategy of Republicans, who are no longer campaigning to end the law.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate Tim Walz, the Minnesota governor, have quickly made the Affordable Care Act central to their campaign, raising the specter of another Republican repeal effort next year if former President Donald J. Trump wins the White House.

headline: Older Adults Do Not Benefit From Moderate Drinking, Large Study Finds
abstract: Virtually any amount increased the risk for cancer, and there were no heart benefits, the researchers reported.
lead_paragraph: Even light drinking was associated with an increase in cancer deaths among older adults in Britain, researchers reported on Monday in a large study. But the risk was accentuated primarily in those who had existing health problems or who lived in low-income areas.

headline: Why Iran Has Not Yet Retaliated Against Israel for Hamas Leader’s Killing
abstract: Tehran is under pressure to avenge the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh, but analysts said it is balancing multiple factors as it weighs a response.
lead_paragraph: Iran vowed revenge at the end of last month after a top Hamas leader was killed in Tehran, leading many in Israel to fear an imminent attack. Nearly two weeks have passed and no large-scale response has materialized, leaving Israel and the wider Middle East on edge.

headline: Registering Voters and Certifying the Votes
abstract: Readers discuss election obstacles. Also: Donald Trump’s claim about Kamala Harris’s crowds; the Olympics; Covid vaccines; food and the climate.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ángel Salazar, Comedian and ‘Scarface’ Actor, Dies at 68
abstract: He first made his mark doing stand-up in New York, but he was best known for his role as Chi Chi opposite Al Pacino in the hit 1983 movie.
lead_paragraph: Ángel Salazar, a dynamic stand-up comedian who became well known for his wild routines and an actor best known for his role in the hit 1983 film “Scarface,” died on Sunday at a friend’s apartment in Brooklyn. He was 68.

headline: The Problem Is Not A.I. It’s the Disbelief Created by Trump.
abstract: He’s exploiting the inability of ordinary people to discern manipulated images.
lead_paragraph: Current artificial intelligence technologies have become surprisingly good at creating realistic images and video, unleashing fears that fake images can be used for political and election manipulation.

headline: Is Chaos the Key to Better Economics?
abstract: The chaos theorist Doyne Farmer believes mainstream economists are getting it all wrong.
lead_paragraph: The chaos theorist Doyne Farmer has led an eventful life. He and fellow schemers beat the casinos by inventing a concealable computer that could predict (albeit with low accuracy) where a roulette ball would land. He got a doctorate in physics in 1981 and took a job at the nuclear weapons laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M., where he did “nonlinear studies,” not weapons research. He co-founded a successful quantitative trading firm, the Prediction Co. And, of course, he worked on chaos theory. Now 72, with an ample white beard, he splits his time between Oxford University and his 46-foot sloop.

headline: Trump Calls Harris a ‘Communist.’ That Shows How Worried He Is.
abstract: MAGA desperately turns to old-fashioned red-baiting.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has been using an ugly word to describe Vice President Kamala Harris. No, I don’t mean privately calling her the B-word, although he reportedly does. I mean “communist,” an insult echoed by some of his allies. For example, Elon Musk, in a post on X, declared “Kamala is quite literally a communist,” demonstrating, among other things, that he quite literally doesn’t know the meaning of “literally.”

headline: The New York Times Will Stop Endorsing Candidates in New York Races
abstract: The paper’s editorial board will continue to endorse presidential candidates, as it has for more than 160 years.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times editorial board will no longer make endorsements in New York elections, including in races for governor and mayor of New York City, The Times’s Opinion editor said.

headline: Map: 4.4-Magnitude Earthquake Shakes Los Angeles
abstract: View the location of the quake’s shake area and aftershocks.
lead_paragraph: View the location of the quake’s shake area and aftershocks.

headline: 4.4-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Near Los Angeles
abstract: The quake was centered about five miles northeast of downtown, according to the U.S. Geological Survey. There were no initial reports of serious damage.
lead_paragraph: Millions across Southern California were rattled on Monday afternoon by a 4.4-magnitude earthquake, though there were no reports of significant damage, according to the United States Geological Survey.

headline: Chairman of Trump Shooting Inquiry Brings Personal Experience to the Task
abstract: Representative Mike Kelly of Pennsylvania was in the audience with family, including three of his grandchildren, during the shooting.
lead_paragraph: Representative Mike Kelly, Republican of Pennsylvania, was in the audience with family, including three of his grandchildren in Butler, Pa., when a would-be assassin opened fire on former President Donald J. Trump, coming just inches away from killing him.

headline: Elon Musk Is Using X to Push His Views, and Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Musk has become a vocal supporter of Mr. Trump. It wasn’t always that way.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk is all in for Donald Trump’s campaign.

headline: Immigrants Are Becoming U.S. Citizens at Fastest Clip in Years
abstract: The government has reduced a backlog of applications that built up during the Trump administration. New citizens say they are looking forward to voting in November.
lead_paragraph: The federal government is processing citizenship requests at the fastest clip in a decade, moving rapidly through a backlog that built up during the Trump administration and the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Hurricane Cleanup Effort Reaps ‘Treasure’: A 1945 Letter in a Bottle
abstract: How did the letter, sent from a Naval base in Virginia, make its way more than 800 miles to Florida? Who wrote it, and for whom? These mysteries remain.
lead_paragraph: A letter written in 1945 from a naval base in Virginia wound up in a glass bottle more than 800 miles away in Florida, where it was found last week — nearly eight decades later — after Hurricane Debby swept a swath of the state.

headline: Worried About a Convention Clash, Democrats Woo Uncommitted Delegates
abstract: A quiet diplomatic effort to ease tensions with uncommitted delegates and head off televised confrontations inside the Democratic convention hall next week has been underway for months.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators are expected in the streets and the parks of Chicago for next week’s Democratic National Convention, most of them to protest the U.S. role in the war in Gaza. But officials are concerned about the potential for a more embarrassing spectacle: prime-time disruptions inside the arena itself.

headline: Polar Bears Kill Worker in Remote Radar Site in Canada
abstract: Polar bear attacks on humans are rare, but last week’s was the second fatal encounter since 2023.
lead_paragraph: Two polar bears killed a worker at a remote radar site in the Canadian Arctic last week in one of the rare deadly polar bear attacks on humans, the facility’s operator said.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Putin Lashes Out Over Incursion
abstract: Plus, A.I. is helping piece together an ancient epic.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin lashed out at the West yesterday over Ukraine’s weeklong incursion into Russian territory. His comments were a sign of how the surprise attack has unsettled the Kremlin.
