headline: Catholic Converts Like JD Vance Are Reshaping Republican Politics
abstract: They’re also helping to build a new consensus across party lines.
lead_paragraph: Despite institutional decline and internal conflict, Catholicism retains a surprising resonance in American life — especially in certain elite circles. It has emerged as the largest and perhaps the most vibrant religious group at many top universities. It claims six of the nine Supreme Court justices as adherents. It continues to win high-profile converts, and its social teaching exerts an influence (often unacknowledged) on public debates, inspiring political thinkers who seek to challenge both the cultural left and the laissez-faire right.

headline: Robert Wilson’s Chance Encounters
abstract: The 82-year-old theater director says that his storied career has been guided by fate and an ironclad work ethic instilled by his mother.
lead_paragraph: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Robert Wilson explains, in his own words, what continues to motivate him.

headline: Kamala Harris Had a Great Health Care Idea in 2019. She Should Embrace It.
abstract: A public option is both smart policy and smart politics.
lead_paragraph: From the moment Kamala Harris became the presumptive Democratic nominee, Republicans have sought to paint her as a far-left California liberal. After all, they argue, she supported getting rid of private health insurance in her 2019 presidential campaign.

headline: Walz Faces New Scrutiny Over 2020 Riots: Was He Too Slow to Send Troops?
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz’s response to the unrest has attracted new scrutiny, and diverging opinions, since he joined Kamala Harris’s ticket.
lead_paragraph: The protests had turned into riots.

headline: How the World’s Oldest Humpback Whale Has Survived Is a Mystery
abstract: Old Timer, a male first photographed in 1972, was spotted last month near Alaska, enduring in the Pacific Ocean while some other humpbacks have struggled in a changing environment.
lead_paragraph: A humpback whale’s tail is as unique as a fingerprint. The lobes, or flukes, at the end of the tail have scalloped edges that vary from whale to whale; the undersides feature distinct black-and-white patterns that mark a whale for life.

headline: Gwen Walz, the Coolheaded, Ultracompetent Political Spouse
abstract: Early in her husband’s political career, she stepped in to help. Some wondered: Why isn’t she running?
lead_paragraph: In 2006, during his first campaign for Congress, Tim Walz was scheduled to speak at a fund-raising dinner in his hometown, Mankato, Minn. At the time, he was a political unknown in a tightly contested race against a six-term incumbent. The dinner was a chance to stump in front of his local district of the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party and to bolster his campaign coffers.

headline: I’m a Liberal. We Need to Face an Awkward Truth.
abstract: The columnist argues there’s a human cost to liberal purity.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Kristof is an Oregonian and, he is quick to point out, a liberal. But in this audio essay, Kristof takes liberals to task for their governing of cities on the West Coast. It’s an election year, and so he asks the question he believes many Americans are thinking: “Why put liberals in charge nationally when the places around the country where liberals have the greatest control are plagued by homelessness, crime and dysfunction?”

headline: $280,000 Homes in Minnesota, Pennsylvania and Maryland
abstract: A three-bedroom bungalow in Minneapolis, a two-bedroom Craftsman home in Pittsburgh and a three-bedroom Cape Cod-style cottage in Hagerstown.
lead_paragraph: This house is in the Willard-Hay neighborhood, a few blocks from Willard Park. It is within walking distance of several amenities: the sports fields and seasonal water park at North Commons Park; Theodore Wirth Regional Park, an expanse of more than 700 acres with a lake, walking trails and a clubhouse; and the Capri, a performing arts center built in 1927. Public elementary and high schools are within a five-minute drive.

headline: A Pigeon Named Dinosaur Will Sit on the High Line
abstract: The art installation will arrive this fall on the Plinth, at 30th Street and 10th Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out about a giant featherless bird that will land on the High Line in Manhattan before long. We’ll also get details on a pretrial hearing in the criminal fraud case against former Representative George Santos.

headline: Inflation Cools to 2.9%, Shoring Up Case for a Fed Rate Cut
abstract: The Consumer Price Index reading in July was the mildest year-over-year increase since 2021.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Price Index cooled in July compared with a year earlier, providing further evidence that inflation is moderating and leaving the Federal Reserve firmly on track to cut interest rates at its meeting next month.

headline: Inflation Data Is the Next Hurdle for Investors Weary From Volatility
abstract: A sharper-than-expected rise or fall in the Consumer Price Index could intensify worries on Wall Street about the economy’s prospects.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street is on edge heading into the July consumer price report after sharp stock swings this month reignited fears over the fate of the economy.

headline: What People Wear in One of the Happiest Places on Earth
abstract: At Copenhagen Fashion Week, outfits on and off the runway had a lively spirit that reflected the event’s location in a country known for its quality of life.
lead_paragraph: Not every fashion week can be characterized as friendly, approachable and relaxed. But those are three ways to describe Copenhagen Fashion Week, a twice-a-year event in the capital city of Denmark, a country that has often been ranked among the happiest in the world.

headline: As Famine Deepens in Sudan, U.S. Leads New Push for Cease-Fire
abstract: The American-backed talks in Switzerland, which started on Wednesday, aim to halt a catastrophic civil war. But only one side has turned up.
lead_paragraph: The United States opened new peace talks on Wednesday that aim to stop Sudan’s catastrophic civil war, driven by a growing sense of urgency that the country’s deepening famine, which threatens millions of lives, could become the world’s worst in decades.

headline: Tracking the Swing States for Harris and Trump
abstract: The presidential race will most likely come down to voters in eight states that remain competitive.
lead_paragraph: The presidential race will most likely come down to voters in eight states that remain competitive.

headline: Late-Summer Travel Plans? You Might Want to Put On a Mask.
abstract: With U.S. Covid-19 cases at very high levels and new vaccines still several weeks away, we asked experts for their advice on when and where to wear a mask.
lead_paragraph: It is the height of the summer travel season: Airplanes and cruises are packed, hotels are booked, and travelers are crowding theme parks and attractions. Yet throughout the United States, Covid-19 is currently circulating at very high levels.

headline: Sex and Murder on Trial: ‘Presumed Innocent’
abstract: Two critics on the legal thriller that just won’t die.
lead_paragraph: When Scott Turow’s best-selling novel “Presumed Innocent” was first published in 1987, it was quickly adapted for the big screen. The film — released in 1990 — was a Hollywood blockbuster, featuring one of the biggest movie stars of the time, Harrison Ford. Over 30 years later, Apple TV+ has rebooted it, this time as an eight-part series starring Jake Gyllenhaal as Rusty Sabich, a prosecutor turned defendant. Our critic Wesley Morris and Parul Sehgal, a staff writer at The New Yorker, discuss the book, the film and the TV series, and ask the question: Why do we need this remake now? (Beware: This episode contains spoilers).

headline: How Extreme Heat Is Threatening Education Progress Worldwide
abstract: Children today face many more extreme weather hazards that can undermine global gains in education.
lead_paragraph: The continued burning of fossil fuels is closing schools around the world for days, sometimes weeks at a time, and threatening to undermine one of the greatest global gains of recent decades: children’s education.

headline: Trial in Texas School Shooting Asks: Could the Gunman’s Parents Have Stopped It?
abstract: The case, against the parents of a gunman who killed 10 people in Santa Fe, Texas, in 2018, is among the first in which school shooting victims are trying to hold parents liable in civil court.
lead_paragraph: As the nation has struggled to respond to mass shootings, often carried out by teenagers still living at home, focus has turned to the parents of the gunmen and whether they bear responsibility for the horrific acts of their children.

headline: Thai Court Ejects Prime Minister, as Old Guard Reasserts Power
abstract: Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin was considered a figurehead leader in a behind-the-scenes power struggle. He was ousted on ethics charges.
lead_paragraph: Thailand’s Constitutional Court ousted Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin from office on Wednesday, throwing the country into fresh political turmoil just days after the court dissolved the country’s main opposition party.

headline: Endless Honking of Waymo’s Driverless Taxis Wakes a Neighborhood
abstract: In late July, Waymo rented a parking lot outside two San Francisco apartment buildings for its vehicles to idle in. Then came the noise.
lead_paragraph: It was a little over two weeks ago that Sophia Tung began waking up before dawn to the sound of cars honking.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,153
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 431
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Aug. 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Abortion Access on the Ballot, and Hamas Won’t Attend Peace Talks
abstract: Plus, new details on Hunter Biden’s business dealings.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: How One Tech Monopoly Paved the Way for Another
abstract: A judge’s ruling that Google abused a monopoly in internet search is likely to have major ripple effects, nearly a quarter-century after Microsoft lost a similar case.
lead_paragraph: In a landmark antitrust ruling against Google last week, another case was at the heart of the story — one from the 1990s.

headline: Ukraine’s Surprise Attack Forces Russia to Divert Forces in Response
abstract: Russia has begun moving some troops from Ukraine to deal with a Ukrainian incursion, the U.S. and Ukraine say. But Moscow appears reluctant to withdraw units from hot spots in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Since its surprise incursion into Russia more than a week ago, Ukraine has steadily gained ground, saying it advanced even deeper into Russian territory on Wednesday. It says it has captured hundreds of soldiers, as Russia has evacuated more than 130,000 people from nearby communities and declared a new state of emergency in one region.

headline: The Global Race to Control A.I.
abstract: We explore who is winning — and what could come next.
lead_paragraph: As artificial intelligence advances, many nations are worried about being left behind.

headline: Makers of Snickers and Pringles to Merge in $36 Billion Food Deal
abstract: Mars is acquiring Kellanova in one of the largest deals in the industry in years, creating a new global giant with a stable of well-known brands.
lead_paragraph: Mars, the company behind M&M’s and Snickers, has agreed to acquire Kellanova, the snack food business spun off by Kellogg’s last year, in a multibillion-dollar deal that will create a new global food giant.

headline: Harris Is Set to Lay Out an Economic Message Light on Detail
abstract: The vice president is expected to recalibrate President Biden’s policy themes in a bid to turn the Democratic economic agenda into an asset.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s sudden ascent to the top of the Democratic ticket has generated a host of questions about her economic agenda, including how much she will stick to the details of President Biden’s positions, tweak them, or chart entirely new ones.

headline: Google’s Stock Falls as the Government Weighs Breaking Up the Company
abstract: The Justice Department could force the technology group to split after a landmark court ruling that the search giant is an illegal monopoly.
lead_paragraph: Shares in Alphabet, Google’s parent company, were down more than 2.5 percent in early trading on Wednesday morning on news that the Justice Department is considering breaking up the technology giant for maintaining an illegal search monopoly.

headline: Judge Denies Trump’s Recusal Bid, Rebuking Him for Claiming Harris Ties
abstract: Justice Juan M. Merchan, who oversaw the trial that led to Donald J. Trump’s conviction, declined for a third time to step aside from the case, dismissing claims from defense lawyers that he had a conflict of interest.
lead_paragraph: The judge who oversaw Donald J. Trump’s Manhattan criminal trial declined for a third time to step aside from the case, rebuking the former president’s lawyers for claiming that the judge had a distant yet problematic connection to Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Can I Tell My Sister That Her Estranged Son Is a New Father?
abstract: A reader is unsure whether to insert herself into three years of icy silence by sharing a major development in her nephew’s life with his mother.
lead_paragraph: My nephew has been estranged from his parents for three years after they had some difficult conversations. I don’t know all the details, and I have tried to remain neutral. When my nephew married, his parents were not at the wedding. Then he and his wife moved several hours away. They now have an infant son, and as far as I know, my sister and her husband are unaware of their grandchild’s existence. My nephew and I keep in touch. I suggested he tell his parents about the baby, but I don’t know if he did. I feel disloyal to my sister, withholding this news. In her position, I would want to know about the baby. But I don’t have my nephew’s permission to tell her, and he may object. Complicating matters: I have issues with my sister, and we are barely speaking. What should I do?

headline: His Trilogy Explored the Nazi Era. Now He Looks at the People Behind It.
abstract: In “Hitler’s People,” the renowned historian Richard J. Evans takes a biographical approach to the Third Reich.
lead_paragraph: “Who Goes Nazi?” is an old essay by Dorothy Thompson that has been making the rounds over the last several years. Writing for Harper’s Magazine in 1941, Thompson suggested playing a “macabre parlor game” to figure out who would sign on to fascism “in a showdown.” (This was before the Wannsee Conference of January 1942, where Hitler’s underlings planned the “final solution.”) Decades later, Thompson’s proposal resonated with Americans who were seeking any glimmer of insight into how far-right extremism — once the marginal purview of dedicated fanatics — had gathered startling levels of popular support.

headline: What Teachers Told Me About A.I. in School
abstract: Many students lean on the technology rather than wrestle with challenging tasks.
lead_paragraph: Leila Wheless, a North Carolina teacher who has been an educator since 1991, tried to keep “an open heart” about using artificial intelligence in her middle school English and language arts classroom. She reviewed the guidance of her state’s generative A.I. “recommendations and considerations” for public schools. But the results of her students’ A.I. use were dispiriting.

headline: Deaths at the Grand Canyon Are on the Rise. Here’s How to Stay Safe.
abstract: There have been 11 deaths at Grand Canyon National Park so far this year. We asked hiking experts to share their best recommendations to avoid danger.
lead_paragraph: The Grand Canyon, one of the most celebrated natural wonders in the United States, known for its deep valleys and rust-colored views, has been the site of multiple deaths this summer, raising concerns about hiker safety at the park.

headline: Germany Issues Arrest Warrant for Ukrainian Over Nord Stream Explosion
abstract: The sabotage of the pipelines that carried Russian gas to Europe has become one of the central mysteries of the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A European arrest warrant was issued for a Ukrainian man suspected of involvement in blowing up the Nord Stream pipeline nearly two years ago, Polish prosecutors said on Wednesday.

headline: Meet a Family That’s Betting the Farm on a Wild Idea. Literally.
abstract: After decades raising hogs in Iowa, they wanted a way out of factory farming. Their solution was a return to nature, and a lot of mushrooms.
lead_paragraph: For years Rand Faaborg, a father of five in rural Iowa, wanted to get out of hog farming. He just didn’t know how.

headline: Teamsters’ Black Caucus Endorses Harris While Parent Union Stays Silent
abstract: The move aligns the caucus with other big organized-labor groups, but the Teamsters president, who spoke at the Republican convention, has indicated he is open to backing Trump.
lead_paragraph: The National Black Caucus of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters union endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris for the presidency on Tuesday, setting it apart from its parent union, which has declined to make an endorsement and whose president spoke at the Republican National Convention.

headline: 5 Things This Bulgari Designer Wishes She’d Made
abstract: Why Mary Katrantzou admires Audubon's illustrations, an Issey Miyake bodice and the rainbow flag.
lead_paragraph: Why Mary Katrantzou admires Audubon's illustrations, an Issey Miyake bodice and the rainbow flag.

headline: This Enormous Artwork Turns a Palace Into a Pawnshop
abstract: Christoph Büchel’s vast installation in Venice is compelling, obsessive and sometimes hilarious.
lead_paragraph: Ascending the grand marble staircase in the center of the Venetian palazzo, you encounter a selection of fake Gucci, Hermes and other luxury handbags laid out on a blanket. A street hawker seems to have been disturbed, leaving their knockoff wares behind.

headline: How Christian Conservatives Are Planning for the Next Battle, on I.V.F.
abstract: Republicans may be backing away from abortion, but these activists have a strategy, with or without Trump.
lead_paragraph: The pivot seems clear. The Republican Party of the post-Roe era is sidelining anti-abortion activists. Project 2025, the conservative blueprint with innovative abortion bans, has been disavowed by Donald Trump. And the new G.O.P. platform even promises to advance access to in vitro fertilization.

headline: Yes, You Can Run a Marathon
abstract: Preparing to run 26.2 miles can be daunting. Here’s how to structure four months of training.
lead_paragraph: When you cross the finish line of your first marathon, the high can make it easy to forget about everything you’ve put your mind and body through to get there. There’s no question that covering 26.2 miles is an impressive feat of endurance and athleticism, but it can be an attainable goal for most runners with the right preparation.

headline: Illuminating a Trailblazing Artist Who Died Too Young
abstract: In her first American museum retrospective, Paula Modersohn-Becker looks bracingly modern.
lead_paragraph: An exultant sense of discovery is the propelling through line of “Paula Modersohn-Becker: Ich Bin Ich / I Am Me,” a glorious exhibition at the Neue Galerie that is, surprisingly, the German artist’s first retrospective in an American museum. (It will travel to the Art Institute of Chicago in October.)

headline: A Chicken Dinner That Tastes Like Your Favorite Italian Dressing
abstract: This new recipe is inspired by the vinegary oregano marinade of spiedies, transforming boneless, skinless chicken breasts into something special.
lead_paragraph: Good morning! Eric here, filling in for Melissa.

headline: The Tony Winner Behind ‘Appropriate’ Is Back. This Time, With ‘Purpose.’
abstract: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins had Broadway success this year with a drama starring Sarah Paulson. In February, he’ll return with a new play directed by Phylicia Rashad.
lead_paragraph: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins won a Tony Award in June for the Broadway production of “Appropriate,” his blistering play about a white Southern family grappling with some serious baggage.

headline: Off the Grid, Extremely Online
abstract: In corners of the internet — and in wooded, undeveloped parts of the country — young men are documenting their efforts to to live off the land.
lead_paragraph: Nate Petroski’s address doesn’t help visitors find his house. Locating it, instead, requires specific GPS coordinates to a spot deep in West Virginia’s Appalachian Mountains, and precise instructions on how to get there. Many of the surrounding roads are impassable without an ATV to traverse several creeks and muddy inclines.

headline: For Stonehenge’s Altar Stone, an Improbably Long Ancient Journey
abstract: A six-ton megalith at the heart of the archaeological site traveled more than 450 miles to get there, a new study concludes.
lead_paragraph: Near the center of the roughly 5,000-year-old circular monument known as Stonehenge is a six-ton, rectangular chunk of red sandstone. In Arthurian legend, the so-called Altar Stone was part of the ring of giant rocks that the wizard Merlin magically transported from Mount Killaurus, in Ireland, to Salisbury Plain, a chalk plateau in southern England — a journey chronicled around 1136 by a Welsh cleric, Geoffrey of Monmouth, in his “Historia Regum Britanniae.”

headline: Cooling Price Growth Has Democrats Tasting Victory Over Inflation
abstract: Soaring prices have been a political albatross for the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: After more than two years of being politically battered over soaring prices, Wednesday’s inflation report left many Democrats feeling victorious.

headline: Hurricane Ernesto Knocks Out Power to Hundreds of Thousands in Puerto Rico
abstract: The island’s frail electrical system struggled as the storm passed on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Ernesto left hundreds of thousands of Puerto Ricans without power on Wednesday after its wind and rain pelted the island’s frail electrical system.

headline: My Aunt’s Son Shouldn’t Be a Dad. Must I Congratulate Her on the New Grandkid?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the etiquette associated with offering congratulations.
lead_paragraph: I have an aunt with whom I’ve always had a warm relationship. She has an adult son whom I am not close to and who seems to have many struggles. Over the past few years, this son has been in relationships that have resulted in multiple pregnancies. My aunt is always excited about these pregnancies and seems to expect congratulations — even though, by her own admission, she does not trust her son to be alone with his own child. Now that my cousin is expecting another baby, I feel bad not to have reached out with congratulations or even support. But I also feel it would be disingenuous to do so. It doesn’t seem like my place to express my concern. What seems appropriate? — Name Withheld

headline: Harris Is Leading or Tied With Trump in Most Swing States, New Cook Polls Find
abstract: The results are a marked change from the same surveys in May that showed former President Donald J. Trump leading by a solid margin or tied in the critical battlegrounds.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump are locked into a tight race in key swing states, according to new polling from the Cook Political Report and the bipartisan team of BSG and GS Strategy Group published Wednesday.

headline: U.C.L.A. Can’t Let Protesters Block Jewish Students From Campus, Judge Says
abstract: The judge’s temporary ruling said that protests that prevent Jewish students from accessing parts of the campus violated religious freedom rights.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Tuesday temporarily barred the University of California, Los Angeles, from allowing protesters to block Jewish students from having access to the campus and facilities such as libraries, classrooms and gathering places.

headline: Does Harris Actually Need to Move Democrats Right?
abstract: Whether the Democrats moved too far left after Obama has serious implications for the next election.
lead_paragraph: The ascension of Kamala Harris to the top of the Democratic ticket has prompted, among many other things, a reckoning with the meaning and legacy of the last decade of American liberalism.

headline: Trump Gambles on Outside Groups to Finance Voter Outreach Efforts
abstract: New federal rules allow political candidates to coordinate their efforts to canvass for votes with outside groups like super PACs.
lead_paragraph: The Republican campaign for president is quietly being remade by new federal guidelines that empower big-money groups and threaten to undermine party control well beyond the 2024 election.

headline: Readers’ Pleas to The Times: Don’t End the New York Endorsements
abstract: Readers disagree with The Times’s decision to stop endorsing in local races. Also: Trump-speak; the human touch in restaurants; student phone bans.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Harris Shouldn’t Forget That Democracy Is Still on the Ballot
abstract: And there are still voters who care about it.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris is running an artful campaign so far, thanks in part to her upbeat, hopeful message. She has shrewdly positioned herself as the change candidate — no small feat for a sitting vice president — and has tagged Donald Trump as representing the weird past we should leave behind.

headline: Whimsical Parade of Banksy Animals Sends Fans on a Giddy Hunt
abstract: Each day for nine straight days, a new Banksy artwork appeared somewhere in London. For some, it became a citywide treasure hunt.
lead_paragraph: The first Banksy piece to show up was a mountain goat, spotted by passers-by on a wall near the River Thames. The second work, a pair of elephants, appeared overnight on a house in southwest London. Then came some playful monkeys, a howling wolf, two hungry pelicans and a cat.

headline: ‘Life and Trust’ Review: Choose Your Own Faustian Adventure
abstract: A new theatrical experience in the Financial District is composed of 25 individual stories, but it’s hard to make sense of any of them.
lead_paragraph: In one room in Conwell Tower, a stately skyscraper in the Financial District, a police officer strips off his shirt and flogs himself — passionately, even sensually — before coolly donning his uniform again. At the end of a long hall, a woman performs a Houdini-esque escape from a straitjacket. Elsewhere, in a dark underground boxing ring, two men trade punches in a cinematic fight scene where lights flash and dim with each maneuver, the bodies sometimes moving in slow motion like scenes from a “Rocky” film.

headline: Ukraine’s Surprise Attack on Russia
abstract: Amid the biggest foreign incursion into Russia since World War II, The New York Times visited a place where Ukrainian forces stormed in. Andrew E. Kramer, the Kyiv bureau chief for The New York Times, describes what he saw.
lead_paragraph: Amid the biggest foreign incursion into Russia since World War II, The New York Times visited a place where Ukrainian forces stormed in. Andrew E. Kramer, the Kyiv bureau chief for The New York Times, describes what he saw.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘BoJack Horseman’ and More
abstract: I’m a food columnist for The New York Times Magazine. Here are five things I’ve recently relished.
lead_paragraph: I’m a food columnist for The New York Times Magazine. Here are five things I’ve recently relished.

headline: Contaminants Found at German Military Base, and Sabotage Is Suspected
abstract: The discovery led to the temporary lockdown of the base while the water supply was tested. NATO officials also reported that an intruder tried to forcibly enter one of the alliance’s bases in the country.
lead_paragraph: Two military bases in Germany were put under heightened security on Wednesday after contaminants were found in the water supply of barracks at one site — the result of possible sabotage, the military said — and an intruder attempted to forcibly enter a NATO base in the country.

headline: Ask TikTok’s ‘Cucumber Boy’ How to Prepare a Cucumber
abstract: “Sometimes you need to eat an entire cucumber,” the TikTok star Logan Moffitt says of the summer’s most riffable recipe.
lead_paragraph: Logan Moffitt has never been more hydrated.

headline: W.H.O. Declares Global Emergency Over New Mpox Outbreak
abstract: The epidemic is concentrated in the Democratic Republic of Congo, but the virus has now appeared in a dozen other African countries.
lead_paragraph: The rapid spread of mpox, formerly called monkeypox, in African countries constitutes a global health emergency, the World Health Organization declared on Wednesday.

headline: Bronx Museum’s Executive Director Leaves During $33 Million Expansion
abstract: Klaudio Rodriguez will become the executive director and chief executive of the Museum of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg, Fla.
lead_paragraph: The head of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, which recently began a $33 million expansion and renovation project, is leaving his position to lead the Museum of Fine Arts in St. Petersburg, Fla.

headline: Hurricane Ernesto Causes Power Outages in Puerto Rico
abstract: Hundreds of thousands on the island lost power as the Category 1 storm strained the island’s frail electrical system.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands on the island lost power as the Category 1 storm strained the island’s frail electrical system.

headline: Peach Cobbler, 2 Ways: Spectacularly Simple and Simply Spectacular
abstract: An easy buttermilk skillet version and an upside-down take from Melissa Clark showcase the stone fruit’s versatility.
lead_paragraph: Generally filled with bubbling fruit nestled into a buttery, sugary foundation, cobblers are beloved in the canon of homey desserts. The problem is, there’s no consensus about what, exactly, they are.

headline: Boeing Faces a Steep Climb in Catching Up to Airbus
abstract: As Boeing works to address quality control issues, its new chief starts at a disadvantage in competing with the other big maker of passenger planes.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Airbus scored a major victory: For the first time in its history, more of its passenger planes were flying around the world than those made by its rival, Boeing. Airbus has only tightened its grip on the market since.

headline: Coming to ‘iPhone City’: An Electric Car Factory From Foxconn
abstract: The Taiwanese company has built a manufacturing hub in Zhengzhou, China, for its star customer Apple, but it is starting almost from scratch in the auto business.
lead_paragraph: The core of Foxconn’s business is in Zhengzhou, the capital of Henan province in central China, known as “iPhone City.” That’s where a network of suppliers, infrastructure and factories, and sometimes as many as 250,000 Foxconn employees, manufacture most of the world’s iPhones for Apple.

headline: California ‘Shaman’ Faces Felony Sex Assault Charges
abstract: Ricardo I. Flores, who the authorities say led a shamanistic community and who goes by Koyote the Blind, has been charged with eight felonies, including rape and aggravated sexual assault of a minor.
lead_paragraph: A man in Southern California who the authorities say led a shamanistic community in Riverside County was arraigned last week on charges that he sexually assaulted two female victims, including at least one who was under 14.

headline: Wally Amos, Enterprising Creator of Famous Amos Cookies, Dies at 88
abstract: With a background as a talent agent, his aunt’s recipe and a winning personality, he built one of the world’s best-known brands of baked goods.
lead_paragraph: Wally Amos, an indefatigable entrepreneur who in 1975 took a $25,000 loan from a few friends in Hollywood to start Famous Amos, one of the first brands to push high-quality cookies in its own stores and one of the world’s best-known names in baked goods, died on Tuesday at his home in Honolulu. He was 88.

headline: Jay Kanter, Agent for Marlon Brando and Marilyn Monroe, Dies at 97
abstract: Later a studio executive, he was among the last of the power brokers who dominated Hollywood in the latter half of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: Jay Kanter, whose long career as an agent to the stars — including Marlon Brando, Marilyn Monroe and Grace Kelly — and later as a studio executive made him one of the last of the generation of power brokers who dominated Hollywood in the late 20th century, died on Aug. 6 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 97.

headline: When Will They Speak Again? Once Close, Biden and Pelosi Are at Odds.
abstract: President Biden is upset that Representative Nancy Pelosi worked to get him out of the race. She is losing sleep over it.
lead_paragraph: When Joseph R. Biden Jr. visited San Francisco as a freshly minted senator and single father in the early 1970s, it was a well-known local fund-raiser and stay-at-home mother of five, Nancy Pelosi, who lent him her Jeep to get around town.

headline: Summer 2024 News Quiz for Students
abstract: How closely have you paid attention to current events? See what you remember by taking our special Summer 2024 News Quiz.
lead_paragraph: How closely have you paid attention to current events? See what you remember by taking our special Summer 2024 News Quiz.

headline: Black Art Week in San Francisco Bay Area Is in the Works for the Fall
abstract: The executive director of the Museum of the African Diaspora says the goal is to “celebrate the rich Black art landscape” of the region.
lead_paragraph: When Monetta White was a co-owner of the San Francisco restaurant 1300 on Fillmore a decade ago, she participated in the city’s restaurant week, promoting the local food scene. Now, as the executive director of the Museum of the African Diaspora downtown, she is organizing a celebration of Black visual culture, called “Nexus: SF/Bay Area Black Art Week,” to run Oct. 1 through Oct. 6.

headline: A New Venue Beckons Jazz Musicians and Beyond to Upstate New York
abstract: The Mill, an arts center with art galleries and a performance space in an old flour mill, opened over the weekend. Its owners hope it sparks a “ripple effect.”
lead_paragraph: Fourteen years ago, Taylor Haskins, a veteran jazz trumpeter, and Catherine Ross Haskins, a visual artist, moved from Brooklyn to Westport, N.Y., a picture-book town on Lake Champlain, 275 miles north of Manhattan. It became “the place on Earth that we love,” Taylor said. “But sometimes it could use a little bit of an injection of the outside world.”

headline: U.S. Army Soldier Pleads Guilty to Selling Military Documents
abstract: Prosecutors said that Sgt. Korbein Schultz had access to top secret information, which he exchanged for payments totaling $42,000.
lead_paragraph: An Army soldier pleaded guilty on Tuesday to conspiracy and bribery charges in connection with a plot in which prosecutors said he sold dozens of U.S. military documents that disclosed details about rocket systems and Chinese military tactics to a foreign national.

headline: City Approves $7 Million Settlement for Exonerated Former Death Row Inmate
abstract: Edmond, Okla., agreed to the payment to settle a federal lawsuit filed by Glynn Simmons, 71, who spent 48 years in prison for a murder he did not commit. He now drives a food truck called FreeMan’s Food Truck, according to his lawyer.
lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma city has agreed to pay $7.15 million to settle a lawsuit filed by a former death row inmate who spent more than 48 years in prison before being exonerated in December, his lawyers said this week.

headline: What to Know About Mpox
abstract: The World Health Organization declared a global health emergency over an outbreak that has spread to more than a dozen African countries.
lead_paragraph: Mpox was declared a global health emergency on Wednesday for the second time in three years, as the World Health Organization urged action on a virus spreading rapidly through more than a dozen African countries.

headline: Unresponsive Brain-Damaged Patients May Have Some Awareness
abstract: Many patients thought to be in vegetative or minimally conscious states may be capable of thought, researchers reported.
lead_paragraph: When people suffer severe brain damage — as a result of car crashes, for example, or falls or aneurysms — they may slip into a coma for weeks, their eyes closed, their bodies unresponsive.

headline: NASA Says It Needs to Decide Soon How Starliner Astronauts Will Come Home
abstract: After agency officials said last week that a decision was pending, they said on Wednesday that deliberations were still taking place.
lead_paragraph: A week ago, NASA officials said they would most likely need to decide by mid-August on how to safely bring home two astronauts who had traveled to the International Space Station on Boeing’s troubled Starliner spacecraft. But on Wednesday, NASA said a decision remained at least a week away.

headline: A.L.S. Stole His Voice. A.I. Retrieved It.
abstract: In an experiment that surpassed expectations, implants in a patient’s brain were able to recognize words he tried to speak, and A.I. helped produce sounds that came close to matching his true voice.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Casey Harrell sang his last bedtime nursery rhyme to his daughter.

headline: In Gaza, Israel’s Military Has Reached the End of the Line, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: Israel has severely set back Hamas but will never be able to completely eliminate the group, U.S. officials said.
lead_paragraph: Israel has achieved all that it can militarily in Gaza, according to senior American officials, who say continued bombings are only increasing risks to civilians while the possibility of further weakening Hamas has diminished.

headline: Thursday Briefing: U.S. Assesses Israel’s War in Gaza
abstract: Plus, a fake Elon Musk scam.
lead_paragraph: Mediators, Israeli negotiators and officials from around the world are expected to meet in Qatar today for a high-stakes push to end the war in Gaza.

headline: Google Pixel Documents a Fashion House in Its 20th Year
abstract: Fashion designer Phillip Lim and photographer Andy Jackson used Google Pixel 9 Pro and its AI-powered editing features in a portrait session dedicated to the women who inspired Lim’s career.
lead_paragraph: Fashion designer Phillip Lim and photographer Andy Jackson used Google Pixel 9 Pro and its AI-powered editing features in a portrait session dedicated to the women who inspired Lim’s career.

headline: Inflation Fell Below 3% for the First Time in Years
abstract: Also, U.S. officials say Israel’s military has achieved all it can in Gaza. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Annual inflation cooled more than expected last month, to 2.9 percent, according to a Consumer Price Index report released today. It was the first time that the inflation gauge had dropped below 3 percent since 2021.

headline: Can a Disney+ Subscription Keep a Widower From Suing Disney in Court?
abstract: Jeffrey Piccolo sued after his wife died from an allergic reaction to food served at a Disney resort restaurant. Disney wants the case handled by an arbitrator.
lead_paragraph: Months after a man sued Walt Disney Parks and Resorts over the death of his wife from a severe allergic reaction at a Disney World restaurant, the company responded with an argument that would keep the case from coming before a jury.

headline: Just How Demure Are You?
abstract: A TikTok trend has breathed new life into a fusty word.
lead_paragraph: If you opened TikTok this week and felt that suddenly everyone was using the word “demure” out of nowhere, you’re not alone.

headline: A Hulk Hogan-Jesse Ventura Grudge Match, in the Political Arena
abstract: Hogan supports Donald J. Trump. Mr. Ventura is backing Kamala Harris. But their beef is more complicated than that.
lead_paragraph: When Jesse “The Body” Ventura faced off against Hulk Hogan in the 1980s, Mr. Ventura played the heel — the caped villain whose staged cheap shots and provocations rallied the audience to the side of the mustachioed hero, glistening triumphantly in his underwear.

headline: Cisco Systems to Cut About 7% of Staff in Second Round of Layoffs
abstract: The cuts could amount to about 6,000 jobs for the San Jose, Calif., maker of computer networking technology.
lead_paragraph: Cisco Systems, one of the largest makers of computer networking equipment, said on Wednesday that it would cut 7 percent of its work force in its second major round of layoffs this year.

headline: Rabbi Shmuel Butman, 81, a Brooklyn Voice of Ultra-Orthodox Jews, Is Dead
abstract: He was the public face of the Chabad-Lubavitch sect during the Crown Heights riots in 1991 and for decades lit its giant menorah in Manhattan every Hanukkah.
lead_paragraph: Rabbi Shmuel Butman, who was the public face of the Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic sect during the antisemitic riots in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, in 1991, and who was literally a keeper of that ultra-Orthodox Jewish movement’s flame by illuminating its menorah — billed as the world’s largest — across from Central Park every Hanukkah for decades, died on July 22 in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: ‘I’m Looking for a Job’: Biden Jokes About Life After the White House
abstract: With a jovial serenity, the president has more publicly embraced the idea of retirement as he heads into his final months in office.
lead_paragraph: With just over 22 weeks left in charge of the country, President Biden is looking for work.

headline: Wyoming Reporter Resigns After Using A.I. to Fabricate Quotes
abstract: Aaron Pelczar left the Cody Enterprise after a competing newspaper presented him with evidence of made-up quotes in several of his stories.
lead_paragraph: A novice reporter for the Cody Enterprise in Wyoming resigned this month after he was caught using generative artificial intelligence to help write his stories, resulting in numerous fabricated quotes, according to editors at the paper and published reports.

headline: Another ‘Nasty’ Woman Strikes Fear in Trump
abstract: Authoritarian tendencies and misogyny rise together.
lead_paragraph: Misogyny has been central to Donald Trump’s identity, rise and political movement, but it is now central to his distemper, as Kamala Harris’s remarkable campaign rollout has frustrated and unnerved him.

headline: In Economy-Focused Speech, Trump Still Lobs Personal Attacks Against Harris
abstract: Mr. Trump’s remarks on the economy and his insults aimed at Ms. Harris suggested the Trump campaign continues to suffer growing pains as it adjusts to a new opponent.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s speech on Wednesday in Asheville, N.C., his first event in a battleground state in nearly two weeks, was supposed to offer him a bit of a reset after his Democratic opponent, Vice President Kamala Harris, gained significant momentum.

headline: Betty A. Prashker, 99, Who Pushed Boundaries in Book Publishing, Dies
abstract: A top editor and executive at two publishing houses, she was an advocate for women in publishing, and for equal pay in an industry that had long been male-dominated.
lead_paragraph: Betty A. Prashker, a pioneering woman in the book business who published the feminist classics “Sexual Politics” by Kate Millett and “Backlash” by Susan Faludi, but who also brought out racy commercial fiction by Judith Krantz and Jean M. Auel — viewing their frank female sexuality as no less a statement of feminist empowerment — died on July 30 in Alford, Mass. She was 99.

headline: It’s Instincts Over Strategy for Trump
abstract: The former president has struggled to settle on a message against Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump held a news conference last week, ostensibly to hit Vice President Kamala Harris for not yet having held one of her own, he said something revealing about how her sudden climb up the Democratic ticket had shaped his own campaign for the presidency — or not.

headline: Search Continues After Inmate Escapes Prison Transport Van in North Carolina
abstract: Hundreds of law enforcement officers were involved in the search for Ramone Alston, 30, who was serving a life sentence for murder, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officers in North Carolina continued their search on Thursday for a convicted murderer who was serving a life sentence and escaped custody on Tuesday morning, according to the state’s Department of Adult Correction.

headline: Connecticut Official Loses to Jewish Opponent After Antisemitic Comments
abstract: In an interview posted online, Anabel Figueroa made comments that have been widely condemned as antisemitic. On Tuesday, she lost her Democratic primary to a Jewish challenger.
lead_paragraph: A Connecticut state representative lost a primary election Tuesday, just hours after a video surfaced of her saying that her challenger should not represent the district because he is Jewish.

headline: Columbia President Resigns After Months of Turmoil on Campus
abstract: Nemat Shafik is the third Ivy League president to resign in the wake of turbulent congressional appearances and strife connected to the Israel-Hamas war.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University’s president, Nemat Shafik, resigned on Wednesday after months of far-reaching fury over her handling of pro-Palestinian demonstrations and questions over her management of a bitterly divided campus.

headline: Jewish Man Charged With Attempted Murder in Attacks on Muslim Neighbor
abstract: Izak Kadosh faces more than 40 charges, many of them hate crimes, including attempted murder and aggravated assault. Prosecutors said the attacks, in Brooklyn, went on for months.
lead_paragraph: A Jewish man in Brooklyn was arrested and charged with attempted murder and hate crimes after repeatedly attacking his Muslim neighbor over several months, ultimately breaking into the neighbor’s apartment and striking him so hard with a mallet that he had internal bleeding, according to a criminal complaint.

headline: M.T.A. Is Ordered to Improve Track Safety After Transit Worker Is Killed
abstract: The Federal Transit Administration released its audit nine months after a worker was hit by a train. If the M.T.A. does not comply, it could lose funding.
lead_paragraph: Federal transportation officials said on Wednesday that the death of a transit worker who was hit by a train in November, as well as a rising number of “near-miss” incidents on train tracks last year, reflected unsafe conditions and practices that were putting transit employees at growing risk.

headline: Gena Rowlands, Actress Who Brought Raw Drama to Her Roles, Dies at 94
abstract: Known for playing on-the-verge characters, she twice earned Oscar nominations for her work in films directed by John Cassavetes, her husband.
lead_paragraph: Gena Rowlands, the intense, elegant dramatic actress who, often in collaboration with her husband, John Cassavetes, starred in a series of introspective independent films, has died. She was 94.

headline: What to Know About the State of the Cease-Fire Talks
abstract: As tensions in the Middle East escalate, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said after meeting with the Israeli prime minister on Monday that Israel had accepting a “bridging proposal.”
lead_paragraph: Israel’s war with Hamas in the Gaza Strip has lasted more than 10 months, with only one weeklong pause in fighting, in late November. That cease-fire led to the return of more than  100 Israeli hostages captured during the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel in exchange for  Palestinian prisoners and raised hopes among mediators and the international community that another deal would follow.

headline: Kennedy Sought a Meeting With Harris to Discuss a Cabinet Post
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was unsuccessful with his request to discuss endorsing the Democratic nominee in exchange for a top administration job, according to two people briefed on the outreach.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the independent presidential candidate whose standing has dropped in the polls, sought a meeting with Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss endorsing her in exchange for a promise of a cabinet post, according to two people briefed on the outreach who insisted on anonymity to discuss private conversations.

headline: Woman Sentenced to Nine Years for Stealing $1.5 Million in Chicken Wings
abstract: Vera Liddell, 68, pleaded guilty to felony theft for stealing more than 11,000 cases of chicken wings valued at $1.5 million, the Cook County State’s Attorney’s Office said.
lead_paragraph: A former food service director for an Illinois school district was sentenced to prison for stealing more than $1 million worth of chicken wings that were billed to the district but never given to students, the authorities said.

headline: Where Lines May Be Drawn in the Sand
abstract: Damon Gulczynski wants to make sure you’re paying attention.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: 10 Terrific Gena Rowlands Performances to Stream
abstract: She delivered vulnerable portraits in movies as varied as “A Woman Under the Influence,” with John Cassavetes, and the drama “The Notebook.”
lead_paragraph: Gena Rowlands, who died Wednesday at the age of 94, was widely regarded as one of the best actresses of her generation, known for her vulnerable portraits of women in states of crisis. Her most acclaimed performances came through her prolific and intensely creative collaboration with her husband, the director, writer and actor John Cassavetes, who gave her parts like the housewife in turmoil in “A Woman Under the Influence.” Even after his death in 1989, Rowlands would continue to work with family members, starring in the directorial efforts of their son, Nick, and her daughter Zoe. And while she became a star of the 1970s with films that broke new ground in independent cinema, in her later years she was introduced to a younger generation, thanks to Nick Cassavetes’s blockbuster tear-jerker, “The Notebook.” Here is where to watch some of her best work.

headline: Bowling, Selfies and the ‘Dougie’: Biden Woos Influencers at the White House
abstract: For its first conference on the creator economy, the Biden administration celebrated social media creators. The president lauded them as a “breakthrough in how we communicate.”
lead_paragraph: As soon as President Biden walked into the Indian Treaty Room across the street from the White House on Wednesday, the smartphones flew up. Dozens of social media influencers and people who work with them stood almost in unison to capture the moment.

headline: Harris Will Back Federal Ban on Price Gouging, Campaign Says
abstract: The vice president is leaning into an effort to partly blame big companies for inflation, as progressives have pushed her to embrace that argument.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris will call for a federal ban on corporate price gouging on groceries in a speech laying out her economic agenda on Friday, campaign officials said late Wednesday, in an effort to blame big companies for persistently high costs of American consumer staples.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Fleeing Sudan Conflict, Only to Find in England a Mob Menacing Them
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “This is not freedom.”

headline: The British Have Finally Learned to Love Peanut Butter
abstract: The land of Marmite and jam is finally embracing America’s favorite spread, with dozens of varieties on supermarket shelves.
lead_paragraph: When the American political commentator and noted peanut butter lover William F. Buckley Jr. arrived at an English boarding school in the late 1930s, care packages from home would include jars of peanut butter, which his British peers, he later wrote, “one after another actually spit out.”

headline: To Solve Its Housing Crisis, Britain Turns to an Old Idea: New Towns
abstract: By reviving an idea from the 1940s, the Labour Party government is hoping to overcome the development hurdles that have plagued previous efforts with a plan to build new communities.
lead_paragraph: On a baking hot afternoon in July, Firouz Thompson proudly drove down the freshly paved road that leads into Northstowe, a new town about six miles northwest of Cambridge, England.

headline: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia Flips the Script on Putin
abstract: The reality of 130,000 displaced Russians and a chaotic official response may begin to puncture the official line that Russia is steadily heading toward victory.
lead_paragraph: Families fleeing invading Ukrainian troops sought shelter from strangers. Russian parents feared that their children might be sent into battle for the first time.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 15, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about a study highlighting how extreme rainfall was made 10 percent heavier by human-caused climate change misstated the name of a scientific organization. It is the Kentucky Geologic Survey, not the Kentucky Geologic Society.

headline: A Chinese Self-Driving Start-Up Is About to Go Public in the U.S.
abstract: WeRide, a $5 billion software maker, is set for an I.P.O. amid geopolitical risks and a rush by Chinese automotive tech firms to raise money in the United States.
lead_paragraph: One of China’s leading autonomous driving start-ups is set to go public in New York as soon as this week, with the strained relationship between Beijing and Washington lurking in the background.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Israel’s goals in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military has severely set back Hamas but will never be able to completely eliminate the group, according to senior American officials who say continued bombings are only increasing risks to civilians.

headline: There Is Still Time to Stop a Wider War in the Middle East
abstract: America’s plan for preventing a full-blown war in the Middle East is unraveling.
lead_paragraph: Since the Oct. 7 Hamas terrorist attack on Israel, President Biden has had two goals in the Middle East: to support Israel’s right to defend itself against terrorism and to prevent the Israel-Hamas war from escalating into a regional conflagration that would compel the United States to step in.

headline: Word of the Day: boycott
abstract: This word has appeared in 308 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word boycott has appeared in 308 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 19 in “Kandinsky Cut Ties With Russia. So Did This Museum” by Nina Siegal:

headline: Seth Meyers Calls Trump ‘Desperate’ for Likes
abstract: Meyers said the former president’s return to X shows he yearns “for the spotlight and for some praise or positive coverage from anyone, anywhere.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: U.K. Economy Buoyed by Reports on Growth, Inflation and Jobs
abstract: After ending last year in a recession, Britain’s economy has so far bounced back this year.
lead_paragraph: The British economy grew relatively strongly in the spring, data on Thursday showed, the latest in a string of positive economic news.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: In South Korea, Documenting a Divide Over Work-Life Balance
abstract: The reporter Jin Yu Young wrote about companies that have pushed their managers to work longer hours, a move that has not gone over well with some young people in the country.
lead_paragraph: I spent much of my childhood in the United States and Canada but have lived in South Korea for all of my adult life. I have noticed one stark contrast between the places I grew up in and South Korea: people’s attitude toward work. In North America, it seems to me that people look for jobs that they are interested in or passionate about. In South Korea, people often prioritize jobs that offer prestige and better reputations.

headline: He Survived Combat in Iraq. Did a Fellow Soldier Kill Him at Home?
abstract: Jacob Ashton and Riley Birbilas, U.S. Army specialists, deployed to Iraq together. Now Specialist Birbilas is accused of killing Specialist Ashton at Fort Drum in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Aug. 2, U.S. Army Specialist Jacob Ashton left Fort Drum in upstate New York for the five-and-a-half-hour drive to his hometown in Ohio, where he spent the weekend with his girlfriend.

headline: Float Planned for N.Y.C. India Day Parade Is Condemned as Anti-Muslim
abstract: The float, slated for inclusion in Sunday’s parade, depicts a Hindu temple in India that was built on the site of a mosque torn down by religious extremists.
lead_paragraph: A float slated to appear in New York City’s India Day Parade this weekend is causing an uproar, with community groups calling it a symbol of anti-Muslim hate, parade organizers defending its inclusion and elected officials scrambling to respond.

headline: Who’s Up Next in Japan? Here Are 5 Potential Leaders.
abstract: Japan’s Liberal Democratic Party is searching for a successor to Prime Minister Fumio Kishida. But is it willing to change to appease a dissatisfied public?
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced plans to step down on Wednesday, he vowed that his departure would clear the way for a new leader who could bring change to Japan’s long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party.

headline: At a Festival Amid Industrial Ruins, Ivo van Hove Takes Charge
abstract: For the Belgian director’s first edition as leader of the Ruhrtriennale, abandoned sites are “the starting point and the end point,” he says.
lead_paragraph: The calling card of the Ruhrtriennale Festival of the Arts is to present shows in former industrial sites, like power stations or coal plants, among cities in the Ruhr region of northwestern Germany. For the theater-maker Ivo van Hove, who is presenting his first season as the festival’s artistic director, this is churning up feelings of déjà vu.

headline: Typhoon Ampil Approaches Japan, Disrupting Flights and Trains
abstract: The powerful storm is expected to bring heavy rain, strong winds and the threat of floods and landslides to eastern Japan, including Tokyo, on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Ampil barreled toward Japan on Thursday packing strong winds and heavy rain, and forcing the cancellation of hundreds of flights and trains in and around Tokyo.

headline: The Secret to Tom Wolfe’s Irresistible Snap, Crackle and Pop
abstract: How the author of “The Right Stuff,” “Radical Chic and Mau-Mauing the Flak Catchers” and other classics turned sociology into art.
lead_paragraph: There are certain writers you should never read before you yourself sit down to write, like P.G. Wodehouse and Tom Wolfe. For if you do, you will not be able to get their voices and rhythms out of your head, and you will have to confront the absolute certainty that you can’t pull off what they did. In Wolfe’s case you’ll find that you can’t quite replicate the raw energy of his prose: the fun; the snap, crackle, pop; the fuzzy effusions of new sociological categories — masters of the universe, social X-rays.

headline: Mobility Issues? Balance Concerns? Try a Chair Workout.
abstract: You can still build strength with a few simple, seated exercises.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, Aarthi Ravindran, then 23, was using a leg press machine at her gym when she suddenly felt an intense pain in her right knee. She was new to strength training and had tried to lift too much weight.

headline: Yoko Ogawa Loves Finding Love at the Bookstore
abstract: “My gaze meets the spine of a certain book,” explains the author of “The Memory Police.” “We exchange glances. … This book has chosen me.” Her latest novel to be translated from Japanese is “Mina’s Matchbox.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: 37 Square Feet That Show Brazil’s Racist Past
abstract: In Brazil, rooms for maids, a vestige of the country’s history of slavery, are disappearing or being transformed as the country confronts deeply ingrained inequities.
lead_paragraph: Ana Beatriz da Silva still remembers her first home: a tiny room behind the kitchen of a beachfront apartment in Rio de Janeiro, where her mother worked as a maid.

headline: Lainey Wilson’s Exhausting (but Rewarding) Country Music Hustle
abstract: The singer and songwriter struggled for years to break through. Now she’s staking a claim for herself — and other women in the genre — with a new album, “Whirlwind.”
lead_paragraph: Lainey Wilson was born and raised in Baskin, La., population 210. Her dad is a fifth-generation farmer. “We grew corn, wheat, soybeans, oats. We did cotton back in the day,” she said proudly in a recent interview. While her ascent to country-music stardom means that her family’s finances are secure, she noted that lately there’s been a lack of rainfall in the northeast part of the state. “This year’s going to be pretty rough,” she added. “Farming has a lot of ups and downs. It’s very similar to the music business.”

headline: Fall Fashion Is All About Refinement
abstract: Crisp, timeless silhouettes and kitten heels signal a return to polish and sophistication.

headline: And the Groom Wore Shorts
abstract: Call it an unintended consequence of climate change or a relaxation of fashion dictates: At weddings, more guests and couples are showing a little leg.
lead_paragraph: As soon as Willie Muse was invited to his cousin’s wedding in June on Cape Cod, he Googled what the “beach formal” dress code meant.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Constitutionality of the ‘Pizza Tax’
abstract: Does driving to pick up dinner entitle you to a car slice?
lead_paragraph: Douglas writes: My family lives near a wonderful pizza place that doesn’t deliver. I don’t mind driving to get pizza, but I recently decided that the effort entitles me to eat a slice on the way home. My family objects very strongly to my “pizza tax.” (If you print this, call me “Spike.” I’ve always wanted to be called that.)

headline: The Odd Duck of Antiguan Art, in His Ecstatic, Expressionist Glory
abstract: At the Drawing Center, the revival of the Antiguan artist Frank Walter continues with a stack of his written archive displayed alongside his  paintings.
lead_paragraph: In “Frank Walter: To Capture a Soul,” a scavenger hunt of an exhibition at the Drawing Center in Manhattan, we find an aspect of so-called outsider art that is not easily conveyed in museums: compulsion.

headline: ‘Jackpot!’ Review: Dystopia, Hollywood Style
abstract: Awkwafina and John Cena star in a fitfully funny near-future comedy with strangely mixed metaphors.
lead_paragraph: In the near future, things are not very different. People wear the same clothes as we do, ride the bus to work, call each other on cellphones and stay in terrible Airbnbs run by hosts from hell. In the near future, everything is still expensive. And if you want to be an actor, you move to Los Angeles.

headline: ‘Alien: Romulus’ Review: Go Ahead, Scream (No One Can Hear You)
abstract: The seventh installment of the series centers on Rain (Cailee Spaeny), a contract worker in an outer-space mining colony, and her friend Andy (David Jonsson), an android.
lead_paragraph: Some movie sequels take a series in new directions, adding original ideas, new characters, different approaches and, at times, heft and myth. Other sequels are more like filler. They help plug the spaces between movies and keep the franchise’s brand in the public’s imagination, all while trying to make some cash. The newest “Alien” movie, “Alien: Romulus,” the seventh installment in this storied, apparently inexhaustible cycle of films, is perfectly adequate filler.

headline: Embrace Your Summer Dad Bod. These Movies Show You the Way.
abstract: Films have much to say about taking a dad bod on vacation — from cheap laughs to the sartorial glories of Gérard Depardieu.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Elon Musk bought Twitter and somehow made the tailoring guru Derek Guy — better known by his handle @dieworkwear — an internet star, men’s wear has been the subject of more volcanically impassioned discussion online than ever. Where should the button on a suit jacket sit? Are brown shoes ever acceptable? Cargo shorts: yes or no? We are all critics of fit and silhouette now, pursing our lips in displeasure at every collar gap. But even in the final month of a brutally hot summer, one question remains underexplored: How should the thick-middled man present himself on the beach?

headline: Homes for Sale in New Jersey and New York
abstract: This week’s properties are a six-bedroom in Saddle River, N.J., and a four-bedroom in New Rochelle, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A six-bedroom, five-full-and-two-half-bath, 8,000-square-foot home built in the 1960s and updated in 2004, with a formal dining room and a sunken living room, a media room, a game room, an in-law suite, a finished walk-out basement with a sauna, an in-ground saltwater pool and a three-car attached garage, on two acres. Sheryl Epstein-Romano, Christie’s International Real Estate, 201-819-2999; christiesrealestate.com

headline: It’s Too Late for Summer Now
abstract: This season is so pushy, so insistent that it be reveled in.
lead_paragraph: I neglected to make plans for the summer. This obviously should have been worked out months ago. According to one market research firm, 56 percent of Americans surveyed in May were planning to take a vacation this summer, despite overtourism and sky-high prices.

headline: The Federal Child Tax Credit Allowed Some Parents to Go It Alone
abstract: A new study shows that the temporary increase in the credit in 2021 empowered some mothers to move on from unwanted partners.
lead_paragraph: A temporary financial benefit for parents during the pandemic helped low-income families stay in their homes. But it also had the effect of allowing mothers to move on from unwanted partners, a new study shows.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are in Yorkville, Hell’s Kitchen and Dumbo.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,100-square-foot apartment with stone countertops, a garbage disposal, an en suite bath with limestone and marble, radiant heat bathroom floors, zoned central air-conditioning and a washer/dryer, on the fifth floor of a 21-story doorman building from 2023 with a live-in super, basement storage cages, a gym, a children’s playroom, an art room, music and recording studios, a pet washing station and a roof deck. Doron Zwickel and Caleb Nickels, Core NYC, 917-400-4404; corenyc.com

headline: Want to See Coral Reefs Grow? Freeze Them.
abstract: We have to buy time while we wait for the world to slow, and hopefully, one day reverse climate change.
lead_paragraph: Since 2018, my lab has transplanted hundreds of coral specimens to reefs in Florida to study what makes them grow. We have albums of photos documenting their lives, starting from branches no bigger than your finger to beautiful treelike adults as big as beach balls.

headline: U.S. Unveils Price Limits for 10 Costly or Common Medications
abstract: The Biden administration said it would have saved $6 billion had the new prices been in effect last year.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Thursday unveiled the results of landmark drug price negotiations between Medicare and pharmaceutical companies, allowing President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris to cast themselves as confronting the drug industry on behalf of older Americans at a critical moment in the presidential campaign.

headline: Has RFK Jr.’s Moment Passed?
abstract: Kamala Harris at the top of the Democratic ticket changes the pitch. But in Michigan, where every vote can make a difference, his message is still resonating.
lead_paragraph: For much of the 2024 presidential election, it felt like there were pretty ideal conditions for a third-party candidate. Republicans and Democrats had both lined up behind broadly unpopular — and familiar — candidates. In the spring, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was polling at 10 percent in The New York Times/Siena College survey of battleground states, and sustained interest in his candidacy was enough to raise alarm among his major-party rivals.

headline: The Anchovy Renaissance Is Here
abstract: This humble fish could play a key role in our future.
lead_paragraph: Anchovies can help make plant-forward eating more delicious and appealing, argues Christopher Beckman, an archaeologist-turned-anchovy-lover. He is the author of “A Twist in the Tail: How the Humble Anchovy Flavored Western Cuisine,” and he makes the case for why we should all embrace the small, oily fish.

headline: WCBS Had a Dramatic Start. Now It’s Coming to an End.
abstract: The all-news station has been on the air for nearly 57 years. Its debut was held up when a stolen plane crashed into the station’s transmitter.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at the history of WCBS, the all-news station. We’ll also look at Justice Juan Merchan’s third rejection of Donald Trump’s move for him to recuse himself from Trump’s case.

headline: Democrats Are Missing Out on a Big Opportunity on Abortion Rights
abstract: Kamala Harris should show voters what Donald Trump could do in a second term.
lead_paragraph: Protecting reproductive rights is one of Democrats’ strongest issues, and their ability to capitalize on it may decide a tight election. Chances are even better now with Kamala Harris, a candidate known for her unapologetic positions on the issue, at the top of the ticket.

headline: The Intensification of JD Vance
abstract: There’s been so much said about Mr. Vance’s conversion from Trump hater to Trump loyalist, but at times he can sound like a millennial who, disillusioned, becomes more radical.
lead_paragraph: Since JD Vance got more political and decided to run for office, making sense of exactly the kind of politician he is and will be has been a challenge. There are different modes of Mr. Vance as a public figure. He has been the populist intellectual who works with Elizabeth Warren and also the tech podcast right-winger who talks about America as being in the “late republican period.” He can be the lawyerly professional on a Sunday show or the guy, when asked what makes him happy, who talks about anger.

headline: Tim Walz’s Bumpy Road to Gun Control
abstract: The vice-presidential candidate wasn’t always tough on firearms. When he ran for Minnesota governor, he tried to recast a legislative record that had gotten high marks from the N.R.A.
lead_paragraph: In a tight primary for governor in 2018, Tim Walz, then a congressman from a conservative pro-gun district in Minnesota, was rebuked for his A ratings from the National Rifle Association. After a school shooting in Parkland, Fla., he went on the offensive.

headline: 36 Hours in Provincetown, Mass.
abstract: P-town offers overlapping identities: one of America’s oldest art colonies, nature preserve, thriving L.G.B.T.Q. resort and historic Portuguese fishing village.
lead_paragraph: P-town offers overlapping identities: one of America’s oldest art colonies, nature preserve, thriving L.G.B.T.Q. resort and historic Portuguese fishing village.

headline: San Francisco Moves to Lead Fight Against Deepfake Nudes
abstract: City Attorney David Chiu has filed a lawsuit seeking to permanently shutter 16 popular websites that turn images of real girls and women into pornography.
lead_paragraph: Like many parents, Yvonne Meré was deeply disturbed when she read about a frightening new trend.

headline: I Wrote ‘Friday Night Lights.’ Here’s Why Coach Tim Walz Stands Apart.
abstract: No one can resist the inspiring allure of “clear eyes, full hearts, can’t lose.” But politics can require a different skill set.
lead_paragraph: Before Gov. Tim Walz became the most famous person in America to coach high school football, there was Eric Taylor.

headline: A Three-Bedroom House in the Bay Area for Under $1 Million? Here Were Their Options.
abstract: After six years in the desert of Palm Springs, a retired couple headed north in search of new construction in Sonoma County.
lead_paragraph: After six years in the desert of Palm Springs, a retired couple headed north in search of new construction in Sonoma County.

headline: A Sunny New Restaurant in a Parisian Train Station
abstract: Plus: skin care inspired by Belize, a Los Angeles designer’s denim collection and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: “I’m So Happy You Are Here: Japanese Women Photographers from the 1950s to Now,” a new book published by Aperture, features wide-ranging portfolios by 25 photographers. As Pauline Vermare, a co-editor of the book, writes in her introductory essay, the primary focus of the women showcased in the book “has been, and remains, to find the means to be independent and represent their own experiences and views of the world.” Among the works included are those by the 77-year-old photographer Miyako Ishiuchi, who co-founded a photography magazine, main, in 1996. The book contains photos from “Yokosuka Story,” a 1970s series focusing on her hometown, the location of a major U.S. Navy base, and a still-life of a lipstick, part of her “Mother’s” (2000-2005) series, for which she photographed her deceased mother’s possessions. One of the youngest photographers in the book, Momo Okabe, 43, trains her lens on her own body and those of her friends, capturing both everyday experiences and life-changing events such as gender-affirming surgery and pregnancy. From photojournalism to works of collage, the book, as its introduction states, “lays the groundwork for understanding the enormity of what has been overlooked.” “I’m So Happy You Are Here” is out on Sept. 17, $75, aperture.org.

headline: Nevada Senate Race Now Favors Democrat, Report Says
abstract: The nonpartisan Cook Political Report moved the race from “tossup” to “lean Democrat” after polling showed Senator Jacky Rosen with a large edge.
lead_paragraph: Senator Jacky Rosen of Nevada, a Democrat seeking re-election to her seat for the first time, is pulling ahead of her Republican challenger, Sam Brown, in a race that was once considered a feasible pickup for the G.O.P., according to several polls released this week.

headline: Half Their Land Burned in a Decade: The California Counties Constantly on Fire
abstract: Park fire became California’s fourth largest this month. It erupted in a part of the state that is increasingly covered with the scars of wildfires.
lead_paragraph: Park fire became California’s fourth largest this month. It erupted in a part of the state that is increasingly covered with the scars of wildfires.

headline: Seeking Calm, Columbia University Asks a Doctor to Lead
abstract: Dr. Katrina A. Armstrong replaces Nemat Shafik as president of one of the most turbulent campuses in America.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Katrina A. Armstrong was out of sorts.

headline: Ukraine Is Poking the Russian Bear
abstract: Its cross-border attack shows “the war is not over.”
lead_paragraph: Here’s one way to think through the importance of the news stories that flood our lives: Which ones will historians still be talking about in 50 years? Are there any that they’ll be talking about in 100?

headline: A Mob Attack on a Toppled Party Shows Bangladesh’s Dangerous Vacuum
abstract: A cycle of vengeance is playing out even as the interim government is trying to establish reforms and keep order.
lead_paragraph: The tables had turned: Yesterday’s victims of brutal suppression were today’s perpetrators of brutal revenge.

headline: Canceling Memberships Is a Pain. New Biden Administration Rules Aim to Make It Easier.
abstract: A new set of rules could also require businesses to make it easier to reach customer-service agents.
lead_paragraph: A set of policies proposed by the Biden administration this week could make it easier for consumers to cancel subscriptions, speak to customer service agents, get flight refunds and more.

headline: 5.4-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Near Taiwan
abstract: There were no immediate reports of major damage, but the island’s fire department warned of the risk of landslides in mountainous areas.
lead_paragraph: A 5.4-magnitude earthquake struck off the east coast of Taiwan on Thursday, the United States Geological Survey said.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,154
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 16, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: All Eyes on Gaza Cease-Fire Talks, and Kennedy Explores a Cabinet Job
abstract: Plus, a scourge of “deepfake” Elon Musk scams.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Connections Companion No. 432
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Friday, Aug. 16, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A Controversial Crackdown on Homeless Encampments
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom has taken sweeping action in the wake of a landmark Supreme Court ruling.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since a landmark Supreme Court ruling opened the door for cities and states to crack down on homeless encampments, California — the state with the largest homeless population — has taken some of the nation’s most sweeping actions against them.

headline: Russia Sentences U.S. Citizen to 12 Years in Prison on Treason Charges
abstract: Ksenia Karelina is accused of donating $52 to a New York-based nonprofit that sends assistance to Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A court in Russia sentenced a dual citizen of Russia and the United States on Thursday to 12 years in prison on accusations that she committed treason by donating money — about $50 — for Ukraine’s armed forces.

headline: A Catastrophic Civil War in Sudan
abstract: How an unexpected conflict is crushing Africa’s third-largest country.
lead_paragraph: After more than a year of civil war, the toll in Sudan is heartbreaking: thousands killed, millions scattered and cities besieged or destroyed across a vast nation three times as large as France. Much of the capital lies in rubble. This month, international officials declared that part of Sudan was in a famine. At least 100 people die of hunger every day.
