abstract: On a hot day, getting hair off the back of your neck is often the simplest way to start cooling down. The sweeping movement is instinctual, but it is also deeply personal.
lead_paragraph: A ponytail. A messy bun. A long, single braid. Dreads platted against one another. Heavy curls, clinging to the back of a bare back.

headline: Russia Closes In on Key Eastern Ukrainian City Despite Kursk Incursion
abstract: A Russian advance toward Pokrovsk casts doubts on Ukraine’s hopes that its cross-border offensive will prompt Moscow to scale back attacks elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Russian troops are closing in on the strategic eastern Ukrainian town of Pokrovsk, according to open-source battlefield maps, casting doubts on Ukraine’s hopes that its new offensive into western Russia will prompt Moscow to scale back its attacks elsewhere on the battlefield.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,155
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Harris’s Strategically Vague Economic Message, and Russians Feel the War
abstract: Plus, charges in Matthew Perry’s death.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Connections Companion No. 433
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Aug. 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: How Air-Conditioning Conquered America
abstract: Indoor cooling has transformed American life, reshaping homes, skylines and where people choose to live. As the planet warms, is that sustainable?
lead_paragraph: Air-conditioning has become both our answer to a warming planet and a major obstacle to actually confronting it.

headline: Who Is Paetongtarn Shinawatra, Thailand’s New Prime Minister?
abstract: The political heir to an influential family is now leading Thailand with no governing experience in a tumultuous time.
lead_paragraph: Thailand’s Parliament chose Paetongtarn Shinawatra, 37, to become the country’s prime minister on Friday, elevating a candidate with no governing experience to the leadership of a nation in profound political turmoil.

headline: Ukraine’s Push Into Russia Met Early Success. Where Does It Go From Here?
abstract: Ukraine’s forces could try advancing farther on Russian soil, or return to the front line, where Moscow is making gains. There are arguments for various options.
lead_paragraph: The success of Ukraine’s secret incursion into Russia is clear. Ukrainian forces pushed past two lines of Russian defenses in the southwestern region of Kursk and moved through Russian highways and villages with little resistance. Since the operation began 11 days ago, they have gone beyond Kursk to the neighboring region of Belgorod, putting other communities on edge and rattling Moscow.

headline: What’s Stopping a Deal in Gaza?
abstract: Washington now sees Benjamin Netanyahu as the chief obstacle.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, the White House said the stars were aligned for a cease-fire agreement that would free the hostages held in Gaza. The framework of a deal first announced by President Biden has been in place since July. Since then, a phalanx of American officials has traveled frequently to the region, pushing Israel and Hamas to sign on. So far, they have failed.

headline: Harris to Lay Out Economic Message Focused on High Cost of Living
abstract: The vice president’s plans represent more of a reboot of President Biden’s economic policies than a radically fresh start.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris will unveil the central planks of her economic agenda on Friday in Raleigh, N.C., during her first major policy speech, focusing on how she plans to fight big corporations and bring down costs on necessities like food, housing and raising children.

headline: Apple Giving Ground on App Store Rules to Appease Regulators
abstract: The company faces pressure from governments around the world and complaints from companies that it is still too restrictive.
lead_paragraph: Governments around the world have pressured Apple with laws and lawsuits that aim to loosen its grip over the digital economy. Now, the tech giant is beginning to make concessions that could change people’s iPhone experience.

headline: The War on Prices Hits the Campaign Trail
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris is expected to make her pitch on Friday for tackling America’s affordability crunch, but many economists are skeptical.
lead_paragraph: Stocks are rallying. Consumers are shopping despite a slowdown in the labor market. And hopes are growing for lower interest rates on the horizon.

headline: Inmate Captured in North Carolina After Escape
abstract: Law enforcement officers captured Ramone Alston, who had been serving a life sentence for murder, at a hotel. He was moved to a high-security prison unit and will face new charges.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in North Carolina on Friday captured a man convicted of murder, whose escape from custody three days earlier had prompted an extensive search, according to the state’s Department of Adult Correction.

headline: How Air-Conditioning Made Us Expect Arizona to Feel the Same as Maine
abstract: It’s a quiet force that contributes to a sameness across the country and to climate change.
lead_paragraph: One force has quietly shaped much of the world around us — our homes, our offices, the look of our cities, the migration patterns of Americans and the economic fortunes of different parts of the country.

headline: Dolphin Attacks Spoil Summer Along a Stretch of Japanese Beaches
abstract: Nearly 50 beachgoers have been attacked in the past three years. Some marine experts suspect it may be the work of a single “lonely” dolphin.
lead_paragraph: At the beaches along an idyllic coastal stretch of central Japan, lifeguards scan the water, poised to call swimmers back to shore at the hint of a fin. Sharp teeth shown on posters warn beachgoers to be careful because, for the third year running, there is danger in the water.

headline: The Price of Getting Inked
abstract: Whether it’s the expense of getting tattooed or the cost to have one removed, Americans are paying for their ink.
lead_paragraph: Mike Weiss has at least 70 tattoos, stretching from his shoulders to his ankles. Since getting his first in 2011, he has spent roughly $13,000 on them.

headline: What I’m Reading: Why Democracy Erodes From the Top
abstract: Three book recommendations from sunny London.
lead_paragraph: Greetings from London’s long, hot* summer, where I am keeping cool through the traditional method of my people: staying inside and reading books.

headline: A Memoir Offers an Insider’s Perspective Into the Pentagon’s U.F.O. Hunt
abstract: In “Imminent,” the former intelligence official who ran a once-secret program shares some of what he knows.
lead_paragraph: Luis Elizondo made headlines in 2017 when he resigned as a senior intelligence official running a shadowy Pentagon program investigating U.F.O.s and publicly denounced the excessive secrecy, lack of resources and internal opposition that he said were thwarting the effort.

headline: How Your Cat or Dog Could Warn of a Bird Flu Outbreak
abstract: Like most countries, the U.S. has no comprehensive national system for monitoring disease in companion animals — which leaves pets and people at risk.
lead_paragraph: Trupanion, a Seattle-based pet insurance company, is partnering with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to create a disease tracking system for pets, the company announced this week. The system will draw on insurance claims submitted to Trupanion in real time when sick dogs and cats visit the veterinarian.

headline: Well Behind Schedule, Trump Names Allies to Lead Transition Team
abstract: The appointment of Linda McMahon and Howard Lutnick is notable, as neither has been associated with Project 2025, a conservative initiative seized on by Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has appointed two of his friends and financial backers to oversee a transition team preparing for his potential return to power. The move comes as polls show that his once-commanding lead evaporated after President Biden dropped out of the election and Vice President Kamala Harris became the Democratic nominee.

headline: Saving Conservatism From Trumpism
abstract: Responses to a column by David French. Also: The candidates’ foreign experience; a loss of diversity in network news; school libraries; independent voters.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks feature a zombie romance, a drug trial from hell and deathly prehistoric evil.
lead_paragraph: Lisa is a lot like I was in 1989: She lives with her middle-class family in the suburbs, loves staying up late to watch horror movies and has a crush on a cute boy with bangs.

headline: Pesto Beans, a Bowl of Summer Tenderness
abstract: This fast, straightforward recipe has all the summery flavors of pine nuts, Parmesan and basil in a bowl of soft, warm, comforting beans.
lead_paragraph: Good morning! This is Tejal, filling in for Sam.

headline: He Made a Game About a Joyous Journey. He Also Got a Bit Lost.
abstract: Anthony Tan was 16 when his idea for a video game about a deer caught the industry’s eye. Nine years later, he’s still working on it.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Tan’s hands shook as he took his seat in a dark Los Angeles theater. The neon green lights sporadically illuminated the 7,000 faces around him.

headline: The Big Number: 2.9%
abstract: The rate of inflation in July on a yearly basis.
lead_paragraph: Inflation slowed in July, the Consumer Price Index showed, increasing 2.9 percent from a year earlier. That was a drop from 3 percent in June, and it marked the first time that inflation had fallen below 3 percent since 2021.

headline: What Minnesota’s Law on Free Tampons in Public Schools Actually Does
abstract: Conservatives have criticized Gov. Tim Walz over the law, but schools have not taken it as a mandate to put menstrual products into boys’ restrooms.
lead_paragraph: Tucked into a stack of budget bills Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota signed into law last May was a measure that went largely unnoticed: Public schools would be required to provide free menstrual products to all students who needed them, beginning in the fourth grade.

headline: This Georgia Republican Defied Trump. Now He’s Fighting a Defamation Suit.
abstract: The secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger, has spent $500,000 defending himself in court. He says the plaintiff will only settle if he effectively endorses a debunked conspiracy theory about the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Brad Raffensperger, Georgia’s Republican secretary of state, has been forced to spend half a million dollars defending himself in court for having stood up to former President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Missouri Woman Charged in Scheme to Defraud Presleys and Sell Graceland
abstract: A woman named Lisa Jeanine Findley was arrested and accused of a brazen effort to foreclose on Elvis Presley’s home in Memphis.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities arrested a Missouri woman on Friday and accused her of orchestrating a brazen effort to shake down the Presley family by threatening to fraudulently foreclose on Graceland, Elvis’s home in Memphis, which is now a popular tourist attraction.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The hosts returned from a break and had much to discuss, including former President Trump’s obsession with crowd size and Vice President Harris’s surge in the polls. Here’s what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: The hosts returned from a break and had much to discuss, including former President Trump’s obsession with crowd size and Vice President Harris’s surge in the polls. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: Typhoon Ampil Brings Heavy Rains and Floods to Eastern Japan
abstract: The storm forced evacuations and caused widespread travel disruptions.
lead_paragraph: The storm forced evacuations and caused widespread travel disruptions.

headline: ‘It Ends With Us’: The Press Tour Drama, Explained
abstract: What’s happening onscreen has become secondary to the conversation about differences between Blake Lively and Justin Baldoni, her co-star and director.
lead_paragraph: The Blake Lively romantic drama “It Ends With Us” revolves around a florist, and the film’s marketing campaign, including the red carpet and the posters, has been entirely floral-themed. But the press tour has hardly come up roses.

headline: Jerry Fuller, Songwriter of ‘Young Girl’ and ‘Travelin’ Man,’ Is Dead at 85
abstract: He found a musical sweet spot between romance and “out of line” desire for recordings by Ricky Nelson, Johnny Mathis and Gary Puckett and the Union Gap.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Fuller, a songwriter who helped give the sexual revolution a Top 40 soundtrack, died on July 18 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: Tehran appears to be allowing mediators time to pursue cease-fire talks, according to multiple officials.
abstract: The delay is meant to allow mediators time to make a high-stakes push for a cease-fire to end the war in Gaza, according to U.S., Iranian and Israeli officials, who warn
lead_paragraph: Iran is expected to delay planned reprisals against Israel for the assassination of a top Hamas leader in Tehran to allow mediators time to make a high-stakes push for a cease-fire to end the war in Gaza, U.S., Iranian and Israeli officials said on Friday.

headline: Charlie Moss, Whose Ads Spread Love for a Battered New York, Dies at 85
abstract: As a pioneer of Madison Avenue’s creative revolution, his “I ♥ NY” tourism pitches helped pump new life into a city deflated by the turmoil of the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Moss, the visionary advertising executive credited with producing the stunningly successful “I ♥ NY” tourism campaign in the mid-1970s — a time when garbage, graffiti, crime, racial strife and a serial killer made America’s cultural capital anything but lovable — died on Aug. 5 at his home in Wainscott, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 85.

headline: Trump Pulls in Tulsi Gabbard for Debate Prep
abstract: Tulsi Gabbard, the former Democrat who has rebranded herself as a celebrity among Donald J. Trump’s supporters, once eviscerated Kamala Harris on a debate stage.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has begun preparing for his debate with Vice President Kamala Harris and has brought in the former Democratic congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard to help sharpen his attacks in a recent practice session at his private club and home, Mar-a-Lago, according to two people with knowledge of Mr. Trump’s schedule.

headline: Trump’s Laughable Effort to Avoid Being Sentenced Before November
abstract: It shows how nervous he is about Justice Merchan’s upcoming decision.
lead_paragraph: For the past half-century, Donald Trump has always had the same spaghetti approach to litigation: Throw everything against the wall and see what sticks.

headline: Indian Kashmir to Hold Legislative Election for First Time in a Decade
abstract: Some measure of self-governance will be restored in the region, which was stripped of its semiautonomous status by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in a decade, Muslim-majority Kashmir in India will hold an election for its regional legislature starting next month, the country’s election commission said on Friday.

headline: Lady Gaga and Bruno Mars’s Throwback Duet, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by the Linda Lindas featuring Weird Al Yankovic, Chlöe and Anderson .Paak, Lou Reed’s early band and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Trump’s Message: Prices (Plus Gangs, A.I. and ‘Bird Cemeteries’)
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump was supposed to focus on the price of groceries at an event on Thursday. His attention wandered.
lead_paragraph: He was supposed to be talking about Country Crock.

headline: 7 Hot Tracks From a New Generation of Female Rappers
abstract: Listen to recent songs from Megan Thee Stallion, Ice Spice, Latto and more.
lead_paragraph: In April 2018, the same week that the Bronx superstar Cardi B released her debut album, “Invasion of Privacy,” Complex magazine published an essay by the writer Kiana Fitzgerald that explored a longstanding question: “Why can there only be one dominant woman in rap?”

headline: OpenAI Says It Disrupted an Iranian Misinformation Campaign
abstract: The company said the Iranian effort, which used ChatGPT, did not gain much traction.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI said on Friday that it had discovered and disrupted an Iranian influence campaign that used the company’s generative artificial intelligence technologies to spread misinformation online, including content related to the U.S. presidential election.

headline: Trump Says Civilian Award Is ‘Much Better’ Than Medal of Honor
abstract: The former president said Thursday the reason was because those given the nation’s highest military award are “either in very bad shape because they’ve been hit so many times by bullets, or they’re dead.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Thursday described the Presidential Medal of Freedom, which honors civilians, as being “much better” than the Medal of Honor, because service members who receive the nation’s highest military honor are often severely wounded or dead.

headline: Liz Moore on ‘The God of the Woods’
abstract: The author discusses her best-selling new novel about family secrets and a missing camper.
lead_paragraph: A summer camp in the Adirondacks. A rich girl gone missing, 14 years after her older brother also disappeared. A prominent local family harboring dark secrets. Liz Moore’s new novel, “The God in the Woods,” turns these elements into a complex and suspenseful meditation on parenting and social class and the rituals of summer friendship: “Those of us with fond memories of summer camp,” Kate Tuttle wrote in her review for us, “will recognize the way campers enter into intense relationships, test themselves against childhood fears and begin to grow into who they’ll become.”

headline: Menendez, Convicted of Taking Bribes, Ends Race for Re-election
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey instructed state officials on Friday to remove his name from the Nov. 5 ballot.
lead_paragraph: Senator Robert Menendez, a famously pugnacious Democrat whose five-decade political career came to a crashing halt last month when he was convicted of corruption, has run his final race for re-election.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, August 17, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: I’m Choosing Which Interns Will Get Job Offers. Do I Take Privilege Into Account?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to fairly evaluate candidates in a workplace.
lead_paragraph: I manage the summer-intern program for my team at a major global financial institution. Together with two other colleagues, I decide to whom we wish to offer full-time positions at the end of the term. Our interns come from an array of socioeconomic and academic backgrounds and perform their duties with varying degrees of skill. Those coming from more well-to-do backgrounds appear to be performing better than those who come from less privileged backgrounds. When providing our final evaluations and ranking these interns, should we take their personal life circumstances into consideration? Or must we evaluate interns solely on job performance? We have been given no guidance on this from our program management. — Name Withheld

headline: When Does a Recession Become Official?
abstract: Just look at these six indicators.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say you’re an armchair economist and you think the U.S. economy is already in a recession (as many people do). Or maybe you’re sure it’s still growing. Either way, you would love to serve on the committee that makes the semiofficial determinations of when recessions begin and end.

headline: Florida Woman Found Guilty of Manslaughter in Fatal Shooting of Black Neighbor
abstract: Susan Lorincz, who is white, shot Ajike Owens last June through the door of her home as the 35-year-old mother of four stood outside. The case prompted national outrage.
lead_paragraph: A white woman in Florida who shot a Black neighbor who confronted her at the door of her home last year in a case that prompted national outrage was found guilty of manslaughter on Friday by a jury in Marion County, Fla.

headline: From ‘Perfect Candidate’ to Sudden Exit: Inside the Fall of Columbia’s President
abstract: Nemat Shafik was vilified on almost all sides for her handling of the protests over the Israel-Hamas war. When given an offramp, she took it.
lead_paragraph: The part-time role in London was unpaid, temporary and only advisory, but to Nemat Shafik, it offered a way out of her beleaguered presidency at Columbia University.

headline: New Zealand Diplomat Is Victim of Armed Robbery, Paris Authorities Say
abstract: The Paris prosecutor’s office said that the diplomat had been struck in the face with the butt of a pistol. The robbery took place in Paris’s affluent 7th arrondissement.
lead_paragraph: A diplomat from New Zealand’s Embassy in France was the victim of an armed robbery in Paris on Thursday, the city’s prosecutor’s office said the following day.

headline: What It’s Like as a Barista at One of the World’s Busiest Train Stations
abstract: Commuters fuel up daily at the Cafe Grumpy in Grand Central Terminal. Here is the man who keeps the coffee flowing.
lead_paragraph: Most co-workers see one another only after they’ve had their morning beverages. Arnaldo Hernandez Mundo doesn’t have that privilege.

headline: Mpox Case in Sweden Sets Off Concerns of Wider Spread in Europe
abstract: Experts expect more cases to surface in European countries because of frequent travel to and from Africa, with the threat of contracting the disease raised from “very low” to “low.”
lead_paragraph: The announcement that a new version of mpox had been discovered in Sweden this week was the first indication that the disease had slipped out of Africa, where it has caused an escalating crisis in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

headline: Harris’s Economic Plan Could Impress a Lot of Voters
abstract: The plan she presented in Raleigh was about how to lower the cost of living.
lead_paragraph: In Raleigh, N.C., on Friday, Kamala Harris did a pretty smooth job of reframing one of her biggest negatives — high prices — into a potential positive. If she can sell her message to voters, I think it will strongly improve her chances of winning in November.

headline: How to Watch the First Harris-Trump Debate
abstract: ABC News will broadcast the debate next month, which former President Donald J. Trump briefly backed out of after President Biden withdrew from the race. Mr. Trump then changed his mind.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump are expected to meet for the first time in a televised debate on ABC News in September, a critical test in a fluid campaign that should draw tens of millions of viewers — if it happens.

headline: JD Vance’s Plane Makes Emergency Landing in Milwaukee
abstract: A problem with the door seal on the Boeing 737 forced the chartered plane to return to the airport before continuing to Cincinnati.
lead_paragraph: A chartered campaign plane carrying Senator JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, was forced to make an emergency landing in Milwaukee on Friday shortly after takeoff because of a door malfunction on the aircraft, a campaign spokeswoman said.

headline: Harris Lays Out Her Economic Vision, Casting Trump’s as Backward-Looking
abstract: In her first major policy speech, the vice president argued that her Republican opponent was too focused on the past, painting herself as someone who would protect the middle class for generations.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris unspooled her economic agenda on Friday in her first major policy address, casting her vision as one for the future and former President Donald J. Trump’s as of the past, as she argued that she would improve the lives of middle-class Americans and benefit generations of their descendants.

headline: The U.N. Calls for a Temporary Truce to Fight Polio in Gaza
abstract: Secretary General António Guterres’s public comments came just before Gazan health authorities announced the first case of the disease in the enclave in many years.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, called on Friday for a weeklong cease-fire in Gaza to allow vaccinations to prevent an outbreak of polio, saying that many children were at risk. He spoke just a few hours before the first case of polio in the enclave in many years was confirmed in a statement from the Gaza health ministry.

headline: Judge Blocks Joint Sports Streaming Service From 3 Media Giants
abstract: The planned service from Disney, Fox and Warner Bros. Discovery was slated to cost $42.99 a month and aimed at fans who had abandoned cable TV.
lead_paragraph: A judge issued a preliminary injunction against Disney, Fox and Warner Bros. Discovery on Friday over a planned sports-focused streaming service from the companies, saying the joint venture would most likely make the market for sports viewership less competitive.

headline: Harris Unveiled Her Economic Agenda
abstract: Also, Russia closed in on a key city in eastern Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: In her first major policy speech since launching her campaign for president, Kamala Harris today explained the core of her economic agenda and argued that she would protect the middle class for generations. She promised to fight big corporations and bring down the costs of food, housing and raising children. A centerpiece of her economic pitch is a new federal ban on price gouging on groceries.

headline: Maurice Williams, 86, Dies; His ‘Stay’ Was a Hit for Him and Four Seasons
abstract: A chart topper in 1960 for his doo-wop group the Zodiacs, it inspired popular cover versions and was heard in the 1987 film “Dirty Dancing.”
lead_paragraph: Maurice Williams, the singer and songwriter whose 1960 single “Stay,” recorded with his doo-wop group the Zodiacs, shot to No. 1 and became a cover-song staple for a long line of musical acts, including the Four Seasons, the Hollies and Jackson Browne, died on Aug. 6 in Charlotte, N.C. He was 86.

headline: Harris and Trump Offer a Clear Contrast on the Economy
abstract: Both candidates embrace expansions of government power to steer economic outcomes — but in vastly different areas.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald J. Trump flew to North Carolina this week to deliver what were billed as major speeches on the economy. Neither laid out a comprehensive policy plan — not Ms. Harris in her half-hour focus on housing, groceries and prescription drugs, nor Mr. Trump in 80 minutes of sprinkling various proposals among musings about dangerous immigrants.

headline: Supreme Court, for Now, Blocks Expanded Protections for Transgender Students in Some States
abstract: The order maintained halts by lower courts on federal rules prohibiting discrimination against transgender people in schools.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday temporarily continued to block Education Department rules intended to protect transgender students from discrimination based on their gender identity in several Republican states that had mounted challenges.

headline: Would You Pay to Attend a Wedding?
abstract: As wedding costs continue to increase, some couples are charging guests to attend their special day.
lead_paragraph: Planning a wedding has become so expensive that some couples are asking their guests to pay to attend their special day.

headline: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks to Resume in Cairo, as Mediators Race to Head Off Wider War
abstract: Top officials from the U.S., Israel, Egypt and Qatar ended two days of talks in Doha aimed at trying to resolve remaining disagreements between Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: High-level talks to halt the war in Gaza ended without an immediate breakthrough on Friday, but the United States, Egypt and Qatar said the negotiations would continue next week as mediators raced to secure a truce that they hope will avert a wider regional conflagration.

headline: Tell Us: Have You Been Forgoing Covid Tests?
abstract: It’s the fifth summer of Covid, and most people seem eager to move on. We want to understand the pervasiveness of the ignorance-is-bliss attitude.
lead_paragraph: Covid cases are surging, but in contrast to summers past, our lives seem to be carrying on with all of their scheduled programming.

headline: Free Vasectomies and an Inflatable IUD: Abortion Rights Advocates Hit the D.N.C.
abstract: This convention is likely to be a head-on display of a new, unbridled abortion politics.
lead_paragraph: While delegates are in Chicago for next week’s Democratic National Convention, they will engage in the typical pageantry and traditions: They’ll vote for their nominee, pose for photos with elected officials, and show off their state with cool buttons or themed hats.

headline: Thinks (On)
abstract: Brandon Koppy submits a clean, confident Saturday crossword puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Brandon Koppy peppers us with misdirects in this grid, his second Saturday and 17th crossword overall for The Times. His constructions are always creative and lively (try this Friday puzzle from 2022 if you haven’t already solved it); he also slips in a lot of twists and winks. I noted a few little accents that are subtle enough to make me wonder whether they were even intentional — not quite Easter eggs but elements that many solvers will appreciate.

headline: Fossils Show Giant Predatory Sea Scorpions Were Distance Swimmers
abstract: Specimens of what appear to be the largest eurypterid species found in Australia could shed light on the sudden extinction of the massive arthropods.
lead_paragraph: Most modern scorpions would fit in the palm of your hand. But in the oceans of the Paleozoic era more than 400 million years ago, animals known popularly as sea scorpions were apex predators that could grow larger than people in size.

headline: Body-Camera Video Shows Chaos Around Fatal Police Shooting of N.J. Woman
abstract: New Jersey’s attorney general is investigating the killing of Victoria G. Lee, whose family has said the police escalated a nonthreatening episode. The police said Ms. Lee had a knife.
lead_paragraph: Newly released police body-camera footage shows the chaotic scene when a police officer in Fort Lee, N.J., fatally shot a 25-year-old woman in her apartment last month after he responded to a call about a person experiencing a mental health crisis and holding a knife.

headline: Harris Accepts an Offer to Meet with Teamsters Union Members
abstract: The head of the union, which has not backed a presidential candidate this year, asked to speak at both parties’ conventions. He spoke at the Republican convention in July.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris accepted an offer from the leadership of the Teamsters union to meet for a round-table discussion, according to the union.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Football Dream Over? NASCAR Has a Job It’d Like to Discuss.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t grow up playing pit crew in your backyard.”

headline: Doubting America’s ‘Nuclear Umbrella,’ Some South Koreans Want Their Own
abstract: Washington says it would defend the South against North Korea with nuclear arms, if need be. But more and more people in the South think it should rely on itself.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Korean War was halted in an uneasy truce in 1953, South Koreans have lived under an American promise to defend their country, if necessary, with nuclear weapons. President Biden emphatically reiterated that commitment last year, vowing that any nuclear attack by North Korea would lead to the destruction of its government.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 17, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Aug. 9 about a Beijing court’s decision to uphold a longstanding rule that allows only married women to freeze their eggs misstated the name of the court that rejected Teresa Xu’s lawsuit. It was the Beijing No. 3 Intermediate People’s Court, not the Chaoyang Intermediate People’s Court.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: When N.F.L. Dreams End, NASCAR’s Pit Crews Beckon
abstract: In NASCAR, victory — and money — is often determined by seconds, one reason car racing teams are increasingly looking to hire former college athletes.
lead_paragraph: D.J. Twitty was taking it all in: the jackmen lifting the racecars, the whizzing of air guns screwing in lug nuts, the slinging of 50-pound wheels. For a South Carolina native like the 24-year-old Twitty, the cacophonous scene was just this side of paradise.

headline: How a Brooklyn Business Owner and Foodie Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Kai Avent-deLeon, who owns a lifestyle store and a restaurant in Brooklyn, starts and ends her day with her journal. In between? Friends, family and delicious food.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, Kai Avent-deLeon craved a space in her Brooklyn neighborhood that embodied fashion, art, music and interiors. But she could not find anything like that in Bedford-Stuyvesant. So she opened Sincerely, Tommy, a lifestyle concept store that is also part cafe, as “a labor of love.” It carried independent designers from all over the world — like Collina Strada, Rejina Pyo and Nanushka — before they became more well known.

headline: Diving Into New York’s Murky Green Waters, Searching for Treasure
abstract: It’s hard to see through the water, and too easy to find trash, but divers are finding joy in exploring New York.
lead_paragraph: Adam Riback has spent a lifetime thinking about what lies beneath the surface.

headline: A New York City Hospital System Has Been Bitten by the Acting Bug
abstract: The Northwell Health system allowed filmmakers to make documentaries following its doctors, nurses and patients. It went so well, the hospital is starting a studio to make its own.
lead_paragraph: Unusual for a hospital system, Northwell Health has opened its doors to several filmmakers in recent years. Camera crews have filmed brain surgeries and births. They have filmed patients receiving good news and patients learning their cancer is back. And all along, the doctors have spoken candidly about their work and their lives.

headline: Israeli Strike on Lebanon Kills at Least 10
abstract: The strike came as tensions between the two countries were running high over the Gaza war. Negotiators are pushing for a truce in Gaza, hoping to avert a wider regional conflagration.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike hit a factory in a small town in southern Lebanon, killing at least 10 civilians, Lebanese officials said on Saturday, as people across the Middle East uneasily awaited reprisals against Israel by Iran and its allies for a pair of assassinations.

headline: Cross-Tabs: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate in Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and North Carolina
abstract: Results of an Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 2,670 likely voters from Aug. 8 to 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of an Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 2,670 likely voters from Aug. 8 to 15, 2024.

abstract: Results of an Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 2,670 registered voters from Aug. 8 to 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of an Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 2,670 registered voters from Aug. 8 to 15, 2024.

abstract: Results of a Nevada New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 677 registered voters from Aug. 12 to 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a Nevada New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 677 registered voters from Aug. 12 to 15, 2024.

abstract: Results of a North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 677 registered voters from Aug. 12 to 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 677 registered voters from Aug. 12 to 15, 2024.

lead_paragraph: Results of a Nevada New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 677 likely voters from Aug. 12 to 15, 2024.

abstract: Results of a North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 655 registered voters from Aug. 9 to 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 655 registered voters from Aug. 9 to 14, 2024.

abstract: Results of a North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 655 registered voters from Aug. 9 to 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 655 registered voters from Aug. 9 to 14, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: August 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate in North Carolina
abstract: Results of a North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 655 likely voters from Aug. 9 to 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a North Carolina New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 655 likely voters from Aug. 9 to 14, 2024.

headline: A Virtuoso Cellist’s Painstaking Path From Long Covid Back to the Stage
abstract: For over three years, long Covid has presented Joshua Roman with health challenges — and has indelibly shaped the music he makes.
lead_paragraph: Since he began playing cello at 3, Joshua Roman’s talent has taken him from his hometown of Mustang, Okla., to concert halls all over the world.

headline: For Abortion Providers, a Tough Business Gets Even Tougher
abstract: After the fall of Roe v. Wade, some clinics thought they could expand their businesses in states that still allowed them to operate. It hasn’t quite worked out that way.
lead_paragraph: Providing abortion services has always been a difficult business, with tiny-to-nonexistent profit margins and often-challenging logistical obstacles. And the Supreme Court’s decision in Dobbs v. Jackson two years ago, which eliminated the constitutional right to an abortion, has made the landscape of reproductive services even tougher.

headline: Weathering the Long Siege of Sarajevo Alone, a Painter Keeps Painting
abstract: Priscilla Morris’s novel “Black Butterflies” makes the case for art in times of war.
lead_paragraph: After receiving the prestigious Legion of Honor award from the French president Emmanuel Macron in 2023, the Albanian writer Ismail Kadare told an interviewer that literature “transformed” suffering “into a life force, a force which helped you survive and hold your head up and win out over dictatorship.”

headline: The Next Stop for Denver Campus Protesters Is the Democratic Convention
abstract: Students in Denver behind one of the longest-running encampments in protest of the Israel-Hamas war disbanded the camp in May. They spent the rest of the summer planning for what comes next.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks into their pro-Palestinian encampment, student protesters gathered in the People’s Living Room, a communal space they had erected on a public college campus in Denver, Colo., to make a decision about the future of their movement.

headline: ‘There Is No Childhood in Gaza’
abstract: A 9-year-old Palestinian boy lost his mother, father and two siblings in an Israeli airstrike early in the Gaza war. Within months, he, too, was killed.
lead_paragraph: The war in Gaza had barely begun when 9-year-old Khaled Joudeh suffered an unimaginable loss. His mother, father, older brother and baby sister, along with dozens of other relatives, were all killed in an Israeli airstrike on their home.

headline: Deploying on U.S. Soil: How Trump Would Use Soldiers Against Riots, Crime and Migrants
abstract: The former president’s vision of using the military to enforce the law domestically would carry profound implications for civil liberties.
lead_paragraph: During the turbulent summer of 2020, President Donald J. Trump raged at his military and legal advisers, calling them “losers” for objecting to his idea of using federal troops to suppress outbreaks of violence during the nationwide protests over the police murder of George Floyd.

headline: What to Know About Non-Alcoholic Beverages
abstract: Sales of NA beer, wine and spirits are soaring. What’s in them and how healthy are they?
lead_paragraph: Nonalcoholic beverages used to be the butt of jokes. Now, they’re the fastest-growing sector of the alcohol market. Sales of nonalcoholic beer, wine and liquor increased by 32 percent from 2022 to 2023, while total alcohol sales grew by just 1 percent. As of early 2024, the top-selling beer at Whole Foods was nonalcoholic.

headline: As the Convention Nears, Chicagoans Wonder: Will It Be a Nuisance or a Party?
abstract: About 50,000 people are expected in the nation’s third-largest city for the Democrats’ convention. Some Chicagoans are thrilled. Others are skipping town.
lead_paragraph: Workers rushed around in the shadow of the hulking United Center on Chicago’s Near West Side this week, planting flowers, spreading mulch, erecting tents and hoisting metal barricades.

headline: With Purple Gold and Bouncy Metal, a Canadian Chemist Shines on YouTube
abstract: Disillusioned with grad school, Nigel Braun dropped out to film chemistry videos in his parents’ garage in Montreal. Then millions began viewing his whimsical and occasionally dangerous experiments.
lead_paragraph: While he can’t turn water into wine, Nigel Braun is making vodka out of thin air.

headline: She Was a Pioneering but Forgotten Musician. Now She’s a Literary Hero.
abstract: In her debut novel, “ The Instrumentalist,” Harriet Constable paints a vivid and nuanced portrait of the groundbreaking 18th-century violinist and conductor Anna Maria della Pietà.
lead_paragraph: Though plenty of talented women have performed and composed music in Europe over the last several centuries, few are enshrined in the classical canon. Why have their names and works disappeared from history?

headline: The Spy America Left to Rot
abstract: In “Prisoner of Lies,” Barry Werth tells the story of a young C.I.A. operative who spent two decades waiting out the postwar era in a Chinese jail cell.
lead_paragraph: At the height of the Cold War, C.I.A. pilots carried a silver dollar attached to a poison-tipped stickpin. Their handlers encouraged them, if their planes went down, to use the pin on themselves to avoid betraying their country.

headline: All the ‘Alien’ Movies, Ranked
abstract: With “Alien: Romulus” hitting theaters, the 45-year-old series is getting a new jolt of life. How does the latest film stack up against its predecessors?
lead_paragraph: Just like the space creature it’s named after, the 45-year-old “Alien” franchise has proved hard to kill: Every time you think the series has been dealt a death blow by a disappointing installment, a new movie rolls around, rekindling fans’ hopes. Following that pattern, here comes “Alien: Romulus” in theaters, seven years after “Alien: Covenant.”

headline: Awkwafina Is Taking John Cena’s Advice
abstract: They are co-stars in the new film “Jackpot!” with Simu Liu.
lead_paragraph: When Awkwafina started training for Paul Feig’s action-comedy “Jackpot!” — about the winner of a dystopian California lottery — her co-star, the professional wrestler John Cena, had some advice.

headline: How Tau Lewis Channels the Spirit World
abstract: Her first solo museum exhibition, at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston, is full of towering, mysterious beings. The exhibit is “all grief work,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Tau Lewis can trace where she found every remnant of old clothing and leather, rusted piece of metal, beached starfish and myriad other well-worn items that she collects and reassembles into monumental sculptures, often evoking fantastical otherworldly beings.

headline: The Best Way to Save Money Cooking for One? Think Like a Co-op.
abstract: Shopping in bulk with a friend or neighbor can reduce costs while strengthening relationships.
lead_paragraph: About a decade ago, Angelika Zamfirescu couldn’t get her favorite coffee beans from her local C.S.A. in Astoria, Queens. Her neighbor, she learned, had the same frustration. So the two women joined with other friends and neighbors to order in bulk directly from the roaster. Their 10-pound orders continued for at least two years.

headline: When Can You Alter a Landmark Building (and When Can’t You)?
abstract: Special features, such as windows with curved glass, may be difficult to replace. Repair or retrofitting might be the better option.
lead_paragraph: Q: I recently purchased a one-bedroom apartment in a landmark 1888 townhouse on the Upper West Side for $800,000. There are three large original windows with curved glass panes on the landmark facade that I’d like to replace for energy efficiency and sound insulation. The Landmarks Preservation Commission requires these windows to be replaced with identical materials, and the quote I got for the replacement is $177,700! I cannot afford this. Is there a way to ask for a variance so these windows can be replaced with more efficient and affordable materials?

headline: Assessing Trump’s and Harris’s Attacks on Each Other
abstract: We examine the two candidates’ criticisms of each other’s policies, promises and records.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks since Vice President Kamala Harris ascended to the top of the Democratic ticket, she and former President Donald J. Trump have each sought to portray the other as extreme and unfit for office.

headline: As California Clears Homeless Camps, Two Projects Point a Way Forward
abstract: While L.A. County grapples with homelessness, elegant new housing projects in Long Beach and Venice signal the solutions — and challenges — ahead.
lead_paragraph: Outside, it is a colorful five-story mix of puzzle-block shapes, raised on stilts, with a jagged roofline and gabled breezeway playing off the single-family houses behind it. Painted patches of green, rose and blue piping sing in the Southern California sun.

headline: They’re Putting Some Fun in Funerals
abstract: Modern, even hip, mortuaries around the world are hoping to answer one question: How do we commemorate death in 2024?
lead_paragraph: In the affluent neighborhood of Crouch End in London, a new business is attracting some attention. The storefront’s blue-and-white facade is airy and minimalist. Three polka-dot vases on plinths sit in the window. To the casual observer, the space might look like an art gallery. But through the window is something a little more curious: a sea-foam-green box measuring 7 feet by 2 feet.

headline: My Wild Night With Edna O’Brien
abstract: On the trail of Ralph Fiennes in 1990s Manhattan, the esteemed novelist pays a visit to a burlesque club.
lead_paragraph: I was terrified the first time I had to pick up the phone to call Edna O’Brien at her house in London. I pictured a grande dame in a Georgian manse.

headline: The Painkiller Used for Just About Anything
abstract: In huge numbers, older people are taking gabapentin for a variety of conditions, including itching, alcohol dependence and sciatica. “It’s crazy,” one expert said.
lead_paragraph: Mary Peart, 67, a retired nurse in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass., began taking gabapentin a year and a half ago to reduce the pain and fatigue of fibromyalgia. The drug helps her climb stairs, walk her dog and take art lessons, she said.

headline: An Earthling With an Extraterrestrial Pen Pal Imagines a Cooler World
abstract: “The systems we’ve learned to depend on are harming us and our planet — but what an opportunity for great change this can be!”

headline: The Confidants Guiding Harris for the Most Important Days of Her Life
abstract: The vice president’s brain trust is younger, more racially diverse and larger than President Biden’s. Her advisers can expect a lot of phone calls in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: Her revamped presidential campaign has quickly added loyalists from her 2019 primary bid. Her former aides have returned to write a convention speech and see her through a debate against Donald J. Trump. Her sister flew to Washington, joining her as she made a pork roast and marinated over her choices for a running mate.

headline: Stranded in Space? NASA Doesn’t See the Starliner Astronauts That Way.
abstract: NASA doesn’t say the Boeing Starliner astronauts are ‘stranded’ on the space station, but it’s a word that a lot of people are using.
lead_paragraph: If you go somewhere expecting an eight-day trip and end up not being able to leave for eight months, most people would consider that “stranded.”

headline: Alex Karp Has Money and Power. So What Does He Want?
abstract: In a rare in-depth interview, this billionaire man of mystery, the head of Palantir Technologies, talks about war, A.I. and America’s future.
lead_paragraph: Alex Karp never learned to drive.

headline: Fact-Checking Harris and Trump
abstract: Linda Qiu, a New York Times reporter who fact-checks statements made by politicians and public figures, looks at how Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump have attacked each other and assesses whether those claims are true or not.
lead_paragraph: Linda Qiu, a New York Times reporter who fact-checks statements made by politicians and public figures, looks at how Vice President Kamala Harris and former President Donald Trump have attacked each other and assesses whether those claims are true or not.

headline: 45 Years of ‘Alien’ Movies From Worst to Best:
abstract: This xenomorph, like the franchise, is “hard to kill.”
lead_paragraph: Elisabeth Vincentelli, a contributing writer for The New York Times, first fell in love with the “Alien” franchise when she was “way too young.” Since then she has seen all of the movies in the series, at least twice, and can’t wait for more. Today she ranks all seven of the “Alien” films.

headline: Harris Gains in Sun Belt as Demographic Patterns Start to Look ‘Normal’
abstract: Gains among Black, Hispanic and young voters lift her into a tie across four swing states, new Times/Siena polls show.
lead_paragraph: With Kamala Harris as the Democratic nominee, the presidential race is returning to “normal.”

headline: Harris Puts Four Sun Belt States Back in Play, Times/Siena Polls Find
abstract: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are in close races across Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and North Carolina, crucial swing states that Mr. Trump had seemed en route to run away with just a few weeks ago.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris has stormed into contention in the fast-growing and diverse states of Arizona, Georgia, Nevada and North Carolina, not long after Donald J. Trump had seemed on the verge of running away with those states when President Biden was still the Democratic nominee.

headline: Sausage Legs and Wax Nose Jobs: Peeling the Layers on a Century of Beauty
abstract: In “All the Rage,” the social historian Virginia Nicholson discusses the changing standards that bedeviled and enthralled a century of women.
lead_paragraph: Paraffin nose jobs. Blinding mascara. “Bicycle face” (think the “Ozempic face” of 1910). As chronicled in Virginia Nicholson‘s “All the Rage: Stories From the Frontline of Beauty,” there’s not much women haven’t done to conform with the aesthetic standards of their day.

headline: Kamala Harris and the Return of ‘Tough on Crime’
abstract: Over her career, her rhetoric has tracked the national mood. So do Americans now want a prosecutor-in-chief?
lead_paragraph: When Kamala Harris published her first book in 2009, recounting her experience as a California prosecutor, she called it “Smart on Crime.” That phrase would come to signal a kinder, gentler approach, but that is not how Ms. Harris meant it. She meant, the book’s marketing copy proclaimed, “making the criminal justice system truly — not just rhetorically — tough.”

headline: Jelly Roll Cannot Believe How His Life Turned Out
abstract: From jail and addiction to music stardom, the singer says he’s living a “modern American fairy tale.”
lead_paragraph: We’ve all had the experience of being in a bad emotional place and, in response, putting on a song. We know that song isn’t going to fix the problem, whatever it may be, or even change the feeling. But the music we turn to when we’re struggling can be like a hand on our shoulder. For a legion of Americans today, the music that does that is by Jelly Roll.

headline: Ukraine Destroys Key Russian Bridge as It Presses On With Offensive
abstract: The bridge’s destruction is a setback for Russian supply lines as Ukraine seeks to consolidate its territorial gains in the Kursk region of western Russia.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has destroyed a critical bridge and appears to have targeted at least one more in Russia’s western Kursk region as it tries to sever Russian supply lines and consolidate its territorial gains, a dozen days into its startling cross-border offensive.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 434
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Aug. 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,156
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: A New National Park That Rests on Indigenous and Industrial History
abstract: The collapse of a steel mill project during the Great Depression preserved natural lands linked to First Nations people in Windsor, Ontario.
lead_paragraph: While I occasionally return to my hometown, Windsor, Ontario, to do reporting for other articles, few of them have been as directly linked to my childhood as the story of Canada’s next national urban park. It was a trip that filled in some blanks from my past.

headline: The Movies of 1999
abstract: Twenty-five years ago was a landmark time for cinema, with films that captured our collective hope and paranoia about the coming millennium.
lead_paragraph: Do you remember 1999? The vibes were peculiar. On the one hand, politicians and pundits talked ceaselessly about “building a bridge to the 21st century” and entering the new millennium (even though technically it wouldn’t start till 2001). On the other hand, fear lurked around all corners, mostly thanks to new technologies. The internet was still a place you wouldn’t dare use your real name, for reasons that were never totally clear. And the much-hyped Y2K bug left a lot of us wondering if society as we knew it was about to end because of faulty computer code, or something. (I recommend the delightful documentary “Time Bomb Y2K” for reliving that weird moment.)

headline: Going Against Conventional Wisdom
abstract: Readers react to arguments by Times columnists that aim to debunk commonly accepted ideas.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Electric Grid Is a Wildfire Hazard. It Doesn’t Have to Be.
abstract: We can expect added strain on the system as weather turns more extreme and demand for electricity rises.
lead_paragraph: One year after the deadly wildfires on Maui, Hawaii, and a few weeks after Hurricane Beryl knocked out power to millions of Houston-area residents, it has become abundantly clear that our electricity grid is dangerously vulnerable.

headline: Trump Is Losing the Humor War
abstract: Admit it: Donald Trump is funny. Or, at least, he used to be. Losing his sense of humor may well lead to his losing this election.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, there’s one truth that liberals have been loath to admit: Donald Trump is funny. This aspect of his appeal prompts far less commentary than his far-right positions, his venality or his mogul’s bravado. But when you watch him at a rally, you can see he’s playing for laughs: jabbing at his opponents, doing crowd work, even being self-deprecating, sort of.

headline: The Dems Are Delighted. But a Coup Is Still a Coup.
abstract: After the bloodletting, Democrats are parading to their convention.
lead_paragraph: We head to Chicago on a wave of euphoria, exuberance, exultation, excitement and even, you might say, ecstasy.

headline: The ‘Unusual’ Strategy That Might Help Democrats Win Back the House
abstract: Long Island is an increasingly Republican stronghold, but Democrats believe they have a chance to win key House races there this year.
lead_paragraph: From the Sun Belt to the industrial Midwest, Democrats, emboldened by the Great Harris Swap of 2024, are licking their chops, sensing increased enthusiasm and bigger poll numbers for their cause.

headline: Masculinity Is on the Ballot
abstract: Has liberalism perfected a model of modern masculinity while conservative culture slouches somewhere far behind?
lead_paragraph: Amid all the joy and positivity and the big, beautiful polling surges for Kamala Harris and Tim Walz, the word has gone out: This election isn’t going to be a referendum on inflation, immigration or foreign policy anymore. It’s going to be a referendum on masculinity in America.

headline: Democrats Have a Josh Shapiro Problem
abstract: If having a “commitment” to Israel is a barrier to the Democratic presidential ticket, then it bodes ominously for future Jewish participation in Democratic Party politics.
lead_paragraph: One reason Kamala Harris is on the Democratic ticket is because of her identity. One reason Josh Shapiro isn’t on the ticket is because of his.

headline: I Knew What My Enablers Were Doing. It’s Murkier With Matthew Perry.
abstract: Sometimes the most dangerous people are the ones who tell themselves they’re actually helping.
lead_paragraph: Deep into my love affair with cocaine, I sat in the living room of a neighbor’s house with several other people, waiting for the mirror with the coveted white lines on it to come my way. It’s why we were all there — to buy coke and get high during the transaction. The woman sitting nearest to me yelped in pain as she snorted the lines through a white plastic straw. She explained that she’d burned a hole through her septum from doing coke. Then she shrugged and said something about having to get it repaired at some point.

headline: Can We Talk? The Characters in These 2 Books Can, and How
abstract: Evelyn Waugh’s garrulous embalmers; Deborah Eisenberg’s urban neurotics.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: The Democratic Party’s Money Machine
abstract: The Democratic National Committee is again raising huge sums from donors, but the rise of super PACs has forced it to adapt to a new era of big-money influence.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention starts on Monday in Chicago, capping an extraordinary few weeks since Vice President Kamala Harris became the party’s presidential candidate.

headline: How to Watch Kamala Harris’s Speech at the Democratic Convention
abstract: The vice president will close out the convention on Thursday, after four days of high-profile appearances by politicians, actors and activists.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention is underway in Chicago, about a month after Republicans held their convention in Milwaukee. The convention runs through Thursday, when Vice President Kamala Harris is expected to take the stage during prime time.

headline: Biden’s Goodbye to Politics Will Begin in Earnest With His Convention Speech
abstract: It will be a bittersweet moment for the president, who left the race and turned the keys of his campaign over to Vice President Kamala Harris less than a month ago.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s goodbye to a half century in national politics will begin in earnest on Monday.

headline: During Ukraine’s Incursion, Russian Conscripts Recount Surrendering in Droves
abstract: More than 300 have been processed in a prison in Ukraine, providing the country with a much-needed “exchange fund” for future swaps of prisoners of war.
lead_paragraph: They were lanky and fresh-faced, and the battle they lost had been their first.

headline: The Times Newsroom Goes to the Democratic National Convention
abstract: Lisa Lerer, a New York Times politics reporter, will cover the D.N.C. with a host of colleagues, building a makeshift office at the event in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Next week in Chicago, the Democratic National Convention will cap off a few tumultuous weeks for the Democratic Party: President Biden dropped out of the race. Vice President Kamala Harris secured the nomination and soon selected her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, in one of the fastest vetting processes in modern history.

headline: A Project That Celebrates Collaboration and Cooperation
abstract: For T Magazine, Kate Guadagnino set out to identify the many people involved in creating a single object or artistic work, including a luxury handbag, a performance piece, a pizza and more.
lead_paragraph: The price tag on a particular Bottega Veneta leather bag is eye-popping: $15,000.

headline: Rick Martínez’s Tostadas Are a Treat
abstract: One reader said, “This was one of the most delicious recipes we’ve ever made.”
lead_paragraph: The other day my pal Eric Kim asked me how I unwind after work. A bike ride, knitting, maybe a yoga class, I replied. A glass of wine for me, a squeaky toy for the dog. I didn’t say what immediately came to mind because it felt too goody-two-shoes, and that is: cooking.

headline: Images of History, From Film to Digital
abstract: The reporter and photographer David Gonzalez once had to ship his film rolls to The Times’s Manhattan office. But in 1999, he went digital.
lead_paragraph: Two notable events in David Gonzalez’s nearly 34-year career at The New York Times occurred in 1999. He was appointed the Central America-Caribbean bureau chief, principally covering Cuba, Haiti, Guatemala, El Salvador and Panama.

headline: Harris Campaign Reserves $370 Million for Swing-State Fall Ad Blitz
abstract: $200 million of that will be spent to reach voters on their phones and other devices, as Kamala Harris’s aides race to define her while drawing a contrast with Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign announced on Saturday that it was reserving $370 million in advertising to begin after Labor Day and run through the November election, including $200 million on digital ads.

headline: Trump’s Media Blitz: Talk Radio, a Video Game Celebrity and Elon Musk
abstract: A whirl of appearances in media venues large and small have defined Donald Trump’s past four weeks, as he tries to wrest attention from his new opponent, Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s media strategy can be summed up with a phrase often applied to one of his erstwhile nemeses, the logorrheic New York City mayor Ed Koch: unavoidable for comment.

headline: George Santos Is Expected to Plead Guilty, People Close to the Case Say
abstract: Mr. Santos could change his mind, but witnesses in his campaign fraud case were told by federal prosecutors that he intends to plead guilty on Monday.
lead_paragraph: George Santos, the former Republican congressman from New York undone by a mind-bending array of biographical lies and moneymaking schemes, has told prosecutors that he intends to plead guilty and avoid a federal trial that was expected to begin next month, according to two lawyers involved in the case and two other people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Are We Ever Going to Get a Civil War Film That Tells the Truth?
abstract: A few thoughts on the movie “Gettysburg.”
lead_paragraph: This week, out of both boredom and my own impulse toward completionism — I’m slowly making my way through the many Civil War movies that have come out of Hollywood — I bought and began watching “Gettysburg,” the 1993 drama directed by Ronald F. Maxwell and adapted from “The Killer Angels,” a Pulitzer Prize-winning novel from 1974 by Michael Shaara.

headline: Harris Campaign’s Legal Team Takes Shape as Election Battles Heat Up
abstract: The campaign is adding Marc Elias, one of the party’s top election lawyers, to help Democrats counter what they expect to be a contentious postelection period.
lead_paragraph: Amid threats of certification battles and mass voter challenges, Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign has assembled an expansive senior legal team that will oversee hundreds of lawyers and thousands of volunteers in a sprawling operation designed to be a bulwark against what Democrats expect to be an aggressive Republican effort to challenge voters, rules and, possibly, the results of the 2024 election.

headline: Leonard Hayflick, Who Discovered Why No One Lives Forever, Dies at 96
abstract: A biomedical researcher, he found that normal cells can divide only a certain number of times before they age — which, he said, explained aging on a cellular level.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Hayflick, a biomedical researcher who discovered that normal cells can divide only a certain number of times — setting a limit on the human life span and frustrating would-be-immortalists everywhere — died on Aug. 1 at his home in Sea Ranch, Calif. He was 96.

headline: Perry Kurtz, Comedian Who Appeared on ‘America’s Got Talent,’ Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Kurtz, who was killed in a hit-and-run on Thursday, honed his routine over decades and eventually became a recognizable face at comedy institutions.
lead_paragraph: Perry Kurtz, who worked stand-up comedy circuits for decades and appeared on “America’s Got Talent” and “The Late Late Show With James Corden,” died on Thursday night in a hit-and-run in Los Angeles. He was 73.

headline: Gate at Joint Base San Antonio Is Site of Two Shootings, Officials Say
abstract: Separate episodes of gunfire happened hours apart early on Saturday at a gate to the military installation. A motive was unclear, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A gate at Joint Base San Antonio came under fire in separate shootings hours apart early on Saturday morning in what officials said appeared to be random acts that prompted base security personnel to return fire in the second episode.

headline: For Your Amusement
abstract: Rebecca Goldstein and Will Nediger’s puzzle takes us along for the ride.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Another Outer Banks Home Collapses Into Ocean, a Stark Reminder of Climate Change
abstract: In Rodanthe, N.C., seven homes have been lost to the ocean in the last four years, as rising sea levels erode shorelines and put more buildings at risk.
lead_paragraph: In the community of Rodanthe on the Outer Banks of North Carolina, residents witnessed on Friday an event that was not new and is unfortunately becoming more frequent: A house on the picturesque shoreline collapsed into the ocean.

headline: ‘Definitely Confused’: New Real Estate Rules Sow Uncertainty
abstract: Changes in how real estate commissions are advertised and paid went into effect this weekend. Buyers and even some agents aren’t sure what they mean.
lead_paragraph: An hour before the open house on Saturday afternoon, a real estate agent paced across the dark bamboo floors, straightening the throw blanket, fluffing the pillows and lighting a scented candle.

headline: Willie Brown to Donald Trump: Mention My Name Again and Get Sued
abstract: The former president has falsely claimed that he nearly died in a helicopter ride with Mr. Brown, and that Mr. Brown said “terrible things” about Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Willie Brown, the former mayor of San Francisco, had a message for former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday afternoon: Keep my name out of your mouth or get sued.

headline: Urged to Focus on the Economy, Trump Leans Into Attacks on Harris
abstract: At a rally in Pennsylvania, former President Donald J. Trump vacillated between criticisms of the economy and immigration and personal attacks on Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump in a campaign speech on Saturday bounced among complaints about the economy and immigration, wide-ranging digressions and a number of personal attacks on Vice President Kamala Harris, including jabs at her appearance and her laugh.

headline: A Family Flees and a Mother Mourns After Israeli Settlers Attack a Palestinian Village
abstract: Residents of the village in the Israeli-occupied West Bank say one Palestinian man was killed by rampaging settlers. Israel’s military confirmed the village was attacked.
lead_paragraph: They came into the village just past sundown, dozens of Israeli settlers wearing masks, dressed in dark clothes and armed with rocks, Kalashnikovs and M-16s, witnesses said.

headline: The Office Assassin
abstract: What should I do about a friend who deliberately undermined one of her colleagues and then bragged to me about it?
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: Trump Turned the Democratic Party Into a Pitiless Machine
abstract: The former president’s victory made it ruthlessly pragmatic.
lead_paragraph: “Many of the same politicians who now publicly embrace Trump privately dread him,” Nikki Haley said in February. “They know what a disaster he’s been and will continue to be for our party. They’re just too afraid to say it out loud. Well, I’m not afraid to say the hard truth out loud. I feel no need to kiss the ring.”

headline: Joe Manchin Has Some Unsolicited Advice for Kamala Harris and the Democrats
abstract: The senator from West Virginia assesses the Democratic Party and its path to victory in November.
lead_paragraph: “I didn’t like being a senator,” Joe Manchin told me last week — quite the statement from arguably the most influential senator of the Joe Biden-Kamala Harris era. But he’s also been the most divisive member of the Senate Democratic caucus: too conservative for the left on party priorities like abortion, climate change and voting rights and too unyielding on the filibuster. Now he’s had enough. He left the party in May to become an independent, and he’s leaving the Senate in January.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Lafayette Bids Adieu Again, 200 Years After Farewell Tour
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Kids my age loved Batman and Superman. I loved Napoleon.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 18, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Aug. 4 about the history of teen beauty trends misstated the nationality of the founder of Tinkerbell Cosmetics. He was American, not British.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘We Were Sitting on a Bench Resting Our Tired Legs Late in the Day’
abstract: A guide’s advice at the Met, giving up a good parking spot and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How the Israel-Hamas War Could Shape the New York City Mayoral Race
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams is a strong supporter of Israel. One of his primary opponents, Brad Lander, the comptroller, calls himself a “progressive Zionist.”
lead_paragraph: The Israel-Hamas war has divided Democrats across the nation, particularly in New York City, which has the largest Jewish population outside of Israel.

headline: A Vice Presidential Learning Curve: How Kamala Harris Picked Her Shots
abstract: As President Biden’s understudy, Ms. Harris did not often get to lead on signature issues. But she found roles to play on abortion rights, gun safety and a Supreme Court appointment.
lead_paragraph: When a draft of a blockbuster Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade leaked in 2022, Vice President Kamala Harris met with Ron Klain, then the White House chief of staff, in her West Wing office. He had an idea: She should lead a new task force on abortion rights.

headline: The Hotelification of Offices, With Signature Scents and Saltwater Spas
abstract: Hoping to lure workers back to their desks, companies are designing “work resorts,” luxe spaces meant to compete with the comforts and versatility of their living room.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the Springline complex in Menlo Park, Calif., are surrounded by a sense of comfort and luxury often found at high-end hotels: off-white walls with a Roman clay finish, a gray-and-white marble coffee table and a white leather bench beneath an 8-by-4 resin canvas etched with the words “Hello, tomorrow.” Springline’s signature scent — hints of salty sea air, white water lily, dry musk and honeydew melon — linger in the air.

headline: Has Power Moderated Italy’s Leader? Not to Same-Sex Parents.
abstract: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has mostly shown a pragmatic streak abroad. But at home, her government is plunging many gay families into panic.
lead_paragraph: While their curly-haired rescue dog napped on the floor, an Italian couple logged on to a late-night video call with their American surrogate, sunbathing in her garden in Oregon. The fathers-to-be cooed as she told them she was playing fairy tales close to her belly that they had recorded for their future daughter. “And she is kicking!” she said.

headline: Young Artists Rode a $712 Million Boom. Then Came the Bust.
abstract: Artists saw six-figure sales and heard promises of stardom. But with the calamitous downturn in the art market, many collectors bolted — and prices plummeted.
lead_paragraph: How did the best years of Amani Lewis’s career turn into the worst time of the artist’s life?

headline: The 47 Seconds That Saved Kamala Harris’s Political Career
abstract: Nearly 14 years ago, Kamala Harris’s opponent in the California attorney general’s race gave an answer at a little-watched debate that was frank — and fateful for the future Democratic presidential nominee.
lead_paragraph: The first thing to know about Kamala Harris’s campaign for California attorney general is that she was not necessarily favored to win.

headline: How Does a Single Water Droplet Connect People Across Centuries?
abstract: Elif Shafak’s new novel, “There Are Rivers in the Sky,” follows the same drop of water from the Tigris to the Thames, from antiquity to the 19th century to today.
lead_paragraph: However water first arrived on Earth — we still don’t really know — every drop in our bodies today is the original stuff. Water has seen it all: the rise and fall of every self-important species, every empire, every catastrophe, collapse and extinction. That water-drop perspective guides the premise of “There Are Rivers in the Sky,” the engaging and melancholy new novel by Elif Shafak in which a single water molecule falls upon characters spanning centuries.

headline: For Convention Goers in Chicago, the Issue of Migrants Comes Into Full View
abstract: The crisis continues to play out on the city’s streets, reminding Democrats of a potential liability — border crossings — ahead of the election.
lead_paragraph: As tens of thousands of delegates and guests arrive for the Democratic National Convention, they will encounter a sight familiar to Chicagoans but startling to most out-of-towners: clusters of migrants from Central and South America, congregating in parks, near highway overpasses and in the Loop, where women and small children on sidewalks sell candy or plead for money with cardboard signs.

headline: Two Sisters Take On the 20th Century, With Ghosts in Tow
abstract: A new novel recalls a dark period of El Salvador’s history, as well as Hollywood’s Golden Age and the art salons of Paris.
lead_paragraph: Gina María Balibrera’s debut novel, “The Volcano Daughters,” spits fire from its very first page just as the fevered mountain of Izalco has flung brimstone for much of El Salvador’s volatile history. This is an epic story, a remarkable achievement for a writer making her first foray into the literary landscape. Balibrera demonstrates a fearlessness that is rare.

headline: Brooklyn? Bah. Manhattan? Meh. A New Book Calls the Bronx the City’s Best Borough.
abstract: Ian Frazier’s history roams far and wide, on foot and in the archives, celebrating (if not romanticizing) a perennially “in between” part of New York.
lead_paragraph: “The Bronx? No thonx,” wrote the poet Ogden Nash for The New Yorker in 1931.

headline: In JD Vance’s Backyard, Conspiracy Theories About Migrants and Voting Abound
abstract: A far-right plank on immigration that is rooted in a baseless theory has found purchase among Republicans and right-leaning independents in parts of Ohio.
lead_paragraph: Paul C. Pauley views himself as a middle-of-the-road Republican — who also just happens to believe in one of the most pernicious far-right conspiracy theories about illegal border crossings: that Democrats are bringing undocumented immigrants into the country to vote for their party.

headline: ‘The Blind Side’ Made Him Famous. But He Has a Different Story to Tell.
abstract: The football player Michael Oher believes his early life was misrepresented by the Oscar-winning movie and the book it was based on.
lead_paragraph: “That’s where Hurt Village was.” Michael Oher was pointing to the site of a now-demolished housing project where he lived with his mother, who was addicted to drugs, and, at various times, as many as seven of his 11 siblings. It was an overcast Monday afternoon in late April, and Oher, the former football player whose high school years were dramatized in the movie “The Blind Side,” was driving me on a tour through a forlorn-looking stretch of Memphis and past some of the landmarks of his childhood. “And right over there, that was a store called Chism Trail. It’s one of the places I’d steal from. Real food, not candy. Pizza, hot dogs, bologna. One time I took a ham.”

headline: How A.I. Can Help Start Small Businesses
