abstract: Entrepreneurs say use of artificial intelligence for a variety of tasks is accelerating the path to hiring and, ideally, profitability.
lead_paragraph: Sean Ammirati has been teaching a class on entrepreneurship for more than a decade.

headline: Joe Biden’s Interrupted Presidency
abstract: He sought the office nearly all his life. When he finally got there, it brought out his best — and eventually his worst.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the 11 minutes were over and President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arose from behind the Resolute Desk in the Oval Office on the evening of July 24, he and his family filed out to the Rose Garden.

headline: Venezuelans Mourn Loved Ones Killed in Protests, and Last Shreds of Democracy
abstract: The nation is in anguish as it buries its dead and enters a new era of authoritarianism.
lead_paragraph: Jeison Gabriel España left home on July 28 to vote for the first — and last — time in his brief life.

headline: Defying Crisis in Local News, The Star Tribune Expands
abstract: The newspaper in Minneapolis is expanding its statewide coverage and changing its name to The Minnesota Star Tribune.
lead_paragraph: Many metropolitan newspapers across the country have narrowed their ambitions in recent years, closing regional bureaus and cutting back statewide coverage in an effort to trim costs.

headline: ‘Bad Blood’ Stalks a Lithium Mine in Serbia
abstract: A Rio Tinto mine that Europe sees as a critical source for electric vehicle batteries has been the target of enormous protests. “I don’t need green cars. I need green apples and green grass,” said one opponent.
lead_paragraph: Their windows broken and roofs smashed, the abandoned homes in an otherwise bucolic valley carpeted with cornfields and orchards near Serbia’s border with Bosnia look like the wreckage of the Balkan wars of the 1990s.

headline: A City of Blaring Sirens Fills With Russians Who Fled Ukraine’s Advance
abstract: In the regional capital, those who left their homes as Ukrainian forces tore into western Russia are uncertain whether they can ever return to their old lives.
lead_paragraph: In the Russian city of Kursk, several dozen miles from the heart of the fighting, Ukraine’s surprise thrust into Russia is not visible even as smoke on the horizon. But the scars of its impact are impossible to miss.

headline: Elaine Welteroth’s Belly Chain
abstract: The former editor in chief of Teen Vogue and founder of the organization birthFund wears custom jewelry to celebrate her growing family.
lead_paragraph: Elaine Welteroth is still getting used to her custom belly chain, a commemoration of her second pregnancy and growing family.

headline: Six Takeaways From the Magazine’s Profile of Joe Biden
abstract: His decision to quit the race ended a remarkable chapter in American political history — and started one that may yet define his legacy.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden dreamed of one day becoming president nearly all his life. By the time he did, he was the oldest ever to hold the office. The Biden presidency became that of a man racing the clock of his own mortal frailty. Here’s what to know about Biden’s journey to and through the presidency — and his attempts to lay the groundwork for Kamala Harris:

headline: JB Pritzker Is Ready to Party at a Convention He Made Happen
abstract: An unusual and chaotic set of political circumstances forced Illinois’s billionaire governor to take the lead in securing the Democratic convention for Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The request for a bid for the Democratic National Convention had been sitting unanswered in the office of Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago for two to three weeks in the summer of 2021 when Anne Caprara, the chief of staff to Gov. JB Pritzker of Illinois, burst into the governor’s office with a Politico article saying Chicago was being courted.

headline: ‘Alien: Romulus’ Solidifies Disney’s Box Office Rebound
abstract: After struggling in recent years, Hollywood’s biggest movie company has now delivered four hits in a row, dominating the summer with a 42 percent market share.
lead_paragraph: “Alien: Romulus” was on pace to collect at least $42 million at theaters in the United States and Canada over the weekend, a strong total that solidified a turnaround at Disney’s movie division.

headline: Alain Delon, Smoldering French Film Star, Dies at 88
abstract: The César-winning actor was an international favorite in the 1960s and ’70s, often sought after by the era’s great auteurs.
lead_paragraph: Alain Delon, the intense and intensely handsome French actor who, working with some of Europe’s most revered 20th-century directors, played cold Corsican gangsters as convincingly as hot Italian lovers, died on Sunday. He was 88.

headline: Blinken Travels to Israel Amid Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu cautioned that the negotiations were “very complex,” as the secretary of state flew to Israel to try to clinch a deal.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken arrived in Israel on Sunday to try to clinch a deal that could end the war in Gaza, even as the Middle East remained on edge amid the looming threat of wider regional conflict.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,157
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Harris Can Change Biden’s Policy on Israel Just by Upholding the Law
abstract: The longstanding Leahy law can — and should — change Middle East policy.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris is in a bind. Despite rallying Democrats behind her, she’s still being heckled by protesters who want to end U.S. support for Israel’s war in Gaza. Many of those activists want her to endorse an arms embargo against the Jewish state. Her chief foreign policy adviser, Phil Gordon, has ruled that out. But a flat refusal risks alienating progressives in key states like Michigan and sparking an ugly confrontation at this week’s Democratic convention.

headline: Jim Foley’s Legacy Helped Change Hostage Policy
abstract: Americans held captive overseas deserve all of our help.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago Monday, my son, the journalist James Foley, was brutally murdered by ISIS in Syria.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 435
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Aug. 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Colleges Can’t Say They Weren’t Warned
abstract: Three new court rulings make it clear that chaos on campus has legal consequences.
lead_paragraph: “In the year 2024, in the United States of America, in the State of California, in the City of Los Angeles, Jewish students were excluded from portions of the U.C.L.A. campus because they refused to denounce their faith.” Those are the first words of an angry court opinion by Mark Scarsi, a Federal District Court judge in California.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Man Who Couldn’t Stop Going to College’
abstract: Benjamin B. Bolger has spent his whole life amassing academic degrees. What can we learn from him?
lead_paragraph: Benjamin B. Bolger has been to Harvard and Stanford and Yale. He has been to Columbia and Dartmouth and Oxford, and Cambridge, Brandeis and Brown. Over all, Bolger has 14 advanced degrees, plus an associate’s and a bachelor’s.

headline: Black Caviar, Champion Racehorse and Australian Icon, Dies
abstract: She won every race she ran, and her fame went beyond the insular world of horse racing.
lead_paragraph: She transcended racing to become a household name in Australia and revived, for a time, a sport in decline. At the height of her career, she graced the cover of Vogue, met Queen Elizabeth II and had her own line of shampoo and conditioner.

headline: A Sharp Downturn in the Art Market
abstract: We explore how a slowdown is affecting a rising generation of artists.
lead_paragraph: As art became a serious business over the last few decades, with record multimillion-dollar sales eclipsing one another, it seemed as though values could just rise in perpetuity. But this year has been a reality check.

headline: Premier League Preview: Here We Go Again
abstract: The European soccer season is back. Here are the top story lines to watch this season.
lead_paragraph: You will, in all likelihood, have heard the sentence already. You will certainly hear it on Friday, at least once, and then over and over again on Saturday and Sunday, delivered by every pearly toothed host and every red-faced pundit and every eager-voiced commentator. The Premier League, they will say, is back.

headline: Europe’s Crackdown on Environmental Dissent Is Silencing Voices the World Needs to Hear
abstract: The tough approach has come as more Europeans sour on the green energy transition.
lead_paragraph: A British court last month issued extraordinarily harsh prison sentences to five climate activists convicted of helping to plan a series of road blockades in London. One of the activists, Roger Hallam, 58, a co-founder of the direct action groups Just Stop Oil and Extinction Rebellion, got five years. The others were each sentenced to four years.

headline: Protesters Are Converging on Chicago. City Leaders Say They’re Prepared.
abstract: Activists are pushing for policy changes on Gaza as Democrats hold their convention. Chicago officials are confident they will avoid a repeat of the chaos that unfolded in 1968.
lead_paragraph: As delegates arrived in Chicago on Sunday night ahead of the Democratic National Convention, protesters gathered along Michigan Avenue. On Monday, as the political show begins inside the United Center, demonstrators say they will gather by the thousands outside.

headline: Marcella Hazan’s Five-Star, 12,000-Review Tomato Sauce
abstract: Its luscious simplicity is the draw: All you need are canned tomatoes, an onion cut in half, butter, salt and time.
lead_paragraph: Hi. Sam’s summering somewhere on an island in the Atlantic. I’m summering here at my desk, where the food news never stops.

headline: 3 More Victims of 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre Found With Gunshot Wounds
abstract: Officials are exhuming bodies to learn more about the victims of one of the worst racial attacks in U.S. history.
lead_paragraph: Three victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre, whose remains were exhumed along with those of eight others, were found to have gunshot wounds, investigators announced on Friday, in the latest findings from research about one of the worst racial attacks in U.S. history.

headline: Where to Stream the Films of Alain Delon
abstract: A look at 10 standout films featuring the actor, who died on Sunday at 88.
lead_paragraph: Most reviews of the films Alain Delon made at his 1960s and ’70s peak mention either his beauty or his inscrutability. Very often they bring up both.

headline: Statue of John Lewis Replaces a Confederate Memorial in Georgia
abstract: The 12-foot-tall bronze statue of the civil rights leader was commissioned after Mr. Lewis died in 2020. It stands where a Confederate memorial was erected in 1908.
lead_paragraph: A statue of John Lewis, the civil rights leader and congressman, was installed on Friday in front of a Georgia county courthouse in a space occupied for more than 100 years by a Confederate memorial.

headline: To Undecided Voters, Harris Is Famous, but Unknown. They Want to Learn More.
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris has lit a fire among loyal Democrats. But many voters still want to know more about what she stands for.
lead_paragraph: Teri York-Singleton is certain about one thing as she considers the November election: She will not vote for Donald J. Trump.

headline: Elon Musk Closes X Office in Brazil Over Fight With Judge
abstract: The billionaire said he would shutter his social network’s Brazil operations instead of complying with a Brazilian judge’s orders to suspend accounts.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk said he closed the Brazilian office of his social network X on Saturday because a Brazilian Supreme Court judge ordered the company to suspend certain accounts or face the arrest of its legal representative in Brazil.

headline: Monday Briefing: The Democratic National Convention
abstract: Plus, the dark side of Shen Yun
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 80 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: Vance Defends Unsubstantiated Claims About Immigration and Crime
abstract: Citing the movie “Gangs of New York,” JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, said that immigration would create “ethnic enclaves” that spur violence and crime.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, on Friday defended his past unsubstantiated claims about immigration in which he suggested that early waves of Italian, Irish and German immigration led to higher crime and interethnic conflict, by citing the movie “Gangs of New York.”

headline: Hurricane Ernesto Brings High Swells and Strong Rip Currents to the East Coast
abstract: Ernesto was creating dangerous surf conditions that were expected to continue for several days, forecasters warned.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Ernesto may be far from land but the storm still threatens beachgoers on the East Coast of the United States with dangerous swells and rip currents, the National Hurricane Center warned on Sunday.

headline: Hoops Player
abstract: What does Kenneth Cortes look for in a good crossword? Location, location, location.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Social Media Influencers to Speak at the Democratic Convention
abstract: While they have millions of followers on platforms like TikTok and Instagram, this week they will share the podium with the top tier of Democratic politics.
lead_paragraph: A speaking slot at a national party’s nominating convention is among the most coveted prizes in American politics, offering veteran officeholders and up-and-comers alike the chance to speak to — and be seen by — an entire nation.

headline: People Are Rescued From Cars Amid Flash Floods in Connecticut
abstract: There were no immediate reports of injuries from the flooding. The New York City area was also getting heavy rain.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rainfall in southwestern Connecticut led to mudslides, washed-out roads and flash flooding on Sunday, while thunderstorms sweeping through New York City disrupted flights and train service.

headline: Tim Walz and the Pull of Rural America
abstract: Responses to an essay about the vice-presidential candidate and rural values. Also: A rattled Trump; cancer screening; the S.S. United States; L.A. Olympic transit.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Test Your Knowledge of Chicago, the Host of the Democratic National Convention
abstract: The Democrats are arriving in Chicago, the country’s third-largest city, for their first in-person convention in eight years. Take our quiz to find out how much you know about the city.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats are arriving in Chicago, the country’s third-largest city, for their first in-person convention in eight years. Take our quiz to find out how much you know about the city.

headline: Letters! Actual Letters!
abstract: When the best — and perhaps only — way to say something is to write it down.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Democrats’ Unity Convention Has One Giant Exception: The Gaza War
abstract: Harris campaign officials and Democratic leaders have stepped up outreach to Arab and Jewish voters before the event, but large protests are still expected.
lead_paragraph: Even as feel-good displays of joy and confidence are set to dominate the Democratic National Convention this week in Chicago, one painful issue is bitterly dividing the Democratic establishment from its left flank: Israel’s war in Gaza.

headline: Harris and Walz Venture Into Less-Friendly Terrain to Court Pennsylvania Voters
abstract: The Democratic presidential ticket went to the crucial swing state on Sunday to visit areas that are competitive and somewhat more conservative.
lead_paragraph: Before their convention this week that will signal the final sprint to November, Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, headed out on a brief bus tour on Sunday to fire up voters in perhaps the most crucial battleground state in the 2024 election.

headline: Democrats Unveil Convention Platform With Familiar Themes
abstract: The party is calling for tax increases on corporations and the rich while also focusing on working families, infrastructure, climate change and abortion rights.
lead_paragraph: Democrats released their party platform on Sunday, unveiling a document that offers plenty of political comfort food for a newly energized party ahead of its convention in Chicago.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 19, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An image with an article on Friday about Mar-a-Lago, the Florida home of Donald J. Trump, becoming a center for some of the most extreme elements of the party’s MAGA wing was published in error. The photo showed Bill White, the former Democratic mayor of Houston, not the man who has visited Mar-a-Lago.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Young Artists Rode a $712 Million Boom. Then Came the Bust.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You are buying a piece of my life — a little history of me and my people.”

headline: Sparing the Horse, Brussels Warms Up to the Electric Carriage
abstract: The city’s last horse-drawn carriage operator says business is good since making the switch, placing the Belgian capital in the vanguard of a global change.
lead_paragraph: It started a number of years ago with angry remarks from tourists every now and again. But in recent years, the comments flew all of the time, with people shouting, “Shame!” at Thibault Danthine, a horse-drawn carriage operator in Brussels, as they walked by.

headline: Businesses Are Already Girding for Next Phase of the U.S.-China Trade War
abstract: Alarmed by the prospect of increased tariffs on Chinese goods if Donald Trump is elected, some American companies are stockpiling parts and delaying expansions.
lead_paragraph: If not for the trade war between the world’s two largest economies, Easy Signs would now be hiring dozens of workers at its factory in Allentown, Pa. It would be readying plans to build a second plant somewhere out West — Salt Lake City was a contender — generating another 100 jobs.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 80 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: John Aprea, ‘Godfather Part II’ and ‘Full House’ Actor, Dies at 83
abstract: He played Salvatore “Sal” Tessio in “The Godfather Part II” in 1974, and the father of a popular character on “Full House,” a sitcom.
lead_paragraph: John Aprea, an actor who played crooks in “The Godfather Part II” and other films, and later appeared briefly as the strict but loving father of a popular character on the sitcom “Full House,” died on Aug. 5 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 83.

headline: Flash Flooding Strands People in Connecticut
abstract: In Oxford, Conn., a restaurant and its parking lot flooded, trapping more than a dozen people inside until a volunteer fire department came to help.
lead_paragraph: In Oxford, Conn., a restaurant and its parking lot flooded, trapping more than a dozen people inside until a volunteer fire department came to help.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Anonymous’ and the Democratic National Convention
abstract: A new competition show airs on USA and Bravo. And Kamala Harris will be officially nominated as the party’s candidate across networks.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Aug. 19-25. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: The China Hangover Is Here
abstract: The party is over for China’s economy, and poor nations around the world are feeling the effects.
lead_paragraph: In the 2000s, former President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela bet his country’s economic future on a rising China, securing tens of billions of dollars in investments and loans-for-oil deals. It paid off at first. China voraciously consumed Venezuelan oil and financed infrastructure projects, such as a high-speed railway and power plants.

headline: Word of the Day: honorarium
abstract: This word has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word honorarium has appeared two times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 26 in The New York Times Style Magazine article “Where the Artists Are Present — and in Charge” by Jennifer Wilson:

headline: 2 Women Die as Storm Batters New York and Connecticut
abstract: Flooding took over parts of Long Island, the Bronx and Connecticut, where two women were swept away by floodwaters and later died, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Two women died after they were swept away by floodwaters as a powerful storm battered the New York City area and parts of Connecticut, where at least 100 people were evacuated, officials said on Monday.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: What Happened to the Bus Lanes New Yorkers Were Promised?
abstract: Buses are often unreliable and slow (thanks to clogged streets), but even projects to ease these problems are getting delayed. Is Mayor Eric Adams to blame?
lead_paragraph: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

headline: Harris’s Candidacy Boosts a Democrat’s Slim Chances on Long Island
abstract: Representative Nick LaLota is questioning John Avlon’s local bona fides as they battle over who is more authentically of Long Island.
lead_paragraph: Out at the exclusive East End of Long Island, John Avlon, the former CNN commentator now running for Congress, seemed quite at home.

headline: George Santos Pleads Guilty to Wire Fraud and Identity Theft
abstract: Mr. Santos, a former Republican congressman from New York, agreed to pay nearly $375,000 in restitution and faces a minimum of two years in prison.
lead_paragraph: George Santos, the disgraced former Republican congressman from New York whose penchant for lying led to one of the oddest sideshows in modern U.S. politics, pleaded guilty on Monday to wire fraud and aggravated identity theft and admitted to an array of other frauds and deceits.

headline: The Senator Warning Democrats of a Crisis Unfolding Beneath Their Noses
abstract: Chris Murphy has been trying to understand why our version of liberalism — emphasizing free markets and consumer choice — feels to many like a dead end.
lead_paragraph: In December 2022, early into what he now describes as his political journey, Senator Chris Murphy of Connecticut gave a speech warning his fellow Democrats that they were ignoring a crisis staring them in the face.

headline: A Deadly Fire Exposes the Plight of Low-Paid Migrants in Wealthy Kuwait
abstract: After the blaze killed 49 migrant workers, a government crackdown focused on building violations — bypassing deeper problems that leave migrants with low wages and unsafe housing across the oil-rich Gulf.
lead_paragraph: On a recent summer day in Kuwait, as the temperature soared above 110 degrees, four Indian migrant workers stood by the side of a road with their belongings stuffed into bags.

headline: The Mennonites Making the Amazon Their Home
abstract: Groups of Mennonites, seeking inexpensive land far from modern life, are carving out new colonies in the Amazon. They are also raising fears that they are adding to the deforestation of the vital jungle.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of living in jungle tents, the handful of Mennonite families trying to make a new home deep in the Peruvian Amazon began to despair. Wasps attacked as they tried to clear forest. Heavy rains turned the road to their camp to mud.

headline: How to Strengthen Your Happiness Muscle
abstract: Psychologists call it reward sensitivity. And simple steps can help you boost your drive to seek out positive emotions and enjoy life.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all experienced it: the urge to withdraw and duck experiences we know we’ll enjoy — even when a mood boost is what we need most. We skip the birthday party. We cancel lunch. They just don’t seem worth the effort. And then, more likely than not, we feel worse than we did before.

headline: A Modern Whodunit Set Among Social Media’s Hall of Mirrors
abstract: “Swallow the Ghost,” by Eugenie Montague, is an up-to-the-minute mystery that defies convention.
lead_paragraph: For the general public, the worst things about the website we used to call Twitter include porn, harassment and fascism. But for writers of fiction taking up the site itself as a subject, the worst might be just how tricky it is to dramatize something that is both immaterial, in the literal sense of the word, and far from immaterial, in terms of its effect on so many lives. The novelist who decides to write a novel about a fictional novelist who is writing an imaginary novel on Twitter has only compounded the problem.

headline: Her Husband Died, Then Her Mother. Northern Ireland Offered Solace.
abstract: Rosie Schaap’s new memoir, “The Slow Road North,” recalls her grief and her subsequent move out of Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: It is a phenomenon known to hospice workers, nurses and priests that the dying often take their last breath once their loved ones have stepped away — say, to get a cup of coffee, take a shower, catch a few minutes of precious sleep. (My own father died while I was out picking up a sandwich.) Some say it is because they are held fast in this world by our voices, hearing being the last lingering sense. When we leave the room, they drift away. But the effects of not being present for a loved one’s death can be devastating.

headline: I ❤️ a Hate-Watch. Don’t You?
abstract: TV shows that are expensively made yet irritating to sit through — for some reason, I can’t get enough of them. Why do so many of us watch things we think are bad?
lead_paragraph: When it premiered in 2017, I quite liked “The Bold Type,” a television series about three 20-something women working at a fictional magazine called Scarlet. Although the show could tend toward after-school special, with the characters learning important lessons about speaking your truth, facing your sexuality or getting regular gynecological examinations, its heartwarming conventions — young women living their editorial dreams in the big city — worked their magic on me.

headline: House G.O.P. Makes Impeachment Case Against Biden Without Proof of Crime
abstract: In a lengthy report released on the first day of the Democratic National Convention, Republicans used circumstantial evidence to accuse the president of corruption tied to his son’s foreign business dealings.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans on Monday formally made the case for impeaching President Biden, releasing a lengthy report accusing him of corruption and seeking to allow his family to profit off his office in connection with foreign business deals made by his son Hunter, who has been charged with felony tax crimes.

headline: ‘PST Art’ Lifts Off, as NASA Scientists Team With Artists
abstract: Sound collages and mechanical grass are being created with the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, in a collaboration to unlock creative pathways that “are just not open.”
lead_paragraph: Surveying the convoluted amalgamation of equipment in his windowless lab at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory the other day, Kevin P. Hand, a planetary scientist and astrobiologist, said he sees “a massive experiment to simulate Jupiter’s moon Europa.” But visual artists looking at the same tangle, he noted, might “see this as some sort of bizarre sculpture.”

headline: Too Young for Teeth, but Not for Steak or Corn?
abstract: A growing number of parents are skipping spoon-feeding their babies and trying “baby-led weaning” instead.
lead_paragraph: Jenny Best was determined that her firstborn son would have a positive relationship with food from his very first bite. Years earlier, as a professional ballerina, she had struggled with disordered eating, and she wanted her son to think of food as fun.

headline: What’s the Next ‘Baby Reindeer’? This Producer Might Have the Script.
abstract: Francesca Moody has put on some of the Edinburgh Fringe’s biggest breakout hits. This year, she has three shows that she’s hoping will go global.
lead_paragraph: One day in fall 2018, the British theater producer Francesca Moody was rummaging around in her bag for something to read during a train ride when she found a script she’d been meaning to look at for weeks.

headline: For Nava Mau, ‘Baby Reindeer’ Felt Private. Then It Blew Up.
abstract: Mau is up for an Emmy for her performance in the hit Netflix series, making her the first transgender person to be nominated for a limited series acting Emmy.
lead_paragraph: Voting is underway for the 76th Primetime Emmys, and this week we are talking to several first-time Emmy nominees. The awards will be presented Sept. 15 on ABC.

headline: Coal Power Defined This Minnesota Town. Can Solar Win It Over?
abstract: One of the nation’s largest coal-fueled electric plants is being replaced with thousands of acres of solar panels and a test of long-duration batteries.
lead_paragraph: The past and the future of electricity in America are perhaps most visible in a Minnesota town surrounded by potato farms and cornfields.

headline: An Insider’s Guide to the D.N.C.
abstract: Leah Daughtry, a veteran of Democratic politics and conventions, on how the party got here and what to expect in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention kicks off in Chicago today, less than a month after Democrats changed their nominee in a remarkable political shake-up. To get set for the week, “The Run-Up” talks with Leah Daughtry, an at-large member of the Democratic National Committee, the chief executive of the 2008 and 2016 Democratic National Conventions and a co-chair of the convention rules committee, an incredibly significant role this year given the nominee switch.

headline: Convention Gives Chicago’s Mayor His Biggest Platform and His Biggest Test
abstract: As his city hosts the Democrats, Mayor Brandon Johnson wants to change how the world sees Chicago. But protests bring uncertainty, and the convention carries risks.
lead_paragraph: Chicago has grown accustomed to being a political punching bag. For years, Republicans have used the city’s real problems with crime and corruption as a sort of dystopian shorthand for all that ails Democratic cities.

headline: $4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A three-story contemporary house in Santa Monica, a four-bedroom home in Mill Valley, and a floating house on a slip in the Santa Barbara Harbor.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom house was designed by leeMundwiler, an architecture studio based in Los Angeles and Switzerland. Parts of the exterior were crafted using custom-made panels of sand, and the roof is finished with recycled glass pebbles designed to reflect light and reduce heat.

headline: The Dark Side of Shen Yun
abstract: The popular Chinese dance troupe has toured all over the world. But young performers described a culture of untreated injuries and emotional manipulation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at findings from The Times’s investigation of the Shen Yun dance troupe. We’ll also see what’s in the waters off New York through the eyes of divers who look for shipwrecks and treasure.

headline: Kamala Harris Takes Her First Big Risk
abstract: A proposal on “price gouging” is stirring up quite a debate.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. How do you feel about price controls?

headline: The Godfather of French Contemporary Dance Passes the Torch
abstract: Jean-Paul Montanari’s career as the head of Montpellier Danse has been entwined with the rise of contemporary dance as a force in France.
lead_paragraph: “But is he really leaving?”

headline: When Chaos Came to Chicago: An Oral History of the 1968 Convention Riots
abstract: When Democrats met that year, the violence that erupted between protesters and the police shook the nation. Here are memories of some of the people who lived it.
lead_paragraph: It was August 1968, and Chicago was ready to combust. The Democratic National Convention had come to town, along with thousands of delegates, guests and journalists. Demonstrators arrived in the city ready for battle, protesting the United States’ involvement in the Vietnam War, which by then had killed more than 25,000 Americans. Mayor Richard J. Daley, who had seen the West Side of his city burn months earlier after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr., was determined to protect the city’s residents from more unrest — and crack down on protesters who were furious at the war, the draft and the deaths of their peers.

headline: Alan Cumming on ‘Chimp Crazy’: ‘I Really Do Understand the Deep Love’
abstract: A documentary series by a director of “Tiger King” tells a wild tale about human-chimp relationships. The actor and activist landed right in the middle.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, Alan Cumming appeared in the film “Buddy,” playing an animal handler hired by an eccentric socialite (Rene Russo) who maintained a menagerie in her Long Island home. One of his co-stars was Tonka, a male chimpanzee on the cusp of adolescence. Cumming felt a special bond with Tonka.

headline: Rachel Maddow: What Worries Me Most About Election Night
abstract: Georgia Republicans have empowered local election officials to delay certifying the vote.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 1, 1960, the far-right preacher and racist demagogue Gerald L.K. Smith sent out a fund-raising appeal, headlined with a shocking claim in red type across the top: “HOLD YOUR BREATH: KENNEDY MAY HAVE LOST.”

headline: Trekking 85 Miles With Grandpa, Scuba Diving With Grandma
abstract: With older adults staying fit longer, many are joining their grandchildren on travel adventures like wilderness hikes, bike tours and even bungee jumping.
lead_paragraph: Rick Rhoads, 80, was “training like crazy” last spring, walking six miles a day — “all hills” — to get ready for his summer vacation. Mr. Rhoads, of Orcas Island, Wash., and Lucy Erent, his 15-year-old granddaughter, who lives in Prague, were planning to trek 85 miles in eight days along Scotland’s West Highland Way.

headline: How a Far-Right Takeover of Georgia’s Election Board Could Swing the Election
abstract: The unelected body that shapes voting rules has a new conservative majority who question the state’s 2020 results. They now have new power to influence the results in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Josh McKoon, the chair of the Georgia Republican Party, boasted at the state convention in late May that he had “very good news.”

headline: Harris’s Early Campaign: Heavy on Buzz, Light on Policy
abstract: On policy, the vice president is drafting off President Biden, essentially cherry-picking the most popular parts of his agenda and betting that a younger messenger can sell them to Americans.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton ran for president in 2016, she had more than 200 distinct policy proposals. Four years ago, Joseph R. Biden Jr. had a task force write a 110-page policy document for his White House bid.

headline: On Cat Ladies, Mama Bears and ‘Momala’
abstract: “Momala” makes for a charming political biography, but it isn’t powerful enough to counter the racial fears that nonwhite motherhood stokes in the nation.
lead_paragraph: While Donald Trump hides out in Mar-a-Lago, JD Vance has spent the past few weeks taking point on the G.O.P.’s continued struggle to define Kamala Harris. The Republican vice-presidential nominee’s beef with women who don’t have children, as outlined in an interview in 2021, has resurfaced. At the time, Vance derided Harris as emblematic of “childless cat ladies” who don’t have a “direct stake” in America. He now claims this “childless cat lady” routine was sarcasm, stating that he meant only that making more babies is a good thing for this nation. That still implies that not having children is un-American. It also underscores how Trump and Vance have very few pro-family policy proposals for actual babies, as opposed to talking about imagined babies that women should be having. Vance’s ham-handed attempts to have it both ways reveal the wink-wink of today’s egregious right-wing identity politics and point to the ways that this election’s identity politics might play out through innuendo and metaphor.

headline: Survivors of Doomsday Starvation Cult Testify Against Pastor and 93 Associates
abstract: An evangelical pastor in Kenya ordered his flock to shun education and medicine and starve their children to death in order to meet Jesus, witnesses in a manslaughter trial said.
lead_paragraph: When her parents denied her food and water for eight days, the girl said that she knew she was going to die, just like her two younger siblings. For days, her parents had beaten her when they caught her sipping water or looking for food. Famished and frail, she said they dressed her in special attire worn for death.

headline: David French on the Pro-Life Case for Kamala Harris
abstract: “I’m voting against Trump precisely because I’m conservative,” the columnist says.
lead_paragraph: David French, an Opinion columnist, is an evangelical, pro-life conservative. For the first time in his life, he plans to vote for a Democratic presidential candidate: Kamala Harris.

headline: 7 Last-Minute Escapes for Labor Day Weekend
abstract: If you’re still hoping to stretch out the last days of summer, there are places in North America that are not too hot, not too crowded and not necessarily that far away.
lead_paragraph: It might sound like an impossible request: a last-minute Labor Day getaway with gorgeous weather and minimal crowds that you can squeeze into a long weekend. There are good reasons many destinations across North America won’t fit the bill. Wildfires are burning in some parts of the West, tropical disturbances are brewing in the Caribbean, the East Coast’s coastal retreats are packed, and much of the South is sweaty and oh so steamy. But if you’re still hoping to stretch out the last days of summer, there are places that are not too hot, not too crowded and not necessarily that far away.

headline: A $6 Billion Breakthrough or a Drop in the Bucket?
abstract: The government is finally negotiating drug prices.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the White House announced a milestone in health care policy. After decades of effort, and for the first time, the government successfully negotiated drug prices directly with pharmaceutical companies. For years, the fight to control health care prices, perhaps the most significant factor in health care spending, has felt like an unwinnable battle, so it’s no small feat that Medicare is finally flexing its negotiating muscles. But it’s also a drop in the bucket.

headline: 3 Women With Harrowing Pregnancy Stories Will Speak at Convention
abstract: The three women, who have been supporting the Democrats’ presidential campaign, will on Monday focus on abortion rights, a key pillar of the party’s policy goals.
lead_paragraph: Democrats on Monday evening will spotlight the stories of women placed in medical peril because of state abortion bans, part of an effort by the party to capitalize on the lasting anger over the Supreme Court’s decision in 2022 to overturn Roe v. Wade.

headline: Harris Campaign Starts a WhatsApp Channel to Target Latino Voters
abstract: More than half of U.S. Latinos are estimated to regularly use the app to send texts and make calls, but it has also been a major source of misinformation.
lead_paragraph: For the past few election cycles, the messaging app WhatsApp has been a major source of news and connection — and misinformation — for Latinos in the United States, a forum to swap memes, jokes and emojis with one another across the nation and Latin America.

headline: Ukraine Says Its Incursion Will Bring Peace. Putin’s Plans May Differ.
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky wants to hold Russian territory as leverage in future talks. In Moscow, many doubt the strategy.
lead_paragraph: In July, as he secretly readied an invasion of Russia, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine sent a very different signal in public: He wanted talks to end the war.

headline: 7-Eleven Gets Buyout Offer From Canadian Owner of Circle K
abstract: Japan’s Seven & i Holdings, which operates 85,000 stores, said it had received a bid from the Canadian convenience store chain Alimentation Couche-Tard.
lead_paragraph: A Canadian convenience store giant wants to buy the Japanese company that operates 7-Eleven in a deal that would create one of the world’s largest retail groups.

headline: At Least 1 Dead and 6 Missing After Yacht Sinks Off Sicily
abstract: Fifteen other people were rescued. Expert divers were called in to carry out search operations in the deep water. Among the missing was a British software mogul, Mike Lynch.
lead_paragraph: At least one person was killed and six others, including a British software mogul, were missing on Monday after a sailing yacht carrying 22 people sank during a violent storm off the coast of Sicily, Italian officials said.

headline: Highlights From Night 1 of the Democratic Convention
abstract: Speeches by President Biden and Hillary Clinton symbolized how Democrats are moving on from the old guard that has led their party for decades.
lead_paragraph: In a city where he was supposed to claim the mantle of the Democratic Party for the final time, at a convention where he was supposed to cement his political legacy, President Biden instead passed the torch of leadership, wiping away tears as the crowd rose to its feet in a sustained ovation and chanted, “Thank you, Joe.”

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,158
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Division at the Democratic Convention, and G.O.P. Efforts to Impeach Joe Biden
abstract: Plus, a hospital system gets into show business.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Connections Companion No. 436
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Aug. 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Story of Kamala Harris
abstract: A look back at the vice president’s career and the moments that shaped her politics.
lead_paragraph: Over the next few days at the Democratic National Convention, Vice President Kamala Harris will accept her party’s nomination and reintroduce herself to American voters.

headline: Kamala Harris’s Muscular Patriotism
abstract: In recent weeks, the vice president’s message has revolved around progressive patriotism.
lead_paragraph: At her first rally with Tim Walz, Kamala Harris delivered a riff about their quintessentially American backgrounds. She grew up in Oakland, Calif., raised by a working mother, while he grew up on the Nebraska plains, she explained. They were “two middle-class kids,” she said, now trying to make it to the White House together.

headline: What Business Wants to Learn About Harris
abstract: Heading into the Democratic National Convention, many of the vice president’s policies have yet to be explained. Corporate leaders hope that will change.
lead_paragraph: The center of the national conversation this week turns to Chicago, as the Democratic National Convention is set to kick off on Monday.

headline: Climate Groups Begin $55 Million Ad Campaign for Kamala Harris
abstract: Three of the ads frame Biden-Harris policies in terms of their economic, rather than environmental, benefits.
lead_paragraph: Several organizations focused on combating climate change joined forces on Monday for a $55 million advertising campaign in support of Vice President Kamala Harris, embracing what they describe as the economic upside of the Democratic Party’s environmental efforts.

headline: Tracking the Remnants of Gilma
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Gilma.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Gilma.

headline: Phil Donahue, Talk Host Who Made Audiences Part of the Show, Dies at 88
abstract: Stalking the aisles, microphone in hand, he turned “The Phil Donahue Show” into a participation event, soliciting questions and comments on topics from human rights to orgies.
lead_paragraph: Phil Donahue, who in the 1960s reinvented the television talk show with a democratic flourish, inviting audiences to question his guests on topics as resolutely high-minded as human rights and international relations, and as unblushingly lowbrow as male strippers and safe-sex orgies, died on Sunday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: ‘World News Tonight’ Producer Named President of ABC News
abstract: Almin Karamehmedovic, the senior executive producer of ABC’s flagship newscast with anchor David Muir, will run Disney’s news division.
lead_paragraph: ABC News said on Monday that Almin Karamehmedovic, the senior executive producer of “World News Tonight with David Muir,” is the network’s next president.

headline: Ukraine Strikes Bridges in Russia, Aiming to Entrap Troops
abstract: The attacks aim to destroy or damage crossings over a river in the Kursk region that are Russian forces’ only routes for resupply or retreat, military analysts say.
lead_paragraph: Russian troops defending a pocket of territory wedged between a river and the border with Ukraine were at risk of becoming encircled, military analysts said Monday, after Ukraine bombed bridges that are the only routes for resupply or retreat.

headline: 6 Things to Watch For at the Democratic Convention
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris has never commanded a spotlight this big. The party faces potential fractures over the war in Gaza. And Hillary Clinton’s speech will be a reminder of what might have been.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention, which opens Monday in Chicago, will be a test for the party and its new standard-bearer, Vice President Kamala Harris, who has never been so center stage. The next few days should signal how Ms. Harris intends to define her candidacy, and will help determine whether the party can remain unified despite deep divisions over issues including the war in Gaza.

headline: Prosecutors Leave Decision on Delaying Trump’s Sentencing Up to Judge
abstract: Lawyers for Donald J. Trump had asked to move his sentencing in Manhattan on 34 felony counts to after the election. In a letter, prosecutors disputed many of their arguments.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors left the politically fraught decision of when to sentence Donald J. Trump in his criminal hush-money case to a judge, declining to endorse or oppose the former president’s request to postpone until after the November election.

headline: 5 Books to Make Caregiving a Little More Manageable
abstract: Health care professionals and other experts shared recommendations for anyone providing and receiving care.
lead_paragraph: Tina Sadarangani, a geriatric nurse practitioner in New York City, has spent years working with older adults and their families. She counsels patients on the medications they should take, the eating habits they should change and the specialists they should see.

headline: This Spider Uses a Light Show to Trick Eager Male Fireflies Into Its Web
abstract: In China, the arachnids seem to somehow manipulate the flashing of a caught male firefly to resemble a female’s come-hither signal.
lead_paragraph: Imagine being a male firefly when suddenly the telltale flashing of a female catches your eye. Enthralled, you speed toward love’s embrace — only to fly headfirst into a spider’s web. That flashy female was in fact another male firefly, himself trapped in the web, and the spider may have manipulated his light beacon to lure you in.

headline: A Personalized Brain Pacemaker for Parkinson’s
abstract: In a new frontier for deep brain stimulation, researchers used A.I. to develop individualized algorithms, which helped a skateboarder and other patients with Parkinson’s disease.
lead_paragraph: When Shawn Connolly was diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease nine years ago, he was a 39-year-old daredevil on a skateboard, flipping and leaping from walls, benches and dumpsters through the streets of San Francisco. He appeared in videos and magazines, and had sponsorships from skateboard makers and shops.

headline: A Colorful, Crowd-Pleasing Zucchini Dinner
abstract: “This is an out-of-this world excellent dish! I’ve served it twice for company and all agree.”
lead_paragraph: Hi, I’m back from vacation!

headline: Warning Signs Flash in a Labor Survey as Fed Officials Watch for Weakness
abstract: The New York Fed’s labor market survey showed cracks just as Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, prepares for a closely watched Friday speech.
lead_paragraph: Americans are increasingly worried about losing their jobs, a new survey from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York released on Monday showed, a worrying sign at a moment when economists and central bankers are warily monitoring for cracks in the job market.

headline: Ruth Johnson Colvin, Champion of Literacy, Is Dead at 107
abstract: Working out of her basement, and with no teaching experience, she created a nonprofit that helped people around the world learn to read.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Johnson Colvin, who founded what became one of the world’s largest organizations of volunteers tutoring basic language skills to functionally illiterate peoples in America and other lands, opening doors to citizenship and better lives, died on Sunday at her home in Syracuse, N.Y. She was 107.

headline: What to Know About the Blue Supermoon
abstract: The celestial event, which is visible from Sunday to Wednesday morning, probably won’t happen again until 2037.
lead_paragraph: Stargazers are being treated to an astronomical show this week as an infrequent blue supermoon lights up the night sky, one of the largest and brightest full moons of the year.

headline: Biden Defends His Record and Endorses Harris: ‘America, I Gave My Best to You’
abstract: In a 52-minute speech, President Biden made the case that Vice President Kamala Harris is the best person to carry on his legacy.
lead_paragraph: President Biden used his valedictory address at the Democratic National Convention on Monday to deliver a lengthy defense of his own record aimed at cementing a 50-year legacy of public service, even as he passed the reins to Vice President Kamala Harris as the new face of the party he led until just weeks ago.

headline: A New Treatment for Severe Allergic Reactions — Without the Needle
abstract: A nasal spray can tamp down potentially fatal reactions, a boon to the many patients in crisis who fear using EpiPens.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Michael Blaiss, an allergist at the Medical College of Georgia, was often surprised by how hesitant his patients were to use their auto-injectors, syringe-like devices like the EpiPen that deliver a drug needed to head off potentially fatal allergic reactions.

headline: Carl Icahn to Pay $2 Million to Settle S.E.C. Charges
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission had accused the billionaire investor of not disclosing that he had pledged personal stock holdings as collateral for billions of dollars in loans.
lead_paragraph: The activist investor Carl C. Icahn was charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with failing to disclose that he had personally pledged his own stock as collateral for margin loans worth billions of dollars.

headline: High Food Prices: The Causes and the Politics
abstract: Readers discuss how to combat high prices. Also: The decision not to pick Josh Shapiro; preparing for campus protests; crypto’s political power.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Woman Accusing Eric Adams of Assault Wrote About It Years Ago, Filing Says
abstract: A former Transit Police Department colleague of the mayor said she told seven people years ago that he had sexually assaulted her in 1993, according to new court filings.
lead_paragraph: A woman who accused Mayor Eric Adams of sexually assaulting her in 1993 told nine people about the encounter and documented her account in emails years ago, her lawyer said in a legal filing on Monday.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Kamala Harris: Inside Their Quietly Close Bond
abstract: Mrs. Clinton, who lost out on becoming the first female president, has been a behind-the-scenes ally for the woman now vying to do so.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton was on Martha’s Vineyard on Sunday, July 21, the day President Biden dropped out of the presidential race, when her phone rang. Her husband, former President Bill Clinton, had already received a call from the same number, so she knew who wanted to talk to her.

headline: Jennifer Egan Looks Back at ‘A Visit From the Goon Squad’
abstract: The fourth in a series of conversations with authors appearing on our “Best Books of the 21st Century” list.
lead_paragraph: As part of its recent “100 Best Books of the 21st Century” project, The New York Times Book Review is interviewing some of the authors whose books appeared on the list. This week, Jennifer Egan joins host Gilbert Cruz to discuss her Pulitzer-winning novel about the music industry, “A Visit From the Goon Squad” (2010), and talks, among other things, about the early challenges it faced in finding an audience, the meaning of its title and her initial reluctance to decide whether the book was a novel or a story collection.

headline: In Nevada, Rosen Skips Convention but Hopes to Benefit From Harris’s Rise
abstract: Senator Jacky Rosen led her Republican opponent by double digits in two recent polls, but she is taking nothing for granted in her competitive and costly re-election race.
lead_paragraph: In sprawling Washoe County, the area stretching from Lake Tahoe to the Oregon border that is widely considered the most politically competitive in Nevada, a surge of enthusiasm in recent weeks has given Democrats hope that Senator Jacky Rosen, one of the party’s most vulnerable incumbents, can pull off a re-election victory.

headline: U.S. Soldier’s Remains Identified More Than 80 Years After Bataan Death March
abstract: Pvt. William E. Calkins of Oregon survived the march but died in a prison camp during World War II. His remains are set to be buried next month.
lead_paragraph: The remains of a U.S. soldier who survived the Bataan Death March during World War II but died in a prison camp have been identified and will be buried in Oregon, a Defense Department agency said last week.

headline: New York City Moves to Shut Down a Growing Migrant Encampment
abstract: Dozens of migrants have been sleeping outdoors near a large shelter complex on Randall’s Island. On Monday, the city forced them to pack up their tents and move.
lead_paragraph: New York City officials began clearing out an encampment of homeless migrants on Randall’s Island on Monday as the city contends with a growing number of migrants sleeping outside.

headline: Mother and 6 Children Are Killed in Israeli Strike in Gaza, Family Says
abstract: A Palestinian teacher and all her children were killed in a strike in Deir al-Balah that the Israeli military said had targeted “a significant Islamic Jihad terrorist.”
lead_paragraph: Hala Khattab’s home in the city of Deir al-Balah in Gaza had been full of children — six of them. There was her oldest son, Hussein, 15; her 9-year-old quadruplets, Kinan, Hamman, Lujain and Sibal; and her baby girl, Wakeen.

headline: Trump Promotes A.I. Images to Falsely Suggest Taylor Swift Endorsed Him
abstract: The former president has been preoccupied with the popularity of the pop music megastar, who endorsed Joseph R. Biden Jr. over him during the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, who has notably harbored a grudge against the pop music megastar Taylor Swift, set the internet ablaze on Sunday when he shared social media posts suggesting that she had endorsed him and that her fans could help him win the November election.

headline: How Well Do You Know Rome, and These Books Set in the City?
abstract: Try this short literary geography quiz focused on Italy’s ancient capital.
lead_paragraph: Try this short literary geography quiz focused on Italy’s ancient capital.

headline: The Midwest Takes Center Stage at the Democratic Convention
abstract: The Midwest is having a moment in American politics. Reid J. Epstein, a New York Times reporter covering politics who grew up in Illinois, discusses what that means as the Democrats begin their convention in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The Midwest is having a moment in American politics. Reid J. Epstein, a New York Times reporter covering politics who grew up in Illinois, discusses what that means as the Democrats begin their convention in Chicago.

headline: 5 Tips for Making a School Lunch Your Kid Will Actually Eat
abstract: With just a few tweaks and a smidgen of planning, you can pack lunches that come home eaten.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to making lunch for her five boys, reality and aspiration diverge for Lisa Pilcher, a finance director in Chicago. “In my head, I’m the mom who creates beautiful bento boxes with love notes to my kids,” she says. “In reality, it is an Uncrustables sandwich and a semi-moldy piece of fruit.”

headline: Michel Guérard, Who Lowered the Calories in Haute Cuisine, Dies at 91
abstract: Appalled by the food options available to those seeking to lose weight, he developed a form of nouvelle cuisine for dieters at a spa in southwestern France.
lead_paragraph: Michel Guérard, a driving force behind the 1960s culinary movement known as nouvelle cuisine and the creator of the enormously influential “slimming cuisine” at his 19th-century spa in Eugénie-les-Bains, France, died at his home there. He was 91.

headline: Philippines Reports First Mpox Case Since W.H.O. Declared Global Emergency
abstract: It was not clear if the patient had contracted the new, potentially more deadly strain of the disease, which first appeared outside of Africa in Sweden last week.
lead_paragraph: The Philippines reported its first case this year of mpox, previously known as monkeypox, on Monday, just days after the World Health Organization declared the disease a global health emergency.

headline: Trying to Recover the British Museum’s Gems, and Its Reputation
abstract: The police haven’t charged anybody over the missing artifacts, but the museum is running its own investigations to get the items back.
lead_paragraph: A year has passed since the British Museum said it had fired a curator for stealing from its supposedly lock-tight storerooms and selling the artifacts online. Ever since, the museum has struggled to deal with the fallout from the scandal, which has battered its reputation as a protector of world treasures.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Could Be Blocked From New York’s Ballot, Again
abstract: Last week, he was booted for using a fake address. This week, a suit claims that people gathering signatures for the candidate deceived voters.
lead_paragraph: A New York judge last week barred Robert F. Kennedy Jr. from appearing on the state’s November ballot, finding that the independent presidential candidate’s assertion that he had rented a bedroom in a friend’s home did not make him a New York resident as he had claimed.

headline: Harris’s Economic Plan Isn’t Perfect, but It’s Better Than Trump’s
abstract: She’s right to focus on the high cost of living, even if the details could use some tweaks.
lead_paragraph: Old joke: If you teach a parrot to say “supply” and “demand,” you’ve got yourself a fine economist. I imagined I had a parrot economist on my shoulder when I listened to Vice President Kamala Harris’s economic speech on Friday in Raleigh, N.C.

headline: Kamalanomics, Revealed: A Solid Center-Left Agenda
abstract: And no, she hasn’t called for price controls.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Vice President Kamala Harris gave her first big economic policy speech as the Democratic presidential nominee. It was, of course, very different from the “economic” speech and news conferences Donald Trump has held in the past couple of weeks.

headline: Outraged Over Gaza, Protesters Show Left-Wing Divisions as Convention Opens
abstract: A protest in Chicago on Monday, which was expected to be one of the largest of the week, drew fewer demonstrators than organizers had hoped for.
lead_paragraph: As Democrats gathered in Chicago on Monday, eager to project an image of a liberal movement fully united behind Vice President Kamala Harris, thousands of people marched a few blocks away, presenting a thorny counterpoint.

headline: Some Republicans Will Take Center Stage at the Democratic Convention
abstract: At least three Republicans will have prominent speaking roles this week, as the Harris campaign taps into opposition to Donald J. Trump from within his own party.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention is expected to feature speeches from at least three Republicans, with a Republican hosting the convention’s second night, as Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign seeks to highlight opposition to Donald J. Trump from within his own party.

headline: Hamas and Islamic Jihad Claim Responsibility for Tel Aviv Bombing
abstract: The two groups described the attack as a suicide bombing, but an Israeli statement did not. If confirmed, it would be the first suicide bombing in Israel in roughly eight years.
lead_paragraph: Hamas’s military wing and Islamic Jihad took responsibility on Monday for what they said was a suicide bombing in Tel Aviv late Sunday, and threatened further attacks because of the “continued civilian displacement and killings” of Palestinians.

headline: Here’s the Speaker Lineup for the Opening Night of the Democratic Convention
abstract: Monday’s headliners include President Biden and the first lady, Jill Biden, along with Hillary Clinton, who was defeated by Donald J. Trump in the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: Democrats have cemented the lineup of speakers for the first night of their convention in Chicago, one that blends nostalgic tributes to President Biden with blunt messaging about the threat of a second Donald J. Trump presidency.

headline: Alain Delon, Godfather of the Belted Trench
abstract: As a titan of French cinema, he dressed the part, even when playing a killer.
lead_paragraph: Alain Delon, the French film star who died on Sunday at 88, was not big on smiling.

headline: What Are Protesters’ Rights During the D.N.C.?
abstract: The boundaries of First Amendment rights and the government’s duty to maintain public order threaten to collide this week.
lead_paragraph: The First Amendment protects the right to assemble peaceably and protest, but courts have also recognized the right of the government to impose some restrictions on protests in the interest of safety and public order. Where are the boundary lines when those rights threaten to collide?

headline: Nicaragua Shutters 1,500 Nonprofit Groups, Many of Them Churches
abstract: The government of President Daniel Ortega revoked the legal status of hundreds of evangelical groups as part of its crackdown on institutions that do not bow to its authority.
lead_paragraph: The Nicaraguan government on Monday canceled the legal status of 1,500 nonprofit organizations — many of them evangelical religious groups — in the authoritarian government’s continued effort to quash people and institutions that are not allied with the government.

headline: Most Columbia Students Arrested During Protests Will Return to Campus
abstract: Some students who were arrested after setting up tents on campus or occupying a university building last spring are still on probation. Others could face consequences later this year.
lead_paragraph: Most Columbia University students who were arrested or faced discipline for participating in pro-Palestinian demonstrations will be able to return to campus this fall, according to information released Monday by a Congressional committee investigating the school’s response to antisemitism.

headline: Four Writers on Kamala Harris, Hillary Clinton and How to Win the White House
abstract: Two women seeking the White House, two historic elections: what will it take to beat Donald Trump this time?
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy: The Democratic convention will be bookended by two historic figures: Hillary Clinton, the first woman nominated for president of a major party, will speak on Monday night, and Kamala Harris on Thursday night will become the second woman nominated to lead America. Maureen, Michelle, Frank: The four of us covered Clinton over the years, and now write about Harris. Clinton and Harris are approaching history pretty differently. For one thing, Clinton leaned into gender in 2016, talking about breaking the glass ceiling. And she won a big vote from women, but her percentage of the women’s vote was a little less than Barack Obama’s — and she had a slightly wider gender gap. Maureen, how do Clinton and Harris differ in how they deal with gender?

headline: ‘Homicide’ Is One of the Best TV Shows Ever. And It Is Finally Streaming
abstract: For years, the foundational cop drama, based on the book by David Simon (“The Wire”), languished in DVD-only purgatory. No longer.
lead_paragraph: Pop the champagne, ring the bells, dance the jigs, cancel all other plans: A time of great rejoicing is here. “Homicide: Life on the Street,” one of the greatest shows in TV history, is finally streaming (on Peacock). So long we wandered in darkness, begging for its return. How we lamented its absence while the years rolled by, our cries growing louder and more sorrowful. But now at last we feast.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. Said Israel Agreed to Cease-Fire Proposal
abstract: Plus, opening night at the Democratic convention.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony Blinken said yesterday that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had accepted a “bridging proposal” aimed at closing the gap between Israel and Hamas on a cease-fire deal for Gaza.

headline: 3 Episodes That Explain Phil Donahue’s Daytime Dominance
abstract: In his very first episode, which aired locally in Dayton, Ohio, the host, who would go on to redefine such talk shows, interviewed one of the most notorious figures in America.
lead_paragraph: Phil Donahue, who died on Sunday at age 88, will long be remembered as the king of daytime television.

headline: JD Vance attacks Harris and Walz for avoiding questions and then delivers his own evasive answers.
abstract: At a campaign event in Philadelphia, Mr. Vance criticized his rivals for avoiding the news media and then deflected questions himself.
lead_paragraph: Senator JD Vance of Ohio on Monday accused Vice President Kamala Harris and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota of misleading the public about their records and taking relatively few questions on the campaign trail.

headline: The Democratic Convention Kicks Off
abstract: Plus, a push for a Gaza cease-fire. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention will open tonight in Chicago with a burst of energy and optimism, fueled by the replacement of President Biden at the top of the ticket with his vice president, Kamala Harris.

headline: Israel Accepts Proposal to Bridge Differences on Cease-Fire, Blinken Says
abstract: The statement by the secretary of state put new pressure on Hamas, whose officials have called the proposal fundamentally slanted toward Israel.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Monday that Israel had accepted a Biden administration proposal to bridge some remaining differences with Hamas on a cease-fire deal, as he pushed what he called “probably the best, maybe the last, opportunity” to secure a truce and free the remaining hostages in Gaza.

headline: Walz Family Fertility Journey Ran Not Through I.V.F. but Another Common Treatment
abstract: Unlike in vitro fertilization, the procedure used by the Walzes does not involve lab-created embryos that may be discarded, so it has not been targeted by anti-abortion leaders.
lead_paragraph: As Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota has introduced himself to Americans through stump speeches across the country in recent weeks, he has alluded to a journey through infertility for his family while warning that conservatives want to restrict in vitro fertilization.

headline: Matthew Perry’s Death Shines a Harsh Light on Ketamine Treatment
abstract: Was Mr. Perry, whose struggles with substance abuse were widely known, a good candidate for a drug used to relieve depression? Doctors say his case raises thorny questions.
lead_paragraph: The actor Matthew Perry, who had long struggled with addiction, grew intrigued by ketamine a few years ago during a stay at a rehab facility in Switzerland where he received daily infusions of the powerful anesthetic “to ease pain and help with depression.”

headline: Delaware Democrats to Their Joyous Party: ‘Et tu, Brute?’
abstract: Convention attendees from President Biden’s home state were careful to emphasize their support for Kamala Harris. But some still expressed a sense of loss.
lead_paragraph: Joyous Democrats have descended on Chicago, a city awash in Kamala Harris merchandise, memes and crowds of people eager to celebrate her White House candidacy, having long moved on from President Biden’s ill-fated run.

headline: Jason Isbell Offers Democrats a Way to Connect With a New Audience
abstract: The Southern white, working man’s musician performs at the Democratic convention and lets loose on the state of politics in an interview.
lead_paragraph: As both a musician who channels the voices of forgotten Americans, and a white man from the South with a working-class upbringing, Jason Isbell provides hope for Democrats.

headline: Yusef Salaam, of ‘Central Park 5,’ to Speak at Democratic Convention
abstract: Mr. Salaam will be joined onstage in Chicago by three other men he was wrongly convicted with and will speak about the dangers of re-electing Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Yusef Salaam, a city councilman from Harlem, was one of five Black and Latino men exonerated in the rape and assault of a white female jogger in Central Park in 1989. Former President Donald J. Trump, who is white, took out full-page advertisements in four newspapers, including The New York Times, calling for the death penalty to be reinstated because of the case.

headline: Batty Outfits, Sappy Romances: How ‘Emily in Paris’ Keeps You Coming Back for More
abstract: A Styles group chat on Season 4 of the Netflix series, with its Eurovision preparations, Claude Monet pond and cardigans included.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for “Emily in Paris” Season 4.

headline: Woman Gets 11 Years in Prison for Fatally Shooting Man She Said Trafficked Her
abstract: The Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled in 2022 that Chrystul Kizer could argue at trial that she had been justified in fatally shooting Randall Volar, through a state law that supports trafficking victims.
lead_paragraph: A Wisconsin woman who was allowed to argue that she had been justified in fatally shooting a man she said had sexually trafficked her was sentenced on Monday to 11 years in prison under a deal with prosecutors in which she pleaded guilty to a reduced charge, according to court documents.

headline: In Pennsylvania, Trump Goes After Biden and Harris
abstract: As Democrats gathered in Chicago, Mr. Trump kicked off a week of events in battleground states with a speech in which he took aim at his old opponent as much as his new one.
lead_paragraph: Hours before President Biden was expected to speak at the Democratic National Convention on Monday, former President Donald J. Trump accused Mr. Biden of being corrupt, fell back on his insistence that the court cases against him were election interference and claimed Democrats did an “overthrow or a coup” in replacing Mr. Biden atop the ticket with Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Harold Meltzer Dies at 58; Composer of Impossible-to-Pigeonhole Works
abstract: His music, which was performed by many prominent ensembles, mixed melodic themes and rich textures with the sharp-edged angularity of modernism.
lead_paragraph: Harold Meltzer, a composer who set aside a career as a lawyer to create a highly regarded body of energetic, colorful chamber, vocal and orchestral scores that mixed accessibly melodic themes and rich ensemble textures with the sharp-edged angularity of modernism, died on Aug. 12 in Manhattan. He was 58.

headline: Former Investigator Assails World Anti-Doping Agency
abstract: The agency, which has faced intense criticism for its handling of positive tests among Chinese swimmers, should be replaced by a “truly independent” organization, its former chief investigative officer said.
lead_paragraph: A former chief investigator for the World Anti-Doping Agency said on Monday that the organization was “broken beyond repair” and had misled the public following disclosure of its decision not to discipline 23 elite Chinese swimmers who tested positive three years ago for a banned drug.

headline: Iran Is to Blame for Hacking Into Trump’s Campaign, Intelligence Officials Say
abstract: American intelligence agencies also confirmed that the effort extended to the Biden-Harris campaign, though that bid was unsuccessful.
lead_paragraph: American intelligence agencies said on Monday that Iran was responsible for hacking into former President Donald J. Trump’s campaign and trying to breach the Biden-Harris campaign.

headline: Democrats Say Hi — and Bye — to President Biden
abstract: A man who spent a lifetime seeking the presidency faces his party after it forced him to step aside.
lead_paragraph: When he was campaigning for the presidency in 2020, President Biden said he would be a “bridge” to a new generation of leaders.

headline: Jury Finds Parents of Gunman Not Liable in 2018 Texas School Shooting
abstract: Jurors decided instead that blame rested with the gunman, who was 17 at the time, and the company that sold him ammunition used in the shooting.
lead_paragraph: The parents of a gunman who was 17 when he killed eight students and two teachers at his high school in Santa Fe, Texas, in 2018 are not financially liable for his heinous actions, a jury found on Monday.

headline: At the Ruhrtriennale, Searching for the Sublime Among the Ruins
abstract: In the abandoned industrial sites that serve as the festival’s venues, our critic witnessed beauty struggling to be born: fitfully, clumsily and sometimes stunningly.
lead_paragraph: “I Want Absolute Beauty,” the title of the opening production for this year’s Ruhrtriennale, sounds like a mission statement of sorts.

headline: Protesters Clash With Police Near the Democratic National Convention
abstract: Protesters critical of the war in Gaza pushed through barricades at the Democratic National Convention prompting law enforcement to step in.
lead_paragraph: Protesters critical of the war in Gaza pushed through barricades at the Democratic National Convention prompting law enforcement to step in.

headline: At Democratic Convention, Hochul Says Trump Lacks ‘New York Values’
abstract: In one of the most high-profile speeches of her career, Gov. Kathy Hochul drew a contrast between the current and former presidents, telling attendees, “If you think you’re tired of Donald Trump, talk to a New Yorker.”
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York took outsize blame for a lackluster election night in her state that helped cost Democrats control of the U.S. House of Representatives.

headline: Surrounding Glow
abstract: Sam Buchbinder shares a few of his favorite things.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Steve Kerr Cheers on Harris and Walz, a Fellow Coach
abstract: The Golden State Warriors coach, well known for his liberal views, wove plenty of sports references into his paean to the Democratic ticket. He also teased Tim Walz a bit.
lead_paragraph: Steve Kerr, the coach of the Golden State Warriors, praised Vice President Kamala Harris onstage on Monday night and urged Americans to come together to reject former President Donald J. Trump as if they were one united basketball team.

headline: Ocasio-Cortez, Once an Outsider, Takes Center Stage at Convention
abstract: In a prime-time speech, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez gave a forceful endorsement of Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Democrats allotted Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York a scant 90 seconds to speak at their convention. She used it to symbolically nominate Senator Bernie Sanders for president and never mentioned Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s name.

headline: ‘Keep Going,’ Hillary Clinton Says at Democratic National Convention
abstract: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton spoke at the Democratic National Convention and urged Democrats to help Vice President Kamala Harris become the first female president.
lead_paragraph: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton spoke at the Democratic National Convention and urged Democrats to help Vice President Kamala Harris become the first female president.

headline: Clinton Rallies Democrats Behind Harris: ‘This Is When We Break Through’
abstract: Eight years after failing to smash the “highest and hardest glass ceiling” in politics, Hillary Clinton urged her party to make Kamala Harris the nation’s first female president.
lead_paragraph: The last time Hillary Clinton appeared in person before a Democratic National Convention, the year was 2016, the city was Philadelphia and Mrs. Clinton was accepting her party’s nomination to run for president in what her audience thought would be a shoo-in of a race against Donald J. Trump.

headline: Paramount Draws a New Bid, Complicating Deal With Skydance
abstract: The offer by Edgar Bronfman Jr., the former head of Warner Music Group, comes days before a crucial deadline in the scramble to acquire control of Paramount.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Bronfman Jr., the former chief executive of Warner Music Group and the heir to the Seagram fortune, submitted a bid on Monday to gain control of Paramount, the media conglomerate that owns CBS, MTV and the movie studio behind such hits as “The Godfather” and “Mission: Impossible,” according to two people familiar with the offer who were not authorized to speak publicly.

headline: Mexico’s Judges Vote to Strike, Opposing Overhaul of Legal System
