abstract: The police faced off with pro-Palestinian protesters outside the Israeli Consulate in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The police faced off with pro-Palestinian protesters outside the Israeli Consulate in Chicago.

headline: D.N.C. Holds Enthusiastic Roll Call to Nominate Harris
abstract: Delegates from each state and territory cast votes to nominate Vice President Kamala Harris as the official standard-bearer of the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: Delegates from each state and territory cast votes to nominate Vice President Kamala Harris as the official standard-bearer of the Democratic Party.

headline: Here Is the Kamala Harris Roll Call Playlist
abstract: As each state delegation was called on, the moment was accompanied by a song.
lead_paragraph: The anthemic synths of Bruce Springsteen. The driving rhythm of Tom Petty’s guitar. The guttural screams of Lil Jon.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Braving the Wild to Rescue the Rarest of Flowers
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not that I am that daring. These situations just arise, and they are not like Superman extreme. Sometimes it’s more Peter Sellers than Indiana Jones.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 21, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 21, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about Hillary Clinton’s bond with Kamala Harris referred incorrectly to dinners hosted by the Clintons at their home in Washington. Douglas Elmendorf, the former dean at Harvard Kennedy School, says he was not in attendance.

headline: Full Transcript of Michelle Obama’s Speech at the Democratic Convention
abstract: The former first lady spoke for just over 20 minutes and told the convention that “hope is making a comeback.”
lead_paragraph: OK. We got a big night ahead. Thank you all so much. Thank you so much. OK. There you go.

headline: Barack Obama Calls for Unity in Soaring D.N.C. Speech
abstract: Former President Barack Obama blamed politicians and social media algorithms for deepening social and political divisions among Americans.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama blamed politicians and social media algorithms for deepening social and political divisions among Americans.

headline: Word of the Day: prolific
abstract: This word has appeared in 738 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word prolific has appeared in 738 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 18 in “Can You Retire if You Never Had a Job? NOFX Will Try” by James H. Martin:

headline: Nancy Pelosi Interrupted by Pro-Palestinian Protesters on ‘The Late Show’
abstract: “Isn’t it great to be in Chicago?” the former House speaker exclaimed in her appearance with Stephen Colbert, an apparent attempt to defuse the tension.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: ‘I Am the Only Person Stupid Enough to Speak After Michelle Obama’
abstract: So said former President Barack Obama after his wife electrified the Democratic National Convention. The delegates loved him, but they really loved her.
lead_paragraph: Whoever set the schedule for the second night of the Democratic National Convention certainly did Barack Obama no favors. As the former president admitted when he took the stage on Tuesday night, “I am the only person stupid enough to speak after Michelle Obama.”

headline: Women’s Cricket World Cup Moved From Bangladesh Because of Unrest
abstract: The United Arab Emirates will host the tournament after many governments advised against traveling to Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: The International Cricket Council on Tuesday moved the 2024 Women’s T20 World Cup to the United Arab Emirates because of the ongoing political instability and security concerns in Bangladesh, which was scheduled to host the tournament in October.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: A Photographer’s Deep Dive Into Murky Waters
abstract: Michael Turek recently descended 20 feet beneath the waves off New York’s coast to photograph divers who brave the green-tinged waters.
lead_paragraph: When most photographers head out into the field, they pack the essentials: camera lenses, external hard drives, battery chargers, a portable light source.

headline: Could That Garage Be Apartments? New York Hunts for Places to Build.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams signed an executive order that directs every city agency to investigate whether they have land that can be developed.
lead_paragraph: New York City is turning to its own properties — including libraries, parking lots and garages — in a desperate search for space to build new homes.

headline: How to Exercise During Menopause
abstract: Your body changes during the menopause transition. So should your fitness routine.
lead_paragraph: When Alison Gittelman turned 49, she found that she couldn’t run as fast or as long as she had before. She was an experienced marathoner and triathlete, but suddenly, as she entered menopause, her heart rate was unusually elevated while running. Her joints hurt. She gained weight. She started experiencing debilitating menstrual cramps.

headline: What Sex Therapists Wish You Knew
abstract: We asked nearly a dozen experts in sex and intimacy for the advice they repeat again and again. For starters, they said, don’t get so hung up on how often you have, or want, sex.
lead_paragraph: Couples worried about “mismatched” libidos. People struggling to orgasm. Lovers wondering if they’re having a “normal” amount of sex.

headline: Robert Louis Stevenson Loved Her. Many of His Friends Did Not.
abstract: In her engrossing book “A Wilder Shore,” Camille Peri tells the story of R.L.S. and his American wife, Fanny Van de Grift.
lead_paragraph: A hundred and thirty years after his death, just a few of Robert Louis Stevenson’s books are still widely read: “Treasure Island,” “Kidnapped,” “A Child’s Garden of Verses” and above all his 1886 novella “The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde,” a masterpiece of the grotesque that presaged the coming Freudian era and has exercised a remarkable impact on Anglo-American culture, with some 60 film and television adaptations to date. But Stevenson’s oeuvre was far more extensive. In his short life (he died at just 44, after a lifetime of debilitating illness) he produced a stunning array of novels, short stories, essays, poems and newspaper reportage. His “Complete Works” take up more than three feet on my bookshelf.

headline: She Survived the Maui Wildfires. She Couldn’t Survive the Year After.
abstract: Edralina Diezon was working as a janitor and sending money to her family in the Philippines when wildfires destroyed everything she had. The road to rebuilding her life proved to be perilous.
lead_paragraph: As a whirlwind of flames nearly encircled the Lahaina Gateway shopping center on Aug. 8, 2023, Edralina Diezon hid in a storage room, surrounded by mops, buckets and brooms. Terrified, Ms. Diezon, who worked 80 hours a week as a janitor, did not leave for two days and two nights. When she finally emerged, starving and disoriented, the neighborhood where she lived was gone.

headline: ‘Dancing With the Other Arts’: The Ballets Russes’ Creative Churn
abstract: An exhibition at the Morgan, drawn from its collection of musical manuscripts, sheds light on one of the most collaborative periods in dance.
lead_paragraph: When Robinson McClellan was sifting through the Robert Owen Lehman collection of musical manuscripts at the Morgan Library & Museum in 2019, he came across a concentration of famous ballet scores from the early 20th century. The manuscripts were all connected to the Ballets Russes, the revolutionary dance company founded by the impresario Sergei Diaghilev in Paris, in 1909.

headline: New Speculative Fiction About the Villainous Power of Universities
abstract: Our columnist takes a look at recent books by Sofia Samatar, Vajra Chandrasekera and Emet North.
lead_paragraph: I feel privileged to witness the emergence of a type of fiction — not a genre, exactly, but an affect — that I might call, in the manner of a Spotify daylist, “queer millennial midlife multiversal crisis.” In it I would pile Isaac Fellman’s “The Two Doctors Górski,” Aimee Pokwatka’s “Self-Portrait With Nothing” and Jo Harkin’s “Tell Me an Ending” — all books that present selves and universes in a state of fracture, asking what if in a way that also demands why, though.

headline: 7 Days in the Cultural Life of an Artistic Director
abstract: Violaine Huisman, who leads programming for the Crossing the Line festival, takes in dance on Little Island, a world premiere at Asia Society and “invigorating” translation projects.
lead_paragraph: Bastille Day felt a little bit different this year than others, said Violaine Huisman, the artistic director of New York’s annual Crossing the Line festival. L’Alliance New York, the French cultural center in Midtown, throws a party every July 14, the anniversary of the storming of the Bastille during the French Revolution. This year, the celebration took place just one week after a surprising snap election left President Emmanuel Macron — and France — in a state of flux.

headline: A 12-Minute Show, Played Only Once, Just Might Live Forever
abstract: Every summer, hundreds of college-age musicians spend countless hours — and their own money — pursuing a single goal: the drum corps world championship.
lead_paragraph: The 159 members of the Bluecoats Drum and Bugle Corps are on the field. Sixty-four of them are standing on a fire-engine-red platform that fills the space between the hash marks and the 40-yard lines. They are dressed in white jumpsuits adorned with red lines.

headline: For Historic Gardens, Climate Change Offers Particular Challenges
abstract: At Wethersfield Estate, in upstate New York, restoring the formal gardens involves dealing with emboldened pests and pathogens — but carefully, so visitors don’t see.
lead_paragraph: A walk through the formal gardens at Wethersfield Estate & Garden, in Amenia, N.Y., offers a dreamy escape back in time. The landscape, some 80 years in the making, conjures the Italian Renaissance and hints of ancient Greece.

headline: ‘A Lot of Us Are Gone’: How the Push to Diversify Publishing Fell Short
abstract: Lisa Lucas was among the big hires meant to shake up the industry. Her departure, alongside other prominent Black editors and executives, has led some to question publishers’ pledge to diversify.
lead_paragraph: When Lisa Lucas was hired in the summer of 2020 to take a big job at the country’s largest book publisher, there was a sense that things were finally starting to change in what has long been an overwhelmingly white industry.

headline: He Tried to ‘Walk the Line Between Elder Statesman and Queen Maker’: The Best and Worst Moments From Night 2 of the Convention
abstract: Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which included speeches by Bernie Sanders, Chuck Schumer, Doug Emhoff and Michelle and Barack Obama.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for Night 2 of the Democratic National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rate the evening on a scale of 0 to 10: 0 means the night was a disaster for Kamala Harris; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which included speeches by Bernie Sanders, Chuck Schumer, Doug Emhoff and Michelle and Barack Obama.

headline: In a Union Triumph, the Seeds of Future Failure
abstract: The U.S. government’s arduous efforts to back the Starbucks campaign may be impossible to replicate.
lead_paragraph: Starting with one small shop in Buffalo, Starbucks workers have unionized 481 stores with more than 11,000 employees in less than three years. It’s a staggering demonstration of what can be accomplished when an aggressive union, an eager work force and a labor-friendly Democratic administration wind up in alignment.

headline: How to Bring Out the Best in Your Last Tomatoes of Summer
abstract: A glut of tomatoes is an embarrassment of riches, especially when put to work in this fragrant curry.
lead_paragraph: When Julius Roberts planted his tomatoes in February, he knew that, come July, he would be greeted by plants much bigger than he is, some growing as tall as two and a half meters. (For the Americans, that’s eight feet and change.) He also knew that, come August, then September, October, even early November, his larder would be spilling over with sunlit fruit as the season’s leaves started to turn and the hot weather relented in the English countryside, where he lives. According to Roberts, a 31-year-old farmer and cook, when you’ve got a good tomato, all you need is olive oil and salt, maybe a piece of toast rubbed with garlic. But when you’ve got a glut of good tomatoes, so many that you can’t keep up, it’s time to reacquaint yourself with the stove and make a curry.

headline: Trump Isn’t Finished
abstract: The damage inflicted on the nation during the former president’s first term in office pales in comparison to what he will do if he is elected to a second term.
lead_paragraph: The damage inflicted on the nation during Donald Trump’s first term in office pales in comparison with what he will do if he is elected to a second term. How can we know this? The best evidence is Trump himself. He has repeatedly demonstrated his willingness to tear the country apart.

headline: So You Want to Look Like a Streaming Star
abstract: Call the stylist Holly White, who has worked with breakout actors on “Bridgerton,” “House of the Dragon,” “The Crown” and more.
lead_paragraph: Streaming services can’t get enough of franchises: swaggering shows with sweeping locations, fertile plots and, perhaps most critically, large casts.

headline: I Kept Failing to Learn French. This Is What Finally Worked.
abstract: Doing exercises in a book was très terrible. A friend suggested something more radical.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene I love in the movie “Husbands,” when John Cassavetes, performing in his own film, is attempting to smooth-talk a beautiful blonde in a London casino. “What languages do you speak?” he asks her. None, she answers. “I’m going to give you a little bit of French,” he says, before launching, with seductive gravitas, into a language that sounds like French. But the words are nonsense. It’s fake French. “You like Italian?” he asks, and then he does his fake version. The woman laughs and says, “It’s not real.” “It’s real to me,” he replies.

headline: Under a Frozen Army Base, He Found Incredible Fossils
abstract: In a new book, geologist Paul Bierman recounts the moment he found astonishing evidence that Greenland’s ice sheet had melted in the ancient past.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere deep inside a glacier in Greenland are the remains of Camp Century, a short-lived experiment in making the Cold War literal. In 1959, the U.S. Army began building a network of tunnels, carved inside the ice, that it hoped might become a launch site for nuclear missiles.

headline: Cycling the Western Balkans: A Wild, Yet Welcoming, Mountain Tour
abstract: High temperatures and higher mountains were no match for our author and her companion as they biked the Trans Dinarica, a new cycling route that winds through eight countries in the remote Dinaric Alps.
lead_paragraph: “Hey mate!” a cyclist called to us in an Australian accent as he pedaled by on the rocky dirt road that serves as the main street of the village of Theth deep in Albania’s Dinaric Alps. Along with my friend and travel companion, Dave, I had not seen another bikepacker in four days.

headline: For Aja Naomi King, an Emmy Nomination Is a Seismic Event
abstract: The earth shook as she talked about receiving her first Emmy nod, for her role as Harriet in the Apple TV+ show “Lessons in Chemistry.” Literally.
lead_paragraph: Voting is underway for the 76th Primetime Emmys, and this week we are talking to several first-time Emmy nominees. The awards will be presented Sept. 15 on ABC.

headline: Another Pandemic Looms. Guess What? We’re Still Not Ready.
abstract: Africa has nowhere near the doses it needs to curb the outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Just one day after the World Health Organization declared the deadly mpox outbreak in Africa a global health emergency, Sweden reported its first case of a dangerous strain of the disease (and there may be more cases). The threat of a pandemic of mpox is here yet again. To curb this crisis, the affected countries in Africa need tests, vaccines and people to respond. Now.

headline: How Kamala Harris Is Trying to Claim the Mantle of Change
abstract: Ms. Harris is working to embody a powerful political force. But Donald J. Trump doesn’t want to let the incumbent party sell itself as anything but the status quo.
lead_paragraph: The fight over whether Kamala Harris can represent change has emerged as one of the early thematic battlegrounds of the 2024 race, playing out both at this week’s Democratic convention in Chicago and on the airwaves of swing states.

headline: Can High Prices and Health Scares Keep Americans From Their Deli Meat?
abstract: Sales dropped after the Boar’s Head recall, but as parents go back to packing school lunches, don’t bet against this popular staple.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a roller coaster of a month for lunch meat.

headline: The Small-Town Nebraska Tim Walz Put Behind Him, but Never Fully Left
abstract: A political persona forged on the prairie: self-assured but rarely self-serious; puckish when possible, stoic when necessary.
lead_paragraph: Tim Walz was 14 or so, trouble-seeking with his cousins across a shaggy patch of family land where they liked to shoot air guns at birds.

headline: Six Questions We Asked 65 Democratic Convention Attendees
abstract: What some of the most committed Democrats think about Kamala Harris, the future of the party and more.
lead_paragraph: What some of the most committed Democrats think about Kamala Harris, the future of the party and more.

headline: Explaining Claims About Tim Walz’s Military Service
abstract: Four veterans who investigate claims of fraudulent military service said they do not believe the governor is guilty of “stolen valor,” but that he did misrepresent his record at times.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota has faced fresh scrutiny over his military service, and how he has characterized his record, in the weeks since he was selected as Vice President Kamala Harris’s running mate.

headline: If Dire Warnings Won’t Stop Trump, Democrats Figure Mockery Might
abstract: The passing of the torch from President Biden to Vice President Kamala Harris has been accompanied by another change: the reintroduction of humor.
lead_paragraph: If Democrats can’t make the nation fear Donald Trump, they have decided that perhaps they can persuade voters to laugh at him instead.

headline: Why Manhattan College Is Changing Its Name
abstract: Colleges competing for international students prefer to be known as universities.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out why, after 171 years, Manhattan College is getting a new name. We’ll also look at why Amtrak’s system keeps breaking down.

headline: Vance Thinks He Knows Rural America. Walz Begs to Differ.
abstract: The Minnesota governor experienced just how much small towns and farming communities rely on public institutions like schools and hospitals.
lead_paragraph: As Tim Walz took the stage at the Astro Theater in the Omaha suburb of La Vista on Saturday afternoon, the crowd roared with approval. Nearly 2,500 people were packed inside the auditorium, and thousands more were watching on big screens outside. It was the first time that Mr. Walz, the Minnesota governor, had been back to the state where he was born and grew up since Kamala Harris tapped him to join the Democratic ticket. He wasted no time in contrasting his running mate’s early years with her opponent Donald Trump’s gilded upbringing.

headline: Beyoncé Loves Her Poetry. You Will, Too.
abstract: Warsan Shire's writing is fierce and urgent.
lead_paragraph: When Beyoncé released her album “Lemonade,” she gave many people their first glimpse into the world of the Somali British poet Warsan Shire — fragments of Shire’s poetry were woven throughout the album. But for Abdi Latif Dahir, East Africa correspondent for The New York Times, Shire’s work had already been close to his heart, and her poems have continued to inspire him for more than a decade. Dahir argues that now is the perfect time to read Warsan Shire’s work, and he explains why he considers her to be “our ultimate modern poet.”

headline: Mishandled Evidence Scuttles Prisoner’s Bid to Prove Innocence
abstract: Prosecutors in Missouri who sought to free Marcellus Williams faced a setback after DNA analysis did not turn out as they had expected.
lead_paragraph: The new DNA lab report came in two days before Marcellus Williams was supposed to have his day in a suburban St. Louis courtroom, and it was a problem.

headline: $3 Million Homes in Oregon, North Carolina and Massachusetts
abstract: A 1911 Arts and Crafts estate in Portland, a four-bedroom home in Charlotte and an 1870 brick townhouse in Boston.
lead_paragraph: This home, listed on the National Register of Historic Places, is in Mount Tabor, about 15 minutes from downtown. It is a few blocks from a dog park and walking trails with sweeping city views in Mount Tabor Park, and within walking distance of a public elementary school, an Irish pub, restaurants that serve tacos and dumplings, and a movie rental shop. An H Mart supermarket is five minutes away by car.

headline: For Tim Walz, the Convention Is Like Marrying Into a Very Large Family
abstract: Every Democrat in Chicago wants to meet him, and maybe give him a hug. “I love him,” one delegate said. “He reminds me of Chris Farley — you know, the man down by the river.”
lead_paragraph: Roughly 50,000 people are converging on Chicago for the Democratic National Convention, and very few of them have ever seen Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota in person.

headline: I Was a Celebrity Assistant. The Power Imbalance Is Very Real.
abstract: I was Harvey Weinstein’s assistant. I understand all too well the toxic nature of the relationship between celebrities and the people they employ.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Kenneth Iwamasa, 59, the live-in assistant to the actor Matthew Perry, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to distribute ketamine, the drug that led to the death of his employer. Very few people have firsthand insight into the toxic dynamic that can develop while assisting a celebrity or understand the inherent power imbalance that can arise. I do.

headline: Walmart Dumps Entire Stake in China’s JD.com
abstract: Walmart has divested as its e-commerce partner has struggled to maintain its market share in the country’s cutthroat online sales industry.
lead_paragraph: Walmart said it unloaded its entire stake in JD.com, one of China’s biggest e-commerce companies, unwinding one of the largest investments in a Chinese retailer by a foreign rival.

headline: Hard Work and Fizzy Drinks: What It Takes to Live Past 110
abstract: They are called supercentenarians, and they have seen it all.
lead_paragraph: One of the oldest men in the world died in August at the age of 111. The man, John Farringdon, was born about a year after the Titanic sank.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,160
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Day of Week, Date, Year.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 438
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Aug. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Obamas’ Back-to-Back Speeches, and a Secret U.S. Nuclear Defense Plan
abstract: Plus, why eating meat may raise diabetes risk.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Inside Ukraine’s Invasion of Russia
abstract: What the unlikely incursion could mean for the war.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains descriptions of war.

headline: Who’s the Change Candidate?
abstract: Inside the fight over who most represents change ahead of November.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard for the party that holds the White House to run as the party of change. But Kamala Harris and the Democrats are trying.

headline: How Gaza Is Showing Up in Chicago
abstract: So far, the D.N.C. does not feature the chaos many feared, but protesters and uncommitted delegates are pushing their cause.
lead_paragraph: After two days of the Democratic National Convention, one thing is clear.

headline: Thailand Reports Mpox Case in Traveler Who Arrived From Africa
abstract: Officials are testing if the patient has the new version of the virus. If confirmed, it would be Thailand’s first case involving Clade Ib mpox.
lead_paragraph: Thailand reported on Wednesday a case of mpox suspected to be caused by the new and potentially more deadly version of the virus. If confirmed, it would be the first such case in Thailand and would come a week after the World Health Organization declared the disease a global health emergency.

headline: Consumers Are Still Bargain Shopping, Macy’s and Target Reports Show
abstract: Department store chains have struggled as Americans, squeezed by budget constraints, spend less time and money at their stores.
lead_paragraph: As U.S. consumers navigate an economy still rocked by high inflation, they are guided by tight wallets and cheaper goods, a trend that’s hitting department store chains like Macy’s harder than discount retailers like Target and T.J. Maxx.

headline: My Race Through the Mini Crossword Archive
abstract: In March, Young Chung set a formidable goal for herself: Solve 3,600 Minis before the puzzle’s 10th anniversary on Aug. 21.
lead_paragraph: My heart pounded as I took a deep breath, readied my keyboard and hovered my mouse over the Mini Crossword’s “Play” button. I clicked and started typing in the answers as fast as I could. Cap. Chino. Latke. Eight. Fro. My breath caught as I looked at my results.

headline: Bus of Pilgrims From Pakistan Crashes in Iran, Killing at Least 28
abstract: Iranian state media reported that the passengers were traveling to the Iraqi city of Karbala for Arbaeen, a Shiite Muslim holiday.
lead_paragraph: At least 28 pilgrims from Pakistan were killed in Iran when their bus overturned on Tuesday night while traveling to commemorate a Shiite Muslim holiday, state-run media in Iran has reported.

headline: Russia Said It Repelled a Large Ukrainian Drone Attack on Moscow
abstract: The attack came as Kyiv presses on with a cross-border offensive into western Russia that has rattled the Kremlin.
lead_paragraph: Russia said on Wednesday that Moscow had come under a sizable drone attack overnight, as Kyiv presses on with a cross-border offensive far from the capital that has rattled the Kremlin.

headline: Investors Brace for a Jobs Wipeout
abstract: Economists forecast that a revision to payrolls data could undercut a robust picture of the labor market, further pressuring the Federal Reserve to cut rates.
lead_paragraph: The torrid weeklong stocks rally has taken a breather as investors again shift their focus to the weakening labor market.

headline: Gunman Kills 3 People at School in Bosnia
abstract: The attacker, a school employee, used a “military weapon, an automatic rifle” before then attempting to kill himself, a police spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: A school employee shot dead three people on Wednesday in a town in northwestern Bosnia, the police said, and was then severely wounded after trying to kill himself.

headline: Peltola Finishes First in Alaska House Primary, With Begich as Top Challenger
abstract: The conservative son of a prominent liberal Alaska political family came in second in a ranked-choice primary that could play out similarly to 2022, when Republicans split their votes and elected a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: Representative Mary Peltola, Democrat of Alaska, ranked first on Tuesday in an open primary to set the field for her re-election bid, claiming just over 50 percent of the vote in preliminary results, well ahead of 11 challengers vying for her position as the state’s sole member of the House.

headline: Should We Tell Our Tween Daughter That Her Father Had a Nose Job?
abstract: When a couple’s 12-year-old starts to point out that no one else in the family seems to have a nose like hers, they can’t agree whether to tell her why.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I grew up in the 1980s, when getting a nose job was not uncommon in our social circles. My husband had one. Our daughter is 12, and she has her father’s original nose. Lately, she’s told us that she doesn’t love her nose and that it’s unlike anyone else’s in the family. My husband wants to tell her about his surgery — with the proviso that he would make a different choice today. But I think he should keep it to himself. I don’t see how sharing this information would help our daughter, and it may harm her. Still, I know this is my husband’s story to tell. Thoughts?

headline: Hundreds of Ultra-Orthodox Israelis Clash With Police Over Draft
abstract: Protests over military conscription highlight the rising tensions surrounding a court order overturning a decades-long exemption for the religious community.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of ultra-Orthodox Israeli men protested outside a conscription center in Jerusalem on Wednesday and clashed with police officers amid rising national tensions about a court decision ordering a draft for the insular community.

headline: Thai Politician Is Under Fire After Slapping a Journalist on Camera
abstract: Videos of Prawit Wongsuwan, a former deputy prime minister, hitting a female reporter in the head prompted angry demands for an investigation in Thailand.
lead_paragraph: A politician is surrounded by journalists while walking down a corridor when one of them asks him a question. Instead of answering it, he raises his hand and slaps her in the head several times before climbing into his vehicle and driving away.

headline: Inmate Who Escaped Mississippi Courthouse Is Captured After Standoff in Chicago
abstract: The authorities had been searching for Joshua Zimmerman, wanted for murder and other crimes, for nearly 70 days. He was barricaded overnight in a restaurant.
lead_paragraph: A man who escaped from a Mississippi courthouse nearly 70 days ago was taken into custody after barricading himself overnight inside a Chicago restaurant less than a mile from where the Democratic National Convention is being held, the authorities said.

headline: What’s in the Latest U.S. Proposal for a Gaza Cease-Fire?
abstract: The Biden administration is pushing for a deal between Israel and Hamas with renewed urgency after months of lagging talks. Here’s a closer look at what the main differences appear to be.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is pushing again for a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, offering a new proposal that it says could bridge the gaps between the two sides. But the latest U.S. effort, which builds on an earlier framework, again appears to have run into difficulty.

headline: Biden Is Leaving the Spotlight. His Son’s Legal Troubles Are Not.
abstract: A preliminary hearing on Wednesday will determine the contours of the tax trial Hunter Biden faces in September. It is often a forum for discussions that could lead to a plea deal.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden watched backstage in Chicago on Monday night as his father, President Biden, strode into the spotlight of the Democratic National Convention to bask in the appreciation of the party’s faithful and to gain a measure of closure after an unforgiving 2024.

headline: Ford Pulls Back Its Electric Vehicle Push
abstract: The automaker said it would invest less in battery-powered cars and scrap a planned electric three-row sport utility vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor, which had once hoped to race ahead of other established automakers in electric vehicles, is again slowing the pace of its investments and new battery-powered models.

headline: Barack Obama’s Speech Was a Reminder of the Possible
abstract: Harris is selling something different, but would continue his legacy.
lead_paragraph: The reservoir of good will for Barack Obama is deep in the Democratic Party.

headline: ‘Hannah Gadsby: Woof’ Review: A Comic’s Pet Themes
abstract: In a soul-baring new show at the Edinburgh Fringe, the Australian stand-up leans once again into fears, anxieties and mental health worries.
lead_paragraph: The title of Hannah Gadsby’s new stand-up show at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe is “Woof,” but the Australian comic has a very specific type of dog bark in mind. It sounds like something between a burp and a cough. It’s impossible to spell, but if you had to, it might go something like “peuh.” Gadsby says it typically signals that the animal is about to go into a frenzy. As a metaphor for Gadsby’s state of mind, it’s inauspicious. Should we be concerned?

headline: Michelle Obama Suits the Moment
abstract: On Day 2 of the Democratic National Convention, the former first lady (and her husband) suited up for the next stage.
lead_paragraph: From the moment Michelle Obama strode onstage at the Democratic National Convention on Tuesday night baring arms, her appearance and her words were a reminder of why she had been such a powerful communicator as a first lady — and as a writer and speaker thereafter.

headline: How U.S. Farms Could Start a Bird Flu Pandemic
abstract: The virus is poised to become a permanent presence in cattle, raising the odds of an eventual outbreak among people.
lead_paragraph: Without a sharp pivot in state and federal policies, the bird flu virus that has bedeviled American farms is likely to find a firm foothold among dairy cattle, scientists are warning.

headline: U.S. Added 818,000 Fewer Jobs Than Reported Earlier
abstract: The Labor Department issued revised figures for the 12 months through March that point to greater economic fragility.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy added far fewer jobs in 2023 and early 2024 than previously reported, a sign that cracks in the labor market are more severe — and began forming earlier — than initially believed.

headline: Congress Asks Regulators About ‘Troubling’ Health Insurance Tactics
abstract: Lawmakers are zeroing in on MultiPlan, a firm that has helped insurers cut payments while sometimes leaving patients with large bills.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers on Tuesday called on health insurance regulators to detail their efforts against “troubling practices” that have raised costs for patients and employers.

headline: Divers Find 4 Bodies From Yacht That Sank Off Sicily
abstract: The discoveries came after the vessel went down this week in what some witnesses described as a waterspout, or a small tornado, during a violent downpour. No names were immediately released.
lead_paragraph: After three days of searching the hull of a sailing yacht that sank off the coast of Sicily, divers on Wednesday recovered the bodies of four passengers who were believed to have been trapped inside their cabins when the vessel went down, officials in Sicily said.

headline: What ‘It Ends With Us’ Gets Wrong (and Right) About Domestic Abuse
abstract: Its depiction of love-bombing and psychological abuse rings true, experts say, but other oversimplified aspects could send a dangerous message.
lead_paragraph: A person trying to escape an abusive relationship, on average, needs seven attempts to actually leave. Lily Bloom, the protagonist of the new drama “It Ends With Us,” needs only one.

headline: The Convention’s Happiest Democrats? The ‘Pretty Psyched’ Minnesotans.
abstract: The unexpected rise of a native son, Tim Walz, has thrilled his local compatriots in Chicago. “The Minnesota delegation is, like, buzzing,” said Senator Tina Smith.
lead_paragraph: The Georgia delegates danced with the rapper Lil Jon at the Democratic National Convention on Tuesday. The Wisconsin delegates cheered in their Cheesehead hats.

headline: Why Kamala’s Mom Was More ‘Brat’ Than She Is
abstract: Shyamala Gopalan created the context for the vice president’s “brat” energy.
lead_paragraph: Shyamala Gopalan created the context for the vice president’s “brat” energy.

headline: The Year of the A.I. Election That Wasn’t
abstract: More than 30 tech companies have pitched A.I. tools to political campaigns for November’s election. The campaigns have been wary.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Diemer, a Democrat running for election in Ohio’s Seventh Congressional District, was approached by the artificial intelligence company Civox in January with a pitch: A.I.-backed voice technology that could make tens of thousands of personalized phone calls to voters using Mr. Diemer’s talking points and sense of humor.

headline: Why Kamala Harris’s Mom Was More ‘Brat’ Than She Is
abstract: Shyamala Gopalan created the context for the vice president’s “brat” energy.
lead_paragraph: Young voters have been embracing Kamala Harris for her “brat” energy, invoking a trend popularized by the musician Charli XCX. But could Ms. Harris’s mom actually be more “brat” than she is? In the Opinion Video above, the journalist Angad Singh digs into this question by examining her Indian heritage to better understand the current momentum behind Ms. Harris’s campaign. Mr. Singh argues that this momentum “could easily fizzle if she doesn’t lay out policies that distinguish her from her predecessor, who was decidedly not ‘brat’ enough.”

headline: An Easy Buttermilk Peach Cobbler to Whip Up on a Weeknight
abstract: It’s just about the summery-est thing you can do with the last of the season’s stone fruits.
lead_paragraph: If discerning the difference between a crumble and a crisp is one fruit-filled conundrum, here’s another: Where’s the line between a caky peach cobbler made with a batter, and a buttery, one-bowl peach cake served warm with a spoon?

headline: Coming Soon to Jersey City: A Gleaming Home for the Symphony
abstract: The New Jersey Symphony, which long lacked a permanent space, will move into a 550-seat theater that it hopes to make a hub for concerts and classes.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey Symphony has long lacked a permanent home, performing in a variety of spaces across the state. But come 2026, that will change: The orchestra is getting a gleaming 550-seat theater in downtown Jersey City, the ensemble and the city announced on Wednesday.

headline: Harris Goes Light on Climate Policy. Green Leaders Are OK With That.
abstract: President Biden made climate change a cornerstone of his agenda. Vice President Kamala Harris has yet to detail her own plan.
lead_paragraph: In the 2020 presidential election, climate activists demanded that Democratic candidates explain, in detail, how they planned to tackle the planet’s greatest environmental threat.

headline: Donations Soared for Harris After Biden Dropped Out
abstract: When Vice President Kamala Harris became the party’s nominee, the money started to flow.
lead_paragraph: Joe Biden’s decision on July 21 to drop out of the presidential race unleashed a gusher of cash that fundamentally changed the money race between Democrats and former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: A ‘Speedy Little Star’ May Be on Course to Escape Our Galaxy
abstract: The so-called hypervelocity object, which is either a low-mass star or a brown dwarf, is traveling through the Milky Way at around a million miles an hour.
lead_paragraph: In his spare time, Tom Bickle, an astronomy student in Southampton, England, likes to blast heavy metal while combing through time-lapses of the night sky, hunting for traces of a hypothesized ninth planet and other hidden objects lurking in the outskirts of our solar system.

headline: Here’s What to Expect at the Democratic National Convention on Day 3
abstract: All eyes will be on Gov. Tim Walz as he formally accepts the Democratic Party’s nomination for vice president on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota will speak to the largest audience of his political career on Wednesday night at the Democratic National Convention, where he will formally accept the party’s nomination for vice president. His speech, on Day 3 of this week’s political coronation at the United Center in Chicago, will be the biggest test so far since Vice President Kamala Harris made the decision to put the jovial, blunt-spoken Midwesterner on the ticket.

headline: The Party’s After-Parties: Once Dreary Democrats Remember How to Have Fun
abstract: “This is a group that’s not used to being happy — they’re used to complaining,” one reveler noted. For now, at least, the rise of Kamala Harris has changed that.
lead_paragraph: “There’s nothing wrong with being over-excited.”

headline: Did You Meet Someone Special This Summer?
abstract: Do you have a summer meet-cute story? Whether it was a chance encounter at the beach or a spontaneous date that turned into something more, we want to hear about your summer romances.
lead_paragraph: In June, The New York Times published a list of hot spots in New York to meet people. Many people are longing for organic, in-person connections, but they don’t necessarily know where to go.

headline: At M.I.T., Black and Latino Enrollment Drops Sharply After Affirmative Action Ban
abstract: Asian American students made up almost half of the 2028 class — the first admitted since the end of affirmative action.
lead_paragraph: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s incoming class of 2028 saw a precipitous drop-off in the percentage of Black, Hispanic, Native American and Pacific Islander students, the university announced on Wednesday. It is M.I.T.’s first undergraduate class to be admitted since the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision last year banning affirmative action, and M.I.T. is the first major university to release statistics on the composition of its freshman class since the high court’s ruling.

headline: As N.Y.C. Reading Scores Slip Under New Program, Officials Urge Patience
abstract: Math scores notched upward in the city, and officials said the drop in reading was explained in part by an effort to change reading instruction and retrain hundreds of teachers.
lead_paragraph: Fewer than half of New York City public school students showed proficiency on reading exams this year, a decline from the previous year that may reflect how hard it is to change teaching approaches as the district embarks on a major reading overhaul.

headline: Bill Pascrell Jr., 14-Term House Democrat From N.J., Dies at 87
abstract: An outspoken progressive, he vigorously opposed President Donald J. Trump and focused on legislation to help “regular Americans pay their bills.”
lead_paragraph: Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., a blunt progressive Democrat from northern New Jersey who was poised to become the oldest member of the House of Representatives, died on Wednesday in Livingston, N.J. He was 87.

headline: Three Delegates, Decades Apart in Age, Converge at the Democratic Convention
abstract: Some participants have been attending for decades, while others will be voting in their first general election this year.
lead_paragraph: Among the nearly 4,700 delegates gathered in Chicago this week for the Democratic National Convention: United States senators and representatives. Top state officials. Leaders of major advocacy groups and labor unions. Democrats aspiring to become one or more of the above.

headline: On Harris’s Price-Gouging Ban, Allies and Foes May Have the Wrong Idea
abstract: The plan does not appear to amount to government price controls. It also might not bring down grocery bills anytime soon.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris threw her support behind a federal ban on price-gouging in the food and grocery industries last week. It was the first official economic policy proposal of her presidential campaign, and it was pitched as a direct response to the high price of putting food on the table in America today.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Dear Ex’ and More
abstract: I cover news in China and Taiwan with a focus on the technology sector for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.
lead_paragraph: I cover news in China and Taiwan with a focus on the technology sector for The Times. Here are five things I’ve been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: How Did the First Cells Arise? With a Little Rain, Study Finds.
abstract: Researchers stumbled upon an ingredient that can stabilize droplets of genetic material: water.
lead_paragraph: Rain may have been an essential ingredient for the origin of life, according to a study published on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Worst-Case’ Disaster for Antarctic Ice Looks Less Likely, Study Finds
abstract: Global warming is putting the continent’s ice at risk of destruction in many forms. But one especially calamitous scenario might be a less pressing concern, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: For almost a decade, climate scientists have been trying to get their heads around a particularly disastrous scenario for how West Antarctica’s gigantic ice sheet might break apart, bringing catastrophe to the world’s coasts.

headline: Divert Great Lakes Water to California?
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay about dealing with groundwater depletion. Also: Feeling hopeful; no comparison between medals; nix “no problem.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Convention Insider: Ro Khanna Never Skips Breakfast
abstract: The Silicon Valley congressman is spending his time going to 15 state delegation breakfasts and maybe, just maybe, laying groundwork for higher office.
lead_paragraph: As Representative Ro Khanna of California left a Michigan delegation breakfast this week after giving a brief speech, he was humble about the impression he had made.

headline: Tim Walz’s Superpower? Jock Insurance.
abstract: Walz has an easy masculine confidence we seem to have all but forgotten.
lead_paragraph: One is an N.F.L. tight end who cries openly and holds his girlfriend’s purse, when he’s not carrying one of his own. The other is a former high-school football coach and National Guardsman who speaks openly about his infertility journey, supports gay rights and was responsible for bringing free period products into Minnesota’s public schools — which resulted in him being cast as “Tampon Tim.”

headline: Al Attles, a Golden State Warrior in Name and in Spirit, Dies at 87
abstract: He was known as the Destroyer for his gritty intensity as a player. He later coached Golden State to an N.B.A. championship and served as its general manager.
lead_paragraph: Al Attles, a Basketball Hall of Fame guard who was among the most prominent figures in the history of the Golden State Warriors and their forerunner franchise in Philadelphia, died on Tuesday at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 87.

headline: We All Live in Vegas Now
abstract: America is becoming a nation of gamblers. Why?
lead_paragraph: In 2022, Americans lost $60 billion betting at licensed casinos and through licensed online gambling, Nate Silver writes in his engrossing new book, “On the Edge,” a meditation on risk, a study of those most comfortable taking it and an invitation for the rest of us to think about what it means that so much more of our lives now seems to hang on it.

headline: Texas Stopped Busing Migrants to Democratic Cities in Late June
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott’s busing program forced Democrats to talk about the border. But a dramatic drop in the number of migrants has left the buses idle.
lead_paragraph: Despite the concerns of some Democratic leaders and city officials in Chicago, the state of Texas has not sent buses filled with migrants to the city this week during the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Fed Minutes Show a Cut ‘Likely’ to Come in September
abstract: Even before a disappointing July jobs report, Federal Reserve officials thought they would probably cut rates at their Sept. 17-18 meeting.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials held off on cutting interest rates at their July meeting, but minutes from that gathering showed that they were clearly poised to lower them at their meeting in September, just weeks before the presidential election.

headline: Should I Take My Share of a Class-Action Settlement I Think Could Be Bogus?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether it’s wrong to participate in a lawsuit you don’t really believe in.
lead_paragraph: I was recently informed via email that I could be entitled to a share of a settlement from a class-action lawsuit. The company being sued denied wrongdoing but agreed to the settlement to avoid an expensive legal battle. I admire this company and have used its product for years. My suspicion is that the lawyers behind the lawsuit are bounty hunters exploiting a technicality. Should I still file for my share of the settlement? (It would be modest — enough to take my husband out for dinner.) If I don’t take my share, everyone else will just get more. — Name Withheld

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Is Expected to End His Presidential Campaign
abstract: Short on cash and losing traction with voters, Mr. Kennedy intends to make a speech about his political future on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is expected to end his troubled independent presidential campaign this week, according to three people briefed on his plans, and is in talks to throw his support behind former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: In Chicago, Democrats Warn of Threat to Democracy
abstract: Even amid a more optimistic vibe, convention speakers remind delegates of Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, the message from President Biden was dark. The very foundations of the country were at stake in the election, he said. An American apocalypse was on the horizon if former President Donald J. Trump was re-elected.

headline: Democrats Use the Convention to Try to Define Trump as a Self-Interested Fraud
abstract: Speeches and videos seek to shrink Donald Trump in order to rise above him, as Kamala Harris and her allies work to minimize him and disengage from him.
lead_paragraph: How to attack former President Donald Trump?

headline: Gen-Z Delegates Push for Change at the D.N.C.
abstract: The Harris campaign has unlocked a wave of enthusiasm among young voters. But how do Democrats plan to fix the real-world problems impacting their lives? We spoke to four young delegates about the issues driving Gen-Z.
lead_paragraph: The Harris campaign has unlocked a wave of enthusiasm among young voters. But how do Democrats plan to fix the real-world problems impacting their lives? We spoke to four young delegates about the issues driving Gen-Z.

headline: A Woman’s Family Reported Her Missing. Her Body Was in Hospital Storage, Lawsuit Says.
abstract: Jessie Peterson, 31, died at a hospital in April 2023. Her family members, who filed a missing persons report, were not told that she had died until a year later, according to a negligence lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The family of a woman who died in a California hospital in 2023 said in a lawsuit that they had not been informed that she had died, leading the family members to believe she had been alive and missing for nearly a year.

headline: Pakistan Arrests Man Over Disinformation That Helped Spur U.K. Riots
abstract: Local police sources indicated that the arrest was made at the request of the British authorities, although there was no official confirmation.
lead_paragraph: The Pakistani authorities arrested a man this week on charges of cyberterrorism for spreading fake news that helped set off violent riots in Britain following a deadly stabbing attack last month.

headline: While the Public Awaited Jobs Data, Wall Street Firms Got a Look
abstract: A report was delayed on the Bureau of Labor Statistics website, but some investors got it in the meantime, raising new questions about agency practices.
lead_paragraph: For more than half an hour on Wednesday morning, economists and investors were stuck repeatedly refreshing their browsers, looking for a delayed report on the U.S. job market from a government website.

headline: Charlene Marshall, Central Figure in a Celebrity Scandal, Dies at 79
abstract: Her husband, Anthony, was convicted of defrauding his wealthy mother, Brooke Astor. But in the tabloids, Mrs. Marshall often seemed to be the one on trial.
lead_paragraph: Charlene Marshall, who played a central role in a high-profile civil suit and subsequent criminal trial in which her husband, Anthony, was convicted of defrauding his mother, the wealthy socialite Brooke Astor, died on Aug. 6 at her home in Northeast Harbor, Maine. She was 79.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Russia Says Ukraine Aimed Drones at Moscow
abstract: Plus, China’s “road-trip auntie.”
lead_paragraph: Russia said it repelled a drone attack against Moscow yesterday, as Ukraine presses on with its offensive in Russia’s southern Kursk region. The Russian authorities did not report any damage or casualties, saying 10 Ukrainian attack drones were destroyed by the capital’s air defenses.

headline: Protesters March Again in Chicago One Night After Dozens Were Arrested
abstract: At least 55 demonstrators protesting the Democratic convention were detained on Tuesday after scuffling with the police outside Israel’s consulate. Hundreds more marched Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Chicago police arrested at least 55 people, including three journalists, at a protest outside the city’s Israeli consulate on Tuesday night, officials said on Wednesday hours before another protest began near the Democratic National Convention.

headline: Liberals Needed a Beyoncé Moment. Kamala Harris Is Delivering One.
abstract: The vice president is giving Democrats what they want while disorienting Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris made a surprise appearance on Monday night at the Democratic National Convention, she walked onstage to the sound of Beyoncé’s “Freedom,” a 2016 song that The Independent said “roars like thunder, and threatens to topple governments in its wake.”

headline: PBS’s Woodruff Calls Comments Suggesting Trump and Netanyahu Discussed Cease-Fire a ‘Mistake’
abstract: Aides to the two men, who met last month at Mar-a-Lago, had denied that such a call had taken place.
lead_paragraph: The veteran PBS correspondent Judy Woodruff on Wednesday apologized for on-air comments suggesting there had been a phone call between former President Donald J. Trump and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to discuss a cease-fire deal. Aides to both men denied that such a call had taken place.

headline: U.S. Investigating Americans Who Worked With Russian State Television
abstract: The F.B.I. raided the homes of two prominent commentators on Russian state television channels as part of an effort to blunt attempts to influence November’s election.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice has begun a broad criminal investigation into Americans who have worked with Russia’s state television networks, signaling an aggressive effort to combat the Kremlin’s influence operations leading up to the presidential election in November, according to American officials briefed on the inquiry.

headline: Andy Kim, Who Cleaned the Capitol After Jan. 6, Debuts on a Bigger Stage
abstract: The likely next senator from New Jersey spoke at the Democratic National Convention with a message about the importance of service and participation to safeguard democracy.
lead_paragraph: The first time most Americans were introduced to Representative Andy Kim was in the wee hours of Jan. 7, 2021, when a photographer captured a single image of the bespectacled congressman kneeling alone in the Capitol Rotunda, picking up trash left behind by rioters who had stormed the building just hours earlier.

headline: The Obamas Strike Back
abstract: Could the former first couple’s convention speeches signal a return to Obamaism?
lead_paragraph: Is Obamaism making a comeback? Tuesday night at the Democratic National Convention, Michelle and Barack Obama electrified the crowd with the most powerful speeches of the week so far, and seemed to anoint Kamala Harris as the inheritor of their political movement. For this audio diary, I’m joined by my producer Elias Isquith to dissect those two speeches. We discuss what Obamaism was in 2008 and 2012, and what it means to pass the baton to Harris in 2024.

headline: Hadley Duvall Says Her Abortion Speech Will ‘Keep My Heart Full’
abstract: Ms. Duvall, a sexual abuse survivor, was one of three women who shared their personal stories at the Democratic convention to support Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: There was Hadley Duvall, calm and measured, hand in her pocket, as she recounted the violence that she endured before becoming one of the most prominent voices of the fight for abortion rights in her home state of Kentucky.

headline: Democrats Look to Redefine Trump
abstract: Also, the U.S. added far fewer jobs than previously reported. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, Democrats have tried to persuade voters that Donald Trump is a villain, a racist and a threat to democracy. Now, with Kamala Harris atop the ticket, the vice president and her allies are trying something new: They are looking to deflate him.

headline: D.N.C. Schedule Tonight: What Time Tim Walz and Bill Clinton Will Speak
abstract: The vice-presidential nominee, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, will deliver the night’s closing remarks. Other speakers include former President Bill Clinton and Representative Nancy Pelosi.
lead_paragraph: As is traditional for the third night of a political convention, the headlining speaker of the Democratic National Convention on Wednesday will be the vice-presidential nominee, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota.

headline: Trump Attacks Harris at N.C. Rally, Asking the Crowd to Back Him Up
abstract: In a speech intended to be about national security, Mr. Trump continued personal attacks on Kamala Harris and asked for validation in doing so from the crowd.
lead_paragraph: After two days of policy-focused addresses with modest crowds, former President Donald J. Trump returned to form on Wednesday with an outdoor speech in North Carolina, where he insisted that he would not give up personal attacks on Vice President Kamala Harris and continued to sow doubts about the integrity of the election in November.

headline: F.A.A. Refers More Unruly Passenger Cases to Justice Department
abstract: A surge in disruptive passenger behavior since the beginning of the pandemic has put pressure on the Federal Aviation Administration.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Wednesday that it had asked the Justice Department to consider bringing criminal charges in 43 serious and dangerous incidents from the past year involving unruly passengers aboard  planes.

headline: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Cross-Border Strikes
abstract: The strikes, in eastern Lebanon and the Israeli-controlled Golan Heights, underscored how months of talks have failed to stop either the war in Gaza or the related conflict along the Lebanese border.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces and Hezbollah militants in Lebanon traded cross-border strikes on Wednesday, fueling concerns about a wider regional conflagration as negotiators struggle to broker a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Ex-U.S. Airman Charged With Child Pornography Appears in Russian Propaganda Video
abstract: “I don’t consider myself a traitor,” said Wilmer Puello-Mota, who has enlisted in the Russian military.
lead_paragraph: A former U.S. Air Force airman who absconded to Russia after being hit with child pornography charges appears to be featured in a Russian propaganda video in which he defends his decision to enlist in the military there.

headline: Bill Clinton Hails Harris as ‘President of Joy’ but Warns Against Overconfidence
abstract: The former president cautioned exuberant delegates at the Democratic National Convention not to be complacent in 2024 because politics is “a brutal, tough business.”
lead_paragraph: For Bill Clinton, there may have been a little déjà vu on the convention stage on Wednesday night. Democrats had just anointed a nominee to become the first woman ever elected president. They faced a Republican opponent they considered a buffoon. And they felt optimistic about victory.

headline: Convention Insider: Lauren Underwood Is Right at Home in Chicago
abstract: The congresswoman is in her home city, and has been a selfie magnet for sorority sisters and young Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Underwood was running late, but she couldn’t not stop for a selfie. Or five.

headline: Paramount Extends Talks With New Bidder, Unsettling Skydance Deal
abstract: Edgar Bronfman Jr. and his bidding group now have until September to sell Paramount on their offer.
lead_paragraph: Paramount on Wednesday decided to extend its deadline to evaluate a takeover bid from the media executive Edgar Bronfman Jr., the company said,  a sign that the company is taking the offer seriously.

headline: Advocates for Palestinians vie for attention at the Democratic convention.
abstract: delegates from Uncommitted, a movement calling for a permanent cease-fire in Gaza and an arms embargo on Israel, are demanding that a speaker of Palestinian descent address the convention from the main stage, as relatives of a hostage being held in Gaza spoke on Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: Behind the scenes at the Democratic National Convention, delegates from Uncommitted, a movement calling for a permanent cease-fire in Gaza and an arms embargo on Israel, demanded that a speaker of Palestinian descent address the convention from the main stage, as relatives of a hostage being held in Gaza spoke on Wednesday evening.

headline: A Bookshop Cancels an Event Over a Rabbi’s Zionism, Prompting Outrage
abstract: Shortly before a talk between a Jewish author and a liberal rabbi, a manager at Powerhouse Arena in Brooklyn barred the rabbi from participating, saying, “We don’t want a Zionist onstage.”
lead_paragraph: Shortly before 6 on Tuesday evening, Joshua Leifer was on his way to an event for his new book, “Tablets Shattered: The End of an American Jewish Century and the Future of Jewish Life,” when he got a call from his publicist.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein on Barack Obama and Michelle Obama’s Convention Speeches
abstract: The August 21, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode on the Democratic National Convention. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Studio Pulls ‘Megalopolis’ Trailer Featuring Fake Review Quotes
abstract: To promote Francis Ford Coppola’s epic, the spot used supposed lines from The Times, The New Yorker and others to suggest critics were wrong about him.
lead_paragraph: A new trailer for Francis Ford Coppola’s “Megalopolis” featuring fake negative quotes from film critics has been pulled by the movie’s distributor, Lionsgate, a spokesman for the company said Wednesday.

headline: Ex-Babysitter Gets 3 Years in Prison in 2019 Death of Man She Injured as a Baby
abstract: Terry McKirchy, 62, violently shook Benjamin Dowling while babysitting for him in 1984, prosecutors said. She was charged with murder after he died from his injuries 35 years later.
lead_paragraph: A former babysitter in Florida was sentenced on Wednesday to three years in prison after she pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the 2019 death of a man whom she had disabled as an infant 35 years earlier, court records show.

headline: Inmates Used Drones to Smuggle Drugs Into Georgia Prisons, U.S. Says
abstract: The authorities charged nearly two dozen people with taking part in schemes over five years beginning in 2019 to deliver drugs and other contraband to inmates in Georgia state prisons.
lead_paragraph: A network of current and former Georgia inmates used drones to smuggle drugs and other contraband into state prisons, federal prosecutors said Wednesday in announcing charges against nearly two dozen people.

headline: The Democrats’ Answer to Hulk Hogan
abstract: Tim Walz will embody his party’s retort to the mega-masculinity of Trumpism on display last month.
lead_paragraph: For better or worse, the image burned most permanently into my brain after the Republican National Convention was that of Hulk Hogan, ripping off his shirt in a display of testosterone-fueled camp that has come to be an integral part of former President Donald Trump’s Make America Great Again movement.

headline: Taylor Swift Says She Felt ‘Fear’ and ‘Guilt’ After Canceled Vienna Shows
abstract: The three stops in Austria on the pop star’s Eras Tour were canceled after the authorities discovered a terrorist plot targeting the concerts.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift said Wednesday that she was devastated by the cancellation of her Eras Tour concerts in Vienna, adding that the terrorist plot that had targeted her shows there had filled her “with a new sense of fear, and a tremendous amount of guilt because so many people had planned on coming.”

headline: Convention Insider: Wes Moore Is in Constant Demand
abstract: For the governor of Maryland and his staff, logistics — and local cuisine — can be a challenge.
lead_paragraph: Wes Moore, the Democratic governor of Maryland, was still shaking hands as his body man began to lead him out of the afternoon cocktail party at an Italian restaurant above the Chicago River. Flanked by a retinue of aides and security officials, he and his wife, Dawn, left through a side door and made their way into a narrow hallway, past waiting trays of meatballs and lamb chops, into a prep kitchen — wrong way, everybody turn around — and, finally, into a capacious service elevator.

headline: Trump Clemency Recipient Accused of Assaulting Wife and Father-in-Law
abstract: Jonathan Braun, whose drug sentence was commuted by Donald Trump shortly before he left office, was charged on Long Island, the latest incident to raise questions of how clemency applications were vetted.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Donald J. Trump issued a series of pardons and commutations as he left office, he and his allies have defended his administration’s vetting of clemency candidates, claiming they went through a vigorous screening process.

headline: Parents of American-Israeli Hostage Make Somber Plea for Middle East Peace
abstract: Jon Polin and Rachel Goldberg, whose 23-year-old son is being held by Hamas, told Democratic convention attendees that there was a “surplus of agony” in the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: It was a remarkably somber moment inside the arena as Jon Polin and Rachel Goldberg spoke of their son, Hersh Goldberg-Polin, a hostage in Gaza for more than 10 months — 320 days, as the tape on their shirts said.

headline: Mindy Kaling Goes From ‘Cooking With Kamala’ to Hosting Her Convention
abstract: Ms. Kaling, like Vice President Kamala Harris, is Indian American. They once cooked masala dosa together in a 2019 YouTube video.
lead_paragraph: In late November 2019, as her once promising 2020 presidential campaign was faltering, Kamala Harris appeared in a cooking video with the actress and comedian Mindy Kaling. A week later, Ms. Harris quit the race.

headline: Former Oath Keepers Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Tampering With Jan. 6 Evidence
abstract: Kellye SoRelle admitted to telling members of the far-right group to illegally delete their text messages after the mob attack.
lead_paragraph: The former lawyer for the Oath Keepers militia pleaded guilty on Wednesday to advising members of the far-right group to illegally delete their text messages after the violent mob attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: 80-Year-Old Seattle Dog Walker Is Killed in a Carjacking, Police Say
abstract: The great-grandmother struggled with a man inside her car before being forced out and then struck by the vehicle, the police said. Her dog was later found dead in a recycling bin.
lead_paragraph: An 80-year-old Seattle woman who worked as a neighborhood dog walker was killed on Tuesday morning when a man got into her car, forced her out, struck her with the vehicle and drove off with her dog, which he later killed with a knife, the police said.

headline: Tough Nut to Crack
abstract: Brad Wiegmann’s puzzle theme is hard to pronounce.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Google Joins $250 Million Deal to Support Newsrooms in California
abstract: The agreement includes $70 million from the state, which needs legislative approval. Some lawmakers objected, calling for a more comprehensive solution with tech companies.
lead_paragraph: Google, a news industry trade group and key California lawmakers announced a first-in-the-nation agreement on Wednesday aimed at shoring up newsrooms in the state with as much as $250 million.

headline: Oprah Winfrey, in a Convention Debut, Calls Harris ‘the Best of America’
abstract: The surprise appearance by the television legend was closely held by Democratic organizers. Ms. Winfrey even rehearsed her speech wearing sunglasses and a face mask.
lead_paragraph: The television legend Oprah Winfrey returned to prime time on Wednesday in a surprise appearance at the Democratic National Convention, calling on Americans to choose “optimism over cynicism” and “inclusion over retribution” as she endorsed the candidacy of Vice President Kamala Harris, whose life story Ms. Winfrey deemed “the best of America.”

headline: Letitia James Fights to Preserve Trump’s Penalty of Over $450 Million
abstract: Ms. James, New York’s attorney general, argued that the civil fraud judgment, which the former president has appealed, should stand. It could wipe out his cash reserves.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general’s office late Wednesday night urged a state appellate court to uphold a more than $450 million civil fraud judgment against Donald J. Trump, arguing that the punishment was needed to protect “the integrity of the marketplace.”

headline: Oprah Celebrates Kamala as a Child of Immigrants
abstract: Oprah Winfrey spoke on the third night of the Democratic convention. She gave Kamala Harris a full-throated endorsement, saying that voting for her is “common sense.”
lead_paragraph: Oprah Winfrey spoke on the third night of the Democratic convention. She gave Kamala Harris a full-throated endorsement, saying that voting for her is “common sense.”

headline: Trump Wants to Distance Himself From Project 2025. Democrats Are Trying Not to Let Him.
abstract: The conservative policy proposal has been front and center at the Democratic convention this week, as Democrats look to tie the controversial document to the former president.
lead_paragraph: Kenan Thompson, the longest-tenured cast member in “Saturday Night Live” history, strode on to the stage on Wednesday night with an oversize book and thumped it heavily onto the lectern: an exaggerated version of Project 2025, a controversial set of conservative policy proposals outlining an agenda for the next Republican president that Democrats have brandished all week.

headline: The War in Gaza Is Making Thousands of Orphans
abstract: Extended families, hospital staff and volunteers are stepping in to care for Gaza’s many newly orphaned children, some of whom are injured, traumatized and haunted by memories of their parents.
lead_paragraph: The boys are aching to see their parents again. They are convinced it will happen as soon as they can go back to Gaza City, where they were growing up before the war bulldozed that life.

headline: A Combat Medic’s Quest to Change Tributes to Fallen Soldiers
abstract: Iryna Tsybukh, who was killed on the front line in Ukraine, wanted to humanize the way Kyiv commemorated the war dead. She also left notes for her own funeral.
lead_paragraph: Her funeral would be “awesome,” the young Ukrainian combat medic said, if it went as she had planned.

headline: 20 Things Seen and Heard at the Convention
abstract: Illustrated scenes and thoughts from delegates and others at the Democratic Convention.
lead_paragraph: Illustrated scenes and thoughts from delegates and others at the Democratic Convention.

headline: Tim Walz, Accepting V.P. Nomination, Tells Democrats to ‘Leave It on the Field’
abstract: Completing his transformation into a party leader, Mr. Walz played up his Midwestern roots and his time as a football coach. “It’s the fourth quarter,” he said. “We’re down a field goal.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota offered himself as a bridge to disillusioned Americans who regard the Democratic Party as a bastion of coastal elitism, in a high-stakes address formally accepting the vice-presidential nomination on Wednesday night.

headline: Full Transcript of Tim Walz’s Speech at the Democratic Convention
abstract: The Minnesota governor compared the election to a football game, vowing that and he and Vice President Kamala Harris would fight “one yard at a time” and “leave it on the field.”
lead_paragraph: Wow. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Wow. Thank you.

headline: Canadian Government Orders Arbitration and End to Rail Freight Shutdown
abstract: The shutdown had threatened to disrupt trade with the United States and other countries, as well as cause serious economic consequences in Canada.
lead_paragraph: Less than 17 hours after almost all rail freight traffic in Canada came to a standstill Thursday following a lockout by the country’s two main rail companies of 10,000 employees, the federal government told a labor board to end the shutdown and ordered arbitration.

headline: Tim Walz Accepts the V.P. Nomination
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota introduced his family and rallied the crowd to get behind Kamala Harris in “the fourth quarter” of the election.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota introduced his family and rallied the crowd to get behind Kamala Harris in “the fourth quarter” of the election.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Hostilities between Israel and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military and Hezbollah traded cross-border strikes yesterday, leaving at least one person dead deep inside eastern Lebanon, as months of diplomatic efforts have failed to ease tensions in the region.

headline: Why These 15 Young Voters Aren’t Rushing to Kamala Harris Like Their Peers
abstract: Participants discuss what it would take for Harris or Trump to win their votes.
lead_paragraph: Participants discuss what it would take for Harris or Trump to win their votes.

headline: Wednesday Night Lights: To Vouch for Coach Walz, His Old Players Step Up
abstract: Fifteen men clad in football jerseys took the stage at the Democratic National Convention as the Mankato West High School fight song played.
lead_paragraph: Over a few minutes on Wednesday night, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota was described as a “Dad in plaid,” a hunter who braves 10-degree weather to hang out in a deer stand and a guy who could push your car out of a snowbank.

headline: Tim Walz and His Party Are the New Small-Town Conservatives
abstract: They look after neighbors, they care about children and they take pride in the military.
lead_paragraph: Republicans used to brag a lot about family values, but Donald Trump cooked that turkey when the G.O.P. traded moralizing for an immoral president.

headline: Guatemala Arrests 7 Over Deaths of 53 Migrants in Texas
abstract: The arrests included the leader of the group involved in the 2022 smuggling operation. He faces extradition to the United States, while the others face charges in Guatemala.
lead_paragraph: A man accused of taking part in a human-smuggling operation that led to the deaths of 53 migrants in Texas has been indicted by a federal grand jury in one of the deadliest episodes involving migrants on the southern border of the United States, federal prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Word of the Day: resonate
abstract: This word has appeared in 434 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word resonate has appeared in 434 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 2 in “My Unlikely Path From Jail to Journalism” by Mario Koran:

headline: Corrections: Aug. 22, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about a conflict of interest in the decision to give the bronze medal to Romanian gymnast, Ana Barbosu, over America’s Jordan Chiles, misstated the name of the institution that first published details of the case. It is the International Institute for Conflict Prevention and Resolution, not the International Institute for Conflict Resolution and Prevention.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For China’s Road Trip Heroine, A Bold Step on a New Journey
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Even though money is very important, freedom is more important.”

headline: Seth Meyers Approves of the Obamas Dissing Donald Trump
abstract: The “Late Night” host remarked that former President Barack Obama burned Donald Trump “without even saying a word” on Day 2 of the D.N.C.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: In the Wake of Tragedy, CrossFit Faces an Identity Crisis
abstract: CrossFit has found success as a training exercise for everyone. But the CrossFit Games may tell a different story.
lead_paragraph: The atmosphere at the closing ceremony of the CrossFit Games last week at the Dickies Arena, a 14,000-seat venue in Fort Worth, was decidedly solemn.

headline: The Trials of a Paralympian Whose Disability Doesn’t Always Show
abstract: Christie Raleigh Crossley has trained for most of her life to be an Olympic swimmer. After surviving two car crashes and a brain deformity, she is finally going for gold.
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to the Paralympics, which start next week in Paris, Christie Raleigh Crossley’s coach asked her a serious question.

headline: The U.S. Open Is Free This Week. Yes, Really.
abstract: “Fan Week” draws thousands during the qualifying rounds of the tournament, no tickets necessary. You still have to pay for the cocktails, of course.
