headline: Watching Their Differences ‘Fade Away’ Like a Snow Globe
abstract: Abi Sommers grew up in a conservative family, while Forrest Gray was raised in a household of creatives. Yet when the two met in college nine years ago, each felt an attraction to the other.
lead_paragraph: Abigail Sommers and Forrest Gray met in January 2015 when both joined Delta Kappa Alpha, an organization at the University of Southern California for students interested in the cinematic arts. The two pledged by participating in challenging group activities, like making a Wes Anderson-style horror film in 24 hours or wearing a beret continuously for a semester. “They said you could only take the beret off for the three S’s — sleep, sex and shower,” Mr. Gray said.

headline: ‘The Fake Grey Lady’ Has Her Own Love Story to Tell
abstract: When Selena Coppock, a former comedian who runs social media accounts that parody New York Times weddings, met Aaron Allietta her views on marriage became more than a punchline.
lead_paragraph: Selena Evelyn Coppock has been reading The New York Times Weddings section since she was about 12. “It all seemed so exciting and glamorous to a girl growing up outside of Boston,” Ms. Coppock said.

headline: Looking for My Mother in All the Wrong People
abstract: Until I held my son for the first time.
lead_paragraph: My cousin and I were standing on the balcony of her house in Lahore, smoking cigarettes in the breezeless night. It was my second trip to Pakistan that year. The first time, I hadn’t visited home in four years and needed to buy wedding clothes. The second time, just two months later, I bought my ticket on impulse. Relatives needled me, shocked at the expense of flying twice from Toronto.

headline: Slow and Steady Wins the Game of Love for These Sports Professionals
abstract: The pandemic forced Monica McNutt, a basketball commentator, and Justin Jackson, the director of basketball operations for the National Basketball Players Association, to continue their relationship from afar.
lead_paragraph: During golden hour on the beach in St. George’s, Grenada, on Sept. 1, 2023, Justin Alexander Jackson suggested that he and Monica Corin McNutt take a couple of selfies. After setting a timer on his phone, Mr. Jackson posed for a photo with Ms. McNutt, then pulled out an engagement ring, bent to his knee and asked her to marry him.

headline: Why Jackson Hole Is the Fed’s Biggest Shindig
abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City’s annual conference in Wyoming gets a lot of buzz. Here’s why it matters for Wall Street and the economy.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has flipped through newspapers or business television channels this week might have noticed two words on repeat: Jackson Hole.

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Starbucks C.E.O.’s New Commute: A Thousand Miles on the Company Plane
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You’re buying a narrative. You’re not just buying the coffee.”

headline: Corrections: Aug. 23, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the recovery of the bodies of four passengers believed to have been aboard the Bayesian, a yacht that sank off the coast of Sicily, transposed the number of crew members and passengers on the yacht. There were 10 crew members and 12 passengers, not the other way around.

headline: ‘The Killer’ Review: John Woo With a French Twist
abstract: Woo’s new version of his Hong Kong action movie “The Killer,” starring Nathalie Emmanuel and Omar Sy, may be a remake, but it’s not a retread.
lead_paragraph: When he started a run of contemporary action movies in the early 1980s, the Hong Kong director John Woo forged a personal mode influenced by the stylized violence of American directors like Sam Peckinpah and Don Siegel (see the shootouts in “The Getaway” and “Dirty Harry”), and the mentholated cool of the French filmmaker Jean-Pierre Melville (à la the existential assassin of “Le Samouraï”). Before taking up in Hong Kong again in 2008, Woo created some galvanizing work in the United States: “Face/Off” (1997) and “Mission: Impossible 2” (2000).

headline: A History Museum Shows How China Wants to Remake Hong Kong
abstract: A new exhibit calls for the city’s residents to be patriotic, loyal to the Chinese Communist Party and ever vigilant to supposed threats to the state.
lead_paragraph: The Hong Kong Museum of History was the place to go to understand the city’s transformation from fishing village to a glittering metropolis. It housed a life-size replica of a traditional fishing boat and a recreation of a 19th-century street lined with shops.

headline: Families of Dead Hostages Vent Anger at Israeli Leaders Over War
abstract: After Israel recovered the bodies of six men who died in Hamas captivity in Gaza, survivors accused the government of sinking the chances of hostages returning alive through a cease-fire deal.
lead_paragraph: The bodies returned for the final time to the villages that, in life, they had called home. Months of anguished waiting at an end, mourners embraced, wept, read tributes and lowered into the soil the remains of Israeli hostages recovered this week from the Gaza Strip.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: The final night of the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 80 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: Kamala Harris’s Stepdaughter Ella Emhoff Speaks at the D.N.C.
abstract: Continuing the D.N.C.’s family theme, Vice President Kamala Harris’s stepdaughter Ella Emhoff took the stage on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: Continuing the D.N.C.’s family theme, Vice President Kamala Harris’s stepdaughter Ella Emhoff took the stage on Thursday night.

headline: U.S. Accuses Software Maker RealPage of Enabling Collusion on Rents
abstract: The Justice Department filed an antitrust suit against the real estate software company, accusing it of creating an illegal pricing scheme to charge tenants more.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department filed an antitrust lawsuit on Friday against the real estate software company RealPage, saying its software enabled landlords to collude to raise rents across the United States.

headline: ‘Central Park 5’ Describe Trump’s Character
abstract: The men – who now prefer to be called the Exonerated Five — recalled how Donald Trump spent $85,000 on a full-page ad in The New York Times calling for their execution.
lead_paragraph: The men – who now prefer to be called the Exonerated Five — recalled how Donald Trump spent $85,000 on a full-page ad in The New York Times calling for their execution.

headline: Best, Worst and Oddest Moments of the Democratic Convention
abstract: The party’s four-day gathering featured memorable zingers, self-effacing humor and more than a few lines that didn’t land.
lead_paragraph: Every convention has its highlights and low points, and the hastily revised Democratic convention was no exception. More than 100 speakers took the stage at the United Center in Chicago over four nights, and their speaking abilities ranged from excellent to, well, kind of bumbling.

headline: Democrats Show That Republicans Aren’t the Only Ones Who Can Wrap Themselves in the Flag
abstract: From references to the Olympics to odes to freedom, Democrats used their nominating convention to stake their claim on patriotism.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 15 minutes, the United Center in Chicago was a blur of American flags fluttering in the air. Thousands of Democratic delegates, on hand to hear Kamala Harris accept her party’s nomination, chanted “USA! USA!” as they sang along to “Texas Hold ’Em” by Beyoncé and “Born in the USA” by Bruce Springsteen.

headline: Full Transcript of Kamala Harris’s Democratic Convention Speech
abstract: The vice president’s remarks lasted roughly 35 minutes on the final night of the convention in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: This is a transcript of Vice President Kamala Harris’s speech on Thursday night in which she formally accepted the Democratic Party’s nomination for the presidency.

headline: Kamala Harris Was ‘Confident, Principled — Presidential’: The Best and Worst Moments From Night 4 of the Democratic Convention
abstract: What our columnists and contributors thought of her speech, and those of Gretchen Whitmer, Roy Cooper and more.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Opinion’s commentary for Night 4 of the Democratic National Convention. In this special feature, Times Opinion writers rate the evening on a scale of 0 to 10: 0 means the night was a disaster for Kamala Harris; 10 means it could lead to a big polling bump. Here’s what our columnists and contributors thought of the event, which included speeches by Gretchen Whitmer, Gabby Giffords and Kamala Harris.

headline: 5 Takeaways From the Democratic Convention
abstract: A history-making candidate told grounded stories. Democrats expanded their anti-Trump playbook. And even if something “magical is in the air” for the party, as Michelle Obama said, there’s a hard road ahead.
lead_paragraph: A month and a day after Democrats made a change, Kamala Harris has the party faithful believing.

headline: Dialing In to Fox News, Trump Offers a Rambling Rebuttal to Harris’s Speech
abstract: The network ended the live interview after 10 minutes. Beeps could be heard as the former president seemed to accidentally press the buttons on the keypad of his phone.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump was watching television on Thursday night and he did not like what he saw.

headline: On Gaza, Democrats’ Most Divisive Issue, Harris Embraces Biden’s Balancing Act
abstract: With her party torn between pro-Israel Democrats and younger progressives, she’s looking for a way to quiet one major issue until after the election.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris on Thursday finally addressed the most divisive issue of the Democratic convention — the war in Gaza — she signaled she would pick up almost exactly where President Biden left off.

headline: Word of the Day: smattering
abstract: This word has appeared in 136 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word smattering has appeared in 136 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 10 in “They Called It ‘Improper’ to Have Women in the Olympics. But She Persisted” by John Branch:

headline: Celebrities and Notable Faces in the Crowd at the Democratic Convention
abstract: See some of the prominent people spotted at Chicago’s United Center this week as Democrats gathered to nominate Vice President Kamala Harris for president.
lead_paragraph: See some of the prominent people spotted at Chicago’s United Center this week as Democrats gathered to nominate Vice President Kamala Harris for president.

headline: Democrats Taste Victory in November. But Are They Too Confident?
abstract: At the Democratic National Convention, party leaders warned against happy talk and said former President Donald J. Trump remains a formidable opponent.
lead_paragraph: Democrats were giddy. After months of hand-wringing and pessimism before President Biden stepped aside, they were finally excited again.

headline: South Korea Battery Plant Rushed Production Before Deadly Fire, Police Say
abstract: The fire, one of the country’s worst industrial disasters in recent years, happened as the factory was rushing to fulfill a military contract, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The fire at a lithium battery plant in South Korea that killed 23 workers in June broke out after the factory’s operator rushed production, ignored signs of danger and provided no safety training to employees, investigators said on Friday.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,162
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: At the Ballpark, a Reporter Roots for Lahaina
abstract: Last year, a Times reporter covered the wildfires that destroyed a town on the island of Maui. This year, he cheered on a team from Maui as it made its way to the Little League World Series.
lead_paragraph: Recently, my colleagues and I at The New York Times were finishing up a package of articles tied to the first anniversary of the devastating wildfire that wiped away the Hawaiian town of Lahaina, on Maui. We had pieces on how the town’s rich history was shaping discussions about rebuilding; the thousands of people who have left the island, forming a vast diaspora of Lahaina refugees; and the lessons learned by the authorities as they tried to prevent another deadly fire.

headline: David Copperfield Vanished. The Problem of His Penthouse Remains.
abstract: Residents of the Galleria, a Midtown Manhattan apartment building, sued Mr. Copperfield, saying he left his once-ornate condominium in disrepair.
lead_paragraph: The new penthouse owner arrived at the stately Galleria building in Manhattan practically unnoticed, as if standing on a dark stage just before the curtain is raised.

headline: Free Booze, a Lake Cruise and Selfies Galore: How Democrats Courted Influencers at the D.N.C.
abstract: Democrats gave social media figures the V.I.P. treatment this week in an aggressive attempt to pump feeds with pro-Harris posts.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Kristin Brey, a podcaster, radio host and newspaper columnist, attended the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee as a credentialed journalist. She set up shop in a dank hockey arena, jostled in scrums with reporters for interviews and often could not get access to the floor of the convention hall because there was not enough space.

headline: ‘Incoming’ Review: Not Another Teen Movie
abstract: Freshman engage in some fairly predictable debauchery in this routine high school gross-out comedy streaming on Netflix.
lead_paragraph: “Incoming,” a bawdy teen comedy from the directors Dave and John Chernin, opens with a familiar gag: an awkward adolescent boy (Mason Thames) delivers a speech to the camera professing his love, only for a cut to reveal that he’s actually rehearsing in the mirror. In a genre rank with cliché, this is not a very promising start — it suggests that the Chernins, who also penned the screenplay, are satisfied with whatever joke is closest to hand.

headline: Jon Stewart Goes Live From Chicago on the Last Night of the D.N.C.
abstract: After Kamala Harris accepted the nomination, Stewart mused: “How funny would it have been if at the end she was like, ‘But seriously, though: not for me.’”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: What Voters Outside the Democratic Bubble Thought of Harris’s Speech
abstract: They are not leaping onto the Democratic Party bandwagon. But one undecided voter said, “Maybe it’s not as hard to vote for her.”
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, it was up to Kamala Harris to make the closing argument for why Democrats deserved another four years in the White House. In her headlining speech of the Democratic National Convention, which had been as festive, and at times as frivolous, as a giant block party, Ms. Harris spoke of standing up to global tyranny, and of lessons she learned from her single mother. She blasted the former President Donald J. Trump as an “unserious man” and spoke of the “awesome responsibility” that comes with the privilege of being an American.

headline: Kamala Came to Slay
abstract: The Democratic presidential nominee was both smart and scorching on the final night of the party’s convention.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris had a message for America about Donald Trump and JD Vance on Thursday night.

headline: Harris Wants America to See Itself in Her
abstract: The vice president’s speech sought to reassure Americans of her values even as many may be unfamiliar with her background.
lead_paragraph: With her acceptance of the Democratic nomination for president, Kamala Harris simultaneously made American history and invited the nation to help her craft the next chapter of it.

headline: Sydney Metro Expands, Opening to Celebrity-Level Fanfare
abstract: In a mostly car-dependent country where public transportation in major cities can be best described as “decent,” the expansion felt momentous.
lead_paragraph: They arrived well before dawn, some from across the city or even from other states. Hundreds of people, some with signs or handmade shirts, others with hair dyed or nails painted for the occasion, waited in line, hoping to be among the first to glimpse the new arrival in Sydney. They were joined by just about every news media outlet in the city.

headline: What Makes Good Chemistry? For Chat Podcasts, It’s Fundamental
abstract: The popular podcast genre makes the generation of compelling conversation look effortless. In reality, it’s anything but.
lead_paragraph: Naomi Fry, a critic and podcast host, had something to get off her chest.

headline: ‘A Box of Surprises’: a Rotterdam Apartment That’s Only 74 Square Feet
abstract: Two architects in the Netherlands made the most of the tiniest of spaces, “maximizing absolutely everything.”
lead_paragraph: Even Le Corbusier appreciated cabin porn. In 1952, the modernist architect built a tiny log house on the French Riviera that he could visit every summer: 144 square feet with a Mediterranean view. Outfitted with austere custom furnishings but no kitchen (it was next to a restaurant), the Cabanon, as he called it, still stands, a work of gorgeous restraint.

headline: Practice Flights and Calm Spaces: Making Room for Neurodivergent Travelers
abstract: Airlines, hotels, theme parks and others are working to ease the challenges of travel for people with autism, A.D.H.D and other “invisible disabilities.”
lead_paragraph: After decades of caring for his autistic son, Ryan, Adam Murphy, a 51-year-old father of three from Gloucestershire, England, noticed that Ryan, 27, was becoming a bit more open to trying new things. His son, Mr. Murphy realized, might be able to take his first airplane ride.

headline: He Raps About Kids’ Books and Grammar, and He Has Fans
abstract: Faced with a roomful of bored students, Jacob Mitchell found a way to make adverbs fun. Now his classroom is global.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Mitchell started out as a star student. At Foulds School, just north of London, he did his homework, enjoyed the perks of being a teacher’s son and discovered rap while performing “Boom! Shake the Room” in an “epic” talent show when he was 9.

headline: ‘Rings of Power’ Returns, With More Creatures and More Evil
abstract: For its second season, the creators of Amazon’s pricey “Lord of the Rings” prequel aim to raise the bar, and have leaned into psychodrama.
lead_paragraph: What does it take to bring Tolkien’s Middle-earth to life? In part, ambition on a scale to rival the fantasy writer’s epic tales, if the set for Amazon’s “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power” is any indication.

headline: Heat Kills Thousands in the U.S. Every Year. Why Are the Deaths So Hard to Track?
abstract: As heat waves become more frequent and intense, researchers and activists say the lack of precise data is leading to needless fatalities.
lead_paragraph: After a string of scorching days in June 2023, the body of an 88-year-old man was discovered in his home in Maricopa County, Ariz. His air-conditioner, set to 70, was blowing hot air. The temperature inside was nearly 110 degrees. Maybe he had heart problems. Maybe a different organ broke down. Maybe he was taking medications that did not work as they should. Did extreme heat cause or contribute to his death?

headline: How Psychedelic Research Got High on Its Own Supply
abstract: There’s an extraordinary hype that psychedelics will change how we treat mental illness. But the bubble might have just burst.
lead_paragraph: Things weren’t supposed to go this way. The drug company Lykos Therapeutics had spent much of this year expecting to vault to meteoric heights. It had sent an application to the Food and Drug Administration seeking approval to use MDMA to treat post-traumatic stress disorder. Lykos expected F.D.A. approval; it was banking on it.

headline: The Children’s Fantasy Novel That Flew Off Britain’s Shelves
abstract: “Impossible Creatures” has prompted comparisons to Tolkien, Lewis and Pullman, but action, not awe, is Katherine Rundell’s strong suit.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Rundell, a fellow of St. Catherine’s College at Oxford, belongs to that university’s longstanding tradition of combining scholarship — her biography of John Donne, “Super-Infinite,” won the Baillie Gifford Prize — with writing beloved children’s fiction. “Impossible Creatures,” Rundell’s sixth novel for middle grade readers, became an instant best seller in her native Britain when it was published last year and has garnered numerous awards, including the Waterstones Book of the Year.

headline: On Luxurious Ibiza, Essential Workers Are Forced to Live in Tent Cities
abstract: The Spanish island fills beachfront hotels and glittering dance clubs with wealthy tourists. But its teachers, firefighters and police officers can’t find a place to live.
lead_paragraph: At 1,900 euros a month, the rent was not cheap. But Alicia Bocuñano still felt fortunate to find an apartment on Ibiza at that price. As a taxi driver pulling 16-hour days, Ms. Bocuñano, a single mother who grew up on this Spanish island, figured that a surplus from the busy summer months might be enough to make the rent.

headline: Scientists Made a List of Lost Birds and Now They Want Us to Find Them
abstract: Some 144 bird species had not been seen in at least a decade, but a project by conservation organizations proposes they all may still be hidden somewhere in the wild.
lead_paragraph: In 2022, an ornithologist high in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta mountains of northern Colombia spotted the shimmering emerald green and cobalt blue feathers of the Santa Marta sabrewing. A large hummingbird, it had only been documented twice since 1879. As the bird sat on a branch the ornithologist, Yurgen Vega, captured images.

headline: How to Keep School Lunches Hot (or Cold), and Other Food Safety Questions, Answered
abstract: Keep your little ones safe from food poisoning with a few simple considerations.
lead_paragraph: The love language of packing a school lunch is strangely at odds with the most basic of food safety rules.

headline: ‘I Like It Here’: Aging Wistfully in the Hudson Valley
abstract: Looking back at the lives he and his friends led, the documentarian Ralph Arlyck delivers a memoir, an essay on mortality and a portrait of his community.
lead_paragraph: “I got taxied into the world in the middle of the last century,” a man’s voice says at the start of “I Like It Here” (at the Firehouse theater in New York). We’re gliding slowly across a green rural landscape. “This is where I live now,” he continues. “I’m 78.”

headline: Zoë Kravitz Needed a Place to Put Her Frustrations. So She Made a Movie.
abstract: Her directorial debut, the #MeToo horror-mystery “Blink Twice,” examines power dynamics between men and women.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2017, Zoë Kravitz, on a break from shooting a movie, posted up at a cafe in London with her laptop and began drafting her first full screenplay.

headline: $1.9 Million Homes in Hamburg
abstract: An Art-Nouveau villa with a historic designation, a five-bedroom semidetached home and a flexible four-bedroom ‘coffee mill’ house.
lead_paragraph: Built in 1891, this home features nearly 12-foot-high ceilings and original details such as decorative brick and filigree window panes. Though renovated in a contemporary style, the interior retains its Art Nouveau aesthetic with herringbone wood floors, stained glass, etched- and lead-crystal windows, and decorative staircase spindles.

headline: Catch a Space Movie, and the Sunset, at the Intrepid
abstract: The former aircraft carrier now docked in the Hudson River will host the finale of its free summer movie series on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today, and on Fridays through the summer, we’ll focus on things to do in New York over the weekend.

headline: How to Be Truly Free: Lessons From a Philosopher President
abstract: Pepe Mujica, Uruguay’s spartan former president and plain-spoken philosopher, offers wisdom from a rich life as he battles cancer.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, the world had a brief fascination with José Mujica. He was the folksy president of Uruguay who had shunned his nation’s presidential palace to live in a tiny tin-roof home with his wife and three-legged dog.

headline: What We Learned About Harris — and the Democrats — This Week
abstract: The hosts argue Kamala Harris’s speech was a “joyful but not transformational” moment for the Democrats.
lead_paragraph: The hosts react to Kamala Harris’s convention speech in this special late-night edition of “Matter of Opinion.” Columnists Lydia Polgreen, Ross Douthat and Carlos Lozada unpack how Harris had a “deft threading of a number of tricky needles” as she accepted her party’s nomination, and look at what the entire week revealed about the Democratic Party.

headline: Why We Love a Movie Star in a White T-Shirt
abstract: No garment is simpler. No garment has more star power onscreen.
lead_paragraph: This is the first installment of Visual Studies, a series that explores how images move through and shape culture.

headline: In Maine, a Father-Daughter Team Wins a Lobster Boat Race
abstract: Jeremy Beal, a boat builder and lobsterman, had a simple strategy: “Point it and punch it!” His 14-year-old daughter took it from there.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of boats zipped across Casco Bay during the Maine Lobster Boat Races on Saturday. Only one had a purple bottom.

headline: Protests at the Democrats’ Convention Weren’t as Big and Disruptive as Some Expected
abstract: Pro-Palestinian organizers predicted overwhelming turnout that would take their case directly to the Democrats. Protesters gathered, but they did not steal the show.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t 1968. It wasn’t even close.

headline: In ‘Shogun,’ Anna Sawai Drew On the Power of Silence. And Mozart.
abstract: “It gives me confidence,” she said about her first Emmy nomination, for best actress in a drama. “I have such bad impostor syndrome.”
lead_paragraph: This interview contains major spoilers for Season 1 of “Shogun.”

headline: 10 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: Ben (Jason Schwartzman), a cantor at a local synagogue who is grieving the loss of his wife, reconnects with his former music teacher in this touching dramedy directed by Nathan Silver.

headline: Medication Mistakes Pharmacists Want You to Stop Making
abstract: Common habits like storing pills in your medicine cabinet can reduce their effectiveness, experts say.
lead_paragraph: I recently visited my parents, and I was ransacking their kitchen for snacks when I noticed something: Their medications were in a cabinet near their oven.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the comedy “Between the Temples.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the comedy “Between the Temples.”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, August 23, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: Two Armed Rebels Who Led a Nation: A Love Story
abstract: José Mujica and Lucía Topolansky have long been married to one another — and their leftist political cause.
lead_paragraph: He led a band of armed rebels. She was an expert in forging documents. They robbed banks, they staged prison breaks and they were in love.

headline: My Son and Gus Walz Deserve a Champion Like Tim Walz
abstract: If the Harris-Walz ticket wins, will parents of people who struggle with being different at last find a powerful advocate in the White House?
lead_paragraph: The sight at the Democratic convention on Wednesday night of Tim Walz’s 17-year-old son leaping to his feet, with streaming eyes, a hand to his chest with a cry of “That’s my Dad” was heart piercing.

headline: Horse Racing Is Starved for Star Power. Could Thorpedo Anna Change That?
abstract: On Saturday, Kenny McPeek’s 3-year-old will try to be the first filly since 1915 to win the Travers Stakes. It could be a boon for a sport whose popularity has dipped.
lead_paragraph: Kenny McPeek is as close to a Renaissance man as horse racing has to offer.

headline: Putin Is Getting Rattled
abstract: The surprise incursion into Kursk has given Ukraine an advantage over Russia in the propaganda battle, an important front in this conflict.
lead_paragraph: In purely military terms, Ukraine’s surprise incursion of Russia earlier this month is a dubious gamble. Moscow has not diverted forces from its grinding advances on the Donetsk front, a main focus of the current fighting, and the physical cost in dead or captured troops and evacuated citizens does not concern Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin.

headline: Billionaire Donors Have It Out for This Legal Prodigy, but President Harris Will Need Her
abstract: Lina Khan of the F.T.C. would be crucial to efforts to combat price gouging.
lead_paragraph: Until about a week ago, a big question in Democratic politics was whether a potential President Kamala Harris would keep Lina Khan — the pathbreaking young lawyer loved by progressives and loathed by some of Harris’s billionaire donors — as chair of the Federal Trade Commission, the agency that enforces antimonopoly law.

headline: Conan O’Brien’s Secret (Hot) Sauce
abstract: How the comedian has stayed so funny, for so long.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Conan O’Brien appeared on the YouTube series “Hot Ones.” What started as a thoughtful interview soon devolved into a comedic master class.

headline: What Happened to the A.I. Election? + ChatGPT for Mayor + The Productivity Tools We’re Using
abstract: “It’s happening, but people don’t want it public.”
lead_paragraph: This week, we discuss why so few campaigns seem to be experimenting with A.I. The Times’s Sheera Frenkel joins us with examples of the many different artificial intelligence products that have been turned down by campaigns in this election cycle, from A.I.-generated endorsements from long-dead historical figures to a synthetic version of Donald Trump. Then, we interview the Wyoming man who ran for mayor on the promise that he would exclusively use a customized ChatGPT bot to run the city. And finally, it’s time for a tech check. We run down the apps we’re using to become more productive.

headline: Mapping Ukraine’s Surprise Invasion of Russia
abstract: Ukraine has captured dozens of Russian settlements, adding a new twist to a war that had largely settled into grueling fighting in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has captured dozens of Russian settlements, adding a new twist to a war that had largely settled into grueling fighting in eastern Ukraine.

headline: With $20 Billion Weapons Deal, U.S. Aims to Help Israel and Deter Iran
abstract: The White House has told Congress it is allowing the sale of $20 billion in arms to Israel. Here’s what’s in the package.
lead_paragraph: For months, the Biden administration waited to formally approve $20 billion in future American weapons sales to Israel, including F-15s and medium-range missiles. The official notification to Congress was finally announced last week — right before Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken traveled to Israel in a bid to nail down a cease-fire agreement with Hamas.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 440
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, Aug. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Harris Makes Her Case, and the New Covid Vaccine
abstract: Plus, an aquarium bids farewell to a queer icon.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: At the Democratic Convention, a Historic Nomination
abstract: What story did the Democrats tell about Kamala Harris? And will it be enough to win?
lead_paragraph: Last night, at the Democratic National Convention, Vice President Kamala Harris accepted her party’s nomination, becoming the first woman of color in U.S. history to do so.

headline: Indian Leader Visits Kyiv as Ukraine Pushes Diplomacy
abstract: Ukrainian officials were portraying the visit by Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India as a welcome show of support for their country during the war with Russia.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India visited Kyiv on Friday, furthering a diplomatic effort by Ukraine to engage non-Western nations in potential settlement talks with Russia, even as Ukraine’s military pressed ahead with an offensive into Russian territory.

headline: The Biggest Speech of Kamala Harris’s Career
abstract: Presenting herself as a pragmatic leader who could unite all Americans behind a “new way forward,” Vice President Kamala Harris accepted the Democratic Party’s nomination for president. Zolan Kanno-Youngs, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, gives his takeaways.
lead_paragraph: Presenting herself as a pragmatic leader who could unite all Americans behind a “new way forward,” Vice President Kamala Harris accepted the Democratic Party’s nomination for president. Zolan Kanno-Youngs, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, gives his takeaways.

headline: Why Kamala Harris’s Centrism Is Working
abstract: The vice president’s convention speech embodied her efforts to win over swing voters.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris capped her first month as the Democratic Party’s presidential candidate with a roughly 35-minute convention speech last night that embodied her aggressive efforts to win over swing voters.

headline: Nepal Asks China to Wipe Away a Loan It Can’t Afford to Pay Back
abstract: A new government in Nepal formally asked for relief from a $216 million debt it incurred for construction of an airport in Pokhara that has been beset by problems.
lead_paragraph: When Nepal’s new international airport opened last year in one of the country’s biggest cities, it was the type of landmark project expected to elevate the fortunes of one of Asia’s poorest countries while deepening its ties with China, which built and financed the project.

headline: The Defining Moments of the D.N.C. Finale
abstract: In accepting the nomination, Kamala Harris told her story and made a pitch for the coalition of voters she’ll need.
lead_paragraph: On the final night of the Democratic National Convention, Vice President Kamala Harris took the stage and formally accepted her party’s nomination.

headline: Final Body Is Recovered From Yacht That Sank Off Sicily
abstract: Hannah Lynch, the 18-year-old daughter of the British tech entrepreneur Mike Lynch, was on board a yacht that was hit by a storm and went down in the early hours on Monday.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a week after a violent storm sent a luxury yacht to the bottom of the sea off the coast of Sicily, Italian scuba divers plunged deep underwater, moving through ropes and fallen objects inside the yacht in a desperate search for the six people missing.

headline: The Donor Report Card on Harris
abstract: Taxes, antitrust, closer ties with business: These were some of the issues corporate backers sought more clarity on at the Democratic National Convention.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s acceptance speech may have been short on the details policy watchers were seeking, but she presented a sweeping vision for how she plans to grow an economy that’s showing signs of slowing. “I will bring together labor and workers and small-business owners and entrepreneurs and American companies to create jobs,” she told the Democratic National Convention last night.

headline: Deadly Floods Strike Troubled Bangladesh
abstract: Disaster has hit just weeks after mass protests led to a lethal crackdown and then prompted the abrupt flight of the long-serving prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Floods in Bangladesh have killed at least 13 people and affected millions of others in the country’s northeast, adding to the challenges of an interim government struggling to return order to a country plunged into anarchy after mass protests forced out its autocratic leader.

headline: Ukraine Steps Up Strikes Into Russia as Moscow Pushes Ahead in the East
abstract: Ukraine struck a port across from Crimea and damaged a cargo ferry. But Kyiv’s forces continued to struggle in eastern areas under a relentless Russian assault.
lead_paragraph: As Ukrainian forces fight to isolate a large group of Russian soldiers caught between a river in Russia’s Kursk Province and the Ukrainian border, Kyiv has launched a series of strikes at airfields, ports and oil depots in other regions of Russia aimed at degrading the Kremlin’s war effort.

headline: If Your Debt Is Ballooning, There Are Steps You Can Take
abstract: More borrowers have been falling behind on their credit card bills and are paying more for basic banking services, like A.T.M. fees.
lead_paragraph: Americans are increasingly struggling with credit card debt and other loans, and consumers are paying more for basic banking services like A.T.M. withdrawals, recent financial research finds.

headline: Coming of Age in 2024: Explore Your Political Identity and Values
abstract: What can you show or tell us to help explain what it’s like to grow up in this political moment? Submit in words, images, audio or video, from Oct. 2 to Nov. 4.
lead_paragraph: Every fall since 2020, we have extended an open-ended invitation to teenagers to document, reflect on or express any aspect, big or small, of what it means to be growing up right now.

headline: Harris Faces Challenge of Translating Convention Joy to Fall Momentum
abstract: The newly anointed Democratic presidential nominee revived a demoralized party. But as she leaves Chicago, a bruising, closely fought contest awaits her.
lead_paragraph: Joy cometh in the morning, but so do hangovers. The party in Chicago is done, the confetti has been swept up, the pictures have been posted to social media. But the real question as exuberant Democrats woke up on Friday was whether they could channel the sheer intoxication of the United Center into a sustained, 74-day sprint to Election Day.

headline: Russia Quashes Deadly Prison Mutiny by Islamist Inmates
abstract: The revolt is the latest in a series of terrorist attacks in Russia claimed by Islamic militants.
lead_paragraph: Russian commandos quashed a mutiny at a southern Russian prison on Friday, killing the attackers and freeing their hostages, according to the local governor.

headline: Book Club: Let’s Talk About ‘My Brilliant Friend’
abstract: The first novel in Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan quartet was just voted the best book of the 21st century. We like it too.
lead_paragraph: This July, The New York Times Book Review published a list of The 100 Best Books of the 21st Century, chosen by 503 literary luminaries. The No. 1 book was “My Brilliant Friend,” by Elena Ferrante, translated by Ann Goldstein. And it wasn’t just critics and writers who loved the book; “My Brilliant Friend” came in at No. 8 in our readers’ choice list.

headline: Guggenheim Curator Will Stage Exhibition of Caribbean Diaspora
abstract: The National Gallery of Jamaica has selected Ashley James to organize the 2024 Kingston Biennial, which opens in December.
lead_paragraph: The National Gallery of Jamaica announced on Friday that the curator Ashley James would organize this year’s Kingston Biennial, a showcase of artists from the Caribbean and African diasporas that aims to link the regional art scene with international audiences.

headline: Fed Chair Powell Signals ‘Time Has Come’ for September Rate Cut
abstract: Jerome H. Powell made it clear that the Federal Reserve will cut rates on Sept. 18, as the central bank turns the corner in its fight against inflation.
lead_paragraph: Speaking in his most closely watched speech of the year, Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, clearly signaled on Friday that the central bank was poised to cut interest rates in September.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Is Expected to End his Independent Presidential Campaign
abstract: Kennedy filed paperwork Thursday to withdraw from the ballot in Arizona, and has been in talks about endorsing Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is expected to end his troubled independent presidential campaign on Friday, according to three people briefed on his plans, and has been in talks to throw his support behind former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: John Lansing, Who Guided NPR Through Tumultuous Times, Dies at 67
abstract: He led the broadcasting organization during the coronavirus pandemic, a decline in revenue and a period of extreme political polarization.
lead_paragraph: John Lansing, who as chief executive from 2019 until earlier this year guided NPR through a global pandemic, an imploding media landscape and widening political polarization that called into question some of its journalistic principles, died on Aug. 14 at his home in Eagle River, Wis. He was 67.

headline: ‘Lie to Fly’: The Story of the Pilot Accused of Attempting to Down a Plane After Taking Mushrooms
abstract: Our new documentary explores why many pilots struggle to seek mental health treatment, and the urgent calls for industry reform.
lead_paragraph: Watch our new documentary on FX and Hulu starting Friday, Aug. 23, at 10 p.m. Eastern.

headline: Kamala Harris’s Main-Character Energy
abstract: Accepting the nomination, the vice president completed a whirlwind ascent — and sought to finally supplant Donald Trump at the center of America’s political drama.
lead_paragraph: There were a lot of big names at the Democratic National Convention. Night 1 had the unprecedented send-off of a sitting president. Night 2 had not one but two Obamas (plus a raucous roll call of states feat. Lil Jon). Night 3: You get Oprah! And you get Oprah!

headline: Biden’s National Security Adviser Will Visit China Next Week
abstract: A final meeting between President Biden and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, is also likely to come up.
lead_paragraph: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser at the White House, will travel to China next week to meet with Wang Yi, the country’s foreign minister, in their latest high-level meeting aimed at defusing tensions.

headline: At Edinburgh Festival, Sometimes Simpler Is Better
abstract: The event’s best theater production avoided the gimmicks of other shows in favor of well-drawn characters and well-written dialogue.
lead_paragraph: If you say “Edinburgh Festival” to most people, they’ll probably think of the Fringe. But the Fringe — primarily a showcase of up-and-coming acts from English-speaking countries — is actually an offshoot of the more global, highbrow and judiciously curated Edinburgh International Festival, and the two events run side-by-side.

headline: Along U.S. Route 144, Scenes of the Demoralizing American Grind
abstract: In “Orange Blossom Trail,” the photographer Joshua Lutz and the author George Saunders pay tribute to the hard living across one stretch of American highway.
lead_paragraph: With an austere frankness, the 62 photos by Joshua Lutz in ORANGE BLOSSOM TRAIL (Image Text Ithaca Press, $40) document the hard living, low-wage jobs and big-box landscapes along a single stretch of highway that runs 400 miles from Georgia to Miami, cutting right through Orlando, Fla.

headline: What School Nurses Want Parents to Know
abstract: The stalwarts of children’s health shared their tips and gripes.
lead_paragraph: Carren Teitelbaum, a school nurse in Ramapo, N.Y., once had a student stumble into her office with a 102 degree fever. Mrs. Teitelbaum called his mother, who said she’d given her son Tylenol that had likely worn off and that she could come give him more.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: In this month’s picks, a yoga teacher in Argentina adjusts to life after divorce, a young woman in London struggles to move past her painful past and more.
lead_paragraph: The Argentine director Martín Rejtman has accumulated a body of deceptively profound comedies over the last four decades, the likes of which are hard to find in American cinema. Often spiraling out of absurd premises, they are low-key but whip-smart dramas about the tragicomedy of everyday human relations, which sneak up on you with their sharp analysis of life under modern-day capitalism. His latest, “The Practice,” follows in this vein.

headline: The Hidden Splendors of Cleveland’s Museums
abstract: It’s not too late to enjoy some lake weather in Cleveland, where the ice cream is fabulous and there’s never any shortage of art to see — let our critic tell you where.
lead_paragraph: In the depths of summer, while other art lovers in New York are catching the B train to Brighton Beach or busy with parties in the Hamptons, I like to enjoy a week or two of lake weather in Cleveland, where my in-laws live, where the ice cream is fabulous — and where there’s no shortage of art to see. In years past I’ve visited Praxis Fiber Workshop and the Sculpture Center — both of which make ingenious use of the huge spaces that a postindustrial city can offer — as well as the Museum of Contemporary Art Cleveland. But these are the places that caught me this time.

headline: I Just Love Button Mushrooms
abstract: Whether browned in butter and stuffed with cheese or, as in this mushroom and eggplant yassa, simmered with caramelized onion and brightened with lime.
lead_paragraph: Did you think I was going to go away after one newsletter? LOL.

headline: How Democrats Honed Their Attack on Trump
abstract: At the Democratic National Convention this week, Vice President Kamala Harris and her allies refined their attack on former President Donald J. Trump. Maggie Haberman, senior political correspondent for The New York Times, explains how Democrats worked to minimize and disengage from him.
lead_paragraph: At the Democratic National Convention this week, Vice President Kamala Harris and her allies refined their attack on former President Donald J. Trump. Maggie Haberman, senior political correspondent for The New York Times, explains how Democrats worked to minimize and disengage from him.

headline: Are These the Most Scenic Islands in Greece?
abstract: A guide to Sifnos, Milos and Serifos, where seaside tavernas, stylish hotels and ceramics abound.
lead_paragraph: Arguably Greece’s most iconic island group, the Cyclades got their name because, if you squint, the 30-odd main islands form a circle, or kyklos, around the sacred island of Delos, birthplace of the twin gods Artemis and Apollo. In the southwestern curve of that circle sit Milos, Sifnos and Serifos, three Aegean islands that share a stark, wild beauty owing in part to the minerals that made them mining hubs well into the last century. (Mining continues on Milos, where it vies with tourism as one of the island’s main industries.)

headline: Fed’s Powell Signals an Upcoming Rate Cut in Jackson Hole Remarks
abstract: Jerome H. Powell indicated the Federal Reserve will begin to cut interest rates in September, but stopped short of stating how large that move might be.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell indicated the Federal Reserve will begin to cut interest rates in September, but stopped short of stating how large that move might be.

headline: Democrats Say the Joy Is Back. Here’s What the Data Says.
abstract: We asked voters to describe their feelings about the election in one word. Joy has jumped; so has anxiety.
lead_paragraph: We asked voters to describe their feelings about the election in one word. Joy has jumped; so has anxiety.

headline: Joy Is Not a Strategy
abstract: A good convention speech isn’t enough to earn the trust of voters.
lead_paragraph: If the Republican convention’s message for America last month had to fit on a bumper sticker, it would read, “Trump is God.” Delegates deified him relentlessly as the risen Trump after the assassination attempt. They told me over and over that he was spared to save the country with his re-election. Only on the final night did Donald Trump come crashing down to earth with his nomination speech. Divine it was not.

headline: The Big Number: 818,000
abstract: The Labor Department issued a huge downward revision on jobs figures for the 12 months that ended in March, pointing to greater cracks in the economy.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. labor market has been less resilient than was initially believed. On Wednesday, the Labor Department said that the economy had added 818,000 fewer jobs than it had previously reported for the 12 months that ended in March.

headline: What to Know About the Business Execs With Mike Lynch on His Yacht
abstract: The two business figures, both associates of the tech mogul, went missing after the superyacht they were on sank off the coast of Sicily.
lead_paragraph: The corporate world reeled this week after a superyacht carrying the British software mogul Mike Lynch, his family and associates, and others sank on Monday during a violent storm off the coast of Sicily.

headline: Harris’s New Strategy: Equate Fighting Climate Change With ‘Freedom’
abstract: The Harris campaign isn’t offering details on climate policy but is framing the fight to protect the environment as one of patriotism.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris mentioned climate change just once in her speech before the Democratic National Convention on Thursday, wrapping it into her larger campaign theme of freedom.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The Democratic National Convention was the talk of late night this week, particularly the speeches given by President Biden, the Obamas and, of course, Vice President Kamala Harris, who accepted the nomination.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention was the talk of late night this week, particularly the speeches given by President Biden, the Obamas and, of course, Vice President Kamala Harris, who accepted the nomination.

headline: Some Oct. 7 Victims Say They Won’t Participate in Government Memorial
abstract: Relatives of hostages being held in Gaza and some communities on Israel’s southern border argue the Israeli government should focus on freeing their loved ones.
lead_paragraph: Relatives of hostages being held in Gaza and some communities on Israel’s southern border that were targeted in the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7 say they will not participate in an Israeli government memorial ceremony for the first anniversary of the attacks, leaving officials scrambling to propose alternatives.

headline: Kamala Harris, Outfitting a New Era
abstract: For the most important speech of her life, the presidential candidate dressed for more than identity politics.
lead_paragraph: In the end, she did not wear a white suit.

headline: Freight Train Derails in Colorado, Injuring Two Crew Members
abstract: BNSF Railway, the train’s operator, and the police did not say what caused the derailment in Boulder late on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: A train derailed in Boulder, Colo., on Thursday night, injuring two crew members, damaging a rail bridge and causing a small fuel leak from one of the cars, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: As Ukraine Pushes Into Russia, Its Next Steps Are Unclear
abstract: American officials are not convinced that Ukraine intends to hold its position in Russia long term.
lead_paragraph: More than two weeks into Ukraine’s incursion into western Russia, Ukrainian politicians have begun talking about establishing a buffer zone there. But how much farther Ukraine might try to advance into Russia, and how long it plans to stay, is unclear, U.S. officials said.

headline: Deadly Floods Hit Bangladesh
abstract: The disaster adds to the challenges of Bangladesh’s interim government, which has struggled to restore order after its longtime prime minister fled the country following a lethal crackdown on protesters.
lead_paragraph: The disaster adds to the challenges of Bangladesh’s interim government, which has struggled to restore order after its longtime prime minister fled the country following a lethal crackdown on protesters.

headline: The Pantry Staple That Can Change Your Cooking
abstract: There are so many kinds of red-pepper flakes. Getting to know them all can give your dishes a glow up.
lead_paragraph: Raised in an Armenian household in Santa Clara, Calif., Levon Minassian recalls trips to the Middle Eastern spice shop where his parents bought Aleppo pepper, the mild, fruity red-chile flakes named after the Syrian city, to use in all manner of dishes at home. Culled from big bins and decanted into bags dragged home, the crimson powder was sprinkled over labneh, baba ghanouj and soups, each pinch a burst of sunlight.

headline: Guantánamo Hearing Cut Short by Crisis on Defense Team in U.S.S. Cole Case
abstract: A military judge allowed the lead defense lawyer to leave next month, but his successor has not yet received the security clearance she needs to take over.
lead_paragraph: A military judge on Friday cut short pretrial proceedings in the U.S.S. Cole bombing case and allowed the lead defense lawyer to retire next month, creating a potential vacuum in the defense staff as it prepares for a trial in 2025 in Guantánamo’s longest-running death-penalty case.

headline: Joyful Feelings as Democratic Convention Concludes
abstract: “Yes, Michelle Obama, hope has made a spectacular comeback,” one reader writes. Also: Help for drinkers; “nudification” apps; eat your beans.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Drinking Water Is at Risk in Parts of Long Island, Study Finds
abstract: Decades of pumping have allowed saltwater to threaten the aquifers that supply many communities, including Long Beach and Great Neck.
lead_paragraph: The supply of drinking water for parts of Long Island is under threat, according to a new federal report.

headline: Inside the Democratic Schmoozefest, Where Hotel Lobbies Are ‘Prime Territory’
abstract: The real jockeying for power in Chicago this week took place a few miles from the Democratic convention, in the lobbies and bars and hallways of the Four Seasons and Ritz-Carlton hotels.
lead_paragraph: They were on the prowl all week. The lobbyists, job seekers, influence peddlers, donors and all manner of ultrarich hangers-on at the Democratic National Convention.

headline: 8 Correct Answers to ‘What Was the Song of the Summer?’
abstract: Revisit contenders from Sabrina Carpenter, Kendrick Lamar and Billie Eilish.
lead_paragraph: I’m sorry to be the one to break it to you, but the end of the summer is approaching. Every year around this time, music fans’ favorite unwinnable debate reaches an apex: What was the song of the summer?

headline: Lifting the Curtain of Shen Yun to Reveal a Dark Side
abstract: Two New York Times reporters spent about 10 months investigating claims that the dance group had emotionally manipulated young performers and left many of their injuries untreated.
lead_paragraph: Like almost everyone in New York City, I’ve spent years walking past ads for Shen Yun Performing Arts, the traditional Chinese dance troupe. The posters intrigued me, but I never really gave them a second thought.

headline: What Stood Out About Michelle Obama’s Speech
abstract: The list of speakers at the Democratic National Convention was long. Astead Herndon, a national politics reporter and the host of “The Run-Up” at The New York Times, explains why Michelle Obama’s speech stood out to him the most.
lead_paragraph: The list of speakers at the Democratic National Convention was long. Astead Herndon, a national politics reporter and the host of “The Run-Up” at The New York Times, explains why Michelle Obama’s speech stood out to him the most.

headline: France’s Political Truce for the Olympics Is Over. Now What?
abstract: Lucie Castets, a relatively obscure bureaucrat, is the left’s choice to be prime minister. Just one person stands in her way: the president.
lead_paragraph: The first thing Lucie Castets intends to do as France’s next prime minister is to peel back the age of retirement to 62. Then, she will pour more money into the creaking health care and education systems. To pay for at least some of that, she will introduce a tax on the country’s ultrarich.

headline: Menendez’s Senate Replacement Has Been a Democrat for Just 5 Months
abstract: George Helmy was selected for the temporary job by Philip Murphy, New Jersey’s Democratic governor. He said he would caucus and vote with the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: When George Helmy is sworn in next month as Robert Menendez’s temporary replacement in the Senate, he will be joining a chamber where Democrats hold a razor-thin majority, outnumbering Republicans by a single seat, 50 to 49.

headline: Abortion Rights, on Winning Streak, Face Biggest Test in November
abstract: Ten states have ballot measures to establish a right to abortion in their state constitutions. The pushback has already begun.
lead_paragraph: Ballot measures on abortion rights have succeeded beyond what even their proponents imagined when the United States Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade two years ago.

headline: Here’s Your Olympic Gold Medal. And Your Buffalo.
abstract: Winning at the Games sometimes brings unexpected rewards.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows what you get when you are faster, higher or stronger than anyone else at the Olympics. A gold medal.

headline: On Truth Social, Donald Trump Tries to Refashion Himself as Supportive of Abortion Rights
abstract: His post about “reproductive rights” appeared to be an attempt to cast himself as a political moderate on an issue that has the potential to be damaging to him in November.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, who recently said he has “no regrets” about appointing the Supreme Court supermajority that overturned the landmark Roe v. Wade ruling on abortion rights, declared on social media on Friday that his administration will be “great” for women’s “reproductive rights.”

headline: Sabrina Carpenter Slices Up Her Sunny Image, and 7 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Yaeji, Amythyst Kiah featuring Billy Strings, Broadcast and more.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: ‘Joy,’ ‘Freedom,’ ‘Goldilocks’: Kamala Harris’s Democratic Party in 7 Keywords
abstract: As Democrats coalesce around their candidate, here are some of the words that define the party now.
lead_paragraph: When Kamala Harris replaced Joe Biden as the Democratic presidential candidate, it wasn’t just the mood and momentum of the 2024 election that changed. The language did too. Even before the Democratic National Convention got underway on Monday, the party’s fledgling presidential ticket had made some notable contributions to the political lexicon. The vice president’s supporters talked about being coconut-pilled; the candidate was declared brat by Charli XCX herself; Harris’s running mate pinned the word weird to their opponents like a “kick me” sign.

headline: Atlanta Hospital Lost Part of Man’s Skull, a Lawsuit Says
abstract: A piece of Fernando Cluster’s skull was removed during emergency brain surgery in 2022. But when it was time to put it back, the hospital couldn’t find it, the suit says.
lead_paragraph: A Georgia man filed a negligence lawsuit this month against an Atlanta hospital that he says lost a chunk of his skull that had been removed during emergency brain surgery in 2022.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Endorses Trump and Suspends His Independent Bid for President
abstract: Mr. Kennedy said he will remove his name from the ballot in battleground states, so as not to be a spoiler.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. threw his support behind former President Donald J. Trump on Friday after suspending his troubled independent campaign for president, saying he was withdrawing his name from the ballot in battleground states and that Mr. Trump had “asked to enlist me” in his second administration.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, August 24, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: U.S. Tightens Technology Controls to Target Russian War Machine
abstract: The Biden administration announced new penalties on shell companies and suppliers that were feeding Russia’s war against Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Friday that it would add more than 100 companies and organizations in Russia, China and several other countries to a restricted trade list and take other measures, as it widens its net to try to capture more advanced technology that is flowing to the Russian military.

headline: Kamala Harris, Hoping to Build Momentum, Plans Battleground State Tour Next Week
abstract: After accepting the nomination, Ms. Harris was flying back to Washington on Friday for a weekend respite before returning to the campaign trail next week.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign for president is entering a new phase, shifting from a 33-day sprint to the convention to something more familiar: Preparing for a debate and pivoting to getting out the vote.

headline: An Ex-Friend Had an Affair With My Husband. Doesn’t She Owe Me a Sit-Down?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on heartbreak and friendship splits.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I learned that my husband had an affair with one of his colleagues, with whom we were also friends. This coupling happened before and during the pandemic. The friendship fizzled out as lockdowns ended — and long before I was told about their relationship.

headline: 16 Republican-Led States Challenge Program to Aid Undocumented Spouses
abstract: The new Biden administration initiative, which could put many undocumented spouses of Americans on a path to U.S. citizenship, began taking applications this week.
lead_paragraph: Texas and 15 other Republican-led states sued the Biden administration on Friday seeking to halt a new program that could give legal status to hundreds of thousands of undocumented immigrants who are married to U.S. citizens.

headline: Helen Fisher, Who Researched the Brain’s Love Circuitry, Dies at 79
abstract: A biological anthropologist, she worked with colleagues to confirm for the first time that love is hard-wired in the brain.
lead_paragraph: Helen E. Fisher, a biological anthropologist who went looking for love in the brain circuitry of people who were besotted as well as people who were rejected, and whose research into love led to a role as the chief science adviser to the dating service Match.com, died on Saturday at her husband’s home in the Bronx. She was 79.

headline: Peace Talks at Swiss Resort Beckoned. Sudan’s Divided Generals Wouldn’t Go.
abstract: American-led mediators secured famine relief for needy areas. But with Sudan’s military failing to attend, a cease-fire was far out of reach.
lead_paragraph: American-led talks to halt Sudan’s war, convened at an exclusive Swiss ski resort, ended after 10 days on Friday with agreements to deliver food and medicine to millions of starving Sudanese in the country’s most famine-stricken areas.

headline: Judge Blocks E.P.A. From Using Civil Rights Law in Pollution Case
abstract: The decision is a setback for a Biden administration strategy for protecting minority communities with numerous polluting industries nearby.
lead_paragraph: A federal court in Louisiana has dealt a serious blow to the Biden administration’s effort to protect communities heavily affected by toxic industrial pollution.

headline: Kamala Harris Wants to Win
abstract: The Democratic presidential nominee’s speech on Thursday night sought to persuade.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, Kamala Harris reintroduced herself to America. And by the standards of Democratic convention speeches, this one was pretty unusual. In this conversation I’m joined by my editor, Aaron Retica, to discuss what Harris’s speech reveals about the candidate, the campaign she’s going to run and how she believes she can win in November.

headline: The Next Generation
abstract: A single image captures the significant moment for young women in America.
lead_paragraph: It was perhaps the biggest speech of Kamala Harris’s life, the first time a Black or South Asian American woman would accept the Democratic nomination for president.

headline: 5 Secret Service Agents Involved in Trump Rally Are Reassigned
abstract: The agents will remain on the agency payroll while investigations continue into failures that allowed a gunman to shoot at the former president last month.
lead_paragraph: The Secret Service has assigned five agents to administrative duties as a result of its investigation into the failures that led to the assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump on July 13, according to two people familiar with the situation.

headline: Paralympics Will Drop Ban on Olympic Rings Tattoos
abstract: Athletes had previously been forced — under threat of expulsion — to cover the symbol because of a rule against body advertising.
lead_paragraph: For years, Paralympians with tattoos of the Olympic rings were playing a dangerous game: They had to cover the tattoos completely in competition, or face penalties from the International Paralympic Committee, which included disqualification.

headline: Israel Presses for Gaza Border Presence as Part of Cease-Fire Deal
abstract: Mediators in truce negotiations, including the C.I.A. director and President Biden’s Middle East envoy, are seeking a summit next week to keep the struggling talks alive.
lead_paragraph: Mediators plan to move ahead with a summit next week pursuing a cease-fire agreement in Gaza, Israeli officials said on Friday, after Israeli security chiefs sought to obtain Egyptian consent for a postwar Israeli presence along Gaza’s border with Egypt.

headline: Democrats Are Upbeat, but Face a Tough Race Ahead
abstract: Also, Powell said the “time has come” for interest rate cuts. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: In Chicago, where thousands of Democrats spent the week celebrating their nomination of Kamala Harris for president, confidence has been overflowing.

headline: Beyoncé Rumors Briefly Took Center Stage. Kamala Harris Grabbed It Back.
abstract: Unsubstantiated rumors that the star would appear at the Democratic National Convention, perhaps alongside Taylor Swift, created a daylong frenzy. Then the headliner took control.
lead_paragraph: The report was published around 7 p.m. on Thursday, in all caps. TMZ announced that Beyoncé would be “PERFORMING AT DNC’S FINAL NIGHT!!!” After days of increasingly frenzied rumors that she would make an appearance at the Democratic National Convention, this report set the United Center in Chicago abuzz. But TMZ was wrong. So was Mitt Romney. So were the betting markets. So was basically all of social media.

headline: Prosecutors Unlikely to Seek ‘Mini-Trial’ in Trump Jan. 6 Case
abstract: Jack Smith, the special counsel, is said to be leaning against requesting a public courtroom hearing where he could broadly set out the evidence that the former president sought to overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in the federal case accusing former President Donald J. Trump of trying to overturn the 2020 election now appear unlikely to seek a broad public airing of their evidence in a courtroom before Election Day, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Why Mpox Vaccines Aren’t Flowing to Africans in Desperate Need
abstract: Drugmakers have supplies ready to ship that are necessary to stop a potential pandemic. But W.H.O. regulations have slowed access.
lead_paragraph: There are no vaccines for mpox available in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the epicenter of a global health emergency declared last week, even though the country first asked for the shots two years ago and the manufacturers say they have supplies.

headline: Former Florida Deputy Who Killed Airman Is Charged With Manslaughter
abstract: Eddie Duran fatally shot Senior Airman Roger Fortson on May 3 when he opened his apartment door, holding a gun pointed to the ground.
lead_paragraph: A former sheriff’s deputy in Florida was charged with manslaughter on Friday, more than three months after he fatally shot a U.S. Air Force senior airman who answered the door to his apartment holding a gun that was pointed to the ground, prosecutors said.

headline: Manhunt in Western Germany After Knife Attack Kills at Least 3
abstract: The attack took place in Solingen during a celebration of the 650th anniversary of the city’s founding. Eight people were wounded.
lead_paragraph: The police in Germany were conducting a large-scale manhunt on Saturday after a person armed with a knife killed at least three people at a festival in the western city of Solingen on Friday night. The attacker, who escaped, also wounded eight others, five of them severely.

headline: Scott Bloomquist, Champion Dirt-Track Driver, Dies at 60
abstract: Styling himself as a rebel, he won more than 600 races and nine championships in a 40-year career.
lead_paragraph: Scott Bloomquist, a superstar dirt-track racer who won more than 600 races and whose car bore the image of a skull and crossbones, died on Aug. 16 when the vintage single-engine plane that he was piloting crashed into a barn close to the airstrip on his family farm near Mooresburg, Tenn. He was 60.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein on Kamala Harris’s Convention Speech
abstract: The Aug. 23, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Aaron Retica on the final night of the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: A Campaign That Just Started Is Almost Over
abstract: Here’s my road map to the campaign’s remaining 74 days. If you blink, you might miss it.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris took the stage at the Democratic National Convention last night, she did not linger on her party’s bliss over the events of the past month. She used the opening words of the biggest speech of her life to change the subject.

headline: Meet the Rural Voters Who Could Swing North Carolina’s Election
abstract: Residents in Wilson County worry about the rising costs of goods and housing — but mostly they just want to get along.
lead_paragraph: Residents in Wilson County worry about the rising costs of goods and housing — but mostly they just want to get along.

headline: Police Investigate Deadly Knife Attack in Western Germany
abstract: The attack took place in a central square in Solingen, Germany, during a festival celebrating the town’s 650th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The attack took place in a central square in Solingen, Germany, during a festival celebrating the town’s 650th anniversary.

headline: In Las Vegas, Trump Calls Harris a ‘Copycat’ Over ‘No Tax on Tips’ Plan
abstract: The rivals have zeroed in on service industry workers in Nevada, a swing state where polls show a tight race.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Friday fumed over the fact that when it comes to exempting tips from being taxed, he and his rival, Vice President Kamala Harris, are on the same page.

headline: Harris’s Convention Speech Seen by 29 Million, a Narrow Win Over Trump’s
abstract: Overall, TV viewership of the Democratic National Convention in Chicago was up 14 percent from the Republicans’ event last month.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was curiosity about the untested candidate who took command of the ticket at the last minute, or the cameos by TV-ready celebrities like Oprah Winfrey, Mindy Kaling and Kerry Washington. The runaway (and ultimately misguided) speculation that Beyoncé might make an appearance certainly did not hurt.

headline: Words Used at the Democratic and Republican National Conventions
abstract: Counting frequently spoken words and phrases at both events.
lead_paragraph: Counting frequently spoken words and phrases at both events.

headline: After Kennedy’s Endorsement of Trump, the Two Signal a New Alliance
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who suspended his independent presidential bid earlier on Friday, was embraced by Donald J. Trump at a rally in Arizona. But the union’s political impact remains unclear.
lead_paragraph: One of the most attention-grabbing days of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s independent presidential bid was also its last.

headline: Affectionate Way to Walk
abstract: Ryan McCarty’s Saturday puzzle takes us on an exhilarating path.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It’s been a little while since we’ve seen a Ryan McCarty crossword in The New York Times. This is his first grid of 2024, but he is a Saturday stalwart and a themeless king. After doing a nervous once-over, since Mr. McCarty’s puzzles are often tough to break into, I started from the very bottom and found success. The trivia, especially, seems easier as you move down.

headline: After a Big Week for Democrats, One Good Day for Trump
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump talked policy in Las Vegas and seemed almost chipper. In Arizona, he reveled in the endorsement of a former campaign rival, Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
lead_paragraph: It was a moment the political world had been wondering about for weeks.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 24, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the unearthing of the second-largest diamond ever found misstated the weight of the diamond in pounds. It weighs a little more than a pound, not more than a pound and a half.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Philosopher President, Near His End, on How to Be Truly Free
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We have a house for the president. It’s four stories. To have tea you have to walk three blocks. Useless. They should make it a high school.”

headline: Why 7-Eleven Is a National Treasure in Japan
abstract: Convenience stores are a part of the country’s culture, meaning that the foreign buyout bid for 7-Eleven, the largest chain, could be a hard sell in Japan.
lead_paragraph: In Japan, convenience stores are celebrated. Clean and bright, they are stocked with fresh and affordable lunchboxes, steamed buns and stews in the winter. The celebrity chef Anthony Bourdain once called them “the one vice” he couldn’t give up.

headline: For Young Cambodians, a Mobile History Lesson From a Dark Time
abstract: Most people in Cambodia are under 30, born long after the horrific rule of the Khmer Rouge. A bus is touring the country to make sure it’s not forgotten.
lead_paragraph: The brand-new bus gleamed as it weaved through rush-hour traffic in Cambodia’s capital. It was headed to a school, bearing a lesson about the country’s darkest period.

headline: The Loch Ness Monster Has Company in the Neighborhood: Wild Boars
abstract: Local residents say the animals are roaming the roads and hills around the lake, tearing up lawns and terrorizing sheep.
lead_paragraph: “Heaven” is how Peter Jamieson describes his home in Scotland, with its uninterrupted view of Loch Ness and the green hills stretching beyond, seemingly forever. But there is a problem in paradise, and it has nothing to do with the mythical aquatic monster that brought fame to the area.

headline: In a Grim Palestinian Refugee Community, People See Hope in Hamas
abstract: In Ein al-Hilweh, Lebanon, long mired in poverty and despair, Hamas recruitment is up and the downtrodden air has given way to defiance and celebration.
lead_paragraph: Ein al-Hilweh, Lebanon’s largest community of Palestinian refugees and their descendants, has long been a downtrodden place, impoverished and racked by factional violence. Its residents usually have a grim view of their future.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How a Children’s Museum Director Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Kate Mirand Calleri, the director of education at the Brooklyn Children’s Museum, braves tarantulas and crowded subways before relaxing with “Antiques Roadshow.”
lead_paragraph: Working at the Brooklyn Children’s Museum is, happily, child’s play for Kate Mirand Calleri.

headline: The Hottest Commodity at the U.S. Open? Shade.
abstract: The tennis tournament, like the rest of New York City, is adapting to climate change.
lead_paragraph: As New York City contends with rising heat and unpredictable storms because of climate change, so does its marquee tennis tournament, the U.S. Open.

headline: Pack Lunch, Drop Kids Off, Skate,Work
abstract: These moms have found a community while picking up the sport, falls and all.
lead_paragraph: On a chilly, windy morning in March, Nagisa Landfield’s and Leila Noelliste’s skateboard wheels boomed in unison with the clanking of construction work and semi trucks echoing nearby at a skatepark under the Kosciuszko Bridge in Brooklyn.

headline: Mexico’s President Bet Big on Oil. His Successor Will Be Stuck With the Tab.
abstract: Mexico’s next leader, Claudia Sheinbaum, is a climate scientist who has signaled a clean energy pivot. But a huge wager on fossil fuels by her political mentor stands in her way.
lead_paragraph: On a sweltering day in August, Claudia Sheinbaum appeared with her mentor, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, to inaugurate one of the costliest infrastructure projects in Mexico’s history: a $16 billion oil refinery.

headline: Teams Leave, but Oakland Still Finds Reasons to Cheer
abstract: The Raiders and the Warriors are gone and the A’s are leaving, but teams in lesser-known leagues are trying to fill the void and connect with the city.
