lead_paragraph: On a cool May night, as the sun set over San Francisco in the distance, drummers and flag-waving fans led cheers of “Ohhhh-O-O-O Oakland” (to the tune of “Seven Nation Army” by the White Stripes) and “Let’s go, Oakland!” (clap clap, clap clap clap) as one of the city’s biggest sports teams pulled out a nail-biting victory.

headline: How Elon Musk Got Tangled Up in Blue
abstract: Twitter Blue, a revamped subscription service that let users buy verified badges, was the first big test for the platform’s new owner. It didn’t go well.
lead_paragraph: By Nov. 9, 2022, anxiety was high among the Twitter employees gathered at the company’s San Francisco headquarters. They had spent part of that morning trying to gently explain to their new boss, Elon Musk, that the service they had just launched was dangerous.

headline: Many Gen Z Men Feel Left Behind. Some See Trump as an Answer.
abstract: Men under 30 are much more likely to support Donald Trump than women their age. It’s a far bigger gender gap than in older generations.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, this presidential election has become a referendum on gender roles — and the generation with the biggest difference in opinion between male and female voters is Generation Z.

headline: Not Only for Killing: Drones Are Now Detecting Land Mines in Ukraine
abstract: Ukraine is a beta test for embedding artificial intelligence and other new technologies in drones and robots to find deadly land mines, saving lives and allowing military forces to advance more quickly.
lead_paragraph: With a stiff gait, a drone dog stomped up and down a makeshift minefield at a U.S. Army testing center in Virginia, shuddering when it neared a plate-size puck meant to simulate an anti-tank explosive. On its back was a stack of cameras, GPS devices, radios and thermal imaging technology that military developers hope will help it detect mines at close range, sparing humans from that dangerous task.

headline: 4 Fast-Burn New Romance Novels
abstract: Our columnist reviews books by Danica Nava, Courtney Milan, Zen Cho and Karelia and Fay Stetz-Waters.
lead_paragraph: Romance loves to build triumphant outcomes out of terrible decisions. And Danica Nava’s contemporary THE TRUTH ACCORDING TO EMBER (Berkley, paperback, $16.99) stars a heroine who makes more bad decisions than most.

headline: How to Soothe an Itchy Bug Bite
abstract: There are a number of ways to stop scratching, from medicines to mental tricks.
lead_paragraph: I’m one of the unfortunate souls who, for reasons still only loosely explained by science, seems to taste delicious to mosquitoes. So was my father, who taught me as a child that the best way to stop the itch was to press an “x” into the middle of the bite with my fingernail. It hurt a little bit, but that was the point: The pain made me forget about the itch, at least temporarily.

headline: A French Museum Has Global Needs (but It Can’t Have New Jersey)
abstract: The Pompidou Center is creating international outposts to help fund a renovation of its Paris home. What happens now that Jersey City has pulled out?
lead_paragraph: The century-old Pathside Building in downtown Jersey City was originally a transportation hub for streetcar lines, but it took on a new role three years ago: It became the chosen destination for an outpost of the Pompidou Center, the Paris arts complex.

headline: Can Grunting During Exercise Give You an Edge?
abstract: Some people can’t help letting out a little noise during a hard workout. It might serve a purpose.
lead_paragraph: I recently went rock climbing in a serene park in southern Wyoming called Vedauwoo. The desert was tranquil in the early morning, a breeze gently moving through the trees.

headline: Yes, You Can Plan a Stress-Free Wedding
abstract: Many couples are incorporating the quiet life trend into their nuptials, avoiding a big, traditional celebration in favor of a smaller, more relaxed gathering.
lead_paragraph: Melanie Neff Díaz and Silvino Edward Díaz Burns wanted to avoid the stress of a large, traditional wedding, so they hosted a quiet celebration at a local restaurant for their nuptials on June 23.

headline: Elon Musk’s X Is Leaving San Francisco. City Officials Say ‘Good Riddance.’
abstract: The company, founded in the city as Twitter, is moving its headquarters to Texas as a shadow of its former self.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco’s long relationship with X is nearly over — and city officials are far from heartbroken.

headline: How to Survive (and Maybe Conquer) the Edinburgh Fringe Festival
abstract: It’s a prime opportunity for performers looking to make a splash. Nadia Quinn, a comic actress and singer from New York, decided to give it a shot.
lead_paragraph: Nadia Quinn had been warned about bringing her show of wacky comic songs to the Fringe Festival in Edinburgh. Facebook groups, Reddit posts and friends suggested that taking on the 77-year-old festival as an unestablished performer was too daunting.

headline: Care Policies Take Center Stage in Harris’s Economic Message
abstract: The Democratic nominee says she wants to make raising a family more affordable. But she has provided few details on her proposals.
lead_paragraph: The “care economy” — a broad set of policies aimed at helping parents and other caregivers — was the great unfinished work of President Biden’s domestic agenda. Vice President Kamala Harris has made it a central aspect of her campaign to succeed him.

headline: Do I Really Need a Real Estate Agent?
abstract: Under new rules, potential buyers may now be responsible for paying their agent’s commission. Some now question the need for that agent.
lead_paragraph: Less than two months ago, Joanne Y. Cleaver sold her home in a suburb of Charlotte for $725,000 in an unusual way: Facebook Marketplace.

headline: Can the G.O.P. Really Become the Party of Workers?
abstract: A new generation of Republicans is learning to love labor. It’s not clear if labor will love them back.
lead_paragraph: The most surprising moment of this year’s Republican National Convention may have come on its first night, when the president of the Teamsters railed in prime time against corporate elites and denounced a “war against labor” by business groups. The gasps from some in the hall were almost audible on television.

headline: Can Building Staff Enter My Rent-Stabilized Apartment Without Permission?
abstract: No, with some exceptions. But different rules may apply to a market-rate rental right down the hall.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan in a building made up of mostly market-rate units. The building staff are known to access apartments without notifying the tenant and without an apparent reason, such as a service ticket or an emergency issue. If I learn that the staff has entered my apartment without notice, what are my rights? What should I do if the building management does not address this?

headline: Toni Braxton, Whoopi Goldberg Fan, Watches ‘The View’ in Her Pajamas
abstract: “I love a good debate,” said the R&B singer and actress, who can be seen alongside her sisters in the TV series “The Braxtons.” “It doesn’t always make you smile, but it always provokes thought.”
lead_paragraph: Toni Braxton wasn’t initially enthusiastic about rebooting “Braxton Family Values,” the reality show in which she starred for seven seasons with her sisters, Traci, Towanda, Trina and Tamar.

headline: New Training and Tougher Rules: How Colleges Are Trying to Tame Gaza Protests
abstract: University officials are spelling out strict codes around protests. They say they are trying to be clear. Others say they are trying to suppress speech.
lead_paragraph: Less than 10 minutes had passed before Daniel Diermeier, Vanderbilt University’s chancellor, told hundreds of new students what the school would not do.

headline: These Young Women Didn’t Want to Vote for Biden. They’re All In on Harris.
abstract: In new polls, a large majority of young women plan to vote for the vice president. We talked with eight of them.
lead_paragraph: Constance Lancelle, 22, of Milwaukee, was “definitely not interested in voting for Biden,” she said. But with Kamala Harris as the Democratic presidential candidate, she said, “I feel like politics have been a dream.”

headline: Sometimes Protest Movements Are a Slow, Slow Burn
abstract: In “To the Success of Our Hopeless Cause,” Benjamin Nathans takes stock of the generation of dissidents who helped loosen the bonds of tyranny in the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: It is widely held that the beginning of the end of Soviet totalitarianism arrived in the 1980s, when the general secretary Mikhail Gorbachev ushered in a period of democratic reform. Under his policies of perestroika (restructuring) and glasnost (openness), the state relaxed censorship laws, brought private enterprise further out of the shadows and stood back as one Soviet satellite after another — Poland, Czechoslovakia, Romania and others — slipped out of Moscow’s orbit. Hundreds of political prisoners returned home and hundreds of thousands, including members of my family, were exonerated for political offenses committed during the reign of Joseph Stalin.

headline: Liza Colón-Zayas’s Medallion
abstract: The heirloom, passed down by her grandmother, connects the Emmy-nominated actress to her Puerto Rican heritage.
lead_paragraph: Liza Colón-Zayas used to ride her bike between the living room and kitchen of her grandmother’s apartment in the Bronx. Her Puerto Rican grandmother didn’t speak English, and Ms. Colón-Zayas, a Bronx-native Nuyorican, didn’t speak Spanish. But the two found other ways to communicate: through her grandmother’s patience as she rode her two-wheeler around the tight space; through hand gestures and homemade Puerto Rican food.

headline: In Critical Border District, Republican Pairs Immigrant Story With Tough Stance
abstract: Representative Juan Ciscomani is seeking a second term by promoting his immigrant biography, but his record in Congress could alienate voters in his Arizona district bordering Mexico.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Juan Ciscomani appeared onstage at a community center filled with banquet tables in Tucson recently to speak to high school seniors from underserved communities, he recounted his personal story of immigrating from Mexico as a young child, helping to support his family and eventually making it to Congress.

headline: The Hunt for the Next ‘Baby Reindeer’
abstract: Inside the Edinburgh Festival Fringe
lead_paragraph: Every August, visitors from around the world journey to Scotland to attend one of the world’s biggest theater celebrations, the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. It is known for cutting-edge shows and a carnival-like atmosphere, and as the place where hit shows like “Fleabag,” “Baby Reindeer” and “Six” got their start. The Times’s European culture reporter, Alex Marshall, went to the festival to find out what makes a Fringe show a hit, and what’s landing with audiences this year.

headline: Ancient Tablets Foretold Doom Awaiting Babylonian Kings
abstract: A new translation of cuneiform relics from the second millennium B.C. highlights the warnings that astrologers saw in eclipses.
lead_paragraph: It was good to be the king in ancient Babylonia, unless, of course, an eclipse occurred during his reign. Such an event foretold revolt, rebellion, defeat in war, loss of territory, plague, drought, crop failure, locust attacks or even the king’s death. Should the last omen be foretold, the king would go into hiding and a substitute — say, a prisoner or a simpleton — would be installed until the danger had passed. To appease the gods, someone would have to die, so upon the return of the true king, the substitute would be executed.

headline: NASA Extends Boeing Starliner Astronauts’ Space Station Stay to 2025
abstract: Persistent concerns with the vehicle’s propulsion systems mean Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore will return home next year in a SpaceX vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Two astronauts who have spent months aboard the International Space Station will have to stay there months longer after NASA decided on Saturday that they could not return on Boeing’s troubled Starliner space vehicle. They will return instead on a SpaceX capsule next year.

headline: Trump’s Carefully Scripted Week Kept Veering Off Script
abstract: Despite calls by his advisers to focus on the issues, former President Donald J. Trump has made it clear that he intends to keep running his campaign his way.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s political endurance this year has been attributed in part to voters’ faded memories about why they denied him a second term four years ago.

headline: Why Harris’s Barrier-Breaking Bid Feels Nothing Like Hillary Clinton’s
abstract: The first-female-president energy of 2016 has been replaced by a more serious tone, with Democrats warning gravely of the new frontiers in the post-Roe era.
lead_paragraph: They still wear suffragist-white outfits and cheer on the prospect of “Madam President.”

headline: Childhood Stardom Is Rough. Jenna Ortega Is Still Recovering.
abstract: The actress talks about learning to protect herself and the hard lessons of early fame.
lead_paragraph: If you have a tween daughter, as I do, you know that Jenna Ortega is a big deal. In 2022, Ortega starred as the title character in Netflix’s “Addams Family” reboot, “Wednesday,” and quickly became beloved by viewers for her character’s snarky, dark and brutally honest personality. The show was a hit, and suddenly Wednesday — and by extension Ortega — were everywhere: on merch, on the streets for Halloween and all over the internet doing her meme-able dance moves. It was the kind of star-making, culture-saturating role that is life-changing for a young actor. It was also, as Ortega told me over the course of our two conversations, completely disorienting to become so famous so fast.

headline: The DMZ Is an Unhealed Wound for Korea. It’s Also a Source of Great Honey.
abstract: The heavily fortified area separating North and South Korea is home to a biodiverse landscape and is a place of deep meaning for nearby farmers whose bees can fly freely through it.
lead_paragraph: Cho Seong-hoan’s father liked to say that the honeybees on his farm were lucky. Unlike typical South Koreans, they could cross into North Korea, as he had done before war divided the peninsula.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 441
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Aug. 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,163
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: With Freight Off the Rails, Rare Open Tracks for Passenger Trains
abstract: The brief lockout of freight railway workers gave Via Rail Canada trains a temporary reprieve from their second-class status.
lead_paragraph: If anyone benefited from the short lockout at the Canadian National and Canadian Pacific Kansas City railways this week, it might have been passengers on most Via Rail Canada trains.

headline: Out of Season
abstract: Summer’s coming to a close soon. You’re still, to some extent, in control of how you spend the time.
lead_paragraph: You are going to encounter people this weekend who will tell you that there’s one week left of summer. You don’t have to believe them. You don’t have to be one of them.

headline: Hamas Agrees to Meet With Mediators in Cairo Ahead of Cease-Fire Talks
abstract: Fighting has raged in Gaza even as the United States, Qatar and Egypt have pushed for a deal, with Israeli strikes overnight killing dozens, according to health officials in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Hamas representatives were heading to Cairo on Saturday to meet with mediators before a new round of Gaza cease-fire talks as the United States, Qatar and Egypt push to reach an agreement they hope can stave off the growing threat of regional war.

headline: Busload of Indian Tourists in Nepal Plunges Into River, Killing at Least 27
abstract: Nepal, a poor and mountainous country, has long struggled with road safety.
lead_paragraph: At least 27 people died in Nepal on Friday when a tour bus fell into a gorge and went into the Marsyangdi River in the central district of Tanahun.

headline: My Play Went to Broadway. Then a Death Changed Everything.
abstract: When my friend and collaborator died before our comedy show opened on Broadway, I mourned him from the stage.
lead_paragraph: Imagine: You make something with someone you love. It’s a thing that’s tangible but needs participation, like a watch that requires winding. Now imagine that person goes away, and you still have to tend the garden you planted with him, or sing the song you wrote together or walk through a house that is now fully characterized by its emptiness. Many people, I know, don’t have to imagine.

headline: Daffy Donald, Turning Pea Green With Envy
abstract: Trump, who usually keeps others off-balance, is unbalanced by Kamala.
lead_paragraph: I have a crow in my backyard in D.C. that has been cawing for three weeks. It has been driving me crazy, so I was happy to get out of town and back on the trail.

headline: An Old Bangladeshi Reflex Threatens Its Revolution
abstract: My country must break the cycle of denial and revenge that has divided and held it back for decades.
lead_paragraph: In Bangladesh, we are experts at erasing history.

headline: Plan Beats No Plan
abstract: The candidates’ housing plans offer a window on how they would govern.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t a policy election. There’s no defining issue like tax cuts in 2000 or health care in 2008 or trade in 2016. Democrats are focused on convincing voters that Donald Trump poses an existential threat to the American way of life, and vice versa. But policy remains the purpose of politics, and the choice of a president is also the choice of a housing policy.

headline: Republicans Are Right: One Party Is ‘Anti-Family and Anti-Kid’
abstract: When right-wingers pursue policies that mire children in poverty, it takes gall to preen about their family values.
lead_paragraph: In attacking Democrats and Kamala Harris, Republicans have been making a legitimate point: One of our major political parties has worked to undermine America’s families.

headline: On Ukraine’s Independence Day, Zelensky Celebrates Push Into Russia
abstract: Although the cross-border offensive carries risks, it also paid dividends on Saturday with the first prisoner swap with Russia in several months.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky, always adept at messaging, used his latest Independence Day speech on Saturday to drive home the idea that Ukraine is taking the fight to Russia, even as his troops struggle along the front line in the east.

headline: New York Is Huge. These Books Help Cut It Down to Size.
abstract: Dear readers,
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Who Is Edgar Bronfman Jr., Paramount’s 11th-Hour Suitor?
abstract: His bid to buy Paramount pits one son of a billionaire against the son of another.
lead_paragraph: When the media executive Edgar Bronfman Jr. submitted his last-ditch bid on Monday to take control of Paramount, his approach was greeted with surprise and skepticism. Who would take his unconventional coalition of investors seriously, especially when an $8 billion deal with Skydance was on the table?

headline: The N.F.L. May Soon Welcome a New Kind of Owner
abstract: At a meeting next week, team owners are expected to approve rules that would allow private equity firms to invest in their franchises.
lead_paragraph: For more than a century, National Football League owners have been an exclusive club. With rules that place tough restrictions on who is allowed to buy teams — and how those purchases can be financed — only the extremely wealthy can afford to join. Now they’re on the cusp of admitting a new kind of member.

headline: Italian Authorities Open Manslaughter Investigation in Yacht Disaster
abstract: A prosecutor involved in the inquiry into the sinking said it was “plausible” that crimes were committed during the accident.
lead_paragraph: Italian authorities said on Saturday that they had opened a manslaughter investigation into the sinking of the Bayesian luxury yacht, but that they had not yet zeroed in on any potential suspects.

headline: New Arrest Made in Knife Attack That Left 3 Dead in Germany
abstract: The authorities announced the end of a manhunt, nearly a day after the attack, which happened Friday night at a festival in the city of Solingen.
lead_paragraph: The German police late Saturday made a third arrest in the fatal knife attack that took place Friday at a street festival in the western city of Solingen. An official said they had ended the search for a suspect in the stabbing episode, which killed three and injured several more, some of them seriously.

headline: Iowa Man Helped Distribute ‘Sadistic’ Videos Showing Torture of Monkeys, U.S. Says
abstract: Philip Colt Moss, 41, paid another man for videos of monkeys being sexually abused, tortured and killed, prosecutors said. A child in Indonesia made the videos, according to a previous indictment.
lead_paragraph: An Iowa man was arrested this month for his role in a group that created and shared so-called animal crush videos in which monkeys were brutally tortured, sexually abused and killed in sadistic ways, federal prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: This Roasted Dill Salmon Is a Thing of Beauty
abstract: “I have made this numerous times, and it is one of my favorite recipes,” one reader said.
lead_paragraph: Is there anything more beautiful than a serving-platter-size piece of perfectly roasted salmon? (Well, sure: a tropical sunset, a $10 bill lying on the sidewalk, my dog.) A heavy fillet of salmon, its fattiness made more unctuous with olive oil and its brininess brightened with citrus and herbs — if that’s on the table, the little “Oh boy oh boy” part of my brain lights up, and I am instantly hungry.

headline: An Early, Original Print by W. Eugene Smith
abstract: W. Eugene Smith was known for his war photography. But a photo he took of a trough as a teenager in Wichita, Kan., helped kick-start his career.
lead_paragraph: The American photojournalist W. Eugene Smith (1918-1978) is renowned for his war photography, including images he captured in the Pacific theater during World War II, and for his gripping photo essays, a form he helped popularize while working for Life magazine in the 1940s. His final photo essay, “Minamata: A Warning to the World,” which first appeared in Life in 1972 and later became a book, brought global attention to victims of industrial mercury poisoning in Minamata, a Japanese fishing village.

headline: Biden’s Asylum Restrictions Are Working as Predicted, and as Warned
abstract: Border numbers are down significantly. But migrant activists say the restrictions President Biden imposed in June are weeding out people who may have legitimate claims of asylum.
lead_paragraph: In the months since President Biden imposed sweeping restrictions on asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border, the policy appears to be working exactly as he hoped and his critics feared.

headline: Explosions Outside a France Synagogue Were a Terrorist Attack, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Politicians quickly condemned the attack, at a time when antisemitic incidents have been on the rise in France. A suspect has been arrested in the case.
lead_paragraph: Two vehicles parked outside a synagogue exploded in a French town on Saturday in what prosecutors called an act of terrorism.

headline: How Media Outlets on the Right and Left Covered Kennedy’s Trump Endorsement
abstract: Conservative coverage of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s decision to suspend his presidential campaign focused on the potential boon for the former president. Liberal outlets downplayed the impact it would have.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s decision to suspend his presidential campaign and endorse former President Donald J. Trump was — depending on where on the political spectrum the coverage came from — treated with either outright glee — or derision. Conservative sites primarily focused on the potential electoral boon to Mr. Trump, while liberal media outlets focused more on Mr. Kennedy’s dysfunctional campaign, including by returning to several negative story lines.

headline: In Hawaii, a Sense of Alertness Without Panic Ahead of Tropical Storm Hone
abstract: Although the storm is not expected to pass directly over the Big Island, forecasters warned of threats including flooding and damaging winds.
lead_paragraph: Debbie Arita, an office manager at a supermarket in Hilo on the Big Island of Hawaii, took stock of the conditions. Tropical Storm Hone was approaching the region, but the scene on Friday was far from chaotic — no frantic rush for supplies, no desperate boarding up of windows.

headline: Fire Destroys Grandstand From ‘A League of Their Own’
abstract: The field and wooden grandstand in Ontario, Calif., were the backdrop for the 1992 movie about a women’s baseball league.
lead_paragraph: The wooden grandstand, locker rooms, press box and dugout of Jay Littleton Ball Park, a baseball field in California that was featured in the 1992 movie “A League of Their Own,” were destroyed in a fire on Thursday, a city spokesman said.

headline: Authorities Open Manslaughter Investigation in Italy Yacht Disaster
abstract: An Italian prosecutor in charge of the case said it was just the “initial phases” of the inquiry into the sinking of the Bayesian luxury yacht where seven were killed.
lead_paragraph: An Italian prosecutor in charge of the case said it was just the “initial phases” of the inquiry into the sinking of the Bayesian luxury yacht where seven were killed.

headline: ‘Run, Kamala, Run’: Mention of Harris’s Father Was a Rare Homage to a Fleeting Figure
abstract: In her convention speech, Kamala Harris told of being inspired by her father, a prominent economist who was otherwise largely a footnote in her personal story.
lead_paragraph: “Run, Kamala, run.”

headline: Overlooked No More: Mabel Addis, Who Pioneered Storytelling in Video Gaming
abstract: She was a teacher when she participated in an educational experiment with IBM. As a result, she became the first female video game designer.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Should We Be Worried About Population Decline?
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay that argued that we should be.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hettie Jones, Poet and Author Who Nurtured the Beats, Dies at 90
abstract: She and her husband, LeRoi Jones, published works by their literary friends. After he left her and became Amiri Baraka, she found her own voice.
lead_paragraph: Hettie Jones, a poet and author who with her husband, LeRoi Jones (who later became the incendiary poet and playwright Amiri Baraka), made her household a hub for Beat writers and other artists — but who was often described as a footnote in the rise of her famous spouse as “the white wife” he disavowed — died on Aug. 13 in Philadelphia. She was 90.

headline: Tom Brown Jr., World-Renowned Survivalist, Is Dead at 74
abstract: For decades, he ran a school in the New Jersey wilderness that taught thousands of students how to survive and even thrive in the great outdoors.
lead_paragraph: Tom Brown Jr., who was considered the country’s foremost authority on wilderness survival, and who taught thousands of people how to track deer, fletch arrows, forage for food and generally thrive in the great outdoors, died on Aug. 16 in Neptune, N.J. He was 74.

headline: Ronda Rousey Apologizes for Reposting Sandy Hook Conspiracy Video
abstract: The former U.F.C. star apologized after Reddit users asked her about the video she shared 11 years ago. She called it “the single most regrettable decision of my life.”
lead_paragraph: The former mixed martial arts superstar and professional wrestler Ronda Rousey apologized on Friday for reposting a video in 2013 that spread conspiracy theories about the Sandy Hook Elementary School mass shooting, calling it “the single most regrettable decision of my life.”

headline: Is There an Echo in Here?
abstract: Hear that? It’s John Kugelman, with a clamorous Sunday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: The Young Frenchman Striving to Give Voice to a Troubled Area
abstract: As a teenager, Amine Kessaci confronted Emmanuel Macron, founded an environmental group and lost a brother to drug violence. At 20, he almost won a National Assembly seat.
lead_paragraph: At 17, Amine Kessaci found himself seated close to the president of France, Emmanuel Macron, who had come to Marseille to kick off his second presidential campaign in 2021.

headline: Questions for Investigators Trying to Unravel Mystery of Luxury Yacht’s Sinking
abstract: The investigators searching for answers about the shipwreck, leaving seven dead, face questions about extreme weather and possible human error or problems with the yacht itself.
lead_paragraph: More than 180 feet long, with a mast towering about 240 feet and a keel that could be lowered for greater stability, the Bayesian luxury yacht did not, in the eyes of its maker, have the vulnerabilities of a ship that would easily sink.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 25, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 25, 2025.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the expansion of abortion clinics misstated the percentage of abortions that are performed in the first trimester of pregnancy. It is 92 percent, not 60 percent. The article also misstated the name of the abortion provider that relocated from North Dakota to Minnesota last year. It is the Red River Women’s Clinic, not the Red River Clinic.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Unusual Breed of Dog in Virginia Could Save Life and Limb in Ukraine
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I could definitely see a future where a drone may find a mine, and then you have somebody who clicks a button that says, ‘Yes, that’s a mine,’ and they click another button to get rid of the mine.”

headline: Trying to Head Off War, U.S. Moves Naval Forces Closer to Israel
abstract: American officials are sending a signal to Iran and its allies, in the form of two aircraft carrier groups and a guided-missile submarine.
lead_paragraph: With fears rising that a wider war could break out in the Middle East, the United States has steadily been moving Navy forces closer to the area, including two aircraft carrier groups and a guided-missile submarine. And it has not been shy about announcing the details, in a clear effort to deter Iran and its allies from more intense attacks on Israel.

headline: To Whom It May Concern: America and Europe Need Each Other
abstract: The trans-Atlantic alliance can continue as the tight-knit partnership we have known for the past 75 years, or unravel.
lead_paragraph: The funny thing about being a European during American presidential elections is the belief that you, too, should be allowed to vote. And can you blame us? Who gets to occupy the Oval Office is correctly seen by many in Europe as a decision of existential significance for the well-being and security of the continent.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Inside the N.F.L.’ and ‘The Bachelorette: Men Tell All’
abstract: The CW airs their annual show. Jenn Tran confronts her past suitors on ABC.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Aug. 26-Sept. 1. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Here’s a Timeline of Recent Strikes and Retaliations in the Middle East
abstract: Tensions in the region had been high for weeks before Israel and Hezbollah began more intense cross-border attacks early Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Before Sunday’s attacks, tensions in the Middle East had been high for weeks in the wake of high-profile assassinations of senior leaders of the militant groups Hamas and Hezbollah.

headline: How JD Vance Found His Way to the Catholic Church
abstract: In his 30s, the Republican vice-presidential nominee read works on theology, mysticism, and political and moral philosophy. And he discovered his faith.
lead_paragraph: From his new home in Cincinnati, JD Vance would go to St. Gertrude to meet the friar.

headline: Would a Group Opposed to Police Blow the Whistle on Its Founder?
abstract: The leader of Raheem AI had a plan to hold law enforcement accountable, but his lavish expenditures derailed the organization.
lead_paragraph: Jasmine Banks’s disillusionment started with a credit-card bill.

headline: How a Migrant Accused of Rape Was Freed and Charged With Rape Again
abstract: A failure of cooperation between New York City and federal authorities allowed Daniel Davon-Bonilla, a 24-year-old from Nicaragua, to slip out of the grasp of law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: For 15 months, Daniel Davon-Bonilla sat in the Rikers Island jail complex in New York City, accused of raping a transgender woman in a migrant shelter.

headline: Why Opening a Roth I.R.A. May Be a Good Move, No Matter Your Age
abstract: These retirement savings accounts, which are often pitched to young investors, can be a good option for older and retired workers.
lead_paragraph: At 72, Janice Campbell might not seem like your average investor in a Roth account. Those investment vehicles — funded with after-tax dollars instead of the pretax contributions that go into most individual retirement accounts and 401(k)s — are typically recommended for younger workers.

headline: Israel’s Hunt for the Elusive Leader of Hamas
abstract: Yahya Sinwar’s ability to evade capture or death has denied Israel a military success in a war that began after he planned the Oct. 7 attacks.
lead_paragraph: In January, Israeli and American officials thought they had caught a break in the hunt for one of the world’s most wanted men.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘I Noticed That the Woman in the Orange Shirt Was Losing Her Balance’
abstract: Trying not to fall on a moving train, a message between old friends and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: ‘Whatever Happens in the Sauna Stays in the Sauna’: Diplomacy, Conducted in the Nude
abstract: The Finnish Embassy offers one of the hottest invitations in Washington: a chance to discuss serious topics in a sauna.
lead_paragraph: “When you are half-naked or even sometimes completely naked, it allows for deeper discussion,” said Mikko Hautala, the ambassador of Finland to the United States. “You talk in a way that doesn’t happen when you are sitting around a table with a tie on or at some formal thing.”

headline: Naomi Osaka’s Ruffles and Bows
abstract: The tennis star unveils her U.S. Open look, made by Nike and the designer Yoon Ahn. It has tulle, ribbons and frills — call it “Lolita goth.”
lead_paragraph: When Naomi Osaka walks onto the court at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in Queens, N.Y., this week, she will be covered in bows.

headline: What if China Invades? For Taiwan, a TV Show Raises Tough Questions.
abstract: Some think the drama, “Zero Day,” helps Taiwan confront an increasingly plausible scenario. Others say the show is alarmist and a tool of the government.
lead_paragraph: On the boulevard in front of the presidential palace in Taipei this weekend, Taiwan’s worst nightmare was unfolding in front of film crews. A crowd of actors and extras portrayed one kind of chaos that might come with a Chinese invasion: a protest descending into violence and bloodshed.

headline: Why Were Justice Dept. Officials Scared to Talk to This Book’s Author?
abstract: In “Where Tyranny Begins,” the journalist David Rohde reveals how former President Donald Trump tried to use the federal law enforcement agency to help himself and punish his foes.
lead_paragraph: A lot of people seem to have forgotten what made Donald Trump’s presidency so dangerous. Wasn’t it just a lot of loudmouthed name-calling, like tweeting that his own secretary of state was “dumb as a rock”? What did he do that was so terrible after all? NATO is intact, inflammatory policies like the so-called Muslim ban and the southern border wall were mostly thwarted, and the economy did well, at least until Covid. We survived — right?

headline: An Impressive Monument to Christopher Isherwood, Man of Letters (and Lovers)
abstract: Though it downplays unflattering details, Katherine Bucknell’s big biography hails the 20th-century writer as an early advocate for the “chosen family.”
lead_paragraph: Many writers’ graves are tourist attractions. Not Christopher Isherwood’s. Indeed, he doesn’t have one. Best remembered for his “Berlin Stories,” which became “I Am a Camera” which became “Cabaret” — and latterly for “A Single Man,” which the designer Tom Ford made into a movie — Isherwood, who died in 1986 at 81, signed away his corpse to science.

headline: These Are Our Favorite Movies From 1999. What Are Yours?
abstract: In our view, these eight comedies, dramas and more have attained classic status 25 years later. Let us know your own picks.
lead_paragraph: On the 25th anniversary of what many argue is the greatest year in movie history, we asked film staff writers and critics to share the movie from 1999 that they love the best or feel is most overlooked. After reading their picks, let us know your choices.

headline: Battle-Hardened Poets Fuel a Literary Revival in Ukraine
abstract: With verses that capture the raw emotions of the war and resonate deeply with the population, Ukrainian poets have emerged as some of the country’s most influential voices.
lead_paragraph: For several days in March 2022, the battalion of Yaryna Chornohuz, a Ukrainian poet and combat medic, faced fierce attacks from a column of Russian tanks in southeastern Ukraine. Outgunned, the soldiers repelled the first two assaults, but suffered many casualties.

headline: Soaring Insurance Costs Could ‘End’ Affordable Housing, Developers Warn
abstract: Developers and landlords of subsidized housing, who cannot raise rents or charge more for starter homes, say property insurance increases could put them out of business.
lead_paragraph: For the poorest Americans, finding an apartment to rent or a home to buy often means tapping into a vast network of nonprofit groups that use public and charitable funds to rehab or build affordable housing. Over the past year, the skyrocketing cost of property insurance has put that network on shaky ground.

headline: Apple Rethinks Its Movie Strategy After a String of Misses
abstract: “Wolfs,” a new film starring George Clooney and Brad Pitt, was going to get a robust theatrical release. But the company is curtailing that plan.
lead_paragraph: When Apple won a bidding war in 2021 for the rights to make the action comedy “Wolfs” with George Clooney and Brad Pitt, it did so in part because it promised the stars it would put the movie into a large number of movie theaters.

headline: On Immigration, Harris and Democrats Walk a Delicate — and Harder — Line
abstract: The message Democrats put forward at their convention last week, a tougher line than in decades, reflects how deeply immigration remains a political vulnerability for the party.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on the Harris and Trump campaigns.

headline: Dashed Hopes and Big Breaks: What It’s Like to Work on Cold Cases
abstract: This month, significant breakthroughs were announced in several murder cases that had been dormant for decades. Investigators explained what cracking these can look like.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Elfmont, a retired Los Angeles police officer, was living in Bozeman, Mont., when the local sheriff invited him to lunch. Over Mexican food, the sheriff described the murder of a 15-year-old girl that rocked a nearby small town almost 30 years ago and had never been solved. The sheriff asked: Would Mr. Elfmont take it on?

headline: As Kamala Harris Claims Oakland, Berkeley Forgives
abstract: The vice president has virtually erased Berkeley, Calif., her hometown, from her campaign biography. The residents of “the People’s Republic” say they get it.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on the Harris and Trump campaigns.

headline: Reuters Safety Adviser Killed and 2 Journalists Injured in Strike on Ukraine Hotel
abstract: Reuters said that a safety adviser working with the journalists was killed, and that two other members of its team were wounded after a hotel in eastern Ukraine was hit in a strike on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A safety adviser working with a team of journalists for the Reuters news agency was killed on Sunday and two journalists were wounded after a missile hit the hotel in which they were staying in eastern Ukraine, Reuters said in a statement.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,164
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: What the Lobstermen of Maine Tell Us About the Election
abstract: There are places in America where climate change feels close at hand — and also far away from politics, partly because of how much work there is to do.
lead_paragraph: Mid-July is peak season on the central Maine coast. The blueberries — the small, low-bush kind long prized by the state’s jam makers and pie bakers — had started to appear in the farmers’ markets, along with the first of the tomatoes. Bright orange tiger lilies burst from front yards, while Queen Anne’s lace and goldenrod line the two-lane roads. The summer light dazzles, falling in soft waves upon the spruce and cedar, and brightening the paint on both midcentury saltboxes and grander Victorian homes. It’s no wonder that people want to come here.

headline: Kamala Harris Begins to Sketch a New Economic Vision
abstract: The vice president is beginning to tell a new story about how the economy works, which could serve as the basis for a governing philosophy that crosses party lines.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris is beginning to offer the first definitive clues of a new economic vision — one with the potential not only to offer a unifying vision for the Democratic Party but also to serve as the foundation for a governing philosophy that crosses party lines.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 442
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Aug. 26, 2024
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: There Are a Bazillion Possible Starbucks Orders — and It’s Killing the Company
abstract: Starbucks is struggling with an overly complex menu.
lead_paragraph: You’re already in line at Starbucks — having failed to order by app — when you spot one of them. That dude who is looking down not at a cellphone but at the Post-it note that holds the orders of his office mates. Which is confirming that you are going to be late for that next meeting, because this person plans to order six coffee beverages, each of which involves some combination of tall venti grande double-pump, one to four shots of espresso, half-caf, oat milk, nonfat milk, soy milk, milk milk, whipped cream, syrup, brown sugar, white sugar, no sugar and mocha drizzle, from the pike position with two and a half twists.

headline: Harris Campaign Says It Raised $82 Million During Convention Week
abstract: The four-day total includes one of the best fund-raising hours of Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential bid, according to the campaign, which has now raised $540 million in the last month.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris’s presidential campaign said on Sunday that it raised $82 million during the Democratic National Convention last week, the latest spurt of donor enthusiasm around a presidential bid that, according to the campaign, has now raised $540 million in the last month.

headline: The Christian Persecution Narrative Rings Hollow
abstract: We are still trying to figure out how to disentangle church from state (and vice versa).
lead_paragraph: This June, I was invited on a friend’s podcast to answer a question I’ve been asked over and over again in the Trump era. Are Christians really persecuted in the United States of America? Millions of my fellow evangelicals believe we are, or they believe we’re one election away from a crackdown. This sense of dread and despair helps tie conservative Christians, people who center their lives on the church and the institutions of the church, to Donald Trump — the man they believe will fight to keep faith alive.

headline: Telegram Becomes Free Speech Flashpoint After Founder’s Arrest
abstract: Pavel Durov, the founder of the app, which has more than 900 million users, was taken into custody by the French authorities.
lead_paragraph: Telegram, founded in 2013 by the Russian entrepreneur Pavel Durov, has grown into one of the world’s largest online communication tools and is central to everyday life in countries like Russia, Ukraine and India for messaging, getting independent news and exchanging views.

headline: How the Latest Israel-Hezbollah Strikes Unfolded
abstract: Israel and the Lebanese militia Hezbollah carried out some of their heaviest cross-border attacks in months on Sunday morning.
lead_paragraph: Israel and Hezbollah, the Lebanese militia backed by Iran, have engaged in some of their heaviest cross-border air attacks in months. Israeli aircraft bombarded southern Lebanon on Sunday to stop what Israel said were preparations for a major Hezbollah attack. Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed Lebanese militia, later said it had fired hundreds of rockets and drones at Israel as retribution for Israel’s killing of a senior commander in July, though Israel said there had been little damage.

headline: Fashion and the Convention
abstract: The Times’s fashion critic explores the deliberate choices behind politicians’ outfits.
lead_paragraph: Every time discussions of fashion intrude on discussions of politics, as they do in moments of high pageantry such as our national party conventions, a certain amount of freaking out ensues. Sexist!, the lament generally goes. Superficial! (That’s the nice version.)

headline: After Attacks, Israel and Hezbollah Swiftly Move to Talk of Containment
abstract: Hezbollah’s long-dreaded retaliation for the killing of a senior commander appeared to be over before it began. But analysts said tensions could yet escalate further.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, Israelis have waited in trepidation for a major attack by Hezbollah in retaliation for Israel’s assassination of a senior commander of the Lebanese group in Beirut last month, amid widespread fears that a cross-border escalation could spiral into an all-out regional war.

headline: French Authorities Arrest Suspect in Synagogue Attack
abstract: Antiterrorism prosecutors said officers had taken a man into custody in connection with a blast outside a synagogue in the southern French resort of La Grande Motte.
lead_paragraph: A suspect who has an arrest record for minor crimes but was not on the radar of French or foreign antiterrorism authorities has been detained in connection with Saturday morning’s attack on a synagogue in southern France, which is being investigated as a terrorist act, the French authorities said on Sunday.

headline: German Prosecutor Says Islamic State Terrorist Link Is Suspected in Festival Stabbings
abstract: The police say they have arrested a man they believe killed three people and wounded eight others at a festival in the town of Solingen, in western Germany.
lead_paragraph: An attack by a man armed with a knife that left three dead at a local festival in a western German city is being treated as terrorism, with possible links to the Islamic State, German prosecutors said on Sunday

headline: Dozens Are Killed in Two Unrelated Bus Crashes in Pakistan
abstract: One of the accidents killed 12 people who were returning from a religious pilgrimage to Iraq, officials said.
lead_paragraph: At least 37 people, including a dozen who were returning from a religious pilgrimage in Iraq, died Sunday in two unrelated bus crashes in Pakistan, officials said.

headline: Oh, This Eggplant Lasagna? It Was Nothing.
abstract: If you roast the eggplant ahead of time, you’re just a half-hour away from a gorgeous, gluten-free vegetarian dinner.
lead_paragraph: My least favorite recipe instructions begin with “Working quickly … ” I have enough pressure in my life. My favorite? “To save time … ”

headline: What You May Not Know About the Fish You Eat
abstract: Readers suggest steps to ensure that seafood is safe, legally caught and properly labeled. Also: The G.O.P.’s Catholic conundrum; blocking emotions.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mitzi McCall, 93, Dies; Comedian Confronted Beatlemania and Lost
abstract: She and her husband had the bad luck to make their “Ed Sullivan Show” debut the same night as the Beatles. They bombed. But their careers would recover.
lead_paragraph: In the decades after they made their first appearance on “The Ed Sullivan Show,” on Feb. 9, 1964, the comedy team of Mitzi McCall and her husband, Charlie Brill, had a successful career. They performed in nightclubs and on television; both individually and together, they acted on television, in films and onstage.

headline: Russell Malone, Acclaimed Jazz Guitarist, Dies at 60
abstract: He first gained attention with Jimmy Smith and went on to work with Harry Connick Jr., Diana Krall and Ron Carter. He also had a distinguished solo career.
lead_paragraph: Russell Malone, a jazz guitarist whose encyclopedic knowledge of musicians and songs, combined with a precise yet relaxed playing style, earned him jobs with Harry Connick Jr., Diana Krall and many others, as well as a dedicated following as a solo artist, died on Friday in Tokyo. He was 60.

headline: Body of Grand Canyon Hiker Is Found After Flash Floods
abstract: The body was discovered on Sunday after days of searching, the authorities said. More than 100 people were also evacuated after the floods.
lead_paragraph: The body of a hiker who disappeared during a flash flood near Grand Canyon National Park four days ago was found on Sunday, according to the National Park Service.

headline: In a Region on Edge, Israel and Hezbollah Launch Major Attacks on Each Other
abstract: The escalating strikes across the Israel-Lebanon border fueled fears of a bigger conflagration, but both sides signaled that they were de-escalating, for now.
lead_paragraph: Amid fears of an all-out war between Israel and Hezbollah forces in Lebanon, the two sides on Sunday mounted the biggest round of cross-border strikes since the war in Gaza began, with Israel bombing dozens of sites in a pre-emptive attack, and Hezbollah launching hundreds of rockets and drones.

headline: Fauci Recovering From West Nile Virus Infection
abstract: The former director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases had been hospitalized and was expected to make a full recovery, a spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony Fauci, the former government scientist who was both lauded and criticized for his work on Covid-19, was recently hospitalized with a case of West Nile virus and is recovering at home, according to a spokeswoman for the doctor.

headline: Monday Briefing: Israel and Hezbollah Exchange Major Attacks
abstract: Plus, DMZ honey.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military and Hezbollah fired back and forth in one of the largest cross-border barrages since the war in Gaza began. Here’s the latest.

headline: Republicans are combing Tim Walz’s record for misstatements.
abstract: Seeking to blunt the momentum that Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, have been experiencing in the polls and hoping to extend after an enthusiastic Democratic National Convention, Republicans have been highlighting small inaccuracies in Mr. Walz’s past descriptions of his résumé.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to blunt the momentum that Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, have been experiencing in the polls and hoping to extend after an enthusiastic Democratic National Convention, Republicans have been highlighting small inaccuracies in Mr. Walz’s past descriptions of his résumé.

headline: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Heavy Air Attacks
abstract: Israel on Sunday launched what it described as a pre-emptive strike against a major attack that Hezbollah was planning on Israeli territory. Hezbollah fired its own barrage later in the day.
lead_paragraph: Israel on Sunday launched what it described as a pre-emptive strike against a major attack that Hezbollah was planning on Israeli territory. Hezbollah fired its own barrage later in the day.

headline: On Hawaii’s Big Island, Hurricane Hone Brings Heavy Rain but No Major Damage
abstract: More than 20,000 customers were without power by Sunday afternoon, but neither the winds nor the flooding from the storm were dramatic.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Hone passed within 60 miles of Hawaii’s Big Island early Sunday, bringing heavy rain, knocking out power to thousands of customers and snapping native ohia trees like twigs.

headline: Brainpower Measures
abstract: Refrain from making assumptions about Zachary David Levy’s puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Tracking the Remnants of Hector
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Hector.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Hector.

headline: Spark Bird
abstract: Stories about birds — the hearts they sway, the havoc they wreak, the lives they change.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Colorado Republicans Vote Out Party Chair Following Anti-Gay Posts
abstract: State Republicans accused Dave Williams, who was ousted in a landslide vote, of dividing the party with “hateful narratives,” most recently against the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
lead_paragraph: Colorado Republicans have voted to remove their party’s chairman amid mounting internal criticism of his leadership, including over recent posts that attacked the L.G.B.T.Q. community and accusations that he had fueled divisions within the party.

headline: 1 Tourist Is Dead and 1 Injured After Ice Canyon Collapses in Iceland
abstract: Rescuers on Monday called off a search for what they initially believed were two other trapped tourists after it became clear that all the visitors were accounted for.
lead_paragraph: Rescuers in Iceland on Monday called off the search of a deadly ice canyon collapse after they determined that, contrary to initial reports, there were no other tourists trapped beneath the debris, the police said.

headline: Latino Civil Rights Group Demands Inquiry Into Texas Voter Fraud Raids
abstract: The organization said many of those targeted by the raids, conducted by a unit created by the Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton, were Democratic leaders and election volunteers.
lead_paragraph: A Latino civil rights group is asking the Department of Justice to open an investigation into a series of raids conducted on Latino voting activists and political operatives as part of a sprawling voter fraud inquiry by the Texas attorney general, Ken Paxton.

headline: Fox Hunters in the U.K. Want Protected Status Under Discrimination Law
abstract: A lobbying group is preparing a bid to define hunting with animals as a protected belief. Many experts have questions.
lead_paragraph: English fox hunters have tried, for years, to push back against a nearly 20-year-old ban on their beloved sport.

headline: Why Nippon Steel’s $15 Billion Takeover of U.S. Steel Is in Peril
abstract: The proposed merger of Japanese and American industrial giants, which proponents say would benefit both countries, is ensnared by political and labor opposition.
lead_paragraph: When U.S. Steel put itself up for sale in 2023, executives at Nippon Steel in Tokyo saw an opportunity: Buying the American steel maker could help it offset anemic demand in its home country and strengthen its hand in a global business dominated by China.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: After Israel’s military and the Lebanese militia Hezbollah fired back and forth over the weekend in one of the largest cross-border barrages since the war in Gaza began, both sides quickly claimed victories of sorts. By yesterday morning, the two sides were employing the language of containment.

headline: The Coming War Nobody Is Talking About
abstract: East Africa is on the cusp of conflict.
lead_paragraph: Trouble has horns to hold but not tails.

headline: No Corrections: Aug. 26, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: From War’s Carnage Springs a Renaissance of Ukrainian Poetry
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 26, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Ten years ago, it would have been unimaginable for a poet to fill a stadium.”

headline: Word of the Day: menial
abstract: This word has appeared in 38 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word menial has appeared in 38 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 7 in “I Didn’t Truly Know My Mother Until I Cooked With Her” by Priya Krishna:

headline: For His Second Trip to Space, Billionaire Has Grander, Riskier Aspirations
abstract: Jared Isaacman is leading three other privately trained astronauts on a SpaceX vehicle for Polaris Dawn, a mission that will include a daring spacewalk.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, a billionaire entrepreneur named Jared Isaacman made a groundbreaking trip to space. That spaceflight, which Mr. Isaacman called Inspiration4, was the first to orbit the Earth without a professional astronaut aboard.

headline: A Trial Asks: If Grocery Rivals Merge, Do Workers Suffer?
abstract: As Kroger seeks to acquire Albertsons, federal regulators argue that the biggest supermarket combination in history will hurt not only consumers, but workers as well.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2015, Leonard De Monte was feeling settled. At 31, he had health insurance and was making a union wage at the Vons grocery store in Woodland Hills, Calif., where he had worked for more than a decade. A familiar face in the bakery section, he knew dozens of frequent shoppers’ orders by heart.

headline: Fare Evasion Surges on N.Y.C. Buses, Where 48% of Riders Fail to Pay
abstract: New York’s bus system has one of the worst fare evasion problems of any major city in the world. The issue is more pronounced on buses than in the subway.
lead_paragraph: Every weekday in New York City, close to one million bus riders — roughly one out of every two passengers — board without paying. The skipped fares are a crucial and growing loss of revenue for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is under severe financial pressure.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Bridging the Uplifting and the Harrowing in San Francisco
abstract: Heather Knight, the San Francisco bureau chief for The New York Times, strives to reflect all sides and perspectives of the city.
lead_paragraph: When former President Donald J. Trump said at a news conference this month that he once nearly died in a helicopter ride with Willie Brown, the former mayor of San Francisco, Heather Knight immediately picked up the phone and dialed Mr. Brown.

headline: Parisians Are Choosing Bikes Over Cars. Will New Yorkers Do That, Too?
abstract: The transformation of cycling access in Paris over the past few years may have lessons for New York and its car-clogged streets.
lead_paragraph: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

headline: Rashid Johnson Will Have Career Survey at Guggenheim in 2025
abstract: A major exhibition by the acclaimed artist will fill Frank Lloyd Wright’s rotunda with plants and artwork. Johnson stepped down from the Guggenheim’s board last year.
lead_paragraph: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum’s landmark 1959 building, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, has always presented singular opportunities for living artists to engage with its sculptural spiraling ramp and central oculus illuminated by a domed skylight.

headline: Israel Averts All-Out War With Hezbollah, but Its Regional Conflicts Grind On
abstract: Relief that an eruption of violence across the border between Israel and Lebanon has been contained is tempered by a lack of progress in ending the fighting in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of foreboding, an all-out war between Israel and Hezbollah has been averted, at least for now, as both sides returned on Monday to more contained confrontations along the Israel-Lebanon border.

headline: Gaza Cease-Fire Talks Will Continue in Cairo, Officials Say
abstract: Four days of high-level meetings failed to achieve a breakthrough, but people briefed on the talks said discussions on technical issues would take place in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: A day after Israel and Hezbollah traded major cross-border attacks but swiftly moved to contain a bigger war, the focus in the Middle East returned on Monday to the effort to achieve a cease-fire in Gaza, where Israel’s 10-month-long war with Hamas is at the heart of rising regional tensions.

headline: A Fire in East London Recalls Deadly Grenfell Cladding Scandal
abstract: More than 80 people were evacuated in the early hours of Monday from a building that had used similar insulation.
lead_paragraph: More than 80 people had to be evacuated after a major fire broke out in east London early Monday, fire officials said. The blaze brought back painful memories of the Grenfell Tower fire that killed 72 people in the city in 2017.

headline: Doctors Saved Her Life. She Didn’t Want Them To.
abstract: When her “do not resuscitate” order was ignored, Marie Cooper found herself in a painful situation she had hoped to avoid.
lead_paragraph: Marie Cooper led her life according to her Christian faith. She baked pies for her neighbors in northern West Virginia, and said grace before even a bite of food. She watched Jimmy Swaggart, a televangelist preacher — a little too loudly, in her daughter Sherry Uphold’s opinion. And she always said that at the end of her life, she did not want to be resuscitated.

headline: Disabled Troops Used to Have to Leave the Military. Now Some Compete for Gold.
abstract: The Warrior Games have become a symbol of the military’s changing perceptions about who is fit to serve. Some of the athletes make it to the Paralympics, which start this week in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Master Sgt. Ivan Morera isn’t used to being in last place. He’s a Green Beret. A relentless competitor. But at the 2024 Warrior Games, with his prosthetic hand hooked into a rowing machine, he was trailing the pack.

headline: What’s the Best Way to Explore Kenya? Join a Local Hiking Club.
abstract: The author sought an authentic experience, and found it in Lets Drift, “an exuberant Kenyan-centered enterprise” of people living in and near Nairobi.
lead_paragraph: By the time we reached the third waterfall on the Kahunira trail, my wife, Kiki, and I had been walking through the forested backcountry of Kiambu County, Kenya, for nearly three hours. Along the way, we had tasted sweet lady finger bananas in the market town of Githunguri, sipped a sour Kikuyu home brew called muratina proffered by laborers at a rural gravel quarry and made a heart-pounding shortcut across rust-flecked irrigation pipes that traversed a steep gorge fringed with tea plantations.

headline: Will A.I. Ruin the Planet or Save the Planet?
abstract: It’s a notorious energy hog. But artificial intelligence can also foster innovation and discovery, and it could speed the global transition to cleaner power.
lead_paragraph: The global experiment in artificial intelligence is just beginning. But the spending frenzy by big tech companies for building and leasing of data centers, the engine rooms for A.I., is well underway. They poured an estimated $105 billion last year into these vast, power-hungry facilities.

headline: A New Generation of Club Kids Is Born. They’re Younger Than You Think.
abstract: In New York, dance spots for tots and techno heads alike are thriving, with veteran D.J.s, oversize headphones and zero “Baby Shark.”
lead_paragraph: At a recent dance party in Brooklyn, Berk Sawyer, wearing Nike high-tops and a white bodysuit covered in city icons like pigeons and a hot-dog stand, bopped his head to the heavy bass. Occasionally, he bounced so hard he tumbled to the floor.

headline: Love Them or Hate Them, This Couple Reign in Russian Literature
abstract: For Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky, translating together extended naturally from their relationship as husband and wife. Now, it is their life’s work.
lead_paragraph: The first time Richard Pevear and Larissa Volokhonsky translated a Russian novel together, it felt as though another man had joined their marriage: Dostoyevsky.

headline: A Brooch That Diana Vreeland Kept on Her Night Stand, Reimagined
abstract: A new Tiffany & Co. jewelry collection mines the archive of the designer Jean Schlumberger.
lead_paragraph: Born into a textile manufacturing dynasty in German-held Alsace in 1907, Jean Schlumberger resisted his parents’ attempts to steer him into banking or the family business and eventually made his way to Paris in the 1930s. There he began working under the couturier Lucien Lelong (who would later become Christian Dior’s mentor). Known to frequent the stalls of the Marché aux Puces, Schlumberger would collect antiques: hand-painted relics, Victorian serpents and multicolored glass objects. By 1936, he was transforming porcelain flowers from old funeral wreaths into fantastical brooches, which were worn by his circle of artist friends, including Jean Cocteau and Christian Bérard. Schlumberger’s whimsical creations also caught the eye of the Italian fashion designer Elsa Schiaparelli, who asked him to create buttons shaped like starfish and plumed hats for her winter 1937 collection. That December, his designs were featured in Harper’s Bazaar, including “a gilded chain with jeweled tassels,” “flying fish earrings” and “a brooch made of roller-skating feet.”

headline: Republican Donors, Do You Know Where Your Money Goes?
abstract: We know the rules on political giving are broken, but so are the rules on spending.
lead_paragraph: We long ago blew past any meaningful controls on political giving in American elections. Now we should focus on the rules governing political spending, which are in equally terrible shape. For that we can blame the Trump campaign and the federal government’s feeble enforcement efforts.

headline: A 95-Square-Foot Caravan Inspired by Roald Dahl
abstract: The multimedia artist Yto Barrada has turned the tiny wagon in her Moroccan garden into a guesthouse.
lead_paragraph: The 53-year-old multimedia artist Yto Barrada grew up in a blue two-story house in a verdant Tangier neighborhood that overlooks the Strait of Gibraltar. About a decade ago, the Moroccan French artist, who also lives in New York City, transformed part of the family compound — including several small structures, as well as an expansive botanical garden that provides the flora she uses to make natural dyes — into what she recently named the Mothership, an experimental arts center where she offers textile and other workshops and hosts artists’ residencies. One of its newest additions, in another small garden up the path from the main street, is a 95-square-foot single-room pinewood caravan, a 50th-birthday gift to Barrada from her husband, the American filmmaker and actor Sean Gullette. “It’s my favorite present ever,” she says.

headline: Humanitarians Are Dying. Why Doesn’t the World Care?
abstract: The president of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies makes an impassioned plea for protecting humanitarian aid workers.
lead_paragraph: In February I met a man. Three hours later, he was dead.

headline: The Cyclone Suddenly Goes Silent in Coney Island
abstract: The 97-year-old roller coaster, a New York landmark, was taken out of service temporarily after a crack was detected in its machinery.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. James Barron is on vacation. Today we’ll look at why the Cyclone in Coney Island was taken out of service just before Labor Day weekend.

headline: What to Know About Getting a DNR Order
abstract: A “do not resuscitate” order can help you communicate your priorities for medical treatment. Here’s what to consider — and how to increase the chances that your wishes are upheld.
lead_paragraph: A “do not resuscitate” order instructs medical workers in and outside of a hospital not to restart your heart if it stops. It prohibits CPR and associated resuscitative measures, including electrical shocks to the heart, intubation, ventilation and certain medications.

headline: In This Fleet, Funny Novel, a Writer Makes Art and Sells Out in Hollywood
abstract: In “Colored Television,” by Danzy Senna, a struggling writer in a mixed-race family is seduced by the taste of luxury that comes with house-sitting.
lead_paragraph: Danzy Senna’s “Colored Television” is among the first major novels of 2024’s truncated fall book season — truncated because few publishers want to release a novel anywhere near the blast zone of the November election — but it feels more like a summer blockbuster.

headline: Gossiping Is Fun. It’s Natural. And These People Won’t Do It.
abstract: Gossip is a universal feature of human culture. It’s also the target of passionate, widespread censure.
lead_paragraph: In its most recent survey on the topic, the polling giant YouGov found that half of Americans admit to having “spread a piece of gossip.” YouGov did not report that the other half of Americans are filthy little liars, but it probably could have.

headline: The Stuff They Strut on the Jellicle Catwalk
abstract: From the first solo to the euphoric final bows, dance is essential to the world-building of “Cats: The Jellicle Ball.” Watch four standout dancers from the reinvented classic.
lead_paragraph: Before anyone steps onto the catwalk in “Cats: The Jellicle Ball,” the wildly popular reimagining of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Cats” at the Perelman Performing Arts Center, a dancer’s silhouette appears at the back of the stage, darting across a row of windows. At first, his movement recalls the limber ballet-jazz of the original 1982 Broadway production, accented with tricks like a split leap and a back walkover. He has two little ears, a tail. He could be prowling on a rooftop at night.

headline: Trump Can Win on Character
abstract: Presidential races are won and lost on character as much as the issues, and often the issues are proxies for character.
lead_paragraph: With the defenestration of President Biden and the ascent of Kamala Harris, conventional wisdom has gone from asking, “How can Donald Trump lose?” to “How can he win?”

headline: When A.I.’s Output Is a Threat to A.I. Itself
abstract: As A.I.-generated data becomes harder to detect, it’s increasingly likely to be ingested by future A.I., leading to worse results.
lead_paragraph: As A.I.-generated data becomes harder to detect, it’s increasingly likely to be ingested by future A.I., leading to worse results.

headline: Dismantling the Ship That Drilled for the Ocean’s Deepest Secrets
abstract: The JOIDES Resolution, which for decades was key to advancing the understanding of the Earth and its innards, concluded what could be its final scientific expedition.
lead_paragraph: A global cataclysm is portrayed in black and white in the sediments off the southeastern coast of the United States. Deep below the seafloor, chalky muds evince an ancient ocean flourishing with life. But a stark black layer cuts through the pale grains, marking the moment 66 million years ago when a six-mile wide asteroid slammed into Earth and our planet was never the same. The impact, known as the Chicxulub event, set off dramatic climate swings that sent 75 percent of Earth’s species — including all non-avian dinosaurs — spiraling toward extinction.

headline: $825,000 Homes in California
abstract: A midcentury retreat in Idyllwild, a two-bedroom condominium in Playa del Rey and a two-bedroom townhouse in Campbell.
lead_paragraph: This home, known as Idyllhouse, is a popular vacation rental within a 10-minute drive of hiking trails in the nearby mountains. It has been carefully restored and updated by the sellers, who added a new kitchen and primary bathroom, but retained classic midcentury elements like the red cedar paneling.

headline: Is It Better to Be Over- or Underdressed?
abstract: A reader seeks guidance on striking the right balance between casual and formal attire at events without a defined dress code.
lead_paragraph: This is like “Hamlet,” the S.N.L. version. You can just imagine a host wandering around a set crying, “to overdress or underdress, that is the question?” as they beat their breast and rend their doublet. In truth, there are two camps here.

headline: Museum to Part With Cranach Portrait Sold as Owner Fled the Nazis
abstract: The Allentown Art Museum agreed to sell the work, by Lucas Cranach the Elder and his workshop, to settle a restitution claim by a Jewish family, which will share in the proceeds.
lead_paragraph: A Pennsylvania museum is relinquishing a valuable 16th-century portrait attributed to Lucas Cranach the Elder and his workshop after reaching a settlement with descendants of a German Jewish couple who fled the Nazis before World War II.

headline: My Bookshelf, Myself
abstract: To walk past the bookcases in our family’s house is to make a different study of the history of time.
lead_paragraph: My husband, Haywood, reached retirement age this summer, but instead of actually retiring, he decided to stay on and teach part time. I work from home, alone in a silent house, and I am thrilled to have more time with the person I like best in all the world. The only downside was his stuff. When it’s time to give up his classroom, what does a veteran English teacher do with 37 years’ worth of posters and three-ring binders and author photos and various bringing-literature-to-life aids? What does he do with all the books?

headline: Kamala Harris Has Left the Building
abstract: The convention may be over, but there’s still a lot to discuss.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, I can’t wait to hear your impression of Kamala Harris’s big Chicago speech. Tell, tell.

headline: Sabrina Carpenter Is Gloriously Sly and Merciless
abstract: The pop singer and songwriter’s new album, “Short n’ Sweet,” lives up to her ubiquitous summer hits.
lead_paragraph: In Sabrina Carpenter’s songs, young romance is all sexy fun and games — until it’s not. “Short n’ Sweet,” her sixth full-length album, is a smart, funny, cheerfully merciless catalog of bad boyfriend behavior and the deceptions and rationalizations that enable it. Carpenter mostly smiles and winks her way through songs that recognize the irrational power of lust, but deftly twist the knife on cheaters and hypocrites. “No one’s more amazing at turning loving into hatred,” she warns in “Good Graces.”

headline: Harris Has the Momentum. But Trump Has the Edge on What Matters Most.
abstract: With early voting only weeks away, the race is still a close one.
lead_paragraph: Every Monday morning on The Point, we kick off the week with a tipsheet on the latest in the presidential campaign. Here’s what we’re looking at this week:

headline: No Evidence That Maduro Won, a Top Venezuelan Election Official Says
abstract: In an interview with The New York Times, an electoral council official expressed grave doubts about claims to victory by the authoritarian president, Nicolás Maduro.
lead_paragraph: One of Venezuela’s top election officials, in a declaration sure to jolt the crisis-weary nation, said in an interview that he had no proof that Venezuela’s authoritarian president won last month’s election.

headline: Fighting Sexual Temptation? Play Badminton, Hong Kong Tells Teenagers.
abstract: Top officials in the Chinese territory have defended new sex education guidance that critics call regressive. Young people are amused.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old girl and her boyfriend are studying alone together on a hot summer day when she removes her jacket and clings to his shoulder. What should he do?

headline: Russia Pounds Ukraine With ‘One of the Largest Strikes’ of the War
abstract: President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned an assault of more than 200 missiles and drones that ranged from Kyiv to Odesa to Ukraine’s West. Energy infrastructure was again a target.
lead_paragraph: Moscow launched more than 200 missiles and drones across a wide swath of Ukraine on Monday, damaging energy facilities and sending residents of Kyiv into basements and subways to seek shelter. President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the assault as “one of the largest strikes” of the 30-month-old war.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 443
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Aug. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level and if you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,165
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Israel and Hezbollah Trade Airstrikes, and U.S. Border Crossings Drop
abstract: Plus, an ambitious, risky private space mission.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Trump vs. Harris on the Economy
