abstract: A Times economic policy reporter breaks down the candidates’ plans on the issue.
lead_paragraph: As the 2024 presidential race enters the homestretch, former President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris are putting economic policy at the center of their pitches to voters.

headline: The Benefits of Shorter Campaigns
abstract: Presidential campaigns are marathons. Not this year.
lead_paragraph: Presidential campaigns are marathons: They start years before Election Day and proceed through door-knocking, living room meetings, candidate debates, newspaper interviews, leafleting, primaries, caucuses and nominating conventions. It’s not unusual, just a few months after a new president is sworn in, to see a contender stake out a state that holds an early primary or caucus.

headline: China to Hold Live-Fire Drills Near War-Torn Myanmar
abstract: Beijing likely wants to signal to Myanmar’s junta leaders that they should return to peace talks and de-escalate the conflict, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: China will hold live-fire military drills near its border with Myanmar starting on Tuesday, fortifying its boundaries with a southern neighbor that has been engulfed in a civil war for more than three years.

headline: Dangerous Heat Returns to Central and Eastern U.S. This Week
abstract: High heat and humidity could make it feel like 115 degrees Fahrenheit in parts of the country this week, forecasters warned.
lead_paragraph: Forecasters warned that “dangerous heat and humidity” will spread across the central and eastern United States this week, threatening to break records for high temperatures and ending a spell of fall-like weather.

headline: Polio Vaccines Arrive in Gaza, but Distributing Them Is the Next Challenge
abstract: UNICEF is pushing for a pause in the fighting to allow health workers to get two doses to every child, after Gaza recorded its first polio case in 25 years.
lead_paragraph: More than 1.2 million doses of the polio vaccine arrived in Gaza on Monday, in preparation for an expansive effort to inoculate more than 640,000 Palestinian children and curb a potential outbreak, the United Nations, Israel and health authorities in Gaza said.

headline: In a First, a Chinese Military Plane Breaches Japan’s Territorial Airspace
abstract: The territorial violation by China is the latest in a series of events amplifying tensions between Beijing and Japan.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese military surveillance plane breached Japanese airspace off the country’s southwestern coast on Monday, marking what Japan’s defense ministry described as the first known incursion by China’s military into its territorial airspace.

headline: Harris and Trump Squabble Over Debate Rules as ABC Matchup Looms
abstract: The former president derided the network and questioned why he would participate, while the vice president called for each candidate’s microphone to be left on for the entirety of the Sept. 10 event.
lead_paragraph: At the weigh-in before a big bout, prizefighters often taunt their opponents in an effort to try to psych them out.

headline: Choose Your Own Meatball Adventure
abstract: Play with the protein, spices, herbs and aromatics in this meatball recipe to get the exact combination you want for tonight’s dinner.
lead_paragraph: I almost never follow recipes, at least not exactly. I like to add a pinch of this and a spoonful of that, guided by what’s in my pantry and what I’m hungry for. This is why I find it almost physically impossible to make the same thing twice.

headline: Can You Guess These Novels That Originally Got Bad Times Reviews?
abstract: Some works that went on to become popular literary classics first got mixed or bad reviews. Try this short quiz to see if you recognize the novels as described by their original reviewers in The Times.
lead_paragraph: Some works that went on to become popular literary classics first got mixed or bad reviews. Try this short quiz to see if you recognize the novels as described by their original reviewers in The Times.

headline: Wave of Attacks Rattles a Restive Province in Pakistan
abstract: At least 38 people have been killed in several assaults across Baluchistan Province since Sunday in what appears to be part of a campaign by armed separatists in the region.
lead_paragraph: The violence began with blasts that ripped through a military camp in Pakistan’s Baluchistan Province late Sunday night, killing at least one soldier. Around the same time, armed men stormed into at least four police stations in the province, spraying bullets at officers and setting police vehicles on fire, local officials said.

headline: Post Malone Returns to No. 1 With His Country Debut, ‘F-1 Trillion’
abstract: The shape-shifting pop songwriter’s new album debuts atop the Billboard 200, and Chappell Roan’s “Midwest Princess” holds at No. 2.
lead_paragraph: Post Malone, the face-tattooed singer and songwriter who emerged a decade ago with a rock-meets-folk-meets-rap style that caught fire on streaming services, opens at No. 1 on the latest Billboard album chart with “F-1 Trillion,” which repositions the star in a country context.

headline: Now an Acclaimed Restaurateur, He Long Concealed a Secret
abstract: Arjav Ezekiel rose through the restaurant ranks becoming a sommelier and opening Birdie’s in Austin, Texas. Few knew of his past as an undocumented immigrant.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, Arjav Ezekiel appears to be living the dream.

headline: Canada Will Impose 100% Tariffs on Chinese Electric Vehicles
abstract: The new tariffs announced by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will match levies imposed by President Biden and could further strain relations between Canada and China.
lead_paragraph: In a significant escalation of trade tensions between Western countries and China, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Monday that Canada would impose 100 percent tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles, joining the United States and the European Union in protecting domestic car production.

headline: Trump and Harris Embody a Stark Partisan Divide on Fighting Poverty
abstract: The two presidential candidates can both point to records of pushing poverty rates down, but their approaches could hardly be more different.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on the Harris and Trump campaigns.

headline: Is Your Water Bottle Really Made From Recycled Plastic?
abstract: A green accounting method called “mass balance” certifies that something was manufactured with recycled plastic — just not necessarily much of the bottle making the claim.
lead_paragraph: The plastic CamelBak bottles displayed in a Target in East Hanover, N.J., offer a promise to ecologically conscious buyers. On the front of each is a bright blue sticker with the words “Tritan Renew made with 50% recycled material.”

headline: Uber Fined $324 Million by Dutch Watchdog Over Driver Data Protection
abstract: The authorities in the Netherlands said the ride-hailing company had violated European data protection laws when it sent sensitive information to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Uber faces a fine of 290 million euros, or more than $324 million, over a violation of European Union rules that protect data privacy, a Dutch agency said Monday.

headline: What We Can Learn From Tim Walz and His Son, Gus
abstract: Parents of neurodivergent children praise a guest essay by Tina Brown. Also: Is Trump funny? RFK Jr.’s endorsement of Trump; antitrust law.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Telegram Founder’s Arrest Part of Broad Investigation, French Prosecutors Say
abstract: A case was opened last month to investigate child pornography, drug sales, fraud and other criminal activities on the platform. The app’s founder, Pavel Durov, was detained over the weekend near Paris.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in France said on Monday that Pavel Durov, the entrepreneur who runs the Telegram messaging platform, had been arrested in connection with an investigation opened last month into criminal activity on the app and a lack of cooperation with law enforcement.

headline: Russia Strikes Ukrainian Cities With Missiles and Drones
abstract: Cities across Ukraine were hit in a widespread attack that also targeted energy infrastructure, Ukrainian officials said.
lead_paragraph: Cities across Ukraine were hit in a widespread attack that also targeted energy infrastructure, Ukrainian officials said.

headline: Hungry for Clean Energy, Facebook Looks to a New Type of Geothermal
abstract: As electricity demand from data centers soars, Meta and Google are looking at a novel solution: harnessing clean heat far below Earth’s surface.
lead_paragraph: Big tech companies across the United States are struggling to find enough clean energy to power all the data centers they plan to build.

headline: Captain of Sunken Yacht Under Investigation in Deaths on Ship
abstract: The investigation does not necessarily imply that formal charges will follow against the captain, James Cutfield.
lead_paragraph: Italian authorities have opened a formal investigation into the actions of James Cutfield, the captain of the superyacht that sank last Monday off the coast of Sicily, killing seven of the 22 people on board, including British tech billionaire Mike Lynch.

headline: Alabama High School Football Player Dies After Sustaining Head Injury
abstract: Caden Tellier, a quarterback, was critically injured after being tackled in the third quarter of a game on Friday night, school officials in Selma said. He died on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A high school quarterback in Selma, Ala., died after sustaining a critical brain injury during his team’s first game of the season on Friday night, school officials said.

headline: Another New Leader for Indianapolis Museum Roiled by Racism Outcry
abstract: Le Monte Booker will be the institution’s third leader in four years. The previous president and chief executive left last year after just over a year on the job.
lead_paragraph: The Indianapolis Museum of Art is getting its third leader in four years as it continues to deal with the fallout from a racially insensitive job posting that led to its longtime leader’s departure in 2021.

headline: Why California Is Considering Banning Food Dyes in Schools
abstract: Concerns about their risks have been swirling for years. Here’s what the science suggests.
lead_paragraph: For decades, researchers have been trying to answer a hotly contested question: Do the synthetic dyes used to add vibrant colors to foods like certain breakfast cereals, candies, snacks and baked goods cause behavioral issues in children?

headline: How Telegram’s Founder Went From Russia’s Mark Zuckerberg to Wanted Man
abstract: Pavel Durov’s anti-establishment streak helped him create one of the world’s biggest online platforms, which emphasizes free speech. It also put a target on his back.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, when Russia pushed Pavel Durov to shut down the pages of opposition politicians on a Facebook-like site he had created, the tech entrepreneur responded online by posting a cheeky picture of a hoodie-wearing dog with its tongue out.

headline: Isabel Wilkerson Looks Back at ‘The Warmth of Other Suns’
abstract: The fifth in a series of conversations with authors appearing on our “Best Books of the 21st Century” list.
lead_paragraph: As part of its recent “100 Best Books of the 21st Century” project, The New York Times Book Review is interviewing some of the authors whose books appeared on the list. This week, Isabel Wilkerson joins our host Gilbert Cruz to discuss her 2010 book “The Warmth of Other Suns: The Epic Story of America’s Great Migration.” In his write-up for that project, Dwight Garner called it “the most vital and compulsively readable work of history in recent memory.”

headline: Telegram Turmoil Threatens Dominant Chronicle of the War in Ukraine
abstract: The detention of Telegram’s founder has highlighted the messaging app’s outsize status in Europe’s deadliest war since World War II.
lead_paragraph: The detention of Pavel Durov, the founder of the Telegram messaging app, in Paris on Saturday has raised questions about the future of a platform that has come to define the public perception of Russia’s war in Ukraine.

headline: What Kamala Harris Needs to Do to Take On China
abstract: Washington cannot win “the competition for the 21st century” against Beijing by itself.
lead_paragraph: The United States needs a strategy for dealing with China as an economic and national security threat, and Donald Trump’s blustery “America First” approach ain’t it. Kamala Harris has a better shot because of her belief in strengthening alliances.

headline: Gus Walz Brought Out Both the Joy and the Cruelty
abstract: He deserved the kind of treatment any person does.
lead_paragraph: Gus Walz’s unbridled emotional reaction last week at the Democratic National Convention to the nomination of his father, Gov. Tim Walz, embodied both the humanity that lies beneath the political process and the momentousness of the political process itself.

headline: The 100 Best Books of the 21st Century: A Printable List
abstract: Print this version to keep track of what you’ve read and what you’d like to read.
lead_paragraph: Print this version to keep track of what you’ve read and what you’d like to read.

headline: Sean Combs Fights Lawsuit by Music Producer Alleging Sexual Misconduct
abstract: The hip-hop mogul’s lawyers are seeking the dismissal of a suit from Rodney Jones Jr., arguing it is baseless and “replete with far-fetched tales of misconduct.”
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Sean Combs filed court papers on Monday seeking the dismissal of a civil suit by a music producer who accused Mr. Combs of making unwanted sexual contact, arguing that the lawsuit was baseless and “replete with far-fetched tales of misconduct.”

headline: 2 Men Charged With Damaging Ancient Rock Formation at Lake Mead
abstract: In a video from April, two men appear to be pushing large red rocks — estimated to be over 100 million years old — over the edge of a cliff at Lake Mead National Recreation Area in Nevada.
lead_paragraph: Two men were indicted last week on charges that they damaged an ancient rock formation at Lake Mead National Recreation Area in Nevada in April, federal prosecutors said. A video appeared to show the men toppling some of the rocks.

headline: Prosecutors Appeal Dismissal of Trump Documents Case
abstract: The special counsel, Jack Smith, argued that Judge Aileen Cannon had erred in throwing out charges against Donald Trump of improperly holding national security secrets after leaving office.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors began their bid to resurrect the moribund classified documents case against former President Donald J. Trump on Monday, telling an appeals court in Atlanta that the trial judge had improperly thrown out the charges.

headline: What’s Dining Out Like For a Vegetarian New Yorker? Share Your Experience.
abstract: The New York Times Food team wants to hear your stories, to help inform our reporting.
lead_paragraph: Eating out in New York has changed drastically in the last several years. It’s now more expensive, more diverse and in theory, more accommodating of dietary restrictions. But even as terms like “plant based” and “vegetable forward” are tossed around, the question remains: Just how vegetarian-friendly are the city’s restaurants?

headline: Dam Collapse Devastates Communities in Eastern Sudan
abstract: The Arba’at dam fell apart after days of heavy rain, killing villagers and flooding communities.
lead_paragraph: A dam that collapsed in Sudan near the Red Sea on Sunday flooded surrounding communities and caused an unknown number of deaths and injuries, local and international officials said. The disaster heaped additional misery on a country where millions are already suffering from war and famine.

headline: Eric Butler, 49, Dies; Promoted ‘Restorative Justice’ for Young People
abstract: As a counselor, he embraced an alternative to “zero tolerance” disciplinary policies that are disproportionately meted out to Black students.
lead_paragraph: Eric Butler, an anti-violence counselor with a gift for winning the trust of emotionally closed-off teenagers, who worked with students, school districts and prosecutors’ offices to divert young people from being sucked into the criminal justice system, died on Aug. 4 at his home in New Orleans. He was 49.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Russia Launches a Large-Scale Attack
abstract: Plus, badminton instead of sex.
lead_paragraph: Russia launched more than 200 missiles and drones across a broad swath of Ukraine yesterday. President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the assault as “one of the largest strikes” of the 30-month-old war.

headline: How a Federal Court in New Orleans Is Driving the Conservative Agenda
abstract: Today, the U.S. Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals is an outlier. But a Trump victory in November could transform it into the standard-bearer of MAGA-era jurisprudence.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court term that ended this summer delivered a number of big wins for traditional conservative causes. The court made it easier to challenge federal regulations. It made it harder to prosecute former presidents. And it delivered another decision that expanded the rights of gun enthusiasts.

headline: Deadly Landslide Strikes Ketchikan, Alaska
abstract: The disaster killed one person and injured three in the town. Researchers said heavy rains preceding the disaster may have played a role.
lead_paragraph: A violent landslide has raced down a forested hillside in Ketchikan, Alaska, killing one person and injuring three.

headline: Harris and Trump Squabbled Over Debate Rules
abstract: Also, Russia attacked Ukraine’s energy infrastructure. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump said today that he was still “thinking about” whether he should participate in a Sept. 10 debate with Kamala Harris on ABC News, threatening again to pull out of the only debate that both candidates have agreed to.

headline: Kroger’s Nearly $25 Billion Merger Is Bad for Shoppers, F.T.C. Says
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission, which is trying to block Kroger’s plan to acquire Albertsons, said in court that the merger of grocery giants would also hurt workers’ pay and benefits.
lead_paragraph: A trial that could determine whether the two largest supermarket chains in the United States can merge opened in Portland, Ore., on Monday, pitting the grocery giant Kroger against regulators who argue that its takeover of Albertsons would eliminate competition at the expense of consumers and workers.

headline: Trump Hits Harris Over ‘Humiliation’ in Military’s Afghan Exit
abstract: Courting military votes, Donald Trump visited Arlington National Cemetery to observe the anniversary of a deadly Kabul bombing and then spoke at a National Guard group’s conference.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump wrapped himself in military imagery on Monday, attacking the Biden administration over its withdrawal from Afghanistan. Observing the third anniversary of a deadly suicide bombing in Kabul, the Afghan capital, he visited Arlington National Cemetery, then later spoke in Detroit to a gathering of National Guard members.

headline: Jill Stein Will Remain on the Ballot in Wisconsin After Court Order
abstract: The Wisconsin Supreme Court denied a Democratic challenge to the Green Party candidate’s ballot access in the state.
lead_paragraph: Jill Stein, the presidential candidate for the Green Party, will remain on the ballot in Wisconsin, the state’s Supreme Court said, after the court declared a Democratic technical challenge to her ballot access moot on Monday.

headline: Assassination Task Force Visits Butler as Right Wing Promises a ‘Parallel’ Inquiry
abstract: As members of the newly formed bipartisan task force investigating the assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump began their work, some hard-right Republicans were already warning of a cover-up.
lead_paragraph: Members of the newly formed House task force on the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump took one of their first investigative steps on Monday, traveling to the site of the shooting in Butler, Pa., to scrutinize the scene.

headline: Three Los Angeles Museums Team Up to Acquire Art
abstract: The Hammer, LACMA and MOCA are establishing a joint collection, starting off with a gift of 260 works from the collectors Jarl and Pamela Mohn.
lead_paragraph: As cultural institutions are recognizing the potential for pooling resources, the Hammer Museum, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles are establishing a joint collection of contemporary art by Los Angeles artists, to be founded through the acquisition of nearly 300 artworks from the collectors Jarl and Pamela Mohn.

headline: Democrats Sue Georgia Election Board, Warning of ‘Chaos’
abstract: The board recently passed new rules aimed at altering the process for certifying elections. The lawsuit says such changes are illegal.
lead_paragraph: Democrats sued the Georgia state election board on Monday, arguing that measures approved by the board this month seeking to alter the election certification process in the state were illegal and could create chaos on Election Day.

headline: Rudy Franchi, Who Put Movies at the Center of a Technicolor Life, Dies at 85
abstract: He brought French classics to New York, published a film magazine, worked as a Hollywood publicist and, as seen on “Antiques Roadshow,” thrived selling vintage film posters and other ephemera.
lead_paragraph: Rudy Franchi, who during a kaleidoscopic life brought French films to New York City, indulged in trysts with Hollywood stars as a publicist, operated one of the country’s largest vintage movie poster businesses and appraised ephemera — most memorably, a lunch menu from the Titanic — on the PBS program “Antiques Roadshow,” died on Aug. 6 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Inflation Is Fading, Statistically and Politically
abstract: The cost of living may not be the G.O.P.’s, um, trump card.
lead_paragraph: Last week was full of speeches. Most of those that attracted national attention were at the Democratic National Convention, culminating in Vice President Kamala Harris’s big moment on Thursday. But there was another important speech on Friday: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s talk at the Fed’s annual shindig in Jackson Hole, Wyo.

headline: Sid Eudy, 63, Dies; Wrestler Known as ‘Sid Vicious’ (Among Other Names)
abstract: Listed at 6-foot-9 and 317 pounds, he faced off against some of the industry’s biggest names, including Shawn Michaels and Hulk Hogan.
lead_paragraph: Sid Eudy, the professional wrestler known variously as Sid Justice, Sid Vicious and Sycho Sid, who rose to fame in the 1990s, died on Monday. He was 63.

headline: Democrats Look to End the Electability Question
abstract: The party is battling a squishy, often self-reinforcing concept about the perceived ability to win.
lead_paragraph: This year, Angela Alsobrooks, the county executive of Prince George’s County, Md., and a Democrat, sought support for her U.S. Senate bid from an elected official she had known for years.

headline: Former Aides to Bush, Romney and McCain Back Harris Over Trump
abstract: The former Republican staffers’ support of the Democratic ticket reflects how former President Donald J. Trump has transformed the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 people who previously worked for President George W. Bush and Senators Mitt Romney and John McCain have signed a letter endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris.

headline: Judge Pauses Biden Administration Program That Aids Undocumented Spouses
abstract: Ruling in favor of 16 Republican-led states that sued the administration, a federal judge put the program on hold while the court considers the merits of the case.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas temporarily blocked on Monday a Biden administration program that could offer a path to citizenship for up to half a million undocumented immigrants who are married to U.S. citizens, ruling in favor of 16 Republican-led states that sued the administration.

headline: Man Is Charged With Arson in California Wildfire That Destroyed 13 Homes
abstract: The Thompson fire also burned over 3,700 acres and forced the evacuation of 26,000 residents.
lead_paragraph: A 26-year-old California man was arrested last week on arson charges in connection with the Thompson fire in July, which destroyed 13 homes, burned over 3,700 acres and forced the evacuation of 26,000 people, according to the law enforcement agencies.

headline: Edgar Bronfman Jr. Drops Pursuit of Paramount
abstract: Mr. Bronfman had frantically put a bid together over the last week even as Paramount raised questions about his financing.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Bronfman Jr. abandoned his pursuit of Paramount on Monday, dropping his 11th-hour bid roughly a day before the deadline to submit a final offer for the owner of CBS and MTV.

headline: Take the Wheel
abstract: Julia Hoepner makes her New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Two Bodies Found in Rice University Dorm Room in Possible Murder-Suicide
abstract: A female student was fatally shot. A man who was not a student had a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the university president said.
lead_paragraph: Two people were found shot dead in a dorm room at Rice University in Houston, the university president said on Monday, in what appeared to be a murder-suicide.

headline: ‘Twilight Love’: Shanghai’s Lonely and Retired Are Looking for Love
abstract: China has the world’s largest population of people 65 or older, and more and more of them are unattached.
lead_paragraph: For Shanghai’s lonely and retired, love is elusive. Divorced or widowed residents gather in a dating corner in People’s Park every weekend looking for a chat. They mill about an Ikea canteen on Tuesdays in search of some fun.

headline: To Stay Relevant, a Spanish Energy Giant Turns to Waste
abstract: Repsol figures that there is still life in vehicle fuels as long as they can be portrayed as low carbon.
lead_paragraph: In a narrow valley with steep sides near the ancient city of Cartagena, Spain, a team of 150 engineers has just finished building a plant that could be a game changer for Repsol, the Spanish energy company, and a bellwether for the transportation industry.

headline: Prosecutor Turned Politician: Could Britain’s Leader Show Harris a Path to Power?
abstract: Like Kamala Harris, Prime Minister Keir Starmer was a prosecutor before embracing politics. The two share a few other traits.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris said last week in Chicago, “you can always trust me to put country above party,” it struck a familiar note in Britain, where the new prime minister, Keir Starmer, used much the same phrase throughout the Labour Party’s relentless march to power earlier this summer.

headline: In Eastern Ukraine, Terrifying Bombardment and Near Total Destruction
abstract: Powerful guided “glide bombs” have helped Russia raze entire towns with ever greater speed. “When you drive into a ruined town, it’s like hopelessness,” one soldier said.
lead_paragraph: In the darkness of the cellar in the eastern Ukrainian town of Toretsk, the soldiers did not know how close the Russian glide bombs were landing. But the sudden change in air pressure that accompanied bone-rattling booms testified to the bombs’ destructive force as they tore into nearby buildings.

headline: A Mercedes-Benz Fire Jolts South Korea’s E.V. Transition
abstract: The government is aggressively promoting electric cars. But a dramatic blaze in an underground lot has left some potential buyers worried about safety.
lead_paragraph: The flames and smoke from a burning Mercedes-Benz electric sedan spread rapidly through the underground parking lot of an apartment complex in South Korea this month. The fire damaged almost 900 cars, and 23 people suffered smoke inhalation.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Moscow launched more than 200 missiles and drones across a wide swath of Ukraine yesterday, in what Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, described as “one of the largest strikes” of the 30-month-old war. Officials said four people had been killed and more than 30 others had been injured.

headline: Typhoon Shanshan Approaches Japan, Bringing Heavy Rain and Winds
abstract: Japan’s southern islands were forecast to receive the most rain. The powerful storm has forced flight cancellations and disrupted high-speed rail travel.
lead_paragraph: Typhoon Shanshan was churning toward southwestern Japan on Tuesday, bringing torrential rain and strong winds, forcing some flight cancellations and disrupting the country’s high-speed rail network.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 27, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Aug. 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about peace negotiations for the conflict in Sudan misidentified Lana Nusseibeh. She is the former United Arab Emirates ambassador to the United Nations, not the current one.

headline: Quotation of the Day: 1 Million Cheat Bus Fare Daily, Foiling M.T.A.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 27, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “If the transit system does not work and nobody plays by the rules, it feels lawless. It is lawless.”

headline: Word of the Day: hatchling
abstract: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word hatchling has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 26 in “Florida Turtle Nests Are Recovering. When They Hatch, Expect Mostly Girls” by Elizabeth Anne Brown:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: For Italian Tennis Stars, a Little Corner of Rome in the East Village
abstract: A Manhattan trattoria has become the de facto lounge for Italians at the U.S. Open.
lead_paragraph: The Wimbledon semifinalist from Carrara sat in the bar area with his family. The 69th ranked women’s player, a hard-charging right-hander from Rimini, ate in the main dining room with friends. Out in the back garden, the 31st best men’s player in the world, a rising star from Rome, chowed down with his team.

headline: His Siblings Gathered to Sell the Family Home. Then He Started Shooting.
abstract: Joseph DeLucia, despondent over the sale of the Long Island house where he lived with his mother, killed three siblings, a niece and himself, the police said.
lead_paragraph: For years, Joseph DeLucia cut a foreboding figure to neighbors in the quiet Long Island cul-de-sac where he lived his entire life with his mother.

headline: Oasis Announces Reunion Tour After 15 Years of Brotherly War
abstract: Liam and Noel Gallagher’s 1990s Britpop band will play dates in Britain and Ireland in 2025.
lead_paragraph: In the list of rock bands considered least likely to bury their hatchets long enough to successfully reunite, the British group Oasis has always been near the very top.

headline: The Finest, Funnest, Most Freeing Footwear
abstract: Go ahead and wear your rubber sandals — even in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Flip-flops have remained one of the most reviled men’s-wear items. Tom Ford regularly inveighs against them, and fashion magazines make special mention of their ghastliness. But in Orange County, where I’m from, flip-flops function in a way that’s only suggested elsewhere: They complete a tableau of carefree, sand-speckled revelry — an endless, almost utopian vision of joblessness and idle bliss. Even the PacSun and Hollister ads, set in an idealized Orange County, are too charged with a manufactured spring-break debauchery to accurately capture the mellow SoCal lassitude. In the O.C., flip-flops were flimsy foot skis meant to help people reach a secluded surf spot — for hopping in cars or treading lightly atop sand dunes.

headline: Why Is the Loneliness Epidemic So Hard to Cure?
abstract: Maybe because we aren’t thinking about it in the right way.
lead_paragraph: In the early months of 2020, as the Covid-19 pandemic settled over the country, a psychologist and Harvard lecturer named Richard Weissbourd approached his colleagues with a concept for a new kind of study. Loneliness, or the specter of it, seemed to Weissbourd to be everywhere — in the solitude of quarantine, in the darkened windows of the buildings on campus, in the Zoom squares that had come to serve as his primary conduit to his students. Two years earlier, he read a study from Cigna, the insurance provider, showing that 46 percent of Americans felt sometimes or always alone. In 2019, when Cigna replicated the study, the number of lonely respondents had grown to 52 percent. God knows what the data would say now, Weissbourd thought.

headline: Russia Launches Deadly New Wave of Missiles and Drones at Ukraine
abstract: The bombardment that began on Monday could have additional significance, coming three weeks after the Ukrainian military’s incursion into Russia’s Kursk region.
lead_paragraph: Russia launched a fresh wave of pre-dawn missile and drone attacks on Kyiv and several other large Ukrainian cities on Tuesday, the second day of a deadly, far-reaching bombing campaign that comes as Moscow fights to fend off a Ukrainian offensive on Russian soil.

headline: Star Wars Outlaws Review: Return of the Ennui
abstract: The vast galaxy is filled with well-worn concepts from other open-world games. Finding excitement requires descending to the game’s black markets and gambling dens.
lead_paragraph: Star Wars Outlaws, an attempt by the publisher of Assassin’s Creed and Far Cry to plug the famous movie franchise into the tried-and-true formula of the open-world action-adventure game, is, unsurprisingly, huge. It spans a broad galaxy broken up into several systems, each featuring its own hub worlds with distinct natural biomes and identities.

headline: The Year Tom Cruise Gave Not One but Two Dangerously Vulnerable Performances
abstract: Twenty-five years ago, the superstar starred in “Eyes Wide Shut” and “Magnolia,” and opened himself up for the camera in ways he rarely has since.
lead_paragraph: “Eyes Wide Shut” had a blunt sales pitch: Cruise. Kidman. Kubrick.

headline: The ‘Beetlejuice Beetlejuice’ Reunion Reunion: How It Came Together
abstract: Michael Keaton, Winona Ryder, Catherine O’Hara and their director, Tim Burton, look back on the first movie, the “Day-O” scene and their ghost comedy’s afterlife.
lead_paragraph: If you wonder why it took 36 years for “Beetlejuice” to spawn a sequel, consider how complicated it was simply to reunite its busy principals for a video call last month.

headline: 4,000 Miles, 6 Small Towns: A Whistle-Stop Tour of America
abstract: Most people who ride Amtrak’s Empire Builder route between Chicago and Seattle watch the heartland whiz by. Our writer hopped off to explore a few remarkable places you might otherwise miss.
lead_paragraph: “See America,” an old Amtrak slogan promised, “at See-Level.” And if you ride the railroad’s Empire Builder route from Chicago to Seattle and back, as I did recently, you’ll watch the scenery evolve, from city to suburb to small town to north woods to sweeping grasslands to Great Plains to sandy buttes to snow-capped peaks to sagebrush meadows to pine-lined streams to small town to suburb to city.

headline: Is DEET Bug Spray Harmful?
abstract: Some worry that this active ingredient is toxic. Here’s what we know about its effect on human health.
lead_paragraph: Q: Everyone says that the DEET in bug spray is awful, but my own research seems to suggest that it’s well-tested and safe. Am I giving myself a little bit of cancer every time I use it?

headline: The Human Cost of Your Breakfast Banana
abstract: In June a Florida jury found Chiquita Brands liable for the deaths of eight men killed by a Colombian paramilitary group the company had financed.
lead_paragraph: Although several El Espectador journalists were killed in the 1980s and ’90s, many young reporters aspired to being on the staff of the storied Colombian newspaper at the end of the 20th century. I loved working there, despite the risks. After the Medellín cartel bombed our headquarters, my colleagues and I rescued from the rubble the desk on which Gabriel García Márquez wrote his first stories for the paper.

headline: 5 Ways to Feel More Connected, According to Dr. Ruth
abstract: In ‘The Joy of Connections,’ a book set to publish shortly after her death at 96, America’s best-known sex therapist offered practical strategies for anyone feeling lonely.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of her life, America’s best-known sex therapist Dr. Ruth Westheimer stopped talking so much about sexual dysfunction and started talking about another topic often shrouded in shame: loneliness.

headline: 19 New Books Coming in September
abstract: New novels by Sally Rooney and Richard Powers, a memoir by the first Black woman on the Supreme Court — and more.
lead_paragraph: An American agent infiltrates a commune of French environmentalists in Kushner’s philosophical rendition of the spy novel. The anarchists should be no match for the agent’s clever tactics, but her loyalties and opinions prove to be vulnerable after she meets the group’s mysterious leader.

headline: At Michigan, Activists Take Over and Shut Down Student Government
abstract: Pro-Palestinian protesters won council elections, and have refused to fund campus groups, like the men’s Ultimate Frisbee team, unless their divestment demands are met.
lead_paragraph: Students were braced for a stalemate. There was an Ultimate Frisbee team without money to compete, an airport shuttle whose cost to students almost doubled without a campus subsidy, and a ballroom dance team unable to rent rehearsal space.

headline: He Bought a (Miniature) Zoo
abstract: The painter Walton Ford has amassed dozens of vintage German animal figurines.
lead_paragraph: Every morning, Walton Ford wakes up in his West Village townhouse and sees a menagerie on the mantel. The 64-year-old artist, who creates detailed, large-scale watercolors of exotic animals, has spent more than a decade building a collection of vintage composite animal figures. (The term “composite” describes the linoleum-like mixture used to create toys before plastic became manufacturers’ medium of choice.) Only two main companies in Germany produced this now-rare product — typically no more than 2 inches high and 2 inches long — between the early 1900s and World War II. “If you’re an artist who studies animal anatomy, you are blown away by these things,” Ford says. “It’s like you have these little zoo animals in the room.” Many of the creatures’ poses will look familiar to fans of Ford’s art; he frequently works from photographs of them. The artist, whose sketches, watercolors and studies are on view at the Morgan Library & Museum in New York through Oct. 20, says that being greeted by the tiny animals each day reminds him “what my purpose is.”

headline: For a Night on the Town, Try Leather and Lace
abstract: This fall, men’s wear is all about embracing the darkness.

headline: On the Covid ‘Off-Ramp’: No Tests, Isolation or Masks
abstract: For many, Covid is increasingly regarded like the common cold. A scratchy throat and canceled plans bring a bewildering new critique from friends: You shouldn’t have tested.
lead_paragraph: Jason Moyer was days away from a family road trip to visit his parents when his 10-year-old son woke up with a fever and cough.

headline: Why the M.T.A. Is Worried About Fare Evaders on Buses
abstract: About a million bus riders fail to pay the fare every weekday in New York. The transit system needs that revenue.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at the rise in fare evasion on city buses, and what officials are planning to do about it.

headline: Who Are the Korean Cheerleaders Flooding TikTok?
abstract: Videos of baseball cheerleaders performing an ultra-chill dance routine have taken over social media algorithms, intriguing millions of viewers.
lead_paragraph: It starts with bouncy drum beats, quickly interrupted by the sounds of sneakers squeaking on a gym floor. Then a thumbs up comes into frame, swiveling up and down like a hammer.

headline: Opera Doesn’t Have to Be an Elite Art Form. Here’s Why.
abstract: If opera at its best aspires to a different world, then we need to cultivate an anti-elite approach to how it is created and performed.
lead_paragraph: Is opera a standard-bearer or a pallbearer of the status quo?

headline: H.R. McMaster Doesn’t Think Donald Trump Is Very Good at Making Deals
abstract: A new memoir by the onetime national security adviser shows how the former president’s insecurities and weaknesses harmed U.S. foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: Recently on the campaign trail, Donald Trump has talked up his aggressive stance on China, positioning himself as a tough negotiator in a brutal trade war. But a new memoir by Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster, one of Trump’s national security advisers, throws that narrative, and many other stories that Trump tells about his time in office, into stark relief.

headline: For a New ‘Empire Records,’ Zoe Sarnak Set Out to Write a ’90s Anthem
abstract: The composer is breaking the rules of musical theater and finding an increasingly warm welcome this year for her rock sound. Next up, “Empire Records: The Musical.”
lead_paragraph: As a teenager in New Jersey, the composer and lyricist Zoe Sarnak was a star soccer player, earning her place in the Princeton High School Athletic Hall of Fame. Her position? “Center mid,” she said in a recent interview. “The one who runs the most.”

headline: A Terrific Adam Sandler Special and Other Stand-Up Shows to Stream
abstract: The star is in fine, filthy form under the direction of Josh Safdie (“Uncut Gems”). Hannah Berner and Langston Kerman also deliver standout hours.
lead_paragraph: When Barack Obama made a reference to the size of Donald J. Trump’s, ahem, crowd size, in his speech last week at the Democratic National Convention, he brought a category of lewd joke into the absolute center of the mainstream. This unlikely achievement owes a debt to Adam Sandler, who has been consistently committed to the art, at least since writing a dirty rhyme in a classmate’s middle-school yearbook.

headline: R.F.K. Jr.’s Brain Worm Speaks Out
abstract: After digesting Kennedy’s thoughts, his motivations become clearer.
lead_paragraph: A lot of people have been wondering what Robert F. Kennedy Jr. can possibly be thinking, and I can say with confidence that no one is better positioned to offer an answer than I am.

headline: The World’s Largest Wetland Is Burning, and Rare Animals Are Dying
abstract: In Brazil, wildfires have roared across the Pantanal, a maze of rivers, forests and marshlands that sprawl over an area 20 times the size of the Everglades.
lead_paragraph: Two jaguar cubs burned to death, their small bodies carbonized. Tapirs with raw, bloodied paws had been scalded by smoldering cinders. Nests of unhatched eggs from rare parrots were consumed by flames as tall as trees.

headline: The ‘Sad Missed Opportunity’ of the Democratic Convention
abstract: Kamala Harris needs to do more to assure voters on Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party’s recent position — or lack of position — on Gaza “feels like gaslighting to a lot of Democratic voters,” Farah Stockman of the editorial board argues in this audio essay. The party claims to value social justice and human rights, but when it comes to the ongoing conflict in the Middle East, she says, Kamala Harris “needs to do more, and she can do more, to assure people she’s going to have a more evenhanded approach when she becomes president.”

headline: If Liza Minnelli’s Jewelry Could Talk
abstract: Studio 54. Versailles. The Oscars. Some of the pieces worn by Ms. Minnelli have seen a lot.
lead_paragraph: The scene had all the subtlety of a sequined sledgehammer: Liza Minnelli, a performer who has often been measured against her mother, the actress Judy Garland, was lounging on a sofa beneath fluorescent Warhol portraits of Ms. Garland, Ms. Minnelli and her father, the director Vincente Minnelli.

headline: Why Some Young, Undecided Voters Changed Their Minds About Kamala Harris After Her Speech
abstract: They were skeptical and even suspicious of Ms. Harris before the convention. Her speech shifted some of their thinking.
lead_paragraph: This summer, Times Opinion organized a new project to follow a group of young, undecided voters through the election, and we kicked it off just before the Democratic National Convention with a wide-ranging discussion about Donald Trump and Kamala Harris. The group had very specific opinions about Mr. Trump. The Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol was searing for many of them, some of whom were teenagers at the time, and they held Mr. Trump responsible. They called him a traitor, a narcissist, untrustworthy. Some worried he would fight another election loss.

headline: How Democrats View Kennedy and Trump: ‘A Weirdo Campaign Just Got Weirder’
abstract: Democrats once seriously worried that Robert F. Kennedy Jr. would be a spoiler. Now, after his endorsement of Donald Trump, they see a political opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: The Election Is in 10 Weeks. These 3 Things About the Polls Keep Me Up at Night.
abstract: It’s important to remember how messy social science can be.
lead_paragraph: Sunday night was an unexpectedly exciting time in the Anderson household: Just after dinnertime, my husband got called and asked to participate in an election poll. I was in the middle of getting my toddler ready for bed when he rushed into the room, holding our baby in one hand and his phone in the other, now on speaker so I could hear the questions.

headline: Abraham Lincoln’s Wiliest Trick Should Be a Lesson for Biden
abstract: A model of how a lame duck can nobly serve the nation.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Convention is over. Kamala Harris has accepted her party’s ringing nomination. President Biden has been relegated to the wings, a lame duck before his time. What role should he play between now and January?

headline: When Your Child Is an Animal
abstract: The charged cultural conversation about pets and children — see “Chimp Crazy,” “childless cat ladies” and more — reveals the hidden contradictions of family life.
lead_paragraph: “Monkey love is totally different than the way that you have love for your child,” Tonia Haddix, an exotic animal broker, says at the beginning of “Chimp Crazy,” the documentary HBO series investigating the world of chimpanzee ownership. “If it’s your natural born child, it’s just natural because you actually gave birth to that kid. But when you adopt a monkey, the bond is much, much deeper.”

headline: Kamala Harris and Donald Trump Are Shredding Basic Economic Good Sense
abstract: It’s worrisome to see the candidates talk down to voters.
lead_paragraph: In a speech on economic policy in Raleigh, N.C., this month, Kamala Harris uncorked a beautiful riff that slammed a certain policy proposal as nothing more than a “national sales tax” on the American public, one that would raise the price of “everyday products and basic necessities” and cost the typical family $3,900 a year.

headline: Tesla’s Rivals Still Can’t Use Its Superchargers
abstract: Elon Musk’s plan to open Tesla’s charging network is proceeding slowly. Nobody is entirely sure why, or when that might change.
lead_paragraph: Scarce and finicky public chargers are among the biggest reasons people hesitate to buy electric cars. So when Elon Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, agreed last year to open the company’s well-regarded Supercharger network to vehicles from other carmakers, many drivers and industry experts celebrated the decision.

headline: Will Harris’s Lead Last? A Few Questions That Will Shape the Answer.
abstract: A certain kind of change candidate that is proving tough for Donald Trump to attack.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris has wrapped up an extraordinary month.

headline: 5 Fresh Takes on Summer Classics for Labor Day
abstract: Packed with sun-sweet fruits and vegetables, these easy recipes are perfect for any party.
lead_paragraph: The days are still warm enough to make this long weekend feel like vacation — even if school has already started — and these dishes lean into these waning days of summer. The truth is, end-of-season produce sometimes needs a little boost. Even though corn, zucchini and peaches remain abundant, they may not be quite as sweet or juicy as their July counterparts. Creamy spreads and sauces and other rich ingredients (yes, butter) bring out the best in them.

headline: Breaking Up Google Isn’t Nearly Enough
abstract: To end Google’s monopoly on search, the company should be required to disgorge its data on what we’re searching for.
lead_paragraph: Have you looked for a recipe online? If so, you probably found yourself on a blinking hellscape of a web page that was as long as an epic poem, but without any of the insight. First, you get the hokey story about the recipe’s origin. Then there are the videos. The irrelevant ads. The photos of each ingredient. The thousands of words are divided up into sections with headlines like, “Chia Seed Pudding Troubleshooting.”

headline: Israel launches a deadly airstrike in the West Bank, and other news.
Top Biden Aide Visits China to Reinforce U.S. Strategy
abstract: The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, will raise thorny issues like Taiwan and Russia with only months left before a new administration takes office.
lead_paragraph: Making another heavy push to work with China in the waning months of the Biden administration, Jake Sullivan arrived in Beijing on Tuesday for talks aimed at showing that the United States and China can manage their differences.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 444
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Wednesday, Aug. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level and if you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.

headline: The First Major Cyberattack of the 2024 Election
abstract: Iran is to blame for hacking into the Trump campaign and trying to breach the Biden-Harris campaign, U.S. intelligence officials said.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. authorities have repeatedly warned that foreign governments would seek to meddle in the upcoming presidential election. It now appears they were right.

headline: Russia Pounds Wide Swath of Ukraine, and F.T.C. Fights Grocery Merger
abstract: Plus, the rock band Oasis is back.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: 21 Questions for Harris
abstract: We’re asking unanswered questions for her potential administration.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris has largely avoided answering questions since her campaign began: She hasn’t participated in a town hall or given an extended media interview.

headline: A Popular Weight Loss Drug Is Getting a Price Cut
abstract: Eli Lilly will now sell cheaper vials of Zepbound, presenting a direct challenge to telehealth companies that offer compounded versions of the medication.
lead_paragraph: With high demand for drugs like Ozempic, and a limited supply, a novel marketplace has emerged to cater to customers who can’t access them. Dozens of telehealth companies offer online prescriptions for cheaper, compounded versions of these medications. These alternative drugs come in vials, with syringes to draw out each dose, and cost hundreds of dollars less than brand-name options.

headline: Dread Lingers in Mideast After Israel-Hezbollah Clashes
abstract: For people across the region, any relief that the adversaries had stepped back from an all-out war mixed with fears that the conflicts in Gaza and Lebanon remained unresolved.
lead_paragraph: Hezbollah and Israel appeared to de-escalate after a major confrontation over the weekend, tempering fears of an all-out conflict in the Middle East. But for people across the region, any feelings of relief were undercut by a deeper sense of deadlock.

headline: What We Know About the Telegram Founder’s Arrest
abstract: Pavel Durov was charged in France, as part of wide-ranging investigation into criminal activities on the messaging platform he runs.
lead_paragraph: Pavel Durov, the Russian-born entrepreneur who founded the Telegram messaging platform, was charged on Wednesday by the French authorities with a wide range of crimes related to illicit activity on the app.

headline: Mariah Carey Says Her Mother and Sister Died on the Same Day
abstract: Ms. Carey, who has spoken and written extensively about her complicated relationship with her family, said the deaths had led to an “impossible time.”
lead_paragraph: Mariah Carey’s mother, Patricia, and sister, Alison, died on the same day over the weekend, the pop star announced. It was unclear what caused their deaths or when exactly they died.

headline: What to Know About the Hostages Israel Has Rescued During the War in Gaza
abstract: Israeli forces have freed eight hostages in military operations in Gaza since Oct. 7, out of the approximately 250 abducted in the Hamas-led attacks.
lead_paragraph: The rescue of a hostage on Tuesday from southern Gaza brought to eight the number of captives the Israeli military has freed out of the approximately 250 abducted in the Hamas-led attacks last Oct. 7.

headline: One Woman’s Quest to Map the Paris Flea Market
abstract: The world-famous stalls have plenty of vintage finds, as long as you know where to look and what to expect.
lead_paragraph: Most anyone who visits Paris and loves to shop will be told to visit the storied flea market — “marché aux puces” in French — which occupies five acres in Saint-Ouen, just north of the city limits. The problem, many visitors find, is that it’s impenetrable.

headline: Who Is Farhan al-Qadi, the Rescued Hostage?
abstract: Mr. al-Qadi, a member of Israel’s Bedouin minority, was working as an unarmed guard at a kibbutz near the Gaza border when he was abducted, a member of his family said. His family was overjoyed at his return.
lead_paragraph: Israelis on Tuesday celebrated the rescue of Farhan al-Qadi, who was taken hostage during Hamas’s attacks on Oct. 7. But none more so than his family, who raced through the hallways of the hospital complex where he was being treated to greet him as quickly as they could.

headline: A Fatal Knife Attack Puts an Immigration Spotlight on a German City
abstract: After the fatal stabbing, which prosecutors say was committed by a Syrian who was rejected for asylum, the city of Solingen finds itself at the center of a longstanding debate over migrants.
lead_paragraph: Two days after a deadly knife attack in the German city of Solingen, the youth wing of the far-right AfD party put out a call for supporters to stage a protest demanding the government do more to deport migrants denied asylum.

headline: With Dams Removed, Salmon Will Have the Run of a Western River
abstract: The nation’s largest dam removal project is nearly complete after a lengthy campaign by Native tribes to restore the river at the California-Oregon border.
lead_paragraph: The Klamath River was once so flush with fish that local tribes ate salmon at every meal: flame-roasted filets on redwood skewers, stews flavored with fish tails, strips of smoky, dried salmon. In the language of the Yurok, who live on the river among California’s towering redwoods, the word for “salmon” translates to “that which we eat.”

headline: ‘Only Murders in the Building’ Goes to Hollywood
abstract: The murder mystery comedy returns with more celebrities than ever but in a winking, self-aware way.
lead_paragraph: In its first three seasons, the Hulu mystery comedy “Only Murders in the Building” recruited an impressively starry array of guest stars — including Nathan Lane, Paul Rudd and Meryl Streep — to join the already stellar main cast of Selena Gomez, Steve Martin and Martin Short. Season 4, which starts on Tuesday, has even more famous faces, which can be overwhelming at times. But there’s a knowing quality to the way these celebrities are deployed: “Only Murders” has gone Hollywood, but in a winking, self-aware way.

headline: Far-Right Israeli Minister Draws Anger for Comments on Disputed Holy Site
abstract: In the latest in a series of provocations, Itamar Ben-Gvir agreed that a new synagogue should be built at the site, which Jews call the Temple Mount and Muslims know as the Aqsa Mosque complex.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s far-right national security minister has drawn outrage for agreeing that he would like to build a synagogue at a disputed holy site in Jerusalem that has long been a flashpoint between Jews and Muslims.

headline: This National Guard Crowd Likes What It Hears From Trump
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump got a warm welcome from an audience willing to overlook his past tussles with the military.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with the latest election updates as Harris and Trump hit the campaign trail.

headline: Is This Concert the Gold Standard for a Green Gig?
abstract: Coldplay and Billie Eilish have tried to drive down carbon emissions while touring, but the British band Massive Attack has tried to take the efforts even further.
lead_paragraph: When the British band Massive Attack was halfway through a West Coast tour in 2019, flying from show to show, the rapper and singer Robert Del Naja had a moment of crisis. Given all the carbon emitted by moving the band and its equipment around, he recalled wondering: Can I justify this anymore?

headline: Save These Summery 20-Minute Dinners
abstract: Each quick recipe — for larb gai, chilaquiles verdes and more — harnesses summer cooking energy without relying on summer produce.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to gush over summer food, to feel grateful for the generous produce and farmers that have eased our cooking lives. Thank you for the juicy spills of tomatoes and stone fruit, for the smell of basil leaves and melon rinds and for all the color and crunch.

headline: In ‘Only Murders in the Building,’ This Actor Is Above Suspicion
abstract: For years, Michael Cyril Creighton hoped one of his small TV parts would evolve into something more. With “Only Murders,” it finally happened.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy morning in early August, the actor Michael Cyril Creighton sat in a dog friendly cafe on the outskirts of Astoria, Queens. With him was Sharon, his seven-year-old rescue, who is part Chihuahua, part Jack Russell terrier, with a soupçon of haunted doll. Another dog scampered over to their table. Sharon growled low in her throat and bared her teeth.

headline: Pro-Trump Super PAC to Begin $60 Million Ad Campaign Next Week
abstract: The group, Right for America, has raised tens of millions of dollars but waited until the fall rush to air any advertising.
lead_paragraph: A super PAC started by supporters of Donald J. Trump is launching what is expected to be a $60 million advertising campaign to boost the former president’s campaign right after Labor Day.

headline: A New Destination for Indian Cuisine in Queens
abstract: Oh! Calcutta opens in Long Island City; Grand Brasserie fills Vanderbilt Hall with Parisian flair and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: The louche collection of sketches by the critic Kenneth Tynan that opened Off Broadway in 1969 has inspired the name of this new restaurant in Queens. Ruhel Amin, who has Indian restaurants in Harlem and Williamsburg, presents dishes from Kolkata, including a Lake Market fish fry, vegetable cutlet, chapli kebab with minced lamb, and kosha mangsho, a goat curry here. Workhorses like butter chicken, rogan josh and saag paneer are also on the menu. The chefs are Sharmeen Rahman and Lisha Khondoka; both women have worked in Mr. Amin’s other restaurants.

headline: Trump to Put Kennedy and Gabbard on His Transition Team
abstract: Mr. Kennedy and Ms. Gabbard, who had been progressive Democrats for many years, will join the former president’s sons and Senator JD Vance, his running mate, as honorary co-chairs.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump plans to name his former rival, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., and Tulsi Gabbard, a one-time Democrat, as honorary co-chairs of a presidential transition team that will help him select the policies and personnel of any second Trump administration, according to a campaign senior adviser.

headline: Telegram’s Loudest Defender: The Global Crypto Industry
abstract: When the messaging app’s founder, Pavel Durov, was arrested, he received a flood of support from a multitrillion-dollar industry that relies on it.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Pavel Durov, the founder of the messaging app Telegram, was arrested in France on Saturday, the chief executive of the cryptocurrency company Tether called the situation “very concerning.” Crypto enthusiasts pledged to support Mr. Durov, posting the hashtag #FreeDurov. Others investors declared that the arrest was an assault on free speech.

headline: On Stonehenge and Mispronouncing ‘Kamala’: The Winners of Our Week 10 Summer Reading Contest
abstract: As our contest comes to a close, we honor both a video and an essay, and hear from students and judges about their experiences participating this year.
lead_paragraph: Our 15th annual Summer Reading Contest received 9,329 entries over the 10 weeks it ran. This week we crown our last collection of finalists, and honor two top winners, Ranvir Sharma, 14, in video and Aarushi Bahadur, 17, for her essay.

headline: What Across-the-Board Tariffs Could Mean for the Global Economy
abstract: Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, has floated the idea of a 10 percent tariff on all U.S. imports, a plan that economists say could badly damage trade.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump blames the global trading system for inflicting a long list of ills on the American economy including lost jobs, closed foreign markets and an overvalued dollar.

headline: Another Icon-of-the-Seas-Style Megaship? Make That 3 More.
abstract: Royal Caribbean and other companies are aggressively building over-the-top ships. “Today’s cruisezillas make the Titanic look like a small fishing boat,” noted one sustainability specialist.
lead_paragraph: The Icon of the Seas, the world’s largest cruise ship, drew as much criticism as excitement when Royal Caribbean launched it earlier this year, but the ship has been a hit among cruise goers. Now the cruise line is adding to its fleet of megaships.

headline: Kennedy Says Trump Will ‘Make Americans Healthy.’ His Record Suggests Otherwise.
abstract: As president, Donald J. Trump slashed protections for clean air and water and weakened school nutrition standards.
lead_paragraph: When Robert F. Kennedy Jr. endorsed Donald J. Trump last week, he recounted speaking with the former president about “the issues that bind us together,” including “having safe food and ending the chronic disease epidemic.”

headline: ‘Free Speech’ Should Not Shroud Criminal Activity
abstract: Some early details suggest the issue here isn’t one of free speech, but of criminal activity.
lead_paragraph: The detention in France of Pavel Durov, the founder and chief executive of the messaging app Telegram, has sparked a loud outcry about free speech. Elon Musk has portrayed the arrest on his X account as an ominous threat to free speech, and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. referred to the app as an “encrypted, uncensored” platform and said “the need to protect free speech has never been more urgent.”

headline: Mexico Pauses Relations With U.S. Embassy Amid Clash Over Judicial Overhaul
abstract: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s proposed changes to the judiciary are at the center of a diplomatic fight with the United States in the last weeks of his presidency.
lead_paragraph: For months, tensions have been building in Mexico over the president’s sweeping plans to overhaul the judiciary, shaking the country’s political system and straining diplomatic ties with the United States.

headline: Harris and Trump Embrace Tariffs, Though Their Approaches Differ
abstract: Both Democrats and Republicans are expressing support for tariffs to protect American industry, reversing decades of trade thinking in Washington.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump ran for president in 2016, there was not much love for tariffs in Washington. Many Republicans and Democrats believed that putting levies on imports created economic inefficiencies and that freer trade was the best recipe for growth.

headline: Trump vs. Harris: ‘Unserious Man’ vs. ‘Untested Woman’?
abstract: Readers react to a column by Maureen Dowd about the presidential race. Also: Falling art prices; “loser pays” legal systems; free school lunches.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How R.F.K. Jr. Went From Environmental Champion to Trump Backer
abstract: Kennedy’s former co-workers in the environmental movement aren’t surprised that he endorsed Trump, who has called climate change a “hoax.”
lead_paragraph: Last week, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., once a prominent figure of America’s environmental movement, suspended his independent run for the White House and endorsed former President Donald Trump.

headline: A Pianist Who’s Not Afraid to Improvise on Mozart
abstract: Robert Levin has long argued that Mozart would have made up new material while performing, and he follows the master in a series of dazzling recordings.
lead_paragraph: Cadenzas are a concerto soloist’s time to shine: the moments when the rest of the orchestra dramatically drops out and a single musician gets the chance to command the stage.

headline: How Twitch Helps Brands Find Their Fans
abstract: How do livestreams help drive culture and brands forward? Streamers like Critical Role and LittleSiha reveal how they built communities on Twitch, and how brands can form authentic bonds with engaged audiences.
lead_paragraph: How do livestreams help drive culture and brands forward? Streamers like Critical Role and LittleSiha reveal how they built communities on Twitch, and how brands can form authentic bonds with engaged audiences.

headline: Connections Bot
abstract: See how you stacked up against other players today.
lead_paragraph: See how you stacked up against other players today.

headline: Connections Bot F.A.Q.
abstract: Introducing a daily, personalized analysis tool for Connections fans.
lead_paragraph: We’ve launched a beta of Connections Bot, a new robotic companion to Connections. Want to know what it is and how it works? You’re in the right place.

headline: For Its Famous Clientele, Peress Was More Than a Lingerie Shop
abstract: For more than 90 years the Upper East Side shop served socially ambitious women, including Brooke Astor, Gloria Vanderbilt, Diana Vreeland, Barbara Walters, Madonna and many more.
lead_paragraph: As word spread that the specialty store Peress of Madison Avenue was closing, fans came to pay homage — and stock up on the beloved shop’s selection of mostly European lingerie, robes, socks, nightgowns, pajamas and slippers at 50 percent off.

headline: Israeli Military Rescues Eighth Hostage Alive From Gaza
abstract: Israeli soldiers and special forces found Farhan al-Qadi by chance as they were combing through a tunnel network in southern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers and special forces found Farhan al-Qadi by chance as they were combing through a tunnel network in southern Gaza.

headline: How to Turn August Grilling Into Autumn Grilling
abstract: With the right gear — and excellent recipes — you can keep grilling well past Labor Day weekend.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to think of grilling as a summer thing — the temps are warm, the evenings are long and you’ve got a pool party’s worth of people to feed.

headline: Is This the Edinburgh Fringe, or a Wellness Convention?
abstract: Grief narratives were in vogue, and psychological maladies, too, at the annual Scottish arts showcase.
lead_paragraph: As I made my way to Scotland for this year’s Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the three-week arts showcase that finished on Monday, I felt a little apprehensive. A conspicuous number of shows were themed around psychological maladies. These included plays about grief, anxiety, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, obsessive compulsive disorder and gambling addiction. I had thought I was going to a festival, but this sounded more like a wellness convention.

headline: Oklahoma Primary Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary runoff elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary runoff elections.

headline: Oasis: Timeline of a Sibling Rivalry for the Ages
abstract: When Liam and Noel Gallagher get together, hide the tambourines.
lead_paragraph: The Kinks, the Allman Brothers Band, the Jacksons: Every band of brothers occasionally bickered, even feuded.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Love Your Pigtails’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: 1986: When Jean left, I vowed never to feel that pain again, and haven’t been intimate since. I embraced drag: the annual Miss Fire Island Pageant, my friend Raven’s weekly La Cage show, more. Leaving Manhattan, I still returned to compete in Fire Island (24 times and counting). After reconnecting last year, Raven came to see me, then drove me to the airport. I smoked. Raven admonished me to see a doctor. “Promise?” Instantly, after 38 years, I realized someone cared. Doctors found lung cancer. Raven’s insistent “Promise?” might well have saved my life. It certainly has revitalized my heart. — Michael Givler

headline: Scientists Have a New Theory About Why Orcas Are Attacking Boats
abstract: A pod of orcas damaged a boat and left its two-person crew stranded. It was the latest in a string of attacks that research suggests could be used for hunting practice.
lead_paragraph: The orcas have struck again — this time ramming a sailboat off Spain’s northwest coast, rescue workers said on Tuesday.

headline: 9 Surprising Songs Sampled in Classic Hip-Hop Tracks
abstract: Hear where moments of Kraftwerk, Enya, Herb Alpert and more ended up in producers’ deft hands.
lead_paragraph: Today’s playlist is a celebration of a tried-and-true method of discovering new-to-you music: identifying the samples in hip-hop songs.

headline: 2 Are Killed at Delta Maintenance Facility Near Atlanta Airport
abstract: Another worker was seriously injured in the accident at the facility’s wheel and brake shop, where wheel parts were being disassembled, Delta said.
lead_paragraph: Two people working at a Delta Air Lines maintenance facility at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport were killed and a third was seriously injured by an explosion in the facility’s wheel and brake shop on Tuesday, according to the airline and authorities.

headline: What to Know About E.E.E., a Rare Mosquito-Borne Illness
abstract: Eastern equine encephalitis has caused one death in New Hampshire, and the virus has also been identified in humans in four other states, health officials said.
lead_paragraph: One person has died in New Hampshire after being infected with the mosquito-borne virus Eastern equine encephalitis, and four others have contracted the rare disease caused by the virus this summer.

headline: Looking for Information on L.G.B.T.Q. Travel to Florida? Don’t Ask Florida.
abstract: The state’s travel website recently removed pages dedicated to L.G.B.T.Q. travel. Some Floridians aren’t happy about it.
lead_paragraph: For years, L.G.B.T.Q. people planning a trip to Florida could turn to the official website for Visit Florida, the state’s tourism marketing organization, for resources on where to go, what to eat and where to stay. While there are other resources for queer travelers, the site offered information about L.G.B.T.Q.-owned businesses that visitors could patronize as well as activities “appealing to a gay community looking for a sense of belonging and acceptance,” a page on the site once read.

headline: A U.S. Open Party So Exclusive, Andy Roddick Just Got His Invite
abstract: An opening-night gala featured celebrities like Lin-Manuel Miranda, Alec Baldwin, Anna Wintour and Mr. Roddick (who won the tournament in 2003).
lead_paragraph: “This isn’t my normal U.S. Open,” said Andy Roddick, the former professional tennis player.

headline: Guantánamo Detainees Moved Amid Structural Problems at Showcase Prison
abstract: The military, which in 2021 disclosed its last major internal relocation of Guantánamo prisoners, declined to discuss this week’s security operation.
lead_paragraph: Undisclosed infrastructure problems forced the military to evacuate the prison housing the men accused of plotting the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks and other detainees from the war against terrorism, according to Defense Department employees.

headline: Hostage’s Rescue Shines a Spotlight on Israel’s Bedouins
abstract: The Bedouins of the Negev desert suffered painful losses on Oct. 7, but less attention has been focused on their plight than on some of the other victims of the Hamas-led attack.
lead_paragraph: Farhan al-Qadi, the hostage rescued from southern Gaza on Tuesday, is a member of the Bedouin, an Arab community marginalized by Israel that suffered painful losses in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack.

headline: Why Economists Worry About Trumpflation
abstract: And why they may not be worrying enough.
lead_paragraph: My latest column is about how inflation is fading as both an economic and a political issue — which is good news for Kamala Harris and bad news for Donald Trump. Yet it remains quite possible that Trump will win. And if he does, inflation may become a major problem again.

headline: Adams’s Pick for Top Lawyer Is Grilled by Skeptical Council Members
abstract: Members of the City Council questioned the record of Randy Mastro, a former federal prosecutor and aide to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
lead_paragraph: After months of saber rattling between the New York City Council and Mayor Eric Adams over his choice of Randy Mastro to become the city’s top lawyer, Mr. Mastro finally got his chance to plead his own case on Tuesday.

headline: To Lure Michigan Voters, Trump Campaign Stokes China Fears
abstract: JD Vance, the Republican vice-presidential nominee, waded into a fight over plans by Gotion, a Chinese battery plant, to build a factory in Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with the latest election updates as Harris and Trump hit the campaign trail.

headline: How the Politics of the Gaza War Engulfed the Melbourne Symphony
abstract: The orchestra faced criticism for canceling a performance by a pianist who spoke about the war. Now a top leader has departed and the ensemble has opened an inquiry.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Jayson Gillham was performing Beethoven’s “Waldstein” sonata and Ligeti’s études at a concert hall in Melbourne, Australia, earlier this month when the concert took an unexpected turn.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Sawed the Head Off a Whale and Drove It Home, Daughter Says
abstract: Three decades later, an environmental organization is calling for an investigation.
lead_paragraph: It is a violation of longstanding federal law to collect parts from the carcass of a protected marine animal if there are still “soft tissues” attached.

headline: Police Hope Dog Breeder’s Missing Dobermans Can Shed Light on His Death
abstract: The police in central Colorado are tracking down Doberman puppies to help solve the potential homicide of a local dog breeder who died last week.
lead_paragraph: The police suspect that a dog breeder found dead at his home in central Colorado last week was killed, and they are tracking down his missing Doberman puppies to help their investigation into his death, according to the Clear Creek County Sheriff’s office.

headline: At an Israeli hospital, the rescued hostage tells his family about his ordeal.
abstract: Farhan al-Qadi, who was recovering in a medical center in southern Israel, told relatives and friends he had spent much of his captivity in darkness.
lead_paragraph: Farhan al-Qadi, the hostage rescued by Israeli troops in an underground tunnel in Gaza on Tuesday, told his friends and relatives that he had been held in the dark for a long time, often alone save for his guards.

headline: Tell Us: What’s Your Favorite Book About Politics?
abstract: Share your thoughts with the On Politics newsletter.
lead_paragraph: Summer is drawing to a close. A long weekend is upon us. And I know there’s only one way you want to spend it: with a good book about politics!

headline: Read the Revised Indictment in the Federal Election Subversion Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors issued another version of an indictment accusing former President Donald J. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election after the Supreme Court granted former presidents broad immunity for official acts.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors issued another version of an indictment accusing former President Donald J. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election after the Supreme Court granted former presidents broad immunity for official acts.

headline: Harris’s Ad-War Message: Trump Is Pro-Billionaire, She Worked at McDonald’s
abstract: The ads, focused on cutting costs, are meant to win over voters who believe Donald Trump would be better on the economy. They also signal a shift in tone from President Biden.
lead_paragraph: Flush with cash and fresh off the Democratic National Convention, Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign is flooding the airwaves and the internet with advertising that is meant to combat an overarching weakness: Voters trust former President Donald J. Trump more than her on the economy.

headline: Special Counsel Revises Trump Election Indictment to Address Immunity Ruling
abstract: Jack Smith’s filing, in the case charging the former president with plotting to overturn the 2020 election, came in response to the Supreme Court’s ruling giving former presidents broad immunity.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors on Tuesday issued a pared-down version of an indictment accusing former President Donald J. Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election, stripping out some charges and tweaking others to help the case survive the Supreme Court’s recent ruling granting former presidents broad immunity.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: A Look at Harris’s Polling Lead
abstract: Plus, looking for love in Shanghai.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 70 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: Why We Cover What Politicians Wear
abstract: For both men and women, clothes can be an important tool for communication. Often, there’s strategy behind the style.
