lead_paragraph: Ever since Kamala Harris became the Democratic nominee for president, making her the first Black woman and the first person of South Asian descent to be nominated for national office by a major party, celebrations of the historic moment have ensued. So, too, have the related moans about how, because she is a woman, her clothes will be used to define and diminish her.

headline: Safety Agency Cites Lax Inspections and Federal Oversight in Deadly Helicopter Crash
abstract: The N.T.S.B. says a lack of F.A.A. oversight contributed to a 2022 helicopter crash in West Virginia, in which six people were killed.
lead_paragraph: The National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday that inadequate inspections and lax federal oversight contributed to a 2022 helicopter crash that killed six people in Logan County, W.Va.

headline: Heat Deaths Have Doubled in the U.S. in Recent Decades, Study Finds
abstract: The finding comes as a late-August heat wave bears down on a significant part of the country.
lead_paragraph: As dangerous heat bears down on the central and eastern United States this week, a new study shows heat-related deaths across the country are on the rise.

headline: The Gender Gap Among Gen Z Voters, Explained
abstract: Claire Cain Miller spoke with eight young women supporting Harris, and eight young men backing Trump. Here’s what she learned.
lead_paragraph: There is a significant gender gap in the political preferences of Gen Z voters in the United States, as evidenced by New York Times and Siena College polls conducted this month in six swing states.

headline: CNN’s Dana Bash to Interview Harris and Walz on Thursday
abstract: The joint interview, airing at 9 p.m. Eastern, is the first time the vice president will face sustained questions from a journalist since President Biden withdrew from the race.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 election here.

headline: ‘No Barrier’ to Nuclear Talks With U.S., Iran’s Supreme Leader Says
abstract: It was unclear if Ayatollah Ali Khamenei’s comments signaled any shift in Iran’s stance, but the country’s new president has called for an accord that would relieve Western sanctions against it.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s supreme leader suggested that his country would pursue nuclear negotiations with the United States, telling the country’s government there was “no barrier,” to discussions with the “enemy,” in a video broadcast on state television Tuesday.

headline: Trump Suggests Debate Rules Are Set. Harris’s Team Says Otherwise.
abstract: The two have been tussling over whether microphones will be muted when a candidate isn’t speaking during the debate, which is scheduled for Sept. 10.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump announced for a second time that he would participate in a presidential debate with Vice President Kamala Harris hosted by ABC News and suggested that the question of whether microphones will be muted when a candidate isn’t speaking had been resolved.

headline: Ex-Mississippi Jail Worker Arrested in Escape of Inmate Who Was Found Near D.N.C.
abstract: Ronnie Hunt, 32, who worked for the DeSoto County Sheriff’s Office, is accused of aiding the prisoner, who escaped wearing plain clothes and walked out of a door with no handcuffs or shackles.
lead_paragraph: A former employee of a Mississippi jail has been charged with helping in the escape of an inmate who was later found barricaded last week inside a Chicago restaurant less than a mile from the Democratic National Convention, officials said.

headline: Man Charged With Tupac Shakur’s Murder Loses Bid for Release
abstract: A judge declined to release Duane Keith Davis, whose trial is scheduled for March, after a dispute over the source of the bail funds.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Nevada declined on Tuesday to release a man who was charged with the murder of the rapper Tupac Shakur after expressing concern that the money provided to bail him out from jail could be connected to a possible deal to tell his story in a TV series.

headline: The Special Counsel Filed Revised Charges Against Trump
abstract: Also, Israeli forces rescued a hostage from Gaza. Here’s the latest from the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors today issued a new version of their indictment accusing Donald Trump of plotting to overturn the 2020 election. The revised document stripped out some charges in order to help it survive the Supreme Court’s recent ruling granting former presidents broad immunity for official acts in office.

headline: Man Dies After Boat Flips on Colorado River in Grand Canyon
abstract: The death of an 80-year-old man was the fifth fatality there in a month, officials said.
lead_paragraph: An 80-year-old man whose boat flipped on the Colorado River over the weekend has become the latest fatality at Grand Canyon National Park, the fifth in less than a month and the 13th person to die there this year.

headline: A Bargain at the Opera: Philadelphia Offers All Seats for as Low as $11
abstract: Seeking new audiences, Opera Philadelphia is putting in place a pay-what-you-can model, one of the first of its kind by a major opera company.
lead_paragraph: In Philadelphia, a night at the opera may now be cheaper than going to the movies.

headline: The Geography of Unequal Recovery
abstract: The U.S. economy has added roughly 19 million jobs in four years. But as of the end of 2023, 43 percent of counties still hadn’t regained all the jobs they lost in the early months of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy has added roughly 19 million jobs in four years. But as of the end of 2023, 43 percent of counties still hadn’t regained all the jobs they lost in the early months of the pandemic.

headline: The Big Border Change Harris Isn’t Talking About
abstract: A Biden administration border policy that has had a dramatic impact isn’t getting campaign play.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. Tonight, my colleague Hamed Aleaziz, who covers immigration, looks at why the sharp drop in border crossings isn’t playing a bigger role in the presidential campaign. Plus, I want to hear about your favorite books about politics. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Man Is First to Be Charged in New York With Wearing a Mask in Public
abstract: Wesslin Omar Ramirez Castillo was frisked and charged with knife possession after the police stopped him for wearing a ski mask.
lead_paragraph: A man on Long Island has been arrested and charged with possessing a knife and wearing a face mask in public, a milestone moment in the debate over whether to criminalize masks in New York State.

headline: Can We Be a Little Less Selective With Our Moral Outrage?
abstract: Here are some alternative focal points for outrage for college students from Columbia to Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: Of all the world’s injustices, perhaps the saddest is that so many of them are simply ignored.

headline: Cellphone Bans in Schools? New York Is ‘Not There Yet,’ Mayor Says
abstract: Districts and states across the United States have supported restrictions on student usage, but New York City’s leaders are backing away from the idea because of logistical concerns.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles became the largest school district in the United States to ban cellphones in June. Entire states, such as Virginia, Ohio and Minnesota, have moved to institute broad crackdowns on phones in schools. But not New York City.

headline: Israeli Forces Rescue Hostage in Gaza as Strikes Kill at Least 20 Palestinians
abstract: A Bedouin Arab citizen of Israel was rescued after Israeli commandos found him alone in an underground warren, apparently abandoned by his captors.
lead_paragraph: An elite Israeli military unit rescued a frail and gaunt hostage from a tunnel deep beneath the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, the eighth living captive to be freed by Israeli troops in nearly 11 months of war and the first to be found alive in the subterranean labyrinth used by Hamas.

headline: First Jan. 6 Rioter to Enter Capitol Gets More Than 4 Years in Prison
abstract: Michael Sparks, 47, was the first rioter to breach the Capitol and among the first to be confronted by the U.S. Capitol Police Officer Eugene Goodman.
lead_paragraph: The first rioter to breach the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced Tuesday to more than four years in prison, federal prosecutors announced.

headline: Court Call
abstract: Jesse Goldberg goes puzzle-hopping.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Trump Team Clashed With Official at Arlington National Cemetery
abstract: The military cemetery said in a statement that federal law prohibits political campaigning on the grounds, and that “there was an incident, and a report was filed.”
lead_paragraph: Members of Donald J. Trump’s campaign team and an official at Arlington National Cemetery confronted each other during the former president’s visit to the cemetery on Monday, the military cemetery said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Mormon Church Broadens Restrictions for Transgender Members
abstract: The new guidance prohibits those pursuing gender transition from working with children, and bans baptism for those who have transitioned both medically and socially.
lead_paragraph: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints expanded its restrictions on transgender members, issuing new guidance that includes prohibiting people who pursue transition from working with children.

headline: More Than 300,000 Customers Without Power in Michigan After Thunderstorms
abstract: A day of extreme heat and thunderstorms left hundreds of thousands without power Wednesday morning. One utility said it would distribute free ice and water.
lead_paragraph: About 330,000 customers across Michigan had no power early on Wednesday, after a day of thunderstorms and extreme heat in the Midwest.

headline: Can Tech Executives Be Held Responsible for What Happens on Their Platforms?
abstract: The indictment of Pavel Durov, Telegram’s founder, as part of an investigation into illicit activities on the messaging app set off worries about the personal liability of tech executives.
lead_paragraph: This month, X closed its Brazil operations after one of its executives was threatened with arrest for not taking down certain content. Last year, Changpeng Zhao, the founder of Binance, pleaded guilty to federal money-laundering violations that took place on his cryptocurrency platform. In 2021, Twitter executives in India faced arrest over posts that the government wanted removed from the site.

headline: Africa’s Debt Crisis Has ‘Catastrophic Implications’ for the World
abstract: Crushing obligations to foreign creditors that have few precedents have sapped numerous African nations of growth and stoked social instability.
lead_paragraph: After a new tax increase incited weeks of deadly riots in Kenya early this summer, President William Ruto announced that he was reversing course. He abandoned the finance law he had proposed, and then he shook up his cabinet.

headline: With Hezbollah-Israel Conflict Contained, Iran’s Next Move May Be Modest
abstract: After weeks of regional fears about a broader war, Hezbollah’s limited attack on Israel suggests that Iran, like its ally, wants to hem in the risk of escalation.
lead_paragraph: As rockets and missiles streaked across Lebanese and Israeli skies on Sunday, the moment people across the region lived in fear of seemed as if it might have arrived: all-out war.

headline: In Quebec’s Casse-Croûtes, Fast Food for a Short but Sweet Summer
abstract: By now, the most famous product of Quebec’s casse-croûtes, the poutine, has gone international. But can the guédille or the pinso ever become just as popular?
lead_paragraph: When newcomers to Canada, the Italian couple had discovered along Quebec’s country roads the joys of the casse-croûtes, the food shacks that lie dormant in the frozen landscape during winter and then burst to life during the all-too-short warm months.

headline: Why Hasn’t Russia Kicked Out Ukrainian Invaders? Its Own Invaders Are Busy.
abstract: Despite its overwhelming firepower, Russia has been unable for weeks to push Ukrainian troops back across the border, with the failure as much the result of priorities as a lack of personnel.
lead_paragraph: The barrage of airstrikes that Russia launched against Ukraine over the past two days, with hundreds of drones and missiles, provided punishing evidence of Moscow’s enduring military might.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: The presidential election is less than 70 days away. This is what we’re watching.

headline: Typhoon Shanshan Barrels Into Japan, Triggering Rare Warnings
abstract: The authorities said the storm could produce a large-scale disaster as it approached the mainland. Nearly 1 million people were told to evacuate, and Toyota closed all its factories on Wednesday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: [Follow the latest coverage of Typhoon Shanshan.]

headline: Uruguayan Soccer Player Dies Days After Collapsing During a Match
abstract: Juan Izquierdo, 27, suffered cardiac arrest on Aug. 22 while he was playing for Nacional against São Paulo in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Juan Izquierdo, a Uruguayan soccer player who collapsed on the field during a game in Brazil last week, died on Tuesday, his team said.

headline: Word of the Day: atrophy
abstract: This word has appeared in 36 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word atrophy has appeared 36 times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 14 in The New York Times Magazine article “Can You Lose Your Native Tongue?” by Madeleine Schwartz:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: For Years, He Has Saved Lives in Rural America. Who Will Take His Place?
abstract: Volunteer ambulance squads are running out of volunteers. What happens when Bob VanCoughnett retires?
lead_paragraph: The emergency radio erupted in a garble of static and a few spare details: possible stroke victim, 14 Grange Avenue.

headline: Michael Crichton’s Estate Calls New Show an Unauthorized ‘ER’ Remake in Lawsuit
abstract: The best-selling author’s estate has filed suit over “The Pitt,” an upcoming series, claiming that it is an unauthorized reboot of the hit hospital drama.
lead_paragraph: The estate of Michael Crichton filed suit against Warner Bros. Television on Tuesday, claiming that its upcoming Max series, “The Pitt,” is an unauthorized “ER” reboot that fails to credit him and compensate his heirs.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Brazil’s Wetland Fires Taking Toll on Wild Animals
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “With the loss of these animals, we lose an evolutionary story that has not yet been fully told.”

headline: To Live in a Wild Sea
abstract: An 86-year-old woman’s decision to end her life raises complex questions about life and death for a filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: An 86-year-old woman’s decision to end her life raises complex questions about life and death for a filmmaker.

headline: ‘That’s What I Would Have Liked, to Live in a Wild Sea’
abstract: An 86-year-old woman’s decision to end her life raises complex questions about life and death for a filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: I first met Carmen, the subject of the short documentary above, while researching a film I was planning to make about euthanasia, which was legalized in Spain in 2021. Her story was unusual — she wanted to end her life, but she could not apply for legal euthanasia because she did not have a terminal illness or pain severe enough to qualify. The first time I met her, she told me she was planning to end her life in six months.

headline: Critiquing India’s Politics With Absurdist Games
abstract: Studio Oleomingus’s video games, often inspired by literature and architecture, are colorful and playful examinations of some of India’s darkest chapters.
lead_paragraph: It is not unusual for steady rain to fall in the video game worlds of Studio Oleomingus. And it is easy to see why if you visit the studio’s lead writer and designer, Dhruv Jani, at his home office in Vapi, a small city on the western coast of India, at the height of the monsoons.

headline: Want a Rich, Rustic Taste of Spain? Head for the Hills of La Rioja.
abstract: A drive through rolling vineyards will take you to 5 family-run restaurants where you’ll find flavorful, affordable dishes you can linger over for hours.
lead_paragraph: Hear the word “Rioja” and the first thing that comes to mind is wine — high-quality, fruit-forward red wine.

headline: In Los Angeles, an Artist’s Studio for a Blind Potter
abstract: Every client is unique, but Don Katz truly broke the mold.
lead_paragraph: For Don Katz, a typical day begins with a light breakfast at his home in Los Angeles before he heads to his backyard pool to swim a few laps. After a therapeutic soak in the spa, Mr. Katz prepares to go to work on his ceramics.

headline: The Address Has Changed. The Spots Remain the Same.
abstract: In a Manhattan apartment festooned with animal prints, Renée Demsey, 92, adapts to her newly single life.
lead_paragraph: With her leopard-patterned pants, chunky brown necklaces and gumball-size gold cocktail rings, Renée Demsey, 92, is as maximalist and vivacious as her one-bedroom Manhattan apartment.

headline: What Has 25 Rooms and Comes with the Job?
abstract: When Crystal Williams became president of Rhode Island School of Design, she moved into a Colonial Revival mansion and rolled up her sleeves.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a 7,000-square-foot house, and I am alone,” Crystal Williams said solemnly, about halfway through a four-hour tour of her Gilded Age residence in Providence, R.I. She moved in two years ago, upon becoming the 18th president of Rhode Island School of Design and is not done arranging it. While hosting nonstop events there, she has staked claim to the interior, intertwining her favorite objects and hues with the creations of RISD faculty, students and alumni.

headline: Yes, Tree Collecting Is a Thing
abstract: A new book explores the obsession and explains why it’s not exactly like collecting dolls: “It puts people in touch with their own mortality.”
lead_paragraph: As collectibles go, trees break the mold — and not just because they don’t fit on a shelf or require periodic dusting.

headline: 4 New Crime Novels Thrumming With Menace
abstract: Our mystery columnist reviews books by Scott Phillips, Morgan Richter, Snowden Wright and Jamie Harrison.
lead_paragraph: If you’re going to write about seedy underbellies and strange subcultures, then follow the road map created by Scott Phillips: Make it funny, make it ribald, make it memorable. That’s what Phillips has been doing ever since his lauded 2000 debut, “The Ice Harvest.”

headline: Trading Porsches for a Houseboat and a Gentler Way of Life
abstract: Rocked by success, a “wallpaper guy” has found peace and a tolerable amount of society on a canal in Amsterdam.
lead_paragraph: These days, the Dutch entrepreneur Rick Vintage lives alone on an old boat, a 75-foot-long vessel from 1895 called “Vrouwe Jacoba” (Mrs. Jacoba, in Dutch) on a canal in a quiet corner of Amsterdam. It is moored in front of a 4,800-square-foot garden that contains a tiny house, now inhabited by his daughter Lux, 18, who comes on board mornings for coffee before dashing off to school. He lives with his dog, Moos. There are no passers-by, and he often dines alone on the deck. “I’ve always been a bit of a hermit,” he said in a video call from the Netherlands.

headline: In a Historic Cairo High-Rise, Apartments That Might Inspire a Longer Stay
abstract: The Immobilia Building, which was once the city’s tallest structure, is home to four new luxurious guest suites.
lead_paragraph: Travelers don’t tend to linger in Cairo once they’ve seen the sights — the city can be notoriously tricky to navigate. But a new collection of serviced apartments from the team behind the luxurious Set Nefru dahabiya boat on the Nile, as well as Al Moudira, a charming hotel in the southern city of Luxor, is giving visitors a reason to stick around.

headline: Did You Even Go to the U.S. Open if You Didn’t Get a Hat?
abstract: The symbol of the tennis tournament — in Queens and beyond — is a simple cap with a logo and the year. The older the better.
lead_paragraph: As a student at Wagner College, Morgan Riddle paid almost no attention to tennis. But she always knew when the U.S. Open was underway at the end of August.

headline: At Clemente Bar, a Love Story Between Chef and Artist
abstract: The chef Daniel Humm’s new cocktail bar is a collaboration with the Italian painter Francesco Clemente.
lead_paragraph: The acclaimed Italian painter Francesco Clemente had always wanted to have a drink named after him (the Bellini, after all, is a homage to the Italian Renaissance painter Giovanni Bellini). Mr. Clemente, now 72 and based in New York City since 1981, is getting a whole bar named after him.

headline: You Will Grow Old Waiting for Your Favorite Show to Come Back
abstract: Remember “Severance”? Remember “Stranger Things”? Today’s leisurely TV schedules are taxing memories and changing the experience.
lead_paragraph: Time moves slowly in Middle-earth. Ages last for millenniums. Elves are immortal. Villains menace the land, are defeated, then are nearly forgotten before they re-emerge eons later.

headline: A Rich, Gingery Tea Cake With Restorative Powers
abstract: A mother’s cure for the blues is transformed into a lively treat.
lead_paragraph: It is a quirk of the English language that to do something gingerly is to be dainty, delicate, circumspect, when ginger itself is none of these things. (In fact, the two words have no etymological kinship.) Ginger is a smack: Wake up. It has the capacity to burn, not frankly like chile but low and steady, evoking not a wanton blaze but a scouring, as focused as a laser. You feel it in the nose and in the unseen corners under your face. It clarifies.

headline: What Does It Take to Become a Prodigy Scam Artist?
abstract: In “Never Saw Me Coming,” Tanya Smith tells of her life as a young financial criminal — and the harsh prison sentence that changed everything.
lead_paragraph: When Tanya Smith was in high school, spending time with her upwardly mobile father in 1980s Minneapolis, she developed a kind of class consciousness — a curiosity about money and race and a desire to know just how much income qualified someone as “rich.”

headline: Venice Film Festival 2024: What to Watch For
abstract: “Joker: Folie à Deux,” with Joaquin Phoenix, and Pedro Almodóvar’s first English-language feature are on tap. Here are the questions we hope to answer.
lead_paragraph: The 81st edition of the Venice Film Festival kicks off Wednesday with the premiere of Tim Burton’s sequel “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice,” and starry fare will follow, like the sexually provocative Nicole Kidman film “Babygirl” and the George Clooney-Brad Pitt team-up “Wolfs.”

headline: The For-Profit City That Might Come Crashing Down
abstract: The dream of Próspera, founded by a U.S. corporation off the coast of Honduras, was to escape government control. The Honduran government wants it gone.
lead_paragraph: Jorge Colindres, a freshly cologned and shaven lawyer, handed me a hard hat to take the elevator to the 14th floor of what is now the tallest building on the Honduran island of Roatán — nearly twice what the local building code allows. When construction is complete, Duna Residences will house 82 units overlooking a jungle of palm trees, the Caribbean Sea and several other new buildings that the Honduran government considers illegal.

headline: Feel Good T.V. Is Great. But Lonely T.V. Gives Us What We Need.
abstract: Dark comedies like “The Bear” and “Sunny,” provide a contrast to contemporary comedy’s relentlessly upbeat streak.
lead_paragraph: Masa is a hikikomori — a shut-in or hermit of sorts — who has been holed up in his room for years. His dirty dishes are piled into towers. His mother is so worried about him that she calls his estranged father, Hiromasa, who offers for Masa to stay in his empty cabin on Lake Biwa, northeast of Kyoto. Masa will still be alone, but at least he will get a change of scenery.

headline: The East Rises in Germany, and So Does Political Extremism
abstract: Closely watched elections in the former East Germany are likely to reveal a still-divided country and yield a worrying challenge to Berlin.
lead_paragraph: Anna Wenske, 69, worked for decades at the national theater of East Germany, where she was born and still lives. “After the reunification, everything went kaput,” she said. She lost her job and her savings; it took her years of part-time work to reach a kind of equilibrium.

headline: Seeking Free Quality Streaming? Try Plex.
abstract: This specialty streamer offers live TV along with a robust collection of free, ad-supported movies.
lead_paragraph: If we’re being honest, the streaming app that your correspondent uses most — more than Netflix or Amazon Prime or Hulu, and more than any of the less-recognizable subscription streamers we’ve previously spotlighted here — is Plex, though for reasons owing less to its current iteration than to its humble beginnings.

headline: How Laurie Anderson Conjured Amelia Earhart’s Final Flight
abstract: The restlessly multidisciplinary performer juggles orchestral depth and historical imagination with her new album, “Amelia.”
lead_paragraph: Imagine — or perhaps remember — a time when the world seemed much larger, when air travel was novel and dangerous, when wireless communication could never be taken for granted.

headline: A Dispute Over a House Led to a Mass Killing on Long Island
abstract: Joseph DeLucia became increasingly distraught after his mother died and his siblings moved to sell the family home, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at how a man on Long Island who was upset over the potential sale of a family home killed four of his family members before taking his own life.

headline: How to Squeeze More Time Out of a Failing Phone Battery
abstract: If your current smartphone can’t make it through the day without needing a recharge, here are a few steps to make it last a little longer.
lead_paragraph: Back-to-school deals and the fall season can make upgrading to a new phone quite tempting. But what if you need to hold off just a little longer — even as the battery sealed inside your ancient phone is already conking out before lunch and you’re just trying to nurse it along for the time being?

headline: Meghan Markle Is a ‘Dolphin,’ Not a Shark
abstract: At least when it comes to investing. The latest addition to her portfolio: the handbag brand Cesta Collective.
lead_paragraph: Many things have changed since Harry and Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, moved from London to California.

headline: Can You Tell Which Short Story ChatGPT Wrote?
abstract: What the fiction author Curtis Sittenfeld learned in a writing competition race against the machine.
lead_paragraph: In this era of artificial intelligence, who can compose a better beach read for the vacationing masses? The beloved fiction writer Curtis Sittenfeld … or ChatGPT?

headline: Bethann Hardison Never Had a Plan
abstract: The pioneering model, modeling agent and diversity advocate credits her success to street smarts and being ready when opportunity knocks.
lead_paragraph: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Bethann Hardison explains, in her own words, what continues to motivate her.

headline: $700,000 Homes in Ohio, Arizona and Oklahoma
abstract: A circa-1900 Queen Anne-style home in Columbus, a two-bedroom condominium in Phoenix and a 1925 Craftsman house in Oklahoma City.
lead_paragraph: This house is a few blocks from Schiller Park, and within a 10-minute walk of a public library, a public high school and restaurants serving a variety of food, including pizza and traditional German cuisine. It is also near a brewery and the Book Loft of German Village, a popular bookstore.

headline: Voting Rights for Nebraska Felons in Flux as Election Day Approaches
abstract: Nebraska’s attorney general not only cast doubt on a newly enacted law, but also on the state’s longstanding policy of allowing many people who finished criminal sentences to vote.
lead_paragraph: When the Nebraska Legislature voted 38 to 6 this year to allow people convicted of felonies to cast a ballot immediately after completing their sentences, it was a moment of bipartisan unity.

headline: Tony Danza on His Love of Sinatra, Boxing and Air Fryers
abstract: Step inside the entertainer’s Upper West Side apartment.
lead_paragraph: Step inside the entertainer’s Upper West Side apartment.

headline: This Is Who Kamala Harris Fails
abstract: Leaning into the powerful marketing of the vice president as a bastion of hope requires enormous amnesia.
lead_paragraph: As a Palestinian American, I’ve watched with growing apprehension the recent rebranding and memeification of Kamala Harris: Look! Here’s a woman who does jubilant dances, is firmly intelligent, has the same guffaw as your mother. It’s endearing. It’s refreshing.

headline: Books for Kids Starting Middle School
abstract: From a Judy Blume classic to mysteries both otherworldly and close to home, these 11 titles capture the nerve-racking first days of tweendom — and all the wonderful and terrible days that follow.
lead_paragraph: As a career school librarian, I have experienced many exhilarating (and exhausting) first days of middle school. All summer long, it seems like that fabled first day will never come: Then, in a rush of hugs, high fives and assemblies, it’s over before you’ve even had a chance to stop and smell the cafeteria pizza. These 11 titles that range from the sublime to the ridiculous aptly convey those nerve-racking first days of junior high — and all the wonderful and terrible days that follow.

headline: Surgeon General: Parents Are at Their Wits’ End. We Can Do Better.
abstract: Raising children is crucial work. Why don’t we treat it that way?
lead_paragraph: One day when my daughter was a year old, she stopped moving her right leg. Tests found that she had a deep infection in her thigh that was dangerously close to her bone. She was rushed off to surgery. Thankfully, she’s now a healthy, spirited young girl, but the excruciating days we spent in the hospital were some of the hardest of my life. My wife, Alice, and I felt helpless and heartbroken. We got through it because of excellent medical care, understanding workplaces and loved ones who showed up and reminded us that we were not alone.

headline: ‘A Terrible President’: 12 Times Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Criticized Trump
abstract: Mr. Kennedy’s recent alliance with Donald J. Trump represented a sharp reversal of a long-combative relationship.
lead_paragraph: The alliance between Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and former President Donald J. Trump, which was fortified on Tuesday with Mr. Kennedy’s appointment to Mr. Trump’s transition team, is a sharp turnabout in a long-combative relationship.

headline: Boeing’s No Good, Never-Ending Tailspin Might Take NASA With It
abstract: NASA’s quest to return astronauts to the moon is tied to the success — and failure — of Boeing and its engineers.
lead_paragraph: Fifty-five years ago, when humans first walked on the moon, the Apollo 11 astronauts left Earth through the massive power of the Saturn V rocket. The greatest punch came from the rocket’s first stage, which provided 7.5 million pounds of thrust. The awesome spectacle of that first stage was thanks to the work by engineers at Boeing.

headline: Last Crusade of Mexico’s President: A Drastic Redesign of the Judiciary
abstract: A showdown over plans to reshape the entire judiciary is raising fears over the effect on the rule of law in Mexico and trade with the United States.
lead_paragraph: As Mexico’s president nears the end of his six-year term, his final mission is a sweeping redesign of the judiciary that he says is needed to fight corruption.

headline: Harris and Walz Point Their Campaign Bus to Rural Georgia
abstract: The Democrats’ presidential ticket will head to the Sun Belt, aiming to sway voters in more conservative areas to their side.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, seeking to build Democrats’ momentum in the Sun Belt, will campaign on Wednesday in the rural counties of southeast Georgia before holding a rally on Thursday in Savannah.

headline: Kamala Harris and Tim Walz Are Road-Tripping Through Georgia. Could They Actually Win There?
abstract: They plan to show up across the state and fight for every vote.
lead_paragraph: I can see why many people might not consider late August the best time to head to the Deep South. So hot. So sticky. But this week strikes me as the perfect moment for the Democratic presidential ticket to take a quick bus tour around southern Georgia.

headline: You Want Policies? Trump’s Got Policies.
abstract: The former president’s plans for a second term are very likely to have unintended consequences.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s policy initiatives for a potential second term are rife with unintended adverse consequences — which, in less charitable terms, could be described as deliberate attempts to delude the electorate.

headline: How the Federal Cases Against Trump Came Sputtering Back to Life
abstract: After legal setbacks and long delays, Jack Smith, the special counsel, is signaling that he will pursue both the classified documents and election cases through the homestretch of the presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: The two federal criminal cases against former President Donald J. Trump sputtered back to life this week after periods of delay and major legal setbacks.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,167
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 29, 2024
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 445
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Aug. 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Introducing Connections Bot: a daily tool that provides a personalized analysis of your Connections solve, inspired by WordleBot. Connections Bot lets you know the puzzle’s difficulty level and if you made the same mistakes as other solvers. The bot is now available exclusively to the Connections Companion community. Give it a try and let us know your thoughts in the comments.

headline: Federal Cases Against Trump Revived, and Israeli Forces Raid West Bank
abstract: Plus, a new theory about orca boat attacks.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The War That Won’t End
abstract: The war in Gaza has been going on for almost a year. Why have Israel and Hamas not reached a cease-fire?
lead_paragraph: It’s been nearly a year since the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks in Israel and the subsequent war in Gaza.

headline: The Rise of Fare Evasion
abstract: We explore why people are ignoring public transit’s most basic rule.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been riding the subway regularly for almost 40 years, first in New York, where I grew up, and these days in Washington, D.C. When I started doing so, in the 1980s, fare evasion was common.

headline: Democrats Begin Highly Targeted Campaign Up and Down Pennsylvania Ballot
abstract: A $500,000 program will send canvassers in the critical battleground state out to voters with locally tailored messages.
lead_paragraph: The Pennsylvania Democratic Party began a program Wednesday to give locally tailored messaging to canvassers across the state, for candidates from the Harris-Walz ticket down to school boards.

headline: Shelling Kills 6 in Ukraine as Russia Pushes Ahead in East
abstract: The rest of the country, though, was largely spared from another consecutive night of large-scale Russian bombardment.
lead_paragraph: Bombing eased across Ukraine after two nights of deadly barrages, but strikes near the front line killed six people and Russian troops pressed ahead in the east, closing in on the key city of Pokrovsk.

headline: Should I Be Worried That My New Boyfriend Admits to Being a Cad?
abstract: A reader is concerned that a new beau’s frequent references to jumping ship in past relationships may be laying the groundwork for him to do it with her.
lead_paragraph: I have been dating a new guy, 40, for four months. So far, we really like each other. Not infrequently, though, he drops little warnings about his behavior in past relationships: He acknowledges a pattern of dropping women after he gets them to like him, for instance, and ending relationships because he feels trapped. His own father asked him if he had “messed up” our relationship yet. On the one hand, I’m glad we’re able to have these conversations, but on the other, I’m worried about moving forward with someone who has these patterns of behavior. Help!

headline: Jenin, a Target of Israeli Raids, Is Symbol of Palestinian Opposition and Militancy
abstract: For decades, Jenin has played a central role in fighting against occupying powers.
lead_paragraph: Jenin, a focal point of Israel’s wide-ranging raid into the West Bank on Wednesday, is a potent symbol of opposition and militancy for Palestinians after decades of fighting against occupying powers.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,166
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for August 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Recent Israeli Raids in the West Bank: A Timeline
abstract: Israel has ramped up a crackdown in the Israeli-occupied territory since before the Israel-Hamas war began last Oct. 7. Here are some of the major raids.
lead_paragraph: Since Hamas’s surprise Oct. 7 attack on Israel, which killed about 1,200 people, more than 580 Palestinians have been killed in the West Bank, according to the United Nations, as Israel has ramped up military raids there and violence by extremist Jewish settlers has increased.

headline: At Los Angeles Galleries, Savoring the Waning Days of Summer
abstract: During an often quiet season in the art world, several outstanding solo shows and one group show offer a feast for the eye and the mind.
lead_paragraph: The traditional summer lull in the art gallery calendar typically spurs a rash of phoned-in group shows, a chance to drag unsold works out of storage and repackage them under limp catchall themes. Not so much in Los Angeles, where several eye-catching solo exhibitions feature artists who are overdue for a moment in the sun.

headline: How Wall Street Learned About Last Week’s Labor Data Before the Public
abstract: The Labor Department provided insight into a recent lapse in which revised payroll data was given out à la carte before it went online.
lead_paragraph: Banks and research firms that serve hedge funds managed to confirm a closely watched economic data point last week as much as 20 minutes before the data was posted online, giving them a possible jump on financial market trading — the latest in a series of lapses at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: You Say Tomato, I Say Risotto
abstract: David Tanis’s fast, five-star recipe is a perfect peak tomato meal.
lead_paragraph: In my head, a steaming bowl of risotto has always been wintry fare, maybe because I associate it with cozy dinner parties and other cold-weather pursuits. But David Tanis has made me rethink my life yet again, this time with his ruddy-hued summer tomato risotto.

headline: These 6 Exercises Are Fundamental to How You Move
abstract: Practicing these movements can make everyday tasks — like carrying groceries and walking up stairs — easier.
lead_paragraph: When you sit in a chair, lift a package off the floor or climb a flight of stairs, your body is doing some form of squatting, hinging or lunging. But just because you perform these movements every day doesn’t mean you’re doing them correctly. Whether you round your back while lifting or overload your knees when you stand up, repeatedly moving with poor form can lead to pain and injury.

headline: How Wildfire Smoke Threatens Health
abstract: As wildfires grow more frequent and more intense, scientists are studying how their smoke might harm our health.
lead_paragraph: As wildfires grow more frequent and more intense, scientists are studying how their smoke might harm our health.

headline: Serena Williams Reflects on Her Life and Legacy in a New Docuseries
abstract: “In the Arena: Serena Williams,” an eight-part documentary on ESPN+, revisits the highs and lows of the star’s career and considers her impact on tennis and beyond.
lead_paragraph: In March 2001, Serena Williams, then just 19, was booed mercilessly by the crowd during the tournament final of the Indian Wells Open in California. The jeering included racist slurs, and it was arguably the most terrifying and scarring thing that ever happened to Williams during her spectacular career.

headline: Should I Report My Friends’ Cocaine Dealer?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the duty one has to mitigate drug-related harm.
lead_paragraph: I am a recent college graduate. Now that I live far away from where I went to school and having some time to look back, I think about the people I knew who used illicit substances (primarily cocaine) and wonder about the harm done by drug dealers. I’ve never used any drugs but being friends with some users, I know where their dealer lives. I never met him, but I heard a lot of things about him. Some of these were wholesome: He has a young kid, a nice girlfriend, enjoys cutting hair.

headline: What Will We Do With Our Free Power?
abstract: The price of solar power is plummeting faster than we ever expected.
lead_paragraph: “I simply cannot believe where we are with solar,” says Jenny Chase, the BloombergNEF analyst and quite possibly the person in the world who knows the most about the business of turning the light of the sun into electricity. “And if you’d told me nearly 20 years ago what would be the case now, 20 years later,” she continues, “I would have just said you were crazy. I would have laughed in your face. There is genuinely a revolution happening.” By just 2030, Chase estimates, solar power will be absolutely and reliably free during the sunny parts of the day for much of the year “pretty much everywhere.”

headline: U.S. and Chinese Officials Discuss Future Talks Between Biden and Xi
abstract: In discussions in Beijing, the two sides made clear that many differences remain over Taiwan, technology export controls and trade disputes.
lead_paragraph: Senior American and Chinese officials meeting in Beijing discussed plans for a call between President Biden and China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, as well as talks between their military commanders in the region, as the two countries work to stabilize relations.

headline: Meet the Trans Actress Who Could Make Oscar History
abstract: Karla Sofía Gascón plays a drug kingpin who undergoes gender-affirming surgery in a performance that wowed Cannes. Is the academy next?
lead_paragraph: There has never been a movie quite like “Emilia Pérez,” so it’s fitting that its star Karla Sofía Gascón is one of a kind, too.

headline: The Best Summer Dinner Is Also the Easiest
abstract: A simple, savory tomato carpaccio begins this menu from David Tanis, followed by tender fish and a crisp plum-almond crumble.
lead_paragraph: September signals the end of summer, but thankfully not the end of summer produce. So much of is at its prime right now. Certainly tomatoes are, and sweet peppers. They both need the whole season to achieve their juicy ripeness. They’re worth the wait, perfect for building a menu around, as are late-season plums, which are now coming in. This menu employs all of these, and, best of all, it’s very doable.

headline: Google Says It Fixed Image Generator That Failed to Depict White People
abstract: The company will allow users of its Gemini chatbot to create images of people with artificial intelligence after disabling the feature six months ago.
lead_paragraph: In February, Google faced a backlash from users who realized its A.I. chatbot Gemini was unable to reliably create images of white people. To quell the controversy, the company shut down Gemini’s ability to depict any human.

headline: Italians Fight for the Right to Feast on the Beach
abstract: For those who feel priced out of expensive, privatized seaside clubs in Italy, elaborate lunch spreads feel like the last bastion of good spirits.
lead_paragraph: At 1 p.m. at the San Girolamo beach in Italy’s southern city of Bari, as the sun reached its summit and temperatures came close to 100 degrees, the smell of fried green peppers made its way through a thick maze of umbrellas and folding chairs.

headline: Troubled Hedge Fund Two Sigma Replaces Feuding Founders
abstract: The multibillion-dollar trading firm said its billionaire co-chief executives, John Overdeck and David Siegel, would step down.
lead_paragraph: Two Sigma, one of the world’s largest hedge funds, said on Wednesday that its billionaire co-founders, John Overdeck and David Siegel, would step down as co-chief executives.

headline: Far From Presidential Battlegrounds, Blue States Could Decide Congress
abstract: New York and California have become unlikely focal points in the fight for control of the House, as Democrats toil to appeal to wary voters in districts won by President Biden.
lead_paragraph: Campaigning on a rainy recent morning, Mondaire Jones had plenty of reasons to be optimistic about his effort to unseat Representative Mike Lawler, a first-term Republican in the Hudson Valley in New York.

headline: Criticizing a Conservative’s Advice for Trump
abstract: Readers discuss a guest essay by Rich Lowry, National Review editor. Also: Debate rules; more campaign substance; pap smears; hospital abortions; hats.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.K.’s Starmer Wants to ‘Turn a Corner on Brexit.’ What Does That Mean?
abstract: On a trip to Germany, Prime Minister Keir Starmer exchanged warm words with Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz. But a reset with the European Union will depend on actions too.
lead_paragraph: Promising a “once in a generation” rapprochement with Germany, Britain’s prime minister, Keir Starmer, on Wednesday pushed his plan to boost post-Brexit ties across Europe.

headline: Canada’s Wildfires Were a Top Global Emitter Last Year, Study Says
abstract: The blazes produced more planet-warming carbon than almost any country, researchers found. That could upend key calculations on the pace of global warming.
lead_paragraph: The wildfires that ravaged Canada’s boreal forests in 2023 produced more planet-warming carbon emissions than the burning of fossil fuels in all but three countries, research published on Wednesday has found.

headline: Jenna Ortega Has Fans Lining Up at the Venice Film Festival
abstract: After the actors’ strike muted the 2023 edition, this year’s event is being powered by stars like the “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice” actress and her castmates.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, several hours before Tim Burton’s “Beetlejuice Beetlejuice” opened the Venice Film Festival, dozens of young people were already camped out by the Palazzo del Cinema in the hopes of seeing one of the film’s stars.

headline: On Kobe Bryant Day, a Celebration of Love and Basketball
abstract: Malika Andrews first caught the attention of fellow N.B.A. journalist Dave McMenamin as she conducted an interview with LeBron James.
lead_paragraph: Malika Rose Andrews has established herself as a well-known presence in broadcast sports journalism, so it may be hard to believe that her first job out of college was merely seven years ago, in 2017. And, in November of that same year, she met fellow N.B.A. journalist David Christopher McMenamin.

headline: Voting Rights Leaders Step Up Election Initiatives After Texas Raids
abstract: Groups working to get voters to the polls are expanding training and communications with election officials in anticipation of challenges.
lead_paragraph: Republican officials in Texas in recent days have investigated a number of Latino voting activists and political organizers as part of an election fraud inquiry, conducting a series of raids that led one group to appeal to the federal government.

headline: Sarah Palin Is Granted New Libel Trial Against The New York Times
abstract: A federal appeals court said the judge overseeing the original trial, which Ms. Palin lost, had wrongly excluded evidence and might have swayed jurors as they were deliberating.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Wednesday ordered a new trial in a long-running and closely watched libel lawsuit that Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska and Republican vice-presidential nominee, brought against The New York Times.

headline: The Most Exciting Hotels in London Right Now
abstract: From big brands to quirky independents, the city’s newest accommodations are luxurious in ways both quiet and not.
lead_paragraph: London is in its global hotel brand era: In the last year, it’s added a Raffles, a Peninsula and a second Mandarin Oriental; a Waldorf Astoria, a St. Regis and a Six Senses are on their way. This new guard is taking over historical icons and throwing up gleaming towers, and it’s upping the ante on amenities, too. A posh afternoon tea is no longer enough, it seems; now, five-stars come with signature scents, subterranean spas, museum-worthy art and long-stay residences. Rooftop bars, a rarity here a decade ago, are now seemingly obligatory (the one at the Emory wins for views, with everything from Big Ben to Battersea Power Station in its sights). But there’s still room for the occasional independent hotel, like the Broadwick, a maximalist love letter to the owner Noel Hayden’s hotelier parents and the creative Soho of the ’90s in which he came of age. “It’s a bit of a sensory overload,” Hayden says. Naturally, there’s a rooftop bar there, too.

headline: Betty Halbreich, World’s ‘Most Famous Personal Shopper,’ Dies at 96
abstract: She was a local New York secret before gaining wider renown as the dressing-room companion of rich, powerful women. A dark past lay beneath her savoir faire.
lead_paragraph: Betty Halbreich, considered by genuine and aspiring grandes dames to be fashion’s leading personal shopper, who made the search for the right clothing a higher kind of quest — one for dignity, standards and self-knowledge — died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 96.

headline: $100 Million Podcast Deals Are Back, but Not for Just Any Celebrity
abstract: After partnerships with famous names fizzled in previous years, podcast companies are paying stars — like Travis and Jason Kelce — with a proven track record as hosts.
lead_paragraph: After a down market in the celebrity podcast business last year, when big spenders like Spotify and Amazon tightened their purse strings, nine-figure megadeals are back in fashion. But this time around, the big-name stars have something more: experience and established followings.

headline: Israeli Forces Launch Raid in the Occupied West Bank
abstract: The operation follows months of escalating Israeli raids, where nearly three million Palestinians live under Israeli military rule.
lead_paragraph: The operation follows months of escalating Israeli raids, where nearly three million Palestinians live under Israeli military rule.

headline: Typhoon Shanshan Makes Landfall in Japan
abstract: The storm unleashed torrential rain, hurricane-force winds and the threat of landslides.
lead_paragraph: The storm unleashed torrential rain, hurricane-force winds and the threat of landslides.

headline: C.I.A. Warning Helped Thwart ISIS Attack at Taylor Swift Concert in Vienna
abstract: The agency provided information about several suspects that led to arrests, the deputy director said.
lead_paragraph: The C.I.A. provided intelligence to Austrian authorities that allowed them to disrupt a plot that could have killed thousands of people at a Taylor Swift concert in Vienna this month, the agency’s deputy director said on Wednesday.

headline: Trump Makes Incendiary Claim About His Secret Service Protection
abstract: The former president accused the president and vice president of denying him sufficient Secret Service protection, echoing remarks he made on social media in July.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump claimed without evidence in an interview broadcast on Tuesday that President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris had denied him sufficient Secret Service protection and that they were therefore partly responsible for the assassination attempt against him last month.

headline: Our Bigger Brains Came With a Downside: Faster Aging
abstract: A study comparing chimpanzee and human brains suggests that the regions that grew the most during human evolution are the most susceptible to aging.
lead_paragraph: The human brain, more than any other attribute, sets our species apart. Over the past seven million years or so, it has grown in size and complexity, enabling us to use language, make plans for the future and coordinate with one another at a scale never seen before in the history of life.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Godzilla Minus One’ and More
abstract: I’m a national correspondent covering guns and culture. Here are five things I’ve watched, read or played recently.
lead_paragraph: I’m a national correspondent covering guns and culture. Here are five things I’ve watched, read or played recently.

headline: Supreme Court, for Now, Keeps Block on Revamped Biden Student Debt Plan
abstract: The new plan was part of a piecemeal approach to student debt after the justices rejected a proposal last year that would have canceled more than $400 billion in loans.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Wednesday maintained a temporary pause on a new effort by President Biden to wipe out tens and perhaps hundreds of billions of dollars of student debt.

headline: Former Las Vegas Official Convicted in Journalist’s Murder
abstract: The highly unusual killing had raised fears about press freedom and the risks facing local journalists.
lead_paragraph: A former county official was found guilty on Wednesday of murdering a longtime Las Vegas reporter who wrote articles critical of him. The highly unusual case had raised fears about press freedom in the United States and in particular the risks facing local journalists.

headline: Elon Musk, Eyeing Edge for Trump, Hires Republican Political Adviser
abstract: The move suggests that Mr. Musk, the world’s richest person, is preparing to become even more involved in the presidential campaign and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the world’s richest person, has hired a Republican operative with expertise in field organizing to help steer his political work, a move that suggests that Mr. Musk is preparing to become even more involved in Republican politics and get-out-the-vote efforts specifically.

headline: A Rare but Dangerous Mosquito-Borne Virus Is Changing Routines in Massachusetts
abstract: Ten communities are at high or critical risk from Eastern equine encephalitis, which killed a man in New Hampshire this month and sickened two people in Massachusetts and Vermont.
lead_paragraph: Sue Ryan, who lives in Plymouth, Mass., is taking no chances.

headline: Police Searched for a Murder Suspect for Months. Then He Fell Through the Ceiling.
abstract: Deario Wilkerson of Memphis is charged with first-degree murder in connection with a killing in an April shooting, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A murder suspect whom the authorities spent months searching for was captured this week in Memphis when he fell through the ceiling while hiding in the attic of a family member’s home, the U.S. Marshals Service said.

headline: Alastair Carruthers, 79, Dies; Pioneered the Cosmetic Use of Botox
abstract: With his wife, Dr. Jean Carruthers, he conducted hundreds of studies on the wrinkle-erasing properties of the neurotoxin that causes botulism. The work revolutionized beauty care.
lead_paragraph: “Pretty Poison,” newspapers called it in the mid-1990s, when the deadly neurotoxin that causes botulism began to make headlines as a temporary wrinkle-eraser.

headline: A 4-Year-Old Boy Breaks a 3,500-Year-Old Jar at an Israeli Museum
abstract: The child, who had been visiting the Hecht Museum in Haifa, wanted to know what was in the jar, his father said. He and his family have been invited to return when the artifact is restored.
lead_paragraph: A jar used for oil and wine during the Middle Bronze Age in the ancient Canaan region prevailed for thousands of years before it was put on display at the Hecht Museum in Israel.

headline: Kouri Richins to Stand Trial for Murder in Husband’s Poisoning. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: The Utah mother of three wrote a children’s book about coping with grief after her husband’s death. Prosecutors say she mixed a lethal dose of fentanyl into his drink.
lead_paragraph: A Utah mother of three who wrote a children’s book about coping with grief after her husband’s death will be tried for his murder, a judge decided on Tuesday.

headline: Elite Girls’ School Offers Free Ride to Families Making $100,000 or Less
abstract: The Brearley School, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, hopes to diversify its student body with a free tuition program.
lead_paragraph: One of New York City’s most prestigious private schools will soon offer free tuition to the children of families earning $100,000 or less, in a newly urgent push to recruit lower-income students whom elite schools rarely enroll.

headline: Straddling Tense Divide, Family of Bedouin Hostage Celebrates His Release and Prays for Cease-Fire
abstract: The marginalized Bedouin community suffered deaths and abductions during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, and also ache for their Palestinian relatives in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Amid the sobs of relatives rushing to hug Farhan al-Qadi and the ululations of neighbors celebrating his return home to a Bedouin village in southern Israel on Wednesday, the first thing the rescued hostage wanted to do was find his mother.

headline: Telegram Founder Charged With Wide Range of Crimes in France
abstract: Pavel Durov, who was arrested near Paris over the weekend as part of a broad investigation into criminal activity on the platform, was also barred from leaving the country.
lead_paragraph: Pavel Durov, the Russian-born entrepreneur who founded the online communications tool Telegram, was charged on Wednesday in France with a wide range of crimes for failing to prevent illicit activity on the app, and barred from leaving the country.

headline: Corrections: Aug. 28, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 28, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a lawsuit targeting new election rules in Georgia misspelled the name of a deputy campaign manager for Vice President Kamala Harris. He is Quentin Fulks, not Quinten Fulks. The story also referred incorrectly to  Mr. Fulk’s statement. He said that Georgia’s new election rules — not the Democrats’ lawsuit — were part of a broader effort by Republicans “to lay the groundwork to challenge the election results.”

headline: House G.O.P. Releases Jan. 6 Videos of Pelosi, Seeking to Shift Blame From Trump
abstract: In recordings shot for a documentary, the House speaker at the time raged about the attack on the Capitol and said she took responsibility for not pushing the police to prepare better for violence by Trump supporters.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans on Wednesday made their latest attempt to rewrite the history of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, releasing a video compilation that sought to shift blame away from former President Donald J. Trump and onto former Speaker Nancy Pelosi, who was pursued that day by a violent mob of Trump supporters.

headline: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway Hits $1 Trillion in Market Value
abstract: The conglomerate joined a small club of companies that have crossed the mark.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway climbed past a market valuation of $1 trillion on Wednesday, joining a small club of mammoth companies dominated by tech firms like Nvidia and Microsoft.

headline: Sister Theresa Kane, 87, Dies; Challenged Pope on Ordaining Women
abstract: A progressive nun, she used a welcome address before Pope John Paul II in 1979 to call for equality in the ranks of the Roman Catholic Church.
lead_paragraph: Sister Theresa Kane, a Roman Catholic nun who called on her fellow sisters to push for ordination, and who led by example when, while introducing Pope John Paul II during his 1979 visit to the United States, she publicly challenged him to let women serve as priests, died on Aug. 22 in Watchung, N.J. She was 87.

headline: Russia Bars Numerous U.S. Journalists From the Country
abstract: The list of barred journalists includes the top editor of The Wall Street Journal. Dozens of other Americans are also forbidden to enter Russia, which said the move was in response to sanctions against it.
lead_paragraph: Russia on Wednesday barred a number of journalists from The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post, as well as dozens of other Americans, from entering the country.

headline: Would-Be Trump Assassin’s Interest in Violence Went Back to 2019
abstract: F.B.I. officials said the profile that has emerged of Thomas Crooks, based on an analysis of his electronics, resembles that of a mass shooter more than a politically motivated assassin.
lead_paragraph: The man who tried to kill former President Donald J. Trump in July first showed an interest in committing acts of public violence in 2019 but narrowed his focus to Mr. Trump after the announcement of his rally in Butler, Pa., according to an F.B.I. analysis of his electronics.

headline: Death Toll Rises to 9 From Listeria Linked to Boar’s Head Meats, C.D.C. Says
abstract: Six new deaths were reported in a nationwide outbreak that started in May. The C.D.C. is advising people not to eat any recalled products.
lead_paragraph: The death toll of people who consumed products tainted with listeria that have been linked to Boar’s Head deli meats has risen to nine over the last three weeks, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Wednesday.

headline: Election Worker Charged With Taking Kickbacks for Polling Place Jobs
abstract: Federal prosecutors said Nicole Torres sold election jobs to Bronx residents for $150 apiece. It is just the most recent smudge on the reputation of the New York City Board of Elections.
lead_paragraph: A New York City Board of Elections employee in the Bronx was charged with offenses including extortion, bribery and fraud after federal prosecutors said she took kickbacks to place residents in temporary poll-worker jobs.

headline: At Least 10 Killed as Israeli Military Steps Up West Bank Raids
abstract: Hundreds of troops entered cities in the occupied territory, targeting Palestinian militants. It was a significant escalation after months of raids that have unfolded alongside the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Israeli troops backed by drones and armored vehicles carried out raids in the occupied West Bank, Israeli and Palestinian officials said on Wednesday, a growing third front in conflicts that extend from the Egyptian border with the Gaza Strip to southern Lebanon.

headline: Texas Removed 1 Million From Voter Rolls. But Most Had Moved or Died.
abstract: Gov. Greg Abbott celebrated the purge, but the numbers were in line with routine culling from the past. Democrats said some removals sent a chilling message to Latino voters.
lead_paragraph: Days after officers acting on behalf of the Texas attorney general raided the homes of Democratic activists and a Latina candidate for the State House, Gov. Greg Abbott promoted his efforts to clear the voter rolls of those who did not belong there.

headline: Nvidia Revenue Jumps 122% in Positive Sign for Tech’s A.I. Boom
abstract: Expectations for the chipmaker have been through the roof because of its dominance in a key component for artificial intelligence systems.
lead_paragraph: This summer, Wall Street and Silicon Valley began to question whether generative artificial intelligence could produce enough benefits to justify its staggering costs.

headline: The Mosquito-Borne Virus Raising Alarms in the Northeast
abstract: Recent infections from the Eastern equine encephalitis virus are worrying health officials. Severe cases can be deadly or leave lasting injuries.
lead_paragraph: Residents of 10 communities in Massachusetts have been warned to stay indoors from dusk to dawn. Some local parks are closed at night. A person in New Hampshire has died. Pesticides are being sprayed from trucks and aircrafts.

headline: Google’s Antitrust Defeat Opens the Door to Lawsuit From Yelp
abstract: Yelp complained for more than a decade that Google tilted the search market in its favor. After its rival’s landmark legal loss, it finally decided to sue.
lead_paragraph: When a federal judge declared Google an illegal monopoly in a landmark ruling this month, it was not immediately clear what consequences the world’s largest search engine provider would face.

headline: At Costco, Shopping for Clues About Consumers
abstract: The reporter Ben Ryder Howe traveled far and wide to better understand Americans’ love of the membership-only retail store.
lead_paragraph: In March, Brian Gallagher, an editor for the Food section of The New York Times, texted me a question: Did I have strong feelings about Costco?

headline: A Parisian Found Patriotism as He Designed Paralympics Costumes
abstract: Louis-Gabriel Nouchi was given an enormous task: create 700 distinctive garments for people with disabilities for the event’s opening ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Louis-Gabriel Nouchi, of the Paris-based fashion brand LGN, was thrilled when he got the phone call asking him to design the costumes for the Paralympics’ opening ceremony, which was held on Wednesday in Paris, with a procession down the Champs-Élysées that ended at the Place de la Concorde.

headline: In the Battle for Georgia, Democrats Lose a Key Fighter
abstract: Bishop Reginald T. Jackson, a leader of the A.M.E. Church, turned Georgia into a political machine for Democrats by mobilizing voters of faith. Now, he is leaving the state just months before the November election.
lead_paragraph: When Democrats flipped Georgia in 2020, Bishop Reginald T. Jackson, the leader of the African Methodist Episcopal Church’s Sixth Episcopal District, had been in the state just four years.

headline: Your End-of-Summer Politics Quiz Is Here
abstract: How closely have you been following the news these last few months? Let’s find out.
lead_paragraph: How closely have you been following the news these last few months? Let’s find out.

headline: Militia Group Member Gets 5 Years in Prison in Jan. 6 Capitol Riot
abstract: Dan Edwin Wilson, 48, of Louisville, Ky., messaged in a group chat that he was prepared to lay his life on the line, prosecutors said. “It is time for good men to do bad things,” he wrote.
lead_paragraph: A Kentucky man involved with the Oath Keepers and other far-right extremist groups who helped devise plans to converge on the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced on Wednesday to five years in prison for his role in the riot, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Israel Launches Major West Bank Raids
abstract: Plus, charges for Telegram’s founder.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Israeli troops, backed by fleets of drones and armored vehicles, raided the occupied West Bank yesterday. Palestinians in Jenin say they have been trapped inside, fearful of Israeli snipers or of having their homes stormed by soldiers.

headline: Trump Reposts Crude Sexual Remark About Harris on Truth Social
abstract: Though the former president has a history of making crass insults about opponents, the reposts signal his willingness to continue to shatter longstanding political norms.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump used his social-media website on Wednesday to amplify a crude remark about Vice President Kamala Harris that suggested Ms. Harris traded sexual favors to help her political career.

headline: What Is the West Bank and Who Controls It?
abstract: Renewed violence has cast a spotlight on the territory, where more than 600 Palestinians have been killed in clashes with the Israeli military since Oct. 7.
lead_paragraph: Israeli troops raided two Palestinian cities on Wednesday in what they called an effort to tamp down rising militancy in the northern West Bank. The raids continued on Thursday, with the Israeli military saying it had killed five militants during a gun battle, including a commander.

headline: Harris Tours Georgia as Democrats See the State Fully in Play
abstract: The vice president on Wednesday began a bus tour in the rural southeastern corner of the state, as her campaign focuses heavily on Georgia and North Carolina, another Sun Belt battleground.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris, aiming to go on offense against former President Donald J. Trump in Georgia, kicked off a bus tour on Wednesday in the rural southeastern corner of the battleground state.

headline: Algerian Man Charged Over Synagogue Arson Attack in France
abstract: The man expressed deep hatred of Jews and said he had acted to “support the Palestinian cause,” according to French antiterrorism prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: A 33-year-old Algerian man was charged on Wednesday with attempted murder and other crimes after an arson attack on a synagogue in southern France last week, prosecutors said.

headline: Israel Began a Major Military Operation in the West Bank
abstract: Also, the Supreme Court blocked another Biden student debt plan, for now. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Israeli troops, backed by fleets of drones and armored vehicles, carried out raids today in the West Bank. At least 10 Palestinians were killed, the Palestinian Health Ministry said, in operations that Israeli officials described as an effort to target militants.

headline: Former Officer Charged With Killing Woman Whose Death Was Ruled a Suicide
abstract: Sandra Birchmore was pregnant when she was found dead in Canton, Mass., in 2021, and she had told the officer that he was the father, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: When Sandra Birchmore, a young pregnant woman, was found dead in her apartment in Canton, Mass., in 2021, it was initially ruled a suicide.

headline: Salesman for Moving Company That Held Goods Hostage Gets 2-Year Sentence
abstract: Andre Prince, who was convicted of conspiracy to commit wire fraud, used a “stage name” as he worked for companies that also frequently swapped identities.
lead_paragraph: As anyone who has hired a moving company in New York City can attest, plenty can go awry.

headline: Ofra Bikel, Filmmaker With a Focus on Criminal Justice, Dies at 94
abstract: Her award-winning documentaries for PBS’s “Frontline” series shed light on serious flaws in several convictions and helped lead to the release of 13 prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Ofra Bikel, a crusading filmmaker for the PBS investigative series “Frontline” whose documentaries about the criminal justice system in the United States exposed deep flaws in the prosecution and convictions of 13 people, died on Aug. 11 at her home in Tel Aviv. She was 94.

headline: Trump Sees a World on Fire, and Says He Knows Who’s to Blame
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump blames President Biden for crises around the globe. But the reality is that presidents inherit a world already hurtling through history.
lead_paragraph: In former President Donald J. Trump’s explanation of global events from the campaign trail, the world would not be aflame had he remained in the Oval Office.

headline: Foreign Citizens Charged With Carrying Out Swatting Attacks on U.S. Officials
abstract: The two men also made false reports about bomb threats at the Capitol and at religious buildings, with prosecutors documenting more than 100 hoax calls.
lead_paragraph: Two foreign citizens have been charged with falsely reporting threats against the U.S. Capitol and prominent officials, including members of Congress and cabinet members, according to an indictment unsealed on Wednesday.

headline: California Legislature Approves Bill Proposing Sweeping A.I. Restrictions
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom must now decide whether to sign into law the fiercely debated legislation.
lead_paragraph: California lawmakers on Wednesday overwhelmingly approved legislation that would create new restrictions for artificial intelligence, clearing a path to the governor’s office for a bill that might set the national standard for regulating the new technology.

headline: Is Europe a Model for America? Or a Warning?
abstract: The continent softens the edges of capitalism and achieves impressive well-being, but it overregulates and is struggling to keep up.
lead_paragraph: For liberals like me, Europe has often seemed a charmed place with sound lessons for America.

headline: Tulsi Gabbard, Robert Kennedy and Trump’s ‘Game of Thrones’
abstract: Sycophants still line up to play his game.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has surrounded himself with ideological shape-shifters — former Democrats and former anti-Trumpers willing to profess a fawning loyalty to him.

headline: Can Democrats Win Back Latino Voters by Treating Them Like Everyone Else?
abstract: Democrats seem to be recognizing that Latinos have the same hodgepodge mix of priorities as other voters. Will that help them make up ground lost to Donald J. Trump?
lead_paragraph: When the Harris campaign released its first television ad targeting Latino voters, one word was conspicuously absent: Latinos.

headline: The Challenge of Interviewing Kamala Harris
abstract: ‘She didn’t break eye contact. It was intense. You feel on trial.’
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris and her running mate, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, will sit down with Dana Bash of CNN tomorrow at 9 p.m. Eastern for the first major television interview of their presidential campaign.

headline: Waterline Breaks Force Grand Canyon to Halt Hotel Stays on South Rim
abstract: The popular destination has put strict water restrictions into effect before one of summer’s busiest weekends.
lead_paragraph: Citing recent breaks in its waterline, Grand Canyon National Park in northern Arizona announced Wednesday that it would temporarily halt overnight hotel stays on the South Rim of the park starting Thursday afternoon, just before the busy Labor Day weekend.

headline: Scientists Discover Similar Dinosaur Footprints on Opposite Sides of the Atlantic
abstract: More than 260 similar footprints found in Brazil and Cameroon help us understand a region that broke apart millions of years ago.
lead_paragraph: They may be an ocean apart, but dinosaur footprints found in South America and Africa are so similar that their discovery suggests dinosaurs may have roamed a narrow corridor that connected the two continents before they split.

headline: OpenAI in Talks for Deal That Would Value Company at $100 Billion
abstract: While some young A.I. companies have struggled to compete with the tech industry’s giants, OpenAI has been rapidly expanding.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI is in talks to complete a deal that would value the company at $100 billion or more, which would be about a $20 billion increase from its valuation eight months ago, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions.

headline: Trump Videos at Arlington Stir More Fallout After Gravesite Visit
abstract: The family of a Green Beret buried there expressed concern about videos and photos taken by his grave. And a cemetery employee declined to press charges after an altercation with the Trump team, fearing retribution.
lead_paragraph: The family of a Green Beret who died by suicide after serving eight combat tours and is buried at Arlington National Cemetery expressed concern on Wednesday that Donald J. Trump’s campaign had filmed his gravesite without permission as Mr. Trump stood in an area where campaign photography isn’t allowed.

headline: Where Does Biden’s Student Loan Debt Plan Stand? Here’s What to Know.
abstract: The Supreme Court refused to allow a key part of President Biden’s student debt plan to move forward. Here’s what’s left of it, and who could still benefit.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s latest effort to wipe out student loan debt for millions of Americans is in jeopardy.

headline: Tropical Storm Shanshan Drenches Southern Japan, Disrupting Train and Air Travel
abstract: The storm weakened after making landfall as a typhoon, still posed the risk of landslides and floods as it moved at a crawling speed.
lead_paragraph: Tropical storm Shanshan was drenching southern Japan with record rainfall early Friday, a day after making landfall as a typhoon and flooding towns, knocking out power to tens of thousands of homes, disrupting travel and forcing more than four million evacuations.

headline: Brazil Threatens to Ban Elon Musk’s X
abstract: The country’s Supreme Court gave the service 24 hours to name a legal representative in Brazil or face suspension.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s Supreme Court on Wednesday gave Elon Musk 24 hours to name a legal representative for X in Brazil or face a ban of his social network across the nation of 200 million.

headline: Skye Writing
abstract: Simeon Seigel sets a course for puzzling adventure.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Backpage Founder Gets Five Years in Case That Shut Down Website
abstract: Michael Lacey, 76, co-founded the website that became known for its ads for prostitution. He was convicted on a money laundering charge in a case that included accusations of sex trafficking.
lead_paragraph: A founder of the shuttered classified advertising website Backpage was sentenced on Wednesday to five years in federal prison in connection with a sweeping case that led to the closing of the website and accusations against its executives that they promoted sex trafficking, prosecutors said.

headline: Hong Kong Editors Convicted of Sedition in Blow to Press Freedom
abstract: The editors said they published stories in the public interest. A judge ruled they were guilty of a crime against national security.
lead_paragraph: The two veterans of Hong Kong’s long boisterous news media scene didn’t shy away from publishing pro-democracy voices on their Stand News site, even as China cranked up its national security clampdown to silence critics in the city.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Pavel Durov, the Russian-born entrepreneur who founded the online communications tool Telegram, was charged yesterday in France with a wide range of crimes and barred from leaving the country.
